Thunderfield R.C. School,
Delmas, Sask., Jan 12, 1837.

Mr. Hoey,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Rev. Father U. Langlois, Provincial of the C.F., wrote to us a few days ago, he tells us that you had been very interested in reading our Thunder Report.

We are therefore greatly pleased to send you a copy. It is published every two months. This is our second number.

We are very thankful to you, Mr. Hoey, for your kind interest.
Happy New Year

Wishing you a happy new year to all those we love, especially to our parents, our pastors, teachers, and benefactors. Lord, we pray for them. Give them your holy peace, may they pass in the world spreading happiness around them.

Wishing you a happy new year to all those who suffer and to whom life is a burden. May God give them hope which will help them to bear their tribulations.

Again, wishing you a happy new year to all our reader especially to you, our friends of the Indian school. May the coming year be one of health, success, peace and happiness.

These will be obtained through love of God and love of neighbor.

Madeline Sipilänen

The Feast of the Immaculate Conception

I have seen by reading your journals that you celebrated the feast of the Immaculate Conception. We did too. At high Mass in our church we sang the "Angel Mass." The altar was beautifully decorated with white roses and lilies. The choir was decked with beautiful festoons of white and blue paper. Blue shields with our monogram could be seen here and there. Fifteen big girls had the privilege of going to High Mass at the parish church, at 10 A.M. There also, it was decorated with much taste. Our recreation room was decorated in blue and white, the colours of the Blessed V.M. The statue of our...
An Interesting Visit.

On Dec. 21st, we had the pleasure of receiving in our class rooms the visit of Mr. Innes, our School Inspector. What a happy visit! He arrived at 2 o'clock and left at 4.

First, we had reading, oral spelling, then a history lesson on La Verendrye. These brought us until a few minutes after three. Then Mr. Innes talked to us. Oh! I wish every one of you, readers, would have been here present. How into resting and useful it was. He talked about science, the love of nature. He told us to be always happy now, at school and later on with our surroundings. He also said not to be afraid of hard tasks. He says, there is real happiness in solving hard problems. We must also have an aim in life and we must do all we can to follow the good inspirations which will lead us to our goal.

Don't think that Mr. Innes was serious all that time; no, he made us laugh very much.

Before leaving we sang our song "Gold the Plant may blow". This song made him think of his school up north, where he was teaching.

We are very thankful to Mr. Innes for the kind interest he shows us and the encouragement he gave us for our school paper.

We hope to see him again in February, but we also hope that he will forget his task.

Alice Deschamps,
Grade VIII

A Preference

Sister: Here is a lolly-pop because you did your work so well today.

Reid: Please give me a good mark on the honor roll instead.

CONGRATULATIONS

What good Fathers we have at Belmont! Many of you know Father Inglin, he is our principal. He is a tall, clean man. His gray hair tell us that he must be between fifty and sixty. He is very kind and generous. The lovely Christmas gifts he sent us are proof of his generosity. We love him very much and only wish he would stay a long time with us.

Rev. Father Tétreault is in charge of the parish. He is not very tall and must be around thirty-five. Much of his time is spent for his parishioners; but always finds time to come and skate with us or amuse us in our recreation room. He is the one to organize the hockey games between the white boys and us. We love him and see him much.

Rev. Father Mercier is a rather young priest very tall and stout. Every Sunday he goes to Mass. If he found Major Roberge to say Mass, the cold weather can keep him from going. We hope that his shortness will pass and bring back to God many souls. A great deal of his time is spent playing and encouraging us in our games. Father Mercier and Tétreault are in charge of our skating rink; I should say of all our sports. They are very kind to us and try to take our duties. May they never leave us for our sorry world!

Rev. Father Chatelain and Maclean are not less amiable. These two young priests are studying Cree. We wish them success, and also thank them for their nice visits after supper. They come for the purpose of talking Cree and English with us, so just hope that they keep on for we like visitors.

Donald Chatelain,
Grade VII

A Strange Fish for a Child

Raymond: I would so much like to have a ground fish.

Sister: Ground? What would you do with it?

Raymond: I would kiss it every night before going to sleep.
Bingo Game

On New Year's day Grades V, VI, VII, VIII had a bingo game in the class room. It lasted two hours. There were about 25 prizes. When the game was over Sister called out the names of those who had scored the highest number of marks. Maria Ladislavich had the first prize, and Donald Chastain the second. I have been so lucky so this was the next time. There had been no interesting that we didn't notice about this was playing so fast.

We will have another one next year, so we all want to invite our friends to our bingo game. There will be a big surprise sister says.

Stella Siskoskan,
Grade VII

Christmas Party

During the Christmas holidays we had a fine party for the sewing girls. Decorated tables were prepared in the sewing room for lunch. During this time Sister Catherine-de-Gros was in the kitchen with a few girls making pancakes. At 3 o'clock everything was ready. After we had apples, sweets and butter lunch was followed by a bingo game. There were useful prizes for the lucky winners.

I think this party will make us love our sewing room more than ever.

Many thanks to Sister Catherine-de-Gros.

Kate Toebosis,
Grade VII
CHRISTMAS TESTS

Our Christmas Tests were long and hard. It was a review of the four months' work. Sister was very strict in grading them. We all aimed at 100% on every subject; some did get it, but most of us did not. The smartest ones changed grades, but I didn't.

When Sister had finished correcting our papers she wrote the names of each subject on a big piece of paper. She gave each pupil a little box or crate filled with holly, for Grade II; on a small bell for Grade I; and on a little sled for Grade III. Each pupil had his own and each was coloured in green and red. This encouraged us very much for they were going to be hung up for the whole month, in the class-room.

You may find on each drawing the results of the tests of the four pupils who came out first.

Elizabeth Snakeskin
Grade VI

We had a party in our class-room. Sister gave us some candy for prizes. I will tell you what we did. We played musical-chairs, the pupils of Grade I played musical-broom, and I played the phonograph. We all had fun. For the prize time, Josephine got a little brown dress & my donkey. The girls cut out paper tails. All of us went to place the tail on the donkey. It was funny to see it with a tail on its head.

The winner was Thomas Parkinson.

Emma Norris
Grade VI

CHRISTMAS DAY

Did you recognize any new name for Christmas? In fact we prepared the Mass of the "Massed Liturgy" in Gregorian. We sang it at the midnight mass, then on Christmas day at the High Mass of the parish church.

We love to sing it for it is so lovely and pious. We also sang a new hymn "Hail of Bethlehem". We got up at 7:30. How anxious we were to go down for breakfast! Our plates were all filled up with candied peanuts and pop-corn.

At about six o'clock in the afternoon, we went to the girls' recreation room to see our Christmas presents.

Rev. Father Brindley had given all the sisters nice presents. We were lovely ladies there. Toys of all sorts, many of which were very useful and others very amusing, were there lying in front of us. Every one has been well rewarded.

We thank Rev. Brindley for the gifts and sweets we had during the holidays.
A week before Christmas we have a beautiful decoration in our sewing room. Your girls looked at it. I am sure you all like decorating, don't you?

Sister M. Catherine—each one in our wardroom. Could you like to know what sort of work we are doing? Most of all the girls of grades V and VI, seven to eleven years, take manual training in the forenoon while the girls of grades VII and VIII, eleven girls, have their turn in the afternoon.

Much work has to be done, such as: mending the clothes, cutting and sewing patches, while others are continually sewing at the machines. There are always new clothes to be done. At the end of the week, when our pending darning and sewing is nearly over, we are allowed to take part in an exhibition work. These are knitted woollen sweaters, shirts, knitted suits, mittens, stockings, etc., etc. Lovely embroidery work is also done. We also learn how to cook. We have each our turn in the kitchen. This work is fine.

Now, if we do not know how to take care of food and how to prepare meals it will be our fault. For every opportunity is given to us on many times. I hope that we will all profit by these useful lessons.

Madeline Nickerson

January 1st, 1913

Margaret Hannah

Margaret: Why do you wear glasses?

Margaret: Because I can see things easily.

Margaret: Would you please take them off, when you are writing your Christmas cards for me.
The Sisters were present as well as a few Indians of the reserves. There were songs, recitations, dialogues, jigs, pantomimes and an address.

Our last wish was: "May Mrs. Millar come stay with us many more years!"

David Hankinson,
Grade VI

Our Chapel

Our little chapel looked so pretty this year in its decoration of tinsel points, settings, holly wreaths and silver stars. These in the sanctuary were much more dazzling than the things outside the crib, but nice it is especially in the morning when it is lighted up. You would think that they were real rocks. The red, blue and green lights give such beautiful tints on the rocks and particularly on the little Child Jesus.

On the top of the crib there are hills. It must be the hills of Judea where there can be seen a little scattered village in miniature. Electric lights are also in them. Small palm trees, eight inches high, are found here and there.

For my part I think this is the most crib I have ever seen.

Mary Poplar
Grade VII
The Girls' Christmas Concert

We held a Christmas Concert on December 25th. It lasted about two hours. The students and grown-ups from the reserves were present. We found it very interesting. We had seventeen articles listed on the program.

There were some recitations and a few skits, one of which they found very interesting. We also sang a very nice little story.

Could you send it? I would like to see it.

Our family was seated amongst the fireplaces at the church. Father had just finished telling us that it is too soon to give presents. He then spoke of children who do not have enough clothes or food. We all felt very sorry for them. After the service we went outside to see the children playing in the snow. We also went to the village rink where the big boys were playing. It was still exciting.

We also had parties of all kinds: bingo, cards, checkers and little entertainments.

I think I will never forget these holidays.

Sally Johnson
Grade VI

How I Spent my Christmas Holidays

What joyful holidays we all passed this year! They were not very long, from the 25th to the 3rd of January, but they were amusing.

I had much fun sliding. We went to the rink to see the hockey games. It was so exciting. Once we went to the village rink. There the big boys were playing. It was still exciting.

We also had parties of all kinds: bingo, cards, checkers and little entertainments.

I think I will never forget these holidays.

Sally Johnson
Grade V

Imaginative Story

Night Before Christmas

After supper Jack and Joan were very much excited. They went upstairs looking for stockings. Jack found one but it was too small for either of them. Joan said, "This will do for our baby brother." Jack went downstairs and tried to hang the little stocking on the fireplace for Santa to put some things for baby. Joan pinned a paper on the stocking. "BABY" was written on it.

After sometime Jack came down screaming with two long stockings. Soon the three were well hung on the fireplace. Father who was reading his newspaper said to see in the living room, and when he saw the three stockings he said, "Oh! Santa has to put many toys in those two long..."
stockings. I think maybe was the Santa
filled all the stockings. How glad were
the children in the morning.

David Tootoosis
Grade IV

Hockey Games

We had many hockey games during the
holidays, the Indian boys against the village
boys. These games were a kind of tough sometimes,
we often went to their rink. The first and
second teams often go and play at the village
rink. We are beaten sometimes. Yesterday the
third team of the village came to play here. They
were beaten six to two. I hope you boys have
just as much fun skating as we have.

Ernest Atchumun
Grade V

Friendly Visit

The white children came to visit our school
rooms on January 3rd. We had Christmas decorations
on the blackboards, in the windows and on the
walls. Not only our rooms but also the other
rooms were decorated. They wished us a Happy New
Year, and we did too.

Lucia Bigkwekan
Grade V
The pupils from the Grade II class came to visit us. Grade II had fifty words and Grade I had twenty-five words to spell. They worked hard and they talked loudly in the afternoon. Grade I junior came to visit us because he knew about spelling. He told us that there was a big rabbit. He showed us how to spell.

This morning it was our turn to go to school. We sang our songs and recited our poems when we found in the back number of our paper. We came to school prepared. It is something new.

We played rhythm band and started to play triangles, bells and cymbals. We sang songs. We played the drums. We made a song to make the teacher laugh. On the organ they invited us to come again.

Furthur Fashions,

Grade III

By Toy

On Monday we had to start school. I looked at my top. What a day! I wish there were no rain.

Edward Frenchman,
Grade I

New Jersey Huskies

It's ready for winter.

In the book of rivers and ponds, there is a beaver. He builds his house in the water. He builds his house by using sticks and mud. He makes a dam across the river. The beaver lives in the dam. He lives in the dam all year round. He stores up food during the winter months.

Fredde Martel,
Grade IV

Surprise

Today we welcome to our school two new pupils from Grade VI. They are Stella McIntosh and Donald Graham. They are both promised to arrive today. We hope that they will find our school very nice. We are sure that they will enjoy all their work. We will surely find little difficulties; I can assure myself that they will be happy at school. Our teacher will be all she can be to make you understand them.

Your pupils from Grade I.
We all invite you for the 16th of this month, there will be a BIG HOCKEY GAME.

---

At Christmas we had one snow day. We had much fun with our toys. The toys were pretty. I like my doll.

Mistakes made in the classroom:

(a) In baptism we promise Jesus his name and his power and live according to the example of J. Christ.

(b) Days of abstinence are days when we must not eat flesh meat.

(c) When we baptize we must pronounce the words at the same time.

(d) Confirmation, baptism and holy orders can be received but once because they imprint a mark in the soul.

(e) Name an early missionary of the West? Columbus.
A PRAYER

O Lord, Father in Heaven,
Look this prayer
Guide me and keep me always
Until I climb the ladder stair.
Help me to take each step right,
With a cheerful smiling face,
So that when I start over,
I reach a higher place.
Take me a mirror child,
In body and in mind,
More and more like Thee,
True, loving, kind.
Show me how to travel the road,
Show me the way of it.
That some day to Thee I'll come
For Thy service make me fit.

This is taken from the Western Press.
Blue Quills Res. School
St. Paul, Alberta.
Feb.17th,1938.

Mr. R. A. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare and Training
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

As Rev. Father Langlois requested we are sending you a copy of our school journal.

We, the teachers and pupils, feel well repaid for our work when we receive journals from other Indian Schools.

The routine of work is much the same in all Indian Schools and it is in trying to beautify these humble tasks and to render picturesque the little incidents of every day life that lies the true value of exchanging school magazines.

We feel honored, Kind Sir, to think that you will read these little compositions and see the sketches of our pupils.

Very sincerely yours,

The Teachers of The Blue Quills School.

[Signatures]

Ottawa, February 23, 1938.

Dear Sister Costello:

Please accept my most sincere thanks for your letter of the 17th instant and for the magazine enclosed therewith.

It is scarcely necessary to state that I appreciate very fully the courtesy of the Reverend Sisters and pupils in writing to me at this time.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. Sister C. Costello,
Blue Quills Indian Residential School,
Saint Paul, Alberta.
MEMORIES OF CHRISTMAS.

Every room that we stepped in made us think of the joys of Christmas; not only by the cheerful people but by the beautiful decorations. What a sight it was to see the boys' Hall, the convent, the school, and the church, all so well arranged. Of course I think the most beautiful decoration was in our classroom, because you see, I gave a hand in putting up the trimmings! — Frank Giroux — Gr. VI.

The week before Christmas, everyone in our class was asked to have a gift ready to exchange. We each wrote our name on a slip of paper, even Sister. Those slips were then gathered and mixed, and then we each took one. We were to prepare a gift for the person whose name was written on our slip. It was most exciting. Jimmy Thomas was the lucky one to get Sister Jean's name. At last the great day came! Our classroom was decorated so beautifully. There was a nice tree under which we put all our nicely-wrapped parcels. Frank Giroux then replaced Santa Claus, by calling out the names and giving out the parcels. When our name was called, we had to go to the front and show the class what we had received, so they could laugh if someone had played a trick on us. We received nice gifts, and we were doubly happy because it was our last day in school before the wonderful holidays. — Dorothy Phillips — Gr. VIII.

My big brother, Harry, who is in his fourth year at St. John's College in Edmonton, has ranked first in his class all year, so as a reward, Rev. Father Selmer sent him some money so he could come home for the Christmas holidays. He was so glad to be here, and we were happy to have such a nice long visit with him again. My sisters Nancy also came home from St. Augustine's Academy in Peace River for the holidays. With her came Norm Mahar, Mary Jane Sinclair, and Agnes and Pauline Kindorwater who had come to spend the fastest days here. The old pupils often went up to our classroom. I wonder if they were homesick for school, or if it is because our piano is such an attraction? — Jimmy Thomas — Gr. VIII., Annie Thomas — Gr. VI.

We were all in dreamland when suddenly we heard beautiful music. It was Sister Mary A. playing the accordion, and Sisters Jean Pius, Guy, and Cecilia Rita singing a Christmas hymn. Did Sister have to ring the bell to wake us up? I should say not; we
Were too anxious to go to see our Infant Savior.

We stayed for two Masses which were sung by Rev. Fr. Falhor. It was beautiful to see the brilliantly lighted altar and crib, the rich Mass vestments of the priest and the boys in their red cassocks. Henry Thomas, also in red, was Master of Ceremonies. Rev. Fr. Betti preached in Croc, then Rev. Fr. Kindervater spoke in English. We were all very glad to have Midnight Mass in our cathedral, as it was almost a year since we had gone to worship there, as the boys had used it for their recreation room.

After Mass, we came back to the convent and took a light lunch. Going back to bed, I regretted that it had passed all too quickly. But we looked forward eagerly to all the joys that Christmas brings.

Mabel Noskeyi --- Gr. VIII.

Before our gifts were given out, we had a little program which was acted by eight boys. It was so funny! They then cleared the stage and started to call out the Christmas presents. Fr. Kindervater was our Santa Claus this year. He was very anxious for our presents because he wanted to see what we had. All our gifts came from St. John's friends at J.J.A. Viking. While they were calling our names out, we tried to take a peek. After all the presents were given, Fr. Kindervater's sister, Agnes, played on the piano and he sang after, for us in German.

Some of the children had games, tops, ten pins, puzzles and so forth. After having played Santa Claus, Father passed candies and peanuts to us. Then all was finished the children went to play with their new toys. You should have heard the noise and seen all the happy faces.

Margie Buddin ---- Lena Twin ---- Gr. VI.

A CHANGE OF THE CLERGY

On Dec. 28th, Rev. Fr. Proulx went east to see his mother who is not expected to live. He is not back yet, and we don't know how he and his beloved mother are getting along, but we hope that God will restore her to health again. Malba Cordiall --- Gr. V.

When we came back to school after our holidays we were sorry to hear that Fr. Proulx, our former Catechism teacher left for Ottawa but we are glad to have Fr. Kinderv...
A PLEASANT VISIT

On Jan. 1st, Mother Provincial and Sr. Aubert paid us a visit; they came on Saturday and went back on Monday. We all thought that was too short a visit, but we had no bus; visiting other missions they had to go. I hope they will come again.

Sr. Aubert was very kind in removing our Club's subscription to the Catholic Messenger. We get it every month. It is a little Catholic messenger with beautiful stories which we enjoy very much. We wish to thank Sr. Aubert once more for her kindness, for this is the second year she gets the Messenger for us.

Jean Bollrose --- Gr. VI.

Sr. Louise de Bon Pasteur who had been at the Molonman Hospital since November, came back in January. She had a sore foot and could not walk. She was very glad to come back and so was everyone else. Now she is doing her work as cook in the kitchen.

Sr. Joseph Augustin who has been in charge of us girls was changed last week. We are very sorry when she told us that she was going to be back. Sr. Vitellia is coming to take her place.

Margaret Auger --- Gr. V.

INCREASE IN GROUARD POPULATION

It just seems like yesterday that Irene Cossette and Julienne Noceydi were sitting in the classroom with us -- but no! It is almost three years ago that they got married. Last month Irene's second baby boy was born. His name is Kenneth Lloyd. I wish it would have been a little girl, because girls help more than boys! Julienne has two little girls, the baby has my name: Edna. Alvino Culifer who was married:
Last year also has a baby girl named Violet Evelyn. We wish these old schoolmates of ours much joy in their new life.

Edna Fulton --- Gr VII.

READING OF THE NOTES

On Feb. 1st, Fr. Felhor came to the classrooms to read the notes. Frank Giroux got the prize in Sister 'Jean Precious' room. He and Mary Callion were both tied with an average of 95% but he got the lucky number. In our classroom Theresa Lussent was the highest, while in Sr. Mary Thelma's room William John Chalifoux was the best. Leonie Herson was the highest in Sr. Guy of the Savior's classroom. We didn't get any report cards, but we all know our points. We will try to do better next month.

Mary Twin --- Gr. V.

While we were having our report cards, Mr. Sprugo the Inspector of Fisheries came with another man to visit the school. When Mr. Sprugo came to our room he asked us a few questions on the different kinds of birds and fish that are found here. We then sang a song for him. So in return he also sang two nice songs for us. We wish we were always as lucky to have visitors sing when they come and visit our classroom, for we enjoy it very much.

Helen Miller --- Gr. VII.

ST. THERESE'S CLUB HAS A MEETING

We invited St. Valentine to our club meeting this year. It was held on the 15th of February. We invited Sister John Precious and her pupils and all those who don't come to school. After having sung our club hymn to The Little Flower, we recited the Summ of Boos as our real call. Then we dramatized "The Pied Piper". The rats made everyone laugh when they ran after the Pied Piper, Raymond Anott. The most important thing was the passing of the valentinos which we
Since Sr. Amy had almost seventy pupils, Fr. Fuller, always so helpful, decided that Florence Shaw, one of our old pupils would help Sister. Florence took over some of the pupils and is now teaching them in the boys' new refectory. She also has six girls; the rest are boys. We hope she will enjoy teaching and close with her much success.

Annie Thomas --- Gr. VII.

On Feb. 17th, all the Fathers and Brothers renewed their vows. Rev. Fr. Lajoie said Mass at half past eight in the convent chapel. The Brothers sang during Mass. Rev. Fr. Lajoie preached in French and English. It was all very beautiful. Before Fr. Drouin received Holy Communion he made his vows for one year. After Mass the Fathers read their vows in Latin, followed by the Brothers. When all were finished they sang the "Te Deum" and "Magnificat". In honor of the feast, we all enjoyed it so much. In the afternoon Rev. Fr. Lajoie gave us a holiday. We all enjoyed it so much. In the afternoon we went for a walk. When we came back we listened to the radio for the rest of the afternoon until night we had potatoes.

Mary Callison --- Gr. VII.

AN EVENING IN "NIGERETOWN"

Several weeks ago, we decided that our next club meeting would be all negro songs and plays. Sister could not find a good minstrel that would suit us, so she
asked us to bring all the negro stories and jokes we could find, and with these and all the catchy negro melodies stored away in our teacher's musical mind, Sister made up a two act play, so whom decided to make this a big affair, and to have it in the evening at the Boys' Hall. So we could invite our parents and friends. On Monday we had a rehearsal in the Boys' Hall. Rev. Fr. Giroux was there and the day pupils with the big pieces. We blochoned up so we would get used to seeing each other looking so funny. Fr. Giroux certainly enjoyed it for he laughed very much. We had great fun practising and blochoning up, putting on our costumes and laughing at one another. We were quite a sight to look at.

Finally the big night came. Our Secretary called out our negro names and we answered the roll call by coming in and making a big bow or doing something like that. We sang some Negro songs and some of the negroes jiggled. Next came the show at which we'll took part. In the first act, Dinah was getting her children ready to go to a concert. The second act was the concert itself. We kept the people laughing the whole time. The part I enjoyed the most was when Chicken Bone (Victor Bourgeois) played the guitar and sang. While he was playing, Fr. Na did his best mocking him with some rhythm sticks as if he was playing a violin. Then old Joe (George Clifford) began playing the violin with his nose and pipe, and every once in a while he would take a puff from his pipe. It was so funny to see him trying to keep time with the music.
After the play, Frank Giroux came in and began to sleep. Just as he started to snore he awakened with a start and said, "Do you think he saw? A ghost standing by him. He tried to sneak out quietly but as soon as he caught sight of the white figure following him he began to run for dear life. He ran out of the hall around the refectory three times. The people just yelled each time he'd come back on to the stage followed closely by the ghost. It seemed as though his hair was standing on end. When he could not run anymore he sat down on a bench and the ghost sat right beside him. That was quite a run to hear," said the ghost.

"I sho' will!" replied Frank in a breathless voice, "and when I got my breath, we sho' gonna run somonore." "Fasta, do yo' duty!!" and with this he jumped up and ran away. Everyone just shouted with laughter at Frank because his feet were as big as saucers.

In between all the funny things, we played beautiful selections with our Rhythm Band, or sang some negro songs. Everyone seemed to enjoy it for they till they cried. So many times we had to stop talking a long while because they were laughing too much.

After it was over, Rev. Frs. Lejoie and Falher spoke to us, saying how much they had enjoyed every bit of it. Many people came to thank our teacher for such an enjoyable evening. But many people missed it, so we were asked to report it. Sister said we would after Easter, perhaps.

Grade VIII.

DEATH OF BROTHER CORNET

Monday afternoon we heard of the death of Rev. Br. Corneil who died at the hospital in Peace River. Br. Corneil was born in France in 1869 and had been ill over this winter. Brother was here for many years; he was the shoemaker, but the last ten years he has been at St. Augustine's Mission in Peace River. When Br. Bossé and Dr. Cunning arrived here with the body the next night, we all went...
to the church and after the singing of the Subvenito, we prayed for the repose of his soul. On March 3rd, a Solemn High Mass was sung by Rev. Fr. Bourgeois, the Superior of St. Augustine's Mission. He was assisted by Rev. Fr. Lejoie as deacon, and Rev. Fr. Kindervater as subdeacon. It was the first time we had heard a solemn High Mass since the departure of our Bishop. Brother Cormier was buried at the right hand side of Bishop Ground. May he rest in peace.

Grade VII.

AN EVENTFUL DAY - M.R. S.

So many things happened today! Early this morning Mr. Superior, who was in Midnapore making her retreat these last two weeks, came back home. We were greatly surprised when we heard that two new Sisters had come with her. One of the Sisters whose name is Sr. Vitillion is coming to replace Sr. Joseph Augustin at the Girls' end the other, Sr. Mary Prosper, is going to replace Sr. Guy in the Boy class, so that Sr. Guy can help Sr. Vitillion to take care of the girls. On the same train, Fr. Troulx returned to Ground after a two months visit to his home, we are very anxious to see him again and to hear all about his travels.

After we had come back from the funeral this forenoon, as we were busily at work, we heard a knock on the classroom door - and to our joy and surprise, in walked Fr. Beauregard with Fr. Kindervater. Although they did not stay long because Fr. Beauregard had to leave right after dinner, we enjoyed their visit immensely. As we looked at our present and former Catechism teachers, we could not help but wish that we could keep them both. But, a few hours later, Fr. Beauregard and the Brothers were off for Peace River again, and the Sr. Bruno car took away Sr. Cecile Ritter who has been changed from here to Vassour. Thus ended an eventful day.

The day before had also been a very happy one, for the boys' new beds arrived. After having slept on the floor for fourteen months, it was "pretty nice" to spring up and down on brand new beds!

SPORT NEWS

BALL

On Easter we had the best ball game ever played at Hobbs. For 2 innings Laybones and Leafors kept tied 0-0. The Referee, Manager Pat Child had a good time counting the strikes but the Scorekeeper only had runs to mark; 6 for Laybones and 7 for Leafors.

Although it was quite cold on the other Sundays they kept on the run. It is very hard to decide who will win the old wooden cup this year. Baghors don't seem to have as much chance as all the best players like Pete Morin for instance are passing to Married Man's side.

STEER RIDING

On the 1st of May the boys started to practice for this summer's stampede. There they were at Francis Bull's place riding steers like real old Cowboys. Some of the steers though were a bit too tough and some of the riders found themselves sitting in dust all of a sudden. George Mindo Pat Rattlesnake and a few others made quite a good show.

Let us hope they all make good at the stampede this summer.

MARY MOTHER OF GOD.

A Pastor was visiting a Catholic family. "Well, Annie," he said to a bright-eyed little girl, "do you know your prayers?"

"Yes," she answered and recited "Our Father." Then she started to recite "Hail Mary" but the other stopped her. "We must not pray the Virgin Mary," he said, "recite the Credo."

The little girl began; "I believe in God" etc., but when she came to the words "who was conceived by the Holy Ghost, born of the Vir..." she stopped short. "What am I supposed to say here?" she asked. "If we must not pray her, then we should not believe in her."

The Pastor did not know what to answer but when he came back to his house he started to think over the subject and kneeling down he caught himself reciting "Holy Mary, Mother of God, pray for us, sinners, now and at the hour of our death. Amen."

DEATH OF ARCHBISHOP O'LEARY.

We were very sorry to hear that Rt. Rev. Archbishop O'Leary of Edmonton, died at Victoria quite suddenly. Our teacher, Sr. Benigna, told us what she heard about him over the radio during the Catholic Hour. She told us about his life when he was a priest, a bishop, and an archbishop and how much good he had done for his people.

On the seventh of March, Father Lejeune and Father Falher went to Edmonton for the funeral. While there, Fr. Falher got sick and had to go to the Grey Nuns Hospital to be taken care of. While he was there, he wrote a nice letter to the children. The pupils of Sr. Jean Placidus wrote to him and sent him some little jokes to make him laugh in his bed.

Core Desjardins—George Prasse...Gr.V.

MOVING PICTURES!

Father Kindervater seems to know just what we like. We were so glad when we heard that on March the thirteenth, we were going to have some moving pictures. That evening we had the story of Rin Tin Tin. As this dog was being drawn along the road, his cage happened to tip, and so he was brought up by the wolves. He grew up with wolf instincts but after he got a human master, he was always very gentle. As his master was going along as usual with some furs, his enemy shot him. Rin Tin Tin tore a piece off the enemy's clothes. Another time, Rin Tin Tin dropped another of his master's enemies down a cliff. After that, he came back to his master's home to live there happily.

Alfred Thibeault...Gr.IV.

On March twenty-third, Fr. Kindervater showed us the Life of Our Lord. Long ago, they had a plague in Oberammergau, so the people promised God if He would spare them they would act the Passion Play every ten years. In the first reels, we saw the city of Oberammergau, and the woodcarvers, carving statues and crosses. We also saw the picture of Anton Lang who took the part of Our Lord in the Passion Play. After that we saw the whole life of Our Lord. We followed Him all the way from His crib to His Cross, and last of all, when He went up to Heaven. The nicest part was when they buried Our Lord. We could see the shadow of the rock while they were lifting it up. We also could see Our Lord lying in the Holy Sepulchre.

Therese Aussant...Gr. V.
GONE... BUT NOT FORGOTTEN.

It is hard to believe that Death has taken from us a classmate whom we all loved: Milton Faverque. When a letter from Harry Thomas to our teacher announced the sad news, we were all so shocked and grieved that we could say nothing. Then a telegram arrived, saying that Milton would be brought here for burial; we were all glad to think we would see him again and would be able to assist at his funeral. It was only after the funeral that we heard the details of his death.

Milton had been a pupil here for seven years. The youngest of the three Faverque boys, he was always a great favourite everywhere. He was the only little boy permitted to play in the big boys' base-ball team. Everyone remembers him for his endless teasing and fun, but also for his great kindness to the little ones. Although he had been attending the Jesuit College in Edmonton for the past three years, he often wrote to us and was always telling us to enjoy our school-days here in "the best school in the world" as he used to call it.

Milton's death was very sudden and unexpected. On Monday, March 28th, he complained of a headache. He was put to bed, but the next day, the Jesuit Fathers took him to the hospital where several of the best doctors in Edmonton did all they could to save him. But God wanted him... and on Thursday, March 31st, our dear friend Milton passed quietly away. He had been unconscious while perfectly conscious that day, and was very gay until about five hours before his death. His brother Donat was with him when he died, but George was not able to be there because of a severe headache, and their father was unable to arrive only two
A few days later, His body was taken to the Jesuit College where the Fathers, students, and friends took their turns to watch and pray near him. On Monday morning, a funeral service was held at the College with the members of his class in their special College uniforms acting as pall-bearers. There were delegations from other schools and clubs, for Milton was widely known through his great success in sports of every kind.

Mr. Fovargue, George and Donat accompanied the corpse to Grouard. Before the funeral, all of us went to see Milton for the last time. It was hard to believe he would never speak, never smile at us again! At 9:00, Rev. Fr. C. Kindervater sang the Requiem Mass. The casket was very beautiful. It was grey, and lined with white silk inside and opened at the head. In the middle was a nice crucifix. On the top of the casket were beautiful natural flowers given by friends and relatives. In a pillow of flowers, Milton's name was written in golden letters. After Mass we all went to the graveyard where they buried him beside his mother.

After we were back in school, we heard a knock at the door, and in walked Fr. Kindervater and the Brothers accompanied by Mr. Fovargue and his two sons, George and Donat. We all shook hands with them and offered them our sympathy. Donat promised our teacher that he would come to the classroom the following day to give us a speech, so we were all anxiously waiting for him. We thought that he would be too scared but when we were least expecting them they came. We were all very glad and especially when Donat gave us his promised talk. It was very interesting and we were all so sorry when he was finished. He told us all about Hilton's illness and his death. It was surely very sad. Then he told us about the hockey games and how they played other games.

A card of sympathy and a Mass offering was given by the senior class in remembrance of Milton who was once a member of our "Good Counsel Club".
May he smile down on us from above and help us all to reach that beautiful Paradise about which we sang at his funeral.

"O Paradise, O Paradise!
Who would not crave for rest?
Who could not seek the Happy Land
Where they sit loved and blest?
Where loyal hearts and true
Stirred ever in the light -
All rapture through and through
In God's most holy sight."

Good Counsel Club.
OUR NEW BISHOP.

On the seventh of April, we heard that Rev. Father Langlois was to be our new Bishop. We were all so glad when we heard the news. There was a special Benediction in the church that evening. Father Father spoke in French and in Cree, telling the people the good news, which I am sure they were all glad to hear. Our new Bishop is an Oblate, and has been the Provincial Superior in Edmonton for many years. Though we do not yet know him, we are anxious for him to come. We're sure we will like him. Will he like us, I wonder?

Kathleen Morden—Grade VI.

RETURN OF FATHER FILLER.

We were all so glad to hear that our kind Superior, Rev. Father Filler, had come back to his little floc of Grouard. We were afraid that we were going to lose our dear pastor. The same afternoon, he paid us a visit in the chapel, which we enjoyed very much. He told us of how kind the nurses had been to him while he was in the hospital those four weeks. He told us many other interesting things, but that was the one I appreciated most: being kind to our dear Father.

Father also spoke of Catherine Tekakwitha. He said that while he was in the hospital he prayed to Catherine, and the next morning when he got up, he took a few steps across the room and he couldn't feel any pain in his legs. He felt much better, and said that we will make a petition to the Pope so that she may be canonized. Father told us that he had spoken to our newly-named Bishop the day before returning; he said he just had to embrace Father Langlois because he was so glad. We could see he was very glad.

That evening at Benediction we sang the Te Deum to thank God Who answered our prayers even if we had to wait long.

THE FAITH THAT MOVES MOUNTAINS.

Who says there is no more faith? A few weeks ago, Robert Fraser, aged six, had a very bad headache. Sister Mary, after putting him to bed, went to the convent to get him an ice bag. Coming up the stairs, she heard him talking very loudly. Being alone,
she wondered to whom he could be talking. This is what she heard him screaming:
"Brother Andrew! St. Joseph! Blessed Virgin Mary! Cure me! HURRY UP!"

PLAY BALL!!

When the Spring season comes each year, it seems to fill our hearts with joy,
because it brings back old memories to us boys, especially of when we used to play
ball with the town men and "skin them alive." The first two games we played were last
Sunday. We boys played against the Brothers and some men. The score was 42 to 23 in our
favour. They said they'd play again after supper, so we told them they'd better take a
good supper if they wanted to beat us. After the evening game, the score was 36 to 23
in their favour. We said, "You must have taken a wonderful supper to give you such good
muscles!"

David Delorme—Urban Cailleau...Grade VII.

HAPPY EASTER!

During Holy Week, Father Falher was sick, so Fr. Floch came from Whitefish Lake to
replace him. Fr. Lajoie preached some very nice sermons on Holy Thursday and Good
Friday. Fr. Proulx went to Girouxville to help during Easter week.

On Easter morning, as soon as we were called, we jumped out of bed to prepare ourselves
to receive Our Risen Lord. This seven o'clock Mass was said by Mr. Aloisio to
which many people came. The altars were beautifully decorated with artificial lilies and
chrysanthemums. After Mass, we all had our breakfast. On coming into the refectory, we
saw Easter eggs, doughnuts, chocolate rabbits and roosters at our places. Did we enjoy
our breakfast? I should say we did! It tasted too good to last long!

At ten o'clock, we went to Solemn High Mass which was sung by Fr. Hindervater. It
looked so nice to see the older-boys and torch-bearers wearing red cassocks. After
dinner, some went for a walk; others went to their homes. Those who stayed played ball
or some games. We had apple pie in the afternoon, and a chocolate bar in the evening. The
older pupils wrote a special letter of thanks to kind Father Lajoie who had bought all
these nice things for Easter.

Grades IV and V.
NEGRO MINSTREL.

We repeated our Minstrel Show on Easter Tuesday night, because Sister Superior and several others had missed it when we first put it on. Many people came this time. We were glad Father Ploch could be here too, for he always enjoys seeing our shows. Father Serand and some Sisters were supposed to come from St. Bruno's, but all day it snowed and blew so that it was impossible for them to travel with the car. Father Proulx missed it again, because he could not get back from Girouxville on time.

The same jolly crowd of "niggers" did their best and made the audience forget their troubles for almost two hours. A few new members had been added to the program, so that even those who came to see it for the second time had some surprises. I am sure Father Bruckert, our last year's Drill Master, would have enjoyed seeing Emile Thibault (in a tight red suit!) as a private soldier obeying the French commands of Sergeant Frank Garo. George Califer as Old Black "oe again was the biggest "hit" of the evening, making people just shriek with laughter. Although George and Frank were the ones who made the people laugh most, all did their parts very well we know, because everybody told us so!

Arnest Giroux, President, Gr.VIII.

FATHER FALHER GOING AWAY.

We were very, very sorry today when we heard that our dear Father Falher is going to leave us again. He has been in bed for over a week again, and seems to be getting worse so it was decided today that Father Giroux would take him to the hospital at Baiefr, so that he can receive some special treatments there. It was the new Bishop who suggested this. Though we are sorry to see Father go, we are glad that he is going to be treated by experts so that he will soon be able to come back to us here. The children are going to pray so hard that God will not be able to refuse our prayers. Besides being the Superior of our Mission, Father Falher is also the Cree Professor of all the young priests who want to learn that language. Father is also the oldest missionary in the Vicariate. May he soon get better and come back to his old home in Grouard.

Dorothy Phillips, Grade VIII.
EASTER GREETINGS

The long Lenten season is at last finished and Easter, with its spirit of joy and gladness, is here again. All are happy, in the joy of Christ's resurrection — and in the certainty that winter is past, and the beautiful season of spring is beginning. We hope that you, dear readers, also carry within your hearts, this same spirit of well-being.

We wish to thank our many friends who have written us such encouraging letters, always so full of gratitude. Bishop Cox and our inspector, Mr. Gilles, for their kind letters.

HELLO EVERYBODY!

HAPPY EASTER EVERYTHING!!

"LEFT RIGHT! LEFT RIGHT!!"
EASTERTIDE

On March 19th, our dear Bishop came home after his illness at the hospital. He stayed home all during Holy Week. Fr. Jungbluth stayed at home to help Fr. Falher while all the other young priests went out to help in different places. Fr. Beauséjour went to McLennan; Fr. Bruckert to Girouxville, Fr. Roué to Lake Magloire and Fr. Proulx to Falher. On Holy Thursday morning they had removed the Communion railing to make the sanctuary bigger. The Bishop officiated and consecrated the Holy Oils. They also had the procession of the Blessed Sacrament. The repository which was nicely decorated was on the Blessed Virgin's side. That evening we made our Holy Hour. On Good Friday, Fr. Falher officiated and in the afternoon we had the Way of the Cross. On Holy Saturday, Fr. Jungbluth blessed the Easter water and said Mass. In the afternoon he and Fr. Dupont went around and blessed all the houses.

Lillian Harris - Gr. V.

Easter is always a very joyous feast. Although we cannot use the Church since it is now the Boys' Hall, we had very nice ceremonies in the Chapel. At six o'clock there was a low Mass for the Mission pupils and at seven o'clock there was a Communion Mass for the people. At ten o'clock we had a Solemn High Mass. Bishop Guy assisted at the throne and preached very nice sermons in English and in French. Jimmy Thomas - Gr. VII ... Annie Thomas - Gr. VI.

Easter Monday, Fr. Falher gave permission to the children to go and see their parents. After the Mass was finished we went to eat our breakfast. While we were eating, already some boys were called. They stayed a whole day enjoying themselves.
The Sisters of St. Bruno's also came to visit on Monday. When our Sisters heard that they were here we could see them hurrying from the different houses to see the Sisters that came. They all seemed so happy that day. Henry Prins - Gr. VI.

MISSION TRAVELLING

On March 30th, Fr. Falher went to Fort St. John to visit Fr. Dréau who was very ill. He stayed there almost three weeks. The roads were so bad that he had to take the airplane from Ft. St. John to Dawson Creek. It was his first trip and he said he enjoyed it very much. The day after Fr. Falher's departure, Fr. Poirier and Br. Dupont left for the east. Fr. Poirier went home to visit his parents. Br. Dupont who was here on account of his health, went back to Montreal. We are glad our good climate made him better, but we were sorry to see him leave.

Danny Simleir - Gr. VIII.

After staying here for two weeks, Bishop Guy left for Ottawa to go and report to the doctor. He went also to administer Confirmation in the East. We are anxious for the day when Bishop Guy and Fr. Cherost will be back which will be towards the end of May.

Fr. Marten was Sr. Paul Sugano left in a big wagon and it took them five hours to reach the station.

George Califer - Gr. VI.
Sister Superior went to McLennan in a buggy. The roads were very bad so it took a long time to reach the station. She went to McLennan to meet Mother Provincial who had been at Peace River and was returning. A few days later Sister Marcelle went to McLennan to bring Denise Lussant to the hospital to be operated on for appendicitis. They are all back now.

Harry Frise - Gr. VI.

Sr. Cecile Rite came from Montreal a few weeks ago. Lizzy went across the lake in the new snowplow to get her at St. Bruno's. She is now helping Sr. Francis Desire take care of the girls. Sr. Joseph Augustine nor taking care of us boys instead of Sr. Guy Joseph who helps Sr. Superior.

Frank Giroux - Gr. VI.

Rev. Fr. Roué, a young Oblate who came here to learn the Cree language has been called to Sturgeon Lake. When he was here every one was glad to meet him for he was very kind. Jo boys miss him but all hope he will like his new home. Ernest Giroux - Gr. V.

FEAST OF THE SOLIDITY OF ST. JOSEPH

The feast of the Solidity of St. Joseph was celebrated on April 18. We were glad when his feast was coming, for we could pray to him to give us special graces, such as to be honest, kind or charitable towards our neighbors and our enemies. Rev. Fr. Roué sang the solemn High Mass. Fr. Jungbluth was the Deacon and Fr. Proulx was the Subdeacon. Fr. Roué preached in Cree about St. Joseph while he was on earth with Our Blessed Mother, while Fr. Bruckert gave an eloquent sermon in French. He talked about the virtues of St. Joseph and how we could imitate him in our lives.

Jean Rollrose - Gr. V.

Frank Giroux - (Just recuperating from Pneumonia) "I had a clothing sickness; my tongue was coated, and my breath came out in short pants."
CLUB MEETING

The meeting of the Good Counsel Club was held on April 20. The Fathers, Sisters, and many of the old pupils who used to be in our class a few years ago, came. Father Superior could not come but Fr. Beauchage gave a nice speech after the meeting. The Musical Travologue was enjoyed by all. It was an imaginary trip to Europe. For each country we visited, we sang a song. The thing that everybody enjoyed most was when we sang a German song, which Fr. Bruckert had taught us. Nobody understood it but they all laughed because it sounded so strange. Fr. Bruckert said we sounded like real Germans.

Raymond L'Hirondelle - Gr. VIII.

A mute comedy called "Wanted: A Wife" was played by four girls and two boys. Ernest Giroux played the part of the bachelor who advertised for a wife. He hung a sign on the door "Wanted: A Wife". There were many knocks on the door. The ones who came in were: Miss Cross Patch (Mary Gallion), Miss Vanity (Lena Trim), Miss Silly (Ruth Morden), and Miss Fatty Grub (Helon Miller). He did not want any of those. After a while, a woman came who had a black veil on. He liked this one and asked her to marry him. When she took her veil off, to his surprise, he found that she was a negro woman and worse still, a boy (George Califor), so he decided to remain a bachelor!

Eina Prudon and Lena Trim --- Gr. VI.

of the Very Rev. the Oblates, on his Getchism to his Salt Prairie lambs.

Designer - Frank Ward - Gr. VIII.
DISTINGUISHED PUPILS

We think our class is highly honored in having Rev. Fr. Jungbluth as a pupil. He wants to learn to speak English well, so he comes to school from one o'clock until recess time. He must find it funny to be sitting in a desk again. You can imagine how we are trying to be good so that he may thank us for our fine pupils.

Fr. Roué also came one afternoon, but we are still wondering what we did to him for he left the very next day for Sturgeon Lake. Rev. Fr. Bruckert also is studying English, but as he wishes to learn the Phonics, he goes to the Junior class. No hope he will soon be promoted to our class!

We are proud to think that our Cree language can be learned so quickly. Already three of the young Fathers have preached very nice sermons in Cree. Now that they have learned this language they are trying to learn English so that they may be able to speak to everybody, and thus win more souls to God.

God bless our Missionaries!

Florence Shaw - Gr. VIII.

SORROWS

April 27th was a very sad day for two of our Sisters. Sr. Marcella received word that her father had died on Thursday. So the next morning Rev. Fr. Bruckert sang the Requiem Mass for the repose of his soul and we prayed for him. Mary Collion - Gr. VII.

That same afternoon we were taking our rests when Sr. Superior came out of our classroom. She told us the very sad news which was received by telegram, that our dear teacher's mother was very ill. They asked her to go home, but as it is nearly the end of the school year Sister couldn't possibly leave. We all prayed very hard for her mother's recovery.

Ruth Morden - Gr. VII.

Yesterday afternoon as we were playing ball, some girls told us that Sr. Jean had received a second telegram saying her mother was better, but still very weak.
from heart trouble. I was just like St. Thomas! I didn't want to believe them until I asked Sister myself. She answered me with a smiling face. You could see that she was happy. We are all very glad too, and hope she will soon be well again.

Nobel Nockeyi - Gr. VII.

Junior Club Meeting.

We had our Club Meeting on April 29th. The Fathers, Sisters and Sr. Jean Placideus and her pupils were invited. In our Enterprise work we took an imaginary trip to Europe. Frank Giroux and Emile Thibeault made our moving picture machine. We drew some pictures which showed the things we saw and all the different countries we passed through. We crossed the Atlantic then went to England to see the king. After visiting England we went to Holland to see the Dutch people. As soon as we left Holland we went through France. Harry Fraser read his composition of St. John of Arc, and Pato Gledu told the story of St. Theresa. We were anxious to hear Pato's story because she is our club patroness. The story of St. Bernadette was a little play by four girls and one boy. After having left France, we went to Rome to visit our Holy Father and St. Peter's Cathedral. Frank Giroux told us about our visit with the Pope in a very interesting way. Then we went to St. Peter's Church to visit all the different things there. Jean Bollrose told us about it in her composition. We then took the ocean liner and came back to Canada. The last thing was our Club song. All who came thought it was very nice.

Rosalie Hobson - Gr. V. ... George Fraser - Gr. IV.
BALLAMES

Congratulations to the Mission girls and Mission boys who beat the town girls and boys! Since the ballgame season has opened we have started playing against each other. Sunday evening was our first game. We all went home feeling happy though we were beaten because we enjoyed ourselves very much. It was a tight game at first. Fr. Besueuge, our kind Catechism teacher, was our umpire, for which we wish to thank him. The boys also had a game at the same time. There were two Brothers with Benjamin Noskeyi playing on the boys' side. All through the game, both sides were tied but towards the end, the Mission boys won. They are going to play another game soon and we hope it will be even better than the first one.

Louise Tomkins - Gr. VI. (A town girl).

MAY ALTARS

This morning as the pupils came into the class room, there were many "Ohs" and "Ah's" heard, for we have a lovely May Altar in our class room. In Sr. Benigna's and Sr. Bernadette's rooms also the altars are very nice. There is a nicely decorated one in the girls' hall and a beautiful grotto in the Chapel. As we look and admire these lovely reminders of the month of the Blessed Virgin, we think of our Holy Mother and pray for her help. The hymn to the Blessed Virgin sung at Mass on Sunday was very beautiful. We are indeed fortunate to have Sisters who decorate so beautifully.

Jennie Gordon --- Gr. VIII.

IT PAYS TO ADVERTISE!

Sister Mary Aquinas, a friend of our teachers, who has been in California, wrote to each pupil who wrote in the last journal. We were delighted with our cards, and the nice views of Golden Gate, the new wonder-bridge of Oakland, and many other beautiful scenes of California. Mrs. Zachlin, Sr. George Wilfred's cousin, sent us
lovely views of Cleveland Ohio. We surely appreciate these acts of kindness and wish to thank Sr. Mary Aquinas and Mrs. Zachin. We are getting educated in an interesting way this year! Frank Ward - GR. VIII ------ Charles McLeod - GR. VI.

Easter Bingo

On Easter evening our dear Father Princapol gave us a Bingo party. All the tables were decorated with pretty little baskets filled with Easter eggs which were bought for that occasion. Everyone had his own box and was glad to have at party that evening.

The Sisters and all the Sisters were invited and answered the invitation. Everyone enjoyed the party.

Holy Week

We had plenty praying time. If we were without any trouble or worry, we could be in a comfortable place. It was late in the evening when we left for the dormitory.

Michele Mironow. Grade II.

Jesus, Friend of the Children

When I take Holy Communion you receive Our Lord into your heart.

Remember that He is told, "Save me, Jesus Who did so many wonderful things for the children of men? We can not see Him. That we know He sees us and watches over us. He hears every word we say; He sees everything we do.

A Visit To My Home

Some time ago I went home to see my Father who was sick. Father Rheamook and Mr. Gilbert were there also. We had a nice time together. Although I felt not I enjoyed my trip. We stopped at Loaf's because Mr. Gilbert lives there and we thought we would visit his parents. His parents have been very kind to us. Then we started for my home which is in Gold Lake. We got there seen for it is only 10 miles from Loaf's. We stopped at the mission and met our priest Father Silvain came with us to the hospital.

That a joy to see my Father and what a pleasure for him to see us, thank you to our kind Father Perdew. From the hospital we went to my home where I found my mother, my little brother and many other friends who wanted to see us. We were gone two days when we came back three days late, same by once back with us we were at school again on time for supper.

Mary Kent, Grade III.

The Month of May

May is the month of our dear beloved Mother, we call it the month of Mary, we like to pray the Blessed Virgin during her month. She is the mother of the infant Jesus and ours too because He gave to us. She loves all the children, she likes to pray for them, she gives us the graces we need, and do bless our parents, the Sisters, all our friends and the sick people. Gr. 3.

In our chapel we have a statue of the Blessed Virgin Mary. It is a large one, Sister had decorated it with flowers. Every evening we hail the Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament at 7:30 p.m., sang hymn to the Blessed Sacrament and we liked it. The statue in our chapel room was decorated with natural plants.

The month of June has come now it is in the month of the Sacred Heart, we pray Him to bless us and all ours. May He listen to us.

During our Easter Holidays, we visited his farm. Our Master had prepared a special lunch for us. As soon as dinner was over, we went to the kitchen. We helped make the cake. It was finished. I ate until I could not eat anymore. We then had lunch. After lunch, we walked to the farm. When we reached the place it was a long walk to back here. I run part of the way with the others boys and we almost lost our way but we finally reached home safely, very tired. Henry Grace Go

My dear children,
With the 1st of July begins officially your Summer Vacation. For a long time you have looked ahead for this happy moment. Yes go back to your beloved parents. Have you deserved this long rest? Yes, for your physical benefit. Your application has been good and success followed consequently. We are proud of you for your sincere piety and love of your Religion. Again all the year along you have been taught "how to know God, to love Him and to serve Him." This you shall never forget and always you shall be faithful to your God and Religion, remembering that there is no rest in the practice of our Religion.

Therefore, every Sunday, my Good Children come to assist at Mass, remembering that one missing Mass on Sunday without serious reason will commit a big mortal sin. Be also faithful to your daily morning and evening prayers. Be obedient to your parents, trying your very best to show them how you love them. May your conduct be good and I can assure you all that you shall be very happy during those days of rest and freedom.

Continue to love your School always have a kind thought towards your School and try to bring some new children with you next Fall.

May God bless you always,
Father Pratt, O.M.I.

Club Feast.....

April 26th was a happy day for us Senior boys and girls, for it was the feast of Our Lady of Good Counsel, patroness of our Club. After saying our morning Offering, Sist told us she thought this would be a good day to remember our departed Members, by fixing their graves. So off we started! As soon as we reached the cemetery, we knelt down by Milton's grave and recited the prayer for the dead; we then sang our Club Hymn. How touching and beautiful the words seemed there in the silent graveyard. I think all of us had very serious thoughts as we sang and prayed.

The big boys went to get some fresh soil, while the others pulled out the weeds and cleaned the graves. Others made a fire outside of the cemetery and cooked some potatoes. When we had cooked about two dozen, we called the others. Sister Joseph Napoleon sent us a nice lunch, which we enjoyed very much after our hard work. After our lunch, we girls went down to the lake shore to get some stones to make a border around the grave. When we came back, Sister had the boys paint the names white. A large flat white stone was then placed at the head of the grave, and then Milton's and Mary Rose's names were printed on them with black paint. It looks very nice. Around three o'clock, all was finished. Since then we have planted flowers on their graves, and must go daily to water them. But we are glad to be able to do this much for the dear old classmates we loved. We are sorry that our other departed classmate, Lilly McDermott was not buried here, so we could do the same for her. When we are dead and gone, we hope somebody will think of us too. "What you do for others will be given back to you."

Helen Miller..... Grade VII.

TO MILTON.

It was a shock and sad to hear, That on to us, who was so dear,
Has left us one and all. In answer to the Master's call.
So, let us ever pray and hope, That St. Peter, our first and greatest Pope
Has gladly opened the Golden Gate, For one who could not dodge the Hand of Fate.
And smiling, showed him his stintly berth, Which he loved and fought for
on this earth.

By Harry Gregory... Dawson Creek, B.C.

The above verse was written by one of our old schoolmates on learning of the death
of Milton Boyer. Harry also wrote another poem about leaving school which we are
glad to put into the pages of our school paper. If there are other poets amongst our
old pupils, just send your verses in and we will put them in print for you!

SCHOOL D.I.'s.

'Twas in '36, I made a sad mistake, When from my boyhood friends did break,
I left behind the golden days of school, Many of which I spent as a regular fool.
I left with a feather mind, but a heavy heart,'Cause from you, 'twas hard to part.
You may call it false pretence, Though I thought it was common sense.

Three good friends I took with me, You know them all as I can plainly see,
Brown eyed Archie, smart Alec, and lonesome Sam, who, on quitting school, thought
it time to roam.
They went their way, and I went mine, Just two years, but it's more like nine.
But you, we never did, and can't forget, You can wage your life, and win the bet!

Some days I'm happy, on others blue, But always my thoughts stray back to you,
Not listen close, you girls and boys, I'll pass the sorrows and my joys.
But I'll stop to give you good advice, For which I've had to pay the price:
LIFE IS NOT YOU MAKE IT! In the game For which you have just yourself to blame.

Answer the bell with a ringing heart, For you'll never get another start,
Do it gladly and learn to read and write,'Cause you'll need it in this earthly fight.
Then too, they only give you once The chance not to stray a common dunces,
You have the teachers, the very best, And I'd say more: the choicest of the West.
Even now as I wander o'er the track, I know I'll never find the trail to lead me back,
To those golden days of pleasure, and if used aright, the future will hold some treasure,
I'm sure our school there's none can press, So show them its rightful class.
For when we put our school amongst the rest, It's the grandest and the best!
Harry Gregory... Class '32.

The Month of May.

During the month of May we had Benediction every night in the church. On May the first
when we came in our classroom, the very first thing we noticed was the beautiful May
altar near the piano. There were lovely roses all around the Blessed Mother, also vigil
lights and flower vases. In Sister Benigna's class, there was also a very nice altar.

On May 26th, before the afternoon Benediction, it was very nice to see the girls all
dressed in white, and carrying wreaths for the crowning of the Blessed Mother. They made
a procession round the church during which they sang hymns. After all the girls had
brought their wreaths, Mary Collins crowned the blessed Virgin, then she recited the
Act of Consecration. Father Floch gave a nice talk to the Children of Mary.

Everyone was very glad when they came to Mass on Ascension Thursday, to see Father
Father back home again after his long illness in Banff. He is feeling much better now,
and we are still hoping that he won't have to leave us again to go so far away.

Ruth Morden...... Grade VIII.

Truck Rides.

We girls felt a little bit jealous when we heard that the boys were going for a ride
in the truck. The Children of Mary were having a conference that afternoon, and though it
was very interesting, we kept looking out of the window, trying to see the lucky boys.
It was not until they came back that we learned that we were to go too. Were we glad?!?
We just kept jumping the whole while we were waiting! We had great fun when we reached
the bridge. The truck was going very fast, and at the same time our hair was just flying
for it was such a swift ride. We had to take our turns off in case they would fall in the-
water. We stopped at one place where Brother Bossé and a few of us girls put out some fire, so you see we are quite good at it, even if we are JUST GIRLS!

We didn't forget to thank the Sisters who were keeping us and the driver too, got his share of thanks and cheers. The little boys and girls who hadn't had their ride in the afternoon went after supper. They went just as far as we did, but it took them a long time to come back. When they arrived we were playing Base Ball and Volley Ball. That night we dreamed wonderful dreams!

Mabel Noskowi... Grade VIII Maggie Budskin... Grade VI.

Visit of Mr. Gilles.

On May 16th, after school, we were surprised to see our school inspector, Mr. Gilles, come walking up to the school with Father Proulx. He was just passing through this district so he decided to pay us a visit. We missed our chance of seeing him this time, but our teacher and a few others had the privilege of speaking to him. The next day was to be a hard day for us, as Sister had told us that she was going to give us some tests. When we saw Mr. Gilles, we were very glad because we thought he would come to our class the next day and then we wouldn't have to take our tests. Imagine our disappointment when we saw him driving back to McLennan that very evening! The next time he comes, we hope his visit will be much longer.

A Happy Day at Ground.

Father Floc'h celebrated his patronal feast on the nineteenth of May. The Grade six pupils had the honor of writing some letters to him to offer him our best wishes. That morning, when we woke up we didn't know that we were going to have such a nice surprise. We came to school as usual, but at eleven o'clock, Sister dismissed us. We were then told to get our dishes because we were going to the park for dinner. The biggest boys carried the food, so we were soon all sorted on the grass, enjoying our picnic lunch. After we had finished, we played ball against the boys. Three guesses who won? We stayed till one-thirty, then it was time for school so we returned to the classroom. I think it was a
Happy day for everyone because it was the first time we have dinner in the park this year. We also had a holiday on May 24th because it was Victoria Day. The Fathers went to Jossard for a meeting, and after a pleasant morning, we children went to the park with some of the Sisters. We stayed all the rest of the day. We played Volley Ball and soft ball. I think that nothing can equal a holiday... for school children anyway.

Dorothy Phillips...Edna Pruden...Grade VII.

Visitors from Far and Near:

One evening, we saw a big car driving up. We could see that it was somebody very important because the Sisters all seemed so happy. We soon found out that the car had brought Mother Provincial and Sister Geraldine from Hindupore, also Sisters St. Therese and Dominic from Sturgeon Lake. The next day, the Sisters from St. Bruno's came to see them too, so there were many Sisters here.

After High Mass, we had the Blessed Sacrament exposed in the church until five o'clock so we could take part in the Eucharistic Congress of Budapest too. All our visitors made the holy hour in the afternoon. It seemed as if we were having the Congress here, for there were representatives from Fort Vermilion (Fr. Hoby), Whitefish Lake (Fr. Floch), Hindupore, Sturgeon Lake, Jossard and Ground. Towards evening, all the visitors went away again.

Mary Collen...Grade VIII.

School Closed:

The dry pupils couldn't come to school for a week because there was an epidemic of Scarlet Fever going around. We were sorry to have to miss school, but Sister told us that if we went well, we could come back in a little while. The Mission children came to school only in the mornings, so they could be outside more and keep well. During this time the Sisters did their best to keep us from getting sick. We also prayed very hard to the Sacred Heart so He would pity us and so the sickness would soon be over with. So now we are back in school, well and happy, and we hope that there will be no more distractions till the end of the year.

Kathleen Morden...Jean Bellrose...Grade VI.
PLAY BALL!

It was an enjoyable trip—we big girls and boys had to Jousserd on the ninth of June. We had received an invitation to go and play ball with the pupils of St. Bruno Mission, and Father Falher who is always so happy when he can give us pleasure, sent the big red truck to take us to Jousserd. Father Kindervater and three Sisters came too. On the road near Jousserd, we saw two deer. They were small, but I don't think I could have caught them running! As soon as we reached the Mission, we played a game of Soft Ball against the Mission Boys. When the ninth inning was over, the score was nineteen to two, in favor of the Grouard boys. The girls then played a game. Father Kindervater was Umpire. Our girls won by just one score. It was just by luck that they won, for it was a very close game.

When I first went into the field, I felt nervous and excited. But after a while I calmed down and then I said to myself, "It's only a game after all... I don't care!" The Jousserd boys are very good at playing Baseball... perhaps if we had not played Soft Ball, we would not have won so easily. After we had had a good rest, we were ready for another game. Just then, Father Gould came along with his High Prairie boys. They were going to play against Jousserd, but instead, they played with us. After a lot of fun and teasing, the game was again over, and I'm proud to say that we won again. The score was 10 to 3. They then gave three cheers for the Grouard winners. Many congratulated us, and we in turn thanked them for such an enjoyable day. At dusk we were on our way to Home, Sweet Home again, tired but very happy. At least we didn't go for nothing; we had a sixty mile ride and we won all the games.

EDITORIAL

A special newspaper, however small, seems to be very badly needed by our Indian population. To support this statement I can bring the following reasons: First, our Indians are brought up in our schools, with the knowledge of the English language, the ideals of the white people, and therefore it seems necessary to devise some means of following up with the civic and religious education, the rudiments of which were given in the school: a monthly, or better still, a weekly news bulletin, answers this need in part. Second, it is a widespread belief that evils must be counteracted by the spreading of truth; here again a newspaper can have a great influence on its readers: the different movements of the day need analysis and explanations which only a paper can give, on account of its frequency and facility of distribution. Third, our Indians have not generally speaking, a very well-developed sense of culture: a bulletin or newsheet, regularly distributed to them, might help them acquire a desire for information, a platform to exchange ideas, and most of all, another efficacious mean for the authorities to teach civics, health and sanitation, moral advice, and to suggest divers means of bettering their lives. Fourth: in a paper such as ours aims to be, we seek to create a link between the parents and their children who are away from them for the greater part of the year, a link which the parents appreciate very much indeed. Fifth: the distribution of a specifically Catholic paper in the Catholic homes is intended to teach two lessons: (1) the need of Catholic literature in the home, (2) the need of supplementing secular reading on Sunday with some religious and devotional reading. Not only children, but adult Protestants belong to Sunday School classes, and every one goes home with a religious paper, which he or she is expected to read as a pious exercise.

Too many Catholics, on the other hand, feel that they do not need a Catholic paper, because they attended denominational schools, where they had a course of religious instruction extending over many years. Yet they find themselves unable to answer questions asked about their religion by their friends, or about pagan practices which the Church disapproves, or about accusations directed against Catholics, occasionally, in secular papers or magazines.

Study clubs are growing rapidly among people who are interested in questions and problems of the day. Now, a short sermon, attended by a few, or a conference given occasionally, does not suffice to instruct the minds in a sufficient degree to enable them to counteract all the errors and all the evils which are brought to the homes by the non-religious dailies or magazines.

In every Catholic school the children are taught to be obedient to all authority, civil as well as ecclesiastical, and to be reverent, and to love GOD above all things, to love his neighbor as himself, and to cultivate habits of virtue.

The Catholic Press, especially, brings to the homes these same teachings. It is therefore the duty of all Catholic people to patronize the Catholic Press, and to read it, in order that they may learn the truth of what is happening in the Kingdom of Christ, co-extensive with the world. It is certainly unpardonable to read, with avidity, every day happenings of a secular nature and to be indifferent about learning what is going on in the world of religion. In reading the daily press, Catholic news, whether international or local, are often unintentionally distorted by non-Catholic reporters who do not very often comprehend the things behind the news.

In conclusion, we might express the wish that in our paper, we want the whole-hearted co-operation of all those who are able to give to us. We want to make this little paper as interesting and as useful as possible to those for whom it is intended. Every field: educational, religious, medical, historical, and even scientific (such as agriculture or home economics), will be given attention. The news element will be taken mostly from happenings at the Boarding Schools, and in the Missions, because the daily press, and other means of information can bring other news much sooner than a monthly bulletin.

G. L., O.M.I.

Robert W. Ogle, resident of the Wood Mountain area, in a letter to the Leader-Post told of aged Indian folk sitting in cold cabins with no kerosene for lamps, no coal for heating and little wood—nearly percent of the cattle dead, 7 percent of the horses gone, he wrote.
