Indian Religion

We are all well aware of the great religiosity of the Indians of America. It was not the wealthy civilization of the Aztecs which amazed Cortez and the Spaniards in the XVI century when they came in conquests of Mexico. What struck everybody was the number of temples of the two hundred or more temples of the Montezuma's city, dominated by the pyramidal temple of the war-god, a the altar of white, up to the red steps, were offered each year, thousands of human victims as a sacrifice. The whole life of the nation, economic, social and military, had religion for a dominating factor.

In the XVII century, the first French missionaries reported carefully the beliefs, traditions and customs of the Indians of the prairie and of the forest. Their nomadic life did not allow them to build temples but certain details show that the old Indians were eminently religious. And that, in spite of many mistakes, their religion is an outstanding instance of what is called Tradition. As their language, the beautiful and intricate grammatical rules of which, are the astonishment of the white people, were kept from generation to generation without being written down so that traditions were the only source of knowledge enlightened with the purity of natural religion and moral law and the last glimpses of the primitive revelation, made by God to the first man.

At least 2000 years before Moses wrote down the laws of the Sacred Books, God gave to mankind a Revelation which was kept jealously by the Patriarchs. Yet, it is from that common treasure that all nations in the world drew the main lines of their religions. Moses, in his time, tells us that, with the exception of the Jews who had a special alliance with God, ignorance, greed, private interests, national pride and shameful passions had obscured the mind of the nations. The Revelation of God, Idolatry and immorality became the cancers of the religious, which, without the direct control of God as for the Jews, became what we call Paganism.

The particular case of the Indians displays the entire loss and the lamentable mistakes of mankind, lost in exile far away from the common Father of Heaven, sinful, yet longing for the lost Paradise in the long waiting for the Redeemer. Scattered over the world, differentiated in many races, under the variety of climates and ways of life, they remained bound by the same ideal and the same common belief. The white or the black, the red or the yellow, the savage with their common origin the same common religiosity. But, once more, among those who cling in the best to the first Revelation are the Indians who kept a great deal of it. God, our Maker, Abba, who wills to save and punish, the need of prayer, of penance, of sacrifice; the cult of the dead; the necessity of morality and many other truths became overburdened with superstitious rituals and bloody practices; how it lost the respect for human life and compromised itself with immorality. Yet, the young Indians should respect their old people, pagans of the old type, in order to learn from them what is right and what is wrong in their belief, and help them climb toward the light of God and find the true Faith. I respect the old pagan who is godless, but I pity the modern pagan who is godless. I have seen the light, tasted the Love of God, but who through immorality, laziness, selfishness, a shameful and sinful life, has lost the faith, believes no more or throws himself back to paganism and its horrors. The spiritually pagan is climbing the mountain toward the Light, the modern godless pagan is falling down, away from God, to animality.—Fr. Guy de Bretagne, O.M.I.

The Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask.

A thoroughly modern hospital for 60 patients was built at Fort-Qu'Appelle, Sask., two years ago, to replace the one at Lortie. Dr. A. B. Simes, M.D., is the medical superintendent of the hospital, and also for the Qu'Appelle health unit. Miss H. Gilbert is the matron.

The hospital has a fully equipped operating room, and an entire flat is reserved for T.B. patients. Much work has been done in the past years for the care of T.B. patients, and in a few years it is to be hoped that the disease will be practically stamped out on the Indian Reservations.

Patients are taken in the hospital from all parts of Saskatchewan. Dr. Wall, trained specialist, has been working in our unit lately, and has made a good survey of the case, and has taken efficacious measures in fighting the dreaded eye ailment.

Dr. Simes has shown great interest in our paper, and we will give him space every month in our column for an article on Tuberculosis, its prevention and its cure.—G.L., O.M.I.

ST. PHILIPS, Sask.

Thank you to the Editor of this little bulletin, we, the students of the St. Philips Indian Residential School, will have the privilege of informing the readers of our local activities.

For those who may not know St. Philips, let us first introduce it to them. St. Philips is one of the oldest missions of the Oblate Fathers; it is not a town, but has an Indian School, a church, a Post-Office and a few other houses; it is a beautiful spot on the slope of the Duck Mountain, 16 miles west of the Canadian boundary, 1 mile North of Kamiskak and 50 miles from Yorkton.

Long ago, before we were born, when this was a good hunting district, and the Indians, of course, were residing there, this place was known as Fort Polly. Father Decorby is said to be the first and only Oblate missionary to visit this region from 1878 until he took up residence in 1888; he built his first log house near the creek which flows into the Duck River, that is 15 miles West from where he erected, 15 years later, a bigger house with logs, using also some lumber which he hauled himself with horses from Yorkton, a distance of 20 miles. The first house was to be St. Philips First Boarding School where our Indian fathers and mothers took lessons from lay teachers as Mr. Barton, our Post-Master, and a little later, from the Sisters de la Croix and the Oblate Sisters. Our actual Sister Superior was one of them.

We are now in 1910. St. Philips is growing in population; many white settlers had helped the Indians to form a considerable parish; a new church was built and that completed Father Decorby's dream as founded the mission. He was growing old and sickness took him away to St. Boniface, where he died in 1913. We have no doubt that Father Decorby was one of the greatest missionaries of the west. During a life full of zeal and heroism, he had scoured this country so many times that he was known by every inhabitant 75 miles around. He had won the hearts of the Indians, and even the he met; old timers of other creeds still speak of him in praise.

The Boarding School was closed not long after he died and the Indian students were sent to the Lebret School; meanwhile, many Oblates came to take charge of the mission. In 1927, the Government built a new School for us and Father Brouillette was our Principal for the first 8 years. During his last two years, he was assisted by Father Wille, whose zeal and energy will be long remembered. On October 30, 1934, Father Paradis took his place as assistant and soon became Principal when a sudden death ended the harassed career of Father Brouillette on Feb. 3, 1935. Father Paradis has been our Principal in charge of the School and Missions for 8 months, until Fathers Poulet, Perreault and Bousquet were successively sent to take charge of the Parish and Missions.

With Father Paradis and Father Bousquet we have the actual staff of 2 Fathers, 9 Sisters, all co-operating in making us happy and learned in our school life under their spiritual and temporal care.

Being only 10 pupils, we live close together and a great family spirit reigns in the School. We also have the advantage of seeing our parents every Sunday. We will, in future issues, have more to say about our daily doings. The students of St. Philips School.

Kinebikons or Little Snake

CHAPTER I

In the year 1902, was born in the woods of Northern Ontario, near Rainy Lake, an Indian girl named Kinebikons, Little Snake. Her mother, a woman of the Odjibwe tribe, died when the child was two; her father departed for the happy hunting grounds three years later.

So the Indian girl was left an orphan; none to care for her but her mischievous looking grandmother called Tewegan—the Drum. This squaw was already seventy years of age, and the great sorceress of the place.

Both of them, the child and her guardian, lived in an old shack, built some twenty-five years ago, on an elevation in the centre of the Indian Reservation of Scandjicaming.

Thirty-five other families made up the entire population of this village. In recent years, many of the men had died. Tuberculosis and the abuse of intoxicating liquor were the two principal causes of their early deaths.

Some fifteen miles away from Scandjicaming, opposite the Indian School of Fort Frances, on the other side of the lake, was situated a small American town called Rainier. The Indians used to come here to sell their pelts, furs, fish, and berries, and in return received very often only fishworms for their pay. The mode of transportation of the Redmen, in those days, was very primitive and frail. They had only the weak birch bark canoe to travel in. One day a strong wind rose, when the storm suddenly rose on the lake and the Indian was driven into very dangerous. Whole families are known to have perished that way and are buried forever in the deep waters of Rainy Lake. Many others who escaped the fury of the waves were killed on the railroad track, running through the Couchiching reserve.

One winter afternoon, two Grey Nuns and the Missionary of the Fort Frances Indian Boarding School went out to visit the poor people of Scandjicaming. It was in the middle of January, the weather was very cold and a heavy blanket of snow covered the surface of Rainy Lake. Thirty-five cabins stood there in the open, looking far away over the great lakes; a thick bush of poplar trees protected the village from the north wind. December—January.

Preparation for Christmas.

At the beginning of Advent our teacher gave us each a little picture for our dear Savior who will come on Christmas in our little hearts. By praying we try to say every day "Oh Jesus I love You." This is to make a little better for the little Babe who is going to have His birthday on Christmas. We will be glad to come into our souls where a little helper will make Him very small there other nice things will be found. He will be comfortable in our hearts.

I hope everybody will have a clean and beautiful soul to receive our dear Little Jesus.

Little Breland VI.

December, the Month of Jesus.

To all know that December is the month of Jesus. We should try to offer Him many little sacrifices. On the first day of Advent our teacher gave us each a picture to offer to Little Jesus. I have to abstain from eating until Christmas. It is quite hard for me.

We are all working together to make a nice warm place in our hearts for Jesus. We are all anxious for Christmas not only because we are going to have presents but to receive Jesus. He will be very glad to find that we have prepared for Him a nice resting place.

Fred Breland VI.
Parish Bazaar.

The Bazaar was at the Parish Hall on December 6-5, to help the Church.

Sunday was for the people and Monday for the children of the Convent and of the Public School.

Right after class, we got ready to go to the hall. There were all kinds of beautiful things and nice decorations. We each had our own money, some had over a dollar, from exhibition works of last year. Our kind Sister Superior gave some money to those who did not have any.

I went with all my friends to play the Horse Name Race. There were two different games of Horse Races; one was Horse Name Race and the other Horse Number Race. I took Seabiscuit and I won six pennies. Reverend Fathers Bidault and Crépeau and Mr. Ouellette called out the two games.

Then at the Bingo stand I played four times but got nothing. We next went to the Fishing Pond and fished four times and had a bag of peanuts, a box of popcorn, a game and a horn. Some who were with me were lucky and had some nice things.

We came to a table where there were beautiful articles to raffle. I took a chance and some others too. Then I bought a set of comb, looking glass and a finger file for fifteen cents.

At 5 o'clock we came back for our supper. At 7-30 there was an entertainment given but we did not go. A large attendance was expected.

Louise Ward VII
The Immaculate Conception.

The feast of the Immaculate Conception of our Blessed Mother is celebrated on December 8. It is the greatest feast of the Blessed Virgin Mary.

Do you know when this feast became better known? It was a little girl by the name of Bernadette to whom the Blessed Virgin appeared eighteen times, that made it known. Bernadette told the world about that but he didn't believe her. One of the Fathers told her to ask that lady what her name was. Bernadette asked her. The Blessed Virgin said: "I am the Immaculate Conception."

On Columbus' second voyage to America, he took along a priest. When they reached a certain place in the West Indies, in 1493, on December 8, he there said the first mass on American soil.

The Immaculate Conception is the patronal feast of America.

Henry Calder VII.

The Employees' Gift.

On the 200th anniversary of the foundation of the Order of Grey Nuns, the employees of the convent presented to Sister Superior flowers for the decoration of the altars. Unhappily they arrived too late to be used on their day.

On the feast of the Immaculate Conception, Reverend Sister Superior had the altars beautifully decorated with them. White, mauve and pink are the colors of these.

Clara House, VII.
Congratulations.

I wish to congratulate Blue Quills and Cluny Schools for using their own mother tongue in several articles of their school magazine. This shows that they are proud of writing and reading their own language. We are sorry that we cannot do the same. We can talk it, but our parents read and write in their own language.

I think that every nation should keep to the mother tongue and be proud of it.

Emilienne Kootenay, VII.

Among Us Again.

Reverend Father Simard returned from the eastern part of Canada last Wednesday night. We were all glad to see him again.

He was preaching retreats in different churches. We prayed for him every day so that he would be successful in his preachings. He said he prayed for us too every day.

He was surprised to find changes in the classrooms.

Emilien Paul, VII.
The New Barn.

Our new barn was built by the hired men. They broke down the other barn because it was too old. We all worked at it. We were glad when it was taken down as it gave a bigger playground to the small boys.

It is about a hundred yards away from the other one. It is divided into three sections. One is for the little calves, the other for the bigger calves, and the middle part for the cows.

It is very pretty, as you see by the picture. It is painted red and yellow. Now we have a fine shelter for all the cows.

Henry Calder, VII.
Among Us Again.

Reverend Father Simard returned from the eastern part of Canada last Wednesday night. We were all glad to see him again. He was preaching retreats in different churches. We prayed for him every day so that he would be successful in his preachings. He said he prayed for us too every day. He was surprised to find changes in the classrooms.

Emilion Paul, VII.

Our Skating Rink.

We started skating in December 5. Our skating rink is fine. We have it in a new place this year. It is beside the summer house and last year it was beside the barn. We worked at it very hard because winter was here and we could not skate. When it is cold at night we flood it again as to put another coat of ice on it and to fill up the cracks. We are glad now that it is finished and every now and then when we have some spare time we go and skate. All the big boys have their own skates. We hope to have a hockey game with the Public School boys.

Walter Salliho, VII.
Painting Our Classes.

Our classes are being painted. Our good Sister Superior had the men do this just to please us. We were making our retreat during that time. They took three days to finish the classes and those were the three days of our retreat. The classes are beautiful now and we wish to keep them that way all the time. The walls are painted pale yellow and the ceiling white. The hall too is painted white and yellow but most of it is white.

I hope you will come and see our school some day. We like it better than before because it makes us happy and gay when we look at it. We thank dear Sister Superior for this great favor.

Bessie Lefthand, VII.

Christmas Decorations.

A few days before Christmas, we clean all the rooms and classes, then we decorate them. Just to look at the pretty decorations makes you happy. The music hall should be the most pretty because on Christmas all the children go there to get their presents.

The parents are there to encourage their children, and at the same time they see what they have done in the rooms or in the classes.

Hector Callihoo, VI.
An Agreeable Surprise.

On December 19, all of Grade VII pupils were in school at work, when a knock was heard at the door; then in stepped Mr. Laight with a cordial morning greeting. We too greeted him as nicely as we could. Sister presented him a chair, then he spoke to us. He asked us if we were in good health, and a few other questions.

What pleased us most was when our teacher offered him our class magazine. He seemed delighted and he asked Sister to put him on her list and not fail to send him our "Enchanted Hill Echoes." We were very happy to see our Agent and we hope to see him more often.

He left us with his best wishes for a "Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year." We wished him the same.

Emilienne Kootenay VII.

Reverend Father Lessard's Remarks.

We have to agree with Reverend Father Lessard's remarks to parents in the Okanagan, that most of the children lose in weight during vacations.

The same has been noticed here, but since September all gained, and most of them from five to thirteen pounds. This is a proof that school is the best place for good health.

We hope that all will keep the proper weight so as to be in good condition when we get older.

George Stamp, VII.
Decorators.

On Thursday afternoon, the Sister in charge of the Reception Hall asked for two girls to decorate the Christmas Tree. Louise Ward and I were chosen.

How privileged we felt to prepare the Christmas Tree. We had bells, silver, red, green and blue ornaments purposely for decorating trees, also cotton and silver tinsel to imitate snow and icicles. We were trying to see who would do best, but it was hard to tell, for the tree was pretty and shiny all over.

Boys also can be fine decorators, for our class is very pretty indeed, and George Stamp decorated it with our Teacher.

Emilienne Kootenay VII.

Public School Concert.

On December 23, we were invited to a concert at the parish hall, given by the Public School Children.

We were certainly pleased to be invited. We liked to see other school children act. We went at about two o'clock and it lasted two hours. We enjoyed every part of it but the last was the best because it was in English and a comedy.

Emilienne K. Walter C. VII.
Midnight Mass.

On Christmas Eve, we all went to bed early, because we had to be up for the Midnight Mass.

When our Sister called us, we hurried to dress. We entered the chapel in procession, along the middle aisle singing a Christmas hymn. All went to the Crib to greet the Sweet Babe, then filed to their seats.

We assisted at two masses only, and we sang during both.

Many of our parents were present and received holy communion.

Reverend Father Simard gave a sermon after the first mass.

After the second mass, we all went to the dormitory, and five big girls went down to the kitchen for some lunch. After lunch we all went to bed and slept until seven o'clock.

Clara House, VII.

Christmas Tree.

Although Christmas Day was cold, many parents came to see their children. They attended the Midnight Mass and received holy communion.

In the afternoon, at two o'clock was the Christmas Tree. The Reverend Fathers and the Brothers of the parish attended.

A dust was played, followed by a little play in which the Old Year dressed in purple bid farewell and the New Year dressed in white greeted a little girl. The old Year
held a scroll in his hand which contained
the good and the bad deeds done by the
little girl. The New Year came in quickly
with another scroll ready to take in the
little girl's deeds. A very fine lesson
was found for us all in this little play.

The Christmas presents were distributed
by Mons Cardinal, Bessie Lefthand, Emilienne
Kootenay and myself, but were presented by
the Fathers and dear Sister Superior.

To close, we sang a lovely Christmas song.

Louise Ward, VII.

Our Parents Visit the Convent.

The parents were asked if they would
like to visit the house on Christmas after-
noon. Four Sisters took them around.
They were very much pleased with the
playroom and the sleeping rooms. They were
glad that their children had such nice
comfortable beds.

The Sisters took them to the sewing room;
here they saw many pieces of sewing done by
the girls. The parents said the girls sewed
well.

They were especially glad to visit the
classrooms. Many of them said that they were
in this school, and were sorry they had to
leave it.

Alphonse Paul VII J.
An Appreciated Invitation.

At first, I thought there would be no fun after Christmas, but we boys were all surprised when the girls told us they were going to invite us to a party. I tell you, we were all very anxious for it to come.

That evening, at about seven o'clock, Sister came into the room where we were playing. She said, "Why don't the boys go to the party?" We told her that we were waiting for her to tell us to go. Sister told us to dress quickly not to be late. We tried to look the best we could. At last, we were all ready to go to the party, given in the big girl's room.

Michel Arcand started to play mouth organ and a number of boys and girls jigged. We then played Bingo. Fifty played at one time. Many won prizes. One of the Sisters won a prize but she was kind enough to give it back and this allowed us to play another turn.

We enjoyed the party very much, and we hope the girls will be kind enough to invite us to another soon.

Patrick Thomas VI.

We Entertain Our Friends.

During the Christmas Holidays, Sister Houle said that we should make a party and invite all the children to our room. This took place on Tuesday evening, December 27. We were well prepared for it.

When we heard the children coming we all stood up to greet them. Some Sisters came too,
and Reverend Sister Superior among them.

Our room was full; we hardly had space enough to carry on the different games planned.

The first thing on the program was a jig by a number of boys and girls. After this we played Beano, which is the same as Bingo, seated in groups of four. Various prizes were given to the winners.

Some girls served refreshments. All the children felt happy because we gave them a splendid evening.

Emilienne Kootenay VII S.

New Year's Day.

-----------

Early in the morning we wished each other a Happy New Year, then went to mass in our own chapel.

About 9 o'clock we had the pleasure of wishing the Sisters a Happy New Year. When we came down to our room, we had a surprise. The little boys were there to wish us a Happy New Year, and then we followed them to the girls' room to give them our best wishes for the year.

This over, we went to church to assist at high mass; during this mass we prayed for our parents and those interested in our welfare.

After dinner, we all went skating until supper time. The evening was also spent very joyously.

Emilien Paul VII S.

With every good wishes to you

HAPPY NEW YEAR
Sweets from Father Bidault.

On January 2, all the children went to the Music Hall to meet Reverend Father Bidault. When we were all placed on the stage, Father came in and we sang a New Year song for him. After the song, Father gave us each a big bag of candy. Three little girls then spoke a piece to thank him. We are all very grateful for his kindness.

Hector Callihoo VI.

Among Us Again.

Doris Cardinal did not come back in September because she was allowed to stay home to care for her mother who was very sick. On December 19, Mr. Laight came to visit us and he told us that Doris's mother had died. We felt very sorry for her. We did not forget to pray for both.

Thursday afternoon, December 23, our friend Doris was once more among us. We all tried our best to encourage her by being kind to her. God will accept our prayer for her mother for she was a very faithful and holy woman.

Emilienne, Clara, Louise VII S.
We Shall Remember.

His Excellency Archbishop MacDonald was so very kind as to take some of his precious time to write a long letter to us. He wrote in his own hand-writing that he likes our little class magazine very much.

WE SHALL REMEMBER the good advice that he gives us, with regard to our pastors and parents, and we will try to be his consolation now, and more so after we have left school.

Walter Callihoo VII.

A Fine Projector.

Reverend Father Simard, who is chaplain of our school, gave us a lesson with his new projector. Father must have thought of us a great deal while he was in the East, since he bought for us that fine machine.

He gave us a lesson the night before King's Day. He showed us some pictures of our Lord's life, and of martyrs how they were persecuted long ago. He explained what he thought we could not quite understand.

We all enjoyed our evening very much. We hope that Father will come again with his projector. We all pray for him in return.

Henry Calder VII J.
A Highly Valued Message.

In answer to our New Year letter, Reverend and dear Mother General sent us a lovely message in which she expressed her wishes for a very happy New Year to our beloved parents and to each one of us.

We shall never forget her advice and we shall be very obedient to our teachers as she requested it in her dear letter.

How much honored we felt on receiving this loving message from Reverend Mother General.

Emilienne Kootenay VII.

The Girls' Concert.

On Friday, Kings Day, the girls gave a concert. It was to give pleasure to the pupils of the school. We were all very much pleased to attend the entertainment.

The following were seen: A Fan Drill by the big girls and a Doll Drill by the small girls. Both were very pretty. Mouth organ was played by two girls accompanied on the piano by our music teacher. The best one was "The Precious Pickles." This playlet was very well done.

It will be our turn some day to give a concert. I hope that we will do just as well as the girls did theirs.

Henry Calder, VII J.
Youville Indian Residential School
St. Albert, Alberta
January 9, 1856.

Miss Agnes Sutherland,
Fort Chipewyan,
Alberta.

Dear Friend,

We were very much pleased with your letter telling us that you enjoyed reading our journal. We shall gladly send it to you every two months.

We also had fine weather here until Christmas, but the week after was very cold. The thermometer went down so below zero say.

All the boys wish there were caribou over here too. What a swell time they would have hunting them! And the girls would enjoy a good earlick steak!

We only wish we could visit your classrooms to see the beautiful decorations you have made for Christmas.

We enjoyed our holidays. We had a party in the girls' ward. We played Bingo and other games. On King's Day the girls, large and small, gave a concert partly prepared by themselves as an agreeable pastime for all the convent people.

The boys will give theirs at the beginning of next month. All the Chipewyan children are invited, and do not forget to bring with you your kind Sister Superior, our Teacher's sister.

We hope to hear from you again, and whenever you can send your class magazine, we shall read it with great pleasure.

Your sincere friend,
George Stapp VII S.
The Old Timers.

The Old Timers were here again on the 8th of January. We were glad to meet them again and they too were glad to come on such a fine weather as we had that day.

When the Old Timers came all the children went to the hall and they gave us apples, oranges and candies. When we had our sweets, we were not going to let the kind Old Timers go without thanking them and showing them that they made us happy, so we gave them a little concert.

Our program began with a welcome song. A song "The General's Fast Asleep" was next, after that, "Drill, Dumb-bells," then a "Doll Drill" followed by the Old Timers Song. Next came the Pan Drill by the large girls, and lastly, "The Old Year's Lesson."

The Old Timers seemed well pleased. They made speeches which we were glad to hear. Some gave us good advice.

After all the speeches, everybody, with a happy heart, sang God Save the King.

Jane Belcourt VI.

Taking Pictures.

Reverend Father Philippot came here to take our pictures on January 7. We were all glad to have them taken.

Father took those of all the children together, then the children of each reserve separately. After dinner he took the picture of the boys of the League of the Sacred Heart, then the altar boys in surplices.
He took our pictures because he might illustrate with them one of his books, for he is a writer.

Henry Calder VII J.

A Trip to Australia.

................

There will be an Easter Show held in Australia, by the Royal New South Wales Agricultural Society, in Sidney.

There will be eight Indian boys sent to represent our tribes. Among these will be two Stonies from Alberta, Douglas Kootenay and Johnny LeftHand.

They will leave in February. They will be surprised when they get there, because it will be summer time. They will land at Port Sidney, and there they will show what they can do as cowboys and also as dancers. They will be accompanied by a Canadian Royal Mounted Police.

Alphonse Paul VII J.

The Church Unity Octave.

......................

These eight days of prayer for the Church unity was established in the United States. It was begun in a Convent, then spread in several dioceses, then finally all dioceses of the States adopted it. Pope Benedict XV established it all over the world.

During these eight days, starting January 18, here, in the convent, we have Benediction of
the Blessed Sacrament at 4 o'clock and
the prayer for the intention of each day,
so that those who are not followers of
the true Church, such as Anglicans, Calvinists,
Lutherans and so on, may come back to the
true Fold, the Church of God. And as to those
who have not heard the word of God yet, that
some missionaries might be sent to them.

Louise Ward VII S.

A Great Honor.

Our Holy Father, the Pope sent the
"Bene Merenti" medal to Reverend Mother
Gallant, on the two hundredth anniversary
of her Order.

His Eminence, Cardinal Antoniutti the
Pope's Legate, presented it to Mother General
and told her that it was sent in recognition
of the many good works done by the Order of
the Grey Nuns.

We rejoice that such an honor was
bestowed on the teachers under whose care we
are.

Clara House. VII S.

Movies.

Reverend Father Bidault was good enough
to invite us to a picture show last Monday
night in the music room of our school.
This show was very funny. It made all the
children happy because they like to see pictures.
of that kind. They were about Mickey Mouse, a man in a cart, and custard pies. How we laugh to see Mickey Mouse running here and there with pies between his fore-paws!

We enjoyed the picture show, and we thank Father for his kindness.

Bessie Lefthand VII J.

-------------------------------

An Exciting Hockey Game.

------------------------

Last Sunday afternoon, we had a hockey game with the boys of the Public School.

Early a great number of boys were waiting at the rink to see the game. Our Captain was Henry Calder and our goalie Michael Kootenay, the best goalie around. We were sorry that two of our best players were sick.

We started off half past two. In the first period we won six to zero, and in the second we scored 4. We were supposed to play up to fifteen goals but the outsiders gave up.

They said they were coming again next Sunday. We hope to beat them once more.

We were very sorry for not inviting our Chaplain for this game, but we will next time.

George Stamp, Walter Callihoo
VII S.
Our Blessed Mother must be pleased to see so many names on the Honor Roll during the month of her HOLY ROSARY.
October 1938

Our Guardian Angel.

Everybody knows that when God first made the heavens, he created the Angels. God was so good that he created man too, and put an angel by each one to protect him. He also placed one over every village, city and country to watch over it.

Our Angels serve, adore and respect God and help us to do so ourselves. They are so good that they will never leave us till the judgment day... We should think sometimes to say, "Thank You," to our dear Angels.

We should try to do our best so that when we die, we may be happy with him in heaven for all eternity.

Jean Belcourt VI.

Visitors from far off Australia.

Last week, we had visitors from two Universities of Australia, one was from Melbourne and the other from Sidney... Reverend Brother Memoriam brought them here for a visit on Wednesday October 2... They said, they were very glad to come here... With them came three professors from the university of Alberta. The pupils of Grades 2, 3 and 4 sang in Cree for them. They were very glad to listen to it. People from far off like to hear other languages.

Jean Belcourt VI.
The First Snowstorm.

We were very glad to see the snow-flakes twinkling down from the sky last week.

That day, the snow was soft. It was good to make balls. We had fun in snowball fighting, but the snow thawed that first day.... We had another fall and we hope it will stay until spring.

We are starting to make bob-sleighs to slide down the hill. We have five ready.

We all enjoy sliding for it gives us fine exercise and plenty of fresh air... Thus we hope that this will give us the best of health and success in our school work.

George Walter Emilian VII S.

Our Last Picnic.

After picking potatoes for two days, we were given a picnic... After our breakfast we hurried with our work and prepared our lunch. Then we made each a sling shot for hunting rabbits and ducks.

We started off before ten... We reached the steep hill near the tracks and we played until we heard Master's car tooting the car horn for dinner... After taking a good meal, we decided to walk to the big lake where we saw men shooting ducks and when we got back, we were just in time for supper.

We played until half past seven, then returned and went to bed for good times have to come to an end.

George Stamp VII S.
In the Potato Field.

...........

We picked potatoes this year on October 6 and 7. We all put on old dresses and stockings, sweaters and old soldier caps. I like picking potatoes. We were at it two days only when we expected to take three days.

On Thursday we picked fifty rows and Friday sixty-one rows and that meant 1600 sacks.

We had our lunch on the field and we liked it. We surely enjoyed eating for we were hungry although we ate raw potatoes while we were picking.

The Sisters came and they seemed to enjoy looking at the children at work because there were so many in the field.

I was holding the bags with Emilienne Kootenay and we enjoyed it as much as those who pitched.

Our Good Sister Superior gave us a fine picnic because we did the work well.

Bessie Lefthand VII J.
The Flour Mill on Fire.

On Friday night about 12 o'clock, I awoke and saw a red light coming into our bedroom. I got up to see what was the matter and saw the flour mill on fire.

I saw the firemen trying to stop it. It was terrible to hear the roaring of flames. I went back to bed and as soon as I got up I went to look; it was still burning, and is burning yet after five days.

Everybody was speaking of it the next morning, and in the afternoon some of the Sisters and the children went to see it. We could see the grain, flour sacks and all that was in it. There were men helping to take the grain out.

It started by the elevator... On Friday morning the miller could smell something burning but did not find fire. During the night it burst out. Nobody was hurt, but it is a big loss.

Adeline Leblanc VII J.

Thanksgiving Day.

Children, would you be glad to hear of the Pilgrim Fathers who gave wealth, health, happiness and friends for a place where they could praise God the way they liked.
They landed on the New England shore where the peaceful village of Plymouth now lies in 1620.

There they built their cabins where the Red Men lived... even the bravest of them could feel his blood running cold for fear these Indians would burn their homes. Before spring many of the band died of sickness, cold and hunger.

When harvest time came, the next year, the patient mothers smiled as they thanked God for the good crops. Governor Bradford, like a good man, to praise and thank God, ordered a day be set apart, which he called Thanksgiving Day.

Our Three Days' Retreat.

We had a retreat of three days. It started on Tuesday October 23.

The preacher was Reverend Father Gagnon. How we gladly greeted him for we knew him before as he preached a retreat to us last year.

We had Mass at 7 o'clock, Rosary at 9 and 1:30 sermons at 10, 4:30 and 7; Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament... The three days were this order until Friday - retreat ended with the mass.

On Friday morning, Father blessed our religious articles, such as medals, holy pictures, beads etc.

All the sermons he gave us were very beautiful and interesting. Even the smallest who were in the chapel did not sleep because they were listening with their two ears wide open.

We and the Cluny children were very fortunate to have such an extra preacher and a retreat in which numberless graces and favors were given to us through the kind Heart of Jesus. This retreat has been a success we hope.

In a special manner we thank Father Gagnon for having done such good to our souls.

Our Visit to the Cemetery.

The Parishioners, Convent Children, Sisters and Priests went to the graveyard at 3 o'clock on October 9.

Reverend Father Naessens blessed the graves and then the choir sang the "Libera." After the hymn, Reverend Father Crepeau gave a sermon, first in French, then in English.

When he spoke English, he said that the souls of our friends or parents that are in the grave are, we hope enjoying happiness in heaven, but he also said that there might be some calling for your prayers and help being yet in purgatory. THE BLAZON
OF THE GREY NUNS.
Two Hundredth Anniversary.

The year 1938 marks the 200th anniversary of the foundation of the Grey Nuns by Mother d'Youville. Adam Youville started this order with three companions in Montreal in 1735. Now there are five branches numbering about 5000 Sisters.

In Montreal, on September 27, this Feast was celebrated at the Lother House. There was a banquet at which three hundred of the poorest people of Montreal took part. The Archbishop presided the banquet. After this, gifts of clothing were distributed to them.

There are Grey Nuns now spread all over from the Southern States to Alaska, north of the Arctic Circle.

There was here, in St. Albert, after high mass on Sunday, "Te Deum" sung in thanksgiving for the graces and benefits that God has showered on the Grey Nuns.

On Friday, November 12, there will be a mass of Requiem for the deceased benefactors of the Grey Nuns. All the parishioners are invited.

In remembrance of these two centuries of foundation we had here a celebration for the employees of the convent. There was a mass for them, after which a banquet followed, presided by Reverend Father Bidault and Reverend Father Philippot was there also. They had their day off.

We will have some other celebrations yet... These will be announced later.

Emilienne Kootenay VII S.
The Employees' Day.

A celebration was organized on November 3, for all the employees of the Convent, on the two-hundredth anniversary of the foundation of the Order of the Grey Nuns, our teachers.

First there was a mass said at 9 o'clock during which all the men received holy communion. All the children and Sisters assisted at the mass.

After the mass, they were led to St. Mary's room which was made into a banquet room. It was beautifully decorated with yellow and white crepe paper. The lights were painted red to give a pleasing effect. The statue of Mother d'Youville was placed near the side wall, facing the tables, and decorated with flowers of lovely colors. The tables covered with nice table cloths, lovely dishes, and platters of delicious fruits looked very pretty.

Reverend Father Bidault presided and Reverend Father Philippot was there too.

The employees each had a picture of Mother d'Youville as a souvenir and were given a day off.

Emilienne, Clara H., Louise W., VII S.

Reverend Father Bidault's Return.

Father Bidault was absent from September 4, to October 27.

When he came back, he told us that he was on the train for three days and three nights to reach Montreal, and from Montreal to Cherbourg, he took five days and five nights in an immense boat.
When he got off at Cherbourg, an officer asked him what his name was and he handed him a telegram saying that the good Father Grandin who was going to feast his diamond jubilee was about to leave this world. As soon as he heard that he took a taxi to go to the place where he was, and when he got there it was after midnight.

He just had time to talk to him and show him the Spiritual Bouquet that the Grey Nuns in Montreal made for him, but containing our prayers. That saintly Father died the next morning. Reverend Father Bidault was at his funeral and he said all the people of that city were sorry because he was a good priest.

Reverend Father Bidault went to the church of St. Teresa de Lisieux and stayed there for three days. Then he went to Lourdes and again he stayed there and prayed for three days. He said there were about a thousand people praying every day at Lourdes. He bought there some medals and had them touch the rock where our Blessed Lady appeared to St. Bernadette and he brought those to us and told us to keep them as a souvenir of him. This we shall do.

Bessie Lefthand VII J.

A Hallowe'en Joke.

Dick, Jim and Bill were planning Hallowe'en jokes on their neighbors, especially those that were cranky and old.

They decided that they would take off Johnson's gate and put it on the roof of his barn; take the tires off Scot's car and smear
Mrs. Jones bakery window with flour.

Bill's sister Kathleen was writing at her desk in the living room. She heard the plotters plans and she came out to them and said: "Listen boys, try to think of other jokes that nobody ever thought of or did. Why not put up a basket for Mrs. Quinn. She is a poor widow with four children."

The boys eagerly listened to her plan for she was a favorite with them, as she often gave them hot gingerbread and homemade candies. Kathleen added: "We can put a bag of flour, potatoes and some jars of jam, vegetables and a pumpkin to show the Hallowe'en joke."

Dick said: "I'll ask mother for a pumpkin, I am sure she will give me one if I tell her why I want it." Kathleen said: "Mrs. Jones will give me a bag of flour if I ask her for it." Bill added: "Mother will give me some strawberry jam if I ask for some." We have some potatoes, I am sure I can have some," said Jim. Mr. Johnson and Mr. Scott will do their part if I ask them. Said Kathleen. They are not so odd as they seem to be."

The boys were glad that Kathleen spoke for them, and this was the best Hallowe'en that they ever had.

Emilienne Kootenay VII S.

Remembrance Day.

Remembrance Day is celebrated on November
11. The World War ended at that date in 1918,
and since then Canada has been at peace,
therefore has been so for twenty years.
The people in Canada were so glad when
war ended that they made great celebrations
everywhere by putting up parades etc.
But right now there is a war between
China and Japan... There was to be a war in
Europe last month but matters were arranged.
Let us hope there will not be one there,
and we hope there will never be one here, in
Canada.

An Enjoyable Evening.

The evening I enjoyed most was last night at our playroom. We played games that Sister Deslauriers taught us. We enjoyed them very much.

Sister comes to our play room every Sunday night. We played a new game last night. Sister have a paper made like a big cake with a string for each of us coming out of it... Reverend Sister Superior's Feast.

Reverend Sister Superior's feast day which comes on November 17 was postponed to November 23. Every year we feast our kind Sister Superior.

An entertainment was given by the children of our school in her honor. It opened with a piano duet followed by a festal song. Then an address was nicely given by one of the big boys of St. Joseph's Ward, George Stamp. The offering of the Spiritual Bouquet was done by the smallest boy here, Eddie Benoit.... The concert followed.

The most interesting number to me, was "Tekakwitha or the Lily of the Mohawks," a drama in two acts and 15 scenes.

A few people who had received an invitation and Sisters from Edmonton assisted at our entertainment.... The reception hall was full.

This must have pleased dear Sister Superior to see so many come to show her how grateful they are towards her.

How happy Reverend Sister Superior felt on hearing all that took place that night, and we too were happy to show our gratitude towards her, for all she does for us.

A Joyful Holiday.

It was on November 24. We had that holiday because it was Sister Superior's feast, and we had a grand time.

You should have been here just to see our breakfast and our dinner... It made us hungry just to see all the good things we had.

After dinner, at about half past two, we went sliding down the hill, and we played there all afternoon until supper time.

On our return, Sister Superior gave us a treat - Chocolate Bars.

After our supper we went outside to play Hide-and-Seek till dark. All the boys then went to bed.

The next day we worked hard in school and did satisfactory work.

St. Albert

St. Albert is the Patron Saint of the parish... This parish was so called because when Bishop Taché came with Father Lacombe, he said he would call it St. Albert in honour of Father Lacombe's patron saint.

We celebrate his feast on November 21. St. Albert lived in Louvain. He was very good and many people loved him.... They did not have a bishop so the Pope named him Bishop of Louvain.... But the Emperor of Germany did not like it because he did not ask him if he wanted Albert so he sent one of his choice to the seat and sent Albert away.

Albert went to Rome where he saw the Pope and told him all about this. The Pope had him consecrated Bishop.

When the Emperor heard that he became very angry and wanted to put him to death. So, one day he sent seven men to his house. He received them well and they ate at his table for sixty-six days.... Then the Bishop left on a pilgrimage to the tomb of St. Remi. When he passed through the forest, he saw those seven men and they took their spears and gave him thirteen mortal wounds.

Edith Callihoo VI.
Arbitration Day.

On November 11, we had a pleasant surprise. Sister told us we were going to Frenchman's Butte for a celebration held there.

We were three girls to go - Marie Louise Chacon, Josie Harris and I.

We rehearsed the songs the day before.

We started out at about nine o'clock and got there a little before eleven.

Two of us girls were sick on the way, it seemed such a long time before we reached the place.

A crowd of people had already gathered for the celebration which began as soon as we were ready.

Father Principal gave a short speech on the Fallen Soldiers of the Great World War, etc.

When all was over we went to the home of Mr. and Mrs. Clark for dinner. We left there about three o'clock. We went to the store, Father bought some souvenirs and other things to take home with us.

We enjoyed our trip very much indeed. Now we are trying to do our very best because we might have other chances again.

Three cheers for Father Principal who does so much to please us in everything.

Another Visit from Santa Claus.

This year Santa Claus came to see us two times. He came on Christmas Day as usual, for we knew he was likely five miles from the station and as the roads were very bad, he could not reach our school on Christmas Eve as he does in most other places.

On Jan. second, a few minutes after supper, Sister came into our recreation room. She seemed to be in a great hurry and told us to take our own places for we were sure to have a visitor.

In a jiffy we were ready, overall taken off and we put on our red sweaters. A few of the boys here have new shoes, pants, mitts or rubber boots.

Then as Slater opened the door, I heard the authors coming down the stairs. They were talking to someone who said, he had been driven back by the snowstorms, that his airplane could not go any further, he also said that he wished to see the boys of this school once more, around the next morning if the storm stopped.

So our great surprise. Father Principal walked in with Santa Claus accompanied by two other strangers whom we didn't know. They carried big bags. Santa Claus didn't talk very much, he seemed to have a cold, because he made many stops and talked very softly. I don't know what language the other two spoke, but they make signs too and shook hands very long with the boys when they gave us some things.

The Little Boys' Hockey Game.

One afternoon the little boys had a hockey game on our rink. They took their hockey sticks, skates, and went down the hill to the lake. We big boys didn't skate but watched the little ones playing. They even used our puck, it was a little too heavy for them to shoot. It was funny to look at them, some could barely stand on their skates. When the whistle blew for them to get ready, they all went to their places. Sure as soon as they touched the puck fell down. One of the goalies seeing the puck flying to him, seemed to close his eyes and wave his hand to catch the puck, but missed it. He cheered and laughed and the little fellow began to cry so another goalie replaced him.

One of the defense men was a little fellow who didn't seem to care about catching the puck, was just standing there looking at his skaters, when somebody got the puck and hit him on the leg. This woke him up and he started the chase. The score at the end was three to two.

During Advent, we were preparing for the coming of Jesus in our hearts by doing our best at every thing at this time. We made our little sacrifices by Sister Harris. Every day we had five minutes to write them down.

Sister also helped us by putting up a list of different kinds of sacrifices for each day. In our recreation room, sometimes at night, at prayer time, she would remind us of what we had to do, and would even help us to make some.

Visitors at our card party.

Now I Missed my School days.

Dear readers, I would like to tell you how and why I missed many of my school days and I am very sorry I was forced to do so on account of an operation I had last summer.

During vacation my sister and I went to Elk Point with my mother to see the doctor. We went by train, and as soon as we got there we went to his house, he examined both of us, here, he all went to the hospital where we had an operation. I was put to sleep, and I didn't feel anything; but my sister could not be put to sleep, so she didn't have so much trouble as I did afterwards.

We stayed in the hospital for ten days, then went back home. We were very glad to be back home now.

Starting Time.

We enjoyed our holidays very much, especially when we would play cards at night.

The boys had a real what party on Friday night, Jan. the sixth. We were going to have one too, but as we wanted to have the Sisters come, we postponed it until later. We felt rather jealous of the boys' party.

Our turn came quicker than we expected, for two days later, on Sunday night, we decided to have one in honor of Miss Laliberte, whose birthday we were celebrating.

The tiny little girls of the baby class presented her a tray filled with nice how pictures, and a little manger with a little Infant Jesus about one and one half inches long.

All the Sisters, Father, Brothers came. We were very sorry our dear Father Principal was away, for I am sure he would have enjoyed it.

We thank the kind Sisters for having devoted so much of their time in making our holidays such pleasant ones.

Edna Carlson,
Grade 8.

Aids for Better Conduct.

This year again we have a crib which our teacher had prepared.

It is in the right front corner of our classroom; it is very pretty and the little Infant Jesus seems to be very much at home. He seems to invite us to be more pious, obedient, humble etc., although we wish to have all those virtues, our success is not always very bright, but we have the pleasure of having tried. We pray Him to make us better.

Joanne Paddy & Victoria Chocon,
Grade 4.
OUR NEW INSPECTOR.

Usually they say that the thirteenth is an unlucky day, but the thirteenth of December was not unlucky this year, for on that day we met our new school inspector for the first time. We used to have Mr. Wilson for our inspector, and we liked him very much. When he went away, Mr. Gilles came. He was so kind and pleasant that we were very sorry when we heard that he was going to Peace River or that we could have a new Inspector again. But Mr. Stehelin made us kind of shy and nervous. He gave us many tests to see how Indian and Half-Breed children compare with white children. He stayed in our room all afternoon, then the next day he visited the other classes, but after school he came into our room again before we were dismissed, so Sister had us sing and play our Rhythm Band. Mr. Stehelin said he had heard many Rhythm Bands, but ours was as good as any of those he had heard in big places. He was so nice at this last visit that we were sorry when it was time for us to go. The next time he comes, maybe we won't feel so shy with him.

George Fraser-Victor Twin. Gr.6.

A GRAND CHRISTMAS SEASON.

How glad we are when it is time to start decorating for Christmas! We love the smell of the Christmas trees. This year our class looked nicer than ever, because we seemed to know how to decorate better and Sister had received some nice things from Sister Noreen from Vancouver which made our walls look so nice. The last two days before the holidays began, the pupils would bring a gift and put it under the tree near Sister's desk.

Then at last we had the Gift Exchange. Each year, we put our names on a little slip of paper and put them in a box. Next, each pupil draws a name, and the name he gets is the one he must get a present for. Sometimes, it is very funny for we like to play tricks on one another. This year, everyone was jealous when two of the boys got parcels from the kitchen girl because Sr. M. Adelia had let the girls make each a nice little cake, all covered with icing, and some candy, for their parcel. Almost all of us had something nice... and we were all so gay when we went home, after saying Merry Christmas to our teacher.

Edna Prudon.... Grade VII.
The Concert.

The day before the concert, we had the general exercise. For the opening song, Sister wanted to place the biggest pupils right on the stage. When about fifteen of the girls were placed, the stage caved right in. There was a big scream from everybody, because we thought it was an earthquake or something, but when we saw that it was not dangerous, we all started to laugh. It was so funny to see them, especially Sr. M. Thistle, who was with them. They looked so scared. So we had to go through our pieces without the stage that day, but the men came and fixed it up right away.

Margaret Auger - Grade VI.

On December twenty-third, we had our big concert. Many people came from Emils, High Prairie and other places. The number I enjoyed the most was the Boys' Drill. They marched all together like real soldiers, then Norman Phillips who was dressed like an aviator, came and sang the solo of the boys' song. Everybody cheered, for he is so small to sing such a big song! Everything was nice, but the piece "The Battle With the Giant" surprised and pleased everybody. The giant was Ernie Cunningham, who made us laugh each time he came on the stage. Frank Giroux was King, and of course he acted his part very well, even if it was not funny. Another very good actor was Jim Smith, who dressed like a little old woman to play a trick on the giant. But the nicest was the band of little soldiers who played music as they came in to guard the King. The people would clap each time they would come in.

We had to leave our concert during Ymas break, because many had missed it, and many others wanted to come and see it again. Bishop Langlois and Father Felton both talked to the people afterwards, and said that they thought it was one of the nicest programs we have had, we enjoyed it too.

Simonne Dubreuil - Grade VII.

NOEL! NOEL! NOEL!

We had gone to bed early on Christmas Eve. All were dreaming of happy things, when suddenly we woke up hearing some singing and violins. Those who had never been here before could not understand what it was, and I guess they thought it was the Christmas angels who thought around was Bethlehem.
But I knew what it was, because every year the Sisters always come and wake us up for "midnight Mass by singing a Christmas hymn before the lights are on. It makes us feel like Christmas. Before going to Church, the singers went to drink something hot.

The Church looked so nice, with its nice crib and all the lights and decorations. Bishop Longlois sang Pontifical High Mass. Rev. Fr. Plhor was Deacon, while Fr. Giroux was Sub-Deacon. There were eighteen boys serving, but we did not get mixed up because Brother Paquette, Master of Ceremonies, and Henry Thomas were there to take care of us. Everybody enjoyed hearing the Bishop when he preached in English and in French. Father Falher preached well too in Cree. After the first Mass, Bishop Longlois gave us another special Benediction in the name of Pope Pius XI.

Roy Smith - Grade VI.

This year we got our toys on Christmas morning. When we came to breakfast, our presents were at our places on the table. We were just so glad and excited! We had such nice toys and games from our kind friends at St. Joseph's Academy in Valparaiso, Washington. They like to play Santa Claus, for they have been sending us our toys each year since Sr. Jean is here. We had such a nice breakfast. We are glad Fr. Giroux's hens had laid so many eggs. We could have some for our breakfast. Sister St. Adolphe had the girls make so many good things for us... pies, cakes, and over a thousand doughnuts! After making those, the girls did not need to put rouge on their faces!

Pete Gladu - Grade VI.

On December 25th, at eight o'clock, there was a double wedding in our chapel: Isabel Gladu and Paul Noskeyi; Mary Whitehead and David Lebouche from Whitefish Lake. Sister Jean played "Here Comes the Bride" when they marched in, then we sang some Cree hymns. Rev. Father Giroux married them. After Mass, they went to have breakfast at the Fathers' house. We wish these old pupils good luck.

Melba Cardinal - Grade VI.
"KISSING DAY."

In Cree, we do not call January first "New Year's Day," we call it "Kissing Day" because on that day, we kiss all our relatives and friends to show them that we wish them good luck. This year, there was a terrible blizzard, but that did not stop the people from coming to Mass. After that they all stayed to shake hands with the Sisters, and then they went to wish a happy New Year to the Bishop and the Fathers. Many of the children went to have dinner with their parents.

At night we all went to the "Boys' Hall," because Bishop Langlois wanted to have a family reunion, as he called it. When the Bishop and Fathers came in, we all clapped, because the Brothers and young Fathers each had a flute, and they were marching and playing as heralds of the Bishop just as Sr. M. Thecle's little soldiers had done for the King in the play. We had a very good time. The Bishop, Fathers and Brothers and even some of the Sisters sang some songs, and we children did our best to act and sing. Then we had a nice treat of candy and peanuts. Don't you think we're lucky children?

Len. Gladu - Grade VI.

KING'S DAY.

Every year on this day (Jan. 6) we have a special cake with a raisin or button in it. The one who gets the button will be King or Queen. This year the king and queen of the children were Maggie Bussard and Victor Trim. They were about the same size; usually they aren't, and so it is funnier. Maggie was dressed like a queen, and she sat on the throne with the king in the front of the room where everyone could see them. We had a nice little program for them.

The funniest play was the Mock Wedding. All the actors were boys, but some were dressed like women. Ernie Cunningham got married to Frank Giroux. We all knew that Frank is a real monkey for acting, and he made us laugh so much when he was talking away like a girl with a high voice. Harry Thomas was the Justice of Peace who married them, and at the end, Frank wanted to kiss him, but the Justice wouldn't let him. Before they went out, all of them went and shook hands with...
the Bishop and Fathers who laughed so much when they got a good look at the bride and her bridesmaids, for their rouge and powder did not look as if it had been put on by experts.

After a very nice evening, we all agreed that this last day of our Christmas tea had been a pleasant one for all.

Julia Dollard - Grade VIII.

A WELCOMING VISITATION IN OUR CLASS.

Just before Harry came's left to go back to College, he paid us a visit in the classroom which he enjoyed very much. After a little teasing, Harry proceeded to playing the piano for us was kept. He played his songs with Sister which he greatly enjoyed. But, I'm surprised he hasn't seen that he sang for us. Most of us had never heard him sing before, but that day he sang the Club Hymn for us, or the "Way To All The Sweet Home." He told us many interesting things about his life at the college which we were glad to hear. He then asked Ellen Brunelle to sing us a song, so she did, but we laughed so much that she got mixed up and had to stop.

Harry stopped in the other classes to say Goodbye to all, and when he got in the Baby Class, Sr. Guy asked him to sing for her pupils, so he sang the "A B C" song to make the little ones laugh. Harry was lucky to go to Edmonton that night, for Bishop Langelois went on the same train as he was going to the hospital for treatment.

Simonne Dubreuil - Grade VII... R. Smith - Grade VI.

OTHER PROVINCE'S FEAST.

On January eighteenth was another Province's feast. It was such a beautiful day out that we were delighted when Sr. Jean Placide said we could celebrate by going for a short walk after the last recess. We girls talked and talked with Sister while the boys ran ahead and did all kinds of foolish things, such as hiding under bridges till we had passed, washing one another's faces, and throwing snowballs when we came back we met Sr. Guy and her pupils, also Sr. M. Theol's sisters. You could tell it was a feast for the Sisters because we saw so many of them out for a walk, or going to visit the sick.

Corin Dosjordiis - Grade VI.
RADIO FANS.

We had been telling Sister often that on Jan 25th would be the big fight between Joe Louis and John Henry Lewis, and we were hoping very much that Sister would give us the joy of listening to it. How glad we were when Sister told us that she would bring us to the classroom this night so we could listen in. We came early, and had the best luck, because there was some nice old-time music and cowboy songs which we like so much. Sister kept promising us an old rocking chair, for she does not like cowboy songs and yodeling.

How excited we were when the fight began! In the afternoon we had bet on the one we thought would win. Most of us wrote Joe Louis to get beaten. Sister laughed right out when she saw Isabel "glares" with big tears in her eyes because J.H. Lewis was knocked out! It didn't last long, so we were on time to go to bed with the others.

Victor Bollrome - Grade VI.

Days of Joy.

Three guests who came to visit us two weeks ago? I'm sure you cannot guess, so I'll tell you right away. It was our dear BISHOP GUY! We had such a joyous surprise on the morning of January 27th when we heard that Bishop Guy had arrived from Edmonton the morning with Bishop Longlois. We could hardly wait to have a chance to talk to him. Just like he always did, Bishop Guy came to say Mass for us in our chapel each morning that he was here. It was not hard to sing at those Masses for we were so happy, we wanted to sing.

It seemed like old times to see him going around, visiting his old home. He knew us all, and had something to say to each one, especially to the little ones who used to be the babies when he was here. It was like seeing a father who has been gone a long time. Bishop Guy left Ground on the 30th of January. He may call it a long visit, but it seemed just like a short peek to me. We all hope that he will come back again soon again, for we never get tired of seeing that jolly smiling face of his.

It was nice to see out the Bishops walking around the Mission together. We were wishing we could always keep the two of them here with us.

Frank Giroux - Grade VII.
GREGORIAN SINGING.

Since our holy Father, the Pope has asked that Gregorian chant be sung everywhere, Mr. Langlois bought some books so we could learn it too. We have been practicing in the Boys' Hall ever since Christmas, and we sing all the Benedictions in Gregorian note. Sr. Mary Immaculate had asked the Bishop to come while we were learning some new pieces, but he got sick so he came just last week. We were glad to have him come, and of course everyone tried hard to sing the way he told them to. Bishop said we were learning it very well, we like to hear him sing with us in the chapel; we all try harder then. I don't sing, but I like him and singing better than the old way, and there are many others who like it too. The singers are all anxious for Mr. Langlois to come to another singing exercise in the hall.

Alfred Thibeault - Grade V.

OUR LANGUAGE.

One of the things that Bishop Langlois wants us to do is to pray in our own language. So Father Salter translated all the Mass prayers, the Angelus, and the Divine Praises into Cree, and then he, with Father Tondier and Father Naphin, taught us all these prayers. We appreciate their kindness, for it was much work for them. The Bishop, Fathers' Brothers, and Sisters pray in Cree with us, and most of them are learning to speak Cree too. We like to speak in our own language, although many of us cannot talk it well.

I am sure many of the people who read the "Echoes" have never seen Cree written in letters or in characters. Everyone says our words are very long. Here are the Divine Praises:

Pitane mamitchimit kisemanitow.
Pitane mivoyitchikateyik oniyomin.
Pitane mamitchimit Jesus Christ esi manitoriit mine esii
ayisilyinimit tegno.
Pitane mivoyitchikateyik Jesus owiyorin.
Pitane mamitchimit Jesus owiyorin.
Pitane mamitchimit Jesus ayinihoesakonowin'k.
Pitane mamitchimit kitchitew Marie Kisemanitowa wekwimikut-
Pitano manitoiyitkaniyik Marie okanatchisyisiyiniwiniwin ka kitchitrayik.
Pitano niwayitshiketoyik Marie oniyowin wekwemit kisik mitohimstihii kometehkwekut.
Pitano manitohimit kitchitew Joseph ka ki wikimat kometehkamayit keteinu.
Pitano manitohimit akamoniito okisikonok mine o kitchitewisinan.

Do you think you could read it? The characters are very easy to learn, because they are all sounds. Many of the older Indians know how to read and write just in Cree signs.

Irene Ward - Grade VI.
NEW CREE STUDENTS.

Father Falter is a very busy teacher again, because he has two more new pupils for his Cree classes. They are Rev. Fr. Hegar, O.M.I., and Rev. Fr. Klein, O.M.I., of Freidenstahl. They came about a week ago and started to study right away. We hope they will like Grouard. It is nice to see so many Fathers here again.

Gerard Thibault - Grade VI.

SICKNESS.

January was a bad month for it brought much sickness. Bishop Langlois got sick right after New Years, so he went to Edmonton for about six weeks. He is home again and is better now. Our little boy, Francis Johnson, and two of our little girls, Louise Chalifoux and Mith Legrand, had to go to the hospital at High Prairie. Louise and Francis came back, but Faith is still there. Then Sister Victoire and Sister Rose Germaine got sick and went to the Mohawkian Hospital. We were glad that Sr. Rose Germaine could not come back at the same time as Sr. Victoire. We hope she will soon be better. Sister Ray is taking her place at the Boys'.

Father Giroux is having his turn of sickness now. He was very sick so they were going to take him to the hospital in Edmonton. The roads were very bad, and there was a big storm. They went part of the way in the bus, part of the way in the car, and then in the snow-plow, but they missed the train, so they took Father to the hospital in High Prairie. We are praying that he will soon get better and come back to Grouard.

Margaret Fraser - Grade IV.

OUR SEWING CLASSES.

This year we are having some interesting sewing. Our sewing teacher is Sr. M. Isabella. Every Tuesday and Thursday afternoon, Sister holds the circle of the big class and shows us how to sew and to knit. We all know how to knit stockings, mittens, caps and sweaters, but Sister is an expert at knitting and she is showing us how to knit sweater, little dresses and other pretty things. We are all so anxious to learn. We will send some of our sewing and other work to the Indian Exhibit in Calgary; that's why we are doing our best. On those
same afternoons, Sr. M. Ambrose teaches the big girls who do not go to school how to make moccasins, gloves, and other Indian work. Sister Superior is much interested in our work, and does all she can to help us out. We will be glad to know how to make all these things later on.

Leni Gladu - Grade VI.

MANUAL TRAINING CLASSES:

The big boys have a chance to learn how to make many things this year. Two afternoons a week, we go to the shop and there Brother Michel shows us many things. Joe Bottle who is a good carpenter, is there too to help Brother. We have all learned how to plane wood already, and now we are going to learn how to make snow-shoes, sleighs, and many other useful things. It is Father Falher who got this class for us, and we thank him very much. We hope he will like the things we make. He said we would soon have some tools from the Government so we can each have our own place and things to work with.

Ernie Cunningham - Grade IV.

OUR OLD PUPILS:

We are always happy to hear from the old pupils, and we are sure all those who used to be in Grouard will be glad to read what has happened to some of their old friends.

At Christmas time, we heard that Harry Gregory had had an accident while he was working. A tree branch hit him in the eye. After being in the Dawson Creek hospital for a while he was advised to go to Edmonton if he did not want to lose the eye. He was to go to the Mission Hospital, but we have not heard since how he is getting along. Charles Gregg is getting along all right at the Shishka for the Deaf.

We have heard twice from George and Donat Fovargue. Don said he had a grand trip crossing the Atlantic, but George was sick most of the time. They are enjoying England so much that they will not come back to Canada for at least seven years, for they have joined the Royal Air Force. Don will go in for engineering, but George will take up Wireless.

Leo Dufresne is still working near Edmonton. He came home for Xmas, but went back about the same time as Harry and Nan Thomas, after enjoying their holidays at Grouard.
Janet Collins, who is District Nurse at Athabasca, wrote a very interesting letter to the Sister last week. Sister Jean read it to Janet and she went to Calgary in an airplane to take two patients to the hospital, and later on, she went out by trail with the policeman to take some prisoners to Edmonton.

Sister received a very interesting letter from Evelyn Polton, our first Club secretory, who is in Montreal with her family, and she will get married with a German-Scotch in April.

Sam Miller and Jimmy Thomas write sometimes. Both seem to be doing good work up in northern B.C.

The marriage of Elmores Shaw and John Edward Cunningham is announced for next week, also another of our former pupils: Charles Jenkins, who is to be married to Lona Anderson. I wonder if someone will give Charles an alarm clock for a wedding present?

Helen Miller - Grade VIII.

DEATH OF OUR HOLY FATHER.

Last Thursday night, my sister and I were listening to the radio. At nine o'clock, they said that our Holy Father the Pope was sleeping but that two male nurses and a doctor were staying up with him all night. Then at nine-thirty, they announced that our Holy Father had just died. We were sure nobody had heard the news at the Mission, so my brother-in-law came over and told Father rather the sad news.

The next morning before Mass, the Bishop told the Sisters and children the sad news and asked everybody to pray for the repose of the soul of the "Pope of the Missions". This morning, at nine o'clock, we had a High Requiem Mass for the Pope. The chapel was all in black. There was a black coffin in the front of the chapel with a white mitre on it, to make us think it was the Pope who is dead. Rev. Father Floch sang the Mass, assisted by Rev. Father Naphin and Mr. Tessier. We are anxious to know who our new Pope will be.

Annie Thomas - Grade VIII.
Pope Pius XI

We wish to express our grief in written word and join the entire Christian world in mourning the passing of Christ's Vicar on earth, Pope Pius XI. He died at the age of 81, on Fri., Feb. 10, two days before the 17th anniversary of his coronation as the 261st successor of St. Peter.

It is indeed a worthy action to record the last words he whispered during the final moments of his life: "St. Theresa of the Infant Jesus is near us. God is merciful... May His Divine Will be done... Peace! Peace!"

How very well this reminds us that to last minute of his long career, as leader of the Holy Catholic Church, he has striven above all to restore peace to the world which so greatly needs it! He offered himself as a victim so that the world might return to God and thus be saved. Let us follow his noble example by continuing to invoke Pope Pius XI's favorite St. Theresa for peace in the world, peace in the family and peace within our souls.

But to us, Pius XI will always be remembered as the Pope of the Missions. More than any other Pope, he has devoted time and work to the progress of the Missions throughout the world. From 1932 to 1939, 6,000,000 pagans have been brought within the folds of the Holy Catholic Church. During the last 3 years only, the number of annual conversions in the Missions has risen to nearly half a million souls.

Let us thank Heaven for having given all the Missions an able Protector and let us pray that God may grant him Eternal Happiness, which he so often preached to his millions of followers to be the only Reward that is really worth striving for.

Montas
Lent ——

We have now entered the season of Lent. As we all know it has been established by the Catholic Church as a time for penance. Therefore, we are not alone in our efforts to repent our sins. So let us consider that since all of us can be called sinners, we must remember that Christ came into this world to save our souls by his sufferings and death. In return, he demands that our sins be expiated by Penance.

Therefore, if we wish to obtain the Eternal Reward set aside for the just and avoid the Everlasting Punishment due to sinners, let us do our share towards expiating our sins.

Surely, we have grave sins to expiate; others just vented shall never see them. They reveal us to make sure that we shall escape them fully and most generously. Give us the supreme example of love. Let us return love for love in sentiments of true contrition, firm purpose of betterment and generous sacrifice.

By therefore making good use of this time of Lent prepared to enter Eternal Happiness without having to pass by the purifying fires of Purgatory.

Holy Scripture gives this to remember and let us not forget it:

"In all thy works remember thy last end, and thou shalt never sin." (Ecclus. VII, 40)

Monte's

Here and There

On Feb. 18th, Solemn Mass of the Holy Ghost was sung in the M'st Church for the repose of the soul of our Holy Father.

LOOK OUT!... "SCHOOL SECTION"

Not having our kind Archbishop's letter on hand for the Jan. issue we did not mention its reception because we wished all our readers to enjoy its contents.

Although our grateful sentiments have already reached him through Sophie Nepocs' letter, we want our Moccasin News to express publicly our most sincere and grateful thanks.

Nor judge by yourself how interested he is in all Indian activities:

My Dear Children:

I just want to wish you all a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.

I hope you have all been well this year, good health is one of the things I wish you for next year. Money and such things are not worth half so much as good health.

I suppose you are all wishing one another a happy new year. I hope you mean it; and that you will really try to make one another happy in every way you can. There are so many ways in which we can make others happy; and we would be mean if we did not use them.

Think how happy our parents and teachers are when they know that we are making good use of the chances we have to get a good education. And your chances, my dear children, are better than those that most people have. It could be too bad then, if you did not learn something every day that would help you to be better men and women after you grow up, better farmers, better citizens, better to love and help one another. These are some of the things that you should be doing at school; and we feel sorry when we hear that you did not make good use of your time.

Praying God to bless all the boys and girls, as well as their kind teachers,

I remain,

Sincerely in the Lord,

Signed: J.H. Macdonald

Archbishop of Edmonton.

R.I.P.

On Feb. the 13th in the Church, Rev. Father Moulin sang a High Mass for the repose of the soul of our Holy Father, Pope Pius XI, who are all sorry, because he was the Pope of the missions and has helped a great deal in the conversion of souls by having many missionaries in far off countries. He also was the Pope of Peace having given his life for this purpose, we ardently hope that God will not permit any "World War".

Mary Jane Gedin—Gr.5

On Ash Wed., Sister N.de G. reminded us that Lent was starting, and that we were obliged to do penance for our sins. The grown-up people have to fast, but the children are not obliged, so we must make sacrifices instead. We all took a good resolution and all made our little chart as the one I drew.
