Sophie Nepocs—Gr.6
Father Provincial's Visit

On Feb. the 26th, Rev. Father Routhier, Provincial of the Oblate Fathers came and stayed with us for 2 days. All were very glad to see him with Father Lebrun who is the Provincial Visitor. Monday morning he visited the class rooms and questioned us in our Catechism; he tried to puzzle us, we hid our best although we did not speak very loud. After his little test he spoke kind words to us. We all would have liked to hear him longer because he was very interesting. All hope he will come back and give us a long talk on the training of our character.

Celine T. Rabbit—Gr. 6

A SMILE

A smile is such a little thing
And yet it means so much.....
And those whose way is rough and steep
Would miss its magic touch.

'Tis like a tonic to the sick,
And sunshine to the sad,
So scatter smiles along the miles,
To make the old world glad.

---

Another Surprise

Last Monday while we were all working at our Enterprise, we heard a knock at the door. Mr. Schmidt, Colonel Lewis and Father Pratt came in. They were visiting the School, but our kind Inspector, Mr. Schmidt spoke to us, asked us a few questions about our Trip and congratulated us for this good idea as well as for our Moccasin News. We then asked him to speak in Cree. This he did willingly and made us laugh with a good joke, but he does not want us to publish his "New Dictionary".......we thank him for his nice visit and hope to see him again soon.

Mary Jane Godin—Gr. 5

---

Operation

Grade One Pupils all feel sorry because their teacher, Sister Amédée de Savoie, feeling sick since a week or so, was finally brought to the Edmonton Misericordia Hospital. About a day or two after, we heard that she had been operated. Sister Superior who came back on Sunday, gave us good news about her, and all seemed to be going on fine, but Sister, during the singing period told us that Sister, in Edmonton, was feeling so good and asked us a few sacrifices so she would get better. We hope she'll pull through and come back with us again. So we are praying for her fast cure.

Sophie Lapois—Gr. 6

---

Cleaning...cleaning....

During the last week of Feb., we were three working in the kitchen; Alice MacKanaw, Isabelle Bull and I. When we had finished cooking our meals, we washed the wall, cupboards, windows and floor, because Sr. Louise-Marguerite, who was the cook, since Sept., is going to change job. There is another Sister from the East who will replace her, she will find the kitchen nice and clean and we hope she will be as good a cook as Sister Louise-Marguerite was.

Helen Gutknife—Gr. 5

---

Lots of Wood

The Indians have been working hard since a week. The wood yard is blocked with wood they have sold to the School. I have counted up to twenty-five loads one day. Just now they are hauling gravel for the School's new building. I am anxious to see the carpenters start.

Joe Shortback—Gr. 4
One day Father Pratt went to Edmonton while he was gone a big snowstorm came up and blocked the roads. When he came back with Father Molin he was unable to pass. The car was stuck between George Field's house and the School. So Father Molin walked up to the School and asked Mr. Erroll and a few boys to go and help. We worked quite hard and came back all wet. Just look at us.

Radio Television

Having finished Problem 2 in our enterprise we thought of celebrating St Valentine's Day by a radio to television program. We had our own broadcasting station - L.R.S. Alex Simon was the announcer. He and others gave a series of talks about different topics while the rest of the pupils represented different things about Pioneer life. But a real radio casting which Joe Wolfe borrowed from his home had made "enthusiastic" service to little the speakers who had the chance of speaking through a real loud speaker which we had purchased from an old gramophone. OUR HOLY FATHER, THE POPE
PIUS XI

On February the 10th, eve of his anniversary, our Sovereign Pontiff died. The whole world now mourns a friend, a protector, a king in the person of our great Pope Pius XI. Throughout the world he is known as the "Pope of Peace", for his greatest wish was to maintain peace between nations and individuals.
A month ago one of our missionaries Father Chatignier received a lovely statue of Our Lady of Lourdes in France. It was sent to him as a present from some of his friends in France.

Our Lady is dressed quite differently from the others. Around her waist she has a girdle instead of a blue sash. Her pure white dress falls down in graceful folds up to her feet. Her shoes are white. A wreath of pink, red, white and yellow roses forms a circle around her. From her hands issue silver rays which represent the graces which she pours over the sinners.

She is also known as "Mother all Merciful."

Our Lady of Lourdes appeared for the first time to St. Joseph Paquette on the 16th of Feb., 1876. It occurred on Monday night. This young lady had been sick nearly all her life. At her first vision she was told that she would be cured on the following Saturday. It happened just as the Lady had told her. After a few hours all traces of her sickness had disappeared. How astonished were the doctors and all those who had known her.

If I had more space I would relate to you the fifteen visions she had. In every one of her visits to St. Joseph a secret was revealed or a special mission was confided to her care which she had to tell the world about.

Father Chatignier then distributed scapulars to some children.

I am from Poveshell Reserve. How anxious I am to see the statue in our new church next summer.

Lucie Chatignier,
Grade VII

IMMACULATE CONCEPTION

Whenever I think of the Blessed Virgin I think of little Bernadette. How lucky she was.

Little Bernadette saw her in a pure white dress and with a long veil while her mantle was of a light blue. Two beautiful roses were resting on her feet. In her arm was a pearl rosary. She was surrounded by a light of wonderful brightness. The vision was so glorious and the blessed Mother's smile so sweet, that little Bernadette who was kneeling below forgot everything else around her. Around the Mother's head were seen the words spoken by her during the vision "I am the Immaculate Conception".

We have therefore chosen December 8th for our patronal feast. The altar had a special decoration of lilies. Our sewing and recreation rooms were decorated in white and sky-blue, the colors of the Blessed Virgin Mary.

At dinner was our usual banquet prepared by the Sisters and some of the older girls.

How thankful we are to Sister Superior who devotes a part of her time for us, and who never neglects an occasion to please us.

Many thanks also to Rev. Father Principal for the lovely medals of the Blessed Virgin he gave us.

Marie Adèle Desrochers,

**INDIAN SIGNS**

Indians when speaking to those of another tribe used a sign language. In making all kinds of silent words with the hands, the fingers or other parts of the body they understood each other in the pictures above; words have been chosen which need no motions.

Axo... Rest the elbow on the right arm in the left hand. Move arm up and down.

Deer... Hold the hands on both sides of the head and spread out the fingers to represent the antlers.

Blanket... Raise and cross the arms in front of the heart close to the shoulders.

Sun... Raise the right hand above the head, with thumb and first finger forming a circle.

Trees... Hold the hand flat and pointing upward on either side of the head.

( This is a lesson we had in our Nature and Language Book. I like these lessons very much because we learn many things about nature. )

LOOKING THE GAME OVER

The Ermines seem quite proud of themselves after skating off the ice with a 4-4 tie. No wonder... they have just experienced the thrill of their very first hockey game against an outside team. As most of them have learned how to play real hockey this year, they naturally felt a bit excited upon jumping on the ice.

1st Period: They were surprised at seeing themselves ahead by a score of 2-0.

2nd Period: This encouraged them during this period to face their visitors with more audacity than precaution and therefore the neat combination plays exhibited in the first stanza lacked and the score turned out to be 3-2 the Ermines holding a single goal ahead.

3rd Period: So confident were they that they threw precaution to the winds and forgot all systematic plays learned during their occasional practices. The Hobema Jrs scored 2 more goals while the Ermines added one more, making the score 4-4.

A 15 min. overtime period did not impress its importance upon them; they played as if they had the whole day to get the goal which would have given them a rightful decision.

So, considering that the Hobema Jrs. had not practiced together before this game, we think that the Ermines have failed in not getting the winning goal which they could have easily scored had they kept in mind the great importance of teamwork and combination plays.

But there's time before the next game and the Ermine are going to win........eh! boys.....

BLESSED ARE THE DEAD

It is hard to realize that our dear pastor, Father Falher, has left us never to return. His illness was so brief and so sudden, that Father is dead. But each time we look out of the classroom window towards the cemetery and see the fresh mound there, we know all about his death.

WHO DIE IN THE LORD

On March 23rd, after school, we were so surprised to hear that Father was very ill, because that morning, he had come to teach the children of his Cree Gethsemane class, and had taught them their Cree lessons all day as usual. At four-thirty that afternoon, he stopped in at the Fathers' kitchen and gave Sr. Joseph Naultie some Cree hymns that he had translated for Sr. Mary A., to teach the children. I was working there with some other girls, and he stopped a minute to tease us. While he was talking, he began to rub his cheek, and he laughed and said, "Well, isn't it strange? I seem to be talking so querely?" He left immediately because he felt sick. We didn't know he would never come to the kitchen again.
On the way to his room, he met Brother Paquette, and already his tongue was very thick, and Brother had a hard time to understand him... all he could understand was Father Giroux's name. The Fathers sent for Sister Superior and Sr. Marcella right away. He could not speak except by signs, and a few little words. He did not want to go to hospital, so they kept him here and took the best care of him night and day. The Fathers and Brothers took their turns watching by him all the time. But the next day, he was worse, so Fr. Lejole gave him the Last Sacraments and they sent a telegram to Bishop Langlois who was visiting Wabasee.

Simon Dufresne-Lone Gladu—Grade VII.

Our Last Visit to Father Falter.

When we knew that Father would not live, our one wish was to see him again, so Sr. Jean Placidus took all of the pupils in our class to see him on Thursday morning. How pitiful it was to see him gasping for breath. We went in small groups and just stayed a minute looking at him in silence. Many people came to see him too. They would kneel down by his bed to pray, and when they'd come out, they'd all be crying, because they knew he was their best friend. Sister took us to the chapel where we said the prayers for the dying. At the same time, the Fathers and Sisters were around him, saying the prayers for the dying, for we expected to hear any moment that he was dead, but no, he lived a day longer. Though Father seemed unconscious, they think he could hear and knew what was going on, for the first days, the Sisters would speak to him, and when they would ask him for his blessing, he would raise his hand and try to make the sign of the cross.

Annie Thomas—Grade VIII.

Death on March 18th.

Everyone thought Father would die before the Bishop could get back from his trip to Wabasee, but God heard our prayers, and the Bishop was able to see him before he died. The priests who were with Father Falter said he died very peace-
fully at half past one on Saturday morning. I guess Father had waited to die on the Blessed Virgin's day.

That morning at six o'clock, Sister told us that Father Falher was dead. All those who had not intended to go to Mass that morning changed their mind when they heard the sad news, and we all went to hear Mass for him. Still, I can't believe he is dead; it seems like I can still see him coming out from his class with all the children crowding around him, for they liked him so much for their teacher, because he would make them sing Crou hymns and would always have such wonderful stories to make them understand about God. The last time he talked to us in the chapel on the First Friday, he told us he thought he was going to die very soon, maybe before a month, he said. He often used to ask us, "Children, if you should die right now, would you be ready?" I hope and pray that I will be ready like he was when it comes my turn to die, and may his soul rest in peace!

Edna Pruden -- Grade VII.

Our precious friend has left this life, In answer to the Master's call,

God was his all. Did he not give "his heart, his soul, his strength, his will,

A Contribution from the Manual Training Instructor.

The industrial training in the shop for the big boys which started on Feb. 7th, was rather tiresome and tedious work at first, for it was that of planing rough plank but fortunately the eight boys in this class are quite brave and did not get discouraged. They seem to respond to the favor offered them and realize it is not like a picnic or only to be allowed to go out of the common routine for a few hours. It is surely a pleasure to see the boys coming directly from the school house to the shop in a group, not scattered and going to talk here and there, and the same picture is show when they go back after work. We cannot praise them too much for this because this is absolutely necessary for keeping good order and is always an important point. I am sure the boys will also continue their good behaviour in the shop for they show that discipline is a marvel to anybody who wants to learn any kind of work.

The boys are very grateful to all those who have been instrumental in organizing this class for them, and thank especially Mr. Schmidt who is always so devoted and interested in all the Indian schools of his district. Now I know that the boys will do their very best to prove their gratitude and to show the result of the training they are now receiving.

Brother T. Michel, O.M.I.

Departure of Rev. Father Naphin, C.S.B.R.

One day we were very sad, for Father Naphin, our kind Catechism teacher, had to leave us and go back to his mission in Grande Prairie. He had been here since September studying Cree. We liked him very much because he used to know what we liked and would make our Catechism lessons so interesting and jolly. We hope he will come and visit us some time and sing with us again.

George Frager - Grade VI.
Bishop's Visit to Fort Vermillion.

Our new Bishop went to visit Ft. Vermillion for the first time on Feb. 13th. He went by airplane. While he was there he confirmed the policeman who was converted. The people there must have been glad to see the Bishop because he has been here almost a year now. He came back the same week, and he said he had enjoyed his trip to the far-away mission.

St. Theresa Club Has a Meeting.

Our last Club meeting was held on Feb. 15th, we invited the pupils of Dr. John Macdonald room. The first thing we did after saying our Club hymn was to give a show with our moving picture machine. We showed how the Bad Habit Family got into the Kingdom of Heaven. Some of us were saying some pieces about each one of the family. While I was our pie leader, I was narrating the medallion stories about their places. Another thing we liked was "A Little Pond" acted out by W. John Chaffaux and Margaret Fraser. The visitors enjoyed the songs. Mary had a little cold. She had a little heart-bush on our sand-table and I enjoyed seeing them fluttering in the air. The last thing we did was to pass the Valentines to the girls and boys. I got one too, but I had to guess who gave it to me.

Now Brothers.

There are two new Brothers in Grouard now. One is Brother Ben Cunningham, and the other is Brother Lambert from Father. Brother Cunningham was engineering here before, and we used to call him Dan then because he wasn't a Brother yet. We are glad he is going to be a Brother, and we are proud too, because he is the first Cree Brother we have known. We hope they will like it here until they have to go away to learn more about being Brothers. Maybe some of the other boys will follow their example in the future.

Sister Superior Goes to Madrasore.

Sister Superior went for her retreat on Feb. 17th. Sister Norbert took her place while she was gone. We missed Sister Superior very much for she was gone about two weeks.
One morning, we were so glad to see her praying in the chapel. After breakfast, she came to see us in the refectory. It was nice to see her home again. Sister Victoire was sick, so she went to Midnapore. Sister Adelia came from New Westminster to keep the girls. A few of the girls knew her because she was here about ten years ago. Margaret Fraser — Grade IV.

Our Last Sleigh Ride This Year

Last month, the boys and girls went for a ride as far as the bridge. There were six teams. Some of the Sisters came with us too. We turned at the Bridge. But Brother Drouin and John Giroux played a trick on the rest of us and went further out on the lake. This tossed the other four teams, so they waited about a mile from the mission till the other two teams caught up, then they had so much fun, snow-balling and playing all sorts of tricks. It was funny to see Uncle Cunningham getting his feet washed by Brother Bossé. But Brother had a little snow on his face too before he hopped into the sleigh again.

Some of us were in Brother Bossé's sleigh to talk to him. This was his last sleigh ride with us. We were asking him why, but all he could say was, "You will find out later on, just wait and see." Well, we soon found out that he was going to Ft. Vermillion to replace Brother Gaucher who has been here since Christmas. We were all sorry he had to leave because everybody knew Brother Bossé and began to smile as soon as they saw him because he is so jolly and is always playing tricks. I guess the boys will miss him very much when they start playing ball, for he was their best player, and he used to make the games lively by teasing the players all the time. We surely hope he likes his new home.

Melba Cardinal — Grade VI.

Senior Club Meeting

The Fathers, Sisters, St. Theresa Club and other guests seemed to enjoy the Club program we had on March 21st. In a little play called "Foxy Grandpa", Victor Twin made everyone laugh, because he was dressed like an old woman, and spoke in a thin little
voice. As a preparation for Lent which was beginning the next day, our president, Frank Giroux, read one of Father Ryan's beautiful poems about Death. Father Falhor said he liked that number best. He spoke so nicely to us afterwards, we surely didn't think this was the last time he would ever come to our Club meeting. We will think of him and miss him the next time we have a program.

Return of Rev. Father LaJoie.

Just before Christmas, Fr. LaJoie left for the East to go and buy some clothes and other things for all the boys and girls of all the Indian missions. He came back at the end of February. How Nice To Have a Radio at School!

We were surely glad to have a radio on March second. It was our radio that brought the news of the Pope's election. During recess, Sister happened to remember the Conciliation so she opened the radio and we just on time to hear the glad news. She went quickly to tell the Sisters and Fathers who knew nothing about it yet. When the pupils came in a few minutes later, we were all so interested, we forgot to sit down, but just stood behind our chairs ... with our mouths open! We heard the rest of the broadcast till eleven o'clock. It was wonderful to hear the bells ringing.

Our Bishop Goes To Labrador Mission.

Bishop Langlois left for his first visit to Labrador on March seventh. When he came a little ways from the Mission, he saw Fr. Bruckert with his dog-teams. Other dog-teams were there too, all gayly decorated to welcome the Bishop. Bishop said it was funny to...
see Fr. Bruckert cracking his whip and shouting to keep his dogs just ahead of the Bishop's sleigh. But the visit was a short one, for just a few days after his arrival, Bishop got a telegram that Fr. Falher was very sick, so he had to come right back.

Here in Grouard, we were all praying hard that Fr. Falher would not die before His Excellency arrived. One noon, while we were washing dishes, we saw a big car coming in, and we saw a man in the front near the driver who was Bishop Langlois, we were sure. Mary Collison ran to tell the Sisters "Bishop is here!" So all ran outside... and you should have seen how happy Sr. Duray was, being sure that her prayers had been answered! A few of the Sisters looked out to see the Bishop, but just then, he got out, and instead of seeing Bishop Langlois, we saw Dr. McIntyre getting out of the car! We were sorry; but we couldn't help laughing. But the next day, we got our wish, for Father was still living, and the Bishop had the consolation (and the consolation) of blessing his oldest missionary before he died.

Victoria Bollrose - Grade VI.

Visit of Former Teachers.

The day before St. Patrick's, Father Beauchage and Fr. Lindervator came to visit our school. We were all so glad to see them both again, for they were both our Catechism teachers before. Father Beauchage had come here with our school inspector who was on his way to visit at Salt Prairie. They had a hard time coming, for the roads were very bad and Fr. Arrival of Father Floc'h from Whitefish Lake.

Father Floc'h has just arrived from White Fish Lake with seven children who are coming to stay here. He had been away on his far-away missions for the last two weeks.
where he couldn't get any news, so Father Falher had been buried a week before he even knew that he was sick. It was a terrible shock for Father Floch to hear the sad news, for he had been with Fr. Falher as a missionary for so many years. One of Fr. Floch's first visits after he got to Groundwood was to the cemetery.

Father said this last trip had been one of the hardest he had ever had. He went to Prairie Lake which is forty miles away from Whitewater, but the roads were so bad, he had a hard time getting through. After a few days here, he had to go to Loon Lake which was about thirty miles further. After much trouble, he got there, said Mass, visited the people and got some of the children who were going to come back with him. One day they traveled only six miles, because the frozen snow would cut the horses' legs and make them bleed. At each stop, the horses would break through the crust and sink in deep. The little boys ran ahead and didn't mind, for they wouldn't break through, but Father and the man would sink. They had to camp out in the open because they couldn't reach the place they intended to stay in. It was snowing and raining all night, and all they had was a couple of blankets to put over them. When they got up in the morning, there was about three inches of snow over their blankets!

They were very cold, hungry and tired when they got to White Fish Lake, but there Willie Hamelin was there with fresh horses from Groundwood to take them home, so they got here the next night. We are glad to see Father Floch again, and are sorry he had such a hard trip, but of course he is a real missionary, so he doesn't mind.

Holton Miller—Grade VIII—-Irene Ward—Grade VI.

Lenten Devotions.

During Lent, everyone has been trying to be as good as possible. We all have slips to fill in every day to encourage us to go to Mass. We are proud to get up or stay in bed three times a week, but in our room there are seven who have not missed Mass once since Lent started. Every Friday and Sunday, the Way of the Cross is made in Cree. We have been very lucky on Sunday, for the Bishop has preached three or four times. How nice it is to hear him preach! Everyone understands every word he says, because it is so...
interesting, we just have to listen. We are very lucky children to have a Bishop preach to us so often. Last Sunday, His Excellency talked about the Annunciation, and told us about the time he went to say Mass in the house where the Angel had announced to Mary that she would be the Mother of God.

On Monday morning, instead of Composition, Sister asked us to write a short account of the Bishop's sermon. After we had finished, we nodded our heads. Suddenly Sister began to laugh, and when she heard us Pete Glidu's composition, we laughed too. This is what Pete had written: "The Angel Gabriel appeared to the Blessed Virgin and told her that she was going to be the mother of Christ. MY TRIP TO JAPAN

One sunny afternoon when I was made disobeying my mother in Canada, my teacher told me that I was to have a long trip to Japan with her. Of course I didn't refuse the great opportunity offered me. I told her I would be ready in about a week or so.

The next day, for it was Monday, I started to pack. First I packed all the things that I thought I would need. I took a large piece of a broken mirror too. I was told in Japan that Japanese folks didn't know how to break glass. So I thought I would show them.

To my surprise, my pack grew quickly up and even before I knew it I was on the large steamer sailing across the Pacific Ocean.

It was a very slow journey and we didn't forget to pray so that we might not have a terrible wreck some place. I made friends with people that I never met before. There were a lot of people on all races on the steamer. Some of them were ladies like ourselves and I was afraid to go near them.

When we were quite near the Island of Japan we saw the beautiful mountains of Fujiyama. The houses were made of all colours. We saw the beautiful green fields of rice and tea which grew in long straight rows. The little Japanese girls and boys called at us as we passed down the streets of the industrious Kyoto and Chizen. We visited an old man's house and I was much surprised to see that his house was made of cardboard.

Then when our visit was ended we had to come back to Canada. On our way back we saw a large whale not far from the ship. One of the men threw a long iron pole something like a spear at it. The pole hit its mark and the great water beast died. I was rather glad to get back home again for I think that Canada is the best country of all.

SAINT VALENTINE.

Once upon a time long long ago there lived in a monastery a very humble monk called Valentine.

He used to wonder why he didn't have a nice voice to sing with nor skilled hand like others. One day a voice said to him, "Valentine, do little things, they are the best." Valentine asked what the little things were but there was no reply. He had to find out for himself.

Valentine took care of the garden. His white lilies and violets were the biggest and nicest of all. There was hardly any bride in town who didn't wear blossoms on her wedding day.

Valentine came to know everybody's birthday. He used to hang a little gift made by his own hands on their doors. His flowers were given to little children on their way to school.

When Saint Valentine died everyone came to look for the last time at the pretty kind face in the rude coffin. The people cried for Valentine. A Brother told them not to weep but to try their very best to please God as Valentine did.

After Valentine died people never forgot his kindness to everybody. That is the reason why to this very day we send all kinds of little tokens on St. Valentine's day to our friends to show that we love them.

A VISIT TO FAIRYLAND

One night as I lay in my bed fast asleep I dreamed I had to take a journey to the beautiful village of Fairyland. The night was dark and cold. I took my coat and hat, put them on and started for the door. As I opened it a strange light surrounded me. I was so filled with wonder that I quite forget my name. As I was thinking of it the light faded away. There stood a little girl dressed all in white. A bright gold crown was on her head and a beautiful wand in her hand. Then she spoke in a voice so sweet that I just couldn't stop wondering who she was.

I trembled a little while I calmed down. She said in a sweet but gentle voice, "What is your name my little girl?" I stepped closer and caught my breath and said in a low shy way, "My name is Florence Nightingale." Then she said to me: "Would you like to go to Fairyland? I can't ride who I am any longer, so I will tell you, I am the queen of the fairies."

And then she asked me if I wanted to go. I said "Yes, But how will we get there?" Just then two beautiful white horses with a wagon came walking up the path. The fairy waived her hand and the driver stopped at once. She told me to get on. She jumped on after me. In an hour or two I caught sight of a beautiful village. The driver stopped at a golden gate in front of a large palace. He ordered me to jump off and help her to step out of the wagon. I asked to know where he put the horses. He said they stayed where they were all day long. If any fairy wanted to go for a ride she could just have to jump on.

After we had talked for a little while the driver pointed over to the palace. I looked up and there I saw the most beautiful sight of my whole short life. Coming towards the queen, the driver said my sight was a line of fairies led by a little fairy boy dressed all in white. When they got up to us they all made a bow to the queen. The little queen said to me: "Do you see this little boy? He is the king of the fairies." She put me in front of all and told me to go to the king. When I got up one step I found a doll I gave to the king. He told me to keep it.

This is what happened when I got to the palace. There in one of the rooms was a big table with many things to eat. I couldn't eat from excitement. After a little while some Brownies came hopping into the room. They got in a ring around the table. After they had gone around ten times the fairies got up and took their places. The Brownies ate the rest of the dinner. Some of the fairies and brownies stayed to wash and put away the things.

When night came the queen took me to a little room in the palace and said: "This is the room you'll sleep in to night. You don't have to go to bed now. Come out in the garden and play."
A VISIT TO FAIRYLAND

One of the fairies danced, some played tag and the others sat around and told stories to me about Fairyland. They were the most wonderful stories I have ever heard. The king and the queen sat on their throne and watched the little fairies play. When it was time for bed my little pets, "Fairyland" was shut up. About ten everything was so quiet you could hear a little mouse run across the floor.

I stayed in Fairyland about a month and a half. One night when I was almost asleep I had a dream I had to leave. When I woke up next morning there she I bef I was not in a beautiful golden palace but in my little house in Spanish. I wondered and wondered how I got back. I wondered so much that my hair became gray. But you must not forget that I am your little friend Florence Nightingale. Do you think you'd like to take a trip to Fairyland?

Since our last number a great change has taken place. Reverend Father Pratt, our Principal here since February 1936, has been transferred to Blue Quills School at Saint Paul and Reverend Father Rheaume, formerly of our School, has arrived here from Saint Paul to take over the duties of Principal.

To Reverend Father Pratt we wish to publicly express our thanks once more for the great work he has done amongst us. The important material changes in and about the School will always stand as a worthy memorial of his devotedness towards the comfort and well-being of our Indian children.

To Rev. Father Rheaume, our new Principal, we wish to express our most sincere submission. Regardless of the fact that there are more difficulties to be faced here than in any other schools he has yet visited, we know that Father Rheaume is willingly ready to give all he has for the betterment of all those who are under his direction.

So let us all unite and generously work together for our own good as well as to relieve our Principal of some of the enormous duties imposed upon him.

For this purpose an appeal is made to the young boys who have just left School and to the young men on the Reserves. Why not each and every one of you try to realize all the worry and trouble you try to realize all the worry and trouble
you cause by roaming around the School at the most undesirable times. Try to imagine yourselves in the position of those who have been appointed to take care of your brothers and sisters in the name of your parents. Think of the damage you can cause by bad example and of the punishment you will receive, if not in this world, most certainly in the next.

But it is never too late. Be generous to yourselves and to your fellow-companions. Respect yourselves and all those about you. As you all know, you are not supposed to forget the training you received at your School. Now is the time to put it into practice and thus show your gratitude to all those who have left their country, their parents and friends; who have given up almost dear to them, to give you the best of all things—a good Christian education.

Alleluia.......This is the joyous word so often sung during the Holy time of Easter. Do you ever stop to realize its meaning? It has been used for centuries to express thanksgiving, joy and triumph. This is the reason why the Church uses it so often during this time of the year to express her joy and thanksgiving upon the occasion of Christ's Resurrection which marks our Savior's triumph over sin and death.

Easter is the principle feast of the year. Commemorating the Death of the true Lamb of God and the Resurrection of Christ, the corner-stone upon which faith is built, it is also the oldest feast of the Christian Church, as old as Christianity, the connecting link between the Old and New Testament.

And now that Easter is here, can each and everyone of us sincerely join our Savior in His triumph over sin. Can we join our joy with His and say: "O Lord I have done my best during this past season of Lent to expiate my sins and thus relieve Thee of some of the innumerable sorrows which I have caused Thee."

But to please Jesus above all, let us not forget our Easter Confession and our Easter Communion. Let each one of us do it most sincerely and most faithfully. Let us by so doing receive God's grace and participate of the infinite merits of Christ, our Savior's glorious Resurrection. This is the wish we express to our readers.

The following is a story that has often been repeated. We think that it will show our readers the Christian spirit that animates some of our Indians.

Recently, when Sister Pierre-Apôtre was here to visit many of the Indians whom she had known, came to see her and congratulate her upon her entry into religion. They felt proud that one of their own blood had given up her life to God for His service and the service of the souls.

Thomas Bull, an old friend, visited her one day and upon shaking hands with her said:

"Well, I should also do something. I cannot be a priest, but maybe I could be a Brother."

A Sister, who happened to be passing by, ventured:

"Be careful, Thomas, you would have to cut your hair. Oh! no—I would keep it to be like Jesus. He will love me better. Don't you think so, Sister?"

Monias

A Trip to Edmonton

On Saturday, March 18th, our Hockey Club traveled to Edmonton in order to play against St. John's College. However, warm weather had done so much damage to the ice that the game had to be postponed. This turned out to be quite a disappointment for both teams, but nevertheless it seems that the Ermines had a splendid time in Edmonton. Let's read what some of them have to say about it.

George Fitch (right wing on our first line) will tell us about his visit to the Edmonton City Dairy. Going in the E.C.D. building, we went to see how milk was being tested. A man there showed us how it is done by making experiments which surprised us. We went on to another room where a man was emptying the milk cans into a big tank. The milk goes into another tank where it is sterilized. Then it goes up and comes down on the rollers at the top of these rollers the milk is boiled by the heat arrives at the bottle filler. From here the milk goes to the bottle filler. In another room we saw boxes filled with empty bottles coming on a roller belt. These bottles go into a tank where they are thoroughly washed. A man stands there and takes the clean bottles and puts them on another belt. These are ready for the milk. They are now filled... a man takes the bottles and puts them in the boxes. He then takes them to the butter machines where also explained. Here are not the only ones working in the dairy—I saw a lady there wrapping the butter. I forgot to tell the nicest part—yes, we had our picture taken. All had their sweetest smiles—so I do hope it turns out to be the best one. E.C.D. has ever taken. And the Ice Cream treat! Even at the end of our visit I must not forget either. For this end course and for the kindness of those who made our visit so interesting I wish to say in the name of all my companions a very sincere "Thank You."

Jiminto Checsecow (sub left wing) will now drive us back to the Edmonton Airport. As soon as we visited the E.C.D., we went directly to the Edmonton Airport. As we were nearing the field, a small plane was circling above in the air. Mr. Roll himself manager of the airport, was very kind in showing us around the hangars. In the first there was a huge plane of Italian making whose wings were about 65 ft. long. It was the largest plane we saw. Farther we also saw another smaller but much faster plane which could go at the rate of 200 miles per hour. In the next hangar we saw more planes, the nearest of which was a big twin motor plane belonging to the Yukon Southern Lines and which flies regularly very much like the T.C.A. planes. If the Air Mail flights could ever be run on time that day, we would have been very pleased. But Mr. Roll told us just how hard it had been to get up to the altitude when it passes over Buteons. He also explained the use of the radio during the flights. We also heard about the trip.

Turning the Hide

At the beginning of Feb., Colonel Louis Sutherland, Agent received a letter from a pupil of his in Badgerwick, asking instructions how to tan the hide. So Colonel asked our teacher to have a pupil of her class to answer this letter. We all made our composition and asked you all to know about this subject.

Other animals they skin it. They then cut 4 or 5 trees in the hide (in the edge) so that they may fit it on the tree. Then they string or tie piece of sinew the hide. We then hang the hide to the branch of a tree or put it flat on the ground. Then take an instrument sharp at the end and scrape the fat or the flesh that was left on the skin. Let the skin dry.

Then use another instrument made of the bone of an animal at its end there is a piece of iron flat and sharp with which we take off all the hair on the hide. We then grease the hide with brains of any animal and bury it for a while so that the grease will go in the hide. Then soak it in warm water and leave it for night. Next morning rinse it, wring it well and put it in the sun to let it dry but rub it all the time while it is drying, this will be the skin nice and soft. But if you want it to be of golden brown, place it over the hole so that the smoke will turn it to nice golden colour.

Seventeen years ago, on February 13th, our Holy Father, Pius XI, was crowned Pope, as the 261st successor of St. Peter.

He was one of the greatest Popes that ever sat in the chair of St. Peter. He ruled over 330,000,000 Catholics.

He wrote many encyclicals during these seventeen years and in these letters he mentioned in a special way, the question of Communism, of Marriage and of Education.

On February 10th, the sad news of his death was heard over the radio. We prayed for him, for he had the responsibility of the whole world, that God may take him to his eternal rest.

Blessing of the Children

We had the blessing of children on February 5 in the church.

Just before the procession, Reverend Father Bidault preached a little while. When he had finished speaking, some little boys of the village took the statue of the Little Jesus and carried it all around the church and the Convent boys followed.

In the choir, some girls sang the hymn "Little King so Fair and Sweet," while the boys went around.

When the procession was over, Father Bidault blessed all the children. Then we said the Holy Rosary and Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament followed.

Rosalie Burnstick VI.

Last week, we were all anxious for Sunday to come, because one of our friends Miss Emilienne Kootenay was to play the organ during mass on that morning.

Our music teacher took all of Grade VII's girls to sing. Emilienne accompanied us. Everybody was glad to hear her play and all said she sang very well.

Sister will bring other girls who will be heard later; one from each reserve, if possible.

Religious Profession.

The profession of seven novices took place on Wednesday, February 15.

At 8:30, His Excellency, Archbishop Mac Donald entered the chapel, blessing us. After a few minutes, the seven Sisters came in carrying lighted candles and led by Reverend Mother Provincial and the Mistress of Novices. They all took their place at the front.

A hymn was sung, then Reverend Father Simard gave a sermon in French. After the sermon, the novices went to the altar to take their vows, then they were given their domino and their cross.

After the mass, said by our beloved Archbishop, he spoke to the young sisters and to their parents.

Then they went to see their good parents who made a big sacrifice in letting their daughters become sisters, and do good to the poor.

Another Picture Show.

Reverend Father Bidault had said that he would come again to give us another show because the last time a film could not be used. He kept his promise and came last Friday night.

High School Girls' Concert.

On February 25, the St. Albert public school girls gave a three act entertainment in the parish hall. The name of the play is "Jessica's Journey."

In the first act the two Foster girls were discussing on what they were going to do to pay the taxes and keep their home. But they were heel over head in debts and didn't know what to do because they were advised that they were going to lose their home in three days.

In the second act, they have company. Six high school girls and their teacher who had a wash out on their way to Ottawa, came to stay overnight in the Foster's home. A telegram announced the coming of their aunt on a short visit. The school girls managed a scheme not to let the aunt know the poor condition of the house and their debts. They did this by playing a trick. They had the Foster Girls dressed in their own ball dresses and the school girls dressed as maids with their teacher as the housekeeper.

In the third act, the old lady is too wise for them and they are discovered in their scheme. The old aunt appreciated their entertainment but she rebuked them for trying to act that way with an old lady, but when the reason was given her, she was touched, and told her niece about an uncle who died leaving her all his wealth. She pays the debts and she adds, there is still enough for all. As to the clever miss who tried to put this over her, she rewards by taking her for a trip around the world.

It surely was a swell entertainment, I enjoyed it very much.

We have a Pope.

When white smoke came out of the silvery chimney of the Vatican, the crowd of people gathered on St. Peter's Square shouted with joy.

A Cardinal appeared on the balcony and said in Latin: "I bring great tidings of joy, we have a Pope, Eugenio........... the people roared like thunder, drowning the voice of the Cardinal, but he kept on as soon as the people were silent again—Eugenio, Cardinal Pacelli, Pope Pius XII.

Cardinal Eugenio Pacelli is now Pope.

Cardinal Pacelli was elected Pope, as Pius XII on his 63rd birthday. He was born March 2, 1876, in Rome.

In 1899, at the age of twenty-four, he was ordained priest. Some years later, he was consecrated Archbishop.

He was sent to Germany during the World War, as Apostolic Nuncio, to present a chart which Pope Benedict XV had planned for the peace of the world.

After duly accomplishing this hard task, he went back to Rome. In recognition of his ability and courage, Pope Benedict XV made him a member of the Sacred College as Cardinal Pacelli. He was made the Papal Secretary of State of our recent Pope, Pius XI from 1929 until his death.

The ardent desire of his life had been that of remaining in priesthood duties—hearing confessions, giving sermons, etc. It surely was a great sacrifice for him to become a Cardinal.

In a sermon he preached on that day he said: "God desires the sacrifice of the body sometimes, but more often he wants the sacrifice of the heart."

As March 12, was the Coronation of our Holy Father, we also joined in praises and thanksgiving, by singing the "Te Deum". There were 150,000 people expected at St. Peter's for this happy day.

Emilienne Kootenay VII S.
Pope Pius XII

Cardinal Pacelli was elected Pope on his sixty-third birthday, March 2.

At the age of twenty-four Eugenio Pacelli became a priest. His Superiors were so much impressed with his ability that they placed him in the office of Papal Secretary of State, and later, Pope Benedict XV placed him at its head.

At the time of the World War he was sent to Munich as Apostolic Nuncio, and in the same year he was made an Archbishop.

In 1929, having done so well his difficult work, he entered the Sacred College of Cardinals and he became the Secretary of State of Pope Pius XI until his death.

It is said that he is the first Pope who ever toured by aeroplane. He went to South America, where a Eucharistic Congress was held in Argentina.

In 1936, he went to the United States and visited the four American Cardinals and many Archbishops. President Roosevelt entertained him at his home, in Hyde Park.

Last Sunday, March 12, the Coronation of our Holy Father, Pope Pius XII, took place, at the huge church of St. Peter. 150,000 people were expected for the magnificent ceremony. We who are not attending, should offer our hearts in thanksgiving. The "Te Deum" was sung after High Mass here, in the church, in our desire to join in praise with the 335,000,000 Catholics of the world.

Louise Ward VII S.

Reverend Father Simard left here about a month ago. He is gone East to preach retreats. We expect him back in a short time now.

Meanwhile, Reverend Father Crépeau kindly gives us a part of his time to come teach us Catechism. Although he has other work to do, for he visits schools out in the country, and the sick of the village, still he comes to our different classes every day.

He is kind and gentle to everyone. The boys seem to be his favorites. He has very good ways of asking questions in Catechism. We all like him because we know he loves us.

Last Saturday, March 18, we were invited to a concert at the Parish Hall, given by the Grandin Dramatic Club.

At quarter to two, we got ready for the Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament in our chapel, and as we came down, we went directly to the hall.

It was three o'clock when the concert started. It was a pleasant Irish play. Between each act, Irish songs were played by the town orchestra. A few minutes after five, the concert ended and we sang, "God Save the King." We all hope to be invited again, for it gives us much pleasure to go.

Forty Hours' Devotions.

We had the Forty Hours' Devotions in the parish church on March 24-26, in reparation for the sins committed against the loving Heart of Jesus.

These Holy Exercises were opened by the holy mass at 8 o'clock, and the exposition of the Blessed Sacrament.

During these three days of reparation, there were many adorers making their Holy Hour. We were also faithful to this for we, children went to church by turns during these days. We also went to the evening holy hour.

On the first day, the sermon was on the Sacrament of Penance. The next two days on Holy Eucharist and on Holy Mass. These interesting sermons were preached by Reverend Father Bidaud, our parish priest.

These Forty Hours have given us numberless graces for which we can never be too thankful. We are very lucky that these were during the Lenten Season. We all hope that we have benefitted by these three days of prayer, for we shall be happier for it in the next life.

Emilienne Kootenay VII S.

OKE NAPE:

Nearly two months since the last edition of Oke Nape has reached you. Did you miss your monthly paper from Crowfoot School? Then you will be in the right frame of mind to listen to what we have to say.

Old Man sickness had caught up with us; and lying day after day in bed, doing nothing but follow the pattern of a few cracks in the ceiling, got tiresome. So we set out to figure how we were doing in financing Oke Nape.

Our thoughts only sent our fever all the higher. We are in the red again this year! We had decided on a fervent appeal.... Numerous plans were presented..... But we finally decided that only to mention our difficulty, would bring a generous response from our readers.

Soon the annual payment of lease-money will give a chance to our Indian readers to give us a little help; and we profit of the occasion to ask of our readers all over the country to help us with a few cents for a subscription.

Natoyekissum

EASTER MESSAGE

"Christ is risen." Those words of the Angel to the folk, "Jesus at the Sepulchre are also for us," says Jesus is living.

His apostles had to the first Christians say when He ascended to heaven, It was with the promise that by the working of the Holy Ghost He would remain with us till the end of the world. On Easter Day itself, He walked from Jerusalem to the tomb of Lazarus with two of His disciples. They did not know Him. Their eyes were opened only when He spoke and blessed them. But then they were able to say to one another, Our hearts burn within us when He spoke to us on the way. So it is with us today. We will still cling and do not know Him. Yet He will still speak to us by the Church. He will still comfort us in our trials and He will still prepare for us our eternal home. He has risen! God has raised Him from the dead. In holy Communion we receive His Body and Blood. We experience also like those of the two disciples, that we are truly in the light of our faith, helping us to build up to that glorious life He has merited by His Resurrection.

The man went hunting every day, when the woman remained at home. One day, when the man was gone, she thought she heard singing; beautiful singing; but took where she would she could find no singers. She spoke to the man about it when he returned home that evening, and made him feel uneasy; if you hear it again, look about more carefully," he told her.

She heard it the next day, and this time located it right under the lodge. She went out to the bank of the river and looked at the bank; there under the water, were beaver "gales in it," and beaver cuttings up on the sandy bottom; by that she knew that the lodges had been set up above a dark beaver's home, and that the beavers were the singers.

She went back to the lodges, lay down and plainly heard the sound. Their singing was so good that it was all she could do to stop listening to them and begin cooking the evening meal.

Then Long Bull came home that night, she told him what she had learned, but he could not hear it plainly although he put his ear close to the ground. Nor could he hear the singing the next day, nor the next, although his women could hear it plainly. So now the woman got her knife and cut a round hole in the ground, and looking down he could see the beavers sitting in their homes, singing beautiful songs, and dancing strange and beautiful dances in time to them.

"Brothers, have pity on me," he cried. "Oh! my younger brothers, teach me your medicine."

They looked up and saw him, and one answered, "We have the hole that you have made, because the night disturbs us, and we will soon be with you." They soon came in through the doorway, four fine-looking men, beautifully dressed. They had changed themselves from beavers to men.

Long Bull, "Brother, what is it that you want of us? You can help us?"

Long Bull told them what it was; his great desire to obtain natural oaks and grow it for the people, that plant. Like us it is from the water, a very precious medicine, but before you can use it, you have to learn songs, much to learn. You have to learn all our songs and prayers and dances and different ceremonies, and gather for the ceremonies skin of every animal and bird that is of the water, one of each, except the beavers, and of them there must be two. You must not hunt all the other birds; but fish hook and all the other birds that get the fish from the life of the water. Why? Because there are two great life-givers in this world: the sun, which gives heat, and water, that makes growth, and in our ceremonies the skins of these different animals are symbols of the water. I shall collect them all, so teach me everything," Long Bull told them. And they began that very night, Long Bull hunted the animals and birds, brought in their skins for his women to carve, and night after night the beavers taught him their medicine, all the sacred prayers and dances and ceremonies of it. And at last he knew them all thoroughly.

HOW A CHILD CONVERTED HIS FATHER

Once upon a time I knew a little boy named Tom. His father did not believe in Christianity. Tom tried every way to get his father to become a Catholic, but his father did not listen to him. His mother died when he was only six years old. His grandmother took care of him.

One day when his father was very sick Tom went up to his room. He told his father how much he wished he were a member of the Catholic Church and he also told him about Jesus. Soon his father could not wriggle away. He told his son that he was very sorry that he had not listen to him before. He told Tom to call a priest. Now Tom was very happy to know he had converted his father. He tried in every way to please him while he was in bed.

A GREAT FRIGHT

Louise and Mary had to stay home all alone in the house one evening. Their father had gone to work and their mother was visiting her friends quite a way off.

They didn't wish to go out that night with their mother because it was so cold. They thought they would rather stay home all alone and see what it was like.

They lived in the country and their nearest neighbors lived about three miles away from them.

Their house was only one story high, but it was always kept neat and tidy by Louise and Mary. It was painted white and the windows were trimmed with green.

Louise and Mary had a good time playing with their dolls and their new set of dishes. They put all their dolls and dishes away and tidied up the room. They sat down near the fire for a little while telling stories. Louise was telling Mary a ghost story which was very exciting and frightening to hear. After that they both said each other good night and went to sleep.

During the night Mary was awakened by a strange sound which frightened her very much. Mary got up and went to Louise's room. She found Louise wide awake too. Both girls were very frightened by the strange noise. They got up to see what it was all about. While they were wandering about the dark room they heard the same noise again. Mary was so frightened that she began to cry. She said to Louise: Perhaps it is one of the ghosts you were talking about last night. Louise was frightened too, but she didn't want to show it. She said: Never mind, let us get back to our room and forget about it. Mary went to her room very obediently but neither of the two slept for the rest of the night. At the break of day Mary got up and ran to Louise's room. They looked all about the room and at last they found out that it had been just the windmill outside squeaking. Louise and Mary looked at each other and burst into laughter at the thought of the noise which kept them awake that night.

Once upon a time there was a little girl. Her name was Alice. She lived in a little red house with her father and mother and two sisters. Their father was a Protestant but they were Catholics. Every day he went to work and in the evening he came home. The priest used to go and visit the children. He told them to tell their father to go to Church.

One day the mother made a little altar for the children to pray at. She put two red candles and a little statue of the Virgin on it. The little children used to kneel beside the altar every day. Alice was the eldest in the family.

One evening when their father came home, all was set out for supper and they sat down to eat. But their father didn't want to sit so he got up and walked all around the room and said that someone was pushing him. He said over again "There is someone in here". His wife said to him: "Oh you are mistaken". The father said: "No, there is someone in here", so he got up from the table and went into the other room. When he came back he said: "This is what made me think". He said: "I did not want any of this in here". Alice ran to her mother and said: "Oh, father we always pray that you will become Catholic". They all knelt to say a little prayer for their father. Then they went to Church and their father went to Confession. They became Catholics. They went to Church every Sunday after that.

THE INCHCAPE ROCK

Once a bell was hung on an Inchcape Rock. It was placed there by a pious man. The bell swung back and forth on top of the waves. It gave warning to the people on the ships.

Ralph the Rover was a wicked man. He called his men and told them to throw him to the Inchcape Rock. He cut off the bell from the fleet. He said: "The next who comes to the rock won't bless the Athlet."

Years later the same man came back. The sky darkened with black clouds. They didn't hear any bell and soon after they bumped into the Inchcape Rock. The boat kept sinking down, down, down, until it was at the bottom. Ralph the Rover was drowned in the ocean beneath the tide. He thought he heard, as he was sinking, the bell which he had thrown away.

Greetings:

As this Year Book is written largely by the pupils themselves, and about them, my message is brief.

We take this opportunity of thanking everyone who has contributed to make this year what we believe to be the best in the life of the School. Good health generally has prevailed; discipline has been easier and conduct better; we believe the religious life of the School is on the upgrade; a fine spirit of good fellowship and co-operation is increasingly manifest.

OF SPECIAL NOTE.

A number of changes are recorded in the personnel of the School Staff. Mr. W.M. Reid, senior teacher, being called to a position in the Treasury Department at Ottawa, had to leave at Easter time, and Mr. Ernest McIwen, B.A., is back with us again to supply the vacancy. We are pleased to announce that Mr. Norman McIwen, B.A., will take charge of this room for the coming School year. Mr. G.W. Mathias of Winnipeg, who has had wide experience in the north end with the Indian people, has come to the School as Engineer. Miss Margaret Cochrane, of Carlyle, Saskatchewan, now has charge of the Laundry. Miss L. Maguire of Portage la Prairie, has been appointed as Assistant in the Sewing Department. Mr. Walter Anderson of Moffat, Ontario, who supplied during the absence of Mr. Zoeland last winter, is remaining with us until after the Shorthorn Cattle Sale in September.

A special feature of morning prayers during this calendar year is the rendering of a "thought for the day," a concise nugget of truth. January was taken by the Staff members; the pupils supplied the "thoughts" for February, and did splendidly. Here is a sample of what they contributed: "Life is not a goblet to be drained, but a measure to be filled." Our church officers and leaders kindly responded to our request and supply a "thought for the day" for the month of June, which gave us the opportunity of telling the School about our Church, its work and leaders; and we appreciate this service they have rendered us. Thirty ex-pupils gave "thoughts" for April, and we want them to have November also. Please send them in when you acknowledge receipt of this Year Book.

Nine of the girls took a St. John's Ambulance Course in Home Nursing and First Aid this winter. Classes were held once a week and the girls were keenly interested. Most of the work was done in the hospital wards, the girls learning how to make beds, take temperatures, give medicines, apply poultices, etc., as well as bandaging. The examination was held June 23; the girls all passed and will receive diplomas.
To my fellow graduates, who elected me as valedictorian, I wish to express my gratitude, for I count it both an honor and a privilege. I sincerely hope I shall prove worthy of this honor which has been bestowed upon me.

It is my purpose in this article to glance back over the years gone by and locate the purpose behind them; and then to glimpse ahead and see as far as young eyes can just what the future might hold for us who are graduating; and finally, to say farewell on behalf of the class to the School and its associates.

Our days of school work have come to an end and we are upon the eve of a new life, a life which will call for the best we can offer. We are going out into a world which is full of difficulties and snares, and which is also rich with possibilities, charm and beauty; so we must walk cautiously and choose wisely.

We are at a critical stage in our life's drama. No longer shall we have the kindly guidance of our Principal and his Staff, but must come to our own decisions. We must face such enemies as carelessness, indifference, laziness, and many other things so apt to defeat our better selves. We are now the captain of our own ship of life. We shall decide our own course, fight the storms that arise, and seek the port that we want.

As we leave this School, may each of us realize his or her responsibility. We know that our School stands for the good in life and if we, graduates, can live as we have been taught, we shall not only find the best in life, but we shall strengthen this great School which is doing its utmost for our race. It will be strengthened by every successful graduate and weakened by every failure. Let us then resolve to do our best by our race and by those who have an interest in us.
May our personal lives reflect the great moral teaching of this School. We have been taught to be honest in all matters, pure in thought and deed, kind and sympathetic in our dealings with others, mindful of the rules that govern, good sports in our games, clean and neat about our appearance, and at all times to possess a deep sense of reverence for our God and Creator. These great lessons have been tested in the ages past and their worth proven. May we enrich our lives, and the lives of those around us by living at our best at all times.

To Dr. Doyle, and to the members of his Staff, I want to say that in the years to come, when we are searching out the course of our lives, he and his associates will be as bright beacon lights, lighting up the dark places, and all that we have learned will be as a store from which we can draw.

I now come to the unpleasant task of saying farewell. We graduates shall have many pleasant memories of our experiences here. This building, and its surrounding beautiful gardens and trees have helped us to see God's work in nature; the twinkling of the city lights viewed from the dormitory windows, the rattle of the key in the door at six o'clock in the morning, filing in and out of chapel, and the quiet period of prayer, shall linger with us as long as we live.

Now, I say farewell to the Staff and thank you sincerely for all you have done for our class; and to the students remaining, good-bye and may your days here be fruitful; and to my fellow graduates, Godspeed, and success in all you undertake; and may we all be spared to meet again.

Irene Black.

With the coming of spring our badminton, hockey, and basketball equipment was tucked away; and our attention turned to outdoor sports. Football, softball, and "treck" took the attention of the boys, while softball and folkdancing occupied the girls. The enthusiasm in all branches of sport has been wonderful. At the beginning of the season many defeats came our way, but now as the season wears on our teams are commencing to hold their own.

ROYAL SPORTS DAY.

The first great victory of the season was the three mile road race. Albert Thompson, our star three-miler, running against a field of eight competitors, fought his way through to victory. Second place was taken by Hanson Hart, who edged out Angus Anderson after a hard struggle, giving the first three places to the School.

The afternoon of the 24th was spent in the playing of games on the athletic grounds. Four mixed softball teams were chosen and an exciting tournament followed. No one is quite sure which team was the winner but everyone reports a good time.
We have a number of teams in this branch of our sports, and space does not permit a full discussion of what each team has accomplished. Our senior girls, after losing two games at the commencement of the season, defeated Alexander Junior High, 13-0. The following week, however, the Earl Oxford Girls turned them back with a score of 5-3.

FOOTBALL.

Our senior football has not been so successful. They, as yet, have not won — but are still hopeful. The juniors have a better record, having won two and lost one.

EXCHANGE GAMES WITH PORTAGE.

On May 20th a junior football team of the Portage Indian School played an exhibition game here. It was a real old battle, which resulted in a victory for us of 3-1. The return game, played two weeks later at Portage, was even closer. In fact all that saved our team was the stellar performance of our goalie, Edwin Ryder, who just could not be beaten. Charlie Crow scored the only goal, to give us the game, 1-0.

Portage, however, came back on June 17th with a team of junior girls softballers that "turned the trick". They hit and ran like professionals. Space does not permit mention of the score.

During the past few weeks the fancy of our most "sporty athletes" seems to be golfing. Anything resembling the shape of a golf stick is used and there is no shortage of balls. The occasional shout of "fore" and the "whiz" of the ball may be heard when work is done in the evening.

John Bomar is now employed at the Round Lake School.

During the past year a large number of graduates have visited the School, and we are always glad to see them. On graduation day no less than fourteen former pupils were in the School, among them Ewart Monias and Mrs. Monias (who was Jessie Bear) and little son Leslie, from Nelson House, where Ewart is now the teacher; Walter Maidwood, a graduate of the Agricultural College, now engaged on the University Farm at Winnipeg; Dora Maidwood who is west on a holiday from Hamilton where she is employed; Marita Hart, now on the staff at the Round Lake Indian Residential School; the other nine were young men and women employed on farms and in homes in Brandon and vicinity.

Ten years ago the fine School herd of Dual-Purpose Shorthorns was established, with some splendid foundation cows and an imported sire; and every year secures more than its share of prizes in the Brandon Fair. For the past two years a group from this herd stood first in the local field day judging contest. The herd has so increased that we are compelled this year to hold a sale of our surplus stock, which will take place on September 27.

The annual School Banquet was held on April 21. "The Marionettes of Life" was the theme chosen. The tables were artistically decorated with clowns, favours, and place cards, all carrying out the marionette motif. Miss Gladys Dreaver made a very charming chairman. Her remarks and introductions were very ably handled. The marionette play was put on by the group of girls who had been working on it during the winter. Mrs. Cragg gave the address which was based on the theme of the banquet and was greatly enjoyed by all. Rev. and Mrs. James, Inspector and Mrs. Robertson, Dr. Cragg, Mr. Reid, Miss Davies, and Miss R. Yeomans were among the guests of the evening. All voted it one of the best banquets yet.

Marionettes! What a fascinating hobby! To see cloth and cotton-batting forming into a distinct personality under one's hand is indeed a thrilling experience. This thrill came to seven of our C.G.I.T. girls last winter. Will any one of us forget our cross' old Joanne, our weak-kneed Pedro, the old-fashioned Lord and Lady Baltimore, and best of all, dear old Wilfred, our comical clown. I think Staff and pupils alike were amazed when the marionettes performed so successfully at the Banquet in April; and—whisper it low!—we, behind the scenes felt pricks of pride running up and down our spines as we heard the laughter and applause coming from beyond the footlights. Altogether we voted marionettes a most interesting and profitable project, and we hope to do more with it next year.

HOBBEMA - ALBERTA
Greetings

The Locosin News will continue with its work at this school. Mr. Frohri is the editor and our boys and girls remain feature artists and reporters.

I take this occasion to wish both boys and girls the best of success in their new work, the boys, on the farm and in their new Manual Training Shop; the girls in the different occupations offered them by a practical course on Household Economics.

And as Christmas and the New Year will soon be here, I wish to address my greetings to the staff, to the children of the School and to all the readers of our little paper. A most blessed Christmas to yours and may God's Blessings descend upon you and upon all you do throughout the New Year!
There is not much space here for excuses concerning our very lengthy silence. We will just try to assure you that starting this year with our Christmas number, we will continue hereafter as regularly as before.

Here's this for New Year's Resolution. Let's hope it sticks to it till the end of the school year!

It may be news to many of you to know that in addition to our school, which holds a large recreation hall for the boys in the basement, four classrooms above this and a dormitory for the boys on its second storey, alongside of this building a general manual training shop has been built. This serves the purpose of giving the boys a good practical preparation for adult life on the farm. They spend their mornings in the classroom; while their afternoons are spent working on the farm, repairing shoes or doing work in the shop. Household economics, on the other hand, is the afternoon occupation of the girls.

To complete this, health and recreation are combined in a physical training course given by an instructor, not only to the school boys but also to the young men of the Reserve, who wish to come to the meetings. And above all, the spiritual welfare of the people of the Reserves is continually striving for.

It may well be mentioned here that the staff has already considered the possibility of the school being transferred to other locations until next year. We have been sent here to take over this old church. In the name of the children our heartfelt thanks are addressed to all of them and a lot of others, though it may be, is directed to all the newest arrivals to our School.

Special mention for our School, Sir Isaac Brock, Justice and Strength, must be made for your Spanish Touch of Spirit and Character. Doubtless the students will find that they will last for a long time, which will be amply enough to read in the near future. The Thunder Report! Our sincere wishes for success!

It is also with heartfelt sincerity that our hearts rise for you, dear friends, of all ages and conditions, who have worked so hard and faithfully for the advancement of the new school, and who have been so kind and generous in your support of the school. May God bless you all around through the coming year, and may His grace and mercy be with you always.

In conclusion, we wish you a Merry Christmas and a Happy and Successful New Year!

ENTERPRISE WORK.

We forget to tell you in our last Magazine, that we are doing some enterprise work this year. We began the last of November. One for each of our grades. Grade 4 has one on "Life of the Eskimos". Grades VII and VIII did one on "Poland" and we are still at ours about a trip to "China" and "Japan". We gather information and pictures to help explain our stories. We have what we call the community enterprise on the art board and each boy has his enterprise book which is about the same as the one we are doing in common. The Trip to Japan required twenty illustrated stories. For example, in the first we try to think what the country looks like and show that by pictures along with this first story.

The second is getting on the train from St. Paul. We get a picture that looks as much as possible like a train stepped at St. Paul Station and the boys getting on. Then we study the train itself, the engine, the tender coach and the rail-
The next story is done in the same way about Edmonton and the fourth, about crossing the great plains and the mountains. We follow along to Vancouver and learn about a port city, the harbor with its warfs and finally we explore the ship that is to take us across. What stories and pictures we produce are about the big ocean! We found the work so pleasant that we learned writing spelling and geography without knowing that we did so; because we were on an exciting trip far away Japan. We had stories and pictures about the Chinese eating with chopsticks and they took us through their city in their jinrickshas. We visited their tea and rice fields and we went fishing with them.

Each of these required a separate story and picture to illustrate. When visitors come to our school we like to show them our enterprise work.

Francis Janvier

CHRISTMAS AT BLUE QUILLS

We had a very pleasant and merry Christmas this year. Our school was beautifully decorated for the occasion. The main corridor was pretty with its decorations, and so were our class room and recreation rooms, refectory etc. We enjoyed our midnight Mass very much; and we like to look at the little Jesus in the Crib. We are thanking them in this letter for all this. We promise to be good and do our best. There has not been one run-away this year. We try to be grateful. We also thank Father for our big skating rink, and for giving all the boys a nice pair of skates.

One of our pupils Albert Cardinal has entered St. John's College in Edmonton to continue his course. Albert has spent his Christmas holidays with us and has written an article about his college life.

My Life At St. John's College

On September 6th 1939 I left for Edmonton to go
St. John's College. I was with four boys and a priest from St. Paul. On our way we had a good time but we came to a place where the road was not very good and we had a flat tire. We fixed up the tire and away we went. We started from Blue Quill School around eight o'clock and we arrived at the college at half-past twelve. We took our suit cases out from the car and brought them in.

At first I was not very happy to be away from my friends of Blue Quill's. This lasted about two months but now everything is alright. I hope I will keep on with the college and also finish my time. We are five Indian boys. We started our class work on Sept. 8th and we were to get done on Dec. 13th for the Christmas holidays.

Reverend Father Walter and P. Pratt sometimes come to the college to see me whenever they come to the city of Edmonton. We played a lot of hockey games already. There are three skating rinks at the
college. One for the big boys, one for the midgets and one for the little boys.

Now I am on my holidays. I came back on the train to St. Paul to see my friends. I found the trip pretty long to amuse myself. We are a big bunch of boys from St. Paul who go to St. John's College. We have about two weeks of vacation and I enjoy them. I skate with the boys. Their skating rink is a little bit bigger this year. The ice is not very good yet because they started late but it will get better. I hope we may always keep friendly to each other and in a near future we shall be happy to meet together.

Albert Cardinal
