The wonderful winter weather has been much enjoyed by pupils and staff here, many happy hours of sleighing, skating and skiing have been had and the boys and girls have been doing very well. Good old Santa found us in our new quarters and was as good as ever to the boys and girls of the school. On December 23rd the several branches of the W.A. took part in a pageant commemorating some of the best known carols, the pageant was very beautiful and reflected much credit on our teacher who had worked very hard in getting together suitable costumes. At other times we have always had a store of costumes in the attic of the school to draw from, but this time there was no attic to visit. After the Pageant various members of our club were on hand a brain trust to enable the W.A. to raise a few extra dollars towards the Archbishop Stringer and Johnson Memorial Fund. Everyone was well satisfied with the success of the whole undertaking. Our thanks are due to the local station agent who kindly allowed us to use the Section House for the pageant and for the two parties for the children and their friends which were given one at Christmas and one at New Year. Without this kindly cooperation many of our native friends would not have attended and our present quarters would scarcely permit us to accommodate the number who attend these gatherings.

The various branches of the W.A. held their annual meetings early in January and the election of officers took place and all reports of last year's work have been forwarded to the Diocese Officers.

We welcome to our staff Miss J. Wright as Boys' Supervisor; Miss H. Hewett as Kitchen Matron and Captain Johannes of the Church Army as General Assistant.

ST. SAVIOUR'S CHURCH

(Rev. H. C. M. Grant)

Our regular services have been very well attended this winter, our largest congregation being on Christmas Eve when a very busy carol service was held and much enjoyed. The church was tastefully decorated by the staff and elder girls of the Chootla School. On Christmas day Captain Johannes came preacher and gave a very helpful address.

The scholars of the Sunday School had their Christmas party on the last Saturday of the year and began by enjoying an elephant's ride and ended up by the children receiving gifts and candles from the tree.

The village W.A. were again glad to be able to give gifts to some forty-five children of Carcross Village and district. These were hung on the Chootla School tree and given out by old Santa himself.

In spite of the war clouds which hang over us we look back with a year of prayer and encouragement at St. Saviour's Church for which we thank God and pray for richer blessings in the year that is ahead.
Joys of a Travelling Missionary

The Editor has asked for material with the work dealing with the tasks of the travelling Missionary among the native people of the Yukon. There is so much to tell that one is at a loss to know where to begin or what to say. The work to be done is great, yet we are able to accomplish very little in comparison therewith. However, the means and the work blessed by the Lord are plentiful.

The Bishop of the Diocese visited the mission House for a ten day period. He was joined by Rev. W. Vasey (Rev. W. Vasey) who was also visiting the mission House. The Bishop of the Diocese went to the afternoon of December 24th, with the Christmas tree and party for the children. Nineteen children were present and a happy time was had by all. The confirmation was held of two of our Indian boys, the eldest of the white settlement, girls were presented, after which gifts were distributed to all by Miss L. V. Brower on behalf of Santa Claus, and the children finished the evening by singing carols. On Sunday, December 29th, several of the services and the school children were well known during Evening prayer by Rev. Mr. Brower, followed by Christmas Day service at 11 a.m., and our thanks to the W.A. for their generous gift of toys for the young children who attended. This morning's services were fittingly concluded with a service of Holy Baptism.

An Indian camp is sighted as we travel along the river and almost at once the children see our small red canoe and come out to meet us. We land, pitch our tents and make camp. Our camp is simple, yet we are able to accomplish very little in comparison therewith, yet the men come forward to shake hands while the women stand behind respectfully to await those they may meet. The harvest truly is plenteous, but the labourers are few. (Amen) Bill Little

For the past few years Rev. Mr. Brower has been working among the Indians in the various In- dian encampments along the Yukon River, and he has been very successful in converting many to the faith. This involves travelling by boat and horseback through the wilderness, learning and speaking the two languages, French and English, native and missionary. The Indians are very friendly and welcoming, and the talk while news is being exchanged is very interesting. The regular duties of school teaching do transmit the teachings of the Bible and movements of the church. I am sure that the Indians will benefit from my stay here, and I am confident that they will be converted to the faith. It is a privilege to be able to serve in such a capacity, and I am grateful for the opportunity to do so.

VACATION TIME

When the long vacation comes,
Then no more must call in vain
All the myriad boyhood chums
From outside the schoolroom pane.
Bird and brook and beckoning flowers
Sky and grass and sun in rhyme—
Comrades such as these are ours
In the long vacation time.

O'er the shady swimming hole
Bends the willow as of yore,
Like a gnarled enchanted troll
Watching by a treasure store.
And the pickurcl, Tom Grey,
Laughs his cloe in pantomime
As he thinks of jokos he'll play
In the long vacation time.

Woodland mysteries await
Just the touch of youthful hands,
To unlock the magic gate
Leading into wondrous lands.
And the fish must deeper glide,
And the hangbird higher climb,
And the chipmunk quicker hide,
In the long vacation time.

When the long vacation comes,
In the belfry sleeps the bell;
Undisturbed the blackboard sums,
Lies the crayon where it fell.
And the river goes the brook,
And the hills are crusted sublime,
And the fields are golden seas,
In the long vacation time.
A Timely Review and Appreciation

At the end of this school year I wish to express my thanks to the parents who have cooperated with the staff towards a better education for their children. At the same time, I beg of all others to try to understand a little better the aim of the school, totally directed towards the entire welfare of their children, be it physically or morally, for the present or for the future.

You are all aware now, that with the cooperation of the Indian Agency, we have established a regular manual training course at this school. During the past year we were given some 50 acres of land by the Ermineskin Band. This will help immensely towards the training of the boys in farm work. We have also received sets of tools from the Indian Department. These are used by the boys in their manual training shop.

Satisfying results have been obtained by the boys at their work on our new buildings, on the farm and in the shop. Our senior boys have had the opportunity of following a course on physical training, which has brought them better health, skill in the performance of many thrilling stunts, and great improvement in posture. In the line of sports our boys have worthily played for the honor of the school.

Our senior girls have also accomplished some wonderful work under the direction of the Sisters of the Assumption. Those who have attended the School Exhibit and Concert held here on June the 19th, have seen the results of a year's patient labor at sewing, bead work, knitting, reed work, weaving, cooking and music. The girls also work in the garden, look after the chickens and occasionally milk the cows. In a word, they are well prepared to undertake the daily task, which is the common lot of a housewife living on the farm.

Next September an ex-pupils' Club will be organized and directed by the Principal and the school teachers. Meetings will be held every month. A sewing Club will also be included in this scheme.

I wish to take this opportunity to congratulate all the children for the good work they have been doing this year, and to each and every one of them, I want to wish the best of holidays. Amuse yourselves well, but remember at all times what you have been taught at school. Be kind and useful at home. Make good use of your religion, which is and always will be the guiding light of your life and the secret of your happiness.

Ed. Rhéaume O.M.I.
Principal

CEREMONY MARKS OPENING OF CHURCH
Colorful Parade Of Indians Welcomes Catholic Archbishop

HOBBERMA RESERVE

Hobbema, June 11 - Official opening and blessing of the new Roman Catholic church at the Indian Residential school, on the Ermineskin reserve, was held recently. Archbishop J.H. MacDonald, of Edmonton, conducted the opening.

On his arrival he was met at the Indian agency, half a mile east of the church and school, by a number of horseback riders carrying flags and banners and headed by Constable McGregor, of the R.C.M.P.

The students' band of St. John's College, Edmonton, furnished the music in the parade.

The church was crowded and among those present included: Father A. Anglair, vicar provincial of the Oblates of Mary Immaculate; Father A. Madean, rector of St. John's College, Edmonton; Father Donohue, St. Joseph's seminary, Edmonton; Father McDonald, Wetaskiwin; Bro. Ansbert, rector of St. Joseph's College; Father T. Bouchard, St. Paul; Father P. Gémeche, of Winterburn.

Archbishop MacDonald complimented Bro. Kael for his excellent work in building the new church. Rev. Father Rhéaume is the parish priest of the new church, assisted by Father Moulin, who has been a missionary among the Indian people here for about 35 years.

A banquet was served after the service.
RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL HOLDS OPEN HOUSE

HOPEMA, June 21.—Emmiskin Indian Residential School held open house for the public, exhibiting all their handcraft work for two years. Reed work, beadwork, painting, drawing, quilting, knitting, weaving, and blanket making on their own loom were shown by the girls.

In the morning they entertained the village school children by showing them all through the school and putting on a program. Tea was served in the afternoon, gifts were also shown through the school, and a program was staged by the children.

Loved by speeches by Col. A.G. Blakes, deputy minister of education, and Mr. J.H. Ross, director for health recreation in Alberta.

EMMISKIN DEBATE AMNESTY FOUND

Decision to donate an ambulance to the Royal Canadian Army Medical Corps was made at a Sunday meeting of the Samsen, Kootenay, and South Bull bands of the Cree Indians. It will be on the goldfield reserve. It was announced by Col. A.G. Blakes, who reserve Indian agent, members of the bands had signed an agreement made by local chiefs to donate the proceeds from the sale of the ambulance to the Samsen band.

The bands are composed of about 1,700 members. They will make the donation primarily to the reserve. Alberta unit of the corps the money will be drawn from interest on funds owned by the bands, which ordinarily would be distributed among members on a per capita basis.

Col. and Mrs. A.G. Blakes have recently returned from their holidays in the east.

A Jumble Contest

This spring we followed a Geography Jumble Contest, which was given by the "Library Magazine." We had to find the names of famous towns and cities in North America. The hard part was to unmix the letters of every word and we spent many of our free periods trying to find those names. Everything went all right until the last two or three weeks when the contest became "mucks" and there were 5 words we could not unmix. There were 100 mixed-up words in this contest. In the diocese of Bristol and Caledonia under the famous Mrs. Rector and Mrs. Stott, there is no such lack of work. Thousands have been trained there by means of missionary schools, skilled helpers and serious devotion. This is partly due to the cold and difficulties of climate, but other causes have also been helpful. Peace River and other distant settlements have seen a dramatic growth in their church life. Visitors from the east have been pouring into Peace River and other surrounding areas for missionary training.

Miss Hazel and the Western Canada Caravan Fund

Through the generosity of Mr. Eagleson, Miss Hazel's home, near the Peoria Forks station, will always be remembered with thankfulness. A church and fellow residents may be among those who benefited from this action.

People at lonely places, like Fort Good Hope, always needed help from others. Dick Bowden, a former resident of the area, was among those who helped the people. Dick's wife,who lived nearby, supported the work at the request of the Bishop.

Miss Hazel's home was built in 1931. Miss Nolen's House, built in 1932, was used as a hospital. Miss Wood, an assistant Secretary, lived in the house.

Miss Eagleson and Miss Hazel are now cared for through the S S U T, under Miss Eagleson. Miss Eagleson and Miss Hazel are the only full-time Christian Witnesses in the north of North America.

HOME SWEET HOME

Yes, this title brings joy, happiness and contentment to my heart because I feel, and you all feel the same, I'm sure, that "There's no place like Home".

Before starting our more or less interesting articles, in the name of all the pupils I wish to thank all the Rev. Fathers and Sisters for their kind doings on our behalf. We do not always exteriorly show our love and gratitude, but on the eve of our departure we feel it is our duty to ring out a most sincere and heartfelt "THANK YOU".

It must also be remembered that we have in Mr. Ostrander, a very interested and kind Indian Agent: His monthly school inspections were a proof of his love for us all. Was it not Mr. Ostrander who first suggested that our school put up our Principal's concert in Battleford and was it not he again who arranged all means of transportation. See the following pages. We wish to thank him for his interest in us.

Kate Tootoosis.
Battleford Trip

Before writing about our trip to Battleford, we are happy to let you read an extract from the newspaper Phoenix Star.

BATTLEFORD: "Camouflage" was the name of a play excellently performed on Thursday evening in Battleford Town Hall by a number of pupils of the Indian Residential School. The performance was part of a fine program staged in aid of the Battleford Patriotic Service League and contained a rhythm band selection, mimeograph exhibition, garland drill, chorus dialogue and an exhibition of pantomime. Sixty children took part in the entertainment which was a remarkable demonstration of thorough and effective training. The children appeared in a variety of costumes and the several items gave delight to their many patrons. J.P. Ostrander of the Indian Office made a fitting reference to the accomplishments of the children and the interest of the school in the patriotic work of the community.

Our Principal's Feast

As usual, we celebrated our Principal's feast not exactly on his birthday but the week after, which brought the solemnity of the occasion and many were excited and couldn't stay in place. The bell rang at last for the people on the stage ready to lift the curtain at open. It would be too long to enumerate the details of the concert and so I shall give you the full programme:

- Choir
- Tin Soldier Parade
- Forebearance
- Camouflage Spectacles
- Garland Drill
- Happy Children We
- Orchestra
- Camouflage
- The Strike

After the concert, Father Anglin spoke kind words to us and best of all, granted a long, long holiday. The next morning, we sang at Low Mass and we did our best to please God, but also to please our good Principal who we love very much, and for whom we pray every day at mass.

Doree Benson.

Wallace's drawing shows you the many cars took us to Battleford. We left on May 9th at 11:30 A.M. to arrive in Battleford for a last rehearsal during the afternoon. Then around 5 Sister Superior took us to the school ground where we enjoyed an open air lunch. Since the concert was taking place at 8 P.M., we hurried back to the Hall for the last preparations.

At last, the solemn hour did ring and here we were with our brightest smiles, doing the best we could. Happily
things went on quite smoothly amid cheers and applause, so that by 10.30 we were packing up for home. Now, let's tell you that we were anxious to care for our beds and dream of this happy day by 1 a.m., but the 60 children and their teachers were in the real land of dreams, dear friends, thanks to the organizers of this trip to Battleford, where we were glad to meet our white friends.

M. Madeleine Laliberté

watching... the War!

Although we will be leaving in a few days for our holidays, our hearts are sad and we cannot help sighing at the thought that so many poor soldiers won't enjoy a much needed rest for another unlimited time.

The drastic news of Nazis progress has stirred our fervor and since 6 or 7 days I know that the girls have been making a novena a day during 9 days; we, the boys did not make novenas, but we have been making sacrifices and other special prayers, so that the Allies may win the final victory.

Long Live The King!

Wallace Simagnis

Month of May

I imagine that we were not the only ones to pray more and better than usual during the daily devotions to our dear Mother in Heaven. This war has awakened our faith and shows us that God's anger is overflowing. We therefore asked our Heavenly Queen to stop and appease God's Justice and to grant us peace. We did our best to praise the Mother of God, not only in our hearts but externally, by singing her glories as well as we could. At the beginning of the month all the grades went up to the choir, but then we took turns. The girls were alone for the second week, then as of May 2nd and the kindergarten class. These latter ones were very sweet to hear and had the honor of singing twice. May our prayers be heard! Lucia Sipiweskan.

Fresh Paint

In our Easter edition we spoke about the men breaking down the plastered walls throughout the school. All this is completed and nice cream color ed walls and ceilings are to be seen. Mr. Tellier & B. & L. Righard were on the job. Mr. Dupont worked the wood but when it was done he went back home, surely enjoyed his jiggling and good jokes, as well as those of the three painters who were always in the best of humour.

All is over now and we can enjoy living in a nice clean school which we... will try to keep this way after our holidays.

Frank Benson
Two Good Hikes

During the first days of spring, we were told that the ice was "melting" up in the river near the ferry. We asked Sister Directrice to go and watch this rather unusual float.

Permission granted, we all climbed up and started at 2 p.m. Three Sisters came by the "steps" and finally arrived to see great blocks of ice racing down the current. We aimed at them but our bullets sunk in the river and the big chunks of ice remained unhurt.

We then took another road to come back. We could soon hear the first group having lots of fun; they did not stop to tell us anything. But we soon discovered that the river had flooded the road and it was still very muddy. We enjoyed it, but the Sisters were not so pleased; some had brand new shoes, others nice clean dresses. Yet they managed to hang on the branches near by and save themselves from the biggest holes.

The second hike was to Battle River, but the boys with Father Allard were the only ones to go. They started off at 12:30 p.m. and had a 10 mile walk that day. Half way down, they took off their shoes, rested a while, had their lunch and reached the river to enjoy a swim. Nobody would have ever guessed that, because they came back as black as tigers. I imagine they had a very good sleep that night, and that Father Allard's legs were rather stiff the next day.

PHILomene Peychev—G. Acheynum

Our First Communion

On Trinity Sunday, we were happy children because little Jesus came to visit us for the first time. We asked Him to make us good and to bless our dear Parents and to stop the war. Kind Sister Superior gave us a very good breakfast and very nice holy pictures, and prayer-beads! Now little Jesus often comes to us, and we love Him very much!

Florestine Gaudre.

The Month of May

The last week of May we were invited to sing for the B.V. Mary in the church for the benediction. All the little ones went. We were very glad to sing to our dear Mother Mary. We sang the hymn "Mother dearest, Mother fairest." We hope to go again! Goodbye! Francis Albert

Happy Holidays to all our Friends!

Gilbert Favel.
Bad luck for us all! Why? Well, we haven't the pleasure of the lamps burnt out. Mr. Desjardin took it to Battleford unfortunately no repairs can be made there, so Mr. Desjardin will be sending an order to the U.S.A. to have them done in favour of world peace. The Fathers had theirs burnt too, and Father Allard was seen coming back and forth with our radio under his arm, morning & night, in order to follow the news.

Cherish we will be listening during the holidays, because we will be here during that time, my sisters!

Nadeline and I. —ooo 0 oo—

A Visitor

Last week we had the pleasure of greeting a Sister of the Providence from the Battleford Hospital. She came for the first time among Indians children far up north. Her name is Sr. Alfred-de-la-Croix.

When we went for our class picnic she came along and even raced not with us but with the Sisters. She seems to be very jolly and we felt a little sad whom we saw her going back to her patients. We will pray for her so that God will grant her a real strong health.

Cecilia Wright.

Gardening

Spring, with its beautifying effect always brings in more work to those who really want to make life worth living. So one morning after the usual breakfast show we were called to the garden. Here Father Augin was seen coming along to show us how to soil the school's garden.

We set to work and soon radishes, corn, beans, onions, turnips, lettuce, beans, peas, cucumbers, etc., etc., were very glad to have the opportunity of earning this work so that when we have our own farms, we will be able to put into practice the famous enterprise getting ready for winter.

After our garden is springing up magically, I hope that when harvest time comes along we will enjoy eating a lot of vegetables which are so healthy to boys and girls.

Encantamiento Kisikotagan

RG-M.R. ?????

A few weeks ago many heads were seen peeping in the Parlor. No wonder, two mountain boys were there asking to see Mr. Smith, the school boy. What was the matter? No one could say, until after a half-hour's time Mr. Smith came out. Bunton was called, you can imagine how anxious all felt. Ray and Horatio and I were then called. We were questioned about a certain man from the reserve. When they asked their questions our answers were written down. At last after this half-hour (which seemed longer than that) was passed they left us but our hearts were beating very fast, all thought we acted as witness. I know what it feels to be facing a real police, and hope this won't happen any more.

Leo Roy Jr.

Dr. Wall's Visit

During the whole year, Sister Marie-de-la-Protection the nursing sister treated the trachoma cases; and one day she told us that Dr. Wall was coming to our school. He comes to see if there is any new cases. In the treatments and if there are any new cases.

As expected no arrived and examined us all. To his satisfaction and much more to our delight, he cancelled our cases from the white list! We now have only 10 cases, 3 of which have copper stick, while the other were treated with copper chloride ointment and a tablet which has been discontinued recently. We were glad of the result and we wish to thank Sister for the good care she has given to all.

New Back Stop

We would be very ungrateful if we did not thank Father for the excellent job he did in the making of our football backstop. I think that in one way we have been very lucky to have it because the boys have got through it. Of course they had their skating rink during winter, so that our turn has come.

It would be very interesting for me to tell you about the boy's games played after the diamond was through, but I should be cheating all the girls who refer to the Sport Page. A thousand thanks, Father Tetreault for all your work done in the girls' school yard.

The Demas Oil Well

I wonder why the Gr. 7 and 9 girls don't speak about their trip to the Oil Well? Whatever the reason is, I'm sure the best I can do is tell you what they said their teacher to go and visit the Oil Well. Sister gave her consent but said to go and visit the Oil Well. Sister sent them to Rev. Fr. Principal. You should have seen them rushing to the Rectory. Their wings were very swift that morning and their faces shinning brightly when they came out. They had the permission of the Rev. Fr. Tetreault to take the car down in his car. As they arrived, they were a little afraid to see that the employees were drilling the well. They were surprised to see the size of the pipes sent into the ground as well as the height of the "tower" holding the giant pally. Father took them all over and explained the functioning of the steam engine, the use of the different instruments of the steam engine, a little more of an oil and gas well. All thanked the kind Father for the ride and enjoyed a good dinner.

After working hard the whole year through and harder still during the Promotion tests, we were very happy to get the result of our year's work. The many readers of "Oke-Nape" will wonder at its long silence; we wish to state here that having lost its editor, it has only now recovered from the shock.

"Oke-Nape" owed its existence to the zeal of our regretted Father Lessard, O.M.I., who left us in November to take charge of the parish at Cochrane, with its surrounding missions.

"Oke-Nape" as well as its readers, wish him every success in his new work, and take advantage of this occasion to express their sincere gratitude to him for his ever ready cooperation in the welfare of the school during his stay among us.

"Oke-Nape's" successor will don the modest title of "Crowfoot Arrows", and will endeavor to keep its readers interested in the school doings. It will be reduced to a quarterly number, however, due to the many duties incumbent on the new staff as well as their financial conditions.

Our earnest endeavor will be to make up for quantity by quality, and since all great undertakings have humble beginnings, we hope that "Crowfoot Arrows" will grow with the years and fulfill our optimistic dreams.

To our many friends we present---

Sept. 3rd...

School Bells Ring.

On Sept. 3rd, the school bells called us back to school. We were very glad to start school again. All the boys and girls that were in my grade had passed their grades, so we moved to the Senior class. My brother and three other small boys came to school for the first time. There are six new girls since school opened. We are happy in our school and we hope this year will be a good one all through.

Alma Crowchief.

Sept. 27th...

Sister Superior's Feast.

On Sept. 27th, it was Sister Superior's patronal feast. We all went to mass, sang hymns and received Holy Communion for her intentions. After our meal and work, we went to the hall and played games, Chinese checkers, Monopoly, etc. Sister Superior came and played Bingo with us, and gave each winner a prize. Sister Superior gave us a treat of candy and peanuts, and we enjoyed ourselves very much on that day. We hope she will give us more holidays of this kind.

Elizabeth Little Chief.

Sept. 30th...

Picture Shows.

We have been having catechism picture shows since last Sept., and we like them very much. We pay 1¢ for a show and when Sister has enough she gets a moving picture reel with the money. Some of the movies we have so far are: Robinson Crusoe, Son of Tarzan, The Little Defender, Australia, Tin Hoss, London on Parade and The Lightning War, also some Indian and Educational pictures. The Lightning War was very exciting, but sad; it gave us an idea of the sufferings the people of Europe had to endure when their country was bombed. I am glad I am a Canadian. We all pray for peace every day.

Clara Calf Robe.

Oct. 15th...

Forty Hours Devotion and Retreat.

Our annual retreat begins today and co-incides with the ceremonies of Forty Hours Devotion. Rev. Fr. Olde, the pastor of Holy Family parish in Calgary presides at all the exercises and instructions, and knows how to hold the interest of his audience. We will strive to put into practice the fatherly advice he gives us, and make our lives truly Christian ones in order to save our souls and help others to do so.

Michael Cat Face.

Oct. 16th...

X-Ray and Clinic.

Our clinic and X-Ray days took place this month. The car made many trips before we all had our turn. When we had finished some of us went to pay a visit to Helen Spring Chief who is a patient at the hospital. After a few weeks two doctors of the clinic returned for the reports. There are just a few observation cases this year which goes to show that the good care we are getting is gradually stamping out the dreaded disease of T.B.

Maggie Storm.
Oct. 23rd.

Netoy-kissus: Loves,

We are all sorry to see our dear Father Lessard leave us today. He has gone to take charge of the parish in Cochrane. When he left we were all standing at the gate to bid him a last Goodbye. He had a new car; it is a coupe. Later on Father Gaudet went to see him; when he came back he told us that Father Lessard would come to visit us the following week. We were very glad to see him again. We thanked him for his visit and asked him to come again. We hope you are well, Father.

Betsy Cutter.

God English.

When we came back in Sept., Sister Superior told us that she wanted us to learn the English language very well, and that we were to speak English all the time except on Thursdays and Sundays. The one that spoke the most English was to wear a medal with a gold cross upon it, so under the cross the word "English".

One day Sister Superior came into the senior class-room and asked who had won the medal. All the boys and girls said that Clarence LeHugh and I spoke the most, so we drew for the prize. I got the prize, which was one dollar, but as Clarence had worked hard too, I gave him half of it. We thanked Sister Superior for her kindness and promised to do our very best in "English".

Florence Carrier.

Oct. 30th.

"Spooks"

We had our Halloween party on Thursday night. We dressed in our best and went downstairs to the boy's hall, which was nicely decorated for the occasion. The Fathers and Sisters were there also, and when they arrived we started to play games. The first game was blowing out candles in a pumpkin with our eyes blindfolded. Sister named those that were to play so that every one would have the chance at some game. The last one was playing a tail on a large cat. Every winner had a prize after the games were over. Sister Superior gave us some candies, popcorn, and apples. A movie of Felix the Cat at the north pole ended our party and we went to bed tired but happy.

Cecile Slough.

Nov. 9th.

Primary teacher leaves.

Our primary teacher, Sister Ernest Marie, left for her annual retreat and did not return. We all miss her very much, especially her pupils, who has gone to Peace River, and Sister Superior is now teaching the babies until a new teacher comes.

Julia Thayer Sams.

Domestic Science.

This year the girls of Grades V and VI have Domestic Science training in the morning. We do not go to school at all in the morning. We take turns at sewing, cooking, baking, etc. In our sewing course we learn to do plain sewing, embroidery, mending and knitting. Last month Sister told us we were to make a set of new aprons soon; we wanted to make them right away, so she let us start. When the aprons are finished we will make a set of dresses. We will wear our new aprons at Easter.

In our cooking classes we learn how to cook, to prepare and serve meals. We make fancy dishes and like to decorate the cakes and salads, etc. This will help us for our future life, so that we will be good housekeepers later on.

Florence Carrier.

Nov. 17th

Death of one of our Pupils.

Helen Spring Chief was a T.B. patient; she spent a month in the school infirmary then went to the San. After a few months she came home and then stayed at the hospital. Then one Friday night, Sister told me to go with one of Helen's best friends to see her as she was dying. We went with Father Gaudet who gave her the last Sacraments. My older sister was there too, Helen was glad to see us. On the following Sunday the nurse phoned to say that she had died. It was a sad day for us. My parents came to take me home. The next morning we had the funeral mass here in the church. The pupils sang the Mass. I am sure Helen is in heaven for she had a great devotion to the Blessed Virgin Mary. When she burned a vigil night she would ask Sister to open the chapel door so she could see it at the Blessed Virgin's statue. She always called her "My Mary". I miss my little sister very much.

Mary Louise Spring Chief.

Dec. 5th

School Inspector's Visit.

Mr. McCullough our school inspector came to see us. He went to the Junior class first. In the p.m. he came to the seniors. He asked us to sing for him, then talked about the stampede. He said he would come again later, and he did so. We like to have him come, he is very interesting and we feel very much at home with him.

Philip Many Bears.

Dec. 23rd

Quarantine.

Our agent, Mr. Gooderham, put a notice on the door prohibiting useless visits. We are also forbidden to go out. This precaution is taken to prevent contagion from the various epidemics breaking out on the reserve.

Alma Crowchief.
Dec. 24th.

Midnight Mass.

We had Midnight mass in our chapel on Christmas eve. The sisters awakened us by singing carols and playing musical instruments. Sister Mary was playing the violin. Some of us thought we were dreaming; it was very nice. We were all able to be in the chapel as no outsiders came because of the quarantine. The school choir sang the High Mass, and sang Christmas hymns at the second Mass. The following children made their First Holy Communion at Midnight Mass:
Doreen Running Rabbit---- Doris Owl Child---- Mable Black Kettle-----
Audrey Calf Child---- John Red Gun---- Ronald McHugh---- Cecilia Many Bears. The altar was decorated with natural yellow chrysanthemums. It all looked very nice. There were natural flowers at the crib also.

Clarence McHugh.

Dec. 25th.

Concert and Christmas tree.

On Christmas morning when we came to the breakfast table we each had an orange and some candies at our place. After breakfast we did our work then played outside all the rest of the morning. For dinner there was turkey with all its trimmings and pie for dessert. It was a real Christmas dinner. At 2 p.m. we had Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament after that we had our concert. Our parents could not come because of the quarantine. Some of the numbers on the program were: The making of the British Flag..... A Japanese drill..... The Snowflakes..... and Bernice Black sang a song called "Everybody calls me Tommy". She was dressed in black. Just before last song Santa's load arrived with all the toys. We boys received two nice toboggans from Sister Superior, a big one for the older boys and a smaller one for the little fellows. We were very pleased and we gave three good cheers for her. Many of the boys had new skates and hockey sticks. We have lots of fun playing hockey, skating, and tobogganing down the hill.

Alexander Scalp Lock.

New Uniform for our Band.

When we played our rhythm band at the concert we had new uniforms on; nice red caps with caps to match trimmed in yellow. They looked very nice all together on the stage. The instruments were also decked out in the same colors. We like them very much and are grateful to Sister for making them. It is too bad our parents could not see us.

Cecilia Many Bears.

Jan. 1st.

New Years Day.

We greeted the New Year with attendance at Holy Mass. The altar was so pretty with its natural flowers and colored lights. After Mass we went down to a nice breakfast of Puffed Wheat, doughnuts and fruit. Then we did our work. After that we went to the hall and played games. Sister Superior came and played Bingo with us; she gave prizes to the winners. Then came a nice treat of candy. After a big turkey dinner we went sleighriding with our new toboggans. We started the year by having lots of fun.

Annie Leather.
Jan. 4th.

Twin Wedding Bells.

We had a double wedding in our church. Gilbert Bear Hat and Neil Selway both ex-pupils were married to girls from the Anglican School. The two girls spent a few weeks here before Christmas taking instructions from Father Riou, in order to be received into the church. They were both baptized before their marriage. The two couples looked very nice; the two brides were dressed alike in floor-length white silk dresses, with long white veils and each carried a nice bouquet of roses. The pupils sang the mass; we had to wait quite a while for them to come, as it took the brides a long time to dress up. After the mass they had their pictures taken.

Alec Red Gun.

Feb. 3rd.

Patient To The Hospital.

One of the pupils, Evelyn Black, left today for the hospital. She was sick only a few days, and nearly died. Father went to give her the last sacraments, then she got better. We prayed for her and made sacrifices for her too. She is not well enough to come back to school yet, we will be glad to see her back.

Many babies died this year on the reserve from the whooping cough and the flu. We were very lucky, as none of the children here got any of these sicknesses.

Charlotte McHugh.

Changes.

Many changes took place among the sisters this year. Sister Clara Etc., Sister Agnes Rita have both been changed and sent to other missions. The sisters who came to replace them are Sister Alino of Charity, who is in the girl's Department, and Sister Boncuit, who takes the dairy work. Some of our parents know Sister Boncuit, as she was here many years ago, and they were very glad to see her back. Sister Gabriel Alphonse teaches the beginners class.

Radios in the Classrooms.

When the inspector came he asked to have the radios installed in the classrooms so that we might listen to the news and the different programs on school work. Every Wednesday we listen to the program given by the Lethbridge School. We enjoy our radios very much.

Annie Leather.

Feb. 14th.

Valentino Party.

On Valentino day we had a party in our classroom. We invited the other classes to attend our party. First we sang a song of welcome, then we were ready for our Valentino box of candies. To get this box each one had to do the stunt that was written on the slip of paper in the box. Some were very funny and although we were a bit shy to perform these stunts before the pupils, we did not shirk the task. We all got a box well earned. Then we had some races, games, etc., with prizes for the winners. Sister Hildobert had made a large cookie for the little class, oh it was such a large cookie, each one had to take a big bite.
take a big bite, but there was still much left, so each one had two more bites. Then the Valentines were given out. We enjoyed our Valentine party.

Rosie Medicine Shield.

Feb. 21st.

The Story of Fabiola.

Every Friday afternoon we all gather in the one classroom to hear the story of Fabiola. We are to have the movies of this story on Easter Sunday. Sister is telling us the story so we will understand the movies better. The film is quite expensive so we are giving each ten cents to help pay for it. It will also be shown to the Indians of the Reserve for the same price. This is a story about the martyrs during the time of the persecution of the Christians in Rome. It will help us to appreciate our beautiful religion still more.

Jane Drunken Chief.

Feb. 22nd.

The quarantine is at last lifted from our doors. It was there as a measure of precaution, and not because we had any contagious disease. But, hurrah! today it has been removed and we are free to go out once more. We were allowed a full day, so our parents came very early in the morning to take us home. The weather was very nice and nearly everyone went home. Those who had to stay at the school because their parents lived too far, said they had a good time also. Now we go home every Saturday.

Irene Cutter.

Feb. 28th

A nice Surprise.

On the 28th some sisters went to Midnapore to be present at the profession of vows of two sisters. What was our surprise when two of the girls were chosen to accompany them. I was one of the lucky ones and the other was Bernice Blank. We got up very early in the morning and went down for some breakfast. We had to hurry, for Mr. F. Corbiell our driver, was waiting for us. We started off when the children were just getting up.

When we got near Calgary something went wrong with the car but we were near a garage and soon had it fixed. We were late for the Profession ceremonies but on time for Mass. The Bishop and many priests and sisters were present. The children sang hymns and they sing very well. We had dinner and went to Benediction. When it was all over we went to the playroom and Bernice sang for the girls. Sister gave her some candy and a little girl called Dolly gave her a little Scotch doll. The girls at Midnapore are always very nice to us when we go there, and it makes us feel like wanting to stay with them. We are glad to have them as our friends. We started for home at 4 p.m., and arrived here at 6 p.m. We enjoyed our trip very much and were told it was a reward for our good conduct. I am very glad now that I tried to be good.

Rita Running Rabbit.
Mar. 3rd.

New Missals.

Sister Superior bought some new prayer books for us. They are called "My Sunday Missal" by Father Stodman. We each have one and we follow the mass with the priest and answer all together. We use them every time we go to mass, and we like to get up for mass now because we find it so interesting. On Sundays when Father reads the gospel we follow it in our Missal. We like to answer in Latin, and like our books very much. We also use them for the way of the Cross. Father reads the prayers from our Missal then. We understand more about the mass now.

Paul Scalp Lock.

Signs of Spring.

Many of our Canadian Bombers and fighter planes are seen around here every day. Some of them fly very low over the school while others circle around it and then go away. The pilots are training so that they can go and help to win the war.

Spring is near also, for a flock of wild geese were seen returning from the south where they went to spend the winter. At first we thought they were aeroplanes in small groups. The swans, ducks and geese, and other smaller birds are coming to spend the summer with us. I like to watch the flocks of geese go by.

Leo Pretty Young Man.

New War Songs.

Our teachers have been teaching us some new war songs. Here are some of them:

There'll always be an England,
Good Luck to the Boys of the Allies
A soldier I'm longing to be
Our own red, white and blue.
Hero comes the thistle,
Bluebells of Scotland,
God Bless our Canada.

We like war songs best of all and find them easy to learn. We are soon going to have a movie show of "Bombs over Burma". It makes us feel thankful that we are not some of the bomb victims.

Margaret Cat Face.

The pupils of the senior class wish to thank their new friends from Woonsocket for the interesting letters they send. We are always so pleased to get them, and we think it is very nice of you to think about us. It is nice to exchange thoughts and prayers too. We know God will bless you for your kindness to others, and for making others happy. Our greetings to all of you in your far-off country. We hope you will like our school paper.

"Tepee Tales."

"Father," said little Red Bird, who had already seen eight sunrises, "why do you always carry with you that arrow in a boundless case when you are on the war-path? Is it a magic arrow? Did it belong to a spirit?" The old man smiled at little Red Bird, for the arrow had a story, one which brought back sweet memories to him, memories which gave him courage, memories which stirred up thoughts of pride because he was brave and strong.

"Come, little Red Bird, sit near me here by the campfire and I will tell you the story of my arrow. You have now seen eight sunrises; you will understand its meaning. Look at your dear Mother standing yonder under the pine trees; she is beautiful, she loves us, she has brought much happiness to our wigwam. It was this arrow found her, that is why I call it 'Sacred Arrow.'"

Once when our tribe was on the war-path seeking revenge against an enemy tribe, my father was leaving us to follow them. I was still young but fearless; I longed to follow him, but they scorned my tender age. Still, I would not be left behind. When they were afar off I silently followed them, intending to make known my presence whom we would be too far to return. The tribe was wary to attack had killed many a father many years before; it was the thought of revenge that had spurred me on. I had carefully kept my father's bow and arrows which my mother had given me, and I took them along on my secret journey. On the third day they camped near to the snow; I was sure they would attack the next morning, but when they woke they had gone from my sight. Try as I would, I could not follow them; I soon realized that I was lost. I went on for three days, and now had no more food. The sound of rippling water made me feel a burning thirst; I went towards the sound. I came to a beautiful lake. A flock of geese were coming towards it. I was hungry, here was food. I drew my bow, let fly the arrow, and saw my prey fluttering to the ground. Leaving my horse to munch the green grass, I went to get the bird. But as I approached the edge of the lake I saw at a little distance the slender form of an Indian maid wading through the water towards the wounded bird. Silently I drew back beneath the shelter of the trees and watched her. With eyes turned heavenward I heard her murmur these words, 'Great giver of all good thou art so pity on thy children dying of hunger. Here is food that will make us live.' I wondered at these words and felt pity in my heart for the hungry. She trembled as she drew the arrow from the breast of the bird, did she fear an enemy had shot it? Advanced and as she looked up put up my hand as a sign of peace. Breathlessly she waited. I asked the meaning of her words. This is what she answered. Many weeks before her tribe had been attacked and beaten by an enemy tribe. Her father and brothers had been killed, her mother badly wounded, and she had begged her daughter to take her away from the camp and let her die in peace. After many miles of struggling they had set up their little tepee near the lake and lived on fish. But the mother was slowly...
finding away. When she had finished her sad tale I looked into her dark eyes and said, "I will help you." We sat there and prepared the bind for a meal. The broth we gave to the dying mother. Slowly, little by little her strength returned and she was soon strong enough to travel. We left then, not to follow those of my tribe, but turned towards our camping ground. The arrow that had brought me this new-found friend, I kept with me always. That little Indian maid is your mother and always I have thanked the Great Spirit who send her to me. The Grandmother died a few months later, happy to know that her daughter had found a good home.

The arrow brings to me good fortune wherever I go; it will always be kept as sacred to me. That little Red Bird, is the story of "The Sacred Arrow."

The Religious Corner.

On awakening in the morning behold the good God extending His hand to you, saying, "Do you wish that I should care for you today?" And you, give your hand to this good Father, and say to Him: "Yes, Lord, be guard me, love me; I will be very, very submissive."

And if you remain under the guidance and the protection of God, is it possible that you should be sad, or fearful, or unhappy?

No, God will never permit a suffering which will hurt your spiritual welfare. No, God will never permit a trial which is not for your good.

Oh, then, spend your day calmly and tranquilly, more securely than when you were a child and felt your mother near you.

Occupy yourself with but one thing—the fear of displeasing God—and you will see how God will occupy Himself with all that relates to your eternal interests, friendly relations, business affairs. You will be astonished at the sudden lights which will come to you, and the peace which will result from your labor and undertakings.

"Lord, for to-morrow and its needs,
I do not pray,
Keep me, my God, from stain of sin,
Just for today."

Anonymous.
Easter Message

He Is Risen

Our Lord Jesus Christ suffered and died for the sins of all mankind. He was crucified on Good Friday. The third day after His death He rose glorious from the grave in spite of the stone and guards, never to die again.

The pious women first discovered that the grave was empty, and were told by the Angel, "Christ is risen". They hurried to tell Peter and the other apostles about Christ's Resurrection.

Now let us join in the festivity of the Church and rise from our sins, for has not the Church made it a commandment for every Catholic able to do so, to confess his sins and receive Holy Communion at least once a year at Easter time?

If we want to arise glorious and immortal in our bodies for our happiness in Heaven, on the day of the Last Judgment, we must heed the lesson of Jesus, and receive His Body and Blood in Holy Communion. He will increase our faith, help us, guide us to that glorious life with Him for ever in His beautiful Heaven.

On April 13th Easter Sunday at Crowfoot School, Confessions Will be heard. Come early, Communion given and High Mass sung by the pupils. In the afternoon a Moving Picture of the Persecution of the early Christians under the title of Fabiola will be shown in the school auditorium at 2.30 P.M.

Holidays

Holidays...........a word full of meaning to pupils as well as to grown-ups, a word upon which all must meditate seriously. When we speak of holidays, we instinctively think of "liberty." To some "liberty" means no self control, life with principles left at the "work-shop," duty, only when back to "work."

These ideas about liberty are false and it is wise to remember that holidays are only days of rest for your mind and for your body. Rest does not mean laziness, nor 2 months to kill time and to dream, on the contrary, they are a change in life where we can make others happy & contented.

Having clean fun, playing from morning till night, roaming in the woods for wild berries, hunting, fishing having a regular after noon nap, destroying crows' nests, playing soft-ball with friendly opponents, that's what we call clean fun.

It might be remembered also that Mass on Sundays is as important during the holidays as it was in the "work shop" months. Not going to mass on Sundays is a mortal sin if there is no special reason for missing it. Since we tried to take the habit of offering our actions to Jesus, why not keep on during the holidays and find out what our "will power" is worth............If we continue this daily offering or all our actions, we are sure to see our morning and night prayer.

Don't forget that respect and obedience to your dear parents is a sacred duty and they are expecting this from their children. Re-read this article and surely you'll enjoy the most cheerful holidays you've ever spent.

A Friend
A Sad Departure

Since our dear "Thunderer" we have lost a good friend. Father Chataigner. He felt sorry because he had worked hard for our souls and never spoke to himself in giving us good advice and in teaching. He wrote twice, since he is going to be very lonely out there in Lac la Biche; I hope that some day he will be back in Delmas. I wish to thank him for all he has done to the Delmas Indian children. May God grant him millions of graces and help him in his new missions.

Marguerite Koosoonin.

Our New Father

Father Paradis is the priest who replaced our good Father Chataigner. We were anxious to know him. After passing a few months in Duck Lake, he seemed glad to know other Indians. He is named to learn cree and to go on all our Reserves. It was the lucky first boy to go with him in Poundmaker. I liked him right away and I think that the Indians on the Reserves like him also, because they say nice things about him. The Sport Page will tell you about the many ball games which he organized with Father Paradis. He is a real, good sport and we hope that we will be able to enjoy other hot games after the holidays.

Walter Tootoosis.

Nature's Science

This is a subject we love very much. Nature is a very nice book and we love reading in it. So as soon as it was convenient for us to start our hiking, we didn't miss our chance. We made a lot of work ahead of us because we had to make a collection of harmful and useful insects. Since the beginning of April, our room has been a regular bug house! We found many kinds of insects put the worst was to get their names. It might interest you to know some of them. We labelled bees, cabbage butterflies, lady beetles, ants, and flies in their different stages. We are taking home in the hope of complete study. I suppose we won't know all their names just when we come back in Sept., our teacher will help us out again.

Florence Kiskotagan.

Our Aquarium

We have had "youth luck" with our aquatic inhabitants. In early Sept., Sister Marie Alberta sent us 2 nice gold fish. We were very proud of them, but temperature came to "fishy cat" and one day she scratched both us for "not being well". We felt sorry because we noticed that they were leaving the school and caught 2 bull frogs, and two tree frogs. Just now we have many tadpoles in the aquarium. I hope that when we come back after our holidays, we will see their legs and their tails disappearing.

Clara Wright.
Visitors from Alberta

Father Tetreault had a very pleasant surprise one morning. His sister from Alberta came with her family. She has four children; the eldest one is Lillian. We think she is a very nice girl.

In the afternoon, they took snap-shots of some of the girls. I was one of them. A little later, we went to the ball game and they came along. Unfortunately we lost. The Sport Page will tell you about it.

Their visit was a short one because they arrived for dinner and left before supper yet their trip was short but sweet! We hope to see them again until then we hope that our Thunder Report will be sent to the family.

Seeding the Garden

As usual, the senior boys and girls went out seeding the garden. This time we wanted to make a record and we succeeded; all was over in an hour's time. We put in turnips, string beans, corn, radishes, onions, lettuce, garlic, carrots, string beans, tomatoes, peas, cabbages and potatoes. When this job was over, we all went to weed the rest of the garden. It was lot of fun getting through quick grass. Doris Laiberty and Clara Wright, 4 or 5 ft. patient digging finally got a root measuring 4 or 5 ft.

Sister was surprised...we had tried many times to get so well that they really looked promising. Since then we have watched the garden grow. The rain has given it a good start, but we could use more rain.

I think that Sister Marie Stanislas can be proud of her nice garden, she is the one who takes care of it.

Train to Battleford

If you remember well, after our Local Dramatic Festival, we were invited to the Battleford Achievement Day. We went there April 25th and were invited to repeat our play "What a Mix-Up" in the Connaught School in North Battleford. This was an exciting moment. But we managed to pull through quite well. While in North Battleford Hall, we were not the only pupils on the beach. Three other schools came on the stage also. It was very interesting to watch the puppet show. Those boys and girls must be clever to have the dolls dancing without having them all entangled up.

We came back on time to enjoy a good supper. Joe Marcellar Rodden told us he had had a very peaceful night.

We all wish to thank our good Father Principal for paying for our trip to the Neighbouring City.

Irene Stapkowsky.

The Lady Beetle

Do you want to know what a Lady Beetle is? Here is her life. She is very useful as well as pretty. She usually wears a red or yellow dress with black dots for ornament. Although her legs are short, she can run quickly. Then she wants to go a long distance she changes herself into an airplane and flies.

Lady Bird spends the winter under the bark of a tree. In spring she comes to the orchard and runs up and down the trees in search of aphids or other naughty insects. She lays her eggs there too. The baby ladybirds who look nothing like their mother, spend their time hunting aphids and other pests.

Frodeline Kiskotagan.
Phone Calls.

One Saturday morning, all the girls working in the Fathers' Rectory had a grand time calling their teacher to the phone. It was funny to see them some held the receiver by the wrong end, others spoke in it while others were puzzled and did not know what to say.

Our teacher from the school asked them all kinds of questions and most of them could only say "yes" or "no." Luckily, some good souls came to our rescue and the conversation picked up a little. That was a very practical lesson and we wish to thank the Fathers and Sisters.

Lucie Chatsis.

New Organ.

We had another proof of our good Principal's kind heart. In the beginning of May we said "Good-bye" to our old organ, Mr. Peil, from Edmonton. Claire-Lucie is living in Battleford where his sisters, Claire-Lucie and Beate, are teaching. Father Angin arranged things in such a way, that since then we have a brand new organ. Protection is very happy she always has an nice broach still since then.

Thanks a lot dear Father Angin. Lillian Albert.

Bread Cutter.

Poor Frank Benson who has been slicing the bread for at least two years with an old rig, and the pleasure of using a brand new one which cost $198.00. By the price you can easily imagine that it is one of the latest style. Thanks a lot to our good Fathers again for this good bargain.

Felix Simagnais.

Exhibition Work.

On April 25th a Musical Festival was held in the St. Jean-Baptiste de la Salle School. The time arrangements had been made by Miss Angin and her pupils from the Delmas District were there also took part and were fortunate enough to come first in the 1st Group of Girls under 13. I was the lucky winner in the 2nd Group of Girls 18 over. Florence also came first. As far as the songs for the group of boys, Daniel Lafrance was the best. The results are not yet known since we are in competition with other urban schools. Let's hope the results prove satisfactory.

Lillian Albert.

The First Visit of Jesus in Communion

How happy we were on Trinity Sunday to receive Jesus in Holy Communion for the first time.

We were 23 children in all, 10 boys and 13 girls.

We prayed for all our relatives and friends. We asked dear Jesus to bless the holidays. Good luck to all!

Victoria Meechan Jr.Gr.I
Many of us are wondering whether Father Routier will be named "Provincial" or not. This year the nomination is delayed on account of the terrible war, but we ardently wish he would be elected for another term. When he visits us he is very kind and we know that he is interested in all the Indians, but especially in the Indian Schools. Let's hope our wishes come true.

Maggie Tootoosis.

Another Edmonton Visitor

Miss Gerard from Edmonton and a sister to one of White School teacher, Sister St. Gamma was here for a week. I imagine these two sisters had a grand time together, because Miss Gerard seems to be a very jolly girl.

We were glad to have her come with us to the woods one Saturday morning. Although we bigger boys were not in her group, we saw her learning how to shoot with a sling-shot, then with Father Tetreault's 22. Unfortunately her bullet killed "spayc".

The girls told us about the little dolls which she dresses as "novices" of the Sisters of the Assumption. She made about 100 of them, these are for Rev. Mother Marie-Eustelle, who sells these at her annual bazar, the profits of which go to the Sisters of the Assumption in Japan.

Felix Simaganis.

We have just learned that Sister St. Clothilde and Sister Marie Alberta will be here around the 26 or 27 of this month. We wish to tell them how happy we are to see them again. We also wish them a happy trip to Meadow Lake.

Battle River Picnic

Last Friday, June 20, the Sr. Class had a grand surprise! Our teacher announced that at 10 that morning we were leaving for Battle River in Mr. John's "Royal Carriage". Dark menacing clouds made us shiver, but when our "grub" was all ready we started off just the same.

You should have seen the smiling faces, the joyful outbursts of our "noisy ones". Arriving there, the boys threw their shoes away and jumped in the water. The girls soon followed until dinner time.

At 12 we enjoyed the meal and right after, we sailed off in the "Royal Carriage" across the river to land in an open space where we enjoyed a good softball game against the boys. Once more we took honours and the poor boys had to cheer for us all.

Races followed, but this time it was the boys turn to win. Nevertheless we came pretty close beating George.

If the chilly weather had not accompanied us all the day long we would have enjoyed a good swim; yet we still had lots o' fun and it was not until 7 p.m. that day, that we came back home.

Maggie Tootoosis

Prizes and Promotions

As usual, Father Angin gives prizes in money at the end of the year. Those who have come first all year in their grade got $5.00. But this year none of us had this big prize. Lucie and Juliette Tootoosis had the most, each received $1.50.

The exciting moment was not yet over, because our promotions had not been given. Some were rather disappointed when they heard the terrible "fail". Out of 110 pupils going to school, only 13 failed. This means that we have been working hard.

We were told to come back on due time. Now this means to be back in the Thunderchild School on Sept. 1st, so that we be all ready to start another good school term.

A MESSAGE.

"Crowfoot Arrows" dart forth once more on their mission of love. Their first appearance met with words of welcome and appreciation from interested readers. Among others we wish to mention in particular our devoted school inspector, Mr. R.V. McCullough, whose complimentary letter will repay the efforts we put forth in this work. To Mr. McCullough and all the other readers who so kindly gave encouragement, we wish to express our deep appreciation and sincere gratitude.

Our second edition appears on the very outset of the summer vacation. No doubt a note of joyous anticipation will be detected throughout these pages; anticipation of the sense of freedom that vacation time offers to both young and old.

FREEDOM—a thing good in itself, if used rightly, but a dangerous thing also, as its very essence breathes alluring temptations. While at school we are under the strain of certain obligations, we have rules to submit to, teachers to obey, lessons to learn. During vacation we break away from these obligations, and rejoice in the thought of being free for two long months.

FREEDOM—yes, there can be freedom from work or studies, but there can be no freedom from duty. Duty towards God by prayer and worship, our parents' duty towards our selves. Vacation time will be filled with occasions of putting this duty into practice. Let us not forget that all the good that vacation time offers us is given by God; therefore, duty of gratitude. Surely, we can acknowledge His gifts of nature with a simple word of thanks.

Duty of kindness and thoughtfulness towards our neighbor; there is always happiness in doing good to others. Duties towards our parents, rendering them the services of love that are denied us during our school-days. Duty towards ourselves; keeping our minds and hearts pure, living clean, honest lives. This is real freedom, found only in the peace of a good conscience.

Let us make of these two months of freedom a milestone on our long voyage to Eternity. Let it make us better men and better women, that when the school-bell rings once more calling us back to our tasks, we may return with the assurance of a vacation well spent.
SUMMER.

Summer now has come upon us,
Summer with her dazzling sunshine,
With her soft winds gently breathing
O'er the prairies, through the forest.
With her fragrance, sweet as honey,
With her songsters and her flowers.
Summer with her clouds of silver,
Floating onwards in the heavens.
All the meadows wave with blossoms,
All the woodlands ring with music,
All the trees are dark with foliage,
As the Summer queen approaches.
All the earth is bright and joyous,
All the air is full of sweetness,
Tree-tops whisper—murmur softly,
Swaying gently in the west-wind.

Forth we wander in this beauty
All the hours of toil behind us.
Hours of study, hours of labor
For a while will vanish from us.
With a toss of consolation,
We will soon go forth to meet her.
Go to greet the lovely Summer.

You who love the haunts of nature,
Love the shadow of the forest,
Love the wind among the branches,
And the rushing of the waters.
You, whose hearts are young and tender,
Who have Faith in God and nature,
Listen to these words of warning.
Cast not from you thoughts of kindness,
Live in purity and holiness,
Thinking of the God above you;
Who has made you, and who loves you.
Think of Him in early morning,
Toll Him of your fears and sorrows.
Think of Him, when in the evening,
You lay down your daily burden.

Farewell, then, to you dear children,
Peace be with you and your people,
Peace of prayer, and peace of pardon,
Peace of Christ, and joy of Mary.
"The Story of Shooting Star"

Like all other prophecies, Little Shooting Star was born in a wigwam. He had three sisters and two brothers. At four years old, Shooting Star with bright eyes, and husky hands was carefully parting the blue-berry bushes where a rabbit-squirrel was awaiting its victim. Shooting Star had no thought of pity for the little creatures; he had been taught not to mind pain. That was his lucky day, for he did catch a rabbit which made his heart beat wild and fast.

He loved to see the warriors painted and talk of the war path and could hardly wait for the day when he too would wear the feathers and be a hero.

Once when a great chief made a speech he heard those words which he never forgot: "Be always brave, be true to your race, and walk always silently and sternly when in pain or distress. Fear not! love the Great Spirit, the giver of life, of meat and fruit, of every blossom and blade of grass."

Shooting Star soon helped his father make a birch bark canoe, then one night went out with him and killed his first deer. Now he was proud, for he knew that the killing of a deer stood nearest glory on a hunter's name. He quickly learned to read and write pictures and stories.

His pride knew no bounds when he and his older brother once killed a grizzly bear he having wounded the animal.

Shooting Star soon grew to be a fine young man, bravely taking part in all the ceremonies required in the making of a warrior, he was very bold and daring. Sometimes he would creep into the camps and huntin' grounds of neighboring tribes just to see what they were doing.

Crash... Whop... Who is this rushing to battle? Why, it is our Shooting Star now become a great warrior.

He wears the eagle's feathers upon his head, which shows he has conquered a foe. He wears the bright paint, he wears three scalps at his belt. Fire gleams in his eyes; for he has seen in the last war dance.

Shooting Star's tribe is at war with another tribe, and Shooting Star is thinking of Bright Eyes, his own promised bride, who has been stolen by this crafty tribe.

Where is she? "Hidden away in some wigwam to slave for some cowardly fox, I must get her back," thinks Shooting Star as he dashes out of sight.

But: This time, with his heart set on one desire "Bright Eyes", he fearlessly creeps into the enemy camp and is made a prisoner with several others. The battle was fierce and now what is left of Shooting Star's warriors are hurrying homeward with thoughts of revenge.

Who is this tied with tough thongs to a tree, with fagots heaped around him?

Our Shooting Star. He has seen the other prisoners die, one by one, without a cry. He looks up through the branches to the blue sky and closes his lips tight.
He will die like a hero.

Hark... there is a rustling in the branches.

An old man parts the low boughs and stands before his son's tormentors. He is the old chief, Shooting Star's father, who having missed his son on the homeward trail returned for him.

"Spare my son" cried the old chief. My hairs are white, my feet are weary. I have hung many a scalp of your tribe above my tepee. My son has not long trod the warpath; he has taken but few scalps. His heart is young; his hopes are high; let him live - let me die," begged the old chief.

The foes are willing to do as he asks.

Shooting Star is set free and his father takes his place. As the old chief sees the fire burning around him, he does not flinch. He raises his hand and says "For my son's sake" then he thinks that he, too, will soon be free, in the Happy Hunting Ground.

That night Shooting Star did not leave the enemy camp before he had found and rescued his future bride.

Bright Eyes now watches for Shooting Star at the entrance of their lodge which he has made for her, fitted with plenty of warm skins and furs.

They are happy and love each other.

O COME HOLY GHOST!

The Gift of Wisdom—The gift of wisdom enables us to value things that count for eternity. It diminishes the attractiveness of evil. Once received it should blossom into a great love of God and a real love of neighbor. It will urge us to love God because He alone is worthy of all love.

Understanding—The gift of understanding helps us by shedding a clear searching light on the meaning of revealed truth. By it we are able to attain a closer union with God. This possession of God makes us so happy that we want to share with the world His wonderful secrets. We will always ask God to make us firm in faith and that many may follow its light.

Counsel—The gift of counsel helps us to choose the better of two right things. We are guided by its light to be 100% Catholics. It gives us a promptness of will to carry out our resolutions. Before each action let us turn to the Holy Spirit for guidance. "Come Holy Ghost and kindle in us the Fire of Thy Divine Love."

Fortitude—By the gift of fortitude we receive a very special grace. This gift bestows on the soul a permanent power which helps us to overcome difficulties in doing what God wants us to do. We need this grace every minute of the day especially when we are ridiculed for doing the right things. It takes a hero of God to be true to Christ. At such times ask the Holy Ghost to make you suffer the loss of so-called friends rather than to disappoint Christ.

Knowledge—By this gift we are given a supernatural light, which convinces us of the truths taught by the Holy Catholic Church. This light helps us to distinguish false philosophy and the teachings of Christ.

It points out for us God's will. It does not make any difference how wise or how old we are; we can always learn more about God and His designs for us. Let us read and study only under the guidance of this gift.

Piety—The gift of piety helps us to turn to God with love and confidence as we do to our Father on earth. It makes us ready to give to God the honor that should be His. This gift makes us ready to do immediately the good deeds that come to our minds.
Sometimes the inspiration is to say a prayer; in passing a church Jesus may call us to stop for a few minutes, and again we are urged to refrain from sin. If we love God we will obey these reminders.

Fear of the Lord—The gift of the Fear of the Lord helps us in a very special way to be afraid to offend God by sin of any kind. God is our loving Father, He has loved us so much that He has given us the dearest Treasure He had, Jesus Christ the Savior of mankind. He forgives us our sins and He gives us His Holy Grace. Surely we will fear to offend Him.

Our Motives.

A life without a motive is a useless thing at best,
Then so many acts want doing which would bring us peace and rest.
It brings us pain and worry, it brings us discontent;
It makes the world seem empty, and all effort poorly spent.

A life without a motive, like a plant without a flower,

Back from the Hospital.

On April 5th I came back from the hospital. The girls were glad to see me come back. I had to stay in bed for a few days, then I was allowed to get up in the afternoon. Then one day Sister told me to get up, and she got me ready to go home for a few days. When my sister saw me getting ready she wanted to go home too, so she went to ask Sister Superior if she could go with me. Sister Superior said she could go too, and my father came to get us that afternoon. We were very glad to go home. Then one of my little sisters got the measles and we had to stay home for another week. When we came back I started to go to school again. When I went to the hospital I was very sick, and received the last Sacraments. Now I am all better again.

Evelyn Black.

Garden Work.

One morning in May Sister Mary named the boys of the Senior Class to work with her in the garden. Some of us had to dig up the earth and make it soft for seeding, others carried new earth in to prepare the beds. Two others had to water the little spruce trees and the flowers that were already planted. For two weeks we worked out in the flower garden all morning, and went to school only in the afternoon. We enjoy outdoor work and are proud to see the garden and lawn look nice.

Alice Red Gun.

Ascension Thursday.

On the Feast of the Ascension we had High Mass at 10 a.m. in our chapel. Many Indians came to Mass, they also had their breakfast here at the school. In the evening we had a moving picture show. The films were very good, and were about animals, and others were comics. We went to bed at ten o'clock that night, and were quite sleepy the next morning.

An interesting visitor.

On April the 15th we had the honor of having a very nice visitor in the person of Mr. Alphonse Doucet, a member of the Indian Educational Dept., at Ottawa. He remained here four days, and visited the classrooms and all the buildings.

When he came to the Senior Class, he read for him and answered the questions he asked us. He did us do some physical exercises then talked to us the rest of the school period about a new course we are to have next year. He told the boys that we were to have carpenter work. We all liked that and are
very anxious for it. We liked Mr. Doucet very much and were sorry to see him leave us. He is doing so much to help us to get a good education and train us in work that will be useful to us when we are out of school. We are going to do our best next year and hope that he will be pleased with our efforts.

Easter.

We had a lot of rain the week before Easter and we thought Easter would be a wet one, but the weather turned out real nice. Many people came to Mass on Holy Communion, and most of them did their Easter duties. After they all had breakfast here at the school, we had Mass at 10 and Benediction right after. The sisters served a lunch to all the people, and then we had a movie in the afternoon. It was "Pabiole" and was very good. We enjoyed our Easter very much in every way.

Dr. Wells payed us his usual annual visit, to examine our eyes. He found them very good and only a few children have to take the Tracoma treatment. We hope he will find us completely cured on his next visit.

May Devotions.

During the month of May we had Benediction and May Devotions every night at the church. Father Guindot said the words and also gave a sermon every other night. We sang a hymn to the Blessed Virgin before the words. Many of the boys and girls got up every morning for Mass, to show their love for Mary. We hope she was pleased with our little sacrifices. We offered them for peace.

We are trying to do our bit by buying War Saving Stamps. Some of the boys have four already. Sister puts a gold star after our name for each stamp we buy. This way we can help our country to get bombers, ships, ammunition, and all the other things that are needed to win the war. On the Farm in May.

May the 2nd was a sunny day. The fields were all prepared to receive the little seeds. Already the wheat was in the ground. We wanted to see how the seeding was done, so we all went to the field with our teacher. The farmer was seeding oats on that day. He showed us the drill, the box where they put the seeds in, and the pipes that the seeds go through into the ground. There are chains that drag behind to cover the seeds. It was very dusty in the field. The farmer was driving the tractor, and he gave some of us a ride on the tractor, and some on the seeder.

When we got to the end of the field we thanked him and started for home. We went to the grave-yard a while until our teacher caught up to us. It was lots of fun walking home, and we got home just as a big storm was coming. We went to the chapel for Benediction, and our day was over.
