Mary's Day.

This year we celebrated Mary's day in a special way. We had Mass at the Church at 8 o'clock with a general communion. All day long we took turns in reciting the beads before the statue of the Blessed Virgin, so that someone was saying them all the time. At 5 p.m., we had an hour of adoration followed by a procession outside. The order of the procession was as follows: First the cross bearer, then acolytes, the boys of the school in navy blue suits and shirts, the white people from the town, the girls all dressed in white, the children of Mary hooded by their banner than Father Guindot carried the statue of the Blessed Mother. On our return Andrea Carl Child carried the statue while the Choir sang, "O Mary, we crown thee with blossoms to-day". Then we had Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament with a prayer for peace. It was all very pretty and we hope the Blessed Virgin was pleased with our efforts to make Mary's day a beautiful one. The biggest part was that we had made the sacrifice of not going home that Saturday, and we are sure that pleased our Blessed Mother the most. In the evening we again sang hymns in the chapel after our night prayer.

Mary Rose Good Eagle.

A Visitor from Wabasca.

For Mary's day we had a visitor from Wabasca with us, Sister Doris. She visited the house and came to the girls hall; there she saw some of our fancy work. She said it was well done. Sister Doris is the nurse at the little hospital there in Wabasca. Sister told us we were lucky to have so many nice things, she says the Cree Indians up there have not as much as we have, yet they are very grateful. We enjoyed Sister Doris very much and wished she could have stayed with us.

Jane Drunkon Chief.

Nature Study.

One day the Juniors and Grade IV girls went to the pond with our teachers. We found a very large beetle, about three inches long. It has very long claws. We put it in a basin of water with some leaves. We have had it for nearly a month but it is still living. We like to tease it, then he gets very cross.

Charlotte McHugh.

Ants.

Sister Margaret, our teacher and two boys went to get some ants for nature study. They were put in glass jar half of sand, so it could be thrown around. We could see the ants making tunnels and moving the eggs around. The next day when we came to school, we couldn't see anything. During the
night they had covered all the inside of the jar in this way. One ant would spit on the glass and the next one would lay a grain of sand on the wet spot. The little ants had done this to keep us from watching them. The pieces of dirt were placed so close together that it made a curtain. They work very hard all day and never stop for a minute. Don't you think they are wise little insects? We should be too. We studied all about the little ants and found it very interesting. We like nature study very much. To go on hikes and find out different things about insects and flowers.

Charlotte McHugh.

Caring for Baby Birds.

This morning our teacher found a bird's nest with five little birds in it. They were very cold, the mother had left them. Perhaps some cruel boy had killed her and left the little baby birds to die. Sister brought them to the kitchen and warmed them up. She filled a bottle with hot straw in it, and put a hot water bottle under the straw. She poured a few drops of wine and water in their mouths and they soon started moving around. She brought them to the class-room and we liked to watch them. Two of them were dead but the other three are very lively. We can hear them chirp during class and their little feathers are growing out now. Sister feeds worms to them and they never seem to have enough. We think that these three will live. I am sure they are lucky that Sister should save their lives.

Mary Louise Spring Chief.

Branding.

Many weeks ago we milkers had a great time branding the little calves. The man who works at the stable asked us to help him. We made a fire in the ground with some wood and heated the iron. In it we roped the calves inside and had a hard time holding them. The big calves were strong and it was very hard to throw them. It hurts them when the hot iron is put on them and it is hard to keep them from moving.

Paul Scalp Lock.

Our Picnic.

When Sister Superior had to go to the hospital she asked us to pray for her, and told us that she would give us a nice picnic on her return. We prayed so well that she came back much sooner than she expected. We were looking forward to the picnic but it was raining all the time. Tuesday was a nice day so we had it then. We did not go to the river as usual but had it on the school grounds. We had our dinner under the trees, and it was a very good one. Sandwiches, apples, cookies, peanuts, and nice orangeade. After dinner we went to the boys' yard for sports. We had all kinds of races and the winners got money. The big boys
also got cigarettes for prizes. Then at 3 p.m. we all came back to the school and had a cone of ice cream. After that we returned to the boy's yard for a ball-games. It was a good one. The big boys played against the big girls and ----the boys won, then the smaller boys played with the smaller girls and the boys won again. We came back and had our supper under the trees to the sound of the gramophone which has been moved out doors. At 7 o'clock we had another cone of ice cream and all went in for a picture show which lasted until 9.00. We all think it is the best picnic we ever had and enjoyed it very much. Religious Corner.

Living one day at the time.

To enjoy real real happiness in daily life there are many
contributing causes, one of these is to live each day by itself.
If we look forward for a number of years we are apt to become
discouraged. We imagine we cannot continue the struggle for our
whole lives. But in reality there are no long years to contend
with. Life does not come to us all at one time; it comes only a
day at a time. The following day is never ours until it becomes
to-day, and we have nothing whatever to do with it but to pass
down to it a fair and good inheritance in to-day's work well
done, and to-day's life well lived.

If we could only realize what one day in our life really
means. How we would simplify each hour. How careful we would be
not to lose a moment of time. Any one can carry his burden, however
heavy, till night-fall. Any one can do his work, however hard,
for one day. Any one can live smoothly, patiently, lovingly, purely,
until the sun goes down. And this is all life ever means to us,
just one little day. Do to-day's duty; fight to-day's temptations
and do not weaken or distract yourself by looking forward to
things you cannot see, and could not understand if you saw them.
God gives us nights to shut down upon our little days. We cannot
see beyond. Short periods make life easier and give us one
of the blessed secrets of brave, true, holy living.

Lord, for to-morrow and its needs,
I do not pray,
Keep me my God from stain of sin,
Just for today.

GROUARD ECHOES.

May-June 1941.

CLUB NEWS.

Each year for the feast of Our Lady of Good Counsel, the members have two Masses said. Father Larocque said the Mass for the living members on the Club feast; then two days later he said the Mass for the dead members. On that same day, our last year's secretary, Victoria Bellrose, was married here in the church. We were sorry we did not know she was going to be married that day, because we could not sing. But Sister Jean played the organ all during the Mass and I am sure Victorie was glad to hear all her favorite hymns. She is now Mrs. Paul Laboucan, and they are living near Kathleen. A happy married life to them both is the wish of her old schoolmates.

Margaret Auger—Grade VII.

A HOLY HAPPY DAY.

On April 30th, many of the little boys and girls made their First Holy Communion. Everything seemed beautiful. Bishop Langlois said the Mass and gave the children their first Holy Communion. We hope "unk"ing was happy to be received in each little heart. At breakfast, the children ate at a table which was all decorated. In the afternoon, Bishop Langlois confirmed them. We always like to hear them renew their baptismal promises.

Florence Maskegon—Grade IV.

BINGO! BINGO!

On the last day of April, we had a Bingo Party in the Domestic Training School. Fr. Forcade, Fr. Mahou and Brother Pequell prepared everything. Fr. Forcade read off the numbers and told us that each one who would Bingo would get fifty peanuts. These peanuts were to represent one dollar for the Auction Sale which we were going to have afterwards. It was very exciting, when someone would Bingo, for we were supposed to keep only half of the peanuts and share the other half with some of our friends.
After we had played quite a while, some had not had
Bingo at all yet, so Fr. Forcade said only those who had
not had any luck so far would play this last game, and
this time he paid the winner with jelly beans which were
worth two dollars each. Fr. Maheu got the whole bag, and
when he had treated all his unlucky friends, they were
richer than most of those who had won two or three times.

Then came the Auction Sale. Brother Piquet was the
auctioneer. As he held up each parcel, he made some fine
speeches. Some people spent all the money they had for some
great big box, and when they opened it, didn't they get a
surprise? Brother Arberve spent all his money buying
back his fur cap which Father had stolen from his room. But
the best joke was on Fr. Maheu when his boots came out of
a big parcel. It was a good thing he was rich in jelly beans
to buy them back.

There were many lovely presents too. We surely were lucky
to have such a nice evening. At the end, Fr. Forcade made a
speech, and presented Helen Miller with a parting gift for
she was soon to fly over the rainbow... going home by plane.
It was the last party of the year, and I think we all agreed
it was the very best one. We wont forget it very soon.

Bessie Tastewitch-D., Training School.

A NEW LAUNDRY AND WELL.

For three years, Sister Superior has been doing the
washing in two small machines because the new laundry had
burnt with the Boys' house. But on May 5th, the new machines
were ready to use, and everyone was glad to see how well
it works. Every Monday there is washing, but now we finish
much sooner than we used to.

We also have a new well. It is right close to the
salt water well behind the boys' house. This well is not
very deep. The water is clear and is not salty like the other
ones, but it is very hard. When we wash our hair, it becomes
very stiff and hard to comb. So we are making a novena to
St. Anthony to give us some soft water. I hope we get it.

Leonard Ward- Philip Fraser -Grade VI.

DEPARTURES AND ARRIVALS.

Father Lajoie went to the East and was gone a long time.
On his trip, he went to see Bishop Guy and Harry Thomas.
I bet Bishop Guy and Harry were glad to see Fr. Lajoie and to hear the Grouard news. We were glad to see Father home again.

Father Grouard had been at Peace River for two months and came home again. We were glad to see him here, but after a few weeks, he told us he was going away for good, because he is the parish priest in Donnelly now. Before leaving, he blessed us. He told us that he would not see us again unless he comes for visits. We were sorry to see him go. He was here five years.

Sammy (win-Grade IV) — George Laboucan-Grade V.

Two weeks ago, we saw two strange Sisters in the church. We knew one of them: Sr. Denis, because she used to be here before the hospital burned down. Now she is in Jussard. The other sister is Sr. Superior's cousin. Her name is Sr. Luciosa. She has been sick, so she is coming here to rest and get strong again. She looks better already, so we hope she will soon be well, and that she will like Grouard.

Mary (makinak-Grade IV).

CONCERT FOR OUR BISHOP.

On the eve of his feast, we had a concert for our dear Bishop. But before everything was ready, there were many people working busily to make it a success. The teachers and pupils had been practicing for a month. Brother Paquet spent almost two days putting up the stage, fixing colored and foot-lights and seeing that everything was right.

Grouard had never had such beautiful printed programs as we had this year. That is because we had Fr. Forcade who is an expert at printing. He made some beautiful progress with gold lettering. Core Desjardins handed these to the guests as they arrived. A big thank you to Father for having spent so much time and work to help us out.

Another who deserves a special thank you is Father Mako, who is always on hand to direct his famous Rhythm Band (Rubber Band, they call it to tease us!). This year, Father also directed the singing of "The Holy City" which was very beautifully sung by the altar boys in their nice red cassocks and white surplices which Sr. Marcella had just pressed and cleaned for the occasion. We wore our Band
I bet Bishop Guy and Harry were glad to see Fr. Lajoie and to hear the Grouard news. We were glad to see Father home again.

Father Troux had been at Peace River for two months and came home again. We were glad to see him here, but after a few weeks, he told us he was going away for good, because he is the parish priest in Donnelly now. Before leaving, he blessed us. He told us that he would not see us again unless he comes for visits. We were sorry to see him go. He was here five years.

Stanny -win-crede IV...George Laboucan-Grade V.

Two weeks ago, we saw two strange Sisters in the church. We knew one of them: Sr. Denis, because she used to be here before the hospital burned down. Now she is in Jossard. The other sister is Sr. Superior's cousin. Her name is Sr. Luciousa. She has been sick, so she is coming here to rest and get strong again. She looks better already, so we hope she will soon be well, and that she will like Grouard.

Mary -makinak-Grade IV.

CONCERT FOR OUR BISHOP.

On the eve of his feast, we had a concert for our dear Bishop. But before everything was ready, there were many people working busily to make it a success. The teachers and pupils had been practicing for a month. Brother Paquet spent almost two days putting up the stage, fixing colored and foot-lights and seeing that everything was right.

Grouard had never had such beautiful printed programs as we had this year. That is because we had Fr. Forcade who is an expert at printing. He made some beautiful progress with gold lettering. Corn Desjardins handed these to the guests as they arrived. A big thank you to Father for having spent so much time and work to help us out.

Another who deserves a special thank you is Father Mahe who is always on hand to direct his famous Rhythm Band (Rubber Band, they call it to tease us!). This year, Father also directed the singing of "The Holy City" which was very beautifully sung by the altar boys in their nice red cassocks and white surplices which Sr. Marcella had just pressed and cleaned for the occasion. We wore our Band
costumes and felt very proud of them. We played two selections: "The Woodpecker Song" and "Dreams of Dixie". I liked the first song best. Some of the boys had boards and rhythm sticks on which to mock the woodpecker. Everybody liked it. In the first piece, Father just directed but in the second, he played his violin too.

There were some nice plays by the boys and girls. I enjoyed seeing the girls of the training school in a tableau called "Vocation".

After the concert was over, I asked Bishop for a holiday. He gladly gave us one, and then he spoke so nicely to us. We could see he was pleased with us; so we were very happy.

Then, to finish it off in the right way, His Excellency gave us each a bag of candy and peanuts which we enjoyed very much.

Ellen Prunelle - Grade VIII.

On Mr. 16th, it was our Bishop's feast. He said Mass at the church; the children sang two new hymns, and the others and brothers sang two too. It was very nice.

For dinner, the boys went to the park while the girls stayed here. After dinner, all the girls went for a long walk. When we got back, we prepared a lunch and went out to the park in our turn. We had lots of fun, but had to come home early for Benediction.

A few days after his feast, Bishop Langlois went for a business trip to the East. He just got home this morning. We are glad he is home so we can see him before we go for our holidays.

Viola Willier - Grade VI.
EUCHARISTIC CONGRESS

On Ascension Day, Nora, Helen Miller and I had the privilege of going to Felton with the Fathers, Brothers and Sisters. It is the first time we ever went to a Congress.

When we got there, it was just time for the procession. I never saw so many people in a procession. His Excellency, Bishop Langlois, was carrying the Blessed Sacrament, assisted by Fr. Forcade and Fr. Bauscage. At the Church Repository then, there was a sermon, then the blessing of the sick with the "blessed Sacrament."

It was interesting to see the school children from all the different schools. They all wore caps of different colors. Annie and Nancy Thomas, and Nora Maher were with the Donnelly girls singing. It was beautiful singing.

After supper, there was a beautiful French pageant. It was out-of-doors. The children represented France, England and Canada. It was very, very nice. The children spoke very loudly and clearly. Then Bishop Langlois got up and spoke so nicely. He thanked everyone for the beautiful Congress.

It was quite late when we started for home. We were tired and sleepy the next day in class, but we were very glad we were chosen to go. That's once I was more than glad to understand French!

Bulla Cardinal - Grade VIII.

OUR TRIP TO JOUSSARD.

Every year, the Grouard truck takes the children to Joussard on May 24th. It is a big day, and everyone is always anxious for it. While we were at breakfast that morning, Sister named the lucky ones who were to go. It did not take us long to get ready, make our lunch and hop into the truck.

When we got there, everyone ran out
to meet us. Father Superior asked us if we wanted to play ball right away, so we said no, we wanted to visit around first and make friends.

After dinner, the boys played soft ball, and lost by three points. Then the girls played a game. Our girls beat. Then the boys played a game of hard ball. Jussard was way ahead. They have a very good team. After supper, they played again for a little while but there was such a cold wind that we soon came home. We got here at 10:30 and had lunch and went to bed.

Lillie "Grade VI."

VISIT OF A SUPERIOR GENERAL.

On May 30th, the Mother General of the Sisters of the Holy Cross came here with two other Sisters to visit. They were here for dinner, and visited all around. They went to Sister Jean's classroom first. They wanted to hear the pupils sing in Creole, so they sang a hymn. When they came into our class, we said our prayers in French for them. They visited all the school, and then went away.

Mary Cardinal - "Grade IV."

MY TRIP....OR MY VACATION.

One evening, Father Mahieu asked me if I wanted to go for a trip with him. I thought he was just "kidding" but anyway, I said "Yes." Next day, it came true. We left about 10:30. We went to Emilie and went around visiting people till Sunday. Father said Mass there. On Monday, we went to East Prairie and were to come back next day, but Father wanted to go hunting so we stayed. The next morning, Father, Ray Moran and I started off on horseback.

On the way, a branch knocked off my cap. Father's horse got scared and gave a sudden jump, bucking Father right off. When we asked him if he was hurt, he laughed and said, "No, I'm all right." On our way back, we took our own way crossing the river instead of sticking to the path. Father's horse was stuck in some quicksand, so Father got off. Just then the horse got loose and left Father standing in the water! While Ray was watching this, his horse got stuck on the bank. I don't know how they finally got out as I was busy watching my own horse. While climbing off the steep bank, I slid off as I had no saddle, and the horse nearly dumped me in the vines.
that night we finally got home again late and we had a lot of fun over it. We didn't get fat eating the same we killed though! The next day we came back to the mission around midnight hour, and wasn't I tired? Sister Jean insists on calling my trip a vacation, because I was gone almost a week instead of just over the week-end. Anyway, I enjoyed it and wouldn't mind going again. Father had his violin and I had the guitar along, so we had plenty of music to keep us happy.

Charlie White - Grade VII

AN OUTING IN THE WOODS.

On the first of June, the ten biggest boys went out to the woods with Brother Beaulac for a picnic. We fixed our own lunch, and put each our own in a little sack and carried it on our back.

All the way down, we had lots of fun talking with Brother because he can't talk English, so we had to say all the French words we knew. We saw rabbits and partridges. We were going to swim, but the lake was too full of sticks, so we went hunting rabbits instead.

We came back and started a fire, where we roasted a rabbit and toasted our bread. Then Brother said it was time for Benediction, so we started back. When we saw we were going to be late, we speeded up. We sure were hot when we got in church, and Sister almost laughed when she saw our dirty, hot faces. She said we looked like tramps.

Alexis Cardinal - H.John Chalifour - Grade VII.

A TRIP TO WHITEFISH LAKE.

On the last day of May, Father Superior left for Whitefish Lake with Sisters Louis, Omer and Hu. They were there during treaty time, so they saw all of our relatives and friends there. They stayed in Fr. Roué's house. Father was gone to Prairie Lake so they did not see him there.
When they came back on Tuesday, we were all anxious to see them. They told us that everyone at home is well. The Sisters said they liked their trip very much. They looked very tired though. The roads were rough and dusty.

Marjorie Wallman - Grade IV.

FIRST PICNIC AT SHAW'S POINT.

We big girls of the Training School had not yet taken the half-holiday which Mr. and Mrs. L'Heureux had given us on their last visit here, so on June second, after classes, we went to Shaw's Point for a pancake supper.

Just as we reached there, we were welcomed by clouds of fish-flies, so many of them that we could not open our mouths otherwise we would have had our supper on them instead of pancakes. But when we went farther up, they were left.

While the Sisters were getting things ready for supper, some went swimming, some went wading, or exploring.

When suppertime came, we sat around in a ring and ate the pancakes up almost as fast as they were cooked. Then we saw a boat coming.

Far off in the distance there was a little sull boat which we were wishing we could go for a ride in. We went down to the shore to meet the boat. It was Mr. and Mrs. McDermott. We talked and joked with them a long time and watched them bring the boats in. They said they had to hurry to feed the mink, so we followed them up and went to watch these animals eat their supper. Some of the Sisters had never seen them before. They fed them fish and other things all chopped up. They were very greedy because they were hungry.

We got home around ten o'clock that night. We sang and laughed all the way. We did not forget to say a big "Thank You" to Fr. Forcade who had given us this pleasure, for he was "Boss" while Fr. Superior was away. I hope this is just the beginning of the summer's picnics.

Mollie Cardinal - Domestic Training School.
DEPARTURES AND VISITORS.

Summer Vacation is just around the corner, everyone is thinking of going "HOME". Some of the girls who have been at the Training School got a head start and are already gone. The first to leave was Delphine Chalifoux. She had finished her two years' training, so she got a job at the hospital in Fort St. John. She was glad to go there.

Madeleine Bigstone had a chance to go back to her home in Wabasca with her father, so she left a few days ago. Helen Miller who had been here at the Mission for thirteen years left for home in Fort Ware last week. She missed her plane in Peace River so had to go to Grande Prairie to get it. We all wish these Club-members success in life, and hope to hear from them soon.

Nora Cardinal - Grade VIII.

On Saturday morning, June 7th, we were surprised to see some soldiers here. They used to be pupils here so they had come for a visit to school. Sister Jean was proud of them because she took their photo. The old pupils who went home on leave were: Edward Macdonald, Alex Fraser, Charles Tomkins, Peter Tomkins, Alfred Macdonald, Malcolm Gardiner, Myles McDermott and Herman Moore. Arthur Maher also came with them. We hope that all these soldiers who are gone to fight for their country will come home safely.

Margaret Fraser - Grade V.

A BIG DAY IN GROUARD.

On June 9th, the King's Birthday, we were all happy because the Sturgeon Lake and Joussard pupils were coming to spend the day with us. Weren't we glad when we saw the Sturgeon Lake truck coming about half past nine? We all ran out to meet them. We played the gramophone and amused ourselves till the truck came with the Joussard pupils.

After dinner, we played around for a while, then we all went to the Boys' Hall. The Sturgeon Lake Band played many pieces for us. They have more instruments than we have. We were very glad to hear their Band. The Joussard pupils sang a cowboy song. Then our Band played two pieces, Frances and Viola sang a lullaby, Ellen Brunelle recited her famous "Baseball Game", and then we sang "There'll Always Be an England".
When it was time for the base ball game, everyone went out to the field to see the game. The Sturgeon Lake team played a few innings against Joussard, but they had not had enough practice to play against Joussard, so Grouard played Joussard. The Joussard boys won again by many scores. After supper, our team played against the Joussard girls but this time we had lost our three best players, so we were beaten all to pieces. We had only 7 runs while they had 27. But it was fun anyway.

When the trucks left, we all cheered. We were glad we were at home so we didn't have to ride a long way before going to bed. The players were supposed to go to Sturgeon this week, but it has been raining almost all week, so I guess that will be just next year now. Too bad!

Faith Gladu—Raymond Burpremont—Grade V.

FEAST OF CORPUS CHRISTI.

For three days before the great feast of the Blessed Sacrament, we prepared our souls by listening to beautiful sermons on the "Holy Eucharist." Fr. Forcada's sermons were so interesting that for the time he was speaking, we didn't know what tired meant. One night, we sat there for forty minutes, and when he was finished, we thought it was only ten minutes ago that he had started. If we put into practice what Father told us, we shall surely reach heaven some day.

Right after High Mass on the feast of Corpus Christi, we had the procession outside. It was quite a long procession but the weather was so nice that it was not tiresome. That same afternoon, the rain started, and it has been raining for four days. We are glad God gave us nice weather Sunday.

More Cardinal—Grade VIII.

SAD NEWS FOR SISTER SUPERIOR.

Tuesday, Sister Superior received the sad news that her dear mother had died on the feast of Corpus Christi. We were all very sorry to hear this, and we offered prayers for the repose of the soul of Sr. Superior's mother. Next Monday, we will sing a Requiem Mass for the dear departed.
OLD PUPILS' CORNER.

Dear Good Counsellors:

'Tis hard to believe that another school year has rolled by, and that this is the last issue of "Echoes". Mingled with the joy that vacation brings is a feeling of sadness. It is always hard to see the older pupils go never to return again, as pupils. Yes, if I could, I would keep you here always, to shield you from life's dangers and sorrows. But as that is humanly impossible, I breathe a prayer that all these dear Good Counsellors who will leave us in a few days, may ever be true to all that we have tried to teach them here—that the principles learned here will guide them safely through whatever may befall them in later life.

Here is part of an interesting letter received from our former Club President, Dolphis Budskin:

"Yes, dear Sister, I was married to Isabelle John on May 8th. I surely appreciate the good wishes you sent, and hope it will be a lasting happiness for both my wife and I. I am sending you a photo of the two of us which I hope you will keep as a souvenir of one of your old boys....Tell my old schoolmates not to wish they were out of school; it will come soon enough and they will surely regret it then. Thank you, Dolphis— and Congratulations!

Last week I had a nice surprise in the form of a letter from Mrs. George Fowarue, in England. Our old George is now back in a hospital, and is doing well when he is off duty, working in their garden or driving the car. So he is lucky to have Eileen as a secretary. I was happy to receive a lovely photo of them both...which is now on the piano. Our best wishes to you both—across the sea!

Donat also sent interesting letters and photos of himself and "Jean". He is still in Scotland in charge of a wireless station. As soon as things look a little brighter, there will be a Mrs. Don Fowarue! How happy I am that both these dear lads have chosen such good Catholic girls. It pays to be good, doesn't it?

One day I saw a tall fellow coming up to school with his hat pulled way down over his face. He had
a familiar look. I guessed right away that it was some "Old Timer" who wanted to surprise "our Teacher".——and sure enough, it was Victor Bourgeois. He has been here three weeks now, recuperating from a minor operation. A few days later, I had a visit from Johnny Bourgeois. MR. DOUCET'S VISIT

From May 16 to May 24, Mr. Doucet, Director of Education with the Indian Department, was a visitor at this school. As he has already done in other Alberta Indian schools, he has studied local problems and has held conferences with the teachers and staff. The result: next year, a very definite programme of studies will be put into effect. It is to be a practical combination of academical and manual training. The teachers and the staff are anxious to follow this new system, which, there is no doubt, will give our pupils a most practical preparation for their adult lives on the Reserves.

Parents, with our cooperation, we would want to be able to join your own. Consider the great efforts being made towards the education of your children. By trying your utmost to set a good example for them at home, by sending your children to school at the proper age, by encouraging your children in whatever progress they may be making at school or after they leave the school, you can contribute very much towards our common ideal: the formation of your children to become honest and useful citizens of Canada.

At the close of this school year we can rightfully state here that progress has been achieved in nearly every line.

Those among you who have had the opportunity of assisting at the concert given by the pupils last May 20, have certainly become aware of a great change for the best, in the pupils.
In the following pages, they will themselves tell you of their great achievements in the field of sports. Some of them have had the grand opportunity of making a name for themselves and for the Indians of Hobbs, by taking part in physical training demonstrations held in Edmonton and in Calgary.

Last February 11th, 101 Indians of the Samson Reserve held a meeting at which it was decided that land would be leased on that Reserve for the erection of a Catholic Church there. More than 95 of those present voted in favour of the building. With the help of the school boys, the old church near the school was torn down. The wood has been transported to the new site and the building is now under construction.

In charge, many of the Indians are wondering why they are not given a chance to work "with pay" on the church. The answer is very simple; not enough money. This is a Mission church where no collections are taken and therefore where the faithful have no share whatsoever in the expenses. That is the reason why only the employed and occasionally the boys of the school are working it now. As the latter started hauling gravel for the foundation from the river, a certain Indian took his team alone, loaded his wagon and hauled his gravel to the site of the new church. BRUSHING

BY Maurice Dion Buffalo-Gr.3

Last May 23 about 50 boys went to the Sumpson Reserve to cut the brush on the place where they are going to build the church. We walked up to the railway and then we waited for Father Rhéaume. While we were waiting George Montour's mother came and took some boys there in her wagon. The big boys went in Father Rhéaume's car.

When we got there we started to work. Some of the big boys cut down the branches and the others piled them up and then we burnt them. At dinner time we found a nice place. We ate sandwiches, beans and had soft drinks. Father Rhéaume brought his gramophone and we played a new record called "Funiculi Funicula."

After that we went to work again but it did not take long to finish. So we all went to the river to swim. Father Rhéaume brought some of the boys and Pat. Yellowbird's father took some or the others. We all had a good time. When we were ready to come back home we all went to the spring to drink some water. On the way we found a well with ice in it. We took some ice out and everybody had some ice to suck. Then one of the boys saw the car coming and we all rushed to meet Mr. Eclerc. He took the small boys first and then he went back to get the other big boys.

OUR CONCERT

by M.Ann Godin & C.T.Dion.

We had a concert on May 21st in honor of Father Rhéaume, our principal.

We enjoyed it very much and everyone who saw it said we had done very well indeed.

First we had a patriotic sing song by the senior boys and girls. Then a drill of little negro boys and girls; this was called "Turkies Delight". It was very funny to see them dance and march.

After that was a recitation by a little boy; a song by grade 2 pupils and last of all was a play of boy scouts which made us laugh very much. Everyone did his part very well.

OUR PICNIC

by A.Oldpan & R.Croce.

On May 24th, we had a picnic on the Sumpson Reserve at the place where they have the Stampede. We went as soon as our work was finished after dinner. Many of us had a ride either in a wagon or in Father Moulin's car.

As soon as we reached the place Chief Sumsan spoke to us in Cree while Dan Johnson repeated what he said in English. Then we sang some patriotic songs and began the races at once. We had all kinds of races for little and big boys and girls. We also saw a horse race. The boys did all kinds of physical training exercises. We liked to watch them. We had lunch and supper there and came back about seven that evening. We stopped at the store on our way back.

CHRIST THE KING

Do you know about the Feast of Christ the King? It is celebrated on the last Sunday in October. It was started by Pope Pius XI. Feasts are made only for a good reason. The Pope began this beautiful feast to honor Our Lord in a special way and to make people remember that He is our King.

When People Forgot

A number of years ago many people seemed to forget that Christ was their King. They forgot His commandment that everyone should love his neighbor. The terrible World War started. Sickness and trouble followed it. Then in some countries leaders arose who tried to do away with all religion. What a sad, bad state of affairs this old world had come to! And it had all come about because people had forgotten that Christ was their King, and had disobeyed His command to love God and their neighbor.

Why The Feast Began

Pope Pius XI saw all this. That is why he began this great new feast. He wished to make people remember that Christ is King of the whole world and that all men should honor and obey Him. Let us honor Christ our King next Sunday in a special way. Let us offer Him our hearts when we receive Him in Holy Communion.

ALL SAINTS' DAY

We usually think of a saint as a person who did wonderful things when he was on earth. There were many saints like this, we know. But there are many others of whom we never hear. They did not work great miracles. They did not die as martyrs. They did not preach great sermons. They did not work miracles because God did not give them that power. They would gladly have given their lives for their faith, but they did not have the chance to do so. They were not
born great preachers.

These people, however, did everything in their power to please God. Today they are in Heaven with God.

Most of the great saints have feast days of their own. On Friday, November 1, however, the Church will honor ALL the saints in Heaven—the great ones and the ones of whom we never hear. It is one of the most important feasts of the year. Because it is a holy day of obligation, we must attend Mass on this feast just the same as on Sundays.

ALL SOULS' DAY

November 2 is another great day in the Church year. It is called All Souls' Day because it makes us think of all the souls in Purgatory. Some day those holy, suffering souls will be saints in Heaven. But now they need our prayers. Some day we may be in Purgatory ourselves. Then we shall want someone to pray for us. We should always remember the Poor Souls, especially the souls of our own relatives.

Month of the Holy Souls

November is the month of the Holy Souls in Purgatory. They cannot help themselves, so we must do all we can for them. Every day during the month of the Holy Souls let us help them by some special act of devotion. We can hear Mass, receive Holy Communion or say the Rosary or other prayers. Saying the Stations of the Cross is another good way to help them. Our dear Lord said: "Blessed are the merciful for they shall obtain mercy." Pray for the Poor Souls and they will pray for you.

R.I.P.

All hale and hearty are the children of this School. And there's no doubt about it. They are really trying hard to do their share towards an education, which each and every one of them require if they are to become good and useful citizens of Canada.

Let us not forget that it is necessary for the good of the community, that its future citizens be properly equipped for all the duties and responsibilities which they will have to face as men and women.

The family is supposed to play an important part in training boys and girls to be good and useful citizens. But the parents cannot do it all, and it would often be unwise to let them try.

This is the reason why the government sees to it that all children are provided with educational opportunities and the government also insists that all children shall take advantage of these.

Many Indians seem to ignore what the government and the schools are trying to do for their children. Here is a summary of the reasons why the government insists upon every boy and girl receiving a good education. 1—Schools do away with ignorance, idleness, and crime, and therefore are necessary to the order, safety, and progress of the community.

2—Schools give every boy and girl in a community a fair chance to start life on an equality with other children and fit them to take their place and do their part in the world.

3—Schools teach the pupils the necessity of obedience and the great value of self-control.

One of the most debated questions of Indian policy today is that which concerns the extent to which Indian customs, traditions, arts and crafts should be revived or encouraged to survive. It would appear that the work of the Indian Affairs Branch to the south of us may be under fire for its position in that matter, regardless of the high opinion they may have won of their work. Even in so insignificant a paper as "Wampum," there have been differences of opinion. It would be well if we could discuss the subject since it is vital to the purpose and program of our work.

In the Christian Century for March 28, 1944, there is an article by Oswald Grey from Tillard on "Leadership and the Indian Affairs Bureau," or course, to the situation in the United States. Now this article is not, I think, strictly from the sentimental point of view the disappearance of the Indian tribe will be a genuine loss. So far as possible their unique handicrafts and ceremonials should be preserved. But there is no doubt among the fact that there can be only one outcome, and that is the disappearance. The Indians themselves will tire of being considered circus exhibits, museum pieces seeking to keep alive vestiges of a life that was altogether and of a culture that was valuable in some degree, though by now it is always.

Public interest is growing considerably in the Indian people, but it is largely from the viewpoint of anthropology and ethnology, and is stimulated by the amazing discoveries of ancient Indian civilizations and various historic sites. I welcome this interest, so long as it does not lead to the exploitation of the Indian as a living exhibit, human museum pieces. We need to be clear in our minds as to the purpose behind our revival of Indian arts and customs, so that this renewed interest will serve to promote the best development of our Indian people in the world of today, it must go a means to an end, rather than an end in itself.

Surely it is our hope that the Indian people will be an integral part of the Canadian cycle, bringing to it their own contribution in culture and philosophy, and likewise contributing member of the family, along with the other races and nationalities which will comprise the true Canada of tomorrow. To this end, an education, on the part of both Indians and whites of the history and culture of the Indian people, is highly desirable. It will make us more willing to admit them as brothers and on a basis of mutual respect. Such a change of attitude, on the part of our people, will have to begin in our schools, by means of changes in text books and some appreciation on the part of teachers, whose attitudes will be communicated to their pupils. This would suggest a required reading course for teachers while at normal school, not necessarily very heavy, but such as to give your teacher a sympathetic understanding of the Indian people. This is no doubt imperative also for the other minority groups in Canada, but we are most interested here in its bearing on the Indian people of Canada.

Let us hear from you on this subject.

H.E.J.
The Place of Home Missions in a Post-war World

By G.E.E. Lindquist

As a basis for my remarks, I quote an old familiar verse, "Nevertheless the foundation of God standeth sure, having this seal, the Lord knoweth them that are His. And let every one that nameth the name of the Lord depart from unrighteousness." (II Tim.2:19) This bit of Scripture seems to me to give the assurance we need in facing the topic before us: (1) that we have, here and now, a foundation; (2) that it standeth sure, amidst the confusions and turmoils of our time; (3) that we have powerful allies, the Lord, high and lifted up, on the one hand, but nevertheless concerned with our infirmities and shortcomings; also, them that are His, the great cloud of witnesses, the pioneers who have gone before with whom we as Christians may enjoy the communion of saints; (4) that we have a Christian Mission, not limited by any untoward conditions. In this connection I quote the words of another, "I am a Christian to be a Christian is to be a missionary; as a missionary I cannot be indifferent to the needs of others;" (5) and with this there is the implication of a social as well as a moral crusade in the words, "let every one that nameth the name of the Lord depart from unrighteousness." May I suggest that this be the key-note verse for our Brome Conference, for it furnishes the foundation, not only for the place of Christian missions in a post-war world, but for Christian missions at all times....

It is fundamental that the place of home missions in a post-war world will depend on the interpretation of missions in relation to people everywhere. Among the characteristics too often in evidence today toward certain racial groups, more especially the Indian, is that of paternalism. Shall governmental and ecclesiastical wardship over Indians continue in the post-war world? It is significant that although the Indian fights for democracy he is still in large measure denied full participation in what we like to term "the American way of life." Since formal citizenship came to our Indian brethren as a result of their participation in World War I, have we not a right to anticipate that release from federal wardship might be forth coming as a by-product of World War II?

In any discussion of missions and a post-war world, we need to continually remind ourselves as well as our constituency that there can be no real freedom without the assumption of obligations. I recall in this connection what is inscribed on the statue of General Giles Waldo Shurtleff of Oberlin College, the first Brigadier-General in charge of Negro troops during the civil war, "Freedom cannot be given, it must be achieved." A similar statement was made at the recent Cleveland Conference by Rabbi Silver, who said, "Freedom without the voluntary assumption of obligations, without sharing burdens and making sacrifices, is no freedom at all, but the sheerest anarchy." Should not the voluntary assumption of obligations in the matter of self-support, as well as self-government, increasingly characterize our Indian missions in the post-war world?

Furthermore, the home missionary enterprise must not be content with institutions which seem sufficient within themselves. The Roman Catholic Church in Latin American countries often fostered missions among the Indians which might be called islands of isolation, the idea being that the Indians being gathered within the mission compound might be guarded from outside contacts and thus become self-sufficient. But history records the inevitable breakdown of this sort of isolationism. Even a mission school, essential and highly desirable in its place, may outgrow its usefulness. "New occasions teach new duties, time makes ancient good uncouth."

(continued on next page) Moreover there must...
Moreover, there must be definite plans to integrate minority groups into community life. The Indian Church may become a real community centre but only as it ministers to all within its sphere of influence regardless of race or color. Is there any cogent reason why an Indian Mission may not become a centre of goodwill to all sorts and conditions of men rather than serve on a level of separation?

Competition must give way to cooperation, which is just another way of saying that ecclesiastical barriers, so menacing along the old frontiers, must be broken down in the post-war world. For here is that saying true that denominationalism, like patriotism, is not enough. And as far as the Indian is concerned, his designation of denominational nomenclature would seem to indicate that he has but superficially grasped our historical denominational differences. The Archbishop of Canterbury in his first radio address to America reminded us that there is a great public ready to listen to what we say together, who do not pay any attention while we say it in separation. And the late Sir Wilfred Grenfell taught us by precept and example that ecclesiastical barriers can be broken down in the pathways of service. He once told about amputating the infected leg of a Catholic member in Labrador. Later, when he was visiting a Congregational Church in the United States, he asked if anyone there knew of an artificial leg that might be donated, since it was difficult to obtain them in Labrador. Following the service, a Methodist woman offered a leg which her Presbyterian husband had used until his death. Grenfell concluded: "When I, an Episcopalian, took that Presbyterian leg, given me by a Methodist woman in a Congregational Church, back to Labrador, and fitted it on my Roman Catholic friend, it enabled him to walk perfectly."

Finally, the Cross must be our uniting symbol in the post-war world. We must put love in the place of hate, fellowship in the place of isolation, cooperation in the place of competition. Shall we not take our place under the banner of the Cross?

"Beneath the Cross of Jesus, I fain would take my stand,
The shelter of a mighty rock, within a weary land.
A home within the wilderness, A rest upon the way,
From the burning of the noontide heat, And the burden of the day."

The Cross thus standing at the centre of the Christian's hope must also become the uniting symbol.

And as we go forth into our respective fields to face the baffling problems of a post-war world, let us bear in mind the fatherly counsel given by the greatly revered Professor Clarke to his theologians: "Young men, remember when you get out in your fields that God was there before you." Yes, He was there in the pre-war world and He will also be there in the post-war world. God grant that we may be attuned to His leading and avail ourselves of His infinite resources as we face our missionary task.

My Indian Day Message

By Big White Owl.

The first Inter-American Conference on Indian Life to take place in the New World has approved the following recommendation (Final Act, LIX):

"First, that the governments of the American countries adopt an 'Indian Day,' dedicated to a realistic study of the present-day Indian problems, in all the schools and universities. Second, that the American countries adopt the 19th day of April as American Indian Day, to commemorate that date, on which for the first time the Indian delegates gathered for the first Inter-American Conference on Indian Life at the Hotel Don Vasco de Giroga in Patzcuaro, Michoacan, Mexico (15th April, 1940), and therefore an invitation is extended to the peoples and governments of the Americas to join in this celebration."

Now, in concluding this paper, I would especially urge the scholars and Indianists of Canada, and the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, graciously to dedicate at least a part of their efforts on that day to a broader and saner consideration of Indian programs and Indian problems, and I further suggest to all newspapers and magazines, churches and other institutions throughout the Dominion of Canada that they commemorate this date by including in their publications and lectures, works and talks on Canadian Indian Life.

My Indian brothers: be not of faint heart—we belong to this continent just as the mountains and hills, the buffalos and beavers, belong here. Our bodies are formed from the dust of our forefathers' bones, and we have not as yet really fulfilled our purpose upon this Earth. We must continue to live, and to try to create a new hope for our people. We must do something to cheer them in their loneliness, and comfort them in their misery... Then some day, out of the gloom and the ashes of the past, shall rise a new people.

I Have Spoken!

Springtime In Old Ontario

As I stand here on the banks of the River Humber, looking to the distant hills which are wrapped in a smoky haze, I see solemn White Birches standing here and there. I wonder how such pale, slim and beautiful trees could escape the destructive march of greedy men, money-men who transformed these wilderness mounds with a touch of artificial splendour.

In the distance I can hear the clamorous Kingfisher calling his mate, and softly the Red-winged Blackbird relates—see a flock of Gulls floating through the warm spring air—how gracefully they skim over the grassy mead. I so often wonder what a white man's dream of heaven can be? Ah, "Springtime in Old Ontario" is good enough for me! Suddenly I can feel the presence of another little brother of the wild. One of the little fellows who helped to form the New Earth out of the great waters. He is swimming through the murky and polluted water along the river bank. I watch him as he struggles among twisted willow saplings and floating debris. He too feels and smells my presence and dives down into the murky water just as silently as he came... Now I see a fisherman lifting his net, a thing that bagged and billowed. A monster wall-eyed Pike finds himself entangled in the clinging meshes. In a frenzy of fear he darts about flashing his silvery scales. And with one last quivering thrust of the mighty tail the curtain of muddy water closed this scene—and I was glad.

(continued on next page) Deepening shades...
SPRINGTIME IN OLD ONTARIO, continued.

Deepening shades now dim the dying day. The fleecy clouds are flying very low. And a lonely owl skimmed over the naked trees. I hear the birds softly fling happy mating calls. I see the dark shadows cast by the friendly trees, and from there a timid hare leaped forth to feed... I came here to commune with the roots and the herbs while all fading landscape sinks into the night. Now I look into the far-flung sky—that great and hushed immensity. I see the pale moon creeping up from behind the birches, the pines and the maples. And I can see a great and queenly city silhouetted against the pale spring moon.

Old memories begin to unfold the sad and tragic tales of yester years. Departed Red Indians rising with the mist from their countless unknown graves. I see their phantom forms come floating through the wet night air. And from somewhere in the realms of space there come the mystic chant of the Turtle clan—my noble forefathers. Then, too, could hear the haunting cry of the Wolf clan, which longs for the cool, still air. Next came the lonesome wail of the Turkey clan to complete the grand review. Far into the night I communed with the council of the dead. And then at last, with weariness and happiness intermingled, I turned to go. A phantom Chief lifts his arm holding forth the sacred Pipe of Peace in a silent signal. Phantom braves taking of their weird masks respond to their leader... I stood alone and mute, in silent salutation, while phantom braves danced by singing out in native ceremonial song. Then came the phantom Chief with slow majestic strides, and speaking with a voice like thunder he lifts his arms. Meekly and humbly I offered my hand and heart to him, who commands:

"O silent mortal son of mine,
Thou art a reckless Brave,
Forsoke not your noble race—
To be a white man's slave!

I place my quivering hand upon my troubled heart as, into that grim hard face I looked. Behold! It was a face radiant with smiles... The Indian Chief now turned to go and vanished with the whispering winds. And all the phantom braves are fading fast away. The ceremonial songs break off in the distant sky to moan at the mellow moon. It was a visitation from spirit-land, where the spirits of many departed Redmen find their happy hunting grounds; where Tecumseh, Pontiac, Sequoia and Brent sit by their little camp-fires and smoke the Pipe of Everlasting Peace. O Brave Warriors, mighty Hunters, and Great Romancers—I salute you!

Lo and behold, across the sleepy river, a great city has risen. A city with a million lights and streets a thousand ways. And many men who consider themselves sportsmen often come forth from the midst of this artificial splendor... turning themselves loose to wreck, to plunder and to murder the helpless creatures of nature.

O Thou Great and Good Spirit, open the eyes and melt the frozen hearts of these cruel pelé-faced men. Help them to understand that to love and to protect the wild creatures of our forests, fields and streams, offers far more real lasting pleasure and delight than does the insane desire of spoiling and destroying our wild life.

This is the plea of one humble and lowly Red Indian, whose life is a long-continued road of despair, neglect and grief, whose every hope is being blighted by false and disappointing civilized white men.

I Have Spoken!

Oronhyatekha

By Kahbaosa.

"Leaving Buffalo at 7.55 Wednesday morning the train, bearing the remains for which sorrowing thousands waited, steamed into the Union Station at Toronto, almost on schedule time. Here awaiting it were the daughter and other relatives of the deceased, the members of the Executive Council, representatives of several High Courts, the Mayor and several Aldermen, the police-borough and guard in honour from Temple Encampment of Royal Foresters. As soon as the casket enclosing the remains was removed from the car, it was raised upon the shoulders of eight Royal Foresters and carried from the station premises to the waiting horse. Then came the funeral procession, the like of which Toronto has not often looked upon, to escort the mortal remains of a great man, and an illustrious Forester, to Massey Hall, where it had been arranged he should lie in state, and where memorial services were to be held in the evening. The thousands of citizens of every degree and all ranks who lined the streets, the drawn blinds along the route taken by the procession, the bared heads, the sorrowful faces, formed a tribute of respect such as is paid to but few men either in life or death."

What great man was this who was so widely mourned and so highly honored? It was Oronhyatekha, a Mohawk Indian.

What! A Mohawk Indian whose body lay in state; in whose cortège walked the mayor of the city and dignitaries of church and court!

Yes, it was a Mohawk Indian. And, moreover, do you see that splendid building standing on the corner of Bay and Richmond streets, Toronto, that known as the Temple of Industry? It stands there as a result of the zeal and energy of that same Mohawk Indian. When you go into that building again, look to your right as you enter and you will see a fine bronze statue erected by the Independent Order of Foresters as a tribute to the memory of Oronhyatekha who is so highly esteemed by the Order as to be almost their patron saint.

But how came he to be accounted worthy of such honour?

To answer that question it will be necessary to tell you this story.

On the tenth of August 1841, a baby boy was born in a home on the Indian Reservation near Brantford. His parents named him Oronhyatekha, which means "Burning Cloud". We do not know much about the early life of the boy except that he had a craving for knowledge, and possessed a mind that readily absorbed all that was offered him. First he attended the Industrial School on the Reserve, when he had mastered all that was taught there he went to the Wesleyan Academy at Allentown, Mass. After that he taught school for a time, then pursued his studies at Kenyon College, Ohio. There he proved himself an able scholar by taking the first two years' work in one year.

Kenyon he came to the University of Toronto.

In 1860 Edward Prince of Wales came to Canada. Little did Oronhyatekha think, when the proposed visit was first announced, what a significance it would have for him. It led to his going to Oxford, that historic seat of learning, the attendance at which is itself a distinction. It came about thus:

While the Prince was in Canada, the Chiefs of the Six Nations Indians prepared an address to the son of their "Great Mother" across the "Big Waters". They chose Oronhyatekha to read the address. The Prince and his party were very much impressed by the fine appearance of the young Indian; and by the literary attainments and ability of the man. He was invited to continue his studies at Oxford. There under Dr. A. Kland, afterwards Sir Henry Acland, he studied medicine and in course of time returned to his native land a full-fledged physician.

(continued on next page)
He practised first in Frankford. From thence he went to Stratford, and in 1873 moved to London. After that, only five years of his life were devoted to the practice of medicine, yet at the end of that time he had gained a reputation for skill and was highly esteemed by the members of his profession. In 1878 he became a member of the Independent Order of Foresters. Henceforth it is as a Forester that we know him, for the rest of his life he was devoted to that organization. As one remarked some years later, "Beyond all question and evil he lived, planned and acted for that great Order." We feel that it would be nearer the truth to say, he devoted his life to the interests of his fellowmen as he could serve them through that Order.

In September of the year that he joined the Order, Oronhyatekha was elected Right Worthy High Chief Ranger of the High Court of Ontario. Soon after he was chosen as the head of the Order in Ontario which office he filled for two years.

On the thirtieth of June 1881 there was a great gathering of the Foresters at Ottawa when the different branches in Canada and the United States were united and the Order was reorganized.

There arose the question of leadership. Where was to be found a man with the necessary qualifications to make the reunited Order a success? The choice fell upon Oronhyatekha but he would not accept the position, and when the gathering adjourned for lunch that day nothing had been accomplished as far as securing a leader was concerned.

Oronhyatekha took lunch at the home of his friend Edward Botterell. On the way to the house and while they ate, they discussed the question of leadership. By and by, when they were near the end of the meal, Oronhyatekha turned to his friend and said, "Well, if you will stand by me, I will accept." Of course Botterell promised he would and thus the question of the leadership was settled. In a short time Oronhyatekha was elevated to the position of Supreme Chief Ranger.

When we consider that there are always in the world some narrow-minded people who regard the white race as God's chosen favourites and all others as inferior beings, we are not surprised to find that some sought to discredit the Order of Foresters because it had an Indian as its chief Officer. But that the Order did not make a mistake in their choice is proved by the fact that Oronhyatekha remained in that position for twenty-six years—until his death; also by the fact that the Order, which numbered only 369 members when he became its head, at the time of his death had "grown to a mighty host of over 248,000." And again by the financial strength of the Order which, at the time when he ceased from his labours, had an accumulated Fund of $10,390,115.61. The wisdom of the choice is further proved by a consideration of other important accomplishments of this remarkable man.

As a result of the policy of the Supreme Chief Ranger, and under his guidance, the Order instituted some very beneficial forms of insurance. In 1898 he secured the site at the corner of Bay and Richmond Streets, Toronto, where on the twelfth of May of the same year, was laid the corner-stone of the "Castle" which in 1907 was described as "the finest office building in Canada." Thus Oronhyatekha's dream of erecting a suitable habitation for the Order was realized.

The next dream born in his fruitful mind was that of founding a home for the orphans of departed Foresters. This was realized when the Home was dedicated at Island Park on the twenty-seventh of August, 1904.

The story of this remarkable Indian will be concluded in the July issue of WAMPUM.
Duck Chief's Medals

By Mildred Valley Thornton.

The peak of the year for Alberta Indians is seen in the Calgary Stampede. They prepare for it for months in advance and live it over in memory long after it has passed.

Knowing that I should find excellent material for my brush, I was glad when at length I was able to attend this famous exhibition. To me the Stampede meant Indians above everything else, and my most ardent dreams did not exceed in colour and romantic appeal the scenes which awaited me there. Naturally I made straight for the Indian encampment as the sole purpose of my visit was to paint as many Indians as possible in the time at my disposal.

The headquarters of the R.C.M.P. was located protectingly in front of the wide circle of tepees, and I knew from long experience that no one could be of so much assistance to me as the scarlet-coated keepers of the law. Corporal Cameron of Crossfield and a young rosy-faced constable from Gleichen were in charge, and immediately became interested in my work. The building they used had been the original Mounted Police Headquarters in Calgary, so had much historic interest.

In front of it stood an enormous, beautifully mounted specimen of a buffalo, which the corporal told me aroused the curiosity of many of the visitors, especially Americans. Some of them thought it was alive and wouldn't have been at all surprised to see it charge suddenly into the crowds. Inside the building were many fine robes whose soft brown hides had once protected the bodies of its brothers.

People came to the Mounted Police for everything but the moon. Women came looking for their lost children, others to ask where the fancy-work was, and still others wanted advice about what to do for a headache, or the best place to eat. The 'Mounties' treated them all with equal good humour. During the week they sold several splendid buffalo robes and other lovely furs. They seemed to enjoy their duties, though some phases of it were not so pleasant....

In a corner of the building was a cell which could tell many stories of the past. Seldom in use now, it contained saddles, suitcases, boxes and other paraphernalia to which I was permitted to add my various pieces and equipment, that I might go in and out at will for my supplies.

On inquiring about the best subject in the camp from my artist's point of view, the first man mentioned was Duck Chief, head of all the Blackfoot tribes in Alberta, so I sallied forth with the constable in search of him. Duck Chief readily when he heard of my request and disappeared into his tepee to get prepared. Soon he came out again however, and quietly announced he would not pose. Extremely disappointed, I turned away, knowing the utter futility of argument. It wasn't long before I was busily engaged painting someone else. The next few days were full of the most intensive work, for there was plenty of excellent material at hand.

That same morning quite unexpectedly, Duck Chief signified his willingness to be painted. Joyfully I grabbed my kit and hustled off to his tepee. I was curious and wondered what had made him change his mind. So was the Mountie, who started making inquiries. It seems that the venerable Chief had wanted me to do it all the time, but his wife wouldn't let him.

Alas, "how the mighty have fallen". Here was the proud leader of a brave and warlike race, strong and fearless in his six feet two of bone and muscle, yet meekly yielding to the will of the fat, black-braided little woman who swept his hearth and embroidered his moccasins. So it appears that the hand that rocks the cradle is also the hand that rules the brave.

(continued on next page) I think of all....
I think of all the Indians I have ever known, Duck Chief was one of the most obliging and lovable. He preferred being painted in his tepee, for which I was thankful, as it shielded me from the curious gaze of dozens of passersby who delighted to watch the process. I liked the Chief just as he was, in his ordinary clothes, and wanted to paint him that way. But he had ideas too. He sat on the ground rumbling with two enormous medals suspended on sleek thin ribbons. Very carefully and deliberately he adjusted them around his neck, turning the medals this way and that, fastening and unfastening several large safety pins with which he made them secure.

Quietly, and in patience, I sat waiting until the solemn ceremony was over. Finally everything was arranged to his satisfaction. Then he suddenly looked up and smiled like a pleased child, which was my signal to begin.

I saw so much beneath that tawny skin. The features were open and generous, and slightly Mongolian, which is unusual in the Blackfoot. One does not paint portraits year in and year out without learning something about human nature, if one is even faintly observant. In the face of Duck Chief I read good humor, patience, tolerance, wisdom and the unmistakable marks of natural gentleness. Added to these desirable qualities was a simple childlike directness of manner coupled with immense dignity which was most appealing.

I was so pleased about doing this portrait that I went off to other work and did not miss my sweater till I was in my room that evening. I had not the faintest idea where I had left it as I had been all over the encampment. Next morning I asked the Mounties to be on the lookout for it but could tell that they weren't very hopeful of ever seeing it again.

Then I went to Duck Chief's tepee to ask if he had seen it. His face was absolutely impassive as he countered my inquiry with a question of his own.

"Was it blue?"

"No," I replied, "it was tan."

Whereupon he turned on his heel, went into his tepee and came out immediately, not only with the missing sweater, but also with a brush which I had overlooked, and smiling broadly, he handed them to me.

I was very curious to know more about his medals. He had many others besides the two large ones he wore when I painted him. The Mountie procured an interpreter for me when I had difficulty understanding him, but he was not able to elicit much information, so my curiosity remained unappeased.

When I returned home, however, I looked up literature on the Royal visit and found much that I wanted to know.

In The Vancouver Sun, May 29, 1939, was the following: "During the five-minute stop in front of the thirty tepees, His Majesty greeted Duck Chief, 75-year-old head of the encampment, and a direct link with the final peace treaty that made all Canadian Indians wards of Queen Victoria.

"Duck Chief wore the medal given him shortly after the signing of Treaty No. 7, the Blackfoot Treaty, and another to celebrate the visit in 1901 of the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York, later King George V and Queen Mary, the parents of the present King.

"Duck Chief gave His Majesty a message that he had always wanted to meet the Great White Father, particularly after he had heard that the King was coming across the water to see his Canadian children."

The Pilgrims And The Indians

According to our school histories, the Plymouth Colony, established in 1620, was able to survive and later to prosper largely because of help received from friendly Indians. Foremost among these was Samoset, a Wampanoag, whose hail, "Welcome, Englishmen," so startled the Puritans in the early spring of 1621. Samoset expanded his limited vocabulary through contact with fishermen along the Kennebec. In his broken English he was able to tell the Pilgrims that they were free to occupy the land, as the Indians to whom it belonged had been swept away by a pestilence the previous year.

On Samoset's second visit he brought with him Squanto, who had a better command of the English language and who subsequently acted as interpreter in most transactions with the Indians. Squanto had travelled widely for one of his race and had had a very colourful career. In 1614 he had been kidnapped and sold into slavery in Spain. Later he had been freed; he made his way to England and finally returned in some manner to his home in America. Samoset and Squanto announced that Massasoit, the great sachem of the Wampanoags was planning to visit the settlement. The Chief appeared with a retinue of warriors, he was received with ceremony; Miles Standish ordered out the army, (even including Standish). With Squanto acting as interpreter on the first treaty with the Indians of New England was made.

The terms were few and simple; there was to be peace between the settlers and the red men. No injury was to be done by either party to the other. All offenders were to be given up to be punished. If the English engaged in war the Wampanoags were to have them. If the Indians were attacked unjustly the English were to come to their aid. This treaty, simple as it was, was not violated for fifty years. Following the precedent set by Massasoit, nine tribes in all acknowledged the British King.

Let us not overlook the good deeds of Squanto. The Pilgrims looked upon him as a special instrument sent of God for their good beyond their expectation. He taught them how to plant corn; to put a dead fish in each hill by way of fertilizer. (An Indian teaching white men the secrets of agriculture!) He became their interpreter and their pilot. From him they learned where to find fish and how to take them. They were soon raising such an abundance of corn that they had surplus to exchange with the Indians for furs. These furs, sent to England, were the source of revenue which enabled the settlers to purchase the merchandise they required. Squanto remained the friend of the settlers until his death and when dying, asked the governor to pray that he might go to the "Englishmen's God in Heaven."

Actually Massasoit desired the alliance of the Pilgrims as protection against the Narragansets whose powerful chief, Canonicus, challenged the settlers by sending the governor a bundle of arrows wrapped in a rattlesnake skin. Governor Bradford replied by returning the snake skin filled with powder and shot. Had Canonicus seen fit to accept this challenge, it is a matter of speculation as to just how much protection Squanto's army of six with its bell-mouthed blunderbusses could have afforded the colony. Happily, however, hostilities were averted.

Notes From Island Lake.

By Rev. J.A. McKim, formerly of Island Lake.

It had been a midnight call and when we arrived home early in the morning we were sure that the baby would live as we left him resting comfortably. He was a fine big fellow whom I had named Donald Sidney. He was Elizabeth's first child, and as it is usual for the first child of Indian women to die, we felt that we had accomplished something.

It turned out that the cause of the sickness had been one of food, for the grandmama had told us that she had given him some evaporated milk undiluted, while she was waiting for the mother to nurse him. That is definitely not the food for a day-old baby.

After that we watched Donald grow strong and healthy till he reached his fifth month, then one evening the father came to the mission and told us that the baby would not eat and did not sleep well. When I visited him the next morning he seemed listless, but cried occasionally and showed signs of the same colic that he had shortly after his birth. I left some baking soda and a hot water bottle and left directions about his food. It looked as if he would soon be well, but that night he was worse, for he started to choke and had a high temperature and was perspiring profusely.

When I arrived at the home all the Indians of the community had arrived before me and were sitting around on the floor as is their custom when anyone is ill. The alarm of the curiosity had taken over the child from the mother, and they had him lying on some quilts on the floor near an open window, and as he was perspiring they had taken off his clothes to keep him cool, and a chilly breeze came in the open window.

By this time the boy was breathing very heavily, even gasping at times. It was quite evident that he had a congestion of the lungs. I had the woman make a warm bed in the corner and cover the child up, and I mixed up a mustard plaster for his chest and told them to keep him covered and use mustard every four hours. When I returned in two hours, the baby was back on the floor naked before an open window.

We had the funeral the next afternoon. Scenes such as this are a common occurrence at Island Lake. The two factors that contributed to that child's death are, Indian habits in regard to sickness, and lack of proper medical care.

The Fairfield Trust.

A strong committee under the above name, has been working with zeal and no small success to restore the ancient Moravian Mission Buildings at Moraviantown, or New Fairfield. We have received a well-prepared sketch of their activities, together with their financial report. They have raised already the sum of $2502.08 and are pleased to receive donations for the project, which includes the transformation of the site of old Fairfield into a public park and memorial, as well as the repair of the buildings. The Treasurer of the Fund is,

Rev. Charles Malcolm, M.A., B.D., 141 Grand Ave., East, Chatham, Ont.

From the circular we quote in part,—

"On the retirement of the Moravian Church from Canada in 1903, they gave their ancient buildings and lands at New Fairfield to the Methodist Church. Thus ended the period when these now belong to the United Church of Canada. During their stay in Canada the Moravians had built two churches on their lands in Western Ontario.

"Their first church was erected in 1792 on their Fairfield site on the north side of the Thames. Their first church and all the buildings of Fairfield were destroyed by fire, set by the U.S. soldiers of General Harrison on October 6th, 1813, following General Harrison's victory in Battle of the Thames on October 5th, 1813.

"After the close of the war 1812-14 the Moravians returned to the site of Fairfield but promptly decided to build their new village on the south side of the Thames. They named this new village New Fairfield.

"It was about 1818 they built the historic old edifice (illustrated in the folder)."

The Society for the Furtherance of B.C. Indian Arts and Crafts,

The Annual Report of the President (extracts):

There is a growing feeling throughout the Dominion that we white Canadians must recognize our responsibility for the welfare of Canadian Indians. This growing sense of responsibility has tended to broaden the purpose and widen the activities of our Society. All the original aims of the Society are being conscientiously adhered to, but in addition, an effort has been made to be of immediate and personal service in individual cases which have been brought to our notice. The long view of practical help in bettering conditions for Indians has been well-expressed in a Brief sent to us by Mr. John Laurie (White Cloud), of Calgary. This statement of present conditions and future needs was carefully considered both by the Society as a whole, and by a sub-committee composed of Mr. Pickford and Mr. Carl, as objects to give the matter special consideration. The Brief has attracted the sympathetic support of the Oliver Society, of which Mr. Albert Allan is the President.

The Report of the Okanagan Society makes reference to the above Brief also, and states that they have a similar report on the rehabilitation of the Indian people in process of compilation. The Society has had to curtail some of its activities due to the war, and the absence of Mr. Anthony Walsh whose work in the Unakonop School had been one of their most successful projects.

Once more as Christmas draws near we wish all our readers and friends a Merry and Blessed Christmas. May the Infant Jesus bless you and all those dear to you.
