The 1940-41 school term is now well underway, despite a late opening of classes this year, due to the spread of poliomyelitis in Alberta.

The newest and most important innovation in our programme of studies this year has been the adoption of a definite course for woodwork. We must admit though that woodwork here has not yet been fully organized as planned, due to numerous improvements about the school and farm buildings, at which our boys have been constantly occupied to date. Unfortunately most of the work done could not be classified amongst the operations and projects of a first year course. However the entire schedule for this year, we hope, will be covered in due time.

Original descriptions of the most recent improvements will be given by the pupils themselves in the "School Section" of this magazine.

This new system has long been waited for and has now been appreciatively received at this School. The entire staff is ready to do their utmost to obtain the results that necessarily should follow. Thus, with the academic, religious and physical training our children are receiving, manual training should help enormously towards the better preparation of our pupils for their adult lives.

The new church on the Sampson Reserve will be ready for the celebration of Midnight Mass on Christmas. Bro. Kacl and Mr. Ovilin Fortier, woodwork instructor, are actually finishing the interior. It is expected that Mass will be celebrated at the new church twice a month. It is also expected that the Indians will respond to all that is being done for their spiritual welfare, by assisting regularly at all Church services.

This organisation has been formed for the benefit of the Indians of the Hobbema Reserves. Its aim or objective is improvement and progress in every line. It is a study Club as well as a 'benefit' club, which has so far sponsored 3 movies to date and which will later sponsor picnics, sports events and perhaps sports clubs.

As it is required of members of any other Club certain obligations are required of the members of this Club. The two first and most important are:

2. Receiving of Holy Communion once a month.

Other obligations and rules are to be formulated by the members themselves. The Club will also devote some of its meetings to study and discussion. For this reason some of the leading men in our locality and from other places, if necessary, will be asked to lecture on problems of everyday importance in the sphere of the home, of the farm, or in the field of health both corporal and spiritual.

The Club has been very fortunate in obtaining Rev. Father Yott, O.M.I., as its Chaplain and Director. 'Tis the secret of Education, albeit a task. "Climb though the Rocks be Rugged". Education is never too expensive if we really believe it is desirable to make our boys and girls good Christians and good Citizens.

In this "climb", the Club gave us the good counsel. Youth Training: the impetus; the C.Y.O.: wings. "Health of the body for health of the mind", says Mr. J.H. Ross. That's what Youth Training has given Grouard's Youth. From this stepping stone, our boys and girls have automatically walked into the C.Y.O. for a higher training...a training of the mind and will at the service of God and Country.

In other words, every member of the C.Y.O. is taught and given a chance to be his best self.

Leader.
OLD PUPILS' PARTY.

This is the first year I have the good luck to attend an Old Pupils' party, and I surely did enjoy it too. The old pupils began to arrive about four o'clock, and what chatting and teasing there was until it was time to set the tables. When all was ready, the boys drew a girl's name from a box, and then took this girl to supper. This was most exciting, and there were many shouts of laughter at some partners.

Supper was served in fancy baskets to about fifty or sixty guests, not counting the six babies of some of our Old Timers who brought the family along. Sister Jean gave us a little talk, in which she urged us to be true to our ideals. She recalled the memory of the many old pupils who are fighting our fight across the sea.

Mike McDermott and Veronica Gamler gave us some good music, and with all the games, music and fun, the evening passed all too soon, and before we knew it, we were home again, anxious for the next Old Pupils' reunion.

Elsie PHILLIPS.

HOLIDAY MEMORIES.

Christmas was a very nice feast as usual. The Midnight Mass brought such a crowd to church that many had to stand at the back. Before Mass, Private John Bourgeois home on leave, sang the solo he used to sing here every Christmas when he was a pupil here. It was sad, and brought back many memories. Johnny said he was wondering where he would spend next Christmas. We were wondering about that too.....

Edith GLADU

On Christmas afternoon, we received our gifts which are sent to us each year by the High School girls at Yakima, Wash. They were nice gifts, and so nicely wrapped. We wrote and thanked them all for their great kindness to us.

Aline MASKINACK

A Tale of a Hare

Before Christmas, Sister often sent us out to the woods to get trees. There were so many rabbits around that we would come home with as many rabbits as trees.

One day, Father Forcade turned a live rabbit loose in the school basement. Our old black cat sniffed and sniffed, and arched her back each time the rabbit moved. It was very funny to watch them. Finally, we sold the rabbit to Father Marcot for twenty cents.

Lance Corporal Sam TWIN.

A NEW PRESIDENT.

On the feast of St. John Bosco we had an election to replace Pete Gladu who is no longer in school. We think we made a very wise choice, and we are proud of our new president: William John Chalifoux.
School Activities

SCHOOL OF THE CIVIL SERVICE.

Our Inspector's Visit.

Just a few weeks before Christmas, Mr. Stehelin came to inspect our school. When he walked into our room, we were all so busy wrapping up the last issue of "Echoes" for that afternoon's mail, that we did not see him till he got right in the room. He must have thought we were having a pleasant time of our Enterprise, for one of our old pupils, Private Victor Bourgeois, home on leave, was playing the piano for us while we worked. Mr. Stehelin seemed to think it was nice that a soldier on leave was interested enough in his old school to come and spend an afternoon to entertain his old teacher and schoolmates. Mr. Stehelin showed his satisfaction when he promised he would come back the following week for our Display.

Sergeant Alfred THIBAULT.

SCHOOL OF ADVANCED TRAINING.

Catechism.

Our catechism classes this year are so interesting that we have had to bring in a lot of extra seats for all those who wish to attend. Besides all our pupils and the Training School girls, we have Major V. Paquet, Captain Nancy Thomas, Pauline Twin, Corporal Nora Cardinal, and even the Bishop's Secretary, Miss B. Lemieux. We often have arguments outside of school to try to find answers to the problems Father Forcade asks us to think over.

Sergeant Viola WILLIER.

SCHOOL OF SOCIAL REFORM.

Gift Exchange.

Our Christmas gift exchange this year was more exciting than ever because all the catechism class put their names in for the exchange. On the last day before the holidays, we all brought our parcels and put them under the tree. Father and Brother Paquet had such a big box to carry, that they had to bring Father Maheu along to help them drag it to school on the sleigh. I won't let any secrets out, but you can just guess that there were plenty of tricks played and that everyone got his money's worth of fun.

Sergeant Viola WILLIER.

SCHOOL OF TRADE AND COMMERCE.

Handicrafts.

Are you interested in learning a trade? Join this school and you will be taught: Printing, Basketry, Weaving, Dyeing, etc., etc.
ACTIVITIES

Religious Ceremony

THE FEAST OF THE IMMACULATE CONCEPTION this year was a special C.Y.O. day. It started off with a beautiful Mass at which Brothers Fortier and Tremblay renewed their vows. At High Mass, we marched to church in squads in full uniform. The Schola sang the Proper of the Mass from downstairs, and at the afternoon Benediction, we all sang the Magnificat in four voices.

Distinctions

Before the Officers' dinner, a court of Honor was held in the boys' hall. The officers stood at attention while our Leader explained the nice ceremony at which Major Brother Paquet received the Distinction of St. Michael while Captain Nancy Thomas and Sgt. Joe Providence were awarded the St. Bernard Distinction. Everyone felt very happy over these well-earned awards, and sang very gayly a song which had been arranged for this big event. We cheered these popular officers, and gave them a hearty hand shake in congratulation for the honor that had come to them.

Lieutenant Charlie WHITE.

Officers' Mess

Our first OFFICERS' DINNER had been so much like a beautiful dream that we were glad to have another "banquet" to prove such things really do happen! Busy hands had decorated our classroom with Our Lady's colors and had turned it into a nice banquet hall. What with a courteous gentleman as my dinner escort, dainty waitress at my beck and call, music, and "food for the gods" such as Sister Mary Adelia knows so well how to prepare, I almost fooled myself into thinking that I was "Queen Ann".

When Fr. Forcade, our Toastmaster stood up, we all began to wonder... Sure enough, the "hunch" I had came true, and the first thing I knew, I was trying to make a speech. Just my luck! I had the misfortune of thanking different ones, especially the cooks, and as soon as I had sat down, the Toastmaster rubbed it in about thanking myself... because I had helped cook that week.

Several others gave toasts too. We are growing braver about this too as Father "spots" us in this, just as he does in Gym and we know he won't ever let us down.

All this, with a few songs, one especially in honor of the guests who came to hear the Toasts, and a box of chocolates given for the supper by Miss Lemieux, made the party end very sweetly.

Corporal Annie THOMAS
Domestic School.

Our Retreat

A few weeks ago, we had a chance to set our spiritual affairs in order in a three day Retreat, preached to us by Rev. Father Nadeau, O.M.I. We all enjoyed it very much and hope we will be better children for it.

Roland GABOURY.
TRAINING SCHOOL

One day early in December, we were very sorry to hear that our teacher, Sister Margaret Mary, was leaving us for the hospital in Edmonton, where she had to undergo a serious operation. We surely worried about her, but frequent letters brought us hope for her recovery. To our great joy, it did come, slow but sure, and we are glad to say she is back home again, with all kinds of new and interesting ideas for us.

KIND HELPERS

During Sr. Margaret Mary's absence, Sr. Norbert helped Sr. Eustache to keep things going at the Training School. She is our tailor, and she shows us how to cut patterns. We appreciate all the help she gave Sr. Eustache during the weeks Sister Margaret was away, and we thank them both for their kindness to us.

A GRAND SURPRISE

During the Christmas holidays, we were occupying the skating rink every minute of our free time. Skating is surely a pleasant amusement in this part of the country. By the way, we wish to thank Rev. Father Habay for being so kind as to buy us skates. When we first got them, we did not know who had sent them to us, but after a thousand and one questions, "a little bird" (with a beard!!) told us. A big, big Thank You, dear Father. Now we don't have to borrow the boys' skates any more, but can just whizz past them! Brother Nichol put a light over the rink the other day; it makes it much pleasanter at night.

BRAVO, MARGARET!

Yesterday, when we came to practice for Singing, we were treated to a grand sight: Margaret Fraser, learning to skate! We were doubled up from laughing; she was doubled up—but for other reasons. She had a strong supporter on either side, but even they were not enough to keep her upright. We all said, "Mr. Winkle has come to Grouard!"

WEAVING

We have some new looms, and you should see all the lovely things we are making. I am happy to think I will learn so many new things this year. Three cheers for our dear old Domestic Training School!!

Corporal Eella CARDINAL.
YOUTH TRAINING

DRAMATICS
Xmas Concert.

Perhaps the most enjoyable concert we ever had was this year's Xmas program. If we took just two weeks to prepare most of it, it was because we had been so well drilled in our weekly Dramatics classes. We are getting over our shyness by volunteering to sing or dramatize something new for the class. We are getting lots of fun out of it, and some are learning that they could be pretty good at acting.

STARS
One who took an important part in a play and surprised everyone, and especially herself by her fine acting, was Cora Desjarlais. Annie Thomas as Mrs. Ruggles will not soon be forgotten. She made us laugh so hard, it hurt.

CHINS UP, BOYS
In memory of our many pupils who have joined the Armed Forces, the boys had the tableau, "Just before the battle, Mother!" From behind the scenes, as the words of the song died away, we heard the bugle call, followed by the roll of drums. Many liked this number best of all.

Marjorie TALLMAN.

Sorry Folks
We were asked to repeat this concert, as many people wanted to come from neighboring towns, and others wanted to see it again, but we were unable to do so. Sorry. The next performance is on March 18th.

THERE'S MUSIC IN THE AIR
Rythm Band

My! My! were we ever proud of ourselves when we came out to play our Band selections at the concert! The applause and the cheers that greeted us were deafening. Of course we knew we looked pretty nice in our Band costumes, so we didn't mind waiting till they ceased clapping.

We had a new cymbal and two nice new drums, which Major Paquet and Sergeant Thibault surely know how to play! Our Band Director, Fr. Maheu, had arranged a medley of Xmas airs and to show you how he makes use of everything, let me tell you what he took to imitate church chimes. It was a big circular saw set up on a stand. It was hidden behind the piano, and when the "sexton" would strike it, one could imagine it was real chimes. A solo played ON SMALL BOTTLES strung up on a stand, brought a great deal of applause. We played as a last number, Fred Scott's favourite song, "Ridin' Down the Trail"...and we had to come back and play it all over again because they liked it so much.

Ellen Brunelle. (VII)

COMMUNITY SINGING
We do a great deal of Community Singing at Displays and Movies on Sunday nights. Fr. Forcade gets on his bench and directs, he teases them and soon he has them all going strong. At the Display, we could hear our BISHOP'S beautiful voice as he joined in the crowd for singing. Even our school INSPECTOR got going with us.

Lt. Cora DESJARLAIS.
Who says Grouard is just a "mud hole"? Well, I don't, and you wouldn't either if you belonged to our Youth Training centre...where we have lots of good, healthy fun, and keep so gay we don't see the mud...if ever there was any!

You should see all the new things we have for our exercises too: a piano for the Girl's Hall, a springboard, benches, new mats, a big box horse and a canvas blanket to make our landing softer when we spring from the board. I fear the blanket won't last very long with our Major landing his 190 lbs. on it so often. Each time he jumps in it, you can hear the poor thing groan!

Sergeant Alfred THIBAULT.

V.T. CONVENTION

During the Xmas. Holidays, Father Forcade, our Y.T. Leader, attended a Leader's Convention in Edmonton. He was gone a week and came back quite satisfied. He told us that the Y.T. Officials had encouraged him and that we might have the pleasure of Mr. Ross' and Mr. McNally's visit in spring. With our new Equipment and our "peppy" Leader we feel we are tops and we are always glad to show others how we feel about it.

Lieutenant Charlie WHITE.

New Year Ride

On New Year's, four teams of horses sleigh-rided us around the country, though it was pretty cold. Swell fun!

Mary Edith GLADU.

Bingo & Display

On New Year's night we had a Bingo Party in which we had lots to eat, lots of prizes to win and lots of fun. A few days after, we had an Amateur Display in which we played informal games. By the time we got through, there were so many peanut shells on the floor that we did not need to use the mats to make rolls and headstands.

Lilly WARD.

The BIG DISPLAY

Our last Big Display was a real hit...at least we were told so. Mr. Stehelin, our Inspector, came all the way from McLennan to attend. He had invited Sr. Superior and the teachers from Guy school to come with him. They all took part in Community singing and seemed to have enjoyed our stunts, our Rythm Band and our dress parade.

In his speech, afterwards, Mr. Stehelin said that we were very lucky boys and girls, "This school, said he, is the finest of my Inspectorate." We gave a big cheer when he gave us a holiday.

Corporal Nora CARDINAL.

IMPOSSIBLE

MAJOR: The pass-word for the week is "dressing!"

GUARD: When will we get a chance to undress? You're always around!
C.Y.O.

BROADCASTING STATION

Our "SUNA," (Finnish Steam Baths), one for the boys and one for the girls, is more popular than any summer resort. What wondrous "steam pudding" we make after Gym classes and on Saturdays.

Officers here don't promote just on their good looks. To become a Major, Capt. Nancy must know how to give First Aid to little Licut. Jeannette if she breaks her collar bone over the Box-horse. To become a Colonel, Major Paquet must know all about Kinseology. He's wishing for the time being that people didn't have quite so many muscles...

Night-watchman Turetto, former P.T. Instructor in the army, has started to ride our Box-horse. Every time he rides it something grunts. QUESTION: is it the horse or the rider or...both?

Everyone thought Fr. Maheu's idea about the circular saw (for chimes) was wonderful except the Manager of the Sawmill. Just what he thought is not known...

Speaking of the Rhythm Band...Fr. Maheu had a Trombone solo at our last concert. The Trombone was made up of a Player blowing a Kazoo in a Gramophone Horn. We still have the Player and the Kazoo but what happened to the Horn...? The finder will get a reward...

What's become of two famous parkas— one white and one black—that were such familiar sights just before Christmas? Did they really journey back to Eskimo-land?

Elvis's got that Bridge stunt done pat. A cheap and elegant bridge at that. Did you see her in the picture?

3d
Old Pupils' Corner

Dear Old Timers:

At the old pupils' party, where so many of us gathered for the sake of "Auld Lang Syne", those of you who were unable to attend were surely not forgotten. We spoke of you and the gay times we have had together in this classroom, where we wished you could all have been to enjoy the fun. It would have done your heart good to hear the gay voices...in particular, Michael McDermott's ringing laugh which cost him a forfeit. Leo Dufresne did his share as usual by being the clown, so that there was never a dull moment.

May I offer my tardy thanks to the many who sent Xmas greetings in the form of letters, cards or sweets? I deeply appreciated your thoughtfulness...and hope to keep sweet throughout the year, in consequence!

Did you hear the wedding bells that rang out a few weeks ago for someone you and I thought enough of some years ago to elect as our first Club President. Yes, our dear Louise Laird is now Mrs. John Calahaisson. I was happy to offer best wishes in your name as well as mine.

Mary Louise Sawan McDermott is the proud mother of a baby daughter born a few weeks ago. This will be good company for Sonny (Richard) who is quite a handsome big chap now.

At the General Hospital in Edmonton, Lena Gladu is still fighting for health, and seems to be winning the battle too, according to a cheery message received at Christmas time.

We have another soldier's picture on our piano...no other than our dear Roy Smith's, this time. Roy was home on leave at Christmas, but we did not have the pleasure of seeing him as he was in the hospital most of the time. Better luck next time, Roy!

Paul Hurtubise is now overseas with the R.C.A.F. Good luck to you, Paul, and may your "shots" be as accurate as they were when you "fired" things at your schoolmates here!

Does it bring back pleasant memories to see your Club motto on the cover of our "ECHOES"? I trust it may remind you to keep your face uplifted towards the beautiful, the worth-while things of life. Cling to your youthful ideals, strive to make them come true in your life, so that those who come in contact with you may be happier and better for it. That is not asking too much of a "Good Counsellor", is it?

On the following page, you will find parts of some of the very interesting letters I have recently received from some of our old crowd. Knowing the great affection you have always had for your old classmates, I can think of nothing that would give you greater pleasure than to share these messages with you. May this strengthen the bonds of friendship that bind us all together.

Sister Jean Placide
Dear Teacher and pupils:

Thanks a million for the last Echoes, which were even more interesting than the previous ones received. Such lovely snaps which indeed puts the finishing touches to the Journal. By the way, Sister, when am I going to get a snap of YOU? If I don't get one soon, I.......

I am pleased the C.Y.O. IS such a success and that everyone is interested and finds enjoyment, besides helping to build body and soul..........................

Lucky Don, that's me! Yes, I was lucky to spend such a lovely Christmas with my wife and family in England. We went to Midnight Mass, and then we made a flying visit to Newcastle to see Baby Fovargue, Eileen and George. I am pleased to tell you that they are all fine, and that we all hoped the Grouard folks had as good a break as George and I.

Pleased you received the wedding cake, and by now I hope you have received the photographs.

So a good many more Old Timers have JOINED THE COLOURS. Good Show! How I should like to run across them. Still may happen, seeing they are gradually coming over............

Well, Teacher, I wish you all the happiness and success possible for 1942, and may we soon have those tough Huns under our heels! Cheerio and keep smiling!

Love and best wishes.....

Don. (Fovargue)

From her

PUPILS

Dear Don;

You deserve all the good things that have come your way, and I trust they may continue...for Time and for Eternity.

Was thrilled to hear that you are now "Uncle Don". Be sure to live up to the dignity of your title! I can well imagine all the tall stories Baby Pauline will soon be listening to from Daddy and Uncle...about the days they spent in Grouard School, when they were Sister Joan's "Angels". Please congratulate George and Eileen on the bonny, wee lassie, and offer best wishes from us all to this second-generation Club Member.

Write again, Old Faithful!

S.J.P.

Canadian Army Overseas.
January 3, 1942.

Dear Sister Jean:

Hello, Sister! Had a swell trip across, and I'm safe and sound, thanks to the good Lord. Maybe it's the
prayers of you and your pupils that helped along. I regret that I did not see you just before I left, to go to Dundurn. I sure had a swell time in Grouard, for I knew it would be my last out there. But I pray I may return someday to the old home.

I will be going on my landing leave next week, for five days. I'll be going to GLASGOW with Antoine Cardinal to see the sights.

The climate is sure great and I like it fine, never saw a bit of snow since I left Canada. Say Hello to all the pupils for me, and tell them to drop me a line. I wish them the best of luck.

Guess I'll sign off by sending best regards to your pupils, and last but not least,, to you, dear teacher, best regards and love.

Your old pupil,
Victor Bourgeois.

Dear Victor;

Sooms impossible to think of you in England...you wore horo such a short time ago. But you know that we're all proud of you, Laddie, and that our prayers will faithfully second daily for the brave soldier boy whose pictured gaco smiles so cheerfully at us all day long.

Hope you haven't lost the heads I gave you, and that you will be the same good old "Vic" in the army that you wore horo. Y... for VICTORY and VICTOR TOO!

S.J.P.

Lebret, Saskatchewan.
January 4, 1942.

Dear Sister Jean,

Thank you, Sister. I received your parcel and letter and enjoyed all..........................

Here Christmas was quiet with that quietness which best stresses the peace and joy of the season. We had just buried one of our young priests who had been ordained last June, and naturally that had some effect in saddening our Community. However, Christmas never loses its meaning...Listen to me chatter away, and are we ever rhapsodical?

How did you like Churchill's address to the Senate and Congress? He simply AROUSES me! I often told you, when I was young, that he was my MAN, and that liking for him has not decreased!! "What a chicken" and other of his "Churchillian" expressions usually strike home...

Don't you think I've been long enough? Goodbye, Sister, and pray for me, don't forget. I'm trying to make sure you hear my "Thank You" for your kindness.

Yours very sincerely,
Harry Thomas, O.M.I.

Dear Harry,

Now, don't be so indignant over my printing part of your letter...In spite of your modesty which we admire, remember, you are still OUR Harry, our first Vico-President in whom we are very much interested. You are also the first and only Good Counsellor so far, who has donned the robe of a Missionary. Need I tell you that this commands all our respect and affection?

Everyone horo sends you greetings; it is always a family feast when a letter from you arrives, so come AGAIN!

S.J.P.

Fort Ware, B.C.
Jan. 2, 1942.

Dear Sister Jean,

"Greetings", Sister, from an old pupil! When I received your letter, I was in the bush, with a survey party, 150 miles North of here, and I had absolutely no chance of thanking you till now..............................

As I sat by the radio and listened to the lovely strains of "Silent Night" on Xmas eve, my mind raced back to the days when I was an altar boy and assisting at Midnight Mass. Yes, as I sat there, my voice unconsciously lifted as it did in days gone by, and not till it had ended, did I realize
Correspondence -- (Concluded)

that I was sitting alone.

"There was a feeling in my breast,
A feeling I could not suppress,
What it was— I leave to you to
guess"........

Sister, I hope this finds you in
the best of health and spirits, and
please forgive me for not writing..
As ever, your old pupil,

Dear old Sambo,

Though the years have made a big man
out of my little boy, I see you are still
a poet—a dreamer of dreams! Your letters
are always a "thing of beauty and a joy
forever" for your old teacher; wish I could
print them all for everyone to enjoy.

Make of your life, a thing of beauty too,
Sam....We want you to help us celebrate
when we get to the "OLD PUPILS' CORNER" in
Heaven. My best wishes to you, and also to
my old lazy Helen, who hasn't written for
ages, but whom I love just the same!

S.J.P.

Dear Sister Jean,

I wish you a happy new year.
Thank you for the candy you sent me.
It is not cold in Montreal. I got a
tie and handkerchief, a V...for
Victory from Mackay School. Goodbye.
Charles Gregory.

Dear Charles,

You write very nice letters. My pupils
think you are a better writer than many of
them. They all like your letters. Be good!
Sister Joan.

Linthorpe, England.

My dear Sister Jean,

This certainly is one of the
greatest privileges of my life, to
be allowed to correspond with you,
and now I am looking forward very
much to receiving letters from you.
Don has told me such a lot about
you that I feel as though I really
know you personally. We are looking
forward to the day when we shall
all meet; it will certainly be a
wonderful reunion.

I always read the "Echoes" you
send to Don, and I enjoy them very
much.

I am sending you under separate
cover, some photographs of our
wedding, also a calendar which I
have been pencil-painting for you.
I do hope you will accept this
humble little present.

Lovingly,

Dear Joan,

I have already thanked you for this
nice letter, but permit me today to add
another Thank You for the lovely photo
and the wonderful silk painting of the
R.A.F. crest. I see Don had married an
artist! I do appreciate your lovely
gift, Joan, and as soon as I can have

right close to your brave husband's photo.

I am sure you and Don will be happy
to know that I have had 75 reprints made
from your wedding photo, for the old
pupils and our friends. Be sure of

LAST MINUTE NEWS......

It is with regret that we have learned of the serious illness of our loved Superior, Rev. Father J. Habay. Father left us last week for Edmonton, and has since been obliged to undergo a serious surgical operation. We pray that all may be well very soon.

Rev. Father Lajoie, our Vicariate Bursar, is also ill at the Hospital in Edmonton. Our sympathy, Father, and we hope it will not be long till you are entirely well again.

Of all the pleasant things to do at the Mission this year, the least is NOT skating...... Thanks to Father Giguere who worked day and night for a time, the RINK is a grand place to fly around on.

Sister Jean has twelve Music pupils this year. You should hear all the harmony, when they practice scales and chords. They all seem to start out with the piece, "Are You Sleeping?", and we all feel like saying, "No, but I sure wish I was, then I wouldn't hear YOU!!"

The boys in the Manual Training shop are doing BIG things in the line of wood-carving. They made some good-looking sleighs too.

It is nice to have our Bishop home again.. He had to be absent for two months just at Christmas time, when we miss him most. But he's home for GOOD, we hope!

Brother Allie and Brother L'Etourneau came home a few weeks ago from Sturgeon Lake.

From MRS. R. E. WODERHOUSE

DOMINION PRESIDENT, WOMEN'S AUXILIARY

I am so glad to have this opportunity of at least saying thank you to all my many friends in the Yukon. It was very gratifying to note the well-kept appearance of the little churches in the Yukon, in many cases of log construction, but inside, so beautifully appointed, and so splendidly clean.

The highlights of my term of office as Dominion President of the Women's Auxiliary, will be one of the most thrilling experiences to remember—the most wonderful scenery surely in the world—and yet, it is not of that I go to evidence of the same thought and devotion to your Church, your community, always among the best things worth while. I think life in the North soon strips one of artificiality and it is this that impressed me most—that in your part of the world only real things matter. It was also most revealing to travel so far from the centre of Canada and find people so well informed on the questions of the day. What a thrill it gave me in Whitehorse, for instance, to be able to listen to the "B.C. News" direct from London"—to meet people following so closely events happening in other parts of the world.

As I think of all I saw and heard while in the Yukon, my mind impresses and blesses.

ST. PAUL'S CATHEDRAL

Dawson

The Annual Harvest Festival was held on August 26th in St. Paul's Pro-Cathedral, when the services were celebrated by the Rector, the Rev. Wm. Valentine.

The Church was very tastefully decorated with the usual Harvest offerings of flowers, fruit and vegetables, together with the beautiful varied autumn leaves so wonderful in the Yukon. There were good congregations at all services.

At a business meeting of St. Paul's W.A. held at the Rectory on September 2nd, it was announced that the sum of $70 had been realized from the sale of refreshments on Discovery Day, August 18th. As it had been formerly decided that this money should be spent on materials for making garments for refugees, approximately $50.00 was spent on flannelette for pyjamas, etc. This means a very busy season for all members of the W.A.

Death has been busy once more among the ranks of our Church members. Mr. Frederick Hickling, a pioneer of Dawson and a valued Church member ever since he came here in the early days, passed away suddenly on September 11th.

The funeral was held on September 28th under the auspices of the Masons, the Oddfellows and the Pioneers, and was largely attended by all classes. He leaves a widow and two sons, one of whom, William, flew all the way from New York to pay his last respects to his Father. Mrs. Hickling has now left to make her future home in New York, and to her we extend our sincerest sympathy, together with our best wishes for comfort in her new life.

The next to be called away was Mrs. Delia Firth, another pioneer and much loved member of our congregation. She was on a visit to Vancouver, intending to spend the winter there, recuperating after the death of her husband only a month or two previously. She was taken ill very suddenly and an emergency operation was performed, but she failed to recover from it, and died in Vancouver General Hospital on October 5th.

Her only son, Howard, attended the last sad rites in Vancouver and a number of wreaths were sent from Dawson. A Memorial Service was held in St. Paul's on October 19th, when the officiating clergyman was the Rev. Wm. Valentine. Mrs. Firth will be greatly missed by her numerous friends in the Yukon.

A very pretty wedding took place in St. Paul's on the evening of September 12th, the principals being Miss Elinor Mary Hough, only daughter of Mrs. E. M. Coukley of St. Paul's Hostel, and Mr. John Francis Donald of the N.C.C. A reception followed the ceremony held at the Rectory by the kind invitation of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine, when a crowd of friends offered their congratulations and good wishes to the radiant couple.

The Little Helpers held their Annual Service in St. Paul's on September 23rd, when nearly 30 Little Helpers, their mothers and friends, attended. The service was taken by the Rev. Wm. Valentine and afterwards refreshments were served in the Rectory.

MOOSEHIDE
St. Barnabas

So far we have had a very mild autumn with almost nightly falls of snow. The Yukon is carrying ice-floes but it is still open water. For one week we had good grayling fishing through the ice but then the present mild spell came and the ice left. The main herds of caribou are still playing around the International boundary so meat is scarce. Preparations are being made for winter trapping.

Many of our menfolk work on an equal footing with whites during the summer and they are beginning to realise that if they are to receive respect and equality from fellow citizens they have to put their own house in order. A new spirit of cooperation is abroad and we are trying to live without relief, that most shattering kindness ever devised by white man for a native. As Moosehide natives have been allowed relief since gold rush days it is going to be some time before it becomes a custom of the past. Prayers supported by hard work are bound to bring success.

EDUCATION OF THE MIND

Personality is developed by personal activities: activities of the mind and activities of the will.

"The mind does not unfold spontaneously." It must be EDUCATED.

In our civilization, we have schools—many of them; attendance is compulsory; curriculums are standardized and laden—We would like to think they might do the job...!!

Is this not wishful thinking? Formal teaching imparts knowledge—it instructs the mind but does not educate it. A learned burglar is always a liability to his country. Until the mind has been educated to BELIEVE in truth, it is still in the dark.

Yet "no one can learn to distinguish right from wrong, and beauty from vulgarity by taking a course of lectures. It can only be taught by making it present in a child's surroundings and part of his daily life. Growth of intelligence is obtained by training and exercise, whereas the other activities of consciousness demand a group with whose existence they are identified."

* * *

At the Grouard School, this education is attempted in the Good Counsel Club and in the C. Y. O.

By various ways and means, these organizations promote Faith in Truth. Everything, in the social life of the members, from their responsibilities and weekly passwords down to their beautiful uniforms is meant to make them feel that truth is equivalent to good, justice, charity, and beauty; that in it is to be found happiness, honor and victory; that it is really worth to live and die for; that it is the ROYAL in us which has CLAIMS on us all.

A staunch Faith in Truth makes better Christains, better Lovers and better Countrymen!!!

If you would live for SONG—WAR—LOVE—

Then Faith must be your guide,
The Justice of your cause,
Should make you brave in strife—
For that which you hold true,
You must lay down your life,
And your honour maintain
E'en though victory be denied—

If you would live—Then Faith must be your guide!

An OLD TIMER Speaks

It turned out to be one of those beautiful days... though the week-end hadn't forecasted as much. But when dawned April 26th, Feast of Our Lady of Good Counsel, the beautiful weather helped us to rejoice.

CLUB MASS.

Every year, all Club members give a small offering so that we may have two Masses said, one for our living and one for our departed members. You see, OLD TIMERS, what a thoughtful teacher you all had, as yearly to participate in the prayers of a second generation of Club members. That's how we started the day, by assisting at the Club Mass.

REMINISCENCES.

As we sang our beautiful Club hymn, all the old familiar faces came to my mind... came to join their dear voices to ours as in days long since gone. My prayers included the dear departed schoolmates who no longer respond to the summons of the Club hall. How vividly the faces of our boys in uniform came. I whispered a prayer that Our Lady would shield you all! And my own dear little brother, who has donned a higher uniform, dedicating his life's work and services to the SUPREME KING. Yes, said I, year by year the Club members chant the Requiem of the departed, sing joyous hymns at some happy classmates' wedding, or listen with joy to the bells pealing out the tidings of baptisms of another generation of Good Counsellors. And through all this, the Club bonds endure though miles and miles separate us from many of our old and beloved companions of bygone, happier days!

CLUB REUNION.

After the evening Benediction, we gathered 'round OUR TEACHER, and visited our departed members' graves. Back in the dear old classroom we listened to the short but effective motherly advice given us by Sister Joan, after which Father Forcade entertained us by lecturing the key Community singing, and showing us beautiful pictures on a Projector. Some photos full of faces of the OLD TIMERS are flashed on the screen, to our great enjoyment. Again, our dear teacher's kindness was shown by the delightful lunch which was served before the festivities ended.

Long live our Club, our Teacher, and all our members!!!

Mrs. JOHN GIROUX (Marguerite Thomas)
School Activities

PRINTING THE "ECHOES".

Have you ever wondered how we go about printing our "ECHOES"? If you were to step in our classroom a few days before we "go to press", you would see a very busy workshop. When the pupils have handed in their articles, Sister Jean types them on to the stencils. I hope I'll soon be smart enough to help her at this job! When Sr. Benigna or Belle Cardinal have put in the designs, Fr. Forcade helps the boys print the stencils. Next comes the sorting and assembling of sheets. A group puts in the photos, while others do the stuffing, or prepare the paper and envelopes for the mail. When the 210 copies are finished, each one gives a big sigh of satisfaction and relief.

Ellen Brunelle—Grade VIII.

PRACTICAL TRAINING.

It is a good thing we have some movable desks in our room, as our class is used for so many useful activities. We girls should surely know how to set an attractive table and to put up decorations after all the practice we've had this year for Officers' Dinners, Old Pupils' Reunions etc.

A Big Secret.

Every evening, of late, our classroom becomes a second "HOLLYWOOD" where great stars take their training in Dramatics. We are working hard in preparation for our concert to be given May 15th, in honor of our Bishop's feast. (Shh! It's a big secret—don't tell him...but be sure YOU keep the date in mind.)

We Learn by Doing.

While the boys have been busy making potato-picking boxes, we girls embroidered a new set of monograms for our uniforms. It took a long time to make the first, but after that it was easy.

Roland Gaboury is proud to see that the nice flower basket he just finished is being used for our May altar.

In the Junior rooms, we see everything from paper houses to live caterpillars.

Elsie Phillips.
HALL NEWS

Did you notice:

The girls' new MERRY-GO-ROUND? It's wartime, and carpenters are few and far between, so we made the new TOY out of an old totter-totter. It's quite the thrill!

That Father Superior took ONLY Girls to cut and sow potatoes? That is SOME FEATHER in our hats!!

That Buster is almost one of ourselves now that his dear master, Father Marcotte, is gone? He knows a good place, so he has adopted the Girls' yard... even though Sister M. Ambrose isn't so fond of this extra "boarder."

Aline Maskinak, since we saw the picture-show, "Ride 'EM Cowgirl." She sure has made up her mind that she can do just as well, if not better! The rest of us aren't quite so sure about that, though.

How SWEET the girls can be when they want to coax Sr. Clare Eva to take them to play ball out of their own yard???

How quiet it was when Marjorie Tallman went to High Prairie for a few days? Marjorie sees ghosts at nights, and does she scream? In the daytime, she makes up for it by being a good JOKER, so we are very glad she is back again.

All the fun we had roasting our potatoes in Sr. M. Ambrose's big BONFIRE last Saturday. Yum! Yum! Did it taste like home? We hope Sister will have more rubbish to burn each Saturday!

Lieutenant Nora Cardina l.

Did you notice:

What a wonderful improvement there is in the Schola? That's because our Director added eight fresh LITTLE BOYS' voices. Everyone is raving about the way they sing the Proper of the Mass in four parts.

How clearly the BASS rings out when the Schola harmonizes? I learned the trick when Brother Paquet and William John deserted me one Sunday and I was left alone for the Bass. But if you want to learn how-you'll have to join the Schola!

How quickly the chocolates and oranges near our plates disappeared on Easter morning? GONE, but NOT FORGOTTEN........

The nice hand-painted neckties the boys are wearing with their second-class Uniforms? Sr. Therese Bernadette painted the C.Y.O. design on them without Sr. Denise Lucille noticing it - and was there joy and surprise all around?????

How much BEBE Noir's chest sticks out since he comes to the Dramatics classes? We rather think he and "Margot" will quite steal the show...as Pickininnies.

The nice rose bushes Sister Denise is carefully and tenderly working over each sunny day? It seems that they are a very rare kind...one that even lambs may eat with relish and feel no bad effects from.............??????

Captain Charlie White.
ACTIVITIES

Religious Events

Easter Sunday's beautiful Pontifical High Mass came as the crowning part of a most impressive Holy Week at which His Excellency, Bishop Langlois, had officiated. We had the pleasure of hearing His Excellency preach in French and in English at the C.Y.O. Mass. Father Superior was well enough to speak to the people in Cree.

In the afternoon, we assisted in full dress uniform, again, at the singing of the Complines, followed by Benediction given by our Bishop. These beautiful ceremonies were attended by most of the surrounding population, as it is their chosen day for their Easter duties.

Colonel V. Paquet, O.M.I.

Court of Honor

At the Court of Honor held on the last C.Y.O. day, we had the great honor of having Bishop Langlois present. Many of our officers and Guards were decorated. After he had sung the Leader's Prayer, Fr. Forcade explained that these awards were given for good deeds. Sister Superior pinned on the St. Michael and Father Superior, the St. Bernard Distinctions. Then His Excellency pinned the St. Ubald's Award on Capt. Janet Clark... and did we envy her? She is the only one so far to have had the Bishop in person present on her. Captain Charlie White wasn't here to receive his St. Ubald's Award, as he had gone to the Hospital for a few days. Bishop then told us how happy he was to know that so many had deserved to be decorated. He reminded us that the C.Y.O. is not selfish; that it trains us to serve a CAUSE: the love of God and of our neighbour. He finished by telling us this reward should urge us on to work hard for the reward that GOD will give us.

Sergeant Bella Cardinal.

Easter Dinner

Our "Banquet Hall" for the dinner was all decorated in Easter colors. Chocolate eggs, bunnies and chicks gazed at us from each place. Sr. Mary A delta must have done a good deal of hard work to give us such a nice supper. I was happy to have the pleasure of eating with the Major Officers for the first time.

In his after-dinner speech, Father announced the opening of a School for Officers. He then called upon Sister Superior, who had come in to hear the toast, to speak next. We congratulated all Sr. Superior said to us, but it made us sad to think that she would not be here for many more C.Y.O. days.

Several Officers gave clever talks. Of course they knew beforehand that they would be asked to speak, so they had prepared for it. After some gay songs, we went to prepare for the big Display. Just one more Officers' Dinner! Too, too bad!

Lieutenant Viola Willier.

Hard Time Party

On the Thursday after Easter, the Officers gave a Hard time Party in honor of those who had won Awards at the Court of Honor. The Sisters chose the funniest costume, as we marched around the classroom. It was a real circus to see us all.

After a Bing party, a treat of popcorn and Punch, we went home with a prize that was a SURPRISE!

Lance Corporal H. Sinclair.
YOUTH TRAINING

C.Y.O. Day.

Easter Sunday dawned bright and clear. It seemed as if it had to be that way, being Our Lord's day of Resurrection...and then too, it was our C.Y.O. Day. After all the other wonderful events of the day were over, it was time for our big Display.

A big crowd attended, and it was considered the most interesting of all our Displays. It started at eight o'clock with Community Singing. Our Leader repeated "Leader's Prayer" by request, and then after we had showed that we had "brought our voice along", Father made us "fall in" for the Dress parade.

Then came the change into Gym suits, followed by a parade which included skipping, dancing, and fancy steps. This was followed by Colonel Dr. Faquet's command of a formation which included V's for Victory, and other pretty figures.

The smaller boys were found very daring when it came to Forward Rolls and head-springs off the box-horse.

What the crowd enjoyed the most was the games. When it came to the race where the two teams had to dress each other up in old straw hats, boots and all, we were just sick from laughing.

A group of girls acted out a car. Some were the wheels, others were the steering wheel, the motor and even the pump to fix flats with! There was a seat for the couple who owned the car, and when the car would go, the old man would hang on to his wife for dear life!

Father said the side who won the first three games would have the next Gym class, and the side that won the next three would get an extra Steam Bath. The boys got the extra Gym class, but we got the other reward.

Goodbye - Displays!

It seemed as if the Display came to a sudden jerk and then stopped...everyone was wishing it would last much longer. There were some people who had seen a Display for the first time, and they were just astonished over it. I suppose it was because there was so much quick action, with not a minute lost. We are terribly sorry that that is the last Display for this year. Father said there would be a Field Day though, and that should be even better fun.

Major C. Desjarlais.

Batter Up!

Along with Spring Fever comes a more pleasant one: Baseball Fever! We have some pretty good teams this year...and it is fun to pit our strength against each other. Because there are many big girls, and very few big boys, we girls have a pretty good chance to beat the boys this year. We have not succeeded yet, but we feel it in our bones that we will...very SOON! Watch for that bit of news in the next issue of "Echoes"....
Another Display has come and gone but our Gym Classes, thanks to Youth Training, "go on forever."

Informal Games

At our last Display, we played a few games, and seeing that it created so much interest and enthusiasm, our Leader decided we should have some more during our Gym classes. First, we divide in teams so we can have the excitement of playing for championship. We have all kinds of games but one which really makes us work is Human Croquet.

Human Croquet

There are ten girls who stand astride to represent the wires, then the players from each side crawl through these "wires." The captains rush and coach and puff in a brave attempt to get their sides through and back first. What excitement! It's a wonder the roof doesn't come off! It's real FUN...if you want to try it you're welcome!

Steam and Showers

When the class is over, we are hot and more or less played out. How heavenly it is to be refreshed by a wonderful cold shower following a Steam Bath. We often wonder what we ever did in the days we had no steam baths...how we would hate to go without them now! The more we get, the more we want, it seems.

Open Air Classes

Father Forcade has told us that as soon as ever it gets warm enough, we are going to have our Gym classes outside. Won't that be just glorious? Just now, we are using all our evenings for Dramatics, but soon we shall be able to have our regular exercises again. We are all anxious for that time.

Officer Trainers

In order that many may be trained for leadership, Father Forcade has organized a school for Officers. Class for Guards desiring to pass tests as Officers is held once a week. When they are ready to try their tests, they notify the Major Officers who observe them drill their Squads in certain specified Gym exercises. The Major Officers then turn in the grading they have given the aspirant Officer, and if they have a satisfactory rating in school and in the Hall, they are entitled to a gold cord to be worn on their uniform. When there is a vacancy in the Staff of Officers, they will then be ready to take up the work of an Officer.

Minstrel

Our DRAMATICS CLASSES are so popular that everyone wants to be in them. Our big enterprise now is a Negro Minstrel...Oh, is it fun? If you notice us slurring our R's, you'll know that it's because we are trying to get that pronunciation.

See the World!

Our Leader is getting a nice Projector for use in the school. It will be a real treasure, as we can then see all the slides and postcards available. Aren't we lucky "chilluns"?

Colonel Nancy Thomas.
Are you interested in NICE STATION-ERY? If so, you should see the C.Y.O. letterheads and envelopes we are using now. And the best part of it is that it was made right here in Crouard. Aren't we lucky to have a professional printer in our midst?

***

We were forcibly reminded of Death during Holy Week. The remains of Rev. Father DREAU who died at the Hospital at High Prairie were brought here and buried on Good Friday. The funeral Mass was chanted only after Easter. R.I.P.

***

A telegram informed FATHER MAHEU of the sudden death of his MOTHER on March 31st. Father immediately boarded a plane and flew home to sing the Requiem for his beloved mother. Our deepest sympathy with our prayers, Father!

***

Did your jaws ache last week? Ours did. They always do when FATHER KINDER-VATER pays a visit to our classroom. When he had exhausted his supply of news and jokes, he climaxed the session by singing for us. Sister says perhaps some had an "ear-ache" too...after that!

***

Santa Claus himself wouldn't have received a warmer welcome than did FATHER MARCOTTE when he paid us a flying visit last Monday. We didn't get to see half enough of him—but we are fully convinced that Father was glad to see us again and that he still knows how to tease. Even the horses and "Buster" knew him and bade him "Welcome" in their own way!

***

Why is it we don't carry a kodak around all the time? Had we done so, we'd have been able to get a prize-winning snap a few days ago—of the Bishop's Secretary! It would have done your heart good to have seen demure MISS LEMIEUX perched beside our mail-carrier in the "one-hoss shay." Judging from the convulsive grasp on the seat handle, I would venture to say it was Miss Lemieux's first buggy ride in years.....

***

"The early bird catches the worm." We had to get up mighty early to catch our Leader on his patronal feast—but in spite of all resistance and trickery—we managed to offer him our best wishes on the eve of his feast, and then to sing his six o'clock Mass the next morning. Sister had asked for about a dozen singers only—but you should have seen the crowd that insisted on coming to join their prayers and voices to Father Forcade's. We feel quite sure Heaven was kept busy receiving and answering petitions that day.

***

Certain C.Y.O. GUARDS are proudly wearing new red and blue cords on their uniforms. This proves they have passed certain tests and have had good reports in school and hall.

Old Pupils' Corner

My dear old pupils:

You will be glad, I know, that I asked Marguerite to write the Club page for this issue....it was indeed a happy inspiration. Marguerite is always my old "Stand-by"; I can't imagine what I would do without her enthusiasm and whole-hearted support. And I may say right here, that she is not the only one whose thoughts strayed back over the years, on Club Day! How fervently I asked God to bless each and everyone of you, so that your lives may be clean, worthy and beautiful.

One day—just before our Club Feast—I had a wonderful surprise. Just imagine receiving fresh flowers. "Hey up here!" I could hardly believe it, but yes, there they were: twelve beautiful carnations, from our Old Timer, Mrs. McLaughlin, of Vancouver, B.C. How dear it was of you to remember, Ethel!

And just as agreeable "Says it With Flowers", our dear Ruth Morden says it with SWEETS....When pupils are so thoughtful, how can one help loving them, and hoping that the best in life will come to them? Be assured of my deep appreciation for what you all try in so many ways to make me feel: your gratitude towards a teacher who, like so many others, only did her duty. But when one loves one's duty, ah! what happiness! It has always been my good fortune to have such dear, good boys and girls to teach—you, even YOU, my OLD TIMERS....in spite of all your mischief!

A few days ago, I chatted with Mabel Gledu, now Mrs. Paul Noskeyi. If you know them both so well, I am sure you will rejoice to hear that Paul is still a wonderful hunter and trapper. Mabel said Paul had killed 63 rats in two weeks, and then she proudly added, "And I got 12 myself, so in all, we got 7500." Paul is out hunting again, but will be home on time for the wedding. Just guess which of our OLD TIMERS is getting married now? None other than our old "JIG-BOO MAN"....Jerome Cardinal! His coming marriage to Mabel Hemolin was announced in church this morning.

Speaking of the Noskeyi family: I have always forgotten to tell you of the tragedy that befell them last fall. Norman was drowned at Prairie Lakes, and a few weeks after, his little brother Maxwell broke through the ice, contracted a bad case of Pneumonia, and died a few days afterwards. God grant them eternal rest!

Alvin Selkirk's baby has her heart's desire: a son! Her two little daughters are quite thrilled over the advent of a baby brother. So, help me bid a warm welcome to this new Club Member with an OLD TIMERS name: ADMN !!!!!!

Two weeks ago, a very erect, nice-looking soldier boy paid me a visit: Leo Dufresne. He has joined the Royal 22nd Regiment, so expected to be transferred to the East very soon. He thinks Army life is quite all right, and left with the hope of meeting some of our dozen and a half Club Members who are in uniform in Canada and Overseas.

A letter from Louis Mathieu last week assures me that he took my remark re his "wicked-looking" little moustache all in good fun, and that some day, he may have enough courage to send me his photo for the "CHOES". Bravo, Louis!

What would we do without our Michael McDermott? He was right here with his good-looking little truck and his guitar to help out for our last Club reunion. If you like hearing about all your former pals, why don't you ALL write and share these pages? I'd like nothing better! In the meantime, GOD BLESS YOU my dears!

Your devoted OLD TEACHER,

Sister Jean Placideau
J.C.S.
Dear Teacher and Pupils;

Here I am back at work after a glorious seven days' leave with my little wifey. The wife and I managed to get leave the same time, so you can well guess we made the best of our short break.

Whilst we were on leave we received your Newsy Journal, which we both thoroughly enjoyed. We both find this New Journal has improved in many ways, but where we got a big surprise was when we saw our wedding photograph in the Journal. It tickled the wife when she found the curtains were the proper colour.

I was just thinking you must have quite a good collection of snaps around you of all the old timers and their children. It makes one think how the time passes by; Look at me now a happy married man and I must confess there's nothing like it for total happiness.

I visited several Churches including our Cathedral in Middlesbrough, so I had three wishes for visiting. Don't worry, I didn't forget you all in one of my wishes, so I hope they are fulfilled.

Well Sister I must close and write to George who as you know has been posted overseas. As yet no word from him, so I can't say much except his posting came as a shock to all of us.

We visited his little daughter, Pauline, and I am pleased that she and her mother are A.l.at Newcastle although you will realize how they miss your Old Timer, George.

So with love and regards from Joan and myself, Good Luck and Keep Smiling.

Your Old Timer, Don

Dear Donny-Boy;

It would have been a disappointment had not your genial letter arrived on time for this issue of "Echoes." Everything in your letter makes me glad: your happiness, your holiday, your appreciative remembrance. Tell Joan I'll be looking forward to receiving her promised letter.

We shall go out to fix your dear brother's and mother's graves in a few days. We are happy to perform this labor of love for you.

Remember me to George and Eileen when you write them. We keep you in our hearts and in our prayers.

S. J.P.

Sacred Heart Scholasticate,
Lebret, Sask.

Dear Sister Jean Placidus;

You have every reason to be well pleased with the 1941-42 School year and to feel it is a success as well as a pleasure. I only wish that your ultimate aim be realized and that the boys and girls live up to the ideals you have striven to give them and this particularly when they step forth to do battle face to face with life.—Father Forcade does seem to be a splendid educator.

And poor old George— it really is too bad he's transferred probably to a more active front—Libya or to the Far East. War
respects no one, no family. Our old world is packed full of that nauseating stuff that is unleashed even upon the best and noblest boys. May God bless and protect him and his little family and make them strong in their duty and in their sacrifice.

Trusting that you have more success and consolation during this last stretch of the school term. Good-day Sister; please have a wee remembrance in your prayers for,

Yours truly,

My dear Sister Jean;
Thanks a million Sister, for the "Grouard Echoes" which I surely enjoyed. I always like to read the "Old Pupils Corner." I admire the ones who have gone far ahead especially my old classmates.

I am feeling swell, but I'm to be transferred to the Calgary Sanatorium for a further treatment. I'm to under-go an operation up there. So Sister please tell your pupils to pray hard for me. The rocks are steep and rough but I'll climb up a winner if it be God's Holy Will. With God's choicest blessings on you, dear Teacher.

Dear Sister Jean and Pupils;
Hello, Sister Jean, just thought of putting "pupils" above, knowing you would read it to them.

There is really not much happening around here, but I may say a few things that will interest you. Charles Tomkins, Louis Auger, and Leonard Anderson are out here. I saw John Smith in London awhile back and last Sunday I saw Gerard Brulotte, an old school friend of mine in my young days. And another couple of friends of mine, Mike and Edward Belcourt. The ball-season is open-and aren't the boys wishing you were here again to play on their team? Hardly seems a year ago that you were doing your share of playing and teasing on our diamond. Reverend Father Desnoyers, who is the Assistant-General of the Oblate Fathers, arrived in Grouard for his official visit in this Vicariate. We have not yet seen him, as he only arrived a few hours ago, but from his remarks to our Bishop, we know that he highly approves of the C.Y.O. in Grouard. Father Desnoyers represents the Superior-General who is in Occupied France.

"No one is a prophet in his home town" is very often a true saying. It so often happens that we get more appreciation from those who are far away than from those with whom we rub elbows. But to prove that that is not always the case, we publish a letter received Saturday from our Postmistress:

Reverend Dear Sister Placidus:

Please accept the enclosed offering to add to your financial part. I am sure proud and anxious to read the GROUARD ECHOES. I think the boys and girls are wonderful. I, as an outsider, see a big change in the pupils; they carry themselves beautifully and are bright and happy. All credit is coming to their leaders, and in particular Rev. P. Forcade who has done wonderful work. I am also glad to note that some of the old pupils remember the kindness that was shown them at the school.

ECHOES, please accept my appreciation for your kindness in remembering me.

Mrs. V. MAURICE.

Since the construction of the new Bishop's Residence in McLennan has started, many of our Brothers are busy doing their bit. They are working under the direction of Bro. Desrochers, O.M.I., an architect who came from the East especially for this construction. We wish them good luck—but how we hate to see that house going up, as it means we shall eventually lose OUR Bishop.

Reverend Brother Fortier has returned to the East.

There seems to be a bit of competition between our two Superiors as to which one will work the hardest! Father Superior, although he is supposed to be convalescing, can be seen at any hour of the day in his garden or potato patch. And in between her washings, soap-making and sewing her Superior is putting in her big garden.

Sister Marcella has undertaker to beautify our cemetery. Any one who wishes a job may apply to her, and be sure of being accepted.

Sr. Louis Omer has a new hobby: going about looking for caterpillar eggs that infest our trees. When she has found a particularly lively crowd of baby caterpillars, she sends them to us with a magnifying glass. Ooooh! Do they squirm??

As we glance over the work done at the school this year, we cannot but notice this year's outstanding innovation, namely, the new manual training programme. It is most certainly a great help in the training of our boys as a practical preparation for their adult lives.

This year the boys have especially learned the fundamentals of hand woodwork. They have completed some wonderful projects including chairs, tables, stools and medicine chests. Three years in such a course will do much more than just prepare them for an ordinary life on the Reserves.

A systematic chart prepared by Mr. P. Boyko, farmer, has given the pupils the splendid chance of evolving through the different phases of farm training.

A regular physical training programme has helped to keep the boys fit and in good health. Winter has seen the boys achieve new laurels in the field of sports.

The girls too have been very busy. They have received important training in the different branches of home economics. Very recently they have taken part in a competition arranged by The Canadian Handicrafts Guild of Edmonton. Our girls emerged victorious with the first prize. Congratulations!

Blessing of New Church and Confirmation

Samson Reserve

May the 17th will long be remembered by the Indians of Hobema. This day marked the Blessing of a new church dedicated to Our Lady of Lourdes on the Samson Reserve, and the Confirmation of a large class of 107 by His Grace Most Reverend J.H. MacDonald, Archbishop of Edmonton.

It is estimated about 1000 were present for the occasion. The procession which accompanied the Archbishop to the church was led by two members of the R.C.M.F. of Edmonton. It also included boy scouts from the Indian School and a cavalcade of Indian horsemen some of whom were clad in native costumes.

As only a small portion of the crowd could find a place in the church, the ceremonies which started at 3:30 p.m. were broadcast to the hundreds gathered outside of the church.

Archbishop MacDonald was assisted by Rev. Father J. Holland of St. Joseph's Seminary, Rev. Father L. Couture of St. John's Juniorate and by Rev. Father F. Moulin, who has spent nearly forty years as a missionary on the Hobema Indian Reserves. It was indeed a great consolation for him to witness the Blessing of this new church on one of the Reserves as well as the Confirmation of so many of his spiritual children.

The choir of St. John's Juniorate under the direction of Rev. Father L. Pepin O.M. was in charge of the singing.

In his sermon, His Grace thanked all who had contributed in the work of building the new church, which upon completion would be the pride of the Indians of the Samson Reserve. Work For The Red Cross

We girls are trying to do our bit to help Canada at war. We are knitting socks, sweaters and scarves for the soldiers and we enjoy it very much. We are glad to do it for them who are fighting for us and for our country. We are not wasting anything in our sewing rooms. We save even the tiniest pieces of cloth and that is also to help win the war.

Madolene Buffalo.

A PICNIC

On Easter Monday, we went for a ride to the new church on the Sampson Reserve. There were three teams, two belonging to the school and one which Mr. Joe Minde had let us have. We were about 45 in all. Mrs. Minde came with us too. We started in the morning, had dinner in the basement of the church and came back about three o'clock in the afternoon. We enjoyed our ride very much and hope it won't be the last.

Isabelle Headman.

TALKIES

We have had talkies very often this year. We like them very much especially when they are about cowboys. One of the last ones we saw was about the war. It was entitled "Canada Carries On". We saw many things we had never seen before, cannons, machine guns, ships and bombers. We saw them all in action. We are going to see another show about the war on May 26th. C. Lightning.

TONSILECTOMY

Twenty three girls and twenty seven boys have had their tonsils taken out. It took two weeks. Every morning 5 or 6 would go to the hospital in Wetaskiwin and then the next morning another group would take their place. Many of the boys kept asking each other who was going to be next. They were afraid every time they saw Miss Conroy's car coming towards the school. I was kind of afraid too. I thought I was going too, but I didn't go.

Last Saturday morning three boys stayed in bed. After we finished our breakfast they got up, dressed up and away they went. They came back the next morning, Sunday morning, but they didn't want to stay in bed because there was a big celebration at the new church on the Sampson Reserve.

Ernest Baptiste.

WITH MUD IN HER EYE!!!

About 3 weeks ago I was on the swing and 3 other girls were playing near it. There was a big puddle of water underneath me and I was just wondering what would happen if I fell off the swing.

Then Sister rang the bell for us to go in and just as I was getting off, I don't know what happened, I fell right into the mudhole. I was afraid to tell Sister but I did and she sent me upstairs to change my clothes. I made marks all the way on the floor, because when I took off my rubber shoes one of them was full of mud. I washed my clothes and when all was finished I went to my classroom. I was all right.

Amalie Chibley.

NEW BABY CHICKS

On May 7th Father Rhéume went to the station and brought back a half dozen big boxes filled with small baby chicks. They are all Leghorns. There are about 250 of them. About 10% of them died. Sister Superior is taking good care of them in a brand new chicken coop that Brother Kael built this spring. We like to go and watch them when they are eating. THE PRINCIPAL'S FEAST

Yesterday May 21st, is our principal's feast day. Yesterday evening we had a little gathering to wish him a happy birthday. We sang a few songs. Then Father Therese Dion read the address and offered a spiritual bouquet to Father RM. In the name of the whole school after the children asked Father to grant us a holiday. He succeeded. Today we had a holiday. We want to thank our kind principal for all he has been doing for us.

HUNTING EGGS

This afternoon May 21st, as it was a holyday in honour of our principal, the girls went out on a picnic and the boys went out to the bush to look for eggs. Mr. Fortier promised a nickel to the one who would bring back the most eggs. The boys brought back 22 cents, 5 nickels, and 12 hawks. So in all there were 39 eggs. I got the nickel with 9 cents.

WOODWORK

We have learned a lot of things in woodwork. We have learned how to use carpenter's tools and how to make all kinds of joints such as the mortise and tenon, dado, tongue and groove, and so on. We have made projects to make. Most of us have made tables chairs and medicine chests. We have also learned how to use various tools, especially the chisel because it is a tool we worry often.

Victor Battlewake.

VI. GARDENS

Some time ago Mr. Protti read a letter to us which Father Rhéaume had received from the government at Ottawa. It said that to help wo Indians should plant gardens which will not only help us but help Canada as well because there is going to be a shortage of the things which are given in the rations to the Indians. By growing vegetable gardens we can get the food and the vegetables we need to be healthy. So let's get down to work on our gardens for victory. Let's get down to work on our gardens for victory. All the school boys are willing to have their own gardens at home.

We want to help not only our parents but also Canada in its battle for victory. So let's all do our part in winning the war by growing these victory gardens because nearly all the food that our old people get in their rations is going to be cut down for the fighting men. So let's store away some food for the winter. Norman Yellowbird.
SCRAP

We are doing our part to help Canada's war effort by collecting scrap. We are grateful to all the people of Hobbs who have helped us in our work. We want to thank Mr. Bilt who took over 5 tons of scrap in his truck from Hobbs to the Wetaskiwin Salvage Depot.

Joseph Shortneck.

WASTE METAL

The duty of my committee was to salvage bones. We picked the smallest and the biggest ones we could find. We have already picked up more than 1,200 lbs. - Emock Crane.

SCRAP METAL

Our committee collected metal of all kinds. Our loads were so heavy we had to take the horses to haul them. After we had all our scrap ready Mr. Bilt came with his truck and brought it all to the Salvage Bin in Wetaskiwin. I. Johnson.

RUBBER

Help Canada by saving scrap rubber. That's what our committee did. We collected old boots, tires, tubes and everything we could get that was made of rubber. We got quite a lot of it and had lots of fun going out around Hobbs looking for it. Percy White.

PAPER, GLASS & RAGS

F.R. Child's group had to pick up paper. They got piles and piles of magazines and journals. I was in J. Bull's committee. We had to collect bottles and rags. We got plenty of rags from the girls sewing rooms and we got more than 20 dozen beer bottles. Alexia Tins.

BE PREPARED

On Sunday afternoon, April 19th, the Boy Scouts were blessed by Reverend Father Rhéaume, our principal. After that we made our three promises. The first to obey all scout laws, the second to obey God's laws, and the third to do good to others at all times.

M.D. Buffalo.

CELEBRATION

We celebrated that same day. After supper the 32 boy scouts went to the bush. There we had a real good time. We put up the flags and built a big fire. After that we played some games and then we had our sing-song. Then we showed Mr. Fortier an Indian dance and then all danced around the fire. We stayed there until 10 o'clock and then came back. We went to bed feeling very tired. The next morning I was so sleepy I could hardly open my eyes. Gabriel Johnson.

KNOTS

Most of us are still in the tenderfoot class. Mr. Fortier, our scoutmaster is showing us how to make all kinds of knots. We are learning how to tie such knots as the weaver, the sailor, the Boland, the cloven hitch and the granite knot.

The Sisters and the girls made our neckerchiefs, pants, socks and kit bags. We want to thank them for all they have done for us.

The boy scouts took part in the celebration last Sunday. Some served in church, some were in the parade and the others helped in the booths and on the grounds. We also helped the members of the band to Club to prepare everything for the celebration on the Samson Reserve. Ernest Baptiste.

F.R. Littlechild and J.Ball.

The Colonels surely felt sorry that they could not play their work-outs at night or on our new rink. The rink has 20 100-watt lights, each player had to pay two cents for every game they played at night. Everybody was glad to pay for all the fun they had.
