OUR INTERMEDIATE HOCKEY LEAGUE

We haven't played many outside games but we surely enjoyed them among ourselves right here at school. We played three teams of our own, and our final game was played against the Colonels. It was a close game, but the Colonels won the single game that was played.

By F.R. Child and J.Ball.
1. The mother cat had 3 kittens in 1937; the cat and her 3 kittens had 3 kittens in 1938. If, in 1939 the cat and her 3 kittens and each of their 3 kittens should each have 3 kittens, how many cats and kittens would there then be altogether?

2. Ned bought 3 marbles from Ted and sold 3 each to Jed and Fred. Ted bought 6 from Fred and 9 from Jed and sold 6 to Ned. Fred sold 3 to Ned. How many marbles then had each boy, if all started with six apiece?

3. Joe phone Jane to meet him at the "Lower Deck" for lunch at 12:30. Jane thinks he said 12:00. Joe's watch is eight minutes fast though he thinks it is seven minutes slow. Jane's watch is ten minutes slow though she thinks it is five minutes fast. At what time will each arrive at the "Lower Deck"?

4. Each time the pump handle is pushed down a quart and a pint of water flows from the spout. How many strokes will be necessary to fill a 4 and 1/2 gallon tub, if every fifth stroke fails to produce any water?

ANSWERS: No fun unless you do the figuring.

1- 64. 2- Ned & Ted each had 12, the others none

3- At the same time: 12:15. 4- 14 strokes.
GROUARD ECHOES

"CLIMB, THOUGH THE ROCKS BE RUGGED"
Our first number of the Grouard Echoes for the New Year 1944, carries with it sincere and loving wishes for the health, happiness and success of all our readers, in their various fields of labor.

The Old Pupils were especially in mind on Dec. 27th when Holy Mass was offered for their welfare at Sister Superior's request.

Once again our worthy and venerated Bishop, Mgr. Landis, has been forced to leave the Vicariate owing to the precarious condition of his health. We trust that it may not be too long before he returns to us again with renewed strength and vigor to resume the work so dear to his heart.

To St. Joseph, our certain hope below, Glory of earth and heaven, Thou pillar of the world, to thee, Be praise immortal given.

To him, we attribute the generous donations received from:
- Vancouver B.C.
- New Westminster, B.C.
- Fort St. John, B.C.
- Iona, California
- Spokane, Alta.
- Vancouver, Wash.
- Baldwinville, N.Y.

Rest assured dear friends your kindness is not forgotten. Every Wednesday, "To Joseph" is sung at Benediction for all the benefactors of the Mission, past and present.

"It is at Joseph"

He never fails those who trust in him.

On Jan 21st, we had the happy privilege of welcoming our beloved and esteemed Directress of Studies, Sister Ebert. She visited the classes on the 24th and 25th.

The pleasure was mutual when she greeted a large number of her former pupils who had come to the Co-Operative Bingo party on Jan. 23rd. No one who has ever met Sr. Ebert has ever forgotten her; it seems that way.

All too soon we had to say good-bye to her and wish her "Bon Voyage" on her way to Joassart.

Another "Old Timer" who visited here in December was Rev. Fr. Floch who is always interested in Grouard.

Sister Joseph O'Gorman, from Lacombe Home visited here in December also.

The remainder of the School Year will be devoted to the development of an enterprise entitled:
"Pioneers of Grouard during the past Fifty Years".
The culmination will be a booklet made up of the pupils' compositions on the subject.

May your Lenten Season be holy and fruitful in prayer, penance and good works, that your Easter may be happy and joyous.
School Activities

OUR RETREAT
Our news items were already given in, so we couldn't mention this important news in our last Echoes. Like the Fathers and Sisters, we too make a retreat every year. Who was our preacher? No other but Rev. Fr. Joseph McGregor, the parish priest of Edmonton (a name we often hear, since our new teacher thinks there is no place like that one). Father gave us three sermons a day and knew how to hold our attention and interest by making his preaching story-like, always bringing home some beautiful lessons. We thank you, dear Father for your kindness and interest. Your words have helped us a great deal and will remain with us a long time.

Mandy Willcox - Gr. V., Albert Ward - VI.

Mr. H. Laird's Death
Mr. H. Laird died Dec. 3rd at High Prairie Hospital. The Indians of Northern Alberta have lost in him a devoted friend for he had been Indian Agent for over twenty years. His time was spent in advising and helping our parents in their difficulties. He was also a devoted friend to our dear Missionaries in their hard work. He was laid to rest in High Prairie cemetery.

We extend our deep sympathy to his daughter, Louise, an OLD TIMER here in Grouard and to his son Gordon, a member of our Canadian Army.

Lucy Smith - Gr. VI.

OUR CHRISTMAS TREE IN THE CLASSROOM
The week before Christmas all the class rooms were decorated and cribs and Xmas trees put up. To us was given the joy of running to the bush for a Christmas tree. It was a nice one too. In its time I had it ready, standing in the corner of our class room. I wanted the honor of decorating it - but the girls said - boys were not good for that dainty work - so they took it in hand and quickly did "fairy work" with it.

Joseph Ward - Gr. V.

Gift Exchange
On Dec. 22nd, the members of the Good Counsel Club had their gift exchange like in the years gone by. What fun! What surprise! But also - what anxiety for fear someone would play a dreadful trick "all wrapped up in tissue paper and tied up with ribbon". Our class president, Tommy Pon, dressed as Santa and gave out the presents, which we had to open before the class. We were all pleased over our gifts.

Frances Willcox - Gr. VI.

MINI-MISS
After attending Midnight Mass in Edmonton several times, it makes a great difference to be in Grouard for that beautiful forest. Dec. 24th at 11:15 P.M. we were welcomed by singing and music. I was told that the Sisters of the Mission were playing "angels" that night and singing "Glory to God".

Like the shepherds of old, we went out in the darkness and cold to go to church, but there it was bright and warm and crowded. People, mostly Indians for and near, came to enjoy the beautiful ceremonies. We had solemn High Mass by three priests. After a light lunch we went back to bed until late in the morning.

Helen Berard - Gr. V.

THE CONCERT
We had our Christmas concert Dec. 28th. It was a very nice one too. We had one song play "Christ Cradle", where a poor little boy was seeking for a home. He found one with a poor but charitable family. All enjoyed the pantomime of "Sleep, Holy Babe", in which the Blessed Mother rocked the baby Jesus to sleep.

Jenny Legrand - Gr. VI.

A WONDERFUL TREE
A Christmas tree loaded with gifts during these hard times? Who gave the one hundred twenty parcels? It was the kind girls of Yakima who have been sending boxes every year to Sister Jean Placidus. This year, Sister was so kind to let us have them as usual though she has another "flock" to look after now. Thank you, dear Sister Jane, for your special thanks to the girls for your generosity.

A special word of thanks to Mr. Hill from his proteges, for he too helped to lend the Christmas Tree, and spread happiness around.

Doris Chalifoux - Gr. VI.
In a letter from Sr. Philothoe, Principal of St. Joseph's, Yakima, Wash., the message following, speaks volumes,

"You are most welcome for all. It has been a labor of real love for the girls and the Sisters, and we are only too happy to be able to do some little tangible act for our beloved Missionary Sisters of the North. The children really love to do it and they believe would be very much upset if they were not allowed this privilege."

Could the dear Sisters and pupils of St. Joseph's see the happy faces of their little Northers when they receive their gifts, they would surely feel a thrill of great joy, for these poor children certainly appreciate the favor of being "Yakima Specials."

CHRISTMAS HOLIDAYS

We had them from Dec. 23rd till Jan. 3rd, and quite a number of us spent this jolly time in bed with the "flu." So, no general outing like usual, no sleigh ride, no "old pupils' reunion," but you were not forgotten! "Old Times" for a Mass was said for your intentions, asking God to bless every day of 1944 for you all.

Merry Christmas - Gr. V.

A WELCOME VISITOR

Mr. Demers, has replaced Mr. L'Houmoir, as Indian Agent for the Northers part of Alberta. He took up his new duties in October 1943. Mr. Demers must have been very busy with his new work, for his first visit to our Mission was only on Jan. 12th. We were glad to make his acquaintance. He visited every department of the school but stayed a little longer in the class rooms. Our agent was interested in our "bonding work," which was going on that afternoon and we were proud to show him our bright colored work.

His first gift to us was a holiday for the sorrow. To our thanks, we added three cheers. We'll be looking forward to your next visit, Mr. Demers.

Rosie Shott - Gr. VI.

COMING AND GOING

Some new pupils came to Ground, Helen Borden from Edmonton, who brought her little sister Gertrude and her baby brother Tommy with her. Billy and Michael Hyres came from Eureka River, and two little people came back who were here last year: Kind and Elmer S. man. Of course, Joe was very glad when he saw them again. Agnes and Eliza Crofton came from afar to join our ranks. To all those who wish us well and are glad to have them with us, but we were sorry to lose the Cunningham girls who went back to Rust after the holidays. We would be glad to have you back again.

Louise Fraser - Gr. V.

WE PLAY BINGO

The pupils of Class III gave a Bingo Party to raise money for their Holy Childhood Fees. Thanks to the generous cooperation of all, they made enough to pay their fees and those of Class IV, and of all the baby boys and girls who do not attend school. Classes I and II paid their own fees and we have a membership of 130. Thirty-eight pagan babies have been ransomed since the association was begun in 1941.

DOWN OUR NAY

Scid the music to the rock,
"Aren't they ever coming back?"
Said the ceiling to the floor,
"Guess we'll have to wait some more",
Said the blotter to the ink,
"Toll me now, what do you think?"
Said the ink unto the blotter,
"Each day grows a little hotter,"
Said the window to the bill,
"Well, I think I've heard my fill!"
Said the dollar to the bill,
"What a long and rugged hill!"
Said the mountain to the ridge,
"Funny how another bridge."
From its height you cast a glance,
At the stream called "Circumstance".
"Obstacle Bridge" 'tis called you know -
"We build and cross as ON WE GO."
**THE BOYS' HALL**

Fifty-five big and small boys give the salute as they come before you. We are all happy and healthy except our dear Jimmy Collins who has been at the High Prairie Hospital since October. Michael Willier, from Briftpile, is a deaf and dumb boy but, you can't get anything on him, for he seems to get everything. Six little boys are too young to go to school so they "split" the day between eating, sleeping, and playing.

Tommy Pon Ying - Gr. VII

Talk about Winter fun!

Skating on our nice rink every chance we get is fun! We had a grand hockey game last Sunday. Coasting down the hill is great too. Some of the Brothers have enjoyed this sport with us more than once.

We had one real good sleigh ride this winter. You should have seen two bob-sleighs full of happy boys supervised by our hall keeper; Sister Denise Lucille.

Joe Sawan - Gr. VI.

**TURKEY DINNERS**

Yes, two real big turkeys came from Edmonton to Tommy Pon from his grandfather. He was so glad to invite some Fathers, Brothers, and big boys for two big dinners in the boys' hall. Thank you Tommy, it was very kind of you, also of your grandfather to send you such a nice Christmas gift.

Tommy Laboucane - Gr. VI.

The latest news about Jimmy Collins is that, slowly and peacefully this brave lad is nearing the top of the hill - where he will meet His Lord Face to Face.

Manly, gentle and quiet, best describes Jimmy - he has always been most grateful for the care bestowed on him, and the letters and visits he received were greatly appreciated.

**THE GIRLS' HALL**

This year we have sixty-five girls in our hall. Five little ones do not go to school. Elsie Andrews is 15 years old but found class work too difficult so she helps in the hall with the sewing machine work. Emma Miller is our deaf and dumb girl who also helps us let around the house. She is able to do nearly everything we do except school work. Less fortunate is Sere Desjardins for she is blind, though not deaf or dumb. Sister duguy, a foundress of this school and who came fifty years ago is trying to teach Sere how to knit stockings and braid carpets. Our youngest little girl, not yet three years old, came from Ft. Nelson with her two sisters after Christmas.

**WHAT A SLEIGH RIDE!**

On Jan.13, making good use of our Indian Agent's, Mr. Demers, Holiday, we had a wonderful sleigh ride. The boys used the teams first and then it was our turn. Sr. Clare Eve went with some while Sr. Jean Leon had most of the little ones with her. It was a good thing, for the sleigh wouldn't stand a heavy load for after a quarter mile the wheels came apart leaving us all out on the snow. No one was hurt. Our teammates went home for another sleigh but our ride ended in a hay field, with lots of fun, a little cold, and no harm to anyone.

**BINGO! BINGO!**

During the holidays we had two bingo parties, one boys and girls together, the other boys alone. The Fathers and Sisters came to see us play and some even joined the game. This fun had been organized by Rev. Frs. Lachance and Potvin and Brothers Paquet and Tremblay.

Nice prizes were given and plenty of pleasure and fun besides.

Nellie LePretre - Gr.VII.
O, Grouard was built for glory,
Grouard was built for fame,
And the master hand that built it,
Shall himself its worth proclaim.

Long he toiled here before us,
Born with patience, trial and pain.
In labor, prayer and exhortation,
Spent himself for others' gain.

As the future rose before him,
He beheld with vision bright,
Greater days and greater conflicts,
Filled with shadow, woe, and fright—

Did his brave heart quail before it,
Did his spirit sink and die,
Did he say—"I cannot do it;
Of what use is it to try?"

His was courage of the valiant,
His a spirit of heavenly fire—
And he bravely struggled onward
To the heights of his desire.

His great soul passed on to glory,
But his spirit grand and true,
Remains to cheer and guide us,
'Tis his work we have to do.

Years have come and gone since Grouard
First was built upon a hill,
But the man of mighty purpose
Leads us on and always will.

Many noble souls have answered
To his call and spent their best,
In labor, prayer and suffering
Knowing God will do the rest.

As the legion grows in number
And other tasks appear,
Valiant hearts take up the challenge
Carry on through doubt and fear.

Though the task at times seems hopeless,
And dark shadows veil the sun,
'Tis God's work lies here before us,
SHALL WE PALTER 'ERE IT'S DONE?

Onward, upward! On to glory,
To eternal heights we climb,
God, Himself, will crown our efforts,
For the glory of His Name!
TRAINING SCHOOL

WEAVING

Our weaving studio is becoming quite an attraction. When the Reverend Fathers of the surrounding missions and other visitors come to Grouard, they are interested to see our large loom in operation. When Rev. Fr. Hugonnet came, he could not resist the temptation of trying a few throws of the shuttle and was so surprised to see two noodles instead of one go down together under the width of his shoes! No wonder why Almo Maskinok and Amio Collin have not had their pictures taken yet, with the patterns they have for themselves.

#########

The Hospital at High Prairie must be very attractive. Thoreso MacDonald and Paulino Tain went there before Christmas. Thoreso had to return again in January. Our dear Sr. Bustacho of Rome spent several weeks there in January. She is at home now convalescing. We surely met her cheerful smile at the Home Centre.

OUR CHRISTMAS

Molbo Cordinal who had been working for Mr. and Mrs. Stoholin since last June, helped to make our festivities very joyful by coming to spend the holidays with us. It must have been sad to part with them as she says they treated her as one of the family.

Mid-Night Mass.

While some were attending the old, yet always new ceremony of Midnight Mass at Grouard, Almo Maskinok, Thoreso Nolan, Rose Ann Klymowosow and Thoreso Jacob accompanied by our teacher, Sister Margaret Mary went to sing at the three Masses said in the church at Enilda. We considered it a great privilege to have been chosen as little Apostles to celebrate the Birthday of the Christ-Child. Rev. Fr. Potvin who officiated there, had a delicious hot lunch served to us at the Hotel after the three Masses. We arrived home at 4:30 A.M. and we did not have to be lulled to sleep after the long ride in the open air. Believe me! we did not get up at 6 o'clock either!

GIFT EXCHANGE

Did you hear our shouts of joy when we walked into our parlor and discovered the beautifully decorated tree loaded with useful gifts? There were even surprises for Molbo Cordinal, Janet Clarko, Annie Thomas, Flore Andrew and Mary Edith Gladus. Molbo and Molbo always want to sleep in now because they got nice milk nightshirts. Margaret Cordinal keeps our clocks regulated since she has a wrist watch, and does she like it? We're watching a nice day to take Pauline's picture with her lovely work basket, but we must not touch it. Yvonne is always wanting to go skating to show us her red ski socks.

And

Then

Dinner!

It was a great honor for us on New Year's day to have kind Fr. Superior Molbo, Annie Thomas and Janet take dinner with us in our home centre. We were anxiously looking forward to hearing our dear Bishop come also, but his ill health deprived us of that happiness. We hope it will not be too long before it will be given us the pleasure of serving him his favorite dish of pancakes. Sister Superior spent the rest of the evening with us while we played games and music and had a very pleasant time.

My dear Old Pupils:

I had been waiting anxiously for this opportunity of greeting you all—and now that I've been reminded that it is time—I have a sort of helpless feeling which comes from wanting to say so much, and being able to express so little of the sentiments that well up in my heart as I think of you. Could I only make you feel a small part of the joy your many letters, gifts and other remembrances have given me! THANK YOU seems such a weak commonplace word to say for all your loving thoughts of me.

First in my "Litany" of thanks was that wonderful week-end visit, shortly before Christmas, of my two OLD FAITHFULS, Annie Thomas and Janet Clarke. I love you to imagine how dear to my heart such a visit was... That they should off Ground to good advantage will please, but not surprise you! Then came Christmas, bringing a real overflow of the most beautiful proofs of your affection and appreciation from far and near; from England, Italy, Sicily, India, and from every part of Canada. Remember Pollyanna and her "Glad Guru"? I feel as she did, when she was ill, and from every one she had ever known, it seemed, came letters to help her play her own "Glad Game". Old friends from whom I hadn't heard for "many moons" suddenly came to life on hearing of my transfer, and keep telling me things that go straight to the heart. And so I thank you, each and every one, and ask God to bless you for it all.

I trust you will not be too disappointed over finding no letters from the Old Pupils, following this page, as in the past. Will you understand, if I say that there are some things that are too precious to be shared with the public? Maybe I am happy to read because I know the loyalty with which they are written, might not be so well understood were I to allow them to be printed. So? Do not grieve, however, OUR TEACHER will surely find some way of sharing with you the news who receives from your old school pals.

Splendid long letters from our boys Overseas assure me that all is still well with them, and that they are hopeful that Peace will soon descend upon our war-torn world, permitting them to return to their dear ones. Each one assures me that it's not a mere 150 miles that will prevent them from coming to Fairview... and each one asks to be remembered to the OLD TIMERS!

Jimmy Thomas, still flat on his back in the Shuswapsoy Military Hospital in Vancouver B.C., would appreciate hearing from old pals, I think. He is better, but it may be a long time before he is able to walk again. Another who would be cheered by a letter from old school friends, is Mary Jane Smithson, now Mrs. John Boring, at St. Joseph's Hospital, Dawson Creek, B.C., where she has been, unable to talk, for 4 months... I hope to tell you more about your other old friends soon. Until then, keep on climbing, though the rocks be rugged, and when you turn, be sure you always turn to the RIGHT! Then, my dears, you'll be sure to find you way HOME where I hope one day to call the Roll and to find that all have been faithful, and so may enjoy that eternal "Old Pupils' Reunion". Keep your eyes on that goal—and the climb will seem less hard!

May God bless this New Year and grant it may bring us all closer to Him—and to one another! And now I say..... Farewell!

Ever faithfully and affectionately yours,

[Signature]

Grouard Alta.,
February 15, 1944.

Dear Sister Joan,

Perhaps you'd like to hear new of all the old timers? I'm lucky to have such a chance to have a chat with you; even if it is on paper.

Among them all, we're sadly missing out boys in khaki who are now mostly all overseas, and even some in actual combat. For these brave lads, and all old-timers I'm sure God receives your fervent and motherly prayers. So we all know we are never forgotten by you and, neither you, by us all. Jim Andrew is another who has received his call to the army and will, no doubt, be donning a uniform.

Some who aren't so remote were here during the holiday season. Delphine Chalifoux and Louise St. Arnaud returned to Edmonton to their jobs; Nellie Cardinal (Ghostkeeper) and Louis Cardinal, her husband with their two little boys were also visitors. Mary Cardinal returned with them to work in a cafe in Ft. St. John. Alvina stopped in for a short chat and gave me the news that John Califer is a proud daddy of a baby girl. We are sorry to their news Florence MacKay is seriously ill in Ft. St. John Hospital where she had been working for quite a while. Claire Gladu (Louboucan) is now Mrs. Narcisse Legrand and still lives in the old place. Yvonne Cardinal had been very ill but is now well and enjoying health once again. Despite her illness, she hasn't lost her shy smile ?? Our dear, old Louise Laird (Calison) is bravely carrying on like a good soldier after the death of her dad. Johnny Norris is home once again, and Ironto still facing life, laughing. You should see young baby Bolanger, she's really cute, and Anne and Simone have reason to be proud of their baby daughter. Sure resembles her Uncle Leo and no foolin' — Wonder of the cuteness is for that reason??!!

The boys I saw were Michael McDonnell, Charles McLeod, William Brunello, Alexie and Jennie Cardinal; the latter returned to Ft. St. John.

I've recently heard from big brother Harry who is well and studying quite hard. Nancy still likes her training very much and sounds real professional. I'm glad to let you in on the glad news that Jim is now doing nicely and expects to be back on his feet before long. Oh! I mustn't forget to tell you - sister and discarded her brides for a new hair doll ?? She really looks grown up now; wait till you see for yourself. Janet, Viole, and Melba are now her companions as they too work for Fr. Forendo.

Now at the closing, I wish to say that from them all, I heard the most familiar and sad words, "Wish Sister Joan were here." So in their names, and all other old-timers far and wide, we lovingly say au revoir and God bless you.

Sincerely,
Marguerite.

Thank you, Marguerite for your kind response to my appeal for an "Old Timer's New Page". I am certain it will be of interest to Sr. Joan and the absent Club Members now so widely scattered through the world.

The "Grouard Echoes" has ever been the trusty messenger between the Good Counsel Club Members of the Present and those of the Past thru the medium of "Our Teacher" - as another "Co-operative venture" we have carried the work through this year.

"So where e'er you may be, at Home or at Sea,
Down on the earth or up in the air,
Good Counsel Club Members every where,
Keep Onward and Upward, 'till we all meet Up There."

Sure resembles her Uncle Leo and no foolin' — Wonder of the cuteness is for that reason??!!

The boys I saw were Michael Macdonald, Charles MacLeod, William Brunello, Alexis and Jerome Cardinal; the latter returned to Ft. St. John.

He was recently heard from big brother Harry who is well and studying quite hard. Nancy still likes her training very much and sounds real professional. I'm glad to let you in on the glad news that Jim is now doing nicely and expects to be back on his feet before long. OH! I mustn't forget to tell you — sister Annie discarded her brides for a new hair do!! ??. She really looks grown up now; wait till you see for yourself. Jocel, Viola, and Melba are now her companions as they too work for Fr. Forede.

Now at the closing, I wish to say that from them all, I heard the most familiar and sad words, "Wish Sister Joan were here." So in their names, and all other old-timers far and wide, we lovingly say au revoir and God bless you.

Sincerely, Marguerite.

Thank you, Marguerite, for your kind response to my appeal for an "Old Timer's New Page". I am certain it will be of interest to Sr. Joan and the absent Club Members now so widely scattered through the world.

The "Ground Echoes" has ever been the trusty messenger between the Good Counsel Club Members of the Present and those of the Past thru the medium of "Our Teacher" — as another "Co-operative venture" we have carried the work through this year.

"So where ever you may be, at Home or at Sea,
Down on the earth or up in the air,
Good Counsel Club Members everywhere,
Keep Onward and Upward, 'til we all meet Up There."

The Editor
LIFE'S CANVAS

Sunshine and shadow and laughter and tears,
These are forever the points of the years,
Splashed on the canvas of life day by day.
So are the painters, the colors are they.
So are the painters, the pigments we use.
Now, we're wholly permitted to choose.
Grief with its gray tint and joy with its red,
Come from Life's tubes to be blended and spread.

Here at the easel, the brushes at hand,
Each for a time is permitted to stand,
White was the canvas when first we began,
Ready to picture the lifetime of man.
Now we are splashing the colors about,
Knowing the rods and the gold must give out.
Soon we must turn to the dull hues and gray
Painting the sorrows that darken the way.

Now with the sunshine, and now with the shade,
Slowly but surely the picture is made.
Even the gray tints with beauty may glow,
Reckoning the joys of the lost long ago!
Let me not doubt it with doubt and despair,
Doors that are heavy, unkind and unfair,
But when the last bit of pigment is dried,
Let me look back at my canvas with pride.

Let me, when trouble is mine to portray
Dip, with good courage, my brush in the gray,
After the tears and the grief let there be,
Something of beauty for others to see.
Lord, let no pain not in anger or hate,
Grant me the patience to work and to wait,
Make me an artist, though humble my style,
And let my Life's canvas show something worth while!

My Literature students will likely recognize this. Don't you think it would be well to study and meditate on it also? There is so much truth in it for all of us! Come, let us make our life's picture beautiful in the sight of God and men!

Sister John Placidus.
GROUARD ECHOES

"Climb, though the rocks be rugged"
As we come to the end of another year of vigorous endeavour, our hearts are filled with happy gratitude as we read over the list of names which we have on our pages of benefactors. To all those who have helped in any way to make the GROUARD ECHOES what it now is, we wish to say a very heartfelt and sincere THANK YOU. Without your words of encouragement, and without your financial assistance, we could not have carried on as we have done. It has been a joy to know that our pages were eagerly awaited and read by so many... and we hope to start off from where we left off, next September.

A very special word of gratitude is due to the following friends for some substantial donations since the last issue:

Doctor and Mrs. T. Wood .. High Prairie.
Mrs. Harry Tremblay .. Edmonton, Alta.
Mr. and Mrs. J. English .. Faust, Alberta.
Rev. Father Boucage .. McLennan, Alta.
Mr. Paul Fovargue .. Culp, Alberta.
Mr. Fred Doll .. Froideventch."

Last June, we were bidding farewell to our much-loved Superior, Sister Michael Archangel, and bidding welcome to Sister Gonzales who was to replace her. The same emotions must be gone through again this June, as our dear Sister Gonzales has given her resignation owing to her continued ill-health.

Though we are very sad at the thought of losing her after such a short while with us, we are happy that her state of health is improving, though it does not permit her to be an active duty for at least another year. We wish to assure our former Superior, Sister Gonzales, that though we had the privilege of being under her wise guidance only a few months, that we shall not soon forget her. Her memory will long be cherished by all who had the privilege of being her "children".... big and small.

"THE KING IS DEAD ... LONG LIVE THE KING!" This is what we are reminded of, because, on the heels of the news that our Superior had resigned her office, came the news that we have a new Superior in the person of SISTER MARY LAURE!

It is not hard to find words of sincere welcome for Sister Mary Laure, as she spent many years here as Mistress of the Girls' Hall. All her old girls will be happy indeed to know that they are to greet their old friend again, as the Superior.

So, to our new Superior: Welcome to Grouard, and best wishes for your happiness in your new work.

At any hour, at any moment now, we are awaiting the sound of the church bells, pealing out the glad tidings of the arrival of our beloved Bishop, Monseigneur LANGELOIS, who has returned to the North. We are so happy to know our Bishop is really cured, and that after a rest period, he will again resume full charge of his affairs.

For this great happiness, we exclaim over and over, "Praise the Lord! Thanks be to Thee, dear GOD!"
Here's Fr. Beaucage!

One evening, as we were coming from Dramatics, we looked out, and then do you think we saw? Well, it was our old friend and teacher, Father Beaucage. My, it was nice to see him, even if we didn't get to talk to him then. The next morning, he visited the classroom, and as our store is in the school basement, he couldn't leave without at least paying us a little visit. He looked at the moosehide work, and he even tried on a beaded coat which seemed to have been made especially for him.

My Companion

As Fr. Forand was printing the Groo Hymn Book, he needed someone to help him at that job. So Nora Cardinal was the one chosen for the task. She is a very good helper, and does she ever keep me company? Now, I'm happy because I've got someone to "chow the rag" with!

Hi Virginia!

Another "old timer" suddenly showed up one morning. She came all the way from Ft. St. John, with Sr. Marguerite of Charity and Mrs. McFarlane. This is our old friend, Virginia Calliou. Virginia is almost completely deaf now, but she reads lips so well, that we can make her understand everything we say. She was so very glad to see all her old friends again. She was glad to bring back Florence Noskowi to work at the hospital with her.

An Angelic Member!

I had a big thrill the other day when I held a tiny new Club Member while the waters of Baptism were poured on his head. This was the wee little son of Mary Louise and Myles McDermott. My god-child's name is Myles Arthur Raymond. I'm sure he'll be a WONDER CHILD!!

Bright Lights

When Father Forand went to the city to get the little truck he had bought, he decided to bring me along. Oh, oh! Was I ever excited? Luckily generous Father Beauchamp was around and he accepted to replace me as clerk in the store.

Mrs. Tremblay was returning to Edmonton after her visit in Grouard, so we made the trip together. And I stayed with her and Madam Morrier in their apartments. They treated me like a queen. I surely appreciated all the kindness received.

My, I felt lost when we arrived in town! (This was my first visit to a big city.) If it hadn't been for Father and Mrs. Tremblay, I don't know what I'd have done! Did I ever open my eyes wide...and they stayed open all the time I was there, for at every place we went, there was something new to look at.

I did a great deal of buying for the Co-operative. That was a good experience for me. I met many wonderful people, saw Jeannette McDonald and Nelson Eddy in two pictures....and had so many thrills.

But when the car was ready, and we started for home, how happy I was! The city is grand....but I don't like its noise and rush. Grouard is the place for me, for as everyone says, "Home sweet Home is BEST!"

Old-Timer ANNIE THOMAS.
Victory Garden

We have some flower beds near the school where we usually grow only flowers. But this year, we are doing our bit for our country, so we have put in a VICTORY GARDEN. It isn't very big, but it will have radishes, onions and tomatoes. There will also be a border of Sweet-Peas and Astors near the well. I seeded the Astors so I am anxious to see them come up. Sr. Denise Lucille put in the sweet-peas for us while Sr. Jenn was sick at the hospital. We hope to get a bite of the vegetables before we go home for holidays.

Joo Sawn...Gr. V.

Oh, Honey!

BUZZ! BUZZ! Hear the bees? They got here last Monday. They looked like hunks of raisins stuck together. There are eight hives of them: 2 for Fr. Superior, 1 for Mr. Lafrenze, 3 for the Co-Operative, and two for us which Fr. Forcade bought, so we could study them and sell our own. They are in the Fathers' garden as there are lots of flowers there. We don't go too close for fear of getting stung on the nose—then we'd go cross-eyed looking at it! Hope the honey will make some of the girls sweet.... 'cause they're pretty sour.

Philip Fraser—Leonard Ward.

Scrub Day

One rainy day, we did our classroom Spring cleaning. First we scrubbed out our desks, washing away each little ink spot, and then came the GREAT job of washing our ceiling and walls. BOY! Did that change the room! It looks like a new ceiling and wall now. I wish my little face could be washed like that. Maybe it would take even the frockles off! I think we feel better now that the cleaning is off our minds.

There is only the floor that needs oiling now, then the room will be spic and span for the holidays.

Loo Hogue—Grade V.

School Activities

Meet Baby Fox!

While we were doing our cleaning, Sister Joan said that if we were real smart, she would take us to see the baby fox that Sr. Margaret has at the Homo Centre. Didn't we hurry?

Nellie and Alino brought the little fox outside so we could all pet him. Is he ever cute? He is about three months old, but is still quite small. His big bushy tail is about a foot long. He seemed afraid of us and would have run away if he could have. He is such a cute pet. Everyone will be sorry when he goes back to his real master.

Albert Ward—Gr. V.

Busy Days

Sister Edward taught Marjorie Tellmon how to make paper flowers; so now, while the other girls sew, Marjorie makes flowers. They go well with the baskets the boys are always making.

And in between all these interesting things we do, and the pleasant outings, there's plenty of hard studying to do, for don't forget... FINAL EXAMS come very soon. Brrrr! I go to sleep and dream I didn't pass.... I'm mighty glad when the morning bell rings and proves it was all—just a dream!

Lucy Amato—Grade V.
YOUTH TRAINING

A HAPPY "BAND"

One night, all the Band members were invited to a party in the Bingo Hall. And since it was a Band party, we brought our instruments along and played several selections. The famous piano accordion was there, of course, and Father Mahou very generously pumped away at it. We wanted to hear TEDDY BEARS PICNIC, but Father didn't know it, so he pumped the bollocks and Sr. Joan played the melody. It was the first Accordion "DUET" we had ever heard, and everyone had a good laugh over it.

Bingo!

We then had a very interesting BINGO game. Father Potvin had arranged many prizes, and when we'd win a game, we could have a choice of prizes. There were sacks of taffy that were most popular, so that each one could really be sweet. Lunch came along then, and before we were ready for such a grand meal, we were told it was time for all good children to be in bed. So we went, but not before thanking Fr. Mahou and Fr. Potvin for a very pleasant evening.

SCHOLA PARTY

Whenever there is some extra singing to do, it is always the SCHOLA who gets the job, so we were not a bit surprised when we were called one night to practice for the next morning. It was to be the anniversary of the Episcopal Consecration of His Excellency, Bishop Guy who was still here. So we practiced the hymns for the Mass we were to sing the next day.

Fun—

Then, we were given slips of paper to play games. It was funny to hear how things turned out. The best part was when we were all invited downstairs with our cups. Some made coffee, others toasted bread, and others buttered the toast. Finally, the whole HAPPY GANG sat down to a fine lunch.

A little bird told us the SCHOLA will soon have another treat...but it is to be a surprise, so we don't know what it will be. So...we're waiting! Lucy A.

Spring

Since June is here, we are not doing our regular work in Gymnastics any more, but we are preparing for a Festival. In between times, you are always sure to see somebody playing Baseball. Long walks and outings are in style too. Tom Pan

LAST OF THE MOHICANS

We have studied in detail of all that concerns Indian Life this year. To finish off our study, came the picture show, "LAST OF THE MOHICANS." This gave us a good idea of what Indian warfare was like in the early days. We are all glad we didn't live in those bloody days.

Jimmie C.

Our Queen

On the last Sunday in May, there was a very nice crowning of the true May Queen, our own dear Mother Mary! Those who had made their First Holy Communion at Easter had the privilege of crowning the Blessed Mother. Nellie Leproto read the Act of Consecration. Corporal Jennie Legrand.

Court of Honor Party

Each time the Officers spoke of the party to be held in honor of those who had been decorated at the last Court of Honor, everyone said, "Let's have a HARD TIME PARTY!" And so we did!

When the Fathers and Sisters came to see the Dress Parade, all the children followed Sister Denise and Sr. Mambrose so that the house was just full. How funny it was to see all the silly outfits! Tommy Pon Ying got first prize. He must have been tired when he got his things off. He and Janet had to do the French Minuet together after. They were a queer looking couple of Commanding Officers!

The funniest game played was "THE CHAIR OF HUMILITY." We laughed so much over this game and the forfeits that followed! Fr. Forcade gave the penalty.

Toot! Toot!

When Father Forcade brought the new C.Y.O. truck home, there was lots of excitement. It is made like an ambulance, is painted black, and on each side, it is printed in silver, "C.Y.O., Grouard, Alberta."

More power to you, little truck!

Party (cont.)

Doris had to go and beg five cents from Fr. Mahou. Was her face red!

Then, instead of a regular lunch, the HOBOS had to go and ask Sister Jean for a hand-out. We got some surprises too!

We decided we could stand a party like that about twice a week!

Jimmy Colin - Roland Gaboury.

Beans! Beans!

"PICNIC TIME FOR TEDDY-BEAR!"

Only the Teddy-Bears last week were the C.Y.O. Officers. It was a big surprise...the first thing we knew, instead of going to dinner with the others, there we were riding away in Fr. Forcade's new C.Y.O. car...

When we got to the nicest spot near the lake, we had the best Pork and Beans dinner you'd ever want to taste...thanks to Sister Proxode. Cake and oranges finished up the meal.

After a good walk around, Father gave us chocolate bars and gum.

To avoid making a second trip, the boys agreed to walk home. They wanted to race, so Sr. Jean said she'd give them some gum if they got home before we did. They took a short cut and when we drove up to the school, there were the boys, panting on the steps! Sister said they surely deserved their gum....

I think we enjoyed this OFFICERS' Dinner best of all. The Officers thank Fr. Forcade and Sister Jean for it.

Doris Chulifoux, Corporal.
HERE AND THERE

FOLLOW THE LEADER!

Follow the Leader, with perfect trust,
Follow the Leader, that we must,
If we would scale the mountain high,
We must follow the Leader, you and I.

OUR BISHOPS.
Our saintly Bishops number five,
Two of them are still alive—
To these men of high renown
We owe the fame of Ground town.
They blazed the trail with zealous hand,
And brought salvation to this land.
They urge us ONWARD in the right,
They urge us UPWARD to the light.
They bid us climb with courage till
We reach the summit of Life's hill.

OUR PRIESTS.
Before God's altar, every day,
For us they kneel, to bleed and pray,
That God may keep us in the right,
And make us victors in the fight.
That we may conquer vice and sin,
And every foe that lurks within.
They lead us ONWARD as they climb
And UPWARD to new heights sublime.

OUR BROTHERS.
In toil that praise will never pay,
They pass their lives from day to day,
Lending us a helping hand
While teaching us to understand
That every duty that's well done
Is just another victory won.
ONWARD, UPWARD, do they go,
Their lives a light, the way to show.

OUR SISTERS.
For us they labour in class and hall,
Without them we could not do at all.
They cook and they sew, they wash and they mend,
The Sisters' work seems never to end.
From early morn to set of the sun,
One task is finished, another begun.
Mother and sister and teacher in one,
Blessings will follow the work they have done.

So, follow the Leader, with perfect trust,
Follow the Leader, that we must!
For Christ is our Leader, Christ our King,
To Him our love and service we bring.

(Sister Mary Stella, F.C.S.P.)

Training School

Spr-r-r-r-ing!!

Spring is surely here, at the rate we're having visitors! It seems they know just when to pop in too. They surely take us by surprise sometimes...keeps us on our toes!

Meet our friend!

Guess who came from Edmonton with Fr. Forcado? Mrs. Trombley, the wife of our L.A. Representative! And isn't she the grand person! She made herself right at home with us, sleeping in our infirmary and making life quite gay for all. We will always keep a fond remembrance of her.

Before Mrs. Trombley left, she bought each of us a souvenir to remember her by. And that's not all. When she arrived in Edmonton she sent Sr. Margaret Mary a nice lace tablecloth for the parlor, and some doilies.

Honoring our Guest

One night while Mrs. Trombley was here, we spent a grand musical evening together. Some of the Fathers sang, and Fr. Mahou kept things lively with his accordion and his funny songs. Everyone enjoyed hearing his favorite, "Clementine." Mrs. Trombley surely laughed!

A Stitch in Time.....

Mr. Stohlin, our School Inspector, honored our HOME CENTRE with a short visit. On his way, he ripped his coat sleeve, and I was the one who had the privilege of sewing it for him. Besides the honor, I got a generous tip for my sewing!

McLennan Visitors

Reverend Fathers Boulet and Beausoleil from McLennan have also come to visit our famous new Home Centre. They seemed very well pleased with our work and encouraged us to keep on. Now, we are looking to the great day that will bring our dear Bishop Langlois here to see what has become of their former refectory, now all transformed into our new Home.

From the North...

Other visitors here were Sr. Margaret of Charity of Ft. St. John, and her sister, Mrs. Douglas McFarlane, R.M. of Beaver Lodge. They sprung a big surprise on their cousin, Sr. Margaret Mary. Both are splendid musicians, so that meant good music for us. They were both so nice to us, we all wanted to go back with them to Ft. St. John. The lucky one to go was Florence Muskeyi.

A "Jacket" Party

Sr. Denise Lucille's sister, Sr. Louis, who left Joussard for Peace River where she is now the Superior, came for a visit. She came to our house to see the 86 jackets we made for the Joussard boys.

Sr. Margaret gave a party of rejoicing the night those jackets were finished. There was joy......for more reasons than one!

A Fox in a Box!!

Who wants to see a real live baby fox? Everyone is welcome—or WAS, rather! We had all sorts of visitors in to see the cute fox we had here a few days. But we had something else up our sleeve too: Before the visitors would go, we'd make them give us a tip for our baby box! We're reasoning pagan babies, and our ransom elevator is right behind the door, so could catch many. Fr. Giroux gave us a dollar, but he shook his fist at us before he went out. We knew him, though, so we knew it was all in fun! He wouldn't box our ears!

NORA CARDINAL
NEWS BITS

You just ought to have seen our Father Superior and Father Potvin go after that refectory roof. First, they shingled it, then they painted it. It is a nice deep green now and looks quite fancy and fresh.

At last, the long-desired fence has come into being, and now Sister Denise Lucille will no longer have to worry about stray dogs, horses and cows who were always too interested in her flower bed. Special credit goes to Roland Goboury and Philip Fraser for making it.

Extending its policy of "A GOOD TURN" to the neighbor, the C.Y.O. has now a truck-car that serves as an ambulance.... a much needed improvement in this remote district.

Like the C.Y.O. itself, we believe that the car will bring happiness in the lives of many, for besides its services for the sick, the C.Y.O. car goes on many joyous errands too.

Have you ever wondered who those two Nuns are who work early and late, in the Sisters' Garden? It's Sister Mirocilla and Sister Duguy.... and from the looks of things, there will be wonderful things in that patch.

Recent visitors to Edmonton were SISTER LAURIAN and SISTER MARY ADELINE. They enjoyed city life for several days but they say, like good country mice, they were glad to get back here.

It's Examination Time! That's the season when teachers find out all sorts of surprising things.... such as:
- A blizzard is found inside a chicken!
- The vowels are something inside a man's stomach!
- A dimple is a bump inside out!
- Storm is water gone crazy with the heat....

A snooze is when a tickle explodes! And perhaps the most sincere definition of all is this one: ETC. That's a sign used to make the teacher believe you know more than you do !!!!!

Is Sister Jean going to Seattle? That is the question we have been asking for several weeks. If the Passport arrives today or tomorrow, Sister will go. Anyway, you will know by the writing on your Echoes address. If you do not recognize her writing, you may write to her at PROVIDENCE HOSPITAL, SEATTLE, WASHINGTON during the summer. She will attend Seattle College there.

One of the pleasures we are looking forward to is a visit from MOTHER PROVINCIAL and her Secretary. They are at Jeussard now, so we hope to see them very soon. We liked Mother and Sister Achille very much last year.

Sister EGEBERT, our Directoress of Studies, is to come here soon too to visit the class. We are anxious to see you, Sister Egbert; you are an old and dear friend of our parents who remember you as the best teacher they ever had.

Jimmy Thomas passed through on his way to Edmonton last night. We hope to see Jimmy here in Grouard soon.
Old Pupils' Corner

My dear OLD TIMERS;

'Tis the merry month of June, and hearts are all astir (that rhymes, doesn't it?) to the glad song of Vacation! Yes, in just a little while, all my Birdies will fly away to greener pastures. I suppose I should be very happy too—but somehow, there is always a sort of sadness connected with the end of the school year.... or at least, I have always felt that way. I should not mind so much were I only parting with my pupils for the two months of the holidays, but with my Senior pupils, there is always the pain of parting for good with some who do not return. And just as I loved you, my old pupils, and would fain have kept you under my wing for many years more, so I say Goodbye to those who are to return no more with a catch in my voice and an ache in my heart....... May Our Lady of Good Counsel watch over them all, and help them to live up to their ideals, being indeed their Counsellor, sincere and true.

And now for a few news flashes of our old pupils.

Nancy Thomas is doing wonderfully well in her Nurse's career, according to word received from Bishop Guy who saw Nancy on his recent stop in Cranbrook. He said those in charge consider her a born nurse, and say that she is very well liked by the staff and patients. Bravo, Nan! Your letters sound very professional, and we are glad you are making such a success of everything.

You should see Hazel and Doctor Wood's little son, Arthur! He has the most marvellous smile, and is so very friendly.... I enjoyed a very pleasant visit at their home a few weeks ago. Hazel told me Jennie is studying to be a Technician at the General Hospital in Edmonton, and Ruth, having finished her Business course is at home for a while. She will soon be working in the Office at High Prairie.....

Charlie White surprised me with a letter recently. He had just come home from "Up North." I quote his promise: "I may be leaving soon again, but I'll try and go 'DOWN YONDER' and see YOUSE."!!!!!

Agathe Cardinal McLoughlin writes that her little son Gilo, now almost nine months old, is wonderfully well and happy. She promises a photo of him soon.

The Grouard men are gradually coming home from the Yukon. Johnny Norris is determined to stay up there for some time yet, and get a good stake. So is Willie Hemlin. Thoro cheers, brave men! Others have gone to Fort St. John to earn big money working for the Yankees up there. John Giroux just returned from there a few days ago, as full of tricks as ever. You might be interested in knowing that John and Brother Cunningham are salesman for a special brand of ORANGES. You might be interested, for they even do SPECIAL DELIVERY on their wares! Ask them for details.....

And now, my dears, Au Revoir! I trust that after the holidays, we shall meet again through these pages, which will be better and better as time goes on. In the meantime, be good, be loyal, and don't forget to pray for us.

Your loving "old" Teacher,

Sister Jean Plaisance
Dear Sister Jean:

I was most pleased to receive your very interesting letter and the ECHOES. Believe me, Sister, I read each bit contentedly. In fact I read it backwards! Ah, that sounds exaggerated, does it not? I'll leave it up to you to guess why I start at the back.....

I'm in fine health now this find you and your pupils the same. Like it exceptionally well over here. In a few days time, I'll be spending my third leave. I have had the pleasure of seeing Scotland and Wales, so I suppose I must be prepared for a long speech when I go back to visit your classroom. But how my voice quivers when I face an audience!

It's nice to hear so many of the ex-pupils are writing to you faithfully. Once again, thanking you for the Echoes. May God bless you, dear Sister.

From your ex-pupil,
Edward McLeod.

My dear Edward;

Your Airgraph reassured me as to your well-being. When I haven't had news from my boys Overseas for some time, I begin wondering what has happened. So, thank you for writing.

Your dear old Grandmother comes here every week to do her shopping. When we meet, we smile our sweetest, and she laughs outright at my Groo! That's one of the things I'm going to enjoy in Heaven; when I can sit down and have a real talk with all these dear old ladies.

I love so much, but cannot talk with because of language handicap. Anyway, in the meantime, Granny and I both send you our love and wishes.

S.J.P.

Dear Sister Jean and pupils;

I have just received your son mail dated 27-12-43. Thanks ever so much, also for the beautiful picture; I think it is lovely. I trust you have received my Xmas card by this time.

There is one friend you will always have, Sister, I shall never forget you as long as I am on this earth, for all you have done for us while we were at the Mission. Those were the days!

A bit of advice to you, pupils! You are in the best part of your lives at the Mission. I remember when I used to say I wish I was finished school, but I did not realize then what it was doing to me. You realize that only when you go out into the world and see for yourself. So while you are there, make the best of everything. Anyway, I am very proud to be a pupil of St. Bernard's, and I shall not let the Mission down.

Choirio, and God bless and protect you all. Au Revoir!

One who never forgets,
George Fovargue.

Dear Laddie,

If all my pupils were other George Fovargues, I should never grow old nor weary!!

Your beautiful sentiments
in the foregoing Airgraph show that you have not changed at all. God bless your grateful heart, dear Georgia, and make it happy in the thought that wherever you go, loving hearts follow you with prayers for your safety and happiness.

I heard from Don not long ago and he was rejoicing in having heard from you. Your kind Dad writes me occasionally to share some of the letters from the dear "lads".... We are all looking forward to the day when you will bring Eileen and Baby Pauline home! Until then, keep up your courage and your splendid spirit, and rely on our prayers...

S.J.P.

Atikomog, Alberta.
May 15, 1943.

Dear Teacher:

At last, news from your old TOPSY! I guess you thought I was dead, oh? I'm not! I often think of you and wish I was back in your classroom doing Arithmetic... My babies are fine and fat. I often wish I had a baby girl. If I ever have one, I will name her after you.

We might go over to Grouard sometime this summer. My husband would like to work at the Mission. Dear Sister, please send me news of Grouard. I'm dying to hear about you and all the old pupils. Don't forget your old Topsy, and thank the Sisters a thousand times for all the trouble they took to bring me up. God bless you and your pupils.

Your former pupil,
Mabel Noskoyi Yollowknoc.

Dear Mabel,

I knew all the old timers would smile happily at news from you, so I hope you will not mind seeing your letter in print. It will remind everyone of all the mischief you used to get into... and who doesn't feel better after a good laugh?

You have received my letter by this time, I'm sure, so you know that you are never forgotten by your old teacher.

S.J.P.

Colgury, Alberta.
May 7, 1943.

Dearest Sister Jean,

I got home safely, but not too glad to be here, for you know the old saying, "NO PLACE LIKE HOME."

Now, Mother, let us as well confess, now that I am far away, that I am married. Please forgive me; I know I should have told you before.

Yes at last, Sister Jean, I have found my mate. She is just my type, and I love her just like I love our old Mission. Won't it be grand some day when I come to see you and say, "Meet my wife."

I am sending you a picture of myself and wife.....

Best regards and wishes to all at the Mission and a big Hello to Fr. Forcado for the wife and I. Hoping to hear from you very soon.

Much love to you from
Johnny and Jean Bourgeois.

---

Dear Johnny,

To say your letter was a surprise, is stating it mildly! I remember your telling me, the day we were walking out to the cemetery on Club Day, that you had a great deal to tell me about that topic, but we were not able to continue our conversation, so you had to write me the glad news.

Of course, I am glad you are married, Johnny, and I offer you my sincerest congratulations. Please tell Jean I wish her all the happiness in the world. Thank you for the pictures... now, send me some large ones so I may put them up with all the other OLD-TIMERS. I will write you and Jean soon... in the meantime, best wishes!

S.J.P.

It may seem strange to our readers, that most of these letters are from the old boys. May I explain that the girls write just as faithfully, but their letters are usually too personal to be reproduced for the public.

St. Catherine's School was blessed by His Excellency, the Most Rev. John C. Cody, Bishop of Victoria, on April 15, 1940. He was assisted by the Rev. M. Lemmens, S.M.I., and other members of the clergy.

The event linked past with present, for, on the same day, Jubilee celebrations were being held at St. Ann's School for Boys commemorating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the opening there of the first school for natives on Vancouver Island.

In keeping with the double nature of the happy occasion, the children of St. Catherine's attended the Mass of Thanksgiving at St. Ann's and, in the afternoon, with many of their parents, were proud and happy to welcome their beloved Bishop on his first visit to their new school.

KATERI TEKAKWITHA

Once there was a little Indian girl whose name was Tekakwitha. When she was a baby, she lived with her father and mother in a village far away in grand and beautiful woods beside a pretty river. Her mother wrapped her in a pretty blanket so that one could see only her sweet brown face and her two black eyes, like beads. She had two red feathers sewed to the top of her warm blanket for a cap. Tied to a cradle-board she had her afternoon nap swinging from a tree while her mother worked near.

There was no church in the village where Tekakwitha was born. No Mass, no Tabernacles, no Stations, and these Indians knew nothing about the good God. Yes, there was one that knew, and that was Tekakwitha's mother. When she was a little girl at Three Rivers some holy priests told her about God and taught her to pray. She wanted Tekakwitha to be baptized, but before she could manage it all the family fell sick and both her mother and father died.

Tekakwitha grew to be a big girl. She wore her hair in two long black braids and she had a band of wampum round her forehead. One day Blackrobe came to the village. "We are priests called Jesuits," they said, and we have come to tell you about God, and about His Son Jesus, and about Heaven." Tekakwitha was very happy and wanted to give her heart to God, but her uncle was angry and did not want her to learn to pray.

TEKAKWITHA'S CROSS. Tekakwitha went into the forest by the river. The sky was blue through the trees and she could hear the water laughing over the rapids. All else was quite still. Indians are always silent in the forest, - they listen... listen... She was still too, she was praying about Our Lord on the Cross, and thinking over the things the Blackrobe had said about Him.

She saw a beautiful birch-tree growing close to the water. Its bark was pure white. She went up to it and spoke to it.

"Little birch-tree, little birch-tree," she said, "will you give yourself to be a pure white cross for Jesus?"

The little birch-tree rustled its leaves gently in the sunshine to mean,

"Yes I will give myself to be a pure white cross for Jesus."

She cut down the little tree and made two sticks. These she tied together with the band of wampum from her forehead to make a cross. She dug a hole in the ground and planted it upright. It was a lovely white cross.

Then she looked in the deep, soft moss under the hemlock trees and found red bunch-berries smiling up to her from their green leaf collars. They looked like red blood.

"Little berries, little red berries," she said, "will you give your red blood to love Jesus."

She gathered a beautiful red garland of them and placed them at the feet of the white cross.

Then she spoke to herself and said, "Tekakwitha, the white birch tree gave itself to be a pure white cross for Jesus, the bunch-berries gave their red blood to love Jesus. Will Tekakwitha give herself to be a pure white cross for Jesus? Will she give herself to be a garland of love for Jesus?"

And so Kateri Tekakwitha lived a holy Christian life and soon we shall call her SAINT KATERI, the patroness of our school.
