NOTES FROM THE JUNIOR CLASS ROOM

GRADES II AND III

Our school is called St. Catherine's School. We pray to St. Catherine every day to help us to be good and to learn. There are four classrooms in our school. Grade I has a classroom. They have forty-six little desks. There are five windows in the room and six big lights. The primary room faces the front of the school. The children learn to read, write, spell, do number work and say their prayers. They sing too. We sit just across the hall from them and we hear them. Many of them could not speak English when they started to school in September.

We are called the Junior Class - Grades II and III. I like our room best. We learn to do many things.

- Lorraine Charlie -

Did you ever visit our school? It is very nice to see. You come along the road on the Cowichan Reserve, look at the white house. That is our Indian School. There is a Thunderbird above the door. It was made and painted by one of the boys. We have a shop in our school. That is where the boys learn to make things out of wood. They are pretty smart too.

The girls have a room called the sewing room. They learn how to make dresses. They make sweaters too. When I go into the Senior Class I will make a dress for myself.

- Allee Modest -

We have a school for ourselves. There are three Sisters teaching in our school. Our teacher teaches Grades II and III. She goes also to teach the Senior Class how to make dresses and cook. There are five grades in the Senior room. While they are learning to sew or to cook, their Sister comes to teach us.

I like to come to school. I never missed one day yet since September. I hope I won't get sick. Sister gave us some games to play with when it is raining.

There is a very nice kitchen in our school. There are four nice tables for the big girls to learn cooking. The stove is cream and black. Mr. Morrison is putting up some nice cupboards along the wall.

- Cecilia Charlie -

When we have a concert we open the folding doors between our room and the sewing room. Our parents and friends sit in our classroom. We use the sewing room for the stage. The boys have made screens to use on the stage.

The lunch-room is next to the kitchen. We have cocoa or soup every day. Sometimes the big girls make pancakes or bread pudding and apple pudding. We all have some. We sit on benches. We have drop-tables around the wall of the lunchroom.

Across from the lunch-room is the boys' playroom; next to it is the boys' workshop.

I think our school is nice, don't you? I hope we always have this school. I love my school. I love my teachers. They teach us lots of things.

- Virginia Pierre -

I come from Khenipson Reserve. I have to walk a long way to get to the bus to come to school. Sometimes the dykes are flooded and we cannot go to school. Then we are sad. The dykes did not flood yet. I hope they don't.

Khenipson is a small reserve. That is why we have no chief.

- Edith Page -
OUR DRESS PARADE

St. Catherine's School is lucky to own three Singer sewing machines which are very seldom idle when we girls get going on our dresses.

We like to look nice, so we are learning how. The cheapest way, we are taught, and the best, is to buy material and make your own things.

Our teacher gets different kinds of dress materials and patterns for us. We are allowed to choose what we want, and with a little help, we do pretty well. The dress parade begins when the choice is made and the pattern is in our hands.

The cloth is spread out straight on the table. The pattern is laid and then pinned in place and we are ready for the big step - the cutting. We really get frightened when we first put the big shears to the material.

We do not find it hard to put our dresses together for we are taught to follow our lay-out. Finally when we get everything together then the machines begin. We like to watch one another's dresses growing from day to day.

We are fitted up with an electric iron. The ironing board was set up by the senior boys. They also made our cutting tables and our benches.

Some of the girls are able to finish two dresses besides having a little time for knitting and fancy-work.

We do not take our dresses with us when school closes in June. We work during the summer months at berry-picking and hop-picking. When we return in the Fall we are pretty rich. We then buy the dress that we made, and from that money Sister buys more material to keep our DRESS PARADE going.

- Janie Underwood -

WE ENTERTAIN OURSELVES As Hallows'een was on Saturday we had our party and games on Friday afternoon. We had all kinds of games. Some of us played Donkey, Feeding them blindfolded, and ducking for apples. Believe it or not, there were pennies and nickels in the apples.

After the games, the girls of the cooking class served pancakes. - Virginia James -
WOOL-WORK AT ST CATHERINE'S SCHOOL

Have you ever washed wool? Come to our school and we'll show you how.

First: buy the fleece from St. Ann's Farm. They have very good wool there. Second: take the fleece outside and get a couple of boys with good muscles to shake and shake it until all the loose dirt, sticks and burrs are removed. Third: get a large tub of cold water and plunge the fleece in it. This water will have to be changed many times as it will look like mud at first. Fourth: get another tub and fill it with soft warm soapy water - Oxydol is the thing - and put the fleece into it. The wool is now ready to be washed by hand.

Each girl gets a basin, goes to the tub, gets a little wool and some water, finds a comfortable place, and tries to get her amount of wool the whitest. The girls have great fun racing. The wool is then rinsed well in warm water. When it is all washed, we each take our basin of snow - because we, the pupils of St. Catherine's wash wool until it looks like snow - and spread it out on the grass, and ask the sun to make it whiter - if it can. Sometimes the rain helps too.

When the wool is dry it is taken to our sewing room where big, little and small boys and girls, spend many happy moments teasing - not one another - but teasing and carding our well-washed wool to the tune of some well-known song. The next step is the spinning, and the long rolls of snow-white fleece are changed into yarn.

The wool is then taken off the spool and put into skeins for another washing to loosen the spinning. When this is dry the wool is wound into balls and is ready for knitting the Indian sweaters which is the trade on the Cowichan reserve. We have knitted some beautiful sweaters and socks and have won prizes.

We are now trying our hand at finer spinning and will use two strand yarn to make knitted articles of all kinds. In this way the wool industry is growing in St. Catherine's.

- Helen Canute -

ACHIEVEMENTS AND PRIZES

We are glad to say that we sent some of the boys' wood work and the girls' sewing and knitting to the Montreal Exhibition last year. The boys won a cash of $5.00 and Madeline Charlie won a personal prize of $2.00 for an Indian sweater. For three years we have sent samples of our work to the Victoria Indian Exhibition and the people seemed to like it.

Alfrida Thorne, Ramona Underwood, Douglas Williams and Leonard Peters won the Gold Seal Certificate of Merit for the promotion of Humane Education, for their poster on the prevention of cruelty to animals. Ramona Underwood also received honours for her booklet that was sent to the T.B. Contest at Sardis.

Do you not think we have been doing good work?

- Louise Underwood -
APPLE PIE IN THE COOKING CLASS

We have tried our hand at many things—cookies, cakes, buns, puddings, and pancakes a few times, and we did enjoy them. But APPLE PIE did you say? Yes, we made that too, but what happened?

"Girls, if you would like to make apple pie bring some apples tomorrow, about six each will do."

"Yes, Sister."

- Next day -
"We shall go to the kitchen after recess to make apple pie. Bring your apples down. Work two together."

Sister goes down after recess.

Virginia, the thoughtful little pie-maker brought apples but we had forgotten ours! OH! OH! We could not even go down to the kitchen. Sister helps Virginia and what a grand apple pie comes out of the oven just as we girls are going down to serve the lunch. Are we ashamed and sorry? Are we going to miss making apple pie and the chance of letting our parents see what fine cooks we are going to be? Not us.

-A remark loud enough for our teacher to hear -

Rita: Are you going to bring apples tomorrow, Ramona?
Ramona: I guess so.
Girls: We all are. We are not going to be cheated out of apple pie.
Rita: What will Sister say?
Janie: Don't worry. She'll give in and help us. Won't you Sister?

The next day every girl brings a dozen apples. We do not need a second invitation to go to the kitchen, and soon apple pie making is in full swing. Virginia is Sister's assistant. To be sure each girl gets her own pie our teacher suggests that we put our initials on our pie.

At three o'clock there is a scramble for the first-bus girls to claim their pies, and every girl of the senior class goes home with the fruit of her labour, the proud possessor of an APPLE PIE. Every one was at school next day. The apple pie was not half bad.

-Louise Underwood-

WHICH WILL YOU HAVE?

A NOTE OF THANKS

Our thanks go to Miss Edwards, a September visitor from Seattle, for her interest in our school—candy, goodies, popping corn for our Christmas parcels, carving tools and magazines for the boys' department, needlecraft books and all kinds of sewing helps for the sewing room, all have come from her kindness and generosity.

Mr. A. Moran also helped fill our parcel with the candy he so kindly donated—not do we forget Mr. Morrison's apples for the same occasion.

Mrs. Kyle of Duncan comes in for a goodly share of our thanks for letting us use his bus when we went to see "Going My Way." The children enjoyed this very much.

-Ramona Underwood-
OUR PROGRAMME IN THE HOME

ECONOMICS DEPARTMENT

We have a programme put out by the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa. It covers a three-year course in knitting, sewing, housekeeping and cooking. When we have completed one year in any subject our teacher sends our names to the Department and we receive a badge. We are very happy to receive these badges because they tell us that we are learning. Many of the girls have received their badges already.

FIRST YEAR: Marjorie Modest, Alfreda Thoms, Josephine Canuto, Ramona Underwood, Evelyn Tommy. They have badges for sewing, cooking, knitting and housekeeping.

SECOND YEAR: Alfreda Thoms, Ramona Underwood and Evelyn Tommy for knitting and sewing. Many other names have been sent in but we have not received the badges yet. One thing that holds so many back is that the girls must be twelve years old before they can apply for a badge.

I hope by the time we finish school we shall have received all our badges. The one pictured is for knitting. Each badge has a picture on it to show what it is given for.

I think they are pretty, don't you?

- Evelyn Wilson -

We are working hard again this year at our T.B. booklet. We hope to win a prize. If we have time we are going to do some more animal posters. We are working too for the Exhibition at St. Ann's in Victoria.

- Rita Page -

OUR CHRISTMAS CONCERT

We would like to tell you about our Christmas concert because everybody liked it. It was on December 19th that we had our concert. Some parents and relatives of the children, and the Sisters and Fathers from Kuper Island, and other guests came. They all liked our school concert. We are glad that we did well.

Our program opened with O CANADA and a song of welcome. We had drills and dances and two little playlets. We then sang Christmas carols.

The children sang the carols so well that at the closing Father Lammons asked if we could sing for him at Mass on Christmas morning. We were there to sing at Mass and he was glad to have us sing for the Baby Jesus, and we did well.

We closed school on December 21st and we enjoyed our holidays very much.

- Violet James -

FIRST HOLY COMMUNION

Some of the boys and girls are to receive their First Holy Communion in our church at Duncan during the month of May. We do not know yet who they will be. May Our Lady always look after those who prepare well for her Son.

I come from Somenos. I have three sisters in school. My brother is only four years old. They call me

Audrey Underwood.
OUR WOODWORK SHOP

WHEN THE SCHOOL FIRST OPENED

We had only some old benches and a few tools which we used in the big play room at manual training period. We were not able to do very much. Then we divided the play room to make a real workshop. The Department gave us more tools each year and all the boys helped fix the workshop. Now we are very proud of it, and are learning to use all the fine tools that have been got for us.

-Norman Joe-

THE MANUAL TRAINING ROOM IS A BUSY PLACE

When we all got to work, each boy is doing something he wants to do and now that we can handle all our tools pretty well we are surprised at the things we can make. Our teacher makes us want to do our best so that we are ashamed of poor work. Everything that has been finished is here for you to see. When I leave school there will be the big painted thunderbird still hanging on the sewing room wall to remind other boys that I spent many hours making it. It takes time and patience to do good work.

-Alloc James-

THE BOYS IN THE MANUAL TRAINING ROOM HAVE LEARNED

to paint designs on the things they make. It takes a steady hand to make fine lines. We sure know that. We use our own Indian designs and choose our colours. We made a large trellis painted with birds and fish. This trellis is on the outside of the school for a rose bush.

We painted the game boards. Francis George made wall-racks to hold them. I made two carved picture frames for Sister Mary Eugenia, the last one framed needlepoint which the girls had done. Dennis is making and painting a wood-packer door-knocker to hang on the senior classroom door. You just pull a chain and the bird pecks at the door. I am going to make one for the Junior Classroom as soon as I finish the bench I am doing now.

-Roy George-

WHEN WE FIRST STARTED WOODWORK

We thought that all we had to do was hack things out and nail them up, but we have learned to plan and make a drawing for each thing we are to make. Visitors are surprised at the way we have fixed up the workshop and we hardly believe we have made all the things that we have. We won a $5.00 cash prize at the Montreal Exhibition and the boys voted this money to be used to help pay for the Stanley No. 55 plane for which we have long been waiting. It will be a gift for the school and those who come after us.

-Douglas Williams-

I WAS A JUNIOR LAST YEAR

and learned how to use many of the tools. We learned how to make paper knives and book stands and paint them with Indian designs.

The seniors spent most of their time building racks for the new tools which the Department sent us. Everything is in its place. Leonard Peter framed the blackboards and made shelves for our lunch boxes. Douglas Williams and Eugene Thorne made racks to hold the saws, chisels, etc. Norman Joe put up a display board and shelf between the windows then he painted the big thunderbird to hang over it.

-Dennis Alphonso-
WE HELPED MR. MORRISON, our teacher, to build a workshop using half of our big playroom. We put down a wooden floor over the old concrete and built a wall. When this was done we made over the old rickety benches putting in new vises, then we planed the tops clean and gave them two coats of stain and varnish. We did not know much about it all at first, but learned how to use the tools and get things done.

- Ernest Alphonse -

THE DEPARTMENT GIVES US A LIST OF THINGS WE MUST DO

to do each year in the workshop. When we have done the work for each year we get a badge from Ottawa. Douglas, Francis, Eugene and I got the first year badge and our names have gone in for the second year badge now.

The senior boys made tables for the classrooms. One of the first things I made was a long bench for the sewing room. Eugene and Douglas made wonderful polished tables for the classrooms. Eugene Thorne painted a big Thunderbird design over the outside of the front door. It looks great from the road and is seen by everybody.

-Kenneth Williams -

THE GROUNDS WERE COVERED WITH TREE STUMPS when the school was first opened. The Department had these pulled out and the ground was ploughed. The senior boys with Mr. Corcoran, put up the swings and seesaws and laid plank walks to keep us from sinking to our ankles in the mud.

In the spring we made a garden. When we came back in the Fall we had potatoes, carrots and other vegetables to eat. We like to eat raw carrots and the girls made stew for us some times using the potatoes and vegetables.

-Francis George -

MORE NOTES FROM GRADES II AND III

St. Catharine's is a nice school. Indian boys and girls go to it. A big green and orange bus brings us to school. The bus leaves Somosos at 8 o'clock (in summer time) and picks up the children along the road. We get to school at 8:15. Sister is waiting for us. We go to study our lessons until the second bus comes. The bus goes to Koksilah with the teacher and the Indian children that go to that school. The bus picks up more children for St. Catherine's on the way back and arrives with the second load at 8:45. Then we take our ranks and march upstairs. We sing a song and then go to our rooms. I like our school.

-Ruby Alphonse -

I like our school too, but sometimes I lose my coat and miss the bus. I have to walk home then.

-Theresa Alphonse -

I live at Clamclamutz. I ride in the bus to school. Sometimes the river is a flood and I cannot get out of my house. The school is nice and warm when we go in. Come and see our school.

-Amelia Tommy -

I come from Khenipsen. I do not like to miss the bus. I do not like a long walk when it is wet and cold. I do not miss school only when I am sick. I have two brothers and three sisters. We go to St. Catharine's School. My big brother is too old to go. My baby brother is too little yet.

-Sarah Page -
STARS FOR THE WISE

The children who are wise enough to come to school every day and learn, get stars. This is how it works. If we do good work we get a red star. If the work is not so good, we get a green star. If it is bad, we get no star. When we have five green stars on the classroom chart we can have a red star posted on the bulletin in the corridor, and when we win five red stars we can get a gold star. You should see the number of gold stars on our bulletin! Spelling, Arithmetic, Reading, Language, oral and written, Geography, History, Health, drawing and singing, all count.

We even get stars for ranks. For five stars for good ranks we may win a silver star. Just watch us march up and down our stairs.

-Roy George-

JOY AND SADNESS

For some time our teachers have been telling us about Reverend Mother General, the head of the Sisters of St. Ann. Reverend Mother has planned to visit all the schools here in the west. She has never seen ours. We have been looking forward to seeing this good Mother who gave us teachers when our school was opened in 1940, hoping that she would come while we were in school.

Now our teachers ask us to say a very special prayer for dear Reverend Mother for she is ill. We promise our prayers and we know our dear Lord, His Mother and Good St. Ann are going to see to it that our prayers are answered and we shall see Reverend Mother this year.

-Margaret Rose Charlie-

THE CORPUS CHRISTI PROCESSION

Every year we have the Corpus Christi Procession, the second Sunday in May, which is a big day for the Indians. Many people from all over Vancouver Island come to the Tzouhalem Indian Church for the High Mass. The Indians sing in the choir. After the Mass Jesus in the Blessed Sacrament is carried in procession to St. Ann's School where Benediction is given, and then back to the church, with singing and hymns all the way. Spring flowers and blossoms look their prettiest; daffodils and tulips are in their best to do honour to their Creator.

The Sisters have an altar on their front porch. The Bishop gives Benediction. The high mountains and the tall green trees seem to listen and bow down in adoration. Then we all walk back to the church.

For many years boat races at Cowichan Bay followed the ceremony at Tzouhalem, but lately everybody goes to Duncan to watch the sports. Last year it rained in the afternoon so we had our sports on the 24th of May.

We are anxious for the procession to come this year. - Alec James -

FIELD DAY

Mike Underwood, Chuck Thorne with some other Indians arrange games for us on Field Day. They are lots of fun. The winners get money for prizes. Last year after the races, Duncan and Saanich played a game of softball. Duncan won. - Alec James -

THE BOYS' PLAY PERIOD AT SCHOOL

On rainy days at school we cannot go outside to play games so we try RING TOSS, CARDS or CHINESE CHECKERS. The boys like ring toss best. In the summer we like baseball. During the winter, when the pond beside the school is frozen, we like to play ice hockey. This winter we were able to play for about two weeks.

We are now waiting for spring. The senior boys will then start to practice up again on baseball. The juniors will be at their marbles. - Douglas Williams -
A MARCH TO MUSIC - AND SALUTE THE FLAG

Every morning to the music of the gramophone, the children march upstairs to the landing by the classrooms. We sing the hymn salute the Flag which hangs over the entry, and then we sing, "God Save the King!"

We then march to music to our classrooms and start the day's work feeling very good. We march to music as we go up and downstairs, six times each day. We are getting to be like real soldiers. Do you want to come and see us do it? We'll be well trained when we join the army.

--Evelyn Tommy--

Before the rationing, the girls of the cooking class used to serve a full hot meal about twice a week, but now things are too hard to get so we shall have to wait until after the war.

OUR NURSE

Miss Hayward is our nurse. She used to visit the school twice a week and often visited our homes too, especially when anyone was sick. She is very kind and good. But, since Christmas she has been sick and we miss her very much. Hurry up, Miss Hayward, and come back. St. Catherine's School will be very glad to welcome you.

A PRAYER AT EVENING

Thank you, dear God, for a lovely day,
I had so much fun in my work and play!
Did you see me the time I ran down the hill?
And the wind made the apple blossoms spill
Right over my head like a golden shower?
We danced together for 'most an hour.

And did you hear the yellow bird sing,
"It's spring! little girl!"
"It's spring! It's spring!"
I laughed and I told him,
"I know, I know."
The frog in the round pond told me so."

And do you remember the lambs at play?
One little black one ran away
And lost his mother, and stood and cried,
Until she came hurrying to her side.
And I thought, "That's the way the Lord takes care
Of His little children everywhere."

And now, dear God, I must say, "Good-night,"
Please watch the world through the long dark night.
Bless mother and daddy, and make them good,
And help all the people to do as they should.
From
The Sechelt Residential
Sechelt B.C. School,

The Indian Village of Bella Bella was the scene of a unique celebration this Easter season. Instead of rivalry or the attempt to stage an old-fashioned "potlatch" the Bella Bella Indians invited the neighboring villages of Bella Coola and Klemtu to be their guests. The main purpose was to have a formal dedication and opening of their new board walk which forms the main street of the village. Owing to the rugged character of the soil, ordinary roads are not practical and this board walk, 10 feet wide and nearly 3/4 of a mile in length, serves as road and side walk. This is the second time it has been rebuilt. Counting their time, it is estimated that it cost nearly $20,000.00. The Indians did the work, getting the logs, towing them in and sawing them into planks in their own sawmill. Except for approximately $100 which the Government contributed, the village bore the entire cost.

About seventy-five people came from each of the two villages. The first evening, Tuesday, was taken up by basketball games between Bella Coola and Bella Bella. The men's team from Bella Bella won both games while the Bella Coola team was victor in the women's game.

On Good Friday, services were held morning and evening. An Indian, Mr. Norman Harris, conducted the morning service and Dr. D. L. Lamb, Medical Missionary took the evening one. Special music at both services was provided by the Alerto choir under the leadership of Mr. William Robinson with Mr. Louis Hall organist.

On Saturday afternoon, the visitors, headed by the Bella Coola concert band, lined up for the opening ceremony. Red, white and blue ribbons were stretched across the street. After speeches of welcome by Chief Charlie Moody, Chief Samuel King of Bella Coola and Chief Philip Brown of Klemtu spoke and the dedication prayer was given by Dr. E. Herby. Chief Brown then unveiled the street sign "Churchill Road" and Chief King cut the ribbons. Everyone then paraded the length of the Village to the musical music of the Bella Coola Band. This ceremony was followed by a banquet in the Community Hall and a dance that evening.

On Easter Sunday, appropriate services were held. A native, Mr. David Campbell, conducted the morning service while Dr. D. L. Lamb was in charge of the evening service. The Klemtu Choir also provided the music, singing such anthems as Haydn's "The Heavens Are Telling" and the "Hallelujah Chorus" from the Messiah very creditably. Although the Bella Bella United Church seats over 250, it was necessary to hold the services in the Community Hall to enable everyone to attend.

Owing to rain, the sports program for Monday had to be cancelled. However, a very enjoyable farewell banquet was served by the Ladies Aid of Bella Bella and in the evening...
the festivities were brought to a close by a concert provided by the members of the Bella Bella choir and Concert Band.

The Committee in charge of arrangements, under the leadership of Mr. Caleb Williams, deserves much credit for the successful way in which the celebration was conducted. Entirely Indian in its conception and management, it was a credit to the Natives, and few White communities of the same size attempt anything like it.

WEDDING

Bella Bella United Church was the setting for the wedding on April 23rd when Miss Mabel Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abel Hall was united in marriage to Mr. Daniel Humchitt, son of Chief Albert and Mrs. Humchitt, all of Bella Bella Indian Village. Rev. George E. Darby, M.D., performed the ceremony.

The bride, given in marriage by her father, wore a floor length gown of white satin with white net overskirt. Her floor length veil of white net was caught to her head by a cap of tiny white feathers and she carried a spray of pink tulips. She was attended by Miss Catherine Martin as maid of honor, while bridesmaids were Miss Alice Humchitt, Miss Marguerite Hall, Miss Lorettta Sandy and Miss Phyllis Hopkins. Their floor length dresses were in pastel shades. Mina Hall, sister of the bride and Betty Brown were junior attendants, while Mr. Carmen Humchitt supported the groom. Wedding music was played by Miss Betty Wilson.

Following the ceremony a banquet was held in the Community Hall. In the evening a reception was held to which the whole village as well as visitors from Bella Coola and Klietu were invited. Mr. and Mrs. Humchitt will reside in Bella Bella.

NOTES ON TUBERCULOSIS

It is not generally known, but there is an Advisory Committee for the Control and Prevention of Tuberculosis among the Indians. This Committee meets in Ottawa and consists of twelve members, ten appointed by the Canadian Tuberculosis Association, one by the Department of National Health and Welfare and the Senior Medical Officer of the Indian Department. These experts are studying the problem of T.B. amongst Indians and advise the Government regarding better ways of preventing and curing this disease. Here are a few of the things they have found out and announced.

The death rate from Tuberculosis amongst Indians in 1943 was fifteen times that of the White population. While the death rate from T.B. in Whites has declined 35% in the past fifteen years, there has been very little change in the Indian rate of death. In 1937 not more than 100 Indians were having hospital treatment for T.B. At present there are 905 in departmental and provincial sanatoria.

In British Columbia, Coqualeetza Hospital has approximately 175 beds for Indians only and is in charge of Dr. W.S. Barclay, a prominent T.B. specialist. The R.C.A.F. Hospital at Millar Bay near Prince Rupert has been taken over by the Department for use as a T.B. hospital for Indians and will have 150 beds. It will be opening shortly and will be in charge of Dr. J.D. Galbraith. Local people will remember him as he was on the "Thomas Crosby" for a short time and at Bella Coola for several years before specializing in T.B. work.

The Government spent over $1,000,000 in 1944 on control measures. Now that the Government is actually doing its part, to a large extent at least, it is up to the Indians to take advantage of the facilities offered and try to help themselves.

HAVE YOUR POCKETBOOKS READY & TWO GOOD CAUSES NEED YOUR HELP!

1. Cancer. This terrible disease is second in the list of "killers". The cause is unknown and unless it is taken very early, when it can be removed surgically or killed by radium or X-ray, it is fatal in a few years at most. A continent wide campaign is on to raise money for research into the cause and cure, education of the public so that people will be suspicious of unusual growths, and the treatment of cases. While it not very common amongst Indians, it does occur and we should help in the fight against it. In the meantime, consult your doctor for lumps that appear in places where they shouldn't; for moles that start to enlarge, change color or lose their skin; for any ulcer (raw place) that does not heal readily; any irregular bleeding.

2. Pension Fund. In order to make the pension fund of the United Church safe, the laymen have started a campaign to raise at least 3 1/2 million dollars. The ministers undertake to devote their lives to their charges for a very small salary. They are not allowed to earn more than this and so cannot save enough to provide for their old age or illness. The Church provides a pension for this reason but unless something is done, this fund is liable to go "broke". Hence, this drive. Help this good cause along, Bella Bella.

G.E. Darby, M.B.

WISHBONES

A backbone, not a wishbone is the thing that you require
If you wish to make your mark, and gain your heart's desire.
Idle wishes get you nowhere; any fool can dream,
But if you want the sweets of life, the sugar and the cream
You can't expect it placed before you on a silver dish
You've got to do much more than sit at home and merely wish.

Wishes, wishes, do not sit and wish your life away
Look around and see what can be got from life today.
If you want the moon - then hitch your wagon to a star.
If you don't, then learn to be content with what you are.
Better not to wish at all, -contented with your lot
Than spend your life in wishing for the things you haven't got.
THE GIRLS' CLUB

The Girls' Club has had a busy and profitable winter. Besides publishing the "Dootseelth", spasmodically, we admit, but non-the-less enthusiastically, they have undertaken a number of other projects.

Two very successful "Fish-Ponds" have been conducted by Club members - the first at the December Ladies Aid Sale of Work, and the second at the Valentine Party in Gibson Hall.

The Valentine Party was organized and managed by the girls, and the program of games was enjoyed by the young people, as well as by some of the not-so-young people of the village. A profitable side line (in addition to the Fish-Pond) was the sale of Hot-dogs and coffee.

In addition to the donations of Babies Ward furniture, which we mentioned in an earlier issue, the Girls' Club recently donated an electric washing machine to the hospital. The machine, operated by a member of the Club, takes care of the daily "Baby Wash", and fills a long felt need. Whenever a satisfactory quality of linoleum is again available, the girls hope to purchase floor covering for the hospital wards.

Illness of club members and club leader during the spring weeks interfered with club meetings, but the girls plan to conclude the season's activities on May 24th with a "Hot Dog Stand".

Club meetings have been held in the Nurses' Home, and when the members were not occupied with publishing a "Dootseelth", or preparing a "Fish-Pond", the work periods were spent in making surgical supplies for the hospital.

While all of the girls have been faithful and loyal, and have worked hard for the club, we would like to pay special tribute to the unsurpassed faithfulness and industry of two of the members, namely Alice Mason and Dorothy Windsor.

*************************************

THE LADIES' AID

While The Ladies Aid has not held regular meetings during the winter, the ladies are planning their regular Spring Sale of Work. Also, they were responsible for the serving of a very fine banquet in the Community Hall during the Easter celebration.
MISSION BAND NOTES

In spite of prevalent colds, the Mission Band held their regular meetings this Spring.

At the Easter Thank-Offering Meeting in the Church, a choir composed of twenty-two girls sang two songs.

The members began working early for their Easter Sale and realized $8.00 mainly from the sale of eggs which the girls enjoyed coloring.

At the close of this term, they will have completed their booklets, "Friends in Africa," and will take these home as a memento of a year's study of the work of the United Church in Africa.

******************************

CANADIAN GIRLS IN TRAINING.

With few exceptions, the girls have met faithfully each week in the Prayer Meeting room at the Church. Since Christmas six meetings have been spent on the study book "Spotlight on Africa." The girls took as their project, the making of a model African village and while it was not as complete as it might have been, still it gave a very good idea of how African homes are built. On completion of the study book, the girls met with the Evening Auxiliary at their April meeting and became affiliated with the W.M.S., in this way. This is one of the necessary credits in order to become a "Recognized Group." In this connection it is interesting to note that the first report on the year's work, submitted in January, received very favorable comment from Miss Gertrude Patmore, Girls' Work Secretary for B.C. The girls hope that when the second report goes in at the close of the winter's activities, that they will win "recognition" and thus become one of the "Chevron" groups in B.C. This will entitle them to wear a stripe on their middies.

The group is a small one and while their influence has not been greatly felt in the village, still the girls have worked hard at many small things and have benefited in various ways from their meetings. We shall look forward to being together again as a group after the summer holidays.
THE EVENING AUXILIARY

The Evening Auxiliary has met regularly in the Nurses' Home the first Monday of each month during the winter. The Study Book has dealt with the work of the United Church in Africa, and while the leader for the evening presented a chapter from the Study Book, the other members were busy doing hospital mending and making surgical supplies. This donation of services has been doubly acceptable this past season due to the unfortunate shortage of hospital staff.

The group is growing in membership; the 1945 paid-up membership was 28, as compared with 14 in 1944, and the 1946 paid-up membership has already reached 24.

Financially also, progress is being made. In 1944, $35.00 was raised, while in 1945 the total receipts amounted to some $75.00.

Besides its regular meetings, the group joins in the World Day of Prayer, and the Autumn and Easter Thankoffering services.

PROCRASTINATION

If you have a job to do—then do it right away! —
Tomorrow is a long way off—we only have Today.
The present time is ours to use, and spend as best we can,
And every hour is precious in this little human span.
We put things off, and then we find we've left it just too late;
And when it's more than likely that we put the blame on Fate,
we never can recapture that odd moment that we lose;
There's no time like the present, as we find out—to our cost.
"I'll leave it till tomorrow"—that's a fatal thing to say!
Don't give the clock the laugh on you—just do that job today.

Clam digging this year has been very good. Although people came back with backaches and colds, they were still happy over their loot from every corner of the coast. Clams, like any other fish, have to be searched for, but are found on beaches instead of in the water. And instead of using nets, you use forks to move them from their watery beds. And once caught, they must be removed from their shells before they can be eaten.

Spring found the people of Bella Bella very busy this year. All were busy clearing their yards and gardens, painting their homes, and repairing the walks. New homes are being built, and old ones repaired. Altogether the village looks greatly improved.

April 6th the Choir members gave a concert in the Community Hall which was much enjoyed by all. Solos, duets and quartets were rendered, as well as several numbers by the entire choir. Choir leader was Mr. Gordon Reid, and Mrs. Agnes Hudson was pianist.

Sunday, April 14th a memorial service was held in the church, honoring the memory of the late Chief Edward Gamble of Kitkatla. The Choir and the Bella Bella Concert Band assisted with the service. We extend our deepest sympathy to Mrs. Gamble, and her son Russell.

The Herring Spawning came early this year, and fortunately the weather was favorable; many people went "fish-egging", and returned with large amounts of Herring eggs, which have been cured and stored for next winter's use.

The Carpenter brothers are hard at work building a 34 foot mill-netter for Basil Carpenter.

On April 25th Vancouver, Bella Bella, and a few other important places went on Daylight Saving Time.

Brenda Campbell, Caleb Williams, and George Wilson attended the Native Brotherhood Convention at Fort Simpson in March.

The people of Bella Bella were sorry to learn that Mr. S.F. Anfield has been transferred to the Prince Rupert Agency. At present Mr. Anfield is managing both agencies.

Dawn came as a welcome relief to Christine. The prospects of her daughter facing the coroner jury the following morning was not conducive to sound sleeping and her dreams were filled with weird fantasies. She was wide awake with the first shaft of light that touched the reserve. For some time she lay in bed dwelling on the possible outcome of the trial. Lyddia was innocent, she knew, yet doubt and fear kept gnawing at her peace of mind. Justice had miscarried before now. For Lyddia to spend even one night in jail would be a disgrace she could not bear to face.

So, the morning hours went slowly on. At seven she arose and called Lyddia. Together they attended Mass and received Holy Communion. Christine prayed as she had never prayed before. She prayed with all the fervor of St. Monica praying for her wayward son, Augustine.

At breakfast she finally summoned up enough courage to tell about the coroner investigation. Lyddia, dear, she began, Father told me last night that the coroner is having a meeting this morning. Lyddia started in her chair, sat up straight, her face becoming strangely pale. "This morning, Mother?" "Yes, dear, at 10 o'clock." "Oh, Mother, I am scared,—what will they do to me?"—"I know how you feel, child; I am afraid, too, but, we must have courage."—"What do they do at the Coroners meeting—will they ask me a lot of questions?" "Oh Mother I will be too frightened to speak."—"They will be nice to you, Lyddia. Mr. Weston came over to see me when you were away. He told me that the Coroner's jury was only to decide the cause of the death."—"But, I did k—" Lyddia shuddered even to say the word—"I think it would be better for us not to talk about it, Lyddia. We must trust in God. If they ask you any question you will just have to answer as truthfully and as well as you can."

About nine o'clock a rap came on the front door. Both Lyddia and Christine were in the kitchen. Christine's heart was quaking as she wiped her hands on her apron saying to Lyddia, "I will see who it is."

It was Father Kelly. "Good morning, Christine," he began, "I hurried over to tell you that Mr. Stuart just sent word that the meeting will be postponed until six o'clock this evening. There has been some delay in picking a jury.

"Oh, Father, I wish they would get it over with. This waiting is killing both of us."

"Well, look, Christine, the women are going to scrub the Church today from top to bottom. Why not bring Lyddia over, it will help you to keep your mind off it."

"Indeed, I will," she answered energetically.

Lyddia came into the living room thinking, of course, that it was an order to attend the Coroner's Meeting. Seeing Father Kelly she said quietly and with some relief, "Good morning, Father", Is it time to go."

"No, Lyddia, it is put off until tonight. I have just been asking your Mother to come over and help with the cleaning of the Church."

"Sure, I'll go." Lyddia answered.

Father hurried back to the Church to tell the other women and young girls that Christine and Lyddia were coming and that no mention was to be made about the pending investigation.

The day passed more quickly than Christine had anticipated as she plied her scrubbing brush with great vigor and prayed with great fervor. Shortly before six o'clock, the Coroner very kindly and thoughtfully sent word asking Father Kelly if he would accompany Christine and her daughter to the Magistrate's house.
It would be, perhaps, offensive to them if I were to send the Constable," the message read. "Most thoughtful indeed," Father murmured to himself as he folded the note up and placed it in his pocket.

Father Kelly, old Uncle John, Christine and Lyddie walked together to the School-house where Court was being held. They arrived a minute or two before six. On the way over Father Kelly gave Lyddie a general notion of the proceedings to take place and of what would be expected of her. Everyone, including Father Kelly was obviously nervous.

On arriving at the School-house they were immediately ushered into the large class-room. The room was fairly spacious, but not sufficiently spacious to hold the number of men mustered for the occasion.

The Jury, which was comprised of the better known citizens of the district were grouped along one side of the room. On the other side sat the Chief, Jimmy Henry and Sam Denny; Mr. Winston and the rest of the men who had searched and found the body of Struthers. They obviously were to furnish the necessary evidence. At the end of the room at the teacher's desk sat the Coroner, the district Constable and the Magistrate. A chair was reserve for Lyddie near by.

The Coroner's Investigation was declared open immediately and the wheels of the law began their tedious and tiring grinding and sifting of evidence. The witnesses were called one by one, their evidence written for time immemorial by the Magistrate. Questions were asked, statements were made by those who had viewed the body. His exact position was duly noted. Their sworn testimony, taken at the time of the discovery identifying the body of Struthers, was produced and read to the Jury. During the examination of Mr. Winston's evidence he insisted on more than once correction and without being asked that the wound caused by the stone, on the side of Struther's face could not have caused his death. Finally, the Coroner somewhat curtly, "Mr. Weston," we are not asking for your opinion, we seek only facts, please confine your replies to the questions asked." Upon this mild rebuke, Mr. Winston took out his handkerchief and blew his nose with resounding vigor in obvious protest. Lyddie, of course, was called upon to give her story and did so in a low and nervous voice. The Coroner interrupted her narrative with numerous questions. Dr. O'Brien who was actually the Coroner of the district, although he was not handling the investigation was longest on the stand. After the usual routine, questions as to name and occupation he was asked to describe the wounds which he did in detail noting their exact position, and their seriousness.

"Do you think, Doctor," the Coroner went on, "that the wound already described as inflicted on the side of the deceased's head might have cause his death?"

"No, your Honor, it is my opinion that it did not. It was merely a flesh wound.

"The wound described on the back of the head which the unanimous testimony of the witnesses has shown to have been caused when the deceased, falling, struck his head on a sharp protruding stone. Could this have been the immediate cause of his death?"

"During the autopsy I examined the base of his skull most carefully. There was no fracture of the skull and probably only a slight concussion. I do not think it was sufficient to affect his death."

"What then, Doctor, in your opinion was the cause of the death of the man in question?"

"Heart failure, Your Honor". There was a sudden new interest throughout the room and a shifting about in seats.

"Would the Doctor, please, explain to the court his reasons for this assumption," the Coroner asked.

"Yes, your Honor, about six months ago, the deceased came to my Office. He complained of suffering from pains in his chest. Upon examination I discovered positive signs of angina pectoris. I suggested the approved treatment for it and in addition warned him to avoid entirely all alcoholic beverages and sudden over exertion. His case was not too far advanced at that time."

"Are you of the opinion, Doctor, that he followed your advice?"

"Regarding drinking, at least, he did not. I discovered him drunk on more than one occasion, and one of these occasions, I repeated my warning to him.
"I am praying for something else, too."
"What is it?"
"That we will be able to get married before Christmas."
Lydia was so surprised by this sudden announcement she said,
"Oh"—very weakly.
Johnny was quick to sense what he thought was a vague refusal.
"But, would you like to, Lydia?—Have you changed your mind about me?"
"Yes, I say I had?" Lydia answered somewhat pertly.
"No,—but, you seem disappointed."
"I didn't say anything. I just said 'Oh!'.
"Well, will you, Lydia. We would get along swell together.
Will you?"
"I'll—Lydia began, and then stopped and smiled.
John was quick to notice this change. He felt he was losing ground.
"What are you smiling at, Lydia?"
"I was just thinking of something funny."
"Heck, do you think it is funny because I asked you to marry me?"
Johnny answered, somewhat irritated.
"Now, I didn't mean it that way, but, I was thinking of a story of David Copperfield that Sister Theresa used to read us in class period.
"Do you remember the note Barkis sent to Peggotty when he asked her to marry him?"
"No, I don't" Johnny answered.
"He said, 'Barkis is willing' ".
"Does that mean that you will?" Johnny asked with sudden emotion.
"If Mother will let us."
"Oh, I am sure she will. Why should she want us to wait any longer."
They sat for a moment in silence and then, the bell, high up in the belfry of the Church began booming out its call to Benediction.
"I guess we had better go, Johnny," Lydia said.
"Yes, I guess so. We will ask your Mother after Benediction."
"I think you had better pray that she will say 'Yes!' "
"You bet I will. And what will you do, Lydia?"
"You know I will be praying with all my heart, Johnny."
And together they passed up the steps of the Church and through the vestibule and into the presence of their Eucharistic God.

The end.

NOTE: This the end of the story. I hope you have enjoyed following the adventures of this young Indian girl. I do not know if I shall be able to find time to continue the story of Lydia's life next year. It takes a good deal of time to type and then stencil 3000 words each month.

So far the present at least we will say GOODBYE to Lydia.

Respectfully yours

Father Dunlop.
"Would you say, then, that these wounds already described did in no way affect his death?"

"It is possible, Your Honor, that they contributed in a measure to hasten his death. But, I am of the opinion that his untimely death was brought about rather by his excessive drinking and by the prolonged overexertion from running which caused his heart to fail."

"That will be all, Doctor," and the Doctor quietly stepped down from the stand and took his seat with the other witnesses. The Coroner then summed up the evidence as received for the Jury. The Jury then retired to the adjoining Class room for deliberations. They were not out long but, it seemed like hours to Lydia and Christine. As they took their places once more in the crowded Class room the Coroner addressed the Foreman saying, "Have you reached a decision?"

"We have, Your Honor," the Jury man replied.

"Would you inform the Court of your decision," the Coroner asked.

"Accidental death, Your Honor."

Someone started clapping, someone cheered, then the whole class room became an uproar. The Coroner pounded loudly on his desk for order, but, order was not restored for some time. When finally the sudden wave of enthusiasm had died down the Coroner spoke, "Miss Lydia, the Coroner's Jury has found you entirely innocent of the death of Sydney Struthers. Let no stigma be attached to your good name for you have done no wrong in the eyes of the State and I feel certain that you have done none in the eyes of God. I congratulate you on your courageous defence of your virtue!" and then he added curtly, "Court dismissed."

Many gathered around Lydia and Christine to congratulate them on the happy ending of this sad event. Christine's only remark was, "God be praised."

Together the Mother and daughter and Uncle John who was beside himself with delight set off for the reserve. As they neared the reserve they saw a young man hurrying towards them. Christine was just about to say, "Who is that coming in such a hurry?" when she caught a glimpse of Lydia's face. There was no need to ask who it was. It was Johnny.

There was no doubt about that.

Johnny was out of breath when he got up to them. He was yet a dozen paces away when he blurted out, "What happened---how did it turn out?"

"It was Christine who answered. It is all over, Johnny, and the Jury said it was accidental death."

"Thank God," Johnny answered, and then stood with his head down obviously embarrassed, his hands in his pockets, and shifting from one foot to another. It was Christine who broke the silence for Lydia had suddenly become tongue tied with the appearance of Johnny. "When did you get in?" she asked.

"Just now. I only heard about the trouble two days ago, and I came right down. Our gas boat broke down near Sloan's Cove. I thought we would never get here."

"It was nice of you to come. Well, I guess we had better go home. It must be nearly time for Church. Old John and Christine walked on ahead. Johnny and Lydia came behind. They seemed to have found their tongues for they talked continuously as they walked along. They did not turn in at the house, but, walked on down to the wharf. Johnny told Lydia all about the boat he was going to buy explaining in detail its lines, its horse-power, the make of the engine, all of which was Greek to Lydia. Yet, she found it all so interesting because Johnny insisted on calling it "Our boat."

Sitting together on a rail that ran down to the dock Johnny assured Lydia how worried he had been when he first heard the news.

"I heard so many different stories before I finally got here, Lydia, I did not know what to believe."

"It was awful, Johnny, but, since you came tonight, it all seems to have happened so long ago. Isn't that funny because it is only a few days."

"I'll bet you could have cheered when the Jury said you did not kill him."

"Yes, you bet I did. But, you know Mother prayed so hard and Sister Mary and the Priest and Uncle John. I guess it just had to be a sure thing."

"And I prayed, too, Lydia."

"Did you Johnny?--That was nice of you."

A Word From The Principal

To the Editorial Staff:

I wish to compliment the members of the Editorial Staff for the interesting "Year Book" they are presenting us. They have drawn a pleasant picture of the pupils' life at school and of their progressive steps in the field of academical work, Technical Training Art and Science.

The Parents and the ex-pupils, I am sure, will take a particular interest in its reading. In recalling to their mind memories of their school days, we hope that it will bring them closer to their Alma Mater.

To the School Staff and Parents:

It is my duty to extend my sincere thanks and appreciation to the School Staff and to the Parents. The progress achieved by the children is chiefly due to their devotedness and to their spirit of sacrifice and cooperation.

For a better understanding and a closer contact between the Parents and the School Staff, we are planning for next year, the organization of the "Parents' Day". All the parents of our pupils would be invited, by groups belonging to the same reserve, to visit the school. They would be shown the class-work of their children and their activities in Technical Training. Full opportunity would be given them to discuss with the Principal and the Staff any matter related to their children's welfare.

This year, we have made a new experiment. We have granted the pupils a holiday for home gardening. We think it to be an encouragement for the parents and a reward for the children. If it proves successful, it will become an annual affair to which parents and children can look forward.

To the Graduates:

Dear Graduates, the school life with all its pleasant and unpleasant moments is over for you. You are leaving us. We witness your departure with deep regret, not only because we have enjoyed your company but mainly because your training has yet to be completed. You understand that it is not at 16 years of age that you can have acquired a complete education and a full knowledge of a trade. Moreover, the parents of many among you are not in the economic position to give you the necessary help to continue your training and to fit you to undertake the
the task of earning your own living. Your situation has been the object of much thinking. We have come to the conclusion that the best amendment to the present system of Indian Education would be to build up a plan that would help you to specialize in the technical trade or profession of your choice and ability and at the same time, would permit you to earn enough to start on your own.

With the encouragement and help of the Department we hope to be able to create next year, out of the revenue of a rented farm, a fund for the Graduates. Our intention would be to pay a suitable salary money for their establishment.

Dear Graduates, in extending you a hearty welcome back, I wish you full success in all your undertakings.

To all the pupils:

Sincere congratulations to all the pupils who can go back home for their holidays with the conviction that they have done their duty, have increased their knowledge and improved their character.

To the others who are conscious that they could have done better, I say: "Try it next year."

Dear Pupils, be good during your holidays, pray well, work well, play well.

May God bless you.

Happy vacation.

PAUL PICHE, O.M.I.

REMINISCENCES

THIS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL you see on the top cover, the finest of its type in the province, accommodates today, two hundred and eighty children, from the tiny tots of the primary grades to the husky young youths and maidens of grade seven and eight.

But, Lobrot too, had its beginning. Many old timers would recall the yearly visits of the first school, from 1894 to 1904. Happy souvenirs are often related of the merited and zealous founder of the school, Reverend Fr. Hugonard. His missionary career in the Qu'Appelle Valley lasted altogether forty-three years, thirty at the Indian School, Bessides being a great benefactor to the Indians he was an ardent lover of his adopted country. One incident very remarkable of this great soul was when the first school, which he had built with unnumberable fatigue and hardship, was completely destroyed by fire in 1904. He was absent. On his return, when seeing the building in ashes instead of complaining, took the staff and pupils to the church nearby and sang the "Te Deum."

The younger generation would recall the second fire which again wiped away a wonderful architectural work of many years of labor. The fire started in early morning and at night 30, 1936, this school was officially opened. His Eminence Cardinal R. Villeneuve on the occasion of his visit to the west, joined with Inspector W. Morrison of the department of Indian Affairs in the official opening.

The school affords religious and social education to children from eleven different reservations. Reverend Brother Piché, Principal, is missionary of the Piapot, Moosepotung and Pasqua Reservations. Rev. Fr. Guy de Brotergno has charge of the File Hills Colony and Agency, while the Assiniboino, Sioux, Wood Mountain, Moose Mountain, Oak River and Oak Lake Reservations are under the care of Rev. Fr. Laviollette.

Fr. Hugonard, O.M.I.

Farewell!

It is for me a great pleasure to express, on behalf of all the graduates, a few words of gratitude to all the members of the Staff of the Lebret Indian School.

Now that the time has come for us to leave the school in which we have lived for many years, we must look back upon what has been done for us, by the Fathers, the Sisters, by our teachers and supervisors, and by other members of the Staff. They have done everything in their power to give us a good education and to make us upright and good, and in this way enable us to take our place in life.

Few schools, I am sure, could have offered us as many opportunities, and at the same time as much enjoyment. Through the kindness of all those who have been in charge of us, we have had many good times and our school days have been both useful and pleasant.

Before leaving, I am sure that all the graduates will join me, in promising to all those who have worked in our interest, that we will try ever to remain faithful to that which they have taught us, and that we will not forget them.

On behalf of all the graduates, then, I say farewell to the school, to the Staff and to the pupils who will follow us later; and I thank the Fathers, the Sisters and all the others who have worked for us, for everything that they have done.

Anthony Peigan

A new manufacture of "papier maché" has developed during the year. Many a broken dish has been put into decorative flower pots, rough pieces of wood into nice silvered frames.

The tissue paper wrappers of fruit have been mixed into flower paste, stuck on milk bottles, to form attractive flower vases, particularly when broken pieces of small mirrors have been placed on. Ash trays from covers, old pyrex coffee pots into fish, toy animals, fruit dish filled with different fruit the top of jam cans into frames.

The finishing touch of oil painting, the gold bronze and silver aluminum, all has been worked by the girls of Grade 4 and 5. None of the girls knew the difference between oil paint and water colour. It took quite a long time to convince them that oil paint on fingers or on clothes doesn't go off as easily as water colour.

The effect and nature of turpentine had been explained and in spite of it all one day a girl forgot with a good intention most probably. She put her two hands down in the oil can to take the hard crust formed on the top. Lifting it up to show her companions how smart she was, When Sister Marcoux happened to come in she immediately asked her to go and wash her hands, saying that she wanted to start right away. Sister took the occasion to teach her in the most effective way this time that oil paint cannot be washed away by water. Many a time she had heard it before, but never was the lesson so well understood and remembered.

The other girls understood it was a trick on Pauline and waited anxiously ten minutes for her reappearance. At last she comes. She acknowledged that when alone in the "cubby room", she recalled that water cannot take away oil paint.
The badge system has stimulated many a girl to graduate in the three year course of the Indian Affairs branch. A very great improvement has been made to facilitate this course. It is the combination of the two sewing rooms. We have a peel manufacturing department now with its different sections. In fact, every girl passes from one place to another quite automatically, from sewing, mending, ironing, pressing, buttonholing, dyeing, carding, spinning, knitting, weaving, beadwork and embroidery.

To mention only a few names, Bernice Jasnomie excelled in sewing. She sewed 35 coats in a month. Father Principal took the occasion to prove to us girls how he appreciates the work we do by giving her a sum of money. Mary Docta is preparing herself to be an excellent seamstress. She has tested her work is well finished, and she seems to have a little speeding motor in her hands. Beatrice Bear is still quite small, but she feels big when Sister chooses her to repair a tear on a very fine garment. The art of mending has penetrated through her fingers quite young. Dorothy Lamont seems to have a strong taste for embroidery, cut-work, and tries to beat everybody in sewing. Irene Nokwisi and Caroline Peigan decided not to be surpassed. Buttonholing has been in style this year on account of the hundreds of snow-suits, coat-suits, and pants that have been re-modelled from Army and Air Force clothing. Sixty snow-suits for the medium-sized girls have been made by the big girls, thirty-five for the small girls, and forty-five pants for the boys. How many buttonholes did we make? I don't know. It's too much to count them. One sure thing about it we made some. You can ask almost any girl to make a buttonhole now.
The knitting machine has been oiled many a time this year. If we recall well, 91 pairs of stockings for boys were made, 36 pairs for the small girls, 60 pairs for the medium-sized girls; Gracie Lavallee, Florence Rockthunder, Ruby Desjarlais and Gladys Habbitskin to mention the best, have shown great skill on the machine. Another improvement worthy of being mentioned is the new electric mending machine which Father Dion bought at the beginning of the year to spare the girls in mending. What a wonderful invention! Rose-Mary Tuckanow is not afraid of "electricity" nor of big holes in garments. She can master both in the wink of an eye. Many other girls passed through this section with success. To mention a few: Ruby Desjarlais, Florence Rockthunder and Gracie Lavallee.

Weaving has also attracted the girls with great enthusiasm. Mary Doota can teach to younger ones, she can give demonstrations to the public, entertain visitors, and so forth. Young girls of Grade 4 had a start in weaving this year with a little loom they had in the classroom; Pearl Deegan is promising for the future.

COOKING -- Since cooking is of outstanding importance to maintain a happy tune, Sister Neumier took as her motto to teach the girls everything that she knows. Every girl from the age of twelve makes two or three stages in the kitchen during the year. "There is no place like the kitchen for me" is the big girls' motto.

It will be with a feeling of pride that we will cook to help our mother during the summer vacation. We learnt how to make appetizing dishes from what is left over from one meal, for instance, apple and orange peelings can make good marmalade, hard crust can make good bread soup, etc.

Old cow meat will always be tough meat, won't it? We happened to know that by Gracie Yusicapi's experience. One day when coming from the kitchen after having cooked steak a long time, she met a sister who told her how hard she had found the steak. She asked Gracie who had cooked the meat. Gracie humbly answered "the stove", but it might have been an old cow, Sister, and old cow is always tough meat.

In spite of all the dishes we broke, and the food we burnt, nevertheless we learnt something. No doubt about that since several girls obtained their badges in cooking year. Many thanks to our kind Sister Neumier.

DAIRYING - Mr. Joseph Muloin, the school herdsman, was again in charge of the cattle this year. Under his direction the boys began milking in November, and they have milked between seventeen and twenty-five cows till the middle of May. They were in this way a great help to Mr. Muloin. There are about three hundred laying hens in the chicken coop, besides two hundred pullets. Throughout the year two boys went twice a day to feed the chickens, clean the coop, and gather the eggs. Many boys thus won a badge in poultrying.
GARDENING - This year the garden has been greatly reduced in size. The part behind the barn has now become part of the large potato field. The Senior Boys with their teacher have taken charge of the garden. The baseball team has taken over the care of the lawns and trees of the school grounds.

CARPENTRY - Mr. Joe Desjarlais is our instructor in carpentry. This work is done in the school shop, one day a week, in groups of eight or ten. In the past much time was given to the building of small wooden articles, such as stools, cupboards, toolboxes, and so on. This year most of the work is done with the school carpenter. There are always rooms or buildings to remodel, repairs to be done, furniture to build. In this way the work done by the boys is valuable both to them and to the school. Among the outstanding pieces built this year are three beautiful oak altars, built by George Lavallee. They will soon replace the altars now in use in the chapel.

FARMING - The school farm is under the management of Mr. William Lecree. The boys work on the farm at the different jobs that each season offers, such as sowing, haying, harvesting. The boys of Grades VII and VIII are also learning tractor operation.

**OUR OTHER SPORTS**

*Football.* - This game is played mostly in the fall before the snow comes. Sometimes we put the 15 biggest boys on one side and the rest on the other. It's quite a tough game, and the big boys usually win. In rugby we usually pick up teams, and it is played rather rough, but we have a lot of fun chasing each other for the ball.

*Swimming.* - We had our first swim on May 28th. The water was quite cold, but we wanted to swim badly. We enjoyed ourselves for about 15 minutes, and made sure that everyone had had a dip. We go swimming almost every day now.

*Boxing.* - We started boxing this winter, and we already have seen some great matches. The ones we prefer in the ring are Wilfrid Payant and Clarence Anckun. We have now six pairs of gloves, and we have great fun watching the small boys' bouts.

*Hunting.* - In the fall and in early spring rabbit hunting is our favorite pastime. We go out with our supervisor or teachers. In one afternoon with the Brothers of the Scholasticato we killed 14 rabbits. The Brothers had rifles and were giving us a chance to shoot. We had a lot of fun chasing the rabbits from bush to bush.

*Fishing.* - In early spring as soon as the ice is gone the fishing season begins. Perch are more common, and once in a while a boy happens to catch a jackfish. The boys are always losing hooks and have to buy new ones. We now fish every day since the perch have started to bite.

*Clubhouse.* - On winter evenings and wet days the bigger boys go to the clubhouse to play pool. We have two tables in excellent condition. Sexton and Nigger are our favorite games.

*Field Days.* - A field day was held at Fort Qu'Appelle on June 3rd, in which all the schools of the district competed. The "Great Priest" visits the Cowichans

The year was 1855. Bishop Demers had been three years in his Victoria Diocese and he was eager to pay a visit to his dear friends, the Indians of the East Coast of Vancouver Island. In 1842 when he had visited the Salish tribes along the Lower Fraser River he had met some of the Cowichans from the Island. Those had brought the message of the Black Church to their people. In 1843 some of them had been at Fort Victoria when Father Bolduc offered Holy Mass for the first time at that point. In 1850 Father Lemfrit had come among them and baptized many and taught them to pray to God. In 1852 another priest was assigned to them and now, in 1855, the "Great Priest" as they called their bishop came to visit them.

The best hut in the village was prepared for their guest. Crushed oyster and clam shells were scattered around. A huge pile of blankets was prepared as a seat of honor. The Indians brought the Bishop and two priests from Victoria by canoe. As they rounded the headland and entered Cowichan Bay they fired a musket to tell the waiting tribesmen of their approach. When the canoe was at last swung with a flourish in to the beach, a long line of Indians, men, women and children stretched from the village to the water's edge to give welcome to the Bishop and to shake his hand.

At length, seated on his throne with his Indian children about him, Bishop Demers answered many questions: Where had he been in the years since they had seen him at Langley? How many people had he visited? The Bishop answered their question; he told them of his visit to Rome where he had seen the Great White Father. He told them that he had spoken to the Great Chief about his Christians of Vancouver Island and that he had brought to them his blessing. At these words the crowd of Indians knelt and with foreheads on the ground, received the blessing sent them from on High.

Are we proud of our altar boy!! I'll say we are. They certainly carried off the ceremonies of Holy Week in grand style and turned out 100% for each service. It took lots of practice and playtime, but it was worth it. Keep up the grand work boys!!

Sunday or Monday he's up with the lark,
Be it raining or fine, daylight or dark;
No matter how early you're at the church door,
You'll find this young altar boy there long before.

His manner is charming, he's merry and bright,
And keeps to the letter the rules of the Knight;
They say that at school he's the best in his class
And none can excel him to serve Holy Mass.

His surplice is spotless, his soutane is neat;
He's polished and groomed from the head to the feet;
He does nothing with the greatest of care,

The reason we learned from other small boys.
They said it was true, or they heard so at least,
That he'd gone into college to become a priest.

Then ten golden years seemed winged to pass,
A young priest is robed on the altar for Mass,
His features are beaming with heavenly joy,
And there once again is our once altar boy!

DEAR READERS:

How about coming to see our sewing room? You'll be very surprised to see what the girls have been doing.

Do come and see our dresses, skirts, blouses, pyjamas, jackets and jumpers. We sew them on the machine. There are three machines in the sewing room.

We have some other things to do too. Sometimes we work in wool, and we knit stockings and sweaters. We have two carding machines, two small spinning machines and one large one. We have two big tables and three big benches in the sewing room, all made by the boys in their shop.

We go to the sewing room at 10:30 in the morning and stay till noon.

We can get a lot in that time if we want to. Sometimes we listen to the radio when we are working in the sewing class. There is a statue of St. Rita standing right on top of the piano. It is very pretty.

There is an amount of different material in the press. There is also thread to match.

An ironing board stand is close to the door. We are proud to have two electric irons, and also two little stands where many books and little boxes may be put. There is a big press where we keep our dresses. The boys make the presses and the ironing boards too. There are two blackboards on each side of the room, and a thunder bird, made by Alec James, is on top of the blackboards.

We are hoping that pretty soon the boys will make cupboards for the girls to keep the articles that they are working in, as our boxes are a little too small and our work gets crushed. What do you say, boys?

We are very proud of St. Catherine's School, so how about coming to see our sewing room? We'll be glad to show you around any time you care to stroll along.

Mary Underwood.

We go to the sewing room at 10:30 a.m., while the Junior and Primary classes go out for recess for fifteen minutes.

In the sewing room I am making a blue pullover sweater and I'm still hoping to finish it soon. After I finish the sweater I will try to make a skirt to match the sweater and a blouse to go with the skirt. When I get
them all finished I will buy them for myself and wear them for school. Maybe it will be too small for me. Then it will fit my sister. Maybe when my sister starts sewing, she will make something for herself.

Many of the girls have made lots of things and bought them for themselves, and some of them are wearing the things that they have made since they started school. Other girls make small clothes for their sisters or brothers, and the parents buy them, as they are finished.

Sarah Ryan.

Every day -- Monday to Friday -- we go to the sewing room to learn how to knit. After we know how to knit, we practice using the sewing machines. Then we start making dresses. We make dresses for ourselves, sometimes for our little sisters. We choose the kind of material we want, and when we get stuck we have to call on our teacher and ask her what to do next. I have made three dresses for myself and a blouse and a skirt for my little sister. Now I am making a pair of pyjamas. They are just about finished.

I am going to make a dress next. In the summer I go to the States and pick strawberries and hops and when I come home I have lots of money. THE NEW FURNACE

Holidays generally make us happy but not this time. When we received the news that our old furnace had broken down and that school would be closed for about three weeks we all felt sorry because we are trying hard to get to High School, and three weeks is a long time to stay out of school. Sister told us to pray that something would happen so we could carry on our classes. Sister Superior of St. Ann's was kind enough to let us use one of the rooms downstairs so grade six, seven and eight went to school at St. Ann's.

Once we got settled, we started working hard. We did our science experiments on air, and as the boys of St. Ann's had not done these experiments yet, Sister took both schools together. We found these experiments very interesting.

Reverend Father LeClair goes to St. Ann's twice a week to teach Catechism, so we attended these classes and liked it.

One thing we missed from our school was the six big blackboards, because we had only one little board, which was painted black, 4' x 4'.

At our school we have no reference books, so Sister took the opportunity to teach us research work while we were at St. Ann's. We borrowed the World Book and the books of Knowledge, and each looked up the work of a different scientist and also work on one industry. At first we did not like it, but when we learned how to look up things, we began to be interested in research work.

Louise Underwood.

We have a piano in our school. So every Friday afternoon we go into the sewing room because that is where the piano is kept. We learn to sing many nice hymns and songs.

OUR SCHOOL

Our school is a very fine one. Inside we have four large rooms, three classrooms and one sewing room, where the senior girls learn how to sew, knit and make dresses.

I am in the Junior room. There are 43 boys and girls in our room. Our boards have pretty pictures all around. There are six big lights which we use so it is dark during the winter. There are five big windows in our room too, and blackboards in the back and front and along one side of the wall.

Downstairs where we eat our lunch and play when it is too wet outside, we have many games. I like to play Jacks best. We also have a big play yard with ten swings. The senior and junior classes play baseball most of the time. Father often comes and plays football with the boys. They are lucky!
