Sister tells the children to bring bags and get what they want out of
the bins to take home, so that they will not go to waste.

Josephine Bartleman

EXHIBITIONS.

On Pentecost Sunday, May 20, 1945, we had an exhibition of our
year's work in the classrooms of St. Catherine's School.

After Mass the school was open for the friends and parents of the
pupils. In the afternoon it was open to the public. There were about
a hundred white people who came, interested in seeing the work of the
Indian children.

All the classrooms were very attractive. Half way down the black-
boards were samples of the pupils' work of the year - Spelling, Arith-
metic, Grammar, Language, Social Studies, Letters, etc. These were
made into booklets, which were strung across the blackboards on a string.
There were also booklets on Transportation, Geography and History and
our Mass and Sacrament books in Catechism. Under the blackboards we
had Agriculture, Physical, Product and Manufacturing maps of Canada.
Other projects that helped to decorate the room were "Protect our
Forests" and "Our Health Project".

All the sewing, knitting and embroidery was displayed in the sew-
ing room. In the manual training room all the boys' woodwork was dis-
played.

We are having a busy time this year getting ready for the big Can-
adian Exhibition at Victoria. We are also preparing work for the
Indian Art Exhibit at the Provincial Museum at Victoria. So you see
we are very busy and important people.

Rona Williams.
OUR KITCHEN

Our kitchen surely had been topsy-turvy for three years because Mr. Morrison, the woodwork teacher, could only work in his spare time, making our cupboards. He completed them on May 31st, 1945. That day was a happy one for the Sisters and the girls. Would you like to see it? Well here is a drawing.

The cupboard extends from one end of the kitchen to the other. It is 19½ feet in length, and is built right up to the ceiling. It is a deep cream in color and decorated with black. The knobs and butterfly hinges are black and make a very pretty decoration. The press is divided into three sections as you can see from our sketch. In the first section is kept all the dishes for the children—cups, bowls, plates, etc. Spoons, knives, and forks are kept in the drawers. In the lower part of the first section are the cocoa pots, pans, and other heavy utensils. In the second section there is nothing as yet. In the third part is kept all the cooking utensils. It is always tidy. In the lower section are large tins pasted cream to match our cupboards. Printed in black letters are the contents of each tin—sugar, cocoa, flour, etc.

Our kitchen can accommodate sixteen pupils. We now have four cooking tables and sixteen stools. This year we received only part of the cooking equipment, but are hoping that next year we will get the remainder, and then the cooking class will be in full swing.

The girls, under the direction of our sewing teacher, made aprons and caps. On the caps are embroidered in green silk the initials J. C. S. They look very nice.

The only thing that mars the beauty in our kitchen now is the floor. It is all cement. Besides it has large cracks all over. In the winter-time it is very cold to work on. We are hoping that we will get wooden floors like the manual training room before very long. Ramona Underwood.

NEW MISSIONARY

Father Stone is our new missionary priest. He took Father Seguin's place. Father has taken charge of our football team. The first thing Father Stone did was to get us sport outfits. Father bought some material and Sister cut out the shorts. Some of the boys' mothers made the shorts. Mr. Morrison designed a thunderbird for our crest. Father Stone made the crests out of green felt and painted the white lines, then Sister sewed them on the sweaters. We have the initials S. C. S. in the centre of the crest. The S. C. S. stands for St. Catherine's School. The sweaters have numbers on the back. Our sweaters are black and our shorts are blue.

We have won six football games and lost two. The first time we played at St. Ann's School and we won three to nothing. The second game was at Kuper School, again we won, two to nothing. The third game was at St. Ann's School, the score four-one, our favor. The fourth time, we went to Kuper, we won again two to one. The fifth game we played at St. Ann's, the score was three-one, our favor. The sixth game, the Kuper boys came to Duncan, the score was nothing-nothing. The three last games were in Kuper. We lost twice, won once, one to nothing.

We are now working up a softball team. WHO WANTS TO PLAY AGAINST US???

Dennis Alphonse.

GIRLS' SPORTS.

Last year the St. Catherine's girls' team were invited over to Kuper Island to play against the girls there. We left Duncan on the noon train on Saturday. When we got to the wharf in Chemainus, a gas boat was waiting for us to take us to Kuper. We stayed there one night. Sister Superior and the girls were very busy making room for us to sleep. Some of the girls slept together to give us enough beds. On Sunday we had a great time. We played the Kuper team. The score was 40-41. St. Catherine's won. The boys wanted to play against the St. Catherine's girls too. They sure licked us.

We expect to play with the Kuper girls in Duncan this year. We hope we can, and we hope we win again too, but if we don't we will be good sports.
In winter time the children play with Chinese checkers, and checkers. Jacks have died out this year.

With the nice weather we are starting to play out doors now. Some children play with skipping ropes, others play softball. We have four different places in the school yard where four different sets of children are playing softball. It is very exciting. The children look like a lot of flies buzzing around the playground.

M. Rose Charlie

WATER SPORTS.

Every summer the Indians have water sports at Cowichan Bay. People come from all over the Island to see our water sports. There are war canoe races. There are eleven men in each canoe. The race is about two miles long. Last year one canoe named "O Boy" sank. Watson Jimmy and Ernie Henry were in it. It was too small for the two of them. It is very exciting to watch these races. The name of the winner was "SHADOW" from Kuper Island. They have won for two years.

The barrel sweep is very interesting too. The tickets are sold at nearly all the stores in Duncan for over months. They are 25¢ each. The money is put together for prizes. A barrel is floated from Cowichan Lake to the White Bridge in Duncan. Fred Thomas and Henry Williams follow the barrel until it gets to the White Bridge. They keep track of the time it takes. There are three prizes given. The one who guesses the nearest time gets $100, the second $50 and the third $25.

Last year it took 13 hours, 20 minutes and 15 seconds. One year it took only 9 hours. The river is very high this year too.

Roy George.

DEBATES

On March 14th all the pupils of Grades 6 - 8 attended a debate in St. Edward's Parish Hall. It was between the C. Y. O. of Nanaimo and Duncan-Chemainus. The topic was "France has done more harm for Spain than good." Both sides were very good. The Nanaimo team won.

We noticed many things because Sister had told us to watch the posture of the debaters, how they spoke out and the grammar and language they used. We have been very interested in debates since we had the opportunity of attending one at St. Ann's Boys' School. We went to this debate to learn more. I noticed that the debaters were not at all nervous but as calm as could be.

Now we have a better idea how debates are carried on. We hope to have one sometimes before school closes. Right now we are working on Oral Reports. Each pupil is writing about one of the scientists he has studied. I am studying about Joseph Wedgewood.

Ramona Underwood.

WE MEET IN NEW YORK

Just about this time last year Sister Larry Eugenia received the good news that she was going to New York to see her people during the summer holidays. She began gathering some little things for souvenirs to take along with her. The boys and girls had a surprise for Sister. They also wrote letters to her to be at New York when she arrived there. While the children were writing the letters Sister kept coming in and out of their room, and they had to keep on hiding the letters until she went out again.

She had a big surprise when she found that the senior boys and girls were at New York to greet her by letters. When Sister came back she told us all about the wonderful time she had with her people, and we were glad.

GOSSIP TOWN

"Have you ever heard of Gossip Town,
On the shore of Falsehood Bay,
Where old Dame Rumor, with rustling gown,
Is going the livelong day?
It isn't far to Gossip Town,
For people who want to go;
The "idleness train" will take you down,
In just an hour or so.

The "Thoughtless" road is a popular route
And most folks start that way,
By its steep down grade; if you don't look out,
You'll land on Falsehood Bay.
You glide through the valley of "Vicious Folk",
And into the tunnel of "Hate";
Then crossing the "Add-to-Bridge" you walk,
Right into the city gate.

The principal street is called "They Say",
And "I've Heard" is a public "well";
And the breezes that blow from Falsehood Bay
Are laden with "Don't You-Tell".
In the midst of the town is "Tell-Tale Park",
You're never quite safe while there.
For its owner is Madam "Suspicious Remark",
Who lives on the Street "Don't Care".

Just back of the park is "Slander's Row",
'Twas there that "Good Name" died,
Pierced with a dart from "Jealousy's bow".
In the hands of "Envious Pride",
From Gossip Town peace long since has fled.
But "Scrubbed Grief and Woe"
And sorrow and care you'll meet instead.
If ever you chance to go.

China."

There are still a few "one Star Rangers." These wild men combine rugby technique with basketball. The rule says, "If the dribbler's path is blocked, he is expected to pass or shoot, that is, he ought not to try and dribble by an opponent unless there is a reasonable chance of getting by without contact." Then there are the dreamers who take anywhere from 8 to 15 seconds to throw the ball in when it goes out of bounds. The rule allows 5 seconds. THE LAUNDRY DEPARTMENT

The three laundry men were in serious discussion. A former friend, Jerome Pheasant, sent them a book he had written during his idle moments in the laundry, "how to answer customers and win friends." Alphonse Shawana decided to follow the advice of such an experienced man. Alec Trudeau agreed with the torn shirt. "Do you expect me to wear this shirt?" "It will ruffled every man to his own taste." "But the shirt is torn." Alphonse smiled as the instructions advised, "My dear Alexander, afflictions are blessings in disguise." Alec, ruffled, shouted, "There are no buttons on the shirt." "Ah," said Alphonse, "Absence makes the heart grow fonder." Joe Conner then put his upstairs with a coat in his hands. "I can't fit this coat on, it's too small." The novice laundryman smiled again, "My dear Joseph, you never know what you can do, till you try." Joe sighed, "At least give me a cap. That red ski cap will fit me." Alphonse remembered the underlined words on page 9 of the book: "A soft answer turns away anger." He found this advice for Joe, by Joseph. Later in the morning J. Fox and R. Jacobs went to take the laundry to the convent. One of the bags was extremely heavy. Opening it they discovered Alphonse with a shirt and coat around his neck.

SCHOOL NEWS

A WEEKLY NEWSLETTER FOR THE CLEAPSAUKEE AND OKEMHA RESERVES

October 26

This week's news concerns the Senior School. When Col. Early was here two weeks ago, he instructed us to "get started" and named November 1st as a starting date. At that time it was expected that at least one bus would be ready, and other preparations complete. There has been some delay in Ottawa in clearing the sale of the bus, so that no permission has been given to remodel it. It may be ready by next Friday, and it may not. Our second teacher will scarcely be here, although there have been some replies to our Ad., and it should be possible to have her here in the near future. The classrooms have been cleaned, so the building can be ready. Mr. Floyd Johnston has been engaged as one teacher, for both Manual Training and classroom work.

It all adds up to this, we intend to start on Nov. 1st, even though it is a Friday, and with one teacher besides the Principal. This means that we can take only Grades 7 to 10 at present. It is a matter of the greatest concern to us that these senior pupils have missed so much of this year's work, especially since so many are keenly interested and anxious to get started. It seems to your Principal that no obstacle should prevent us from starting in next Friday, and I believe that our young people are interested enough and made of the stuff which will get them here, even if the bus system is not ready. Certainly some can get here without a bus, and for those at least, we ought to open school and let them get started. It is still possible that some means will be found of providing transportation for those who are some distance from the School; every effort will be made to secure this. I expect to be in touch with most of those concerned between now and Friday, but it may be necessary to issue a News Letter on Thursday with instructions.

Let me stress the importance of ALL those wishing to take Grade 7, 8, 9, or 10 work along with as much practical work as can be provided, to come on Friday, Nov. 1st, at least, to enroll, so that we can know what to expect and what to provide for. Unless I am badly mistaken about you, you will find some way to get here. For four months I have been working to convince the authorities that we need a Senior School this year. The number who come will give the final answer. THERE ARE 43 who have expressed their wish to take work in these four grades, and who are eligible. How many of you will be here on Friday?

M.M. Joblin.
Hockey is in the air but basketball still is the game of the season. But about a personal foul when both players are running for a loose ball or a pass? "The ball is free. Two opponents start quickly for the ball and collide. The personal contact may be serious but no foul is committed if both were in a favorable position when they started. However if one player is about to catch a ball and an opponent behind him jumps into his path the player behind is irresponsible for the foul because he was not in a favorable position to get the ball."

S.P.C. League - The last few games have been much faster because dribbling has been almost eliminated. The Red Wing Seniors are proving unbeatable although not a strong team on paper they play tough and fast and take advantage of every loose ball. Accurate passing and team-play could bring the Canadians to the fore, but alas....

The Intermediates have yet to learn a fundamental rule of good basketball - "A player only dribbles when he is not able to advance the ball by passing." There is a rumor that they are going to learn this fundamental rule.

Convent Basketball League - On Saturday afternoons when the boys are in class the Sunbeams, Flashers, Lightnings and Mercuries, from the Girls' School, take over the basketball court. This style of playing has improved a hundred percent. The little Intermediate team in red has the best passing combination yet seen on the floor.

SHOE SHOP DEPARTMENT

Well now, you would think that the Laundry Department has all the clever boys in the school. Just the other day Mr. Raymond Pitawanakut had a brilliant idea the other day. ("It's a very good idea," he said.) When he repaired the small boys' shoes he left nails inside each shoe. He claims that they will not be able to walk or run very far and therefore will save shoe leather. James Venigwans can sew with his eyes closed. Yesterday he sewed both sides of a shoe together or rather he sewed the shoe together using rubber bands. He still persists in keeping the bladder inside the cover when he patches.... Paul Pitawanakut and Alce Trudeau are very forgetful. It takes them half the morning to decide whether they should be baking bread, repairing shoes or carrying ashes. They spend the rest of the morning explaining what they would have done if they had been in the right place, why the place they were was not the right place but the wrong, and why they were wrong because they were not right. Alphonse Trudeau has the important task of placing the left soles on the right shoes.

Movies - The educational films are not as exciting as the cowboy movies; however they are very instructive. Teddy Bears, Three Little Kittens, Children of China, Eskimo Life, Making the Grade were very enjoyable. Brother Westaway had to keep a close guard over the kitchen dishes during the showing of "Run in the Dark." In this thrilling Western the hero and heroine defeated the bandits by throwing dishes at them. Perhaps that explains the broken milk pitcher and saucers in the kitchen. Did Augustine and Stuart rout Robby Drybutch and Peter Deere?

Grade Nine thumbed pages, frowned and concentrated on Friday evening. On Saturday Nov. 23 they wrote the final exam in Art Studios. After the extra studying there were some very brilliant answers. Dominic McCosher describing the Sudan wrote: "There is plenty of grazing land, plenty of negroes and a great deal of heather." (We know that the Sudanese play the bagpipes but never heard they grow heather.) Harold Bilboe very crudely wrote about Cornwall as a great battle between the English and the French. (Forgot the body?) ... William Pitt was the superman of his age for according to David Jocko he fought in England and America at the same time. Grade Seven wore a harassed and frightened look. They rush up to study as soon as the doors open. "What is the reason?" Simon Kitching Ting always gets it snelling right. Has he been receiving extra help? SCHOOL NEWS

A WEEKLY NEWS BULLETIN FOR THE CHIPPEWA, HURON AND ONTARIO RESERVES

December 14

"There is no royal road to learning." Some of our students have rediscovered the truth of this old saying, by the help of the inevitable tests and examinations at the end of a term. Some have apparently thought that it would suffice to submit themselves to the atmosphere of the school, and by some magic they would be able to reproduce what they have heard. Some are capable of a large amount of physical activity with a minimum of mental activity, and little control, so that they resemble an army tank out of control. Some seem to be strangers to activity in any form. For not a few, the test results have been like a dash of cold water which has brought an awareness of their position and their need for some real mental activity. Learning does not take place by a mere passive acceptance of the spoken word, but requires the purposeful activity of the learner, while the good teacher can do much to secure this effort; there is a limit beyond which he cannot go, when the results depend upon the pupil.

Other pupils have done conscientious work. We are proud of them whether they have obtained a good mark or not. Their work must be judged by their capacity and opportunity rather than by some other pupil.

It is probable that some examinations will be held over until after the holidays, because of the lateness in starting. This may mean that we shall be unable to provide reports now. In the new year, the Department intends to provide a uniform report card for use in our schools. These will be issued at regular intervals to the parents.

The Concert will mark the end of the term, since the pupils are expected to be present and take their parts. We hope that their parents and friends will be able to attend, and that they will help us make it memorable, this for our pupils. The girls and boys have decided to have an exchange of gifts, but this will not make a very well dressed tree by itself. The school is not planning to give gifts other than these. The whole venture is a student activity; they may find some way to use some of their proceeds for a well-earned treat, if your support is large enough.

No more News Letter until January 4. The Staff of the Mt. Elgin School and of the other Day Schools join in wishing all of you a very joyous Christmas and a Happy New Year.

H.M.H. Joblin.

ANGELS SINGING?

"Oh, Come All Ye Faithful".... Angels singing? We jump up in bed, wide awake. No, Father put on the electric phonograph to listen to us for the Midnight Mass. After Mass, we went down to have lunch. We had cocoa and coffee bread. After lunch we had a nice sleep. —Cortie Amos

CHRISTMAS AT CHRISTIE

On Christmas Eve at midnight, we went to the chapel where we had High Mass followed by the Low Masses. We sang very well that night. Baby Jesus was there in the little crib.

After that we went to get our lunch and then went to bed again, but I did not sleep until in the morning.

About 10 o'clock we went to the Girls' gym where we got our Christmas presents. First the little boys and girls danced for some visitors. Then all of us sang the song, "White Christmas." After that Father Mulvihill gave us our treats, candy, and cracker jack.

The children who live near by went home to spend the rest of the day with their families. Those of us left visited our brothers and sisters in the afternoon.

Around two o'clock the boys came, bringing our Christmas mail and show. Supper was early, because the show was long.

As soon as the work was finished after supper, we had Jimmy Mulvihill's show "Foot of the Alamo," and "Junior Prom." Thus ended a happy and holy day for us.—Johnnie George

A few weeks ago there was a rumour that a tall man, wearing a long coat, was prowling around one of the nearby villages, frightening people. This did not bother us until one evening a member of the staff told us girls that Gobol had seen what he thought was the same man outside near the carpenter shop. He had long yellow fangs and bush hair and ran off through the bushes.

Another staff member came along and tried to tell us ghost stories for about half an hour. We did not want to believe the story about the wild man, but we heard so many spine-chilling reasons why it could be so that we were really scared and did not want to admit it or show that we were frightened...but even a door slamming made us jump.

After we went to bed, many of us lost half a night's sleep thinking of ghosts. I had just dropped off to sleep when I thought I heard a scream. I was certain that the man in the long coat was here at last. Dad had always told me there was no such thing as ghosts, but for a moment I doubted him.

However, we had our revenge for those ghost stories. The same night the staff member who frightened us was coming up from the beach and ran into a snow man he had made and dressed up; so I imagine he was just as frightened as we were.—Anna Joe

One of the staff members overheard two of the little boys, Simon John and Freddie Ginor, talking. They were trying to see who could spell the most words.

On Feb. 26 the Junior team traveled to Sudbury to play Sudbury Imperial Juniors (21 years and under). Sudbury reinforced their team with three players from the Copper Cliff Wolves (Intermediate O.R.A.). A packed Cassoy Arena cheered our boys and boosted Sudbury because we feared hopelessly outnumbered. The fans enjoyed sixty minutes of fast, clean hockey. The speed of the Imperials carried them to a 4-1 lead at the end of the first period. S.F.C. fought hard and managed to hold their opponents to a 1-1 result at the end of the second stanza.

The third period opened up with a furious rush by our boys. Our smooth passing first found a weak spot in Sudbury defense. Short passes from Maxie to Frank and then over the boards resulted in four quick goals. Clever playing by our defense kept the puck in the Sudbury territory practically all the third period. Our opponents were checked at their own blue line and could not utilize their speed. A breakaway by Terrimont (Copper Cliff Wolves) ended in a goal. S.F.C. surged up once more around the Sudbury goal and crossed the score. Spectators were by this time shouting and yelling so much that the old Arena seemed to be shaking. The Imperials threw on their best line to break the deadlock and again went attacking. The fans begged and pleaded with S.F.C. to get a goal. We found the corner of the Sudbury net and made the score 6-0. The period ended with S.F.C. swarming around the Sudbury net trying to get the winning goal. Cassoy fans claimed that it was the best game seen in years. The two greatest displays of hockey of the game were the valiant rally in the third period when S.F.C. outlasted and outplayed the Imperial rink, and the clean, gentlemanly conduct of the Sudbury players. Sudbury was actually pleased that we had held them to a tie.

DEATH

"THAT THIS SIGN SHALL THOU CONQUER"

Christ preached a new doctrine and by his life proved it; that suffering and sorrow are not the curse of man but his privilege; that he who would do the greatest things is he who can endure the greatest that only by suffering and sorrow can the evil of life be overcome. Human nature deserves worth by suffering and judges a man's bravery by his endurance of sorrow. Christ has taken this truest trait in man and united it to Himself; has perfected and purified it, and His is given back to man as His highest ideal — fortitude and courage in the face of trial and temptation to sin.

At the invitation of the Mayor and Councillors of Somerville, your Editor was present at a recent meeting at which the discussion of the proper administration of the Town was the main topic. The following rules were made, approved, and voted to the satisfaction of all, to be LAW.

1. No person is to go out on the fire escape unless by order of our Chief Advisor Miss Moore.
2. Throwing paper on the floor is an offence, also throwing paper in the sand pails.
3. Do not write on the walls and bulletin board.
4. Leaving classroom unnecessarily is forbidden.
5. Reading funnies in the classroom is forbidden.
6. Hanging out windows - punishment, loss of 3 marks.
7. Coming back to class late - loss of 2 marks.
8. Careless use of Bibles - loss of 5 marks.
9. Going up to the attic - sweep floors.
10. Going in room behind blackboard - scrub desks.
11. Writing on desks - clean windows.
12. Spilling ink accidentally - wipe it up right away.
13. No notes to be written - if found to be read out in class.
14. No spitting, use kleenex after using throw in wastebasket.
15. Do not put pencil or pencil lead in your mouth.
16. Keep hands and fingernails clean, do not write in ink or pencil on your hands.
17. Stay outside as much as possible in the fresh air after and before class.

These suggestions were brought forward by the Mayor, Councillors, Judge, and Doctor - and are to be enforced by Policeman David Scoow, and Policewoman Dorcas Darson.

The Story of Easter

People will say that Easter is late this year. Unlike Christmas it does not fall on any particular day, but is governed by the moon.

Easter is always on the first Sunday following the full moon after March 21st. The earliest day that Easter can fall is March 21st and the latest April 25th. If you will look at your calendar you will find that the moon will be full on April 5th so that April 6th will be Easter Sunday.

April is one of the best months of the year, because the earth which has been bound up with winter frosts, starts to release all the lovely flowers we love to see, which have been buried under the hard ground all winter, which now come up in spite of frosts or snow, bringing forth promise of the glorious feast of colour. Who does not look forward to the Spring?

It is believed that April's name is derived from the Latin word "aprilis" which means to open. April is also sacred to Venus, the Roman goddess of beauty, named Aphrilla by the Greeks.

The early English name for April was Easter month, for it was sacred to Easter or Ostara the goddess of Spring. Although Easter is now a great Christian Festival, it was once Pagan, and some of the customs which still survive, such as the gift of eggs, date back to those by-gone days.

- Mr. Gifford

January 1947

Another year has gone by and your children are going back to school. I am glad that they are doing well in good health, (while I am extremely sorry for those of you whose children will pass the holidays in the hospital) and I am satisfied that they have not lost their time here in school.

If you expect a very big change in your children and very much learning after one year of schooling, you may be disappointed. Just as a child grows very little at a time, so his mind and knowledge can be developed but little at a time, and no one should expect too much after even a few years of school.

To achieve in your children what you expect of them and what we would like them to have, we need your children for many years and this means three things:

1- That they should come to school as soon as possible when they are 7 years old, and not wait until they are 10, 12 or 14;

2- That once a child has started school, he should not be kept away from it for any reason. A child who comes to school one year and then stays home one year is hardly more advanced when he comes back the third year than when he started;

3- That they should be left at school old enough to complete their studies; it is unfair for your children to sell them back home before they are 18 years old; their last years of schooling are the ones that show the most definite results.

Yes, dear parents, it means sacrifices for you to part from your children 10 months in one year for such a long time, but since you do it for the sake of your children's future, I ask you to be generous enough not to stop your children's development in full growth by withdrawing them from school when it is not time yet.

In shall, in return, ask you to make the school staff do our very best to make you proud of the progress of your children and the children themselves shall be happy about their own achievements while they enjoy the school atmosphere.

Yours,

[Signature]

The Hobbema Indians are leading the white men this time, in this respect, they have just installed a large seed grain cleaning plant, using the same kind of machines that are being used in the government Grain Elevator in Calgary.

The Hart Emerson Uniflow Cleaner has a capacity of 250 bushels per hour and the Emerson Wild Oat Cleaner has a capacity of 100 bushels per hour, and can clean any wheat, oats or barley up to certified seed standard, after the grain is cleaned it is automatically weighted and put through a Kemp Ceresan Treater ready for the seed drill.

The Indians purchased these machines and the lumber for the building from their Band Funds, the building was designed by T. G. McLeod, also, the hoppers and spouts, the installation of the equipment and machines was a real problem as there was nothing in the country of this description and had to be a special design which Mr. McLeod had to figure out.

This machine is also to be used at harvest time to clean mixed grain, and to save the good feed that is a present being lost to every one as dockage, there is a possibility that the feed saved will more than pay back the money invested in the building and equipment in two seasons.

There is a great need in every farming community for a cleaning plant of this kind. It would not only save the farmers thousands of dollars in feed and would also cut their freight bills. Clean seed every year would be a stride toward cleaning up the Noxious weed problem that we all have today.

Mr. McLeod has provided a real service and essential feature on the reserve on which he is farm demonstrator.

The office of Welfare Officer for the Rehabilitation Council, which has been open three days a week for the past 15 months in the Civic Building is closed. This office has been conducted by the late W.J. Burroughs and latterly by Alderman J. Gillespie. During the time office was open over 350 veterans were assisted in many ways; many hundreds of trips to Edmonton were avoided.

The Hotbema Indians are leading the white men this time in this respect, they have just installed a large seed grain cleaning plant, using the same kind of machines that are being used in the government Grain Elevators in Calgary.

The Hart Edison Uniflow Cleaner has a capacity of 250 bushels per hour and the Emerson Wild Oat Cleaner has a capacity of 100 bushels per hour, and can clean any wheat, oats or barley up to certified seed standard, after the grain is cleaned it is automatically weighted and put through a Kemp Ceresan Treater ready for the seed driller.

The Indians purchased these machines and the lumber for the building from their Band Funds, the building was designed by T. G. McLeod, also, the hoppers and spouts, the installation of the equipment and machines was a real problem as there was nothing in the country of this description and had to be a special design which Mr. McLeod had to figure out.

This machine is also to be used at harvest time to clean mixed grain, and to save the good feed that is a present being lost to every one as dockage, there is a possibility that the feed saved will more than pay back the money invested in the building and equipment in two seasons.

There is a great need in every farming community for a cleaning plant of this kind. It would not only save the farmers thousands of dollars in feed and would also cut their freight bills. Clean seed every year would be a stride toward clearing up the Noxious Weed problem that we all have today.

Mr. McLeod has provided a real service and essential feature on the reserve on which he is farm demonstrator.

TO THE PARENTS.

It does not matter how well a boat has been guided in the past; it still needs guidance if the skipper leaves the wheel. The boat may stray off its course for a little while, but if no one is guiding it, it will go off its course and land up on the rocks.

No parent should be so naive as to think that their children do not need guidance when they go home for the summer holidays. No matter how well the children have been guided during the school year, they still need the guidance of their parents when they return home. Like a boat they may stay on their course for a little while if no one is guiding them, but like a boat, they will not stay on their course for long if no one is at the wheel.

By the Law of God all children are obliged to obey their parents. By the same law all parents are obliged to insist on respect and obedience from their children. Parents who do not make their children obey them are guilty of serious sin. Too many parents do not press to realize the seriousness of this obligation which pertains to it only in a rainhearted manner.

Parents must see to it that the children help with the ordinary duties around the house. They should know where their children are at all times, particularly in the evenings. They must keep a loving watch over them at all times.

On May 22nd His Excellency Archbishop Duke came to visit our School. We were all excited to hear of his arrival. He reached here with two other priests, Rev. Father Brown and Father Plamondon. They got here at noon hour.

CASINO POINT.

Mr. Davies, the school inspector and Mr. Taylor our Agent visited the school in May.

One thing we did for him was to put on a Scout and Guide parade. We marched to music and then we had a Prize and Demonstration. After that the Scouts did Morse Code Signalling. Mr. Davies gave a message to send. Dave Fraser sent it. Then we had a knot tying competition between the Scouts and Guides. The Scouts won. Mr. Davies took pictures of everything we did.

Mr. Davies spent two days inspecting the class rooms. We were all kind of nervous.
SCOUT HIKE.

One day in May Father called the Scouts and told us he were going out at nine. We knew that Dr. Davies had given us a holiday because we got it by Horse Code when he was here.

The Scouts put on their outfits and went to the kit- chen to get a lunch and then they headed for the Lake eight miles away.

After one hour's walking we ate our lunch. We had hard sandwiches, oranges and hard boiled eggs. Then we continued on again.

It took two hours to reach the lake which is at Half Moon Bay. The water looked warm and we wanted to go swimming right away, but we had orders to wait until Father came up with the rest of the children in the truck later on in the afternoon.

That was a long wait but at last they did come. After we had a swim Father told each of the Scouts to make a fire and cook his own supper. This was going to be our cooking test. Each Scout was given two matches for his fire and a piece of paper for the cooking. Then our fires were my test. Some let their meal fall in the fire. It passed good. The boys said they were better cooks than the girls.

Before we left for home we had another swim and then passed out the popcorn and afterwards we started for home in the truck. It was a good holiday.

Mary Shem Gr. III
Sarah Fleming Gr. III

STRING CANOES AT NIGHT

On December 23rd, we went to all the houses in the village that night. We took a gift to each house. We had made them in school. We all had good time. We took many lanterns and flashlights. First we went to David's house. Then to another and another. At each we sang one or two Carols before we went in to say "Merry Christmas" to every person that we saw. The snow was so deep that night, it blew skirts so that our noses went right into the deep snow. The children that were too little did not go. Hannah Mathew was there in the School to see that the little people were not noisy. When we got to David Lourtit's house we all had two candies each also the staff. At Mr. Soper's house the girls sat down on the floor near the kitchen. The boys were in the porch. Charlotte, who works at Mr. Soper's house, was very busy giving us tea and biscuits. After we had our snack we went into the living-room to see the Christmas tree. The lights were red, blue and green on the tree. Mr. Soper gave us all some candies. We all had to go right home to the School. I was with my best friend Gracie Herodier. It was late, nearly twelve o'clock. We had had a good sleep. This is the end of my story.

Elizabeth Joyce Napash Gr. III

CHRISTMAS DAY

On Christmas Eve Miss Quirt told us a story of St. Nicholas before we said our prayers. When we were all in bed the Staff sang a song of Santa to us. In the morning Miss Quirt said, "Merry Christmas Girls". We jumped out of bed to get our stockings. We looked at them to see what was inside them. Every one of the senior girls got combs, beads, handkerchiefs, hair ribbons and candles. Mr. Hittingham gave each of us a perfume bottle. After we dressed all the Staff came into our dormitories to see what each girl had. Then Mr. Senior, Jr., Hittingham and the boys came in too. After the boys had gone out we went to their dormitories and we saw everything that they got in their stockings. We senior girls went downstairs to put the food on the tables. We saw the Christmas tree decorated, the whole dining-room, each table and the staff table was in with ours too. The buzzer rung for breakfast. Then we lined up upstairs. We came down wearing our Christmas hats. After we finished eating we sang carols before Santa came. During our singing Santa Claus came running in. Some of the little girls were nearly crying because they were scared of Santa Claus. He called each person's name to get their presents. The senior girls got needle cases, belts, and triangular scarves. The senior boys got fountain pens and games of all kinds. The junior boys had toys and colouring books of all kinds and crayons. The junior girls had these too only dolls instead of toys. Every boy and girl had a big bag of candy. We played with our Christmas presents until dinner time. Each of us had half a white bird, potatoes, carrots and a dessert. When we finished the dishes we went home to our people. We showed them our Christmas gifts. We all had a happy Christmas and nice holidays.

Nellie Potts Gr. IV

The Christmas Concert is always the great event of the year. We are just giving the programme as it would take pages to describe each party.

1. The Magic Hour - A Fairy Play, Bunnies, Teddy Bears, Wooden Soldiers, Baby Dolls, A Mother Goose, Jack in the Box, Christmas Fairy, Pierrot and Columbine.
2. **Lightbouy Sketch** - A comic sketch by some of the Scouts.

3. **An Angel** - "Merry Christmas" by 14 boys.

4. **Rose Drill** - By 9 senior girls dressed in white, carrying rose streamers.

5. **A Military Drill** - By 9 senior boys.

6. **The Six Little Milkmaids** - By the intermediates.

7. The combines school choir twice assembled to sing three new carols and three Christmas songs. Carols: "Rocking", "When Christ was born of Mary", "Stars All Bright are Beaming". Songs: "Jolly Old Fellow", "Jolly Santa Claus".

The Concert ended with the Pageant written up by Elizabeth Napash. Afterwards we had a lunch and so did all the people who had come to see us. Father Christmas came and gave gifts to all the village. We had our gifts on Christmas Day.

I want to tell you in a simple way about the pageant this year 1946. We had a good time this year in the concert. Elijah was Joseph, Nellie Potts was Mary, the mother of Jesus. All the Nations came to worship the Baby Jesus. First the three angels and three girls sang "Holy Night". They were doing the actions also. Then the three angels wore, like Shem, Ham and Jemima. The first scene was the three shepherds who went around the fire. We sang two verses of "The First Noel". They pretended that they saw a star and went away. The wise men came to worship Him and presented their treasures. We sang "The Three Kings". The Wise Men were Jerry, George and Robert Matthew. Then all the Nations came and worshiped Him. Dinah Flowing was Joseph Napash, Sarah Ekomeak, India. Dinah Ekomeak was Chinese and Margaret Napash, Sarah Ekomeak, India. **Saturday House**

We change our sheets on Saturday. The boys who sweep pile all the sheets. They carry the sheets to the Laundry. One boy does the pillow cases and one boy does the sheets. One boy does the pyjamas. Then we all make our beds. We go downstairs again to work. Still some boys are sweeping the bedrooms. Then they finish they gather the dust in one pile. One boy takes the dust and puts it in a basket and they go downstairs to work. The boys pile wood and keep the school room clean.

There are fifteen Girl Guides. We have our meeting on Wednesday.

We enjoy our Girl Guide work. Miss Quint is the Captain. We are not in groups yet. We like to play all sorts of funny games. The games we like best are Poor House and Grand Old Duke of York. We like our Captains, Miss Quint. She hasn't got a real uniform yet. Miss Quint is very kind to all in the School. She is a very good and kind Patron. We had our G.A. meeting every other Wednesday after supper. We sang a hymn first, then Bible reading and prayers, hymn and the Grace. We sewed patches together for a quilt. GIRL GUIDE PICNIC

We had a Girl Guide picnic. We put our bread in bags, tea, sweet milk, pail and the cups, sausages, sweet cookies, some candies. The other girls went to the Parish Hall to get the snow-shoes to wear then. Then we are all ready to go. There were fifteen girls and two ladies, Miss Quirt and Miss Adams. We all went together. We had the bags on our backs. We all wore snowshoes but Miss Adams. We walked on the ice on the river. We walk as fast as we can go. Miss Quirt knows how to walk with snowshoes. We came nearer, nearer to the other bank. Then we went up the bank. We put the bags on the ground but we did not take off our snowshoes. We went to the bush to get sticks to make a fire. The other girls went to the trees to get the branches to sit on. After that we make the fire and put snow in the pail. The snow melted. When it was boiling we made the tea. The other girls sat around the fire and cooked the sausages on sticks. After we had eaten our supper Miss Quirt took a picture of us. Oh, my, we had a jolly time that day. We put out the fire and came home when the sun was vanished. We walked on the ice. We put our snowshoes in the Parish Hall. We put our bags in the kitchen. We didn't feel tired. We thanked Miss Quirt for the picnic. Then we went upstairs to bed. It was beginning spring when we had our picnic. Only the Girl Guides went to the picnic that day.

Nellie Herodier Gr. IV

BOYS PICNIC

We went with Miss Houldcroft and we did not take our guns. We crossed the river and as we came near the bush Miss Houldcroft gave us some candies. Then we went on again. We lit a fire and had sausages and bread. We had coffee. We put milk into the coffee. We slid down the hill and there were rocks at the bottom of the hill. We clambered up a tree and rescued Richard when he was caught on the ice and laughed and laughed. Miss Houldcroft told us a story of "The Five Knight and the King".

R. Mathew.

When we came home we went ahead on our snowshoes but Miss Houldcroft was away back. We had to wait for her.

R. Kanatewat.

BEST GOOSE DINNER

On our first goose dinner we were very glad to have a nice dish of goose. We were very very thankfull that we ate geese before the Staff did. We had plenty of goose that dinner dish. We had our first goose dinner on Saturday May 24th, 1947 A.D.

Mary Herodier Gr. XV

BIRDS IN SPRINGTIME

We kill them with bows and arrows. We make the bows and arrows. We go out on the Common in the evening to shoot birds. Elijah made a net. We catch them with a net. We pull the stick with a string. The net falls down.

Johnny Swallow Gr. III B
GRADUATION

On Thursday June 13th, we had our Graduation dinner. The tables were decorated with green crepe paper and the daffodils we made for Easter.

The Staff and the Hudson's Bay and Miss Andrew ate with us. We had goose and lemon pie.

Miss Adams led us while we sang the songs we liked best. Then Mr. Senior presented the Certificates, a Croc Book - "The Ten Words" and a pictorial "Life of Christ", to each one of the graduates. We sang "He (or she) is a Jolly Good Fellow" every time. After Mr. Senior had spoken to these pupils, Nellie Potts stepped into the centre of the room and made a very good thank-you speech. We stood and sang "God Save the King".

The school room had been cleared of desks and cleaned up by the boys so when we marched in we began to play "Grand Old Duke of York" right away. We had lots of fun. Mr. Senior taught us a new game. We laughed and laughed. We had orange drink and cookies and sang "Auld Lang Syne" and "O Canada".

The certificates are beautiful. Mr. Church of the Hudson's Bay printed them in Old English print. They have the Arctic crest on them.

Gracie Horodier Gr. IV

FIELD DAY

This paper has been planned as solely a pupil enterprise. As this report must go to press immediately I regret that it cannot be inserted by a student.

Friday, June 13th, has been a happy though strenuous day. Mr. Senior and Mr. Whittingham were in charge of the activities. Miss Quirt and myself lined the children up for each event. Miss Adams distributed the prizes to the excited winners.

Four groups of girls and two groups of boys took part in the relay, sackrace, three-legged race, ball throwing, high and broad jumping and the 50 yard dash. Gracie Horodier, aged 12 years, vaulted 1½ inches higher than any of the senior boys.

Girls who won more than two prizes were, Nellie Potts, Sally Macappo, Gracie, Larry and Nellie Horodier, Elizabeth Mcpash, Gracie Linklater, Ellen Bobbass and Juliet Head. Among the boys the most successful contestants were Jimmy Sponcer, Jerry Sam, Elijah Menorik, George Snowboy and Alex Chewaynosh. The tug-of-war was as usual, a very keen, heated, hilarious event. The jubilant girls being the victors.

Refreshment was served to the very busy judges at the hospital on the grounds of which the events were held.

H. Houldcroft.

AND SO TO PRESS:

The end of the official school year was marked in appropriate ceremony by a children's Thanksgiving service held in St. Philip's Anglican Mission Church on Sunday morning, June 15th, 1947. Bibles, suitably inscribed by the Missionary-in-Charge, were awarded to each of the four graduates; Nellie Potts, Sally Macappo, Dinah Fleming and Jerry Sam. The school choir led in the singing of special children's hymns of praise and thanksgiving.

In his farewell sermon Mr. Senior placed special emphasis on the blessing of the Almighty upon the School during the past year and asked the congregation for their continued prayers that the work of the School and Mission might go on to new height and achievements in the coming years.

The children returned to the School for dinner after which they were dismissed from School in the care of their parents or guardians.

"TOWARDS THE SUN RISING"

Reynold Smith's illustration of our school motto has become a part of our history. We know where we are going. The way will not always be over a calm mountain-sheltered lake. There will be rocks and rapids to test the craftsmanship of the canoe, the strength of the paddler's arm, the cleverness of his brain. In storm and calm may the lessons learned at St. George's give help and understanding for a safe journey to all her children.

Reynold Smith's drawing is copied for us this year by Jeanette Dunstan.
THE PRINCIPAL'S MESSAGE

This is just a short message to the "Dragon". I wonder what kind of a message St. George would have given to the original dragon? Perhaps this: "Play the game, Dragon!" These words are just an echo of those I gave you yesterday, just before you went to the Field Day sports at Lytton. All through the day, and after the day was over, I felt very proud of you girls and boys, because you played the game. Yes, you won the silver cup, and one of you girls won the highest number of points, but best of all, you were clean in all your games.

My most earnest desire for you, dear girls and boys, is that you will always play the game as you go through life. In all your dealings with one another, in all your dealings with your own self, each one, play the game. In all your work, and in all your play, play the game. Be clean and honest, kind and inspiring, and put your whole heart into the game of life. You may not win a medal or a piece of red ribbon; but you will win self-respect and the respect of other people, which is worth more than a silver cup or anything else material.

The cleanest and best Competitor this world has ever known was Jesus. He did not win a medal. It was a crown of thorns He won. He did not have a piece of red ribbon pinned on Him. They threw over Him a fool's scarlet robe. They did not shout "Hurrah" at the end of the "Field Day". They put Him on the cross and killed Him. And yet we know, and all the world knows, He won the race; and He has carried off the highest prize. Let Him be your Leader, your Guide and your pattern of clean sportsmanship.

Principal

SPORTS ACTIVITIES

"LOOK OUT BELOW"

If you were one of those people unfortunate enough to walk past the "Big Hill" on a bright winter day no doubt you heard that cry. And if you were even more unfortunate and did not move quickly enough, you probably had someone come hurling down upon you -- one of St. George's amateur ski champions.

Lack of regulation skis did not hinder these enthusiasts. Any narrow board would do as long as it protruded an inch or two in front of, and behind your shoe. Skis ranging in length from one to five feet were frequently seen on the hill.

Falls were numerous at first, even on the little hill behind the school, but as the winter progressed, technique improved and soon many of the boys were experts.

The more timid ones did their travelling on sleighs again - anything from a board or piece of tin to a toboggan would do. Even sleighing took a certain amount of courage, however. Especially if you consider the fence, the woodpile, and the barn which we had to contend with.

Even snowballing had its place in our winter sports and the many battles were fast and furious. Altogether, with skiing, sleighing and snowballing, the winter passed quickly -- a winter full of great fun.

-- Wilfred Wills

FIELD DAY ON MAY 22ND

We had our field day on May 22nd.

We all marched down to the field before dinner and sat around in a circle and then the dinner was served to us.

After dinner (about one o'clock) we started the races. The big boys had relay races and hundred yard dashes. The smaller boys and girls had seventy-five yard dashes, sack races, potato races and a few other races. There were only three boys in the high jump. The highest jump was four feet, nine inches, cleared by Hector McIntyre.

At the end of all the races there was a greased pole to climb. It was twelve feet high and the part that was greased was about four feet from the top. The boys that tried to climb it would get just about to the top and then slide down. Norman Bastace finally climbed up to the top.

We all had great fun that day.

--Albert Wells
THE KITCHEN...........

When it comes to dishwashing or pot-scraping, where you get all greased up, I feel like running away. But we really like working in the kitchen where it is training for best cooking. I like it so I'll know how to cook my own meals instead of somebody else doing it. We also learn to plan our own meals.

--Amelia James

THE SEWING ROOM.........

We do lots of sewing up there besides housecleaning. Sometimes we sew by hand and sometimes on the machine. I surely like working up there when it gets to spring cleaning. Besides, I like that place because every year I learn new things to do in sewing.

--Mary Jane Charlie

THE MANUAL TRAINING SHOP....

We go to the manual shop to learn about the machines and how to use them. Mr. Hill is our instructor and he has taught us how to use the band-saw, the sanding machine, the lathe, and a few other things such as hand tools.

--Albert Wells
THE LAUNDRY

The laundry is the place where there is work to be done. I like running the machinery. I like the work but it is not a very good job on Mondays and Fridays because the room's just full of steam. On Wednesday we iron the clothes. I was taught how to run the machinery and how to stop it, and see that it runs perfectly all right. But one thing I don't like is washing by hand because I get so hot and the sweat goes down my face.

--Annie Frank

THE FARM

Fall Work

Apple picking is liked very well by the boys because of the opportunity to eat. Nearly a thousand boxes were picked and stored in the cellar for winter use; also about a hundred and fifty boxes of pears were picked.

Potato digging is also done. The boys don't like it very well, because they don't like potatoes raw. But just the same we got a good cellar full stored.

The canning of fruit and jam is done also. The jams were apple and apricot. The preserves were pears, plums, peaches and tomatoes.

Some of the hay is put in the barn while most of it is stacked. Silage is made for the cows, and put in the silo.

Spring Work:

The fields are first plowed, then disked, then harrowed. Some of the boys have learned to drive the tractor and the truck. The early potatoes were planted first. Then the grain and vegetables.

The pruning of trees was done by Harry Thom, who also gave instructions to the farm boys who were helping him.

Winter Work:

In winter we haul hay for the two barns, and also for the sheep, and the horses cut in the fields. We grade the road with the tractor when the snow is too deep. Wood hauling is also done. Mr. Vaughn-Jones is the Farm Manager.
The Dairy

We have twelve milk cows at present which give around thirty-five to forty-five gallons daily. There are also eleven heifers. We have about fifteen to twenty hogs, and a big flock of chickens, which give about two pails of eggs daily. There are two turkeys which have a brood of about fifteen which are being raised for Christmas dinner. Mr. R. Biddle is the Dairy Manager.

ST. GEORGE'S AND LYTTON SPORTS DAY

On June 11 we had our sports at the Lytton Race Track. I think it was one of the best sports days we have had yet.

Mr. Medici, the owner of the New Lytton Hotel, put up a silver cup to the school that had the most points. St. George's School won it.

The events started off at 10:30. Some of the events were relay races, sack races, broad jumps, high jumps, dashes, and wheelbarrow races.

About 12:30 we had our dinner. We had hot-dogs, ice-cream, cake, doughnuts and besides that we were given tickets to get free drinks and ice-cream.

After dinner we had more events and after they were all over we had a softball game and Lytton beat us. The score was 15 to 13.

After everything was over they added up the points to see which pupil had the most. Daphne Thom had most with 18 points and Wilfred Wells was second with 16 points. Both pupils are from St. George's School.

Our Christmas party was held on New Year's Eve and we all had a swell time. We also had a new electric organ so Miss Hives played on it for some of our dance music. After having our refreshments we each received a Christmas present from Mr. Richard Spencer.

THE GIRLS' AUXILLARY AND WOMEN'S AUXILLARY SALE

On June 18th the Women's Auxiliary and Girls' Auxiliary had a sale of work and tea at 2:30 in the afternoon. The Women's Auxiliary made some delicious cakes, cookies, pies and candy which disappeared very quickly. Then outside was all the sewing, knitting, embroidery work, etc. While the W.A. was serving tea on the little lawn in front of the school, the bigger boys and girls, led by Mr. Arthur Hives and Miss Phelps, put on a display of calliophones.

There were quite a few of the children's parents present as well as other visitors from Lytton.

After the sale, on June 21st, the G.A. had their last meeting, and also went out on a weiner roast beside the swimming pool. We each bought our own bottle of orange crush while Mrs. Ingram bought the hot dogs and doughnuts. I think we all had a wonderful time for after eating our hot dogs (which didn't take long) we sat around the fire and sang songs before going home.

-- Phyllis Dunstan
THE CHURCH CORNER

The Wedding.....

Everyone was invited to attend the wedding of Rosie Adams and Martin Abbott on Oct 1st, 1946. We were all neatly dressed in our Sunday best and all waiting for the first glimpse of the radiant bride.

Rosie wore a white satin wedding dress and carried a bouquet of white carnations and white asters. Her bridesmaid, May Dunstan, wore a pink dress and carried pink carnations and asters. Everyone was simply thrilled.

Thanksgiving Service.....

On Thanksgiving Day we had our regular Harvest Festival Service. Everyone that was able to attended. The church was specially decorated with farm produce as well as autumn leaves and flowers, by Miss Jobling with the help of a few girls. It was very lovely indeed.

Christmas Service.....

On Dec 22nd we had our Carol Candlelight Service. On every window there were three candles all lighted and there were some very lovely flowers on the altar. The choir sang carols and the congregation in turn sang Christmas hymns. On the night before Christmas at 12 o'clock, we had our midnight celebration of Holy Communion.

Services Before and After Easter.....

During the Lenten Season we had evening services at 7:30, taken by Mr. Hixon and by Rev. Baker when Mr. Hixon was away. On Easter Morning we had Holy Communion at 7:30 and in the afternoon we had evening prayers and sermon at 2:30. We were all wearing our best. The church looked lovely with lilies and tulips. Everyone agreed that it was a lovely service. There was a service of Holy Communion on Ascension Day. There was Holy Communion in the morning and evening prayers and sermon at 2:30 in the afternoon on WhitSunday.

Confirmation Service........

On Sunday, Jun 29th, the Bishop of our Diocese came to confirm over forty of the pupils. The service took place at 10 in the morning. We sang five hymns in our very best way. The Bishop said that he had never heard us sing so well before.

New Organ........

During the year a new electric organ was installed in the chapel.

--Marjorie Alec
LIFE AT ST. GEORGE'S

A whirr of an alarm clock and shaking of a head,
"Ahh! It is too early to get up from my bed;"
'Tis time to rise," says one, "and be about."
"Where are my boots?" I heard another shout.
"Now to milk cows, we must get dressed."
"Hey, wait, Alby, is your pants pressed?"
Now hear a clip-clop down the hall,
Which isn't necessary there at all.
Then an impatient call — "Come on, you girls!
Now hurry up and brush those curls."
"These curling pins are tangled in my hair,
Help me, Amelia, do not stand and stare."
"All kitchen girls blow; rings cut the cry,
"I wish you wouldn't push — I cannot fly!"

Then rings that darn old bell again
Whether in wind, sunshine or rain,
Soon the great building throbs with wakening life,
The hum of action, clatter, too, of strife.
"We breakfast soon," say all, and stop below.
Some hurrying, others still bemused and slow.
Milkers are there returning from their chores,
Treading with noisy boots about the floors.
The kitchen girls are scurrying here and there
Setting tables, placing bench and chairs.
At length, in order every no lines up
To have their breakfast without ketchup!
Soon they are eating milk and bread,
And also porridge (a cereal I dread).

Breakfast is done and now above the stairs
We line the hall, all reverent for prayers,
An hallowed moment ere begins the day,
Its pleasures, disappointments, work and play,
That with its happenings of joy and pain
When once departed never comes again.

Then some boys chop wood down at the woodpile
And they all sit with a happy smile,
Also others work down at the barn,
And still others labour on the farm.
"It", said a tall lad, "to class must progress
And there remain until recess.
Wilfred asks me how to pronounce a word,
The big-little-hard-easy word is absurd,
But I do the asking when it comes to arithmetic
And when he doesn't know, I sure feel sick.
But soon the dinner bell will be ringing
And by that time my stomach for food is singing,
Then to the farm I must proceed
And if I'm late, I shall have to use speed."

But after that noon bell rings very soon,
Some girls are busy serving with a big spoon.
The dinner is ready and the children come in
Not so quiet you can hear the drop of a pin.
And none of the children are a minute late —
You can tell by the clattering of each well-filled plate,
After dinner starts the washing of dishes,
"I wish I were outside," Dorothy wishes.

Now to the Laundry come will go,
Some climb the stairs to learn to mend and sew,
Some for their health's sake take a needed rest,
While others go to classrooms neatly dressed.
Says Johnny Joe, "Who hath my pencil took?"
"And who," says Wesley, "has my spelling book?"
Francis, as usual, is up to tricks
While Gerald grumbles at Arithmetics.
"Sleep," quoth the teacher, "will your life prolong,"
"Will calm the nerves, and make the muscles strong."
"I'll try some, now," our gentle Jeannette sighs,
And pillowed on her desk, doth close her languorous eyes.

At four o'clock they all come hurrying out
With marbles, balls and laugh and joyous shouts.
For this is playtime ore the evening's share
Of labours, milking, supper to prepare —
And washing dishes comes to claim the hours —
Toch us not skill of work, and greater powers.
Then comes the evening, gently rises prayers,
The little ones soon after mount the stairs.

May sew or read according to their likes,
Sometimes the joyous sound of dancing feet
Sometimes the music of a sing-song sweet
May reach the ear, but soon 'tis hushed and still
As each one seeks their couch to rest until
The morn.

I lay my weary head
Upon the pillow of my welcome bed.

Note: The above was composed by the School Poets, of whom there are (believe it or not) quite a number.

To Our Parents

It is with the greatest of pleasure that we have looked forward to the day when we could again present you with one of our year books. We have all co-operated to make this piece of work as interesting as possible for both pupils and parents, as well as for our dear friends. For you especially, our parents, we have obtained the Interview and Historical Section, which is in itself very realistic, to bring back to you memories of the days you spent at school.

Before you could read this book, many steps had to be taken to get the required material, reports, critics and news, to say nothing of the photography, stencil work, drawing, printing, joining, trimming, and so on. However we did it to please you, and the task was an easy one.

All in all, I do believe our work has been a success; we sincerely hope that your pleasure in receiving it will be as great as ours was in doing it.

To you our parents, we dedicate this book.

Dorothy Dumont, Grade VIII

PRINCIPAL

MESSAGE
from the PRINCIPAL

The Year Book for 1947 is going to press and again it is my pleasure to extend greetings to all the parents, ex-pupils and friends. Our students are happy to report to their beloved ones, their school activities and their achievements during the year which now comes to a close, and I wish to compliment the editorial staff for the excellence of this book.

The success of our pupils, during this year, in the various competitions with High Schools and Collegiates of the Province has added to the renown of our institution and is a credit to the parents and to the Indian people. The sons and daughters of your homes are fine boys and girls, and it is your prayerful desire to give them not necessarily what is easiest and sweetest but what is strong and of eternal value: Christian education.

This means that in the training of your children we endeavour to consider not only their mind and their body, but also their soul, their will and their heart. We strongly believe that the subject of true education is "man whole and entire", soul united to body in unity of nature, and that unless a man's heart is filled with high ideals of the dignity...
of man, of the purpose of life, of his final destination and
of the duties that he has towards God, his Creator, and to-
wards his fellowmen and country, and lives and acts accord-
ingly, he is not educated.

On account of its utmost importance, this religious tea-
ching must be given not only in Church, but must start in the
home and should be continued in the School. If the home fail
to give this training; the school can repair some of the harm
done, but will always encounter failures among its pupils. On
account of the lack of religious practice at home, the chil-
dren will come to consider their duties towards God and their
neighbours on a "part time basis." We know that religion must
be on a "full time basis," and must dominate all that we do
and think, because there is no field of action or study where
one can consider himself independent of his Creator and Mas-
ter.

This year sixteen pupils are of age to be discharged.
We are pleased with the desire of many of them to continue
their studies and training. Full opportunity and means will
be given them for advancement in higher studies, but it re-
mains for you, parents, to get behind them and give them en-
couragement.

The Year Book records the interest our school is gi-
ving to Music, Singing, Dramatics, Calet Training and Voca-
tional Training. We feel that all these activities meet with
the needs of our students and provide opportunities for main-
taining morale and good spirit, and for the building of cha-
racter.

May my last word be addressed to you, ex-pupils and
graduates: The school wants to be proud of you. Keep in your
heart the love of God and neighbour. Be honest and dependable,
for when it is said of someone: "He cannot be trusted", it is
the final condemnation. He has no place in society. In life
you will often meet with things that do not suit you, but you
must learn to accept them with a smile. Moreover, if you want
to be successful, be good workers. Too many men with ability
are failures because they are afraid of work. Do your work
even if it is difficult.

My last advice: Be kind and unselfish. Do not always
ask yourselves "What is in this for me", but rather "How can
it help others". All this gives room for plenty of work but
it will lead you to happiness and prosperity.

Paul Piche, O.M.I.,
principal.

Mr. LAFLEUR

Mr. Verreault: I am sure we are all very happy to have you with us this morning, Mr. Lafleur. We know that you have been at this school for 43 years, and we would like to ask you a few questions about the old days.

C. Bellegarde: How did you come here?

Mr. Lafleur: I arrived from Ottawa by train, on Jan. 26, 1904.

Mr. Bedard: I wasn't born then! But tell me, what did I see look like in those days?

Mr. Lafleur: It was a tiny village, with the school, old convent, mission, and the houses of Mr. Goupal, Paquin, and Mrs. Desnoeux, about seven houses altogether.

Mr. Bedard: Were you always a baker?

Mr. Lafleur: I am now 72, and have been a baker all my life.

C. Bellegarde: How many loaves of bread have you baked in all these years?

Mr. Lafleur: I did not count them.

Tom Desnomie: Have you known the first school?

Mr. Lafleur: It burned down three weeks before I came. I had met Father Hugonard in Ottawa, where he hired me, and he was on the way back when he heard about the fire.

Mr. Verreault: Weren't the pupils of those days the parents of the children here today?

Mr. Lafleur: Yes, I remember in particular Henry John, Pat Cappo, Joe Goodwill, Mike Dubois, Nicholas and Anthony Ironchild, and Alec Desnomie. There were also a few from Crooked Lake.

Tom Desnomie: What activities did the boys have then?

Mr. Lafleur: The boys worked on the farm or in the shops. There was the blacksmith shop with Mr. MacDonald, Carrier Brown and Carbonneau as successive instructors. Mr. Crossley was instructor in the carpenter shop. There was also a shoe shop with Mr. Richer, and a tinsmith shop with Mr. Polier.

Mr. Verreault: And of course, a bake shop with Mr. Lafleur. Did any of the boys work in the bake shop?

Mr. Lafleur: There were two boys in the bake shop until 1912. I remember having Noel Pinay and Anthony Ironchild. Baking was not a trade which could be used on the reserves, so these boys were merely helpers.

In Our Parents' School Days

After the first school had burned down in 1904, this question was present in the minds of many: "Is the government going to erect another?" Father Hugonard laid down plans for a new school but without immediate success. After two months of fruitless efforts he came back from Ottawa without having received even a promise of help.

However before spring of 1905 things changed swiftly. Reconstruction began with $35,000. Father Hugonard's plans were followed as far as dimensions were concerned, but the execution was improved. Thus at the cost of $125,000, one of the best of Canada's Industrial Schools was built. It was opened in the fall of 1905. The new building had modern equipment, according to a uniform and carefully studied plan which facilitated supervision.

It was a beautiful three winged edifice with a stone foundation. The south wing was occupied by the girls, the north one by the boys, while in the central building were the chapel, the personnel's apartments, the parlors, the infirmary, the kitchen and the dining rooms.

Father Hugonard regarded his school primarily as a tool for the christian civilization of the Indians. For over 40 years he devoted himself to mission work. "He loved his Indians, and appeared fully happy among these little children whom he loved as a father, as a mother, as God alone can love". He died in Feb. 1917. His loss was keenly felt at the school and in all the valley. After Father Hugonard's death a monument was erected to his memory. This memorial was unveiled in the summer of 1927, among an immense gathering. It represents Father Hugonard standing between an Indian boy and girl.

On Nov. 13, 1932, at 6:45 a.m., during mass, fire broke out in the girl's wing of the building. The blaze spread rapidly, and by 10:30 a.m., the entire school had been completely destroyed. Aided by the citizens of the town, and also by the scholastics, the staff saved everything that it could reach.
books, clothing, furniture, etc. Some of the outbuildings were also saved. The financial loss was estimated at a quarter of a million dollars.

The Scholastics busied themselves in sorting, moving and putting away what had been snatched from the flames. Father Blanchin, superior of the Scholasticate sheltered all the boys, while the girls were housed in the town hall, old church. The Sisters divided their numbers between these different localities.

At the Scholasticate children and Scholastics mingled and became one large family. Shy at first, the boys quickly got used to the new order of things. Catechism was taught by the Scholastics. An instrumental band was begun and built up by Brother Piche, now principal of the school. The brothers acquired a fresh interest in Indian missions, and quite a few began to study the Indian language. Among the latter was Father Laviolette, who quickly mastered Sioux and is now missionary of the Sôhian missions of Western Canada.

The girls had classrooms in the town hall, the old church was used as a chapel, dining room and recreation hall, while the basement of the new church was transformed into a dormitory. The staff and children were thus sheltered until March, 1936, when they moved into this the new school, a splendid modern fireproof building which now shelters approximately 300 pupils.

WORK AND STUDY

Programme of Studies

The basis of our programme of studies, as with all other Indian schools of Canada, is the curriculum of the province in which we are located. Therefore the instruction given in the Lebret Indian Residential School is fundamentally the same as that given in the public schools of the province of Saskatchewan. This programme provides instruction and experiences in ten subject. Four of these, language, reading, spelling and writing, are intended to develop skill in the use of the English language. Mathematics provides the pupils with the ability to perform the ordinary computations of everyday life, and forms a background for higher studies. Agriculture and science, social studies, health, art and music, complete the curriculum, with the purpose of making the children familiar with the many interesting aspects of nature, the community, and the artistic. In Indian schools, religious instruction has been added to this programme because of the undeniable necessity of religion in true education, and forms an important part of the activities of the school.

Another feature of the instruction of our school is Manual Training, which is intended to enable the children to earn a living successfully by manual work. This necessary addition to the programme makes it impossible to maintain the academic standards of the public schools in the higher grades.

The training division of the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa closely cooperates with us. This year it has introduced a number of new textbooks, and has shown its interest in our work by publishing a periodical "Indian School Bulletin", in order to guide us in the task of Indian education.
Religious Instruction

A new course in Catechism has been organized this year by Fr. Guy. Not a new doctrine, but every class has studied a different part of our faith in a different way. The course in Grade One deals with the preparation to the first communion. Grade II studied the life of our Lord in the form of Bible stories, His miracles, His apostles, etc. Grade III learnt that everyone is called to be perfect as His Father in heaven is perfect; therefore they have studied capital sins, the means to avoid them, and the sacrament of Penance. In Grade IV and V the Mass and Liturgy have been the central point of view; a study of the different vestments and articles with a review of a few other sacraments. The older pupils from Grade V up have studied the Creed and the Sacraments.

Our aim in Catechism is to bring these young children to appreciate more and more the beautiful life of God in everyone of us, to bring their will to perform freely what is right according to their knowledge, to obey the authority of God as well as of men. The young Fathers and Brothers of the Scholasticate have been invited to come and give a lesson every week in each class and to prepare a classroom book for every grade as a guide for the future. They have gladly accepted and all the teachers have appreciated their help.

Posters on Food

To all Indian Day and Residential Schools, a good drawing contest has been provided by the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa. The form of the drawing consisted of one poster in three parts, illustrating all three of the following points: the food I like to eat in a day, the ways I like to get the food, how I like to eat the food. A board of three judges was selected by Father Principal for choosing the three prize winning posters among the competing pupils of this school. Dr. and Mrs Simes from Fort Qu'Appelle and Father Lavigne, provincial, accepted the invitation as judges, and decided the three following posters worthy of entry for the Grand Prize Awards: First: Gracie Yusicapi, grade 7; second, Jeannie Cyr, grade 5; third, Lucy Desnomie, grade 4.

The prizes were $5, $5 and $2 for each Indian School, and $50, $25 and $10 for the Dominion Award winners.

Among the above three drawings sent to the Nutrition Division at Ottawa, news came shortly that Gracie Yusicapi's drawing had won the third Grand Award. Congratulations, Gracie!
