Manual Training

Shop-talk - Some people think that there is nothing to sawing a board. We carpenters know better. You first have to mark your board with a square to have a straight cut. Then you start sawing gently on the corner opposite to you, and carefully watch that the saw does not slant or get out of line. Driving a nail is another complicated operation. Greenhorns usually end up with a smashed thumb, a crooked nail, and a split board. There is beauty in driving a nail straight, in two or three clean strokes.

With these and many other principles in mind, the boys greatly enjoyed the day that they spent in the shop each week, and turned out a number of different articles; frames, cabinets, bookcases, dust-boxes, ironing boards, cedar chests, cupboards, tables, pews, ladders and stairs. The models are supplied by Mr. Joe Desjarlais, carpenter and instructor. The boys also worked at roofing and repairing the chicken coop.

In this way we learn the use of many tools, such as hammer, saw, chisel, plane, coping saw, key saw, square, drill, brace and bit, screwdriver, rasp, file, etc.

In other departments, Alfred Lavallee and Richard Poitras have had charge of the chicken coop, and have successfully taken two batches of spring chicks through the period of incubation. The boys have also worked on the farm and in the garden. Pat Fourhorns has spent the greater part of the year in the shoe shop, and from a torn, wrinkled old shoe can now make an elegant shining piece of footwear.

A Stitch in time ... Look at this wonderful sewing-room! The sister in charge, small but active Sister Micheaud, is so proud of it that she would gladly show it to all the ladies, mammas and misses of the reserves and of the whole world. There, new clothes are made - old ones renewed, stockings knitted on the knitting machine and by hand - weaving is done - patches are put on - slick mending and darning goes on with the famous darning machine.

We must not forget the concert costumes, the various pieces made to obtain the proficiency badges, etc. If all these stitches are to be written in the eternal book, how many pages will it take?

Pots and Pans - I am sure that you will agree with me if I say that the kitchen is the most important department of the whole school. We do not always think of it, but what would happen if there were no meals ready when we come into the dining room with wide open eyes and empty stomachs? None of that in the Lebret School. Sister Neudel will certainly have a splendid reward, for she gives us not only a cup of cold water, but plenty of good food which is much appreciated by us boys and girls. And the Senior girls who have been under our cook's guidance will surely be the joy of their husbands if they ever have the fancy to get married.

One would never believe it but she is a great tease in spite of her bashful ways. Her favorite hobbies are reading comics and hiking. Ruth Bear of Sioux Reserve. Though not very brilliant in class work this girl can surpass anyone in knitting. She is not much of a singer but never misses the Range Round Up Program at 4 o'clock. Her favorite hobbies are listening to the radio, copying songs and hiking. Enjoys watching hockey and ball games and is always ready to cheer. Ruth is of an easy going disposition and never gets excited about anything.

Gracie Yuzicapi is a fifteen year old brunette, with brown eyes and a chubby face, and has also completed her Grade VII. Gracie is quite a girl to know. Does work in every field, class, sewing, fancy work, housekeeping. She likes all her work. Her hobbies are painting, taking snap-shots and going for hikes. Her favorite subjects is Maths. Gracie is the teacher's right hand and we call her "our artist." One of her horrible habits is trying to beat Gracie Lavallee in Catechism. She is also very fond of singing. Her pet phrase is: "Now don't you dare..."
Patrick Fourhorns is remarkable for his strength and size. He can easily do the work of three men, and could, I believe, lift the school off its foundations if he had the fancy. "Punchy," as he is known, is a character which seems to have dropped out of a western show, complete with ten-gallon hat, good-nature, and... muscles. He has worked in the shoe shop, barns and on the farm. Pat is a star hockey and baseball player, where his great strength and speed break all opposition. As to work, give him any kind.

Victor Tachan is a good looking, rather reserved young fellow, famous for his sparkling laugh and comical ways. Though not outstanding in his studies, he does well and is reliable. He is very sportive, having played hockey and baseball this year with the senior team. He is a good worker and is ever ready to do his share. He likes farm animals, and is and will do well around the farm on the prairies of Manitoba, where he comes from.

Allan Goodwill, of Sioux Reserve, is a rather stout boy. He is playful, always happy and full of jokes. He has good manners when he makes use of them, and is well liked by everyone. He excels in sports and in band music, and does fairly well in class. His main abilities are in carpentry and farming, and in these he will probably make his future.

John James Tawiyaka, of Sioux Reserve, "Jackson" is a good natured fellow, friendly, and is liked by everyone. Although rather silent, he is full of energy and is active in every school activity. He likes sports, and has been one of our prominent school athletes this year, being a part of the senior hockey and baseball team and a representative of the school in the field meet. John James probably prefers outside work to study although he does well in class. Yet he seems more at home around the shop, barns or on the farm, where his work is always carefully done. In the future, we see him as a prosperous farmer, and, naturally, as a member of the Sioux Baseball team.

Moses Deegan - "Mosie" is tall, strong, and wears a grin on his face. Although he likes to tease, there there can be no evil in him, and so he is the friend of everyone. In class he is not among the first, but does his best. He holds the pencil in his big left hand and writes in a large square handwriting. He takes parts in sports, baseball in particular, where he is pitcher for one of the teams. Mosie's domain is the out of doors, where his strength and conscientiousness make him fit for any kind of work.
Billy Bollegarde, of Filo Hills. "Freckles" is the name he is usually known by. With all his bossiness, pep and self-confidence, Billy is nevertheless a popular boy, and is certainly as good as they come. He is highly fond of teasing and annoying his younger brothers. Billy is very successful in his studies; he is intelligent, ambitious and hardworking, and if he continues his school grades, as he intends to, will certainly do well. Baseball, hockey, band music are among his other activities, and in each of these he is outstanding. His hobby is hunting. He also works well, and with enthusiasm.

Benjamin Bell, of Griswold, Manitoba. Ben is a small, quick and likable fellow. His wide smile, laughing eyes, and his peculiar front teeth give him a bright and frank expression, and all will certainly miss him a great deal. His usual occupation seems to be running from those he has teased beyond endurance. Ben is not a great scholar, but is a good worker, and a very reliable one. He can be seen at all times of the day, with his cap turned backwards, going to and from his chores.

Roland Whitebear, from Moose Mountain. Roland is tall, powerful fellow, who moves quickly and noiselessly. The small boys in particular are fond of him. His favorite occupations are listening to the radio (he knows scores of cowboy songs) and can sing, yodel or play the guitar, and torturing his friend Francis. He seems to have a knack for picking up nicknames, such as Barabbas, Bonos, etc. Roland loves to work, and is ever ready to do any job he is offered, particularly around the farm.

Harry Biggshotty, came to us this year from Northern Manitoba, and has quickly become one of us. He has a good character, and is famous for not minding his own business. They say he is the grand champion at the dinner table. Everyone rather likes him for his cheerfulness and pleasant personality. Harry is quite good in class although his headaches, if he has any, don't come from too much study. He likes to strum on his guitar and sing western songs. He is a steady and reliable worker, and does well the great amount of work that is asked of him.

Leslie Hotain, of Oak River, is a steady, amiable boy who will probably never have an enemy, and has had good conduct all through his school years. He is very patient and reliable. Leslie excels in sports, and though not a scholar works well in class. He does best in outdoor work around the barns and farm, and is good in carpentry. No one has ever known him to be a job carelessly. His good character and seriousness will serve him well in the future.
Sept. 2: Opening of the school year. Most of the pupils enrolled for the coming year back. We find a few changes. Sister Superior Sauve has been replaced by Sister A. Gaudet, formerly of St. Michael's, N.D. We extend to her a hearty welcome. Her smiling countenance has already won our hearts. Miss C. Piche takes charge of the Grade II class. Being an accomplished pianist she will have many an occasion to show her talent. Sister Bilodeau and Laneville also are new-comers. Sister Winter, although a bit late, is nevertheless received with open arms, especially by the Senior Girls. To all we extend a glad welcome.

Many of the pupils earnestly look forward to see whether or not they were awarded prizes at the Provincial exhibition. They were not disappointed, as our school had many prizes in art, writing, exercise books, pressed flowers and weeds, insects, embroidery work, crocheting, knitting, sewing and mending.

Sept. 9: Father Richard C.F.M. from Montreal took pictures of the pupils at work in the classrooms, sewingrooms etc., and also of the beautiful scenes of the valley. He is producing a film in color, which we hope to see some day.

Sept. 13: The Pupils and members of the staff go to Fort Qu'Appelle to see the show "Bells of St. Marys".

Oct. 2: Patronal feast of the school - Holy Guardian Angels - Holiday. In the afternoon we go to the bazaar at the parish.

Oct. 6: His Excellency Archbishop Routhier of Alberta is our honored guest.

Oct. 10, 11, & 12: Annual retreat preached by Father Durocher O.S.I. He insists on Indian vocations.

Oct. 16: Canon Lorgnier of Boulogne, France, comes for a short visit. He tells us about the starving children of Europe and asks us not to forget them in our prayers.
Oct. 21: Miss McCready, dietician from Ottawa, comes around for inspection. She also pays a visit to the different classrooms.

Oct. 28: Mr. & Mrs. Wm. Desanctis celebrate their golden wedding. Some of the singers and relatives of the jubilarians go to File Hills to sing at mass and take part in the celebration.

Oct. 29: Some of us are quite embarrassed this morning when Archbishop Cabana, St. Boniface visits the school, as we are not certain whether or not he is a bishop. His brother, a missionary in Africa is with him.

Nov. 4: A banquet is served in honor of two lay brothers, Brother Adolphe Gauthier and Brother Eugene Gauthier who celebrate their golden jubilee of religious life.

Nov. 12 & 13: Teachers' Convention at Indian Head.

Nov. 8: Most of the children go home for three days.

Nov. 23: Mr. Doucet does not forget us. While passing through Lebret, he spends a few hours with us.

Dec. 7: Mother Provincial of the Grey Nuns spends a few days at our school.

Dec. 11: A drama Festival is held at Lebret Town Hall. Our school put on two plays, "Stolen Prince" and "Golden Slipper." The Stolen Prince is highly praised by Mrs. Harrison and takes first place.

Dec. 23: Jan. 5: Something very extraordinary takes place... The children, with the exception of a few from the distant reservations, spend their Christmas vacations at home. Now we have something to look forward to next Christmas.

Jan. 17: The sudden death of His Eminence Cardinal R. Villeneuve takes us all by surprise. A requiem high mass is sung on the 21st, for the repose of his soul.

Jan. 23: Everyone is bustling around this afternoon, for Mr. Os- trander, Indian Commissioner, is here and for the first time since his appointment we have a little concert for him. Perhaps he will come often now, since Father Principal had him understand that he didn't come very often. All turn out well and he grants us a holiday.

Feb. 2: It being the Principal's feast day, we make the most of it. A very nicely prepared concert takes place in the evening, after which a reflection is served in the dining room. Everyone admires the cake which was made in the form of our school. Next morning a high mass is sung, followed by a holiday.
Feb. 2-20: Great blizzards, railway blocked - no trains. In all only three trains passed from the second to the twentieth.

Feb. 5: Are united in marriage this morning in our chapel, Irene Lecaine and George Poitras. Father Laviolette officiates and the choir sings hymns appropriate for the occasion.

Feb. 18: Reverend Father M. Lavigne, Provincial of the Oblates, celebrates his silver jubilee. Here at the school a banquet is attended by many Fathers, and also by Dr. & Mrs. Simes. After the banquet a short concert takes place. The military band is in attendance. Rev. Father says a few words of thanks and encouragement and to top it off grants us a holiday which is taken the following day, Ash Wednesday.

March 13: Bernadette Bellegarde, an ex-pupil of the school, who had been sick at the Indian Hospital for some time, quietly passed away this afternoon. She died a very peaceful death. Our sincere sympathy is extended to the parents and near relatives of the deceased.

March 21: This evening, a musical amateur night, the girls chorus takes first prize with a mark of 90% and win $5.00. Father Laviolette is adjudicator.

March 23: This afternoon Archbishop Lajusonose administered confirmation to 116 children. Miss C. Piche and Mr. Florent Verreault were the sponsors.

March 31 & April 29: Superintendent Gould pays his annual visit, and seems pleased with the work done.

April 8 & 9: Gladly do we welcome to the school our former principal, Father Maurice De Bretagne. He appears very pleased to see all the children.

April 21: Mr. Scott, adjudicator at the Provincial Drama Festival Finals at Regina made a special trip to tour school to see the play "Stolen Prince". He enjoyed it immensely.

May 1: A surprise awaits us this evening. Mr. Doll is going to entertain us with another of his plays a drama entitled "Lonely Lady." However, we were quite disappointed when all is over as we find it too short.

May 2: The news of the newly elected Superior General of the Oblate comes to us over the radio. He is a Canadian by the name of Father Deschatelets, former Provincial of the East. When one member is honored everyone is honored so Father Piche grants us a holiday.

May 7: No class. Teachers attend an Institute at Fort Qu'Appelle.
May 6. The sad news came over the radio this morning of the death of our Archbishop, His Excellency P.J. Monaham. He passed away in the Grey Nuns Hospital in Regina. We sing a Requiem high mass for the repose of his soul on the 9th. We hope his successor will be as kind hearted and good as he was.

This afternoon some unexpected visitors come to the classrooms: Mr. & Mrs. Gould and one of the Primary teachers from Moose Jaw Normal School, Miss Welland. They take everyone by surprise.

May 8 & 9. A lady from Ottawa, Miss Lock, spends a few days with us. She encourages all to eat vegetables, by giving a seven minute film "Do You."

Picture Show this evening, given by Father Joyal, who is in the School. The films, instructive and interesting are mostly about nature, animals etc., and in color. Before retiring we sing songs both in French and English.

May 13 & 14. Annual Musical Festival. Mr. Ian Barrie as adjudicator. It turns out to be a great success and our school wins many honors. Everyone is becoming more music conscious, which is an excellent thing.

May 16. Tonight, many of the children went to Loria to put on a concert for their parents.

May 24. In the afternoon the band boys to to Ft. Qu'Appelle Sports Day to play. Later on in the afternoon a group of girls leave to sing for the sick patients at the Indian Hospital, where the band is now awaiting them to give a concert.

May 25. Pentecost Sunday, birthday of the church. Bishop Lemieux from Gravelbourg says mass privately in our chapel. The children leave for home. Flower Day at Pasqua, and two-day vacation at home.

May 27. It is very cold and it snows in the forenoon. All the children come back tired, but happy.

May 28. Cadet Inspection. In the evening, at the town hall, we see a show entitled "Desert Victory."

Mimeograph and pantograph - Mary Julia Episkenow is an expert with the pantograph. She enlarges and reduces drawings, prints, etc., for the Indian Missionary Record. We need more skilled and patient girls and boys for this kind of work.

The mimeograph has seldom been idle this year. It has turned out heaps of circulars, forms, briefs, tickets, worksheets, programmes, and a complete hymn book, to say nothing of the Year Book. * Gone are the days.—The School bus has done its last mile with us. After having been part of every trip, outing, and adventure of the school for many years, after rattling on every highway, road and trail of Saskatchewan with the staff and pupils, it has been sold away, and will probably continue being the headache of mechanics for years to come. We have lost a good, though unreliable, friend.

A bright new little truck has filled its place. We are glad to welcome this newcomer among us, and extend to it our wishes for a long and happy life.

* Why mothers get gray:—On the night of the flood, one of our small boys, Sweet Pea (Wilfrid Nokusis) tried to cut across the garden to be the first into playroom, but stuck fast in the mud. A big boy pulled him out of his shoes, and Sweet Pea walked in his stockings.

- Whenever you ask Elvina Cappo to lend you her comb, she is certain to say: "There are 18 teeth broken already. Be sure not to break anymore, or else I won't have anything left to lend you."

Art and Crafts—When George Lavallee knocked at the Junior Girls' classroom one morning to bring in the marvellous large show case he had made for us, we could hardly believe that we had enough articles to fill it, but come and see it now. We girls do all sorts of small pieces of work, woolen stocking, sweaters, dresses, scarves, caps, cushions, doll's clothes, toy animals, pottery, bird charts.

* * *

During our spare moments in the intermediate girls' playroom, many of us have taken to knitting and at Christmas were proud to take home a good pair of socks, made with our own hands. We are getting so smart that Sister Michaud takes us like the senior girls on holiday afternoons in the sewing room. You should see us all at work, knitting, sewing, mending, ripping old clothes and even trying ourselves on the weaving and knitting machines. Violet Blacksioux has a very nice knitted dress for the exhibition and Marjorie Goodwill a beautiful sweater.
Jeannie Cyr and Marjorie Goodwill, our talented artists, have provided the show case with many delightful articles, apart from their numerous Christmas cards and their oil-paint decorated dish-boards for the Fathers' dining room.

* * *

Beauty and proportion is a great help for a girl to keep a home later on. A well decorated home with curtains, carpets, cushions, quilts is more beautiful. Sr. Winter who took charge of fancy work this year has found great talent among the girls for this work. The girls also helped in decorating cakes. Father Principal's birthday cake represented the school and his mission churches, and himself coming back from Pasqua with David Sayer in a cutter.

* * *

Even the small girls seem to be busy. "After we started to learn how to mend and knit, Shirley Strongeagle and Loretta Bellegarde were able to knit each one a pair of Short stockings. The same two, and also Lorraine Bellegarde, Florence Ward and Rose Alice McArthur made each one a spool knitted cord for the cross of our missionaries."

Be The Valentine - On Valentine's Day most of the girls sent cards to the boys. Seeing the boys had no money (!) to buy cards they sent back the same ones. It seems that one of the Fathers told them to do this. I hardly think they would have thought of it by themselves.

Fire, Wind and Water. - Four a.m., Dec. 22. The snores of the boys are suddenly interrupted by the cry of fire. In the reddish light of the blaze everyone makes his way to the windows of the dormitory. The hockey club house beside the rink is a mass of flames. The boys battle a while for a good view, and then settle down to looking at the building burn to the ground.

The February storm hit us hard. Mountains of snow were shovelled off the rinks every day, and every morning were back again. Coal became scarce, and the two boys classrooms were sent one morning to see what wood they could find, should the bad weather keep on. We struggled a whole morning in four feet of snow and returned tired and soaked to the bones.

In April came the big thaw. The creek which crosses the school grounds overflowed, and all the school turned out to see the flood. Mr. Bedard had a hard time keeping his wood, and perhaps his house, from going down into the lake.

Wise Girl - While sliding at the Scholasticate Antoinette and Rita sprained a knee and an ankle, and had a sleigh ride back to school. Antoinette had a week's rest, reading and advancing her fancy work. Dorothy Dumont, who had not managed to sprain anything, but wished she were in Antoinette's place, froze her feet.
Epiphany - Sophia was elected queen and Gorion John, king. A banquet was served in honour of their majesties in the Senior Girls' dining room. As they entered we sang God Save the King and entertained them with music and songs. That evening, Fathers, Sisters, Brothers and pupils had a skating party with music on the boys rink. Ruth Bear, Roland Whitebear and several other sang through the microphone. The party was followed by a swell lunch, to which Father Principal sweetly contributed a box of chocolates.

Girls' Sports: * Results of a hockey game between Brother Montgrand and the Senior Girls: Brother 22, Girls 2.
* From the medium girls: "After Christmas Father Principal provided us with skates. How we enjoyed our skating parties on holidays! Now that summer is coming, swings, merry-go-round, ball and picnics are our best recreation. Father Dion has also given us a nice football."
* From the small girls: "Now that spring has come, guess what we play? Not only little baby games, oh no! We play baseball. We do not play yet like the big ones and we never break windows, but just the same we have many good players."

Nature Hike: May 21 found everybody in Grade III looking happy. It was a beautiful sunshiny day, and a hike had been promised for the afternoon...We had no sooner started to climb one of the hills when a rabbit darted away at the sight of so many children. But James Tuckanow finally caught the rabbit stuck in a low bush. A box was at once prepared for the rabbit so as to take him home alive. The following day, however, he was allowed to go back home and hop up and down the hills in freedom. When the butterflies, beetles, wild flowers and weeds were carefully collected, we had a fine lunch of bananas and cake.

Fun and Frolic: Several bingo and card parties took place during the year in the different playrooms. The most popular seem to be those in which the Senior Girls invite the Senior Boys. In turn the boys invited the girls to their skating parties, and waltzed them around the rink with grave courtesy. Hikes, picnics, hunts, cornroasts, too numerous to mention, have also been part of each playroom's fun.

Dramatics

This year the pupils took a very active part in dramatics. Four plays were presented throughout the school year with great success. Plenty of work is attached to dramatics. One rehearsal follows another, until the director is satisfied that the actions, emphasis, tone, are perfect. Our reward arrives on the night of the first performance, and in knowing that we are putting the play over with success.

The Golden Slipper: Directed by Sister Herauf, this play was entered in the local festival with an all-girl cast, and every part was well acted. The interest of the audience was held throughout the play. The costumes were beautiful.

This play was entered in the local dramatic festival and won top honors. Willie Dumont brought more honors to the school by winning the medal for the best actor, in portraying the Property Man. This play was invited to take part in the Regina Festival. Here the competition was much keener. Again we had the honour of winning, which placed us in the Southern Saskatchewan finals in Moose Jaw.

Although the play had received the most applause, and its cast was the only one to be called back on the stage for a second curtain, we came second, one point behind the winning play.

The Musical Clock

The boys and girls have again during their school year made a good showing in music. The band under the direction of Father Laviolette and the Senior Girls' chorus directed by Sister Gosselin are certainly to be complimented for the enjoyable entertainment they gave us. The first concert was given on January 25 in honor of Mr. Ostrander. Here, the girls sang "Welcome Song" and Brahms' "Lullaby". The band played "Sharpshooters' March" and other selections such as "Lindenau" and "Cuckoo Waltz". Gracie Lavallee and Helen Therese Bellegarde rendered a solo. Mr. Ostrander assured us that he had greatly enjoyed this programme.

The second concert was held on February 7, on Father Principal's feast. The musical programme consisted of selections by the band, girls' chorus and numbers by Grade 2 and Grade 3, with also a piano duet by two young pianists. The Grade 3 boys and girls sang the "Fest Song", Shirley Capo, Louise Poitras, Ruth Ann Cyr and Alice Fugar of Grade 3 sang "Gentle Night". They were accompanied by Lorraine and Barbara Bellegarde. "The Pells of St. Mary's" sung in two parts by the Senior Girls was warmly applauded. The evening was most enjoyable.

Two other public appearances were made. On May 16, the band and chorus accompanied the dramatists to Iorrie. Then on May 24, the boys and girls gave an "Open Air Concert" for the sick people at the Indian Hospital in Fort Qu'Appelle. The Senior Girls on this occasion sang "Come to the Fair" for the first time. Besides such concerts, the chorus took part in an "Amateur Night" in the Lebret Town Hall on March 21. They won a $5 prize for the highest mark.

Religious music is also of interest. Two new Latin hymns, well worth mentioning, have been learnt this year; Jesus Salvator and Christus Resurrexit. Sister Gosselin is director.

Many compliments to our organists, both the accomplished ones and the beginners. Special thanks to Mary Doota for her readiness to teach the organ to the beginners. We must not forget to mention our very young pianists. These are Ruth Ann Cyr, Louise Poitras, Lorraine and Barbara Bellegarde, Shirley Capo, Esther Wajuhunta, and Shirley Bellegarde. Although they do not play perfectly yet, they have done marvelous work.

Musical Festival

On the evening of May 13, at 8 o'clock, the Lebret Town Hall opened its doors to all music lovers for the third musical festival. So once again our boys and girls exhibited their musical talents. This time they carried back not only the highest mark in many competitions, but also awards and scholarships.

To the enjoyment of all the audience, on the adjudicator's signal, the Instrumental Ensemble tuned in with the snappy music of "Indian Trail" and Golden Spur. Eight boys then proceeded with their playing of Mendelssohn's "On Wings of Song" on various band instruments. These boys were Charlie Bellegarde, Billy Bellegarde, Sam Cappo, Clifford Goodwill, Kenneth Goodwill, Gilbert Bellegarde, Alfred Lavallee and Gordon John. All were given very good marks; but Gordon who played the Euphonium with extra smoothness deserved the highest mark, which was $4. He was awarded not only a silver medal but also a $10 scholarship.

The harsher tone of brass and horn was then replaced by a smoother one. And that is, of course, by the delicate voices of our soloists, Helen Therese Bellegarde, Mary Julia Episkenow and Gracie Lavallee. The three were praised by the adjudicator for "their pleasing voices". Helen Therese, who charmed the adjudicator with her sweet little voice, obtained a scholarship for $25. Wonderful work, Helen!

More honors for our school kept rolling in during the next day's sessions. For in the morning the Grade II pupils performed a very attractive singing game "Fly Away Crow". The little ones worked their way up to an 87 mark. So three cheers for the farmers and crows!

Choruses and boys' vocal solos were the main attractions of the afternoon's sessions. Both the Grade II and the Grade 7 and 8 Girls' Choruses were very much enjoyed by all. We're very happy to say that the girls' chorus, who sang "There Is Joy in the Song We Sing" and "Fairy Belle", came out first of their group with 85 ½. The adjudicator, Mr. Ian Barrie, remarked that the work was very nicely done, musically good, had a sweet tone, pure and clean but that the words needed more vitality.

In the boys' vocal solos, only one of our boys took part, and that is no other than Willie Dumont. Willie sang with much expression "The Spider Hunter", and although he did not win either a medal or a scholarship, he came in third with 84 ½. We enjoyed your song very much, Willie!

In the evening the band played Laurentian Echoes and Sharpshooters' March. Their performance was highly praised by the adjudicator, who awarded it 88 ½, the highest mark of all the festival.

Although our director was absent most of the time this year, the band under the direction of Mr. Bedard has continued its improvement. Greater success would be obtained if the revenues of our public appearances were used for purchasing better instruments.

Background: The Hugonard Cadet Corps was organized in 1944 by Lieut. Maurice Bedard with a strength of 31 cadets. This corps came first at the annual inspection made by Major P.C. Jardine, Cpt Pearce and Sgt. M.Jr. Vint.

In 1945 the corps was reorganized with Lieut. Bedard and Mr. F. Verreault as instructors and a strength of 49. The inspection was made in May by the same officers, who reported they were much impressed by its fine performance.

The corps continued its work in 1946 with Lieut. Ed. Doll as instructor and Lieut. Bedard in administration, with a strength of 50.

Activities of the Year: Most of our time was spent in lectures given by our instructor Mr. Doll. In Fundamentals we learnt of the organization and purpose of the Cadet movement, of military ranks and badges, etc. Another activity was First Aid, where we studied the treatment of shock, fractures, bleeding and so on. In Woodcraft we covered such topics as living outdoors, building camp fires, outfitting, handling boats and canoes. We did not do much drill during the year, but received some training in tactics in preparation for the coming inspection. We have Physical Training nearly every day with Mr. Bedard, and once in a while also some Small Arms Training.

Protection

Tuberculosis is a contagious disease. The germ which causes the disease is spread from a person who is ill with tuberculosis to healthy persons.

Every time a tuberculous person coughs millions, even billions of these germs are spread into the air for a distance of at least ten to fifteen feet. The sputum raised is completely filled with these germs as well. So the people around you are liable to breathe in this air, and so become infected if you are careless in your coughing and raising of sputum.

If you cover your mouth every time you cough, and carefully spit into your sputum box, then the danger to people about you is very slight.

These germs, usually enter the body with the air that is breathed, but they are also swallowed, reaching the stomach and intestines, when food which is contaminated with the germs is eaten.

The germs of tuberculosis seem to prefer the lungs as a place to settle and grow — thus so many people have lung tuberculosis. On the other hand the germs at times are able to enter the blood stream, and thus drift throughout the body, settling down in various locations, such as bones and joints, the kidneys, and the coverings of the brain.

Wherever the germs are found in the body, the only real weapon we have to fight them is our body resistance. There is no magic medicine yet discovered which can kill these germs.

The body resistance can be compared to an army. The blood and its cells are the soldiers. In order to overcome the germs of tuberculosis, we must rest all the time, so that our soldiers can spend all their time fighting the germs.

This fight usually takes months or even years to win, but our soldiers finally overcome the germs either killing them or placing them in prison (surrounding the germs with scar tissue). Then and only then can we return to our normal way of living.

(Cont'd)
So to each and every one of you I say:

1. protect your loved ones and those who look after you by ALWAYS covering your mouth, and using your sputum box.

2. take all the rest you can, and so help your body soldiers win their fight over the germs of tuberculosis.

H. Meltzer, M.D.

A WORD FROM OUR DENTIST.

In our hospital there is a team. It is comprised of every member of the hospital staff. It has a captain, Dr. Meltzer, and the whole team is working to get our patients well.

The dental clinic is going to try to be a worthy member of this team. Our job is to see that every patient has a clean and healthy mouth. This can be accomplished only by the fullest co-operation between the patient and dentist. While we are sick, it is only natural that our gums show a weakened condition. They become spongy and tend to bleed. If this condition is allowed to progress, particles of food stick in the crevices and form pyorrhea pockets, and cause dental caries.

This condition can be overcome by more careful cleaning of the teeth, massaging the gums, and the use of mouth washes.

We are most anxious to help. So, any time you have dental problems come, and pay us a visit.

H.M. McCaffery, D.D.S.

A FAREWELL MESSAGE.

It is with a feeling of regret that my first contribution to the Arrow must also be my last. As you all know, Dr. Bill and myself are leaving the Charles Camsell Hospital in order to continue our studies in medicine. We have enjoyed our year here very, very much. We have enjoyed meeting people from places as far apart as Holmon Island and Cardston and all the territory in between. In looking after patients with tuberculosis, one has an opportunity to get to know the patients very well. In that respect it has been a very profitable year to us.

We have also greatly enjoyed our association with Dr. Meltzer, Dr. Matas and Dr. Porth. We have learned a great deal from them. Before we came to this hospital we had done very little work with tuberculosis, so that we were learning all the time from them as well as doing our best to help the patients. We think you are very fortunate to have these doctors.

The nurses here, too, we have found to be grand to work with. You are very lucky to have such fine nurses to care for you.

We are both sad and happy at leaving. Sad because we have had such a good year and we hate to leave it but happy that we have the opportunity for further study. We wish you all the best of luck in your efforts to overcome your disease. We will look forward to receiving monthly copies of the Arrow in order to keep in touch with you all.

Good-bye and best of luck.

M. Barclay

MY TRIP TO THE YUKON.

On July 22 I started for the Yukon to see about the Indians there and in northern British Columbia and between here and there. I took with me Nurse Helen Larkin who was going in to help look after them.

The Yukon is a very big country covered with low mountains and with many rivers. The Indians, here, do not live on large reserves, but in villages. The biggest village is made up of perhaps thirty families and there are many of only two or three families. It is a good fur and game country and the Indians spend most of their time in the bush, hunting and trapping. Some catch and eat fish. They are not very poor people but many of them live along the rivers a long way from town. Not many of the children ever get to school, but, you would be surprised how many of them speak English for all that.

There is quite a lot of tuberculosis here. Many of those who have it never get to a hospital nor do they want to go to one. The well are catching the disease from the sick and I do not see how tuberculosis is ever going to be stamped out if hospital treatment cannot be arranged for them.

These people look and dress the same as other Indians but they speak a language which Indians in Alberta could not understand.

Now, if you look at a map you will see how we went, by train to Dawson Creek where the Alaska Highway begins, then by bus to Fort St. John on the Highway, and from there by aeroplane to White Horse in

(Cont'd)
the Yukon. It was open country with plenty of hills and bush until we got away north of Fort St. John. From there we went over mountains which were not very high.

White Horse is a small town, not as big as Wetaskiwin, on the Lewes river, often called the Yukon river. It has a great airport on a high hill above the town. There is a railway to Skagway, Alaska, on the Pacific Ocean. Many summer visitors come in by the railway to see this country where the sun stays up nearly all night in the summer.

From Whitehorse we drove fifty miles to Carcross. Here is found an Indian Boarding School. The boarding school is small and the buildings are not very good, but the children looked happier than some I have seen in larger and richer buildings. They are learning to read and write just like other school pupils. They had the mumps. We had the X-Ray with us and made chest films of all the Indians. Here are found also, a few families of Indians living in fairly good houses. Some trap for a living and some work on the railway.

On returning to Whitehorse I took the plane to Dawson, five hundred miles north, down the river. This is where they dug the gold fifty years ago. You can read about it in the poems by Robert Service. I passed over Lake Laberge, where Mr. Service says they tried to burn the dead body of Sam McGee. All that happened was that he thawed out and said that he was warm for the first time since he left his home in the States. They still dig gold at Dawson but now they use big machines. As they dig they find the horns of big elephants who lived in that country about a hundred thousand years ago. They must have been big animals for their horns or tusks are about eight feet long and as big as a fence post.

It is so far north that the ground never thaws out at Dawson, but it does thaw enough on the top so that they can plant gardens and raise good potatoes. In the middle of summer it never gets really dark and at Christmas they see the sun for only an hour or so.

Near Dawson is an Indian village called Moosehide. Nearly all the Indians were away hunting but we saw an old blind man, Richard Martin, his wife, two or three old women and one family. Their homes were not very good.

(Cont'd).
I came back to Whitehorse by plane and spent three days with the nurses and Indian agent. We talked about what could be done to make sick Indians well and keep the well Indians from getting sick.

From Whitehorse I took the plane south to Fort Nelson, on the Alaska Highway. The Indian agent from Fort St. John met me there with his truck. We saw some Indian people at Fort Nelson. There is a school there for the Indian and white children and a missionary.

Then by the Alaska Highway we came to an Indian village where there is a day school and a missionary teaching. There is a gas well there. There we no people at home, but we found them camped beside the road about thirty miles away on their way to the mountains to shoot moose, caribou, mountain sheep and bears. They were having a dinner of meat. They like meat and will not eat any other food if they can get enough of it. Each person had a horse and tents, blankets and grub were carried on a wagon.

After driving all day we came to Fort St. John by evening. The Indians of that Agency do not live on reserves, except at one place. They hunt and trap over a country covering a distance equal to that from Edmonton to Calgary. They have many horses and move to a new place as soon as the horses eat up the grass where they are. Here, too, we find a great deal of tuberculosis, and it is going to be hard to do very much about it, as the people never stay in one place for more than a few days, and very few families ever stay together for any length of time.

From Fort St. John I flew back to Edmonton. It was a great trip but I didn't see any place better than Edmonton, Hobbema, Blackfoot, Sarcee, Morley, the Blood, the Peigan or Saddle Lake.

Dr. E.L. Stone.
WARD I.

Helen Laroque, Ruby Cutknife, Mary Littlechild, Lucien Roughfoot, Mary Listner and Lena Cardinal enjoyed a car ride last week. We visited the Journal building and saw the press. From there we went to the south side over the high level bridge. On our way home we passed the airport. Then we came home by way of St. Albert Trail. Ruby Cutknife did not recognize the staff units, as we passed them, and said, "These cottages look like the Camsell Hospital." She must have been badly mixed up. We enjoyed our ride very much and hope to have another one soon.

Many of our people stopped to visit us on their way home from Lac St. Ann. Every year hundreds of people go there for a pilgrimage.

WARD II.

On Wednesday, July 30, ten of us girls went for a very interesting car ride to McGavin's Bakery. After we were shown through the bakery we were each given a nice package of cookies. We enjoyed the ride so much that we wished we need not come back to be in a hospital again. But the cookies helped to make up for that.

Violet Cutknife from Hobbema has not been feeling so well lately and has been moved to a private ward. We were sorry to see her moved and hope that she will soon be well and moved back again.

Agnes is the only one who gets local mail regularly. Lucky girl, isn't she? I wonder from whom?

We are glad to welcome three new girls to our ward: Ruth Kennedy, Lillian Frank and Yvonne Tibbet.

On July 22, Adeline Jackson and Delia Cardinal were fortunate in having visits from their folks. Delia had not seen her relatives for almost a year.

(Cont'd)
One morning Lily Papin was playing with a wheel chair and suddenly over she went, wheel chair and all! Lily is the chief entertainer in the ward and is always doing something to make us laugh.

We can have an orchestra without instruments. Eliza Whitehead plays well on an imaginary guitar and Agnes Augibelle turns a pillow and stick into a violin and bow. The music is so good we dance to it.

We are glad our teacher, Mrs. Grantham, is back from her holidays. While she was away we enjoyed reading story books but now we must get busy with school work again. Mrs. Kerans showed us a nice picture show while Mrs. Grantham was away.

We were sorry our night nurse, Mrs. Jesse, was ill. It was nice of Miss Kautz to take her place and we appreciated having her.

WARD III C

We think that the name "The Camsell Arrow" for our newspaper is very suitable. We are very pleased to have our own newspaper so that we may hear from the other patients. We all wish our paper every success and will look forward to it each month with pleasure.

On Tuesday July 22, we had the pleasure of seeing two Educational shows, the story of Rubber and on Fishing. It was very interesting to see where rubber came from and how useful articles were made out of it. We are looking forward to the next one, so that we may learn more about our surroundings. We wish to thank those who make these shows possible.

On Tuesday Nellie curled her hair so tightly that she couldn't close her eyes to go to sleep.

Maggie Royal and Margaret Eaglechild are both in casts. They are very fond of one another. Sometimes, however, they get into arguments and wave their fists at one another but we just laugh at them and they soon get over it.

We think Maggie must be trying to run a store. She has everything on her table but the kitchen sink. She even boasts of having a

(Cont'd)
toboggan but it is not on display with her other goods as she sleeps on it.

We wish to express a word of thanks and appreciation to our doctors, nurses and staff for the many kindnesses and their efforts to please us and keep us happy. Sometimes we may appear to be rebellious, but at heart we know that all regulations are made with the sole object of restoring us to health. We also wish to thank those who provide entertainment, and the teachers for their lessons, books and picture shows. Especially did we appreciate Dr. Meltzer's talk to us in the last "Arrow". Most of us understand what the doctor expects of us and will try to do what is asked.

WARD III F.

Three of us go out walking every day. On August the first we were walking along the highway when a black cat crossed the road in front of us. We said it meant "bad luck". Elizabeth Villeneuve wouldn't believe us. But, sure enough, she had the bad luck, for she fell into a ditch. When we go out we leave Ethel Coutoreille all alone. She enjoys herself reading and playing cards.

A new patient, Leona Chalifoux, from Grouard, came into our ward a week ago. We are very pleased to have her with us.

During the rainstorm last week we had quite a time dodging the drips from the ceiling.

We had a lady in our ward weighing 275 pounds. One day she quarrelled with a little girl of 7 who called her a "big egg". They have both gone home.

Dr. Porth comes to see us every day. All the patients like him. We hope he'll be our doctor till we go home.

WARD X A.

On July 9, we went for a car ride. We saw the different types of dairy cows at the university farms. It was a real pleasure to see the outside again after being indoors for so long. We hope we may have another ride soon.

On Friday we had watermelon for supper for the first time. Harry Kigiona had never seen watermelon before because his home is almost at the north pole. We had to laugh at him because he didn't seem to know what to do with it.

On July 13 three of the boys went outside for rest period for the first time. They seemed to enjoy it so much. They liked to watch the small animals and birds that came around.

Richard Dick is the best patient in our ward. Keep it up Richard, and you'll be well soon.

Emile Quinn is our violinist. If he works hard at it maybe some day he'll be a great man in the music world.

We would like to make an entry in the weight contest. We have a lad that has gained 51 pounds in eleven weeks. He now weighs 195 pounds. Can anyone top that?

Abraham Okpik is a wonderful friend to us. He makes our ward a much happier place.

WARD X B.

One night the patients were disturbed by a visitor who came in the back door without a pass from the doctor. The sad part of it is that he died in the ward. No inquest will be held. Don't feel badly, folks, it was only a mouse.

(Cont'd)

Robert Onespot and Ernest Horseman are having an eating contest. They are to clean their plates every meal for a month. After one week Robert gave up, because of a pain in his stomach. So Ernest was the winner.

Dear Mr. Editor:

This issue of the School paper contains a farewell to those who are graduating from School this spring, and I am glad to be able to add my wishes to those Junior pupils who will be ending their days at St. Michael's at this time.

Over 1,300 boys and girls have passed through these walls through the years of our history. There may be great changes in the future when the recommendation of the Special Parliamentary Committee comes into effect, but it is certain that St. Michael's will continue to make a worthwhile contribution to the education of the Indian people on the Pacific Coast.

The group who leave us at the end of June to take their place in the school of Life will be on trial. They will be judged by those with whom they work, in their homes, and in their villages.

What do people expect of St. Michael's Graduates? They expect something different. Perhaps a better education, but certainly a better character. The influence and training given you over the years should make for Christian character.

Remember it is not only the Graduates that are on trial - but our School, our Staff, will all be judged by the way you live.

Do not let yourselves down, do not let the School down, do not let the School Staff down.

May God bless you all.

Your sincere friend and Principal,

S.J. Wickens

S.J. Wickens,
MESSAGE TO THE GRADUATES

As you graduate from this school you have come to one of the turning points in your life. From the protection and guidance of life in school, you go back to your village to take part in another way of living. It will bring you the great happiness of being with your family, but nevertheless, it will undoubtedly present some problems to be overcome in the greater freedom of village life.

While in school it has been our aim to give you the knowledge which will help you to meet these problems and overcome any difficulties.

During the past year you have developed greatly, and one may say with confidence that you will become useful members of your communities. You have shown the quality of leadership and you will have many opportunities in future to use this gift. Do not be discouraged when difficulties come to you, but hold fast to the teachings you have been given, stand firm for what you know is right. Be honest, true, and faithful.

May God bless you all and give you His guidance in the new life which is opening before you.

D.M. Lucas,
P.M. Lucas,
Head Master.

My Friends:

Once more we have reached the completion of another school year. I feel that this year has been a very successful one, both for the students and for the staff.

Each one of you has advanced further into the state of womanhood and manhood and I trust that as you continue to advance you will remember the foundation of "good citizenship" in which we have tried to instruct you. Loyalty and Honesty are the two main items which make the "inspector worthy of his hire". It is not how much we can get out of life that counts, but how much we put into it for the benefit of others that pays us on the day of reckoning.

There will never be any need for a Graduate of St. Michael's School to hang the head in shame if you practice the Christian principles in which you have been instructed. Your road is long, and the fight is hard, but each one of you has the strength and ability to succeed if you keep honesty on your side.

It has been a great pleasure to have worked with such fine, outstanding boys and girls. I wish you one and all a very pleasant and successful holiday.

Your friend,

T.H. Bulteel,
Vice-Principal.
School Days

Grade Eight

I don't think there is anybody who graduates from a school, and forgets everything he has learned. Nor does he forget the fun he had in all his school days. It gives him a nice feeling when he looks back and thinks of all the things he used to do in school. Sometimes he laughs at the silly mistakes he made when he was young, but he is probably ashamed when he thinks of the bad things he did.

Some people who have the opportunity to go to school never think of going to higher grades. All they think of is leaving school when they finish grade eight, and having a good time. Those who don't have the opportunity to go to school are the ones who do their best to keep on. Often it is not until one is older that he realizes how important an education is. Then he is sorry for not having carried on. He finds that living an adult life or "loafing around" is not so much fun after all. Learning while young makes later life easier.

So, boys and girls, do your best while you are still young. Don't be foolish and just stop when you get to grade eight. The best days of your lives are your—

SCHOOL DAYS!

Louisa Morvon

To those of you who are coming back I hope that you will not do many of the things that I have done. I used to gaze out of the window when I was supposed to be studying or doing my work. When our exams came I studied the last minute and didn't have enough time. My marks weren't very high, so I hope you will try hard in your lessons. I hope that you will all keep on in school and get a good education.

I know what it is like in school. Sometimes I wished I were not then something new and hard came up. I fooled around when I didn't know how to do the subject that was new to me. Of course I had to do it when I got up in the higher grades, so please try your best while you have the chance.

Gloria Morvon

When I was at the Day School at home, I did not learn very much. I always ran away from school. Early in the morning we would sneak our clothes out and go up to the lake and stay there the whole day. When I went home my mother used to find out that I had not been to school that day, and she would spank me and tell me not to run away from school. I would be good for about two days, and then I would start to run away again. I was still in Grade One when I was sent to this school, where I have learned more than when I was at home. I have been in school for seven years. If I pass my exams this year I would like to go on to grade nine; but I wouldn't mind doing grade eight over again. If, however, I don't come back next year, I won't forget "St. Michael's School" where I have had so much fun.

Kenneth Windsor
School Days - (continued)

My six years at St. Michael's have been happy ones. Although I have been scolded at times, I ought to thank those staff members who punished me or gave me a tongue lashing, as this is the only way I could learn not to talk back or give dirty looks.

Among the many things I have learned while here, is the art of farming - how to run the machinery, care for the animals, and plant and harvest the crops. I also had a course in Animal Training, which will come in handy some day. But most important of all I have learned to be obedient to those who are younger.

I want to thank the Principal and his staff for giving me a good time during my stay at St. Michael's.

- Rev. Robinson

The reason why I like a Residential school better than a Day School is, because we learn a lot more. I started school at home in a Day school, and I'm sorry to say that I didn't go to school every day. I played with some of my friends instead of going to school sometimes, until I came to this Residential school. Now I can't stay out of school even if I want to. Perhaps we would learn more if we had more teachers here and a whole day of school, but it can't be helped now, and we learn a lot more things than at any Day school. In the Ojibwa we learn how to march, shoot, and many other things that may help us in the future. I don't think any Day school has things like the Ojibwa. We learn to work with our hands, and to use many different tools. I know it is hard to leave your parents, but it is better for you in the end.

- James Cook

In St. Michael's School we have made many friends that we would not have met anywhere else. We were kind of shy when we first came, but the boys and girls were friendly to us and made us happy. When we were lonely these friends cheered us up. Now I've been here for five years. I try to do the same for the new boys who come each year. St. Michael's School is the best school I have ever attended, and I will never forget "Good old St. Michael's", nor all the things the staff have done for me.

- Percy Campbell

If I were to be given another chance of coming back to St. Michael's School next year, I would certainly accept it. Now that it is getting near the end of the school year, I am beginning to realize the benefits of this school. I didn't want to stay here, I wanted to go home, but after a while I began to like it. Now I don't want to leave. I've been here six and a half years, and I hope the Principal will let me come back for another year.

There are a great many things I neglected to do, just because I was careless. One of the things I did often was to waste my time in school. In our classes I usually finished my work first, and that was usually before the time was up. I had some extra time, but I was foolish enough to waste it. I just sat and daydreamed. When my teacher used to ask me about that, and I used to think that she was just pickin' on me. Now I don't, I guess I know better now, but I still waste my time once in a while. There are some subjects I don't like in school, but I do them, because if I don't, I won't be able to pass on to grade nine.

- Alvin McKay
VALEDICTORY ADDRESS

June 16th 1947

Greetings to the Principal, Staff, Graduates, boys and girls of St. Michael's School, and friends.

On behalf of the boys and girls of St. Michael's I wish to thank the Principal, Head Matron, Vice-Principal, and staff for all they have done for us during our stay at St. Michael's, for education, friendships, and a broader view of life through having lived away from home although we have missed our parents a great deal at times.

Now we are to meet the challenge of Life, but we trust that with the aid of God's help, and the outlook on life given us at school, we may go forth into the world with high ideals, and our eyes raised to the noble goal of being the best person possible. We hope all tried our best, faltered, and sometimes failed, but I think what we have learned will stay with us, and as we look back we will remember all the good things we learned and will practice them more steadfastly when we are on our own, than when we had the school to lean on and guide us.

ACTIVITIES 1946 - 1947

This has been a great year even though we were in quarantine for nearly three months. We certainly appreciated the shows we had each Saturday afternoon during that time. We also thought it nice of Mrs. Wickens and her helpers to open the candy counter for us each week.

Our first big party of the year was Halloween. It was a great success and everyone was dressed in gay fashion. We marched up the stairs and through the dormitories so the Lower School could have a look at us. Also made a funny clown and made us laugh all evening.

We did the same things at Christmas as we usually do. The school was beautifully decorated and we were sorry when we had to take down the decorations. Little "Yankie" cut the Christmas cake and my, his eyes got big and round.

We also had a nice concert this year. Some of the children sang...
and danced. The staff put on a skit. Mr. Jones was supposed to be a teacher (such a funny wig he wore!) and the other staff were his pupils. They had the same names as our own. How we laughed at them!

Our Easter Service was lovely, and the Church looked very nice that day. We had our Easter party a week later, but we certainly had a grand time. The boys' orchestra played a few pieces for us.

Finally there were the Graduation Service and Exercises.—When the Graduates received their Bibles and diplomas, many a person's eyes were blurred at those last events, and I think each one sincerely meant every word of the hymn when we sang "God Be With You."

**Cadets — Boys and Girls**

The Cadets will not soon forget the past year. Lieut. Robertson inspected the Corps in May and he complimented Lt. Gifford and the Cadets on their fine performance. He said that he had seen "a lot worse Cadets in Victoria."

We were proud to have Bishop Sexton, Rear-Admiral Laingay, and Capt. Evans, take the salute as we marched to our Confirmation Service. Rear-Admiral Laingay is in command of the Pacific Coast.

In May the Cadets paraded with the sailors who made a "stop-off" at Alert Bay for a few hours. Again on the 24th of May they took part in the Lay Day parade.

The end of another school year has come and the end of my term as Sergeant-major. I would like to thank all the Cadets, both boys and girls, for their cooperation. It has been a great privilege and a lot of fun being Sergeant-major. Although there has been quite a lot of work to do, I have usually enjoyed doing it. I hope the Cadets will behave as well with their new Sergeant-major as they did with me.

Always remember that whether you are a Sergeant or a Private you are an important part of the Corps. Everybody has to play his part in order to accomplish anything; and always keep in mind that you have to work up from the bottom in order to get to the top.

In closing, I wish to thank Mr. Gifford for all the things he has taught me. If it weren't for his help, me when I didn't know what to do, I guess I couldn't have done very well.

— Alvin McKay

This is a wonderful privilege of having the opportunity to write about my Cadet Girls and the work I have done with them as a Sergeant-major.

There are so many nice things about them that I can never express in words. Of course there have been miserable days when they have got into trouble for things that they shouldn't have done, but I used we all have our ups and downs.

Looking back to when I began my duty as a Sergeant-major, I feel very happy and proud of all the different girls that have become Cadets, now ranking near the top. These girls worked hard to be a credit to their parents and school, besides trying to earn marks for their teams.

It is very simple to spell or pronounce the word "Cadet", but being a Cadet is quite a difficult thing for some boys and girls. Each one must learn to take and obey orders.

Now that I am older, I understand this better, and I appreciate
Galeto - Boys and Girls (continued)

all that has been taught me by both staff and pupils. I hope as long as this school stands, there will always be boy and girl co-educators who will prove a credit to their instructors.

SPORTS

Through sports we learn to be good losers as well as good winners. This is the way we can learn to make good citizens.

In a Democracy, the people choose their leaders through a system of voting. The majority always wins. In order to make good citizens, the minority must be good "losers" and be willing to support the chosen leader.

By participating in sports, we also learn to do whatever the captain says, to cooperate with others, and most of all to "give and take." This is one of the ways we may learn to become one of the "third group of Indians" mentioned in the Brief that the Native Brotherhood presented to the Special Joint Committee at Ottawa.

So, "kids" continue to take this advantage of preparing yourself for the future.

THE PARLIAMENTARY OBSERVER

To sum up one's impressions of the evidence given to the Parliamentary Committee on Indian Affairs in the past two years it seems evident that two factors in improving the status of the Indians will be immediately acted upon.

These are up-to-date legislation, together with a more streamlined administrative policy, and, secondly, a larger financial appropriation. Public opinion has reacted favourably to the pressing needs of the Indian population of Canada. The Indian problem tends to aggravate itself yearly with the increasing rate of births. We can foresee a 200,000 Indian population within the next 30 years.

There remains, however, an element of the problem which cannot be solved; neither by legislation nor by money. This is the Indian's own code of standards of progress such as the present state of our civilization exemplifies. There are standards of living which are commonly accepted in North America, and which can be attained by anyone, provided a reasonable effort is made. Whether the Indian wishes to become a full-fledged citizen or not, it remains that no degree of self-sufficiency and of freedom can be obtained without a minimum of effort.

When one considers that millions of immigrants have come to America in the past century, penniless, and have through their own personal efforts and ingenuity, achieved an honored position through their education and wealth in our society, it is hard for the ordinary citizen to conceive that a group of privileged people should be perpetuated under governmental care forever. This is the case for the Indians of our country. The Indians have undeniable rights granted them by Treaties; these rights, however, are sometimes extended by some persons a long way beyond what was originally promised in the Treaties.

It would do well to consider that what was actually promised in the text of the Treaties, in many instances, did not amount to very much; and it would not be rash to affirm that the Government of Canada, as a whole, has done for the Indians a great deal more than what was promised in the Treaties. No matter what the new legislation may be, no amount of additional grants of money are to be spent to improve the lot of the Indian population so remote that unless the native population takes hold of the present opportunity and uses it to achieve progress through their industry no real change for the better will be made.

The example set by the numerous Indians who have attained economic independence would induce everybody to strive to rely upon their own personal effort and earnest toil. Thus the solution of the Indian problem will be hastened considerably.

There are groups in Ontario, in British Columbia, and in other provinces, as well as numerous individuals throughout Canada who have advanced to a stage that renders them undistinguishable from their white neighbors. In general, however, the reserve system has unfortunately engendered conditions of economic dependency which have killed outright the initiative, courage, independence for which the Indians were so well noted before the arrival of the white population.

New Appointments To Indian Health Services

OTTAWA—To help meet the need for better health services for Canada's Indians and Eskimos, two regional medical superintendents for Quebec and the Eastern Arctic have been appointed in the Indian health services directorate of the Department of National Health and Welfare and the acting director of Indian health has been confirmed in that position by the Civil Service Commission.

Confirmed in the post of director in which he has acted since January 1946 is Dr. J.M. O'Leary of Ottawa. Dr. O.R.A. Lercou, for the past 11 years with the Royal Army Medical Corps, has been appointed for the Quebec region and for the Eastern Arctic area. Dr. H.W. Lewis of Ottawa since 1931 in Indian medical work in the northern parts of Alberta and Saskatchewan. (Dr. Lewis was making his second trip to the north, his first in his new post, on the "Nootka" wrecked off Baffin Island.)

Expansion of the health services to the Indians and Eskimos is part of a long-range plan to meet the health and welfare needs of a widely-scattered and nomadic group.

It would be unfair, therefore, to lay the blame for the Indians' failure to advance entirely upon the Indians themselves, as the fundamental failure was with the system of administration used in the past, and with the lack of sufficient funds allotted to the Indian Affairs Branch.

Now given a chance with a new and adequate modern legislation for the Indians, and the assurance of increased funds, it is hoped that the Indians will receive an education which will make them economically self-sufficient, and that they will be given a training to govern themselves, to accept responsibility, to handle money and to generally fit themselves to a much higher standard of living.

In the evening of Sept. 1, Caughnawaga Indians gave a splendid theatrical representation recalling the history of their tribe and the triumph of civilization over paganism.

MIDLAND, Ont., Aug. 3.—Standing Rock, the much sought Huron Portal to the "Land of Souls," remained a closed door to the past. The heart of Huron mythology, Standing Rock was frequently mentioned in the relations and reports of the Jesuit missions to the Hurons, and the lights or reflection of village fires commented upon. The object of the test was to light a huge Indian-type fire on the village site and motor the 40 miles from Standing Rock to the look-out point above the ruins of old Fort Ste. Marie, checking either the flames or the reflection with these ancient reports penned as far back as 1636.

A party, headed by J. N. Bourrie, and Wilfred Jury, curator, Museum of Indian Archaeology, University of Western Ontario, left the proposed village site the main test. A large swinging electric light had been erected from Standing Rock, itself situated on the summit of the village flat lands, on the Blue Mountain, where the end of the Niagara escarpment towers over the surrounding country, some eight miles from the Canadian National Collingwood station.

At a point about 20 miles north, on the shore of Nottawasaga Bay, the light could be seen distinctly, but there was no trace of the fire or its reflections. At French's Hill, about seven miles from Fort Ste. Marie, the light was thought to have blinked, but the view was indefinite. Plans were made to re-light the fire on Saturday night at the same hour, but thunder clouds gathered above the mountain and a drenching rain fell. It was as if the Thunder Bird or the Huron Spirit of the Storm had flown across three centuries to defeat the project.

The actual site of Standing Rock is such as would give rise to the Huron legend. It projects upwards and outward from a bare side of a cliff. Some tremendous convulsion of nature thrust it from the main cliff and deposited it where we see it today, the mountain, dropping to 90 feet in depth, might easily be looked upon by primitive Hurons as torn asunder by the mighty spirit of the rock.

There are three possible sites of Standing Rock, all the relations of 1636, a Jesuit writer, Father John de Brebeuf, at Thonatiria, eight miles inland from the mouth of Nottawasaga Bay, says "one day I asked one of our savages, where he thought Village was, described it was. He answered that it was in the direction of the Petun country, that is towards the west eight leagues from us, and that some had seen them as they journeyed on. The road they followed was wide and paved well and that they passed near a rock, which they called Ekaremioni-di. It was often found embellished with the paint which they used to daub their faces."

Huron Quotation poses two questions to investigators, first why was Standing Rock in the Petun, or tobacco, nation country. These first growers of Tobacco in Ontario, were the enemies of the Hurons. A clue may be found in the Huron name for them—People Who Spoke the Same Tongue." It is believed that originally they were a part of the Hurons and later broke away; the second question is the derivation of Ekaremioni-di—a better translation, either as "The Rock That Stands Up," or "The Rock That Stands Out," the inland rock stands up in a rocky open country, it is further stated that the departed souls, "passed by Standing Rock and were seen no more."

Indian Trappers Voluntarily Restrict Beaver Catch

Native trappers of northern Saskatchewan have been conservative conscious to the point of sacrificing several thousands of dollars on this year's catch, the Hon. J. L. Phelps, Minister of Natural Resources of the Sask. Government said when announcing that more than ten percent of the beaver trapping seals issued last March had been returned unused. The seals had been distributed to Indians in proportion to the number of beaver in the conservation area was believed capable of supporting.

In returning the seals the Indians said they had cut their traps so that there might be a sustained catch from year to year and thus ensure a constant source of livelihood. Trappers from the Sipamok, Reindeer Lake, Pelican Narrows, Red Earth, Wabwood and Love were among those who voluntarily restricted their catch.

Making a survey of the beaver population the trappers used the figures as a basis to set the number of pelts to be taken. Trapping was less than allowed by the provincial Game Branch more than 300 seals were returned to head office amounting to a loss of approximately $30.00 on each seal taken, Mr. Phelps said.

"The Trappers in this area have shown community spirit to the extent that they distributed their muskrat catch returns proportionately among every man, woman and child in their conservation area. At Canoe Lake the Indians decided to forego the catching of muskrat for fear that the beaver in the vicinity might accidentally get caught", the minister stated. The transplanting of nuisance beaver from the south of the province is continued with some 500 being live trapped for transportation to the north this year. Special permits are issued for trapping in the south where beaver are surplus and destructive, Mr. Phelps pointed out.
The Only True Sacrifice

As man had not in himself the power to offer an acceptable sacrifice to God, and as God could make him holy by purifying him from his sins, Christ, the Son of God made man, could be the only one whose sacrifice would be accepted by God.

As St. Paul writes in his Epistle to the Hebrews: "Sacrifice and holocaust for sin Thou wouldest not, for they did not please Thee. Then I said: Behold I come to do Thy will." (Hebr. X: 6-9).

The first picture shows Jesus, the Son of God, coming from heaven, at His Father's bidding, to offer Himself as a victim in the sacrifice which would save mankind. Christ is shown here wearing a stole, sign of his priesthood, and the cross is shown the cross on which He would die. On the right is shown the altar of the sacrifices of the Jews, which sacrifices God could not accept.

The only true sacrifice, therefore, is the Incarnation of Jesus Christ, that is God the Son becoming man in order to sanctify the human race. Mankind is "sacrificed" in Christ—as "sacrificed" means "made holy."

The word "Christ" means "anointed." Priests, victims, kings were anointed with oil as a symbol of consecration. As the oil penetrates through any substance, the divinity of the Son of God penetrates and makes holy human nature, through His birth as the Son of the Virgin Mary.

The second picture illustrates the Virgin Mary offering to God, the Father, her living Son Jesus, as a victim. The Holy Ghost is pictured as a dove. The whole picture shows the mystery of Incarnation: the Son of God becoming man, by the operation of the Holy Ghost, in order to sacrifice Himself as a victim for the salvation of mankind.

As the blood of the animals offered up to God could not satisfy the justice of God, nor purify mankind from its sinful state, the infinite merit of the God-Man, shedding His Precious Blood, could be accepted by God as a satisfactory sacrifice.

The third picture shows Christ dying on the Cross and shedding His Blood in a chalice. The word "chalice" comes from it is often used in the Scriptures in such expressions as 'the chalice of salvation,' in reference to the shedding of Christ's blood—therefore His death—for the salvation of mankind.

Duck Population Greatly Improved

BRANDON, Man.—Western Canada's duck situation has greatly improved during the last month, executives of the Canadian Federation of Game and Fish associations were told here by Bert Cartwright, chief naturalist of Ducks Unlimited Canada.

The situation has brightened what had previously been a dark picture of the waterfowl situation, with bag limits having been drastically altered in both Canada and the United States in attempts to cope with these former poor reports.

"Manitoba still remains the poorest of the three prairie provinces," Mr. Cartwright said, "but even there the birds are more numerous than expected."

He said migrations from North and South Dakota may have been responsible for the increased bird life in western Canada.
