SEA MONSTER SEEN BY INDIANS

ALBANY, Ont.—British Columbia's Ogopogo and Scotland's Loch Ness monster better look out—there's a new sea serpent and he's a dandy, by all accounts.

The new sea serpent is unnamed as yet, but he's becoming a familiar character to those permanently attached to this wide spot on the Albany river on the west James Bay 100 miles north of the Canadian National Railways' transcontinental line.

Discovery of the monster can be credited to a Toronto newspaper reporter on a flying vacation. But he has little evidence to back up the story. Creel Indians here are quite familiar with the creature.

According to Mrs. David Sagetehaway, the creature is "something like a big snake. It's as big as a barrel, and it goes under the water. The head was covered with hair and the thing had a mane like a horse. It undulated as it went through the water."

The Indians naturally were skeptical, so Daniel Wopese went out in a freighter canoe with an outboard motor. He broke all speed records coming back. He said that he had seen the "thing" and that it was too horrible to describe.

South Sea Islanders May have American Origin

LIMA, Peru, July 19—Radio reports say six Norwegian scientists sailing a frail balsa wood and bamboo craft have successfully completed a 3,500-mile crossing of the south Pacific by reaching the Marquesas Islands.

Headed by Thor Heyerdahl, 32-year-old ethnologist and archeologist the expedition was designed chiefly to prove his theory that the South Sea Islands were populated originally by a pre-historic South American people who crossed the Pacific on rafts impelled by ocean currents.
The Patriarch Abraham

Many years after the human race had scattered from Babel, there lived in Ur, a herdsman called Thare, who had three sons, one of whom was called Abram. (Ur is in Chaldee, see Map).

They moved their family from Ur to Haran. After Thare's death God told Abram to leave his native land, and He promised Abram he would be the father of a great nation. In obedience to God Abram moved to the land of Chanaan; when Abram reached the city of Si-chem God said to Abram: "To thy children I will give this land."

Abram built altars to God. Then as a famine spread over the land he moved to Egypt in order to escape it. Returning to Chanaan, Abram settled down near Bethel. Abram grew very rich.

Some time later foreign kings invaded the country, making prisoner the nephew of Abram, Lot; Abram went to war to rescue his nephew, and on his return from the battle, Abram was blessed by the King of Sodom. The prayer of God, who in thanksgiving offered a sacrifice of bread and wine. After this victory God made a covenant (or treaty) with Abram, saying: "I am thy protector," said God, "and thy reward is exceedingly great. Look up to heaven and count thy stars at their count, so shall thy descendants be." (Second picture).

Thus God chose one nation to belong to Him in a very special manner. Abram was to be the father of the "Chosen People." God changed Abram's name to "Abraham" meaning "Father of a multitude." A son was born to Abraham, named Isaac.

To test the faith of Abraham God called on him one night and told him: "Take your son Isaac and go to a mountain which I shall show you and offer him to Me as a sacrifice." Having travelled three days Abraham saw the mountain; then he climbed with Isaac, there he built an altar placed wood upon it, and bound Isaac and placed him on the altar; as Abraham reached for his sword and was about to slay Isaac an Angel stopped him: "Do not lay your hand upon the boy. Now I know thou fearest God and hast not spared thy only-begotten Son for His sake." (Third picture).

Abraham took Isaac off the altar, and offered up instead a ram as a sacrifice to God.

Thus Abraham died his son Isaac married Rebecca. Abraham lived to the age of one hundred and seventy-five years. His life was filled with exemplary faith in God and trust in Him. Abraham was buried in Hebron, near his wife Sara.

How God wants us to serve Him

II. THE SECOND COMMANDMENT OF THE CHURCH.

By this law the Church imposes the obligation of fasting and abstinence from meat on certain days of the year.

The Church has good reasons for doing so: Fasting and abstinence are beneficial both for the body and the soul.

Moderation in eating sharpens the power of the mind. It strengthens the will power and brings the body in subjection to the soul. Our bodies, like wild animals, need to be tamed, so they will be receptive to spiritual food.

Moderation in eating is a most powerful means to overcome temptations of the devil, for the body is his best weapon.

Moderation in eating improves the health: "He that is temperate shall prolong his life." (Ecclus. 37, 34). "A moderate man also rejoices with sound and sound sleep." (Ecclus. 37, 34).

Fasting inclines to prayer. It helps one to master himself. It is a remedy against sin. By fasting the Ninivites obtained mercy for their sins.

The Preface for Lent sings of Christ, whose grace, through bodily fast, restrains our vices, uplifts our mind and grants to us strength and rewards.

Fasting is commanded on all days of Lent.

ABSTINENCE from meat must be observed on all Fridays of the year, except those on which is celebrated a Holyday of Obligation. In case the Church will not impose penance upon us on days given to rejoicing.

FASTING and ABSTINENCE are observed on Wednesdays and Fridays of Lent, on Ember days, and on vigils (days preceding special Feasts).

The Ember days are 3 in number: Wednesday, Friday and Saturday.

Ember days are observed at the beginning of each season:
- in Winter: third week of Advent;
- in Spring: second week of Lent;
- in Summer: week following Pentecost Sunday;
- in Autumn: third week of September.

Vigils on which fasting and abstinence must be observed are the day preceding the four great festivals of Christmas, Pentecost, Assumption of the Blessed Virgin and All Saints' Day.

On Friday, meat, and all dishes in the preparation of which it enters, are forbidden. Fish, eggs, butter, milk, cheese etc., are permitted.

There are three reasons for this measure: Firstly, in honor of our Lord, who, on a Friday, sacrificed His flesh for us; Secondly, as a means of penance, because we can easily dispense with, and yet it is a food men generally like best. Another reason is as a reminder that we must restrain our appetite which the use of meat fosters.

During Lent, only one full meal a day is to be taken. (Either noon or in the evening.) At each meal meat must be eaten (except on Friday and Ember days). Eating between meals is forbidden; drinking is allowed.

The Law of Lent obliges all between the ages of 21 and 60, whose health and work permits. Fasting must not impair one's health or the fulfillment of his duties. (In case of doubt consult your Pastor).

The purpose of Lent is to honour our Lord's fast of forty days; it is a time of penance and sorrow for sin; a time of preparation for the great Feast of Easter.

Ember days are observed in order to pray to God for good priests, and to thank Him for the benefits received during the last season.

Confederacy of the Interior Tribes of B.C.

The object of the Confederacy is to work in union for the general welfare of our people, and to make known to the governments our requirements so that we may assist each other in the attainment of these requirements.

Last year all the chiefs of the Interior of B.C. received a circular from the Joint Committee of Parliament inquiring into the Indian Act, through our respective Indian Agents, wherein they were asked to express our opinions on the eight points contained in the circular letter. Some of the tribes replied to the circular letter, but others had not replied. We had hoped that our accredited delegates would be given an opportunity to make representations to the Joint Committee. We have been with great concern that the Native Brotherhood of B.C. has presented a brief purporting to be the desires of all the Indians in B.C. We wish to say to the Government of Canada through the Joint Committee that the Native Brotherhood of B.C. did not represent our views or opinions, and that their delegates did not have our permission to speak for us, and that Guy Williams, the alleged delegate for the unaffiliated did not speak for us, and we disavow anything which he may have taken, as it was performed without our knowledge and consent and contrary to our pleasure.

We do not approve or in any way endorse the brief presented by the Native Brotherhood of B.C. to the Joint Committee of Parliament in Ottawa during the month of May, 1947.

We desire to discuss with the Government, without delay, an adequate compensation for the rights we, the Indians, have had taken away from us, but it is to be understood that we do not abandon any of our rights until such time we accept a settlement.

We ask in a most sincere way that a Royal Commission from the Joint Committee make a tour of B.C.

A LEGEND OF THE INFANT KING

By Sister Mary Jean, O.P.

Perhaps in your school or in the church nearby, there is a little statue of the Christ Child, dressed like a tiny King and wearing a golden crown. The dress with its royal cape may be part of the statue itself, or may be made of velvet or silk and trimmed with fur or pearls. If the dress is made of cloth, very likely it is the gift to the Infant Jesus from someone who wishes to show him for favors He has granted.

Have you ever wondered why a statue of the Christ Child should be dressed this way when everyone knows that the Child on earth, He was very, very poor? One reason is, of course, that He is really the King-King of all the universe, of all the starry worlds. But there is a story about this particular little statue that children always love, and now is a very good time to tell it.

A long, long time ago, for around the world there were lived a very kind lady who was very devoted to the Infant Jesus. She was a very rich woman, and she used her riches to help the poor in memory of the poverty of the Holy Family when they were on earth. This made her very pleasing to God. You must have heard the saying that God would give her all she asked for in prayer; but God does not always answer our prayers in just the way we ask them. For the good lady had a great sorrow: she had no children of her own, and kind as she was to other people's children, she was often lonely. Finally her prayers were answered and a little son was born. But he died soon afterwards, and she was lovelier than ever.

THE CHILD WALKED

So that night she did not go to bed, but watched from behind a heavy curtain. And when all the house was quiet, a light was shining through a high window, the statue moved—and a lovely Child, all radiant with light, stepped down from the pedestal and walked down the chapel aisle and out the door! She followed Him as though in a dream. And at midnight she followed His heavenly Child as He walked up and down, the roads of the world looking for sinners to save. No wonder His little shoes and dress were worn! Hers were worn, too, when at last they slipped back into her little chapel and she saw the little figure standing on the pedestal, and the light grown. And she never again forgot to pray for sinners, so they say.

How much of the story is true and how much a legend, it is hard to say. There really is a little statue with richly decorated dress and golden crown. It is called the "Holy Infant of Prague." It has a long history wherein the Holy Infant has blessed and cared for those who venerated His statue, and many miracles are reported by the good Carmelite priests who guard it. But whether or not there ever was such a lady, it is a good story for us to remember, especially at Christmas time. For the Holy Infant still comes at Christmas-time, to go up and down the roads of the world and look for sinners to save. When He knocks at your door, be sure to let Him in!

The Trail of Hanpa

CHAPTER III

THE VISION QUEST

Daniel had found his grandfather unable to rise from his pallet one morning; the Sun-Dreamer had taken very ill.

"Grandfather, grandfather what is the matter?" cried Daniel as he tried to lift up the heavy old man's head. He brushed the white hair away from his pain distorted face; he gave the man some cold tea to drink. The old man would not eat anything.

"Grandfather, come with me, and incense it with sweet grass... In that leather bundle is my Sun-robe... my grandson, be brave, I am going to seek the sun soon."

His heart aching, Daniel unwrapped the bundle and unfolded the Sun-robe. It was a hide, well worn, and decorated with designs with a faded yellow sun surrounded by the stars (Wicahntpi-oyate), the moon in its decline, the rainbow, and a larger star. At each corner were two wakan-tanka (pipe-blowing flutes), and tied to the four corners were eagle plumes.

With moist eyes Daniel joined his grandfather in prayer; the humble adobe shack was now a sacred shrine where unseen beings seemed to be present.

Pausing up with pillows and supported partly by Daniel, the Sun-Dreamer prayed thus:

"Wakan Tanka, look down upon me and see me. I am humble and I am pitiful. Give me a strong mind and a brave heart. I desire that all will be well with These and with me. Sun, Tunkanshila, Thou who crossest the earth, and art present down on the nation and see all, O Sun, my Lord, who was pleased to reveal to me who Thou art, and to make me to be of service to my people. Look down upon me. O moon, Hanwi, Thou who wast pleased to come with Thy sacred robe, pity me. Star Nation pity me, I commit myself to you.

Pausing for breath he added weakly:

prayer. To him the prayers of the christian were empty recitations, meaningless and void.

While his grandfather prayed to the Sun, to the Moon and to the Nation, the hero lay below. Daniel felt the mysterious power hovering over the Sun-Dreamer's bed, he united himself with all his heart and soul to his grandfather's prayers. Although he had been taught Daniel preferred to practice his religion in the pagan manner, without questioning or rationalizing just because his grandfather believed so, and told him so. It was a typical Lakota trait in him to be always subconsciously aware of the Supernatural Powers, therefore though he felt helpless and humble. While he did not actually worship or pray to the manifestations of nature which are not in themselves Wakan he saw the Wakan in all things. Faithful to the oldest tradition of his people he sought recourse to the supernatural for help. His prayer to the sun was the most ardent of all.

"The only way of communicating with the Supernatural lay in the quest for a vision. He felt inescapably the call for this effort, and he decided to call upon his kola, a cousin of his called Toto, who had already been through such an experience in his youth.

Leaving his grandfather after a few days of watchful care, in the hands of relatives, Daniel left with his cousin Toto, for the Rock Creek canyon, in the Bad Lands, some twenty miles west of White Mountain, and where Sitting Bull seeking refuge in Canada, had made once his winter camp.

For many days Daniel had forgotten all about Marianne, the only thing on his mind was that his aged grandfather was about to die, and that he went upon the sacred quest for a vision.

As the two companions rode on they saw many farmers tilling the land raising grain, but their mind and attention was fixed on the picked secluded trails so they would not be met by any one on this secret mission. The moon was very bright for this time of the year, clouds of dust raced across the horizon. The men rode in silence for several hours before reaching the secluded spot where the quest was to take place.

Arriving at the canyon, they prepared a sweat bath where Daniel cleansed himself thoroughly, in the meantime Toto disappeared into the "Wakpa", and bedded the ground with dry dead wormwood on the edge of a reed bed.

The companions remained separated; Daniel tied a white eagle feather to his close cropped hair; then naked, he ascended the hill, and laid himself down on the offerings of tobacco and of bright-hued cloth. Then he stood erect, holding reverently the sacred Pipe in one hand; and the other hand he clasped to the heavens in supplication.

He had nothing to eat, nor to drink. Now and then his voice rose in prayer, and the cool wind the rose from the deep canyon. As the night wore on, it grew colder, the chilling damp air cut and stung at him, yet he showed no physical discomfort. He never moved, except for changing the pipe from hand to hand. He had eaten nothing that day his head had become very light, his senses were so delicate and acute that even a little bit of pricking stick was unbearably intensified. There he waited on the hallowed plot, until some one came to lead him into the realm of the Wakan. If a bird called his mind heard a noise from the spirit world, if an animal came near, he might see it as a guide to his vision...

Between midnight and dawn he went and prayed; his very soul cried out to the Wakan Tanka. Lightning flashed in the West, thunder pealed, then a terrific downpour drenched his body, yet he stood there unmoved, until dawn...

That day Daniel returned home.

"How are you grandfather?" he asked entering the hut. "I am happy you came back, grandchild," answered the Sun Dreamer, "where have you been? I have waited two days for you to return... Now I know, I smell the odor of wormwood upon you" he added in a whisper.

"You have to know, grandfather," replied Daniel with reverence and in subdued tones. "I was at Cankausa Wakpa".

"What was your vision, grandchild?"

"Grandfather, I saw a great river flowing into darkness. The river was not of water, but of human faces... and these faces were of two colors: white and red... far away in the veiled horizon the river was forked and it disappeared in the darkness beyond... that is all I saw, grandfather..."

After some time, the Sun-Dreamer spoke again with effort: "Grandchild, I believe you have recognized someone in that river of faces...?"

"No one, grandfather," lied Daniel, for he had seen the face of the Sun-Dreamer in that river.

SENIOR PLAY A SUCCESS

The Senior Dramatic Club presented "The Upper Room" on April 3rd and 4th. It was the most successful production of the year. Each part was well interpreted by the actors. The simplicity and sincerity of the players impressed upon the audience the spirit of the passion. The choir of thirty voices, singing off-stage, provided a suitable background for the sacred theme. Particularly noteworthy was the singing of the lamentations during the scene depicting the death of Christ. The audience was requested before the play to remain silent between acts and to give no applause. This helped to bring home the sacredness of the play.

Special praise should be given to the veteran actor, Dominic McComber for his performance as Samuel, the servant. At no time did he overlook his part. Throughout the play he was the key figure in every action. Joe Fox, minor, as Our Lady, and Cornelius McComber, as Mary Magdalene, handled the female roles with skill.

EASTER HOLIDAY

The sky was cloudy and the days dark with the threat of rain or snow yet we had a very enjoyable time. The vacations, from April 4th to the 12th passed like one day. The Midgets and Juniors engaged in hard fought basketball games every morning. In the afternoons we all went for a walk. The Seniors stretched their legs with a four or five mile jaunt. The Juniors and Midgets joined Cowboys and Indians in the woods on top of the hill.

Every evening of the holiday was filled with some activity. Great was the joy among the Midgets when they were allowed to stay up late to see the Cow-boys' movies. The special feature of the holidays was the Senior basketball games. The girls played their games first and then cheered the boys on to victory or defeat. The walls shook from the yells of the Green, Yellow, Red and Blue teams swept into action.

Alphonse Trudeau and Julius Neg- anig tastefully decorated the Boys' Dining Room with blue, yellow and white streamers. The decorations and the green curtains gave the place an Easterly appearance. Two large paint- ings, six feet by four feet, painted by Julius, were hung in the dining room.

The hallowed name of St. Peter Claver has gone. Henceforth we shall be known as The Garnier Residential School. This name is more appropriate than St. Peter Claver. The bell in the school belfry is inscribed Garnier School and this shows that years ago it was the intention of Superior, to change the name, St. Peter Claver, honoured in South American while St. Charles Garnier was one of our own Canadian Martyrs. Therefore it is more fitting that we should honour him and ask his protection. S.P.C. was known up and down the North Shore for hard fighting, clean sportsmanship. We hope that the same adjectives will be attached to the name Garnier.

IT'S BACK TO SCHOOL WE GO

It was cloudy, but who would say it was cold, when on September first three sturdy, sun-panicked buses from Sudbury gracefully came to a stop in Wikwemikong. They were empty, but they held the eyes of the whole village. Everyone had heard the news and children had gathered in front of the old stone church and rectory built high in the forest. The school bus watched the buses speed along in procession up the last mile of curving road. As the buses came behind the other, the crowd grew mushroom-like.

Boys and girls for Spanish get ready! Girls girls in the first bus! Small girls and boys in the second bus! Older boys in the last! Without ado boys and girls took leave of parents, sisters, brothers and friends. Words were few, but feelings countless as the stuff. In each parent's heart waged a battle, the sense of loss was struggling fiercely against the hope for a happier future. That somber tone of the same struggle echoed the hearts of many a tired bus boy was evident from the deep hush that followed the closing of the school doors. However, the quickly changing countryside and a few of those magnificent views that swell the heart with Divine beauty soon healed the hearts that bled. Remember the wonderful view of bay and town just before we reached Manitowaning? Remember the strands we saw far below us at Ten Mile Point?

Perhaps the loss isn't so bad if they give us free bus rides.

A STORY in PICTURES

What do we read in pictures?

Most of us, very little. Perhaps we see a house, a man, an animal, a flower. We see so little, when in every picture there is a whole story, the background, the foreground, the main subject.

Will you read the pictures in this little book? At first glance they are just pictures of boys and girls. Perhaps you are particularly interested because some of them are your boys and girls, perhaps you do not even know any of them. Whether you know them or not, they all have their story to tell you, and it is well worth the reading.

Read these pictures slowly and carefully—get the story from every face, then put the stories together and you will have one of the truly great stories of the Missionary Educational Enterprise of the Church and Government in Canada.

School and Buildings from South Side of Assiniboine River

The school is situated on the north bank of the Assiniboine River just west of the City of Brandon, in the Province of Manitoba.

The first building was opened in September, 1885. The original register records 29 boys and 27 girls from six Indian Reserves in Manitoba in attendance.

As time went on it became necessary to enlarge and finally rebuild the school to provide accommodation for the steadily increasing number of students.

In 1929 it was felt that the building then in use had served its day and should be replaced. Plans were accordingly made to erect a modern fireproof structure on the same site. The new building was finished and opened in September, 1930. The registration this year is 175 with an average of 173 in residence.
Grades III, IV, V, VI

The beginning came a little late for some of these, but, under interested, careful teachers and staff members, development has been rapid.

In these grades pupils become acquainted with the necessity for, each one in their turn, making a contribution in labor for the well-being of the whole school. The boys in work of general mixed farming, repairs to machinery, and minor repairs to the school buildings. The girls in the general and specific duties of home making, housekeeping, cooking, sewing.

This is the end of the grade school experience, the next step is Junior High School.

Beginners to Grade II Senior

Yes, here is where we begin. For some quite early enough, for others two, three, five years later than it should have been. Parents! Guardians! Friends! What does this mean for the future of the race?

How many of these will, because of a late start, leave school before graduating?
Junior High School Grades, VII, VIII, IX

Here it is that we watch the unfolding and developing of the individual personality of the student. The exploring of many paths in his or her search for the right path.

No one reading these faces slowly and carefully could help but be enthusiastic about the possibility for their futures.

At the same time, what a challenge the opportunity to guide and help mould their characters, provides.

Collegiate Institute

This is possibly the most difficult period in the whole of school life.

Here the pupil meets the challenge to face difficulties, accept a more rigid self discipline, and prepare through further study for a vocation of service and the acceptance of the responsibilities of leadership in the various spheres of life.

My Dear Friends:

In July of this year I began my twenty-fifth year of service in Indian Mission work.

Looking back over the years there is so much for which I am thankful to Almighty God. I also see much that I would have liked to accomplish remains undone.

Looking into the future, in the light and with the experience of the past I am more than ever conscious of the immensely big task that lies ahead. Particularly am I impressed with the need for trained Indian leadership in the administrations of the Church, the Nursing and the Teaching professions.

I am today very much concerned with the seemingly indifferent attitude of our young people; their apparent unwillingness to pay the price demanded in terms of self discipline, time, and application to study; so necessary for them to attain to the academic standards required for leadership both now and in the future.

I am convinced that there is no easy way—not any short cut to economic security for our people. Blind indeed we are to all the lessons to be found in the histories of the different races and nations that have peopled this earth, if we think that suddenly—somehow tomorrow—we shall achieve, without adequate preparation today for that tomorrow.

On Friday, October 10, the teachers of Indian schools in Western Ontario met in convention at Moraviantown. The meeting was well attended by teachers and Inspectors, and was further supported by the presence of Col.B.F.Neary, Superintendent of Welfare and Training, Indian Affairs Branch. Teachers in convention are not usually very easily satisfied, but it should be said that Col.Neary succeeded in reassuring those present of the real concern of the Department in the education of the Indian people. The choice of school materials, texts and supplementary books etc., was encouraging. The most heartening feature was probably the presence of a man of Col.Neary's ability, training, experience and enthusiasm in such a position.

There have been other indications that appointments are being made with greater care than heretofore, particularly in the case of Indian Agents. The Department appears to be quite well aware that no program can succeed without a trained and effective personnel to put it into effect, especially in the field of education or administration. We rejoice that the number of these men who inspire confidence is increasing, yet we cannot quite shake off the apprehension that they are frequently prevented from carrying out their good intentions by the incomprehensible methods which governments seem to have of passing responsibility around until somewhere it is dropped and lost. It is highly frustrating to all concerned when capable men with excellent intentions are prevented from carrying out their programs by a highly involved and inefficient "system". Perhaps it is not too much to hope that one result of the parliamentary committee will be to make it possible for such men to meet a need promptly without fear of consequences.

New Zealand Letter
By Dr. Daniel J. Smith

The following items have been taken from New Zealand papers:

"Rod Indian Nurses. Maternity training will be put to use among their own people. Two Rod Indian nurses, Miss Martha Soonias and Miss Dorcas Gladstone, who arrived in New Zealand from Canada to do a two years course in maternity nursing, commenced their training at St. Helen's Hospital, Wellington. When they have finished their training they will return to Canada to work among their own people. Miss Gladstone comes from Alberta and Miss Soonias from Saskatchewan. Both say that after the wide prairies of Canada they feel shut in by the hills in Wellington and the buildings seem so tiny. Used to central heating they feel the cold inside New Zealand buildings. When they went for a walk to look for the 'drug store', that famous American and Canadian institution round which the social life of young people in those countries revolves, they did not find one. Both girls are olive skinned with dark eyes and hair. They spoke English with a pleasant accent as well as their native dialects of the Crow and Blood tribes of Indians."

"Since 1931, Dr. Gordon started travelling scholarships in obstetrics, the funds for which were derived from a foundation established by the women of New Zealand, had been granted to outstanding graduates of the Medical School in Dunedin, but the conditions of service in the Dominion were not such as to attract back to this country men with high qualifications. Dr. Gordon said: 'From the viewpoint of the welfare in gynaecology and obstetrics of the women of New Zealand, who had endowed these scholarships, I cannot but deplore the policy which is depriving the Dominion of these men who should rightly be consultants in large provincial areas. Intrigued and puzzled, I have pondered these things far into the night - many nights. Why does man always follow the rainbow seeking the pot of gold? Why does he look outside himself for that which can only be found within? Why does he look afar off for that which is to be found at home?

The Indian people have slumbered - many generations - but we are becoming aware. We are trying to rise. We shall rise. Let wisdom guide us in this time of awakening. Test all the avenues we will take.

(continued next page)
NEW ZEALAND LETTER
(continued)

See that our people are not led by interests which will take advantage of this period of awakening to further political and commercial aims, or for personal gain.

Once we had wise and honourable leaders, and we were a great nation. If we had not been great people we would not have survived the chaos and degeneration of the long period of confusion through which we have been passing. Now we desire to build again - order out of chaos. Plan well and build slowly lest we make haste to follow the paths which are not fundamentally good for us. Weigh in the balance everything we would do. Consider all the things which have depleted us, and first eliminate those weaknesses. When we ourselves, individually and collectively, have awakened within to our full stature, then nothing can prevent us from reaching our goal.

What is our goal - to become part of, and lost in, a confused, unhappy world? Are we prepared to follow the well-worn political, economical and spiritual paths of the day - man's world of today? There does it lead? Are these so-called freer people more happy, more hopeful than we? Or, do we aspire to rise above the fog to take our place in the sun - God's sun? Were not our people happy, prosperous, peaceful in that day when they lived according to the natural laws, and God's Wisdom as they interpreted it? They did not need another race to lead them.

Immediately you say: but circumstances are different now. Of course they are, and will always be as time moves on. That continuous change has served to confuse us and bring about an attitude of hopelessness, but also therein lies hope, our hope, as out of change come better things.

Everywhere we hear talk of the new era. What is a new era? Is it not a change in the understanding of the fundamentals of life, the attitude toward, and philosophy of life? Is it not a turning away from the errors of the past? Is it not a turning away from darkness into light? In every country the people cry aloud for this new era, yet everywhere is disharmony, destruction, death, and no hope is expressed. Yet, all the time there is light. In all things there is light, yet in all things man sees darkness. To those who are in light this may seem incredible, yet to God who is Light this is understood because in the beginning the end was known. To man there came darkness, yet there has always been light. Man could not see the light because he peered into darkness. To those who are trained to peer into darkness, sickness, death, the way is hard and discouraging and is ever joined to disappointment and failure, to the joylessness that darkness brings.

It is time to be joined to light, to turn our backs on darkness, to be joined to God's way - joy, health, life. Life is now in its awakening. As yet man sees not life but death. Yet even so, life is awakening and all things will know life. The present is but the result of the past, and we cannot alter the past, so let us look forward, let us look to a future that is open to those who will take it. It is not a time to follow, but a time to lead. (continued next page)
NEW ZEALAND LETTER
(concluded)

To prepare for leadership, individually or collectively, the laws are the same: self-discipline, self-development, self-training and above all, an all-consuming desire to do so. Long ago our leaders were developed from childhood for the day when they would be called upon to lead. That race which will lead its brother races must awaken, prepare, now for that day when the opening will present itself. It is evident that time is closing the present chapter; the age of exploitation of soil, animal, man. In as much as we stray from natural laws, to that degree we invite destruction, sickness, death. Man must reap that which he sows. An exploited, depleted nature must build again in all its branches. Leadership must go to those who are capable of grasping this understanding—those who can turn aside from darkness into light.

"Sacred Song"
(23rd Psalm)

1. Kitchi Manitou, Great White Eagle of my Dream! O little prayer fire
   -- my tobacco!

2. Lo! in the dusk do I repose upon the needles of the Signal Pine.

3. He restores me to myself: He blazes a good trail.

4. In the rapids, He steadies my canoe. I know no fear, O Mino Manitou.

5. Lo! unto me-nah-ga, the island of the blueberry, I am guided, and
   there, even where atchitamo, the red squirrel, hoards the butternut
   beside the secret pool of the trout, namegoss, there do I make my fire,
   by unfamiliar hills well hid. Nor have I drawn upon non-dah-min,
   my little store of corn.

6. Surely, on the Wings of the Eagle am I borne to the mountain. Hear
   me! On the wapuu waters of waning day my white canoe will move,
   gliding, soaring into the setting sun, to the land beyond tomorrow.

   Ass-e-na! This my incense! I have spoken.

Author's note:
For those who do not readily grasp the fidelity of this Ojibway
rendition of the 23rd Psalm, the following will be helpful: (1) God is
like the sacred dream of his youth, his guiding light. It is a holy
thought, only to be mentioned ceremonially, with prayer incense (tobacco).
(2) The right trail was marked, often, by a signal pine. (3) His confid-
ence in himself is restored. (4) Obvious. (5) On his journey through
strange and dangerous territory, God has led him to food in abundance,
and has found for him a hidden hollow where the smoke of his fire will
not be seen by anyone. He feels secure, doesn't have to draw upon his
reservoir store of food. (6) In the main, this is obvious; the exclama-
tion, Ass-e-na!, at the end, means "Tobacco", a little prayer cloud
which is the equivalent of "Amen". But I doubt if the white man says
"Amen!" with the same sense of absolute reverence with which the
Redman made his prayer cloud.

Wallace Havelock Robb.

The Beaver Magazine for September includes a story by Raymond Bell of the broadcasts of Rev. R.B. Horsefield. The opening paragraphs are quoted here.

"Wacheyak netotemek": with this greeting brown ears are alerted in a score of little settlements in the northern wilderness within 150 miles in every direction from Flin Flon, Manitoba. It is the opening moment of the Cree language broadcast that goes out twice a week from radio station CFAR, Flin Flon.

The idea was hatched a year ago by Rev. R.B. Horsefield, for twenty years a missionary to the Indians in northern Manitoba and Saskatchewan, and one of the compilers of the Cree dictionary published by the Anglican Church in 1838.
He knew that Indians have a hard time understanding what is going on in the white man's world, and that few white men have the time or the imagination to explain things to them. So he sought the cooperation of the management of CFR, which was readily afforded him, and began to broadcast once a week a five-minute summary of the world news.

The response was immediate. Indians stopped him on the streets of Flin Flon to tell him how much they appreciated the service, and letters began to flow in, laboriously traced on all sorts of strange scraps of paper, in pencilled syllables, with the same message, and always asking for more. At the end of a month it was found necessary to have two broadcasts a week—"Teepee Tidings" on Monday at 4.15 continuing the world survey, and "Teepee Chitchat" on Friday to answer the correspondents' letters and to pass on intimate bits of news, humorous anecdotes of the hunt and the trail, messages from patients in hospitals to their friends at home, and enquiries about the whereabouts of relatives from whom no word had been received in the ancestral lodges for many moons...."

Port Franks Flint Middens

London Free Press, July 11, 1947.

First projectile manufactory in Western Ontario, the key to Indian politics, is this site at Port Franks (on Lake Huron) explored by a University of Western Ontario excavating team led by Wilfred Jury. The diggings were made recently and reports are now being compiled. The Attawandrian Indians controlled the flint beds, at the point where the old bed of the river flows into Lake Huron. Indians carried the flints along the river bed to chipping beds... There they used granite-headed hammers to pound the flints into sharp tools and projectiles. Fine edges were procured by pounding with deer antlers. Through control of the flint beds, the Attawandrians managed to remain at peace with both the warlike Iroquois and their enemies, the Hurons and Algonquins. All three tribes needed the flints of the Attawandrians, and remained at peace with them to procure their supply. In 1640, the French, for this reason, nicknamed the Attawandrians the "Neutrals", a name which has stuck.

Midland, August 1. What may develop into one of the most important archaeological finds in ancient Huronia has been made by Wilfred Jury, curator, museum of archaeology, University of Western Ontario, at Teanocostay. Once the bulwark of Huronia's southern frontier, the site is located overlooking the Coldwater River, near Hillsdale, about 13 miles from here. As a result of a number of test holes made over an area of about two acres, Mr. Jury found evidence to show that Teanocostay had been occupied both before and after the arrival of the French in the country of the Hurons, in the first half of the 17th century, and that it had been destroyed by fire....
Youthful Indian Artist

By Humphrey Davy.

Judith Phyllis Morgan, a pretty 17-year old Indian girl who up to seven months ago never held a paint brush in her hands, today is being acclaimed by B.C. professional artists as a painter of exceptional talent. The Indian girl is the first member of her race to win the $150 scholarship offered by the B.C. Indian Arts and Crafts Society at an exhibition held in the West Coast capital recently. The exhibition was open to all Indian school children in British Columbia.

Five feet tall, with an attractive bronzed complexion, Judith is quiet and reserved; she has poise and is perfectly at ease with strangers, but is reluctant to talk about herself. She belongs to the proud Tsimsian tribe who inhabit the Skeena River in the B.C. mainland, about sixteen miles south of Prince Rupert. She has three sisters and eight brothers. Two of her brothers, Kelly and Raymond, fought in the war, the latter having been wounded in Sicily. Raymond, she says, was a skilled wood carver until he was seriously wounded in the arm when his tank blew up.

Judith was brought up in accordance with the strict traditions of her people, a famous fighting tribe. She was initiated into the secret tribal societies and was taught native tribal ritual and dances at a very early age. But her parents found the educational facilities were inadequate on the Skeena Indian reserve, and sent her to Alberni four years ago to continue her studies. She has just completed her ninth year in school.

When an art class was formed at the school last December under George Sinclair, a well-known Victoria painter, Judith from the outset showed exceptional talent. Within a few months she had outstripped her classmates, and was producing paintings fit for an art gallery. Even before her work came into public notice, people were offering her up to $100 for her works. She has refused the offers on the advice of her instructor. Judith says she got a surprise when informed she had won the scholarship; she had hoped to be able to hold her own against scores of competitors from all parts of the province. Now, greatly encouraged, she wants to continue with her work and to paint Indian scenes and the legends of her people.

Since Judith has come into public notice, she has met some of the best professional painters in British Columbia. Her paintings, along with others, are on exhibition in Vancouver. Her teacher, George Sinclair, considered hard to please, described his pupil as "a girl exceptionally talented and one who has shown great promise." He admits, however, at first he was afraid that his pupil's success might go to her head. "But I had no reason to be afraid," he says, "she is a level-headed girl and will go far with her work."

Arthur Mielke, one of the best known anthropologists in the province, and who has one of the largest private collections in Canada, said she was a "discovery." "West Coast Indians are artistically gifted," he commented. "She is undoubtedly the forerunner of many others who are to follow."

Committee Recommendations

Ottawa. - Setting up of a separate Indian affairs department with civil service preference for Indians employed on its staff was recommended by the joint parliamentary committee on Indian affairs. The committee's report, tabled in the Commons by chairman Don Brown, called for widespread changes in present Indian administration. The report also recommended appointment of the committee again next session to consider "long overdue" amendments to the Indian Act.

Other recommendations:

1. An Indian claims commission be established to inquire into the terms of all Indian treaties.
2. That enfranchisement be left for further consideration of the committee next year.
3. That the Indian Affairs Branch take "immediate steps" to remove non-Indians from reservations consistent with the wishes of the band concerned.
4. Decentralization of the Indian administration with regional directors for various parts of the Dominion.
5. Widening the competition field, now confined to local districts, for appointments as agents.
6. Abolition of the "permanent quota" for the Indian administration staff.
7. Immediate adoption of a project to erect central hospitals in northern agencies with nursing sub-stations in remote areas.
8. Statutory provision for the care of aged, infirm or blind Indians.

The committee proposed appointment of an Indian commissioner with deputy-ministerial rank as an alternative to establishment of a separate department. The commissioner would have two assistant commissioners, one of whom would be a Canadian of Indian descent.

The committee noted failure of the administration to act upon a recommendation made last year that more direct methods be used to collect land rentals on behalf of Indians. It urged that immediate steps be taken to remove this grievance.

Pending further decisions with regard to education, the committee urged that all educational matters, including the selection and appointment of teachers in Indian schools be placed under the direct and sole responsibility of the Indian Affairs Branch.

G.L.

Indian Health Services

Ottawa, July 24.

To help meet the need for better health services for Canada's Indians and Eskimos, two regional medical superintendents for Quebec and the Eastern Arctic have been appointed in the Indian Health Services Directorate of the Department of National Health and Welfare and the acting director of Indian health has been confirmed in that position by the Civil Service Commission, Hon. Paul Martin announced today.

Confirmed in the post of director in which he has acted since 1940 is Dr. P.E. Moore of Ottawa. Dr. O.R.A. Leroux, for the past 11 years with the Royal Army Medical Corps, has been appointed for the Quebec region and for the Eastern Arctic area. Dr. H.W. Lewis of Ottawa, since 1931 in Indian medical work in the northern parts of Alberta and Saskatchewan (Dr. Lewis was making his second trip to the Arctic, his first in his new post, on the "Nascopie" wrecked on Tuesday off Baffin Island).

Expansion of the health services to the Indians and Eskimos is part of a long range plan to meet the health and welfare needs of a widely-scattered and nomadic group, Mr. Martin said. The program, which is being put into effect, was first outlined in detail in 1946 to the special joint committee appointed to examine the Indian Act. Appointment of regional superintendents is expected to relieve the headquarters staff of detail work and to give better, on-the-spot service.

Dr. Moore entered Indian health work in 1931, immediately after graduation from the University of Manitoba, and for seven years was medical superintendent of the Fisher River Indian Agency in Manitoba. He came to Ottawa in 1938 as assistant superintendent of medical services in the Indian affairs branch, Department of Mines and Resources, and since 1940 has been acting head of the medical work. From 1940 to 1945 he was medical advisor on Eskimo health to the Bureau of the Northwest Territories and Yukon Affairs. He served in the Royal Air Force in the first World War.

Dr. Leroux, a graduate of the University of Ottawa and the University of Montreal, practiced at Grenville, Quebec, until 1935 when he joined the Royal Army Medical Corps. He served in the British Isles, India, Burma, British Honduras and various parts of the West Indies before being discharged this year with the rank of lieutenant-colonel.

A graduate in medicine from the University of Manitoba and in public health from the University of London, Dr. Lewis was in private practice in Winnipeg until 1928. After three years as superintendent of the Saskatoon City Hospital, he entered Indian Medical work at Fort Chipewyan, later becoming medical superintendent for northern Saskatchewan with headquarters at Battleford. He has served a total of nine years in the Canadian medical corps in the two world wars.

Thou hast opened thy hand among the stars,
And sprinkled the sea with food;

It might however, make for the more general use of the service if it contained the direction for its use of the Sunday preceding the following July 1st. Such a tragedy as Dominion Day became nothing more than a national holiday where there can be few countries which have greater cause to be thankful to God. In a world in which the grim specters of want and famine confront millions we live in the age of plenty. "A mari usque ad mare" stands as our motto, but let us not forget the Psalm from which our name came and the vision of "Dominion" which the Psalmist saw. The elements of true greatness lie in the very soul of man and can only be quickened by the sense of God's Let us make Dominion Day the occasion to reaffirm the Dominion of Christ in our souls and in our lives—So that loving Thee above all things, we may fulfill Thy gracious purpose in this land.

OUR GIRLS AND BOYS

Sermon for the Netherwood School Closing Service at St. Paul's Church, Rothesay, N.B., on June 8, 1947, by Sydenham B. Lindsay, Rector of the Church of the Advent, Westmount, Que.

Our Lord Jesus Christ says to us: "I am the Vine; ye are the branches."—St. John XV: 5.

There is no one thing in the world more valuable than a girl or boy. But the saddest spectacle possible today is that many girls and boys at the present day, is that they have little or no religion. It is certainly not their fault. These girls and boys have well-meaning parents who believe that their bodies are nourished with a balanced diet; but by strange inconsistency allow them to grow up without practically no spiritual diet. To have a child without definite religion is leaving out the most important spiritual vitamin. Religion is the meat of the soul; Christ Himself said so. Speaking of His friends He declared: "My meat is to do the will of Him that sent Me, and to accomplish His work." (John iv: 34) Many parents are challenged on this point, they become in some cases an attitude, that is hardly believable. "Why don't you give your child some religion?" we ask. "O if she wants any religion, she can have it, if she wants to go to Church, it's up to her. When she grows up, it will be time enough for her to decide how she wishes to live. We as well say about a child: "If she wants a balanced diet of milk and meat and vegetables and fruit, she can have it; but if she prefers a diet of candy and ice cream, it's up to her. She can decide about her own diet, when she grows up". But by the time she grows up, it may be too late: if she has been feeding upon the wrong kind of food, taking some essential calories and nutrients, she will have developed an unhealthy puny body, and when she has grown up, it is too late to cure the damage. It is just as foolish and just as harmful to bring up a child without any religion, as to bring her up without proper food. No girl can be or do her best without religion. Religion gives moral fibre and spiritual muscle.

Spiritual Health

If you ask what I mean by religion, I would reply: UNION WITH CHRIST. To be united with Jesus Christ is to be in a state of salvation; and salvation is nothing else than spiritual health. Christ Himself summed up the whole thing in those eight words, which I chose for our text: "I am the Vine; you are the branches. Just as a branch is nourished and fed and developed by the life of the vine, so we Christians derive everything we need spiritually by being united with Christ. By union with Him we absorb the spiritual power we need, we become inoculated with a sense of the Divine presence and the grace of God has plenty of opportunity to permeate our souls. By union with Christ the Holy Spirit guides us in difficulty and uncertainty, and makes us strong to do what we should. Union with Christ gives reality and effect to all experiences of the Christian life in prayer and worship, in the use of the Bible, in Sacraments, Christ strengthens and nourishes the Divine life in our own souls. Union with Him sanctifies our relationships one with another, our intercourse, and our friendships. There is nothing to fear in the fellowship of good friends if they have the Spirit of Christ in their hearts.

Not only is union with Christ essential, if we are going to be able to do anything but that is, we cannot get along without Christ. Individuals need Him, families need Him, nations need Him, the whole world needs Him. Christ is the only Saviour of the world, and apart from Him we cannot advance very far, we cannot achieve very much. Not long ago the representatives of the United Nations were gathered together at Moscow, for weeks; and then they disbanded after accomplishing so little. Why? They were sincere, they were all anxious to draw up a wise and just treaty, but they failed. I don't like to criticize or condemn, but I would point out, that not once did we read of these representatives kneeling down at their meetings and asking the Holy Spirit to show them what to do. We cannot get along without God; God is our greatest need. Just as the Vine provides the branches, the Vine abideth in Me, and I in Him, the sameareth much fruit: for apart from Me you can do nothing. A great statement! David (Psalm 28:1) has said that the world must make its choice between two alternatives: Christ or chaos.

Sometimes you hear a person say: "I know a man, who has given up going to Church and saying his prayers, and yet he is leading a good useful life. Yes; I know a man, whose branch may be cut off from a vine, and go on living for a while; its foliage may keep on growing, and it may even produce fruit. The explanation is that the branch has put into itself the life and fruitfulness of the vine, which it retains for some time. But how long can a branch go on like this before it withers away? And how long can a man, who cuts himself off from Christ, go on keeping to Christian ideals and principles, before he falters and weakens? It is given this advice: Any one who is leading a good life apart from Christ, would lead an even better life, if he were united with Christ. We must be united with Him, if we are going to be and do our best.

The Solution

In Christ you can find the answer to all questions, and the solution of all problems. There is one question, which everybody must answer. Many of you girls have undoubtedly answered it already, but some have not. The question is: man is. What are you going to do with your life? What is your vocation? In answering this question, put aside all thought of money and worldly advantage, and ask Christ to show you to what state of life He is calling you. Only by accepting God's vocation for you can you be really successful, making a good mark for yourself, your family, and adding lustre to the good name of your school and your country. And now it is time again for me to say, I must say how greatly I appreciate being asked to preach to you on this important occasion; it is certainly a privilege and a pleasure. In conclusion, let me say a special word to the girls of Netherwood,—in particular to those who are graduating, and yet to the entire school without exception. Most of you I don't know, but I know I am sure you are all like the ones I do know—full of life, full of charm, eager to do things. Remember there is no one thing in the world more valuable than a girl or boy, but if you are going to be your best, you must be united with Christ. You need Christ, and Christ needs you. To each one of you I say, in the blessed name of Christ, that you may be blessed, that you may be God bless your mind, that you may do your work well, God bless your feet, that you may see only God, God bless your lips, that you may have His Word, God bless your lips, that you may spread His message, God bless your hands, that you may always walk in the right path, God bless your feet, that you may walk in the right path. And may you always live for the Glory of God and the good of mankind—in Simplicity, in Sincerity, and in Service.

CANADIAN CHURCHMAN, JULY 3, 1947
GOD AND HUMAN ILLS

It is a queer quirk of human nature which puts all the blame on God when things go wrong and takes all the credit to itself when things go right. It is a strange insensibility for man to say "If God only a little make Him responsible for human ills; when during all the sunny days of life he acted as if God didn't exist; or to teach the conclusion that because human life is chaotic, therefore there is no God.

Is it not odd that, with all the boasted intellectual development of the human race, the struggle does not persist? Is it a problem as old as the race, the problem of human suffering which fastens itself not only upon the obviously wicked but also upon the presumably righteous and innocent. It is the problem which righteous Job had to face. The reluctance of men to face up to the real issue even in this twentieth century of enlightenment reveals the fact that spiritually the human race is still in its childhood.

We are still refusing to understand God's character and purpose. We still side-step the issue and refuse to take the long view of life, to see that with God one day is as a thousand years and a thousand years as one day.

"The Lord is no God" says a woman whose parents have all but reached fourscore years, years of singular happiness and freedom from the ills which beset mankind, but who now are stricken, one physically, the other mentally. "I don't believe anymore. They lived good lives. Why should they not be allowed another five years to enjoy the fruits of their labours?"

That is an unreasonable and impossible attitude, and yet in the variety of ways in which the problem affects us—war, depression, sickness, accident—it is fairly generally held. It is a denial of the interdependence of all the beings with each other. It is a belief in individual responsibility alone, an assumption that some are so virtuous as to merit immunity from suffering. It is the reducing of man to the status of an automation which is the very thing that God refuses to do.

God has created in the dignity of man. He made him His noblest creature, but in the very nature of things "male" has no meaning apart from the possibility of being ignoble. God so loved man that He made him free—free to choose Him or not to choose Him, free to do right or not-right. Without that provision freedom would not be true freedom. God may not love Him, but He has given him free will, for that is the only liberty in which love can be real and service perfect freedom. In exercising that free will mankind sometimes rises to great heights of noble living, sometimes he sinks to ignoble acts which re-act upon himself and others and result in suffering and sorrow. But God does not give up special grace; but if we have faith in God we soon come to see that sense of mind which understands that there is a balance of things which adjusts itself sooner or later, and that suffering, rightly accepted, bears rich fruit in the moulding of character. Despite all the problems it raises, it is better to be free than to bound unwillingly even to God. That is God's plan.

A few years ago Bishop Walter Carey wrote a little book entitled "Thinking Straight about this War". He gave a very lucid illustration of this problem of suffering and free will. He asked us to imagine a perfect human father. His son grows up with complete freedom, an all-clearance and a latchkey. He tells him what the risks are. After that the boy is always free to remember his father's advice and example, and if he does so he will have no inflicted punishment. But if he uses the latchkey to come in at three in the morning after drinking, then he will be punished. He has purchased himself with degradation, and his father may also be caught in the meshes of evil which others bring upon him. May be knocked down by a drunken motorist. And this is because the world is one. We are interlocked, intertwined. A man runs away with somebody else's wife. What does that mean? "It's a man's life, isn't it?" But does the devil has it got to do with anyone else? That is just where the devil comes in. It affects a deserted husband and a deserted wife and perhaps deserted children. The world is affected, downwards.

The "perfect" earthly father does with his son what God has done with all His children. If all goes well He rejoices and helps. If anything goes wrong, He grieves but still loves and is always ready to build up, but until repentance comes he can do nothing else.

This stubborn refusal to understand God's relation to man is responsible for the various ills related to the problem—fallenness, apostasies, wholesale. It is the root cause of present day unrest. It adds greatly to the very ills against which men rebel. It is responsible for the indifference to religion which betrays the frustration besetting men's minds. Honest thinking which courageously faces the issue is not only the solution of the problem itself, but the only way to secure that serenity of life which every man craves.—An editorial contributed by Canon C. A. Moulton, Church of St. Simon-the-Apostle, Toronto.

THE QUIET HOURS

CHRIST'S GREAT WORDS, "WATCH"

Among the great words of Christ there is none in which our relation to Him is revealed more intimately than the word, "Watch". In only one passage in the Gospels does He refer explicitly to His soul, His inmost being. It is in the most tense moment of his recorded experiences where He says "my soul is exceeding sorrowful even unto death, tarry ye here and watch". The watching He refers to is that the watching of the unconscious, the sleeping, the faltering of life. Not is it the curious peering of the "crystal gazer" who seeks to find out what is coming to pass. It is (1) The watching of the Sentinel; or The Shepherd o'er his flock; or The servant at his work. It has in view the warding off, of an enemy; or fidelity to duty. There is the original language which suggests "keeping awake". In Christ's world the night was divided into "watchings" measured by the times when Sentries were changed. St. Paul has the idea in mind when he bids us in the presence of the principalities and powers of darkness to put on the whole armour of soul and body, to stand in the full assurance of faith, and to be in business alert to seize every opportunity, and to do the most of it. The tragic element here is that we fall asleep when the chance to do something serviceable presents itself. The door closes and the opportunity is gone. "But once we pass this way... the door opens... charity is there which was not there before. It is the invitation. It is Christ searching the horizon for a sail. It is the lover waiting for the beloved one. Tragedy here may rise to a higher pitch. "My beloved had withdrawn himself and was gone", "How often would I have gathered you, and ye would not". "Who holds a stake in the doomed stock". It is the hunter here whose faithful watcher is faithful to his watching come in the highest moments of Christian experience, where Christ is all and no other. "Whom have I in heaven but Thee and there is none upon earth that I desire in comparison of Thee".

All this is the heart of Christian experiences. It is therefore at the heart of Christianity. It points to the Church's great opportunity. Only in the life of the Church do such experiences be hoped for and developed. Then they emerge into being; without them the world perishes.—W.C.C.

OUR WORLD—Whither Bound?

The miracles of modern science have reduced our world to the dimensions of our neighbourhoods. Within that neighbourhood a surging complexity of social and industrial forces which constitute and harmonious principle of reconciliation must be found, or else—? Nothing less than a world-wide explosion is the only alternative. And with the forces of atomic power increasingly at human disposal, explosion is not too strong a word to describe the possibility in one direction.

One point is clear enough. No nation in such a world as ours can behave as though it were independent of, or unrelated to, the universal issue. We ought to have learned that lesson already, those of us who have lived through two "World Wars". It was a common theme in my lectures in the last war that the first explosion was the lawless ambition of a megalomaniac that plunged us into the second, more widespread, convulsive, catastrophe. That, no doubt, is an over-simplification of the issue, but there is enough truth in it to encourage us to think seriously, and it is as certain as anything on earth can be that if, instead of having our interests and fate in the hands of all the facts and all the warnings, the upshot will be more complete, more universal, more convulsive, and more destructive than anything we have yet experienced; perhaps than anything we can anticipate or imagine.

We must believe that the only inference to be drawn from the unmistakable facts and tendencies is that it is dark and despairing in the extreme. And when we learn the lessons provided by history, contemporary international affairs, and a realist estimate of human nature, it is sheer madness to disregard and ignore the ground for pessimism. Christians may well ask 'Has God so completely forsaken the World He made and redeemed?' And if not, "Whither bound, this one World?"—T. W. Isherwood, Director, The Canadian School of Missions, Toronto.

RADIO CHURCH SERVICES

III

By Canon J. E. Ward

A great deal could be said about the choice of music in services of radio worship. If the music is to get across to the congregation, as it must if it is to be of any real value, several things must be remembered. First, in radio worship the congregation, in effect, have no books. If in church with all the words before them they like familiar hymns, surely there is much to be said that they will plead for these in the home. Not only are they without books but they are an interdenominational group. They do not have more truly, about two-thirds of the countless little units that listen will be of another denomination than that of the broadcasting church. It will be wise then to choose hymns that are used in common by the various denominations.

When we say they have no books this is not quite all true. Some and their nearest souls do take out their hymn books and actually sing with the broadcasting congregation. For them, hymn numbers are not sufficient. They probably have the same book. But the first words of the hymn mean a great deal. They ought not to be left to guess at them when the choir begins to sing. The announcement of the words would not help them find their place but gives them the feeling of belonging to the worshipping group. It might be a distinct gain if from time to time a complete verse might be read on the microphone in this way.

Say the Prayers

It has been the experience of the writer that immersed prayers are more musical and on a microphone than they do in church. Even in a sung service therefore it may be wise to sing the choir parts and say the actor prayers.

When we come to anthems, we enter into the field of the musical specialist here and there will be little agreement. One or two things though may be said. If the anthem is to be considered mainly as a sort of tone poem, there is little need for discussion. That kind of an anthem may have its value for an electric gramophone, but most anthems are heard in some sense as a musical commentary on a text. They are meant to add to the feeling of worship and to carry through a certain message or something more than just music to the hearer. In listening to a great many services one is given the impression that most choirmasters sacrifice the message for a striving after quality of tone. Very rarely do we hear a choir whose broadcast words are clear. Except in broadcasts of a recital type, we wonder why choirs do not perform an anthem in radio worship. One cannot help but feel that it would be a distinct gain could the words be clearly expressed and transmitted to the hearer.

Enunciation

Two things at any rate might help here. First, there is a certain type of singing in which the parts play against each other and in which the words are considerably mixed. It may be wise not to use this type more than necessary. Certainly the words must be more clearly heard when all the voices carry them alike across the stage.

Secondly, in listening to, in fact and broadcast it will be found that some choirs will articulate clearly in patches and in other places give the words so indistinctly as to be hardly distinguishable. This seems to be due partly to lack of enunciation and preparation, and partly to the degree of familiarity with either the words or music. The average choir seems to be incapable of enunciating both words and music when either one is not fairly familiar. In broadcasting one cannot help but feel that there would be a distinct gain if the choirs could give the hymns or the anthems sufficiently in advance and could be induced in some way to become so thoroughly familiar with the words, or the music, or both, that they could naturally find it easy to speak their parts. Were they taking part in a play this would be demanded of them or they could not go on the stage. They are the medium of worship and through them only can the words of the hymns and psalms and anthems, which constitute about half the service, be carried to the ears of the listeners. They are not asked to go on the stage in this way, without their books but a reasonable familiarity with what they are doing would greatly help.

The Essential Thing

Having said this, our final essential is often lost sight of in our radio services. Worship is the essential thing. That is what we are in church for. It is what we are seeking to foster and transmit, the whole feeling and spirit of worship into the homes of our listening people in such a way that they will not only listen but worship. The only instrument we have for doing this in broadcasting is the quality of the human voice. Through the voice alone can we hope to transmit the spirit for which we meet.

The choir to a great extent leads this worship. Unless they themselves worship, a great part of the meaning of the broadcast is lost. We must see that whichever we are perfectly aware that the singing is good and the reading done perfectly so far as musical or voice techniques is concerned, but we find our hearts touched and feeling no warmth of heart that draws us into a friendly spiritual circle. Maybe it is asking a great deal but it might be a good thing for churches occasionally to discuss what the purpose of a choir is, what it is in the general picture of that which we do in church on Sunday and try to send out something that is particularly needed in the shorter services that we broadcast though, which may be broadcast from churches, are virtually studio services. In these, there is no congregation present and it is easy till it is terribly easy, for the whole group both choir and speaker to let the microphone take the place of God.

In all our broadcasting activities we shall see that a great ministry, if not far greater ministry than any of us have ever dreamed of before the radio came into play. It is a ministry that brings great rewards but that also holds a great responsibility and has in it the demand for a peculiar and intimate approach which can only be attained by earnest thought. It is as a side thought thought that very short articles have been written.

R.C. Veneration of Mary Assailed

Rev. Alford Abraham, rector of the Church of St. Andrew Memorial, said in a sermon at London, Ontario, the veneration of the Virgin Mary at the Roman Catholic Marian Congress in Ottawa cannot be condoned by Anglicans if they "would be true to the Scripture and their church."

"However broad-minded and charitable they want to be," he said, "Anglicans cannot condone in any way, shape or form anything that vies with the fact that Christ is the only Mediator. There is no other name."

Mr. Abraham charged that "more and more the distinctive feature of Roman Catholicism is the cult of the Virgin Mary." He quoted the passage from the truth of the life," from John 14, verses five and six, and said it was plain that "no man cometh unto the Father but by me."

"Let it be proclaimed," he added, "from every Anglican pulpit that the mediatorial office of Christ, our great high priest, must not be compromised through the use of human names in religious invocation."

Bitterness Caused

"Let me stress however that I do not believe in bitter denunciation," he said. "It causes only bitterness and spreads bigotry. Our aim is to elicit truth and in our search we do not advocate temporizing or evasion because some people may not like what we say.

"I have no patience with critics who say this Congress should be stopped, nor with those who say that lumber should not be used for the purpose of the Congress. It has been reported that it has been heard about the use of lumber for construction of stands for the Marian Congress. Congress officials have said, however, that the lumber could be used again for ordinary purposes without damage."

Indians Need Our Help

Mention has often been made in your columns of the great need for workers in the Residential Schools. Dr. Alderwood has appealed for workers in every department of the schools and still the vacancies are filled.

The Residential School work is only part of the educational work that is undertaken by the church on behalf of the Indian people of Canada. Missions are carrying on their arduous duties among the many scattered Indian Reservations throughout the land.

We have in Saskatchewan in the Diocese of Qu'Appelle seven reservations where our work could be carried on but for the shortage of workers. There are but two full time missionaries to carry the Gospel and to interpret the Gospel by their lives to the people of five of these reserves. Two reserves are wholly neglected because there is no one who can go to them.

Two of these schools are in operation for two reserve alone, one at Little Pine and one at Red Pheasant. Teachers are needed for these schools and a great opportunity for the advancement of the educational work among the children by qualified teachers of Christian character stands out as a challenge for those who will answer the call.

The Indian Department has introduced a new plan of bursaries for teachers which should be an inducement to many to answer this call which is among the foremost that the Church sends out. The Class's holding 2nd Class Certificates are at a salary of $1,200.00 and may increase to $1,560.00, while First Class Certificates command a salary up to $1,980.00 according to special qualifications and service given.

Will City Parents Ever Understand?

"What are you going to do this summer?" a retired farmer friend of ours asked the high school son of a friend of his, as he grasped the arm of a fine husky boy of seventeen.

The Hebrew Idiom

I have just today received your issue of June 5. In passing I wish to congratulate you, not only on the vast improvement in your paper, but on your declaration of attention to continue improving. Being as it is well described as "Make-believe life in death," and though life is equally well described as a comedy of errors, it is the only way we propose.

But my immediate purpose is to comment on your editorial, "The English of The Bible." Its purpose, and in general its matter, are excellent; though personally I fancied it would have been improved by omitting the list of figures of speech and possibly introducing more illustrations. I suggest that at any rate a course would have made it more intelligible to the average reader.

But my particular point is the use of the quotation from Genesis which is God's. The use of these is not due to being better English, but to the impossibility of giving a reasonably literal translation of the original Hebrew without them. Anyone who has even a rudimentary acquaintance with Hebrew knows something of the use of the so-called "Van converter". I am not going into the exact nature of it other than to say that it is one of the most characteristic of Hebrew forms, essential to the verbal structure of the language, and that in many it is best expressed by not the literal hint of its chief purpose in the Hebrew.

I am not attempting to pose as a scholar; but you yourself will admit that apart from the Bible where its use was necessitated by the Hebrew idiom, even the standards of the translators' English would condemn translations of such a multiplication of "ands" in such a short passage anything but good form.—Harry Allan, Smooth Rock Falls, Ontario.

It was my privilege to follow the discussion of "The State of the Church in the Deanery of Mackenzie River" at our recent Provincial Synod of Rupert's Land. So critical are Church conditions in this Deanery that His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land made a special scow visitation to get as much first-hand information as possible.

In 1920 Bishop Lucas asked me to act as his deputy and pay a visit to all the parishes of the Mackenzie basin. Church conditions have changed very little since then. I thought the impressions that were made upon me then might be of some little help to our Church leaders to-day in dealing with this critical situation.

Canon Gould, Secretary of the M.S.C.C., asked me for any observations that I might care to make. Some were as follows:

One of the chief complaints that were made to me by the missionaries, was the frequent and lengthy periods of absence of the Bishop from the Diocese. I explained that Bishop was abroad in order that he might obtain more helpers and more money for the work.

Was this condition improved when this great territory was attached to the Diocese of Athabasca? The answer is definitely no. I consider it was a great blow to our work in Mackenzie River to cease to be a Diocese. The cure was not less episcopal supervision but more.

Was that brought about? My firm conviction is that the Diocese of Mackenzie River should be reconstituted with Fort Chipewyan as the See Town and that a good river boat be provided for the use of the Bishop on his parochial visits.

Not only for the sake of our Indian people who were largely Christianized by the great missioners (e.g., Bishop Bonomi, Archdeacon MacDonald, Rev. Mr. Spedding) and others, but also because of the fact that the Mackenzie is becoming a second St. Lawrence, with its great potential oil, lumber and industrial life that is being developed in that mighty land.

The native work is most important, but even more important is the white work that our Church should and must be interested in. We have pride of place in strategic centres, e.g., Fort McMurray, Fort Chipewyan, Hay River, Fort Simpson, Fort Norman (where the great oil wells are) Fort McPherson and the truly wonderful Church centre at Atklivik. Also the great mining centres that are being developed.

The north was won by our Church, are we going to throw it away? It is a great opportunity to our Collegians and younger Clergy.
