Sacraments Are Necessary

In recent months we have heard much about the few who attend church services at present day; of the many who prefer something else to church. This paucity of numbers at our services has caused great alarm in this country and in England. So much so that committees have been appointed to study the problem. The Canadian Church is considering proposals of affiliation with other bodies, believing that such unity will counteract the difficulty. We wonder sometimes if we are approaching the problem from the right angle?

I was on the train a year or two ago en route to Toronto. When about sixty miles from the destination, a man from an Ontario town boarded the train on his way home. As we moved along he pointed out many places, one of which of course was now almost dormant. This, he eagerly pointed out, was the result of Wycliffe teaching. Far be it from me to say anything of that kind. I believe the roots go deeper. With the Reformation the church of the Sacramental life of the Church was swept away. Sacraments no longer held their esteem in the eyes of the people. Under this system of Papal surveillance, that gave rise to Protestantism. This new aspect of religion, disregarding the Sacraments as necessary to Salvation, placed Christ on a pedestal. He, who had once lived among men, was now ascended far above the heavens, out of the sight of men. People were called upon to look to the Holy Spirit to fill Him. All very true, but He is not here anywhere on earth, but in heaven. With the absence of the sacramental part in worship came the necessity of introducing the social side and making it a purely moral religion. I feel we are still suffering the after effects of the Reformation and shall not improve our position by organic union with protestant bodies, or by condoning a moral and socialized form of belief, but by a return to the sacramental. The Church has always regarded the Presence of Christ in the one great Sacrament. If this strue, then His presence is not sent from the world, but presents it. It is here that men must come to know Him, receive Him and be that which is spiritually Hiskin the flesh. They must know He is not only as One who ascended, but One who is here, though hidden beneath earthly elements.—A.

Enlisting and Training Lay Leaders

By Herman J. Suet

The greatest need in leadership training for lay workers in the local church is an adequate theory of Christian education. At present too much reliance is placed on the Sunday school. The Sunday School has not outlived its usefulness, as some say. It must be strengthened. But in its very nature the Sunday school alone cannot meet the whole job of Christian education. It is a necessary part of a total program, including training in home and family and in many other church activities for nurturing the Christian life.

Lay workers for Christian education in sufficient number and of high quality will respond to the call of the church for workers when the following conditions are met:

1. The call to service must be a dignified call, officially representing the entire congregation.

2. The demands of the task must be clearly defined, with standards set high enough to challenge thoughtful people. Our aims are now too abstract and hazy to attract busy and earnest persons, our standards too low.

3. There must be a very clear spiritual emphasis. The evangelistic motive has a central place in education which must not be obscured.

4. There must be recognition and appreciation. It is a justifiable human desire to be appreciated. An important responsibility deserves high honor and teaching is one of the most essential and distinctive of services in the church. Yet often it seems a thankless task—a cheap function among church activities.

5. The church must have a long-range, intelligent plan for finding, enlisting and training lay workers. Our present haphazard, "hand-to-mouth" plan of finding teachers is destructive of morale and lowers the prestige of the Sunday school. Choosing a teacher for a class of children may be as important as choosing a pastor. The teacher may much more profoundly affect the lives of those children.

6. The church must be ready to train its new workers. Teachers must be persons with a religious experience to share. But teaching needs skill and the floundering teacher is soon discouraged. When an intelligent person accepts a job he wants to know just what is expected, just how and where to begin, and how to move forward toward definite results. Training is a task undertaken on the job and essential to sustained interest. Every failure of a volunteer leader is a hard blow to morale.

7. We shall enlist lay leaders readily in Christian education when we cease to use so largely in our lesson helps and books on educational methods, a "professional" vocabulary which leaves the average layman uninspired. We must have sound educational theory in everyday terms of the common life so that they may be understood.

Christian Education in The Local Church

By Dr. Philip Cowell Jones

Our greatest failure has been that we have been tacticians rather than strategists. One cause has been reverting to traditional denominational formulas; it is as though some imitable law had bound us to ox-cart methods in the airplane era. Perhaps the chief reason for our "survival strategy" is that we have not yet mastered our best Protestant brains.

When the war required that our industry be converted, the requisite intelligence and skill were found to be immediately available. The "know-how" latent in the Protestant Church, waiting to be requisitioned, but our most able people will not be interested in tinkering with the ox-cart.

Vacation Schools Released

Time Education, Sunday Schools—these and other agencies, which have been found useful, must be perfected and used connectedly, but the time demands long-term planning, encompassing the entire church—on parish, denominational and united Protestant levels—and confronting an age which is, to our dismay, almost completely secularized.

Some of the current issues which must be met with wisdom, vigor and persistence are the alarming incidence of divorce, the sexual revolution, the urbanization of our life, materialistic standards of success, racial and cultural bigotry, the liquor problem.

Issues of such magnitude cannot be met—to say nothing of being solved—without a long-range strategy which will affect our total program. The Christian Church cannot be sufficiently vital to be truly effective unless it undertakes to be redemptive, not only of our individual lives, but of our social institutions.

If we muster all of our available Protestant leadership, we shall discover in our Christian faith, with its Book of Life and its available Power, the incentive and the "drive" needed to infuse our people with a dynamic which will not be thwarted.

THE LAW AND THE PROPHETS: by Ernest Marshall Howse, S.T.M., Ph.D., (Ryerson Press, Toronto: $1.00) is a series of sermons "on the making of the Old Testament."

They were preached by the author to his own congregation in the Westminster United Church, Winnipeg. The first sermon is a clear and rapid survey of the rise and fall of the successive empires of the ancient Near East. The second tells the story of the travails and spiritual growth of the little nation of Israel during the seventh century B.C., the Century of Woe. Then follow three further biographical studies of the three great prophets—Jeremiah, Ezekiel and Second Isaiah. The two concluding sermons develop the return of the Jewish refugees from the Babylonian Exile and the growth of the canon of the Law. Each of these sermons is reared by the author with his evident knowledge of his subject and his enthusiasm for it; these must have been interesting and stimulating to hear. In their present form they make very good reading and are full of suggestions for any interested in interpretation of the Old Testament and making it real and alive for his hearers.

Dr. Howse's approach is historical and topographical. It is the history of empires, the characters are kings and governments and the theme is the work of the prophets which are his central theme and constitute the largest part of his message. The distinctive religious teaching of the various prophets and the religious developments of the period cannot be neglected. The author in his treatment shows how these emerge in each case out of historical situations or the personal experiences of the prophet writers. The canon of the Bible is God's Book and ours. It is completely adequate as the Source Book of our individual and separate spiritual life. Today we see His Book being embraced with widespread enthusiasm, and we hear the cry: "We must put content into our Christian teaching." Indeed, we must turn back to the Book and know what we believe, but we must look back at what we must advance. Theological ideas alone do not automatically save. Indeed if we communicate to others an individual salvation alone, this may be but a retreat from reality; for true redemption is in the life process or it is no redemption. We shall find in our gospel the urge to accept social responsibility or fail to meet the paganisms of our day—which threatens not only the Christian Church but all life. Discovering the true Gospel, we shall find that it involves unending struggle but in striving we shall find that we need God's power and, discovering our importance, we shall find it.

CANADIAN CHURCHMAN, JULY 3, 1947
Music and Worship

The death of Sir Sydney Nicholson removes from the sphere of contemporary Church musical circles one who combined religious devotion with his art. Those of us who had the privilege of knowing him over a long period of years will agree that our Communion has lost a master among “such as found out musical tunes.”

Sir Sydney Nicholson will always be remembered as the Organist and Choirmaster of Westminster Abbey who gave up his high position in order to devote himself to the study of Anglican Church Music and its better rendering. With this aim in view he founded the School of English Church Music, later to be honoured by His Majesty the King with the title of The Royal School of Church Music. His scheme was widely supported, and there are few places where the Anglican Communion is to be found which have not their associated choirs. The School now has its headquarters at Canterbury, a fitting home indeed.

The spirit of music is a tremendous thing. It is a gift from God “flowing from the glory of the Almighty.” By it the artist expresses, and helps others to express, the beauty, the gladness, the moving splendour of the pressions which have become his own, a part of his very self. The function of all art, like that of religion, is to make us aware of great truths. And whatever the form of the art, if the artist’s impressions are good, true, and beautiful, the expression will take care of itself.

The simplest form of religious musical expression is the hymn tune, and here, despite the highbrows, we may put in a plea that in considering the hymn tune the emotional appeal may not be forgotten. The words which the tune accompanies may be pure and faultless; and yet the hymn may miss its mark. It is easy to write down a tune as merely a mental or commonplace, yet many a hymn thus condemned has moved the hearts of millions. Such is the subtlety and mystery of musical expression. Those who have heard Sir Sydney Nicholson conduct a choir practice—not of some great Cathedral choir, but of lesser mortals in the chorister world—will recall how the great man led the souls as well as the voices of the singers and made even a hackneyed hymn sound fresh.

The Church may thank God for the care, the pains, and the devotion of her choirs and choirmasters and organists. We have become accustomed to think back on the thousands of men and women in our land who devote much time and care to this service that it has become a commonplace and we do not realize what it means. In village, town, and city this fine devoted service continues, and we shall do well to recollect this as we honour the memory of the man who, to use colloquialism, definitely put our choirs on the map, and taught the smallest and most inexperienced rascal of a choirboy something about the privilege of singing God’s praises in God’s House.—From The Scottish Guardian.

Death of Bishop Farthing

Recalls Interesting Incident

The death of Bishop Farthing, at the age of 85, has drawn from both secular and religious observers warm eulogies on his contribution to the life of the Church of England in Canada. It is interesting to recall that his career once touched the Bishop's career on a personal point. Back about 1905, Canon Farthing, of Woodstock, (as he then was) and Canon Dann, of London, went a visit or more at Fern Cottage. Both were convalescing from rather serious illness. One day the present writer received a private and confidential letter from Mr. E. B. Penne, editor of the Kingston Whig and then the leading Anglican layman in Kingston, stating that Canon Farthing was being considered for the post of Dean of the Cathedral, and asked whether, in his opinion, the Canon, whose nervous system was reported to be severely shaken, was likely to regain complete health within a reasonable time. On consulting the Canon's local physician, we were able to give Mr. Penne assurance on this point, and shortly afterwards it was announced that Canon Farthing had been appointed Dean of Kingston Cathedral. Some years afterwards he became Bishop of Montreal, a position in which he won a wide reputation for tolerance, wisdom and eloquence. Even after retiring he maintained vigour of mind and body, and continued to give much useful service.—Orillia Packet and Times.

Importance of the Bible

A Communist, who often writes and gives his views on many things, said recently that what the Bible says about God is all "stuff and nonsense." He said that God doesn't walk in the garden as the first book of the Bible tells; He walked in the Garden of Eden! God doesn't lead people as the Bible says He led the children of Israel out of Egypt! What, the Communist asked, had I to say to this?

First, it is necessary to get it clear in our minds that in these stories, the Bible is talking in pictures. What the Bible means is that God is working in the world. God is concerned not only with what takes place in churches on Sundays; God is concerned with the whole of life. It is a perversion of the truth to suppose that religion is something apart from the ordinary business of living. In the Bible there is no distinction between sacred and secular. The Bible deals with the unfolding of the purpose of God in all life. The Bible tells of the coming of God into the world's life, the act of God God working for a deliberate end. The meaning of the Bible is that we do not live in a universe where things happen without cause or reason. At the very core of the teaching of the Bible, from its earliest pages, is the belief in God as the Author and Upholder of all things, a belief in other words, that God is working in the world, that God is making history.

The Power Behind Sound Government

By The Rev. Alan Gardiner, M.A., B.D.

Today is one of the important festivals in the Christian World. It is Ascension Day. The Gospel describes the Ascension of Jesus Christ very briefly as follows. "And after Jesus had spoken these words He was taken up into heaven, and sat down at the right hand of God. And they went forth and preached everywhere, the Lord working with them, and confirming the word with signs following."

The truth embodied in this last event of His life of Jesus Christ upon earth, by that life He showed us how we should live to secure happiness and peace in the world. Now having given us a sound example of the way to go and have opened the way to the heart of our Heavenly Father by His death upon the Cross, He spends His time praying that we will give a good account of ourselves in His footsteps. The writer of the Epistle to the Hebrews tells us, "For we have not an high priest which cannot be touched with the feeling of our infirmities; but one who has been tempted in all points like as we are, yet without sin. Let us therefore come boldly unto the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy, and find grace to help in time of need." Hebrews 4:14-16.

We are living in God's world. Jesus Christ the Son of God, by His example showed us what our family life, our social life, our everyday personal life should be if people are to live in love, happiness, and peace day by day. He stated one indissoluble rule of life, "I am the vine, ye are the branches: he that abideth in Me, and I in him, the same bringeth forth much fruit; For without Me ye can do nothing." During the recent war, when things were tense, dangerous, and perilous, prevalent, all thinking people were convinced that without the presence and power of God, all of our plans and purposes for victory would have been but little. Prayers for God's help were offered daily in our churches and cathedrals. The answer to our prayers came by way of an overwhelming and convincing victory to our men and arms.

Then came the peace. Certain restraints were removed from our daily lives. The smooth waters of our civil life have been ruffled by economic disputes and social unrest. Multitudinous schemes for the establishment of peace and security at home and abroad have been suggested, some of which are being tried. Yet things are not going so smoothly as we had hoped. The Festival of the Ascension of Jesus Christ rings out the message — God reigns. He has given us the formula for securing peace at home and abroad. His formula cannot become effective until the people of our families, our communities, and our nation accept and follow the Message of our Lord and His way of life in their way of life. The heads of our families, the leaders of our communities, and the citizens of our nation must be all people everywhere all over the world to follow the example of those who witnessed the Ascension of Jesus Christ, before God's will can be expressed in our social and economic life. "They were continually in the temple, praising and blessing God." The movement in God's world cannot be achieved apart from God's presence in the minds of men.—From The Cranbrook Courier.

Normal Youth

GRAND RAPIDS, Michigan—Normal religious experience for normal youth should be the aim of church programs for youth, declared Dr. Paul Weaver of Columbia, Mo., director of the department of religion and philosophy, Stephens College, in speaking before the closing session of the Division of Religion of the International Council of Religious Education at the 25th annual meeting recently.

Opportunities for the application of Christian principles to social life in a community should be afforded through work projects, which identify religious values as the expected conduct of the normal life instead of making religion a thing apart, Dr. Weaver recommended.

"The youth of today need a cultivation of their capacity to feel in terms of objects worthy of their emotion," Dr. Weaver said. "They need sensitivity toward the real issues of life. However, we have given them self-confidence without sensitivity and that is dangerous."

Dr. Weaver scored the church for its habit of letting poor planning and inadequate preparation be the church's answer to the spectacular productions of the theatre and modern advertising.

Warning that youth makes these comparisons to the disadvantage of religion, he said:

"We can no longer countenance a lack of enthusiasm in religious programs for the youth in our churches. Our cause must have nothing but the best."

The evidence submitted to the Parliamentary Committee on Indian Affairs, between March 1st and July 2nd, of this year, comprises over 2,000 pages of testimony given by Departmental officials, professors of ethnology, in various churches which have been visited, women of various ages, an assistant Commissioner of the U.S. Indian Affairs bureau, and numerous representatives of the Indians of Canada.

In addition to sitting this evidence, along with the material gathered last year, is indeed a large one. Every phase of Indian law, administration, education, medical services and general welfare has been quite well discussed and covered either by the witnesses called or in the briefs submitted by various organizations. There are many divergences of opinions, due mostly to the great variety of Indian tribes in Canada, and to their different status.

To get a true picture of the situation one should travel through the breadth and depth of Canada from the Arctic to the Pacific, from the U.S. border to the Arctic sea. It seems that many groups of Indians are ready for local self-government; incorporation in villages, hamlets, municipalities would give them a greater degree of self-governance, assigning them with definite rights and responsibilities. For other groups, less advanced, or nomadic, it will be some time yet before they can achieve any degree of self-government.

The recommendations of the Parliamentary Committee to the House of Commons, made in their fourth report, July 10, (published elsewhere in this issue), cover the main points discussed at the advancement of the Indians. It is regrettable however that the House of Commons has not paid much attention to the recommendations made in previous Committee reports. One instance: on August 15, 1948 it has been recommended that: "more direct action be taken for the return of rentals collected on the behalf of Indian lessees", -which recommendation has not yet been implemented.

The Old Age Pension Bill did not include any provisions for the Indians, the 1949 bill report states that there are no provisions to be made for the adequate care of aged, infirm or blind Indians; and that in the meantime rations given to properly care for Indians should be sufficient in quantity and quality.

There are many recommendations which require very certain and immediate implementation without necessitating the revision of existing legislation, and which, if they were put in immediate effect would remove some of the causes out of which have arisen many grievances and complaints of many Indians.

It is hoped that the new ministerial staff for Indian Affairs will be brought to bear in full the estimates made by Departmental officials. When an Inspector of Agencies tables his estimates, usually reduced to a bare minimum, it is most distressing to him to be told to further reduce his estimates, as there is not even money enough by far, therefore to cover them. While 40 day school rooms are urgently needed in Saskatchewan alone; yet only four schools will be built this year.

A substantially larger appropriation and an immediate improvement in the administrative set-up and policy will go very far in fulfilling the obligations of Canadian citizens towards the Indians.

Indian Missionary Recommendations

Ottawa—Setting up of a separate Indians' affairs department with civil service preference for Indians employed on its staff was recommended by the joint parliamentary committee on Indians.

The committee's report, tabled in the Commons by chairman Don Brown, called for widespread changes in present Indian administration.

The report recommends re-appointment of the committee again next session to consider "long overdue" amendments to the Indian act.

Other recommendations:

1. An independent commission be established to inquire into the terms of all Indian treaties.

2. That enfranchisement be left for future consideration of the committee next year.

3. That the Indian affairs branch take "immediate steps" to remove non-Indians from reservations consistent with the wishes of the band concerned.

4. Decentralization of the Indian administration with regional directors for various parts of the Dominion.

5. Widening the competition field, now confined to local districts, for appointments as agents.

6. Abolition of the "permanent quota" for the Indian administration staff.

7. Immediate adoption of a project to erect central hospitals in northern areas and nursing sub-stations in remote areas.

8. Statutory provision for the care of aged, infirm or blind Indians.

The committee proposes appointment of an Indian commissioner with deputy-ministerial rank as an alternative to establishment of a separate ministry. The commissioner would have two assistant commissioners, one each for Indians and Catholics of Indian descent.

The committee noted failure of the administration to act upon a recommendation made last year that more Indians be employed to collect land rentals on behalf of Indians. It urged that immediate steps be taken to remedy this grievance.

Pending further decisions, the committee urged that all educational matters, including the selection and appointment of teachers and school sites be placed under the direct and sole responsibility of the Indian affairs branch.

Indian Aid Plea Made

OTTAWA—J. P. B. Osterland, inspector of Saskatchewan Indian agencies, told the joint parliamentary committee on Indians that large financial appropriations would be necessary before any program could be carried out.

He predicted "the whole work of this administration will fail" if more money is not granted for extension of education and health, upon which the future of the Indians depends.

Saskatchewan needed buildings and teachers for 40 additional day schools to accommodate 900 children.

$15 Million Grant for Indians Turned Down by Committee

OTTAWA, June 10—The joint parliamentary committee on Indian affairs rejected, not opposed, a motion recommending that at least $15,000,000 be granted to the Indian affairs branch this year.

The committee heard that Indians were in need of immediate assistance, was placed before the committee by John Blackmore, supported by G. R. Campbell.

Progressive Conservative and Liberal committee members who opposed the measure said it failed to offer a plan by which the money could be spent. They opposed the committee defer any recommendations for expenditure until an interim or final report on its proceedings could be compiled in the fall.

Mr. Blackmore argued that some money should be spent in order to give departmental officials the opportunity to show what they could do with it. He said many members of the committee were agreed that expenditures in the past had been woefully inadequate.
Survey of Remote Bands

Ottawa—An intensive survey of the economic, social, educational, and health status of one or more bands of remote Indians began in mid-June.

The purpose of the study is to examine the whole texture of life among the Indians and thereby to obtain a sound basis on which to plan ways and means of assisting the Indians to become self-supporting and to improve their way of life.

Costs are being borne by a grant of $12,000 from the Canadian Life Insurance Company. Additional funds will be raised by the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources and the Indian Health Division of the Department of National Health and Welfare. A number of the investigators are donating their services.

During the survey field activities will be carried out by specialists in agriculture, forestry, fisheries, education, nutrition, economics, sociology, and various aspects of public health and welfare.

The investigation was endorsed by the joint committee of the Senate and the House of Commons which is examining the Indian Act.

The Canadian Handicrafts Guild sponsored an exhibition of Indian crafts at the Montreal Art Association.

Last November, under the supervision of Rev. A. Paradis, O.M.I., the young men of this reservation organized a hockey team. The officers elected were Mr. Yenne, Pres., D. Lafond, Sec., D. Greyeyes, Coach.

A rink was constructed and completed in two days. Two pie and bingo parties were then held to raise funds for the team. The sum of $110 was realized from these two parties. There were also several donations.

Strenuous workouts were then held under the able eye of the coach whenever time permitted.

Shortly after Christmas, the team began to play with the nearby towns. Unfortunately, these teams proved no match for the razzle-dazzle play of our boys, and each time they were swept aside by a decisive goal.

Later the team was invited to participate in Hockey tournaments held in Blaine Lake and Shellbrook for the Albany and Demers trophies.

Courses for Indian School Cooks

Twenty cooks from Indian residential schools in various parts of the prairie provinces gathered at Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Sask., on July 3 for a week's special instruction in food preparation and service. As part of its kind ever offered to cooks in the Indian schools, it was followed by a course specially planned for cooks' assistants.

Instruction was given on how cooks may teach Indian girls proper kitchen procedures and simple courses which they will do later in their homes.

For cooks' assistants the instruction covered the more important aspects of food service with special emphasis on food preparation, cooking and cleanliness. The cooks' assistants' course began July 11 and also lasted a week.

Alberta Indians Would Rather Roam

EDMONTON—Provincial and federal government officials are wondering if they will ever succeed in getting 200 Indian signatures on the dotted line.

Two hundred Chippewa Indians, responsible for the longest holdout in the relations between the white man and the Indian, are making the 40th consecutive year they have refused to sign a treaty with the federal government.

Dominion and Alberta government officials recently returned from Rocky Mountain House, where they met here, in the latest of a series of unsuccessful attempts to induce the Indians to sign the treaty.

The party was led by M. McCrimmon, chief of the reserve division of the department of Indian affairs. He returned to Ottawa Monday night that the day is not too distant when the Chippewa band, members of the Algonquin tribe originally living in the vicinity of Lake Superior, would join their elders in signing the treaty.

The history of the Chippewa Indians opposition to treaty signing dates back to the late years of the last century when, all chiefs of the Indians nations of western Canada signed for their tribes.

Later the situation was changed so that each Indian was required to sign individually for treaty rights. During the past 40 years the Chippewa Indians have refused to sign.

Thirty thousand acres of land are provided for the Indians in the same manner as other bands but the Chippewa tribesmen rove about in nomadic style on land to which they are not actually entitled.
Caughnawaga Indians Hold Meeting

MINUTES of a meeting of the Caughnawaga Band of Indians, held at the Kateri Tekakwitha Hall in Caughnawaga, May 26th, 1947, at 8 p.m.

The Indians attending chose Mr. Tom Lahache as Chairman, who acted as such throughout the meeting; and chose Mr. L. E. Beauvais as Secretary.

After preliminary explanations, as to the purpose of the Meeting, came the question of Education for the Indians, particularly as regards denominational schools and non-denominational schools for Indians, and after a lengthy discussion by various speakers on Section 10, Sub-section 2; Section 10, Sub-section 3; and Section 10, Sub-section 2 and 3, of the Indian Act, it was unanimously decided by all Members of the Band present, as follows:

1. That the Sections of the said Indian Act above quoted, namely—Section 10, Section 100, Sub-sections 2 and 3, should remain as they are.

2. That no change in the Indian Act should be made which would prevent Catholic parents from sending their children to Catholic schools.

In answer to the following question—"Where do you want your children, or grandchildren to go to school?" each Indian present answered that they should be in favour of denominational schools, that is, to be able to send children to the school of their own faith.

It was also unanimously decided to request and urge the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources to adopt a policy of assisting and aiding Indian boys and girls to pursue studies in High Schools, Colleges, and Universities of the country, and that proper and sufficient financial assistance be given to such Indian Students by the Department.

After the fall of man from the grace of God, the earth seemed enveloped with darkness. You will find that the promise of salvation was given to men before they became numerous; and even after the destruction by the flood, the children of Noah, who were spared, in their turn also grew away from God.

God sent, from time to time, prophets, to renew among the nations the Faith in the Redeemer promised to our first parents.

To Abraham, to Isaac, to Jacob, God renewed His promises. Next to Moses, to King David, to Isaiah, next to the Prophets, finally to St. John the Baptist.

A sacrifice is essentially the offering of an object to God alone, and the consuming of it to acknowledge that He is the Creator and Lord of all.

The purpose of the sacrifice was to make the people holy. It comprised three rites or ceremonies:

1. OFFERTORY—the victim was given to the priest for him to offer it to God.

2. CONSECRATION—the victim was laid on the altar, slain, and destroyed by fire to show how completely the offerer was giving himself to God.

3. COMMUNION—a part of the offering was given back to the offerer to sanctify him.

However worthy these sacrifices were, they could certainly not satisfy the justice of God, nor could they possibly purify men from their sins.

The sacrifices made under the Old Law, foreshadowed the sacrifice of Christ on the Cross.

THE GREAT FLOOD — THE TOWER OF BABEL

When God saw that the people had become evil, He was sorry He created them, and said: "I will destroy man and all living creatures that I have created, from the face of the earth."

Among the sinful people there lived one just man who still loved God, his name was Noah. God spoke to him and said: "To punish men for their wickedness I will send rain upon the earth, and there shall be a great flood. Every living creature shall be destroyed. Only you and your family shall be saved because you have loved and obeyed Me."

God then told Noah to build an ark of wood, three stories high and divided into little rooms.

When the ark was finished God told Noah to go into the ark with his wife and his sons and their wives, also with seven pairs of clean animals and one pair of all the other living animals and other creatures, as well as much food for his family and for the animals.

It rained in torrents for forty days and nights; the waters covered the trees and the houses, and lifted the ark above the high mountains. Every creature was destroyed. The waters remained on the face of the earth for one hundred and fifty days, and gradually dried up.

Noah's ark finally rested on the top of mount Ararat in Armenia. Noah opened the ark's doors, having sent out a raven, which did not come back he sent a dove which returned. A week later he sent the dove out again, but it came back with an olive leaf; the third time the dove was sent out it did not come back.

Then Noah was commanded to leave the ark, so God he offered a sacrifice of thanksgiving to God for having saved him from the waters of the great flood.

God promised Noah that He would never again destroy the earth by water and He said: "As a sign of My promise I shall set my bow in the heavens and when I shall cover the sky with clouds and send the rain upon the earth, My rainbow shall appear and I shall see it, and remember My covenant to save you and your children and their children for all time."

After many years the human race grew larger and larger. Some of them built a large city and a tower of bricks. The tower grew taller from day to day; God saw what was in the hearts of these people, and he doomed them for their pride. Little by little the language of each family became different from that of another, and they could no longer work together; they ceased to build the city and the tower. God scattered these people from that place, called BABYLON, into all lands.

The sons of Noah were Sem, Japhet and Cham. The five sons of Sem settled in Persia, Asshria, Syr, Chaldea and Mesopotamia. The seven sons of Japhet settled in Greece, Scythia, Thrace; while the four sons of Cham went to Chanan, Ethiopia and Egypt.

Egypt was a fertile country along the banks of the river Nile; eventually the kingdom of Egypt was established at a Pharaoh. The land of Babylon was populated by the Assyrians, whose greatest king was Hamurabi. The Canaanites, who came after the Hittites dwelt; they inhabited Palestine, and later, were called Chanaanites. The human race had now begun to spread all over the face of the earth.

FLIN FLON, Man.—Another nickel-copper rush is on at Lynn lake.

The rush started when some 20 to 40 Indian residents of Sioux Indian lake, 250 miles northeast of The Pas, suddenly began applying for prospectors' licences at the recorder's office. There are promising claims between Sioux Indian Lake and Granville lake, the eastern extension of the Lynn lake exploration area.

Claims staked by the members of the native prospectors are reported carried by the Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting company and International Nickel of Canada Limited.

Although many mineral finds in the north have been recorded at the recent discovery of copper smelting rocks, this rush is unusual in that it is the first prospecting rush spearheaded by the native finders themselves.

CHAPTER II

THE DOE-MAIDEN.

As the sun rose that morning in its full glory, the song of spring burst forth from everywhere. The trilling of birds, the honking and trumpeting of the water-fowl, the gurgling of the running brooks, the softly sighing breeze, everything animate and inanimate sang the new birth of nature.

As Daniel Little was busying himself with the morning chores, he resolved to have a heart-to-heart conversation he had had the previous evening with his grandfather.

The Sun-Dreamer had attempted in vain for the past few years to induce his grandson to marry. Often he had told him: "You are a man now, in a short time you will be old before that time you must get yourself a woman and live in your own house and raise children... Look over the maidens among our people and make up your mind on one." But Daniel had always felt annoyed when his grandfather told him these things.

The previous day the patience of the Sun-Dreamer was nearly at an end because he had felt his end coming near... and he wanted security for his grandson. That is why Daniel thought he would have to go out to the ordering of presents to the Old-Wise-Stutterer as to win the hand of his daughter; the Doe-Maiden.

But Daniel did not want to be compelled into marriage, so he had refused although some notable people of his kin had done so before, by Ahlo-Hoksha and Woonikapi-anai.

He did not want to expose himself to the ridicule attached to such a practice. He was still young and confident, and why should he not wait a while and enjoy his freedom for a few more years?

After a frugal breakfast Daniel left his grandfather, having made sure he needed nothing during the time he would be away. "I will be back early in the next moon," he said.

As Daniel trotted along on his pony he was filled with joy, reverence and thankfulness at the beauty of nature. He listened with pleasure to the symphony of spring; the regular pounding of the horse's hoofs sounded like beating drums, and the jingling of the halter-chains was like merry bells.

As he went along the Willowbunch trail, his thoughts gradually returned to the Doe-Maiden, the daughter of the Stutterer. Her mother was a Lakota, and as such, she was of his own kind. Yet, when he met her face to face for the first time, quite accidentally, he had never dared raise his eyes upon her, and he had always been too bashful to speak to her, yet guiltily he thought. If he had been deliberately unmannerly and impolite, he thought, but then he excused himself: "oh well, what do I mean to pay anyway?"

Yet, today at the thought he would have to meet her, and that he would have to live at her house for several weeks, Daniel felt deep trouble rising within him. For a while he thought of turning back but the fact that he was practically penniless urged him on to his destination.

As a last compromise Daniel deliberately went out of his way to reach the ranch of LeBeque, and stopped a few hours at Scout Lake for his lunch. In the late afternoon he postponed another day, Daniel added his heavy pack, and headed back towards the ranch.

LeBeque greeted him cordially: "How Kola!" (Hello Friend). Daniel immediately set to work until dusk.

As he came into the ranch house for supper LeBeque called out his dingy name: "Marianne! Come to meet a stranger!" The girl came into the kitchen where Daniel was washing, and her father added: "Daughter, may I present to you our unknown sweetheart, Daniel Little, the grandson of the Sun-Dreamer..."

The two young people were too stunned to realize what was happening. LeBeque was so earnest, or whether he was jesting as usual. They just stood there gazing at one another. They did not even touch hands.

For the first time Daniel had set his eyes upon the beautiful maiden, he was rapt in admiration. The Doe-Maiden was the fairest daughter of the Lakotas, with raven-black hair and braided in the shape of her roundish but delicate face. Her short but comely body was graceful and poised, her eyes sparkled with excitement and the whole face glowed with delight at the sight of Daniel, and she blushed deeply.

For a few moments she too was rapt in ecstasy at the sight of the tall and erect bronze hero of her dreams. LeBeque aroused them from their trance. "Forget the introduction, Dan," he said, "have a bottle of beer, while supper is being prepared."

The women bustled themselves at the table, as it was ready all of them ate in silence. The meal over Daniel and LeBeque went out again for a while, but there was nothing said to indicate that LeBeque was further interested in the meeting of the two young people.

During the evening Daniel did not dare to look at Marianne, but he and LeBeque talked business the girl and her mother silently appraised him; they were full of silent admiration. Marianne felt ill at ease with everyone excepting her father and Daniel, and she wondered why his presence affected her so much. Daniel felt quite at home, yet there was a certain reserve in his demeanour that betrayed his innate self-consciousness.

The round up lasted two weeks. Daniel rode wide and under circuits to see every stock house. Sometimes he had to spend the night out on the range, or at some farm home, as the horses had strayed far away during the unguarded several nights.

At times Marianne worried over him, fearing some harm had come to him, and her joy at seeing him returning home after a few days absence was evident. She knew that he would not even admit to herself.

While Daniel spent another two weeks at LeBeque's—much to Marianne's regret—not only did the young people show any sign of affection or even interest in one another. At night, sometimes, Daniel would hear Marianne and Marianne would sing the words softly—and this set her dreaming but she never remained very long in his company.

When the LeBeques went to nearby Scout Lake in the evening, Daniel always found some excuse to remain at the ranch, then he would go alone on horseback and come back early before the family returned home.

One day Daniel asked LeBeque for his pay; the rancher wanted to keep him for the seeding of his crop, but Daniel went his way.

He visited his grandfather whom he had not seen for nearly a month, and nothing could prevent him from returning home when he had the urge.

When he left the house he did not say goodbye to Marianne, but she knew he was leaving. She went up to her room, watched him ride out of sight, and then she threw herself on her bed, crying bitterly.

As Daniel returned home in the early evening his heart was heavy. He realized he loved Marianne deeply. He realized the width of the gulf that separated them. She was the daughter of a well to do white man; she had been raised in comfort and luxury, and although her mother was a Lakota, she had the ideals, the culture and the customs of the white people. She was very popular among them, and many a young man had set his heart on her.

Daniel considered his own poverty and the uncertainty of his future and compared it to the steadfastness and prosperity of the white. Rightly the Lakotas called him the Washicu (Spirit-man)—because he had learned the secret of the powers of nature and had mastered them. Marianne was of a progressive race, and what could he offer to her the security and the luxuries she would expect from a husband?

"No, the Doe-Maiden will never know how much I love her," Daniel vowed to himself, "I am not worthy of her. I will go on my lone trail, the old trail of the Lakotas."

The following day Daniel went to Wood Lake and there he wrote a letter for her friend from Scout Lake. He offered her his hand in marriage.

"Dear Mr. Daniel,

Could you please make a saddle for me, report style, with square skirts, stamped with flowers throughout, I would like the following initials inscribed on it: D & M. I guess you could use any other letters. They may mean the maker and the owner of the saddle, for one thing... How soon can you fill my order?

Yours truly, Marianne LeBeque.

Daniel was astonished. This letter had been written while he was at her place; why then did she not ask him verbally? What did she really mean when she wrote those one thing... What was the other meaning?

Then it dawned upon Daniel that perhaps she too loved him, and that aside the material things of life, there were the nobler aspirations of the heart and soul which directed the actions of men.

STUDENT OF THE MOHAWK LANGUAGE

Mrs. Martha Champion Huot, of New York City, has been on the reserve for the past few months making a study of the language of the Six Nation Indians. As far as is known she is the first woman to be engaged in such research on this reserve.

Mrs. Huot has been living at No. 11 School with her ten-year-old daughter, Jennifer, and eight-year-old son, Jonathan. A grant from the Viking Fund for research in social sciences enables her to do her work. At present she is striving to receive her Ph.D. degree from Columbia University. In previous years she has done research in other Indian languages.

Concerning the Mohawk language Mrs. Huot states that it has changed a lot in the last hundred years. She says that the language, the way it is spoken today, compares quite differently with the first published works in the tongue. Pointing out that language and music are the two living parts of a culture, Mrs. Huot observed that the Iroquoian language and music have survived the influence of the white man admirably.

SETTLEMENT OF SIX NATION RESERVE

By Orma General

When America was first discovered by the early explorers of Europe, they found Canada inhabited by Iroquois, Huron and Algonquin Indians. The Iroquois tribe lived in the United States at the Mohawk Valley what is now New York State, south of Lake Ontario. The famous Iroquois had found British officials trustworthy.

In the time of the Seven Years' War Europe, England tried to tax the American colonies. The colonies revolted and declared themselves independent of Great Britain.

When the American colonies talked of celebrating the Iroquois tribe under the Mohawk Chief Joseph Brant, remained loyal to the British Crown. During that time, Captain Joseph Brant, the leader of the Iroquois tribe, came to the aid of the Loyalists. In 1775 he met King George III, the ministers of State, and many other distinguished people. He sailed homeward in the autumn of 1776. With his people he fought gallantly on the side of the Loyalists.

In the years that followed a guerrilla warfare was waged in New York between the Loyalists and the Revolutionists. It was a bitter struggle but in 1778 the Americans won the war and declared their independence from Britain.

When the war was over the whole territory of the Iroquois passed to the United States. The Iroquois tribe rather than remain under the Americans set up new homes in British territory.

In 1784 Brant went to see Sir Frederick Haldimand, the Governor of Canada in order to receive a grant of land for the Six Nations. After some agreement with the British government, Brant obtained a grant of land six miles wide on each side of the Grand River from its mouth to its source.

Brant sold most of the land which belonged to the Indians—claiming that it was a gift from God and they could not part with it as they wished. The land which is now left on the Six Nations Reserve, is about 100 square miles, the population is 5,500 people.

The majority of the people is mixed farming, the soil is very rich. There are schools, churches and a hospital for the people. Their houses are very comfortable. The people on the reserve will live and enjoy this land forever.

Phonograph Records Made by Indians Are Obtainable

Records of the songs and dances of the Six Nations Indians, performed by noted Indians from the Six Nations Reserve, are being released by William N. Fenton of the Smithsonian Institute, Washington, D.C., now available to residents of this country, according to an announcement by the U.S. Library of Congress reference department.

The records were cut in 1941, and come under the album title "Songs from the Iroquois Longhouse." The album is part of a collection of folk music from the United States.

Five records are included in the album. Songs and chants performed by district Indians include: Midwinter festival chants, medicine man celebration, corn song, war dance, war or birthing dance, warrior's stomping dance or trotting dance, women's shuffle dance.

Among the Indians who performed were Joseph Buck and Simeon Gibson, now deceased; George Buck and Chief Joseph Logan, still residents of the Reservation.

REV. ZENO PORTER

Residents of the Six Nation Reserve were shocked to learn of the passing on Tuesday, September 16, of Rev. Zeno Porter, Pastor of the Five Nations Pentecostal Church, who efforts enlarged the formerly small group of followers of the Pentecostal faith on the Reserve to such an extent that hundreds now attend the Church. Mr. Porter, who was born on the Reserve in 1895, is his 83rd year and has spent his entire career at the Pentecostal Church here.

BULLET PENETRATES HEART OF 15 YEAR-OLD GIRL

Delores Smith, 13 year old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Smith, R.R. No. 6 Hagersville, died instantly when a bullet from a .22 repeating rifle passed through her heart, early Tuesday afternoon, October 14th.

Delores and her cousin, 14 year old Fay Smith, had gone bicycle riding before returning to school for afternoon classes. They stopped at the Martin home just as Harold Martin was calling out to his wife with brother Leslie. When the gun was accidentally discharged, Harold Martin was on the veranda and Delores was standing about four feet away. Dr. C. W. McCormack, who was called from nearby, sent word to coroner, Dr. A. J. Craven in Brantford when he found the girl had met instant death. Dr. Craven and Crown Attorney, F. E. D. Macdonald, K.C. attended and, after investigation, reported that no inquest would be held.

Corporal A. H. Langille and Constable W. A. Schulz of the R.C.M.P. also investigated.

Besides her parents, Delores is mourned by two brothers, William and Robert, and four sisters, Gwen- delyn, Vivian, Myrna and Gail, and by her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. George Smith.

Funeral service was held at the home of her parents on Wednesday evening, and funeral took place at St. Paul's church on Thursday afternoon.

Iroquois History...

(Continued from a previous issue)

Degannahwide then said that since the mind of Hiawatha was now clear, he was now competent to judge. They should make laws for the Great Peace whose purpose shall be to abolish war and robbery between brothers and bring peace and quietness.

They now composed their peace song which had the power to make straight the path of Adadahro if it stood without error.

The emblems of the chieftainship titles are deer antlers which should be worn upon the heads of the confederate chiefs.

The two men then told the Mohawk Council of their plan for a council and the building of a house of peace. He Degannahwide, told them that all the chiefs must be very virtuous, patient men. These shall wear deer horns because emblem of their position because their strength comes from the meat of the deer. It was necessary to know the Mohawk Council's opinion and have its consent before they could proceed.

The two men talked about in the council and the Mohawk speaker said that they, the Mohawks, would hold to the Tree of Peace and would talk strongly for peace. Their hearts were happy at the thought of coming together.

Messengers were sent to the Oneidas (People of The Stone) to ask them if they would consider the plan.

After considering the plan for one year, Gaius Beaver (Olatshodeh), head chief of the Oneidas, said "We will join the Confederation".

Two messengers were sent toward the setting sun. They carried wampum strings and the invitation to join the Confederacy. They arrived in the country of the People of the Muckland, or Great Pipe People (Cayugas). They built their fire as was the custom and recited their message. One year from that date, the Cayugas sent word, "We do agree with Degannahwide and Hiawatha. We will hold fast to the Tree of Peace".

A runner was sent to the People of the Great Hill (Senecas). They lived toward the rising sun (west).

They were divided in their opinions. One large band lived west of the Genesee River. They were allied with the Erie Nation who were against the League. The second who resided near the Great Mountain near Canandaigua Lake, were for the League. Messengers built their smoke fires near both bands and they were both invited to join.

The People of the Great Hill were divided and would not agree because there had been trouble between their war chiefs. They asked the messengers of Degannahwide to return the next year.

But consultation finally and considered the proposals. After a year had passed, they sent messengers to say that they had agreed to enter into the Confederacy, that they would grasp the Tree of Peace.

The Onondagas Nation and the Five Hills had been approached before. The people wanted to enter the Confederacy, but had hesitated to agree officially because of their fear of Adadahro. When a messenger approached them, however, they also had agreed to enter the Confederacy.

Degannahwide requested the Mohawks to again call a council and at this council all of the people were present. At this Mohawk council the two men then reported all that had been done during the five successive years. "We have obtained the consent of the Five Nations. They are the Mohawks, the Oneidas, Cayugas, Senecas. Our desire is to form a compact for the union of our nations", he said.

"Our next step is to seek out the fire of Adadahro; it is he who always sets at naught our plans for a peace league", he said.

Hugonard wins CHALLENGE CUP.

The Cadets of Lebret Indian School are a happy lot these days. Not only did they win the efficiency award for "E" Group, but also that highly-sought award, the Challenge Cup, emblematic of top Cadet Corps in the Province for the year. Congratulations! It is a well-known fact that competition for this honour is keen, and this year was no exception, Yorkton and Star City tied for runner-up, and were not far behind the winners in points.

An outstanding feature is the fact that the Hugonard Corps has only been in operation for four years, and therefore makes the award most deserving. The Corps was organized in 1942 with Lieut. M. Bedard as Instructor, and an enrolment of 31 Cadets. They got down to business right away; and came first in their group, in the Annual Inspection that year.

In 1945, Mr. F. Verreault joined the staff to assist Lieut. Bedard, as the strength of the Corps had increased to 49. A very fine showing was made that year also. Lieut. Ed. Doll took over as Instructor in 1946, and under his guidance the Corps has made tremendous strides, hitting a peak performance this year.

At camp this year, these lads gave a good account of themselves. Remember that thrilling mile race won by Pat Fourhorns, and Pat had to be coaxed to run too.

Not content with all this, the Corps has gone on to add new laurels to its crown, competing successfully in various other events. To quote some of them:

The Baseball League Trophy, donated by the Principal of the school, Father Piche, O.M.I., was won by these lads. Teams that comprised the league were Balcarres, Lebret, Fort Qu'Appelle, and Lebret Indian School. During the hockey season these lads lost only one game. Nice going. At the annual Track and Field Meet, held at Fort Qu'Appelle in May, further honours were won. The Intermediate and Grand Aggregate Cups, and they tied with the Fort for the Senior and Junior Cups. Right in there pitching eh?

To prove that they also have talent in other directions, several members of the Band participated in the Lebret Musical Festival. All made good marks, and the Cadet Gordon John had the distinction of winning not only a silver medal, but a scholarship as well. Nice going Gord.

In Dramatics, notable success was achieved by winning the local and the Regina Festivals. THE SUPERINTENDENT'S FOREWORD

It is indeed a privilege to speak to all the members of our fellowship at the beginning of a new school year. Fully one-third are new workers who have answered our call from every part of Canada. We welcome them and wish them well, while we are thankful that so many veterans have been willing to carry on for another year.

The flowing tide in Indian Affairs The longebb has ended and the tide is flowing strongly. National interest is growing through the work of the Parliamentary Committee, through many articles in the press, and through new activity in the Indian Affairs branch. Among Indians there is a real revival and provincial organizations are gaining strength. It has meant very much that at last opportunity has been given for public expression of grievance and desire. In the Church there is also an awakening and the recent Conference of Indian Workers at Saskatoon gives evidence of this. As a result there will soon be a new S.C.C. ready to concentrate upon Indian work and to find and train recruits for it. For every quarter emphasis seems to be laid upon education as the essential basis for the advancement of our Native Canadians and it is encouraging to know that we are in the main stream of this effort.

The end for which we strive The full development of thousands of Indian and Eskimo boys and girls, in body, mind and spirit is our goal. For formative years many of them are placed in our care at a sacrifice to their parents. Many a home lacks childish laughter and high spirits for ten months of the year. How glad is our trust to them it has been said - "Take this child and nurse it for Me."

The means we must use We shall best attain our end as we respond all our works done for love of our Saviour and Lord. Realising and responding to His love we shall see each child as dear to Him and shall still be patient and kind even when childish mischief and perversity must try him. The recognition that all is done for Him and must be done in His spirit is the necessary motive and means to our high end.

Along practical lines we are confident that marked advances are being made. Our pupils are being better fed and the general level of health is undoubtedly higher today than in the front line of the war against T.B. and other scourges and the fight is being won. The transition from too much work and too little play is gradually being made, though some older workers find it hard

It is with great pleasure that we announce the appointment of Major-General G.R. Turner to the staff of the Administration. He will have general charge of the business end of our work and brings to the office very wide experience in the Canadian Army. For his military service he received the honours of D.C.M., M.C. and C.B. The following particulars of General Turner's record may be of interest.

General Turner was born and educated in New Brunswick and was engaged in railway construction engineering until August, 1914, when he enlisted in the ranks and proceeded overseas with the Engineers of the First Canadian Contingent, serving overseas throughout the First World War and reaching the rank of Major. He was appointed to the Permanent Force (R.C.E.) in 1917. General Turner served as Engineer Officer in a number of large Canadian centres (including construction work for the R.C.A.F. in northern Manitoba and Saskatchewan), as Assistant Director of Engineer Services at N.D.H.Q., Ottawa and as Instructor at the Royal Military College, Kingston. He was also on the General Staff at Ottawa and Victoria. He spent about five years in all at various military schools and colleges in England and India.

In 1939, General Turner proceeded overseas as Senior General Staff Officer, 1st Canadian Division and held various senior appointments with the Canadian Corps and the First Canadian Army. He returned to Canada in 1944 and in 1945 was Inspector General (Army) Western Canada with headquarters at Calgary. He retired in 1946, having reached the age limit for the post-war Army.

General Turner is an active member of Christ Church Cathedral parish in Ottawa, president of the Red Chevron Club of Ottawa and chairman of the Ottawa Branch, Engineering Institute of Canada.

5. That the matter of enfranchisement of Indians be left for further consideration when the Indian Act is under revision.

15. That in view of the fact that Indian reserves are widely scattered across Canada, and in view of the diversity of the problems confronting those charged with the administration of Indian Affairs, the Indian Affairs Branch should be decentralized and regional directors be appointed to look after and to determine such matters as appropriately fall within their particular regional jurisdiction.

25. That the project of building a central governmental hospital in northern Indian agencies, with nursing stations in far outlying districts, be proceeded with at once.

Having difficulty getting the children to read aloud? Miss C. Hauver at Prince Albert uses the following method to overcome the children's hesitancy. She asks a child to read from his text-book (e.g., John said, "Mary, give me your book") and then has him address the request, statement or question he has just read to a classmate, who would respond with the appropriate action or reply. In addition to this, Miss Hauver has the children enact Nursery Rhymes, while she herself is narrator. A big box at one end of the classroom contains costumes and props of a very simple nature and from this the children get hats, aprons, pie plates or whatever is required to put them 'in character'. The actors speak the dialogue and Miss Hauver reads the descriptive portions. The children apparently enjoy this way of learning their lessons and it certainly helps to develop their self-confidence.

At ELKHORN, the teachers take extra duty (e.g., dining room supervision) during the weekdays in order to have the weekend free. This plan was also being tried at Prince Albert towards the end of last term so that the teachers there might have weekends off in rotation.

Opportunities for Service in our Residential Schools

This is a very important part of our missionary work because in each school there are from 80 to 250 children in residence for almost nine years. If properly staffed with real missionaries and efficiently administered they act as the "Leaven that leavens the whole lump". In some places where schools are on Reserves, with their people all round them, they have been the means of regenerating whole tribes both socially and spiritually. They are the greatest tool at present in the hands of the Church for the propagation of that gospel of Christ, "I am come that they might have life and have it to the full". By some freak of circumstance, the Church has lost sight of their real significance and for a number of years has failed to give them the attention they deserve.

Rev. J.W. House, Old Sun School

The authorities of the residential schools are alive to the dangers of regimentation. They are trying to combat these by means of free play and games, leadership training in Guides and Scouts, etc. Besides shortness of staffs, a great handicap is lack of space in the school buildings. The older boys and girls need rooms where they can pursue their hobbies and relax away from a dingy playroom in which there are sixty to eighty other children including all the younger ones who want to play group games, skip, etc. The older boys might be encouraged to fix up for themselves a room which they could call their own, with a good big table for games, a work-bench, books and other things. The older girls would enjoy planning a sitting room where they could spend their leisure with books and magazines, games, a radio, sewing and knitting. Such a plan, if it were carefully handled, would help to give more of a home atmosphere and a sense of maturity. It could also be used to help to develop a sense of responsibility which needs to be and can be taught.

Miss W. Hinchliffe.

With regard to religious instruction in the schools, I may say that when I was in charge of the Manitoba department of Education and Welfare we brought up from Chicago university a man who was the head of the faculty of education and we had a rather heated discussion that afternoon about religious instruction in the schools and how it should be provided. And this was a distinguished educationist, a Cambridge graduate and head of the department at Chicago University, and this is what he said: Ladies and gentlemen, if you have the proper character at the head of your school, a man or a woman of exemplary character, a certain spiritual quality, one who is interested in the advancement of his or her pupils, religion is taught in that school from ten o'clock in the morning until four o'clock in the afternoon; it is taught in mathematics, it is taught in history, it is taught in accuracy in writing; but if you have at the head of that school a selfish individual, a man or woman whose moral integrity is in doubt, then religion is not taught in that school at any time, even though you make creeds and the Bible your only text books.

It was a holiday voyage up the Huron, witnessing the most magnificent sunset I have ever beheld as the clouds banked almost from the horizon amidst a profusion of color. One felt even more than among beautiful flowers that one was looking into God's Garden. Through the Soo locks the next day into vast Superior with its sea breezes and chill evenings; visiting Port Arthur and Duluth, surveying their scenic beauties; then returning again across the lake to Sault Ste. Marie for a visit to Shingwauk School, the deepest experience of all.

To be privileged to spend a few days sharing the life of those who "live their service" is something one feels rather than tells. Interested in their work for many years, this was my first actual visit to a school. The summer brought other visitors to the Soo and I was permitted to listen in on the reminiscences of earlier Shingwauk and old Mackay School. There is a comradeship which grows deep in those who have struggled for the cause with singleness of intent.

Shingwauk has the special privilege of being not only set amid beautiful surroundings but convenient to the city where graduates go to attend High School. School had not yet re-opened but nearly forty children of all ages were on hand providing a special interest with their curious, intont gaze and shy ways, yet withal lovable. What nobler task in this land than to bring children like these to a true knowledge of the living Christ and instil it into their lives to such extent and on such numbers that eventually they will prove a leaven for their whole people. It presents a challenge to us who try to help in some small way and a test to the quality and quantity of that 'Life' which radiates from us.

Bright in learning, many of the older pupils have a deep desire to develop music and art, which drives them, on their own, to the available instrument or paints to express that which is within them. Reminding us that under red skin, so called, and white alike lie hidden talents. Our own children now have these privileges within their daily curriculum; should not those of other color in this Dominion be granted a like privilege under some sponsorship?

As in other schools, the playroom for the children is lacking in equipment or toys. This also offers a further scope through which associations other than those already burdened with the upkeep and clothing might help on the work.

Among the sadder aspects was a visit to the little graveyard in the rear of the school, which tells the story of faithful workers and converts who served nobly in their day. Also, through the kindness of friends, I was permitted to visit the old Indian cemetery among the pines on the Garden River Reserve. Over the graves of many years still stand wooden houses, the length of the grave with gable roof and a small opening in the end, through which food and essentials for the welfare of the spirit could be placed from time to time.

(continued next page)
In the little church at Garden River by the evening lamplight, one felt the presence of enquiring minds and that indescribable something that brought a hush - an atmosphere which has no doubt grown out of efforts of the earlier years (since 1832) even e'er the building took form.

Each day in the school one was deeply impressed by the attention of the children at morning and evening prayers in the auditorium. Then on Sunday morning we attended the early celebration in the little chapel in the school and, later, morning service in the little stone church almost hidden in the cluster of trees near the roadway. The vestibule is entered through gates preparatory to passing the doors into the church proper, where one beholds different memorials, including the sentences carved in wood to the memory of early workers. Truly a sacred spot.

One hated to leave this place of continued endeavour and the family of workers but other duties called and we said farewell with fond hopes that we would meet again someday.

Home-going is commonly a very happy event for our pupils and the manner of it varies according to local conditions. It was our privilege this summer to see prairie children going home with their parents in wagons and to see the fleet of motor boats at Alert Bay waiting to take the children to various fishing villages along the Coast. The Ottawas had several curious old legends and traditions, very similar generally to those of Ojibways. Nanabozhoo, they say, became a man and he had for his hunting dog a great black wolf. His brother was a monster with a body made of flint. Nanahbozhooh was enraged with the flinty brother because he had killed their mother, so he pursued him all over the earth and kept striking at him with his war club; and every time he struck him a piece of flint was chipped off, and that accounts for the flint stones being found scattered about everywhere.

June 23rd brought the school year to a close and it was with a great sense of thankfulness we realised the 102 pupils under our care had passed through its months in safety and had made progress.

The arrival in our midst of Mr. Forward from the Ottawa Office gave rise to much speculation at the breakfast table early one July morning as to how and when? One of the members then recalled hearing and seeing a small plane leaving the air strip in front of the mission property at 2 a.m., under the rays of the Midnight Sun. Upon enquiry this probable theory became a fact - Mr. Forward had flown over in a one passenger plane from Fairbanks to Aklavit at a time when we were asleep (or should have been). A stranger, with no one to meet him, he was taken care of by the Police! (R.C.M.P.) who, finding him interested in All Saints', escorted him to the Residential School.

GIRL GUIDE PICNIC AT FORT GEORGE

We had a Girl Guide picnic. We put our bread in bags, tea, sweet milk, pail and the cups, sausages, sweet cookies, some candies. The other girls went to the Parish Hall to get the snow-shoes so we could go. Then we were all ready to go. There were fifteen girls and two ladies, Miss Quirt and Miss Adams. We all went together. We had the bags on our backs. We all wore snow-shoes but Miss Adams. We walk on the ice on the river. We walk as fast as we can go. Miss Quirt knows how to walk with snowshoes. We came nearer, nearer to the other bank. Then we went up the bank. We put the bags on the ground but we did not take off our snow-shoes. We went to the bush to get sticks to make a fire. The other girls went to the trees to get the branches to sit on. After that we make the fire and put snow in the peel. The snow melted. When it was boiling we made the tea. The other girls sat around the fire and cooked the sausages on sticks. After we had eaten our supper Miss Quirt took a picture of us. Oh, my, we had a jolly time that day. We put out the fire and came home when the sun was vanished. We walked on the ice. We put our snowshoes in the Parish Hall. We put our things in the kitchen. We didn't feel tired. We thanked Miss Quirt for the picnic. Then we went upstairs to bed. It was beginning spring when we had our picnic. Only the Girl Guides went to the picnic that day.

(Nellie Herodier Gr. IV - From GOOSE FEATHERS)

MY PURPOSE
To be a little kindlier with the passing of each day;
To leave but happy memories as I go along my way;
To use possessions that are mine in service full and free;
To sacrifice the trivial things for larger good to be;
To give of love in lavish way that friendship true may live;
To be less quick to criticize, more ready to forgive;
To use such talents as I have, that happiness may grow;
To take the bitter with the sweet, assured 'tis better so;
To be quite free from self-intent, whatever the task I do;
To help the world's faith stronger grow, in all that's good
and true;
To keep my faith in God and right, no matter how things run;
To work and play and trust until the journey's done.
God grant to me the strength of heart, of motive end of will,
To do my part and falter not this purpose to fulfill.

...Anon.

JUNIOR DRAMATICS

Under the capable direction of Mr. Emmett McArt, Mr. Lorenzo Deschamps and Miss Virginia Laroque, the boys of Grades 1-5 staged a most enjoyable evening's entertainment, October 29th.

The first playlet was "The Discontented Crow." Peter Chong narrated the story in a loud clearcut voice, while Bruce McComber, as the crow, and Rolland Matlowabi, as the happy robin, gave some acting. Peter Chong ... The little lads from Grade One gave a display of their progress in class in the form of a pantomime. Bruce McComber, both of whom recited nursery rhymes plus gestures and all.

Two songs and some selections by the Rhine Band from Grades Four and Five added a fine musical touch to the programme. The highlight of the evening was "The Bank Strike" by these same two Grades ... This play was done as part of their Social Studies work to tell the story of the discovery of the Indian Ocean. Wallace Belleau, as Abie the money lender, and Albert Bourneau, Balboa's part, were the main characters.

Congratulations to the younger girls of the convent who presented that same evening in the Halloween programme. Their musical choruses were very well done and their playlets interesting and entertaining.

The Teachers of the various Grades deserve a special word of praise for the successful outcome of their patient, painstaking labours.

BOXING

On October 17th the first Boxing Bout of the season was staged and it was a good show from the opening round to the final gong.

The boys were in there throwing punches and playing hard-fighting boxing no quarter was asked by anyone. Every round was exciting and the gym rang with cheers from an enthusiastic audience. It was evident that the boys had made excellent progress since Father Skillen took over the assignment as instructor last September.

Probably the best bout of the evening was between Eli Commanda and Adam Roy. These lads at 120 pounds were really good and were a big attraction on any boxing card. Tall rangy lads, they have developed a fine range technique, have plenty of speed and a good punch.

Another outstanding bout in the 140 pound class between Henry Smith and Charlie Belcourt drew a good hand of applause from the crowd. Frankie Commanda, Clement Trudeau and Arnold Belleau showed plenty of class in their own divisions and much is expected of them.

There was not one of the boxers who didn't put up a good fight and they deserve great credit for their fine sportsmanship.

Father Skillen handled the boys in the ring with the ease and grace of a professional. Judges for the evening were Mr. William McGrath and Mr. Joseph Sammon. Referees in the ring, Bob Syrett and Cecil Murray. Time Keepers ... Alvin Nashiwe and Julius Neganeigigig ... Alfie Cooper announced the bouts ...

SENIOR PLAY A SUCCESS

The Senior Dramatic Club presented "The Upper Room" on April 3rd and 4th. It was the most successful production of the year. Each part was well interpreted by the actors. The simplicity and sincerity of the players impressed upon the audience the spirit of the passion. The choir of thirty voices, singing off-stage, provided a suitable background for the sacred theme. Particularly noteworthy was the singing of the lamentations during the scene depicting the death of Christ. The audience was requested before the play to remain silent between acts and to give no applause. This helped to bring home the sacredness of the play.

Special praise should be given to the veteran actor, Dominic McComber for his performance as Samuel, the servant. At no time did he overdo his part. Throughout the play he was the key figure in every action. Joe Fox, mirror, as Our Lady, and Cornelius McComber, as Mary Magdalene, handled the female roles with skill.
