EASTER HOLIDAY

The sky was cloudy and the days dark with the threat of rain or snow yet we had a very enjoyable holiday.

The vacations, from April 4th to the 12th, passed like one day.

The seniors, engaged in hard work, basketball games every morning, in the afternoons we all went for a walk.

The seniors stretched their legs with a four or five mile jaunt. The juniors and seniors played Croquet and In-

dian Clubs placed on top of the hill.

Every evening of the holidays was met with an enthusiastic reception. Great was the joy among the seniors when they were allowed to stay up to see the cow-

boy movies. The special feature of the holidays was the Senior basketball games. The girls played their games first and then cheered the boys on to victory or defeat. The walls shook from the yells of the Green, Yellow, Red and Blue teams swept into action.

The name Club Star was suggested by Henry Deere. The Club is a special prerogative of the Senior boys. It is open nightly from 9 p.m. to 10 p.m. There they can play bridge, checkers and other games; read the newspapers, listen to the radio and discuss the weighty papers of the world. The idea of the paper originated from the Club and the paper mainly records the activities of the Senior boys.

The hallowed name of St. Peter Claver has gone. Henceforth we shall be known as The Garnier Residential School. This name is more appropriate than St. Peter Claver. The bell in the school belfry is inscribed Garnier School and the intention of Superiors to change the name, St. Peter Claver, is buried in South American while St. Charles Garnier is none of our own Canadian Martyrs. Therefore it is more fitting that we should honour him and ask his protection. S.P.C. was known up and down the North Shore for hard fighting, clean sportsmanship. We hope that the same adjectives will be attri-

buted to the name Garnier.

IN FLANDERS FIELDS

In Flanders fields the poppies blow,
Between the crosses, row on row,
That mark our place; and in the sky
The larks, still bravely singing, fly
Scarce heard amid the guns below.

We are the Dead, short days ago
We lived, felt dawn, saw sunset glow,
Loved and were loved, and now we lie
In Flanders fields.

Take up our quarrel with the foe:
To you from failing hands we throw
The torch; be yours to hold it high.
If ye break faith with us who die
We shall not sleep, though poppies grow
In Flanders fields.

- John McCrae.
THE INDIANS AND THE WAR. 1939-1945.

Throughout the Dominion of Canada keen interest in the World War, 1939-1945, was shown by the Indians. The men showed their loyalty by voluntarily enlisting in the armed forces and the women by generously donating to the Red Cross. They knit many socks, mufflers and other comforts for the men.

The following figures give the records for the three services:

(a) Total number of volunteers 921,292
(b) Total number of Fatal Battle Casualties 32,472
(c) Total number Battle Casualties (Non-fatal) 138,166

In proportion to their population the number of enlistments among the Indians was exceptionally good. Indian girls enlisted in both the Army and Air Force. Some 46 Indians enlisted in the United States Armed Forces. This information is considered incomplete as many Indians may have enlisted away from the reserves without reporting to the Indian agents.

Many brave Indians laid down their lives in the cause of freedom. Many won honor and distinction. George Badger, Pelly Agency, Saskatchewan, deceased, was taken Prisoner of War at Hong Kong in 1941. John Smallboy, Moose Factory Agency, Ontario, fought through the campaigns in Africa, Sicily and Italy. Private Frederick Webster, Seaforth Highlanders, Lytton Agency, British Columbia, won the Military Medal. Gunner Dick Patrick, Royal Canadian Artillery, Okanagan Agency, won the Military Medal for "gallant and distinguished conduct in the field." Private Huron Eldon Brant, Tyendinaga Agency, Ontario, was awarded the Military Medal in the battle of Grammichelle in 1943. This gallant soldier was later killed in action in Italy. A wonderful record is held by an Indian family of Cape Croker Agency. John McLeod, the father, served in the last war and with the Veterans Guard in this war. His six sons and one daughter enlisted in the Armed Forces. Two sons were wounded in action and two others were killed.

PLAYING THE GAME.

In some of our recent articles we have emphasized the extreme importance of BED REST in the treatment of your Tuberculosis. We cannot repeat these words too often to make you realize how important it is!

You will have noticed that we have School Teachers and an Occupational Teacher who visit you and help you both to improve your education and to occupy some of your time which is not spent in absolute rest.

The time that you spend on your studies and other occupational work should not interfere with Rest Periods in any way. They are not meant to replace your rest, but are definitely to help you pass the many long hours which you have to spend in your bed.

The length of time that you are allowed to spend on your studies and other work is carefully worked out by consultation between the Doctors, Nurses and the Teachers. Some people have a lot of disease, and therefore, we feel that they should do little or no work and should spend all their time resting—not only during Rest Periods but at all times during the day. As soon as we feel you are able to spend some or more time in studying and occupational therapy, we will make these adjustments. Under no circumstances do we want patients to do these extra things without being officially allowed to do them!

You must realize that we who comprise the staff are just as anxious as you are for you to get well and leave the hospital. The more you try to do by yourself, without permission and without supervision, the more likely you are to prolong your stay in the hospital. At times you may think we are unfair and mean to you because we do not give you extra privileges, but that is not so for we are thinking of your welfare at all times.

(Cont'd)
In conclusion, today, I would like to impress upon you how helpful the teachers and the occupational worker can be to aid in your recovery, but you must co-operate with them and with the rest of the staff to the fullest degree to shorten your stay in the Hospital.

H. Meltzer, M.D.
Medical Director.

Remembrance Day.

November 11 was Remembrance Day. It is a day set aside to honour the veterans who gave their lives in the two World Wars.

This tribute generally takes the form of a parade and solemn services at a War Memorial. We must also remember the veterans who are living, those who are suffering and those who are in need. We can do this in a concrete way, by generously supporting the Poppy Day each year.

MY TRIP SOUTH.

Our good dentist, Dr. McCaffery, is at the Blood Agency in the south, fixing the children's teeth at the two boarding schools. I took him there on Monday, November 3. It's a lovely thing to have a good dentist of our own. Some time before school closes next June Dr. McCaffery will visit every school in Alberta. He saves a lot of teeth and a lot of pain.

From the Blood I went over to the Peigan Agency at Brockett. There was a little girl there with a hole in the top of her mouth. She is now here at the hospital and we hope that a small operation will make her talk better.

Coming up to Calgary I met the Hon. Mr. Martin and Dr. Moore. These are the two gentlemen who visited the hospital on October 27. We all know, of course, that Mr. Martin is the government Minister at Ottawa who directs all the health work done by the Government there. Family Allowances are part of his business. Dr. Moore is the officer who has to see that sick Indians, all over Canada, are looked after. He lives in Ottawa, too. They came out here to see what we are all doing and were very pleased with our hospital.

Mr. Martin, Dr. Moore and I visited at Morley and at the Blackfoot. Then they went away to Saskatchewan to see the Indians and their hospitals there.

On November 11, I met three patients at the railway station in Calgary and we drove to Edmonton. The road was slippery with ice but we arrived safely. One of them is our old friend, Emile Medicine Traveller.

I have never seen the Indians in the south so well dressed and so well off in every way as they seem to be now. They have had a pretty good crop and are getting high prices for it. This is the time when it pays to farm.

Dr. E. L. Stone,
Regional Director.
Our New Doctor.

In a recent page of the "World News in Pictures" we were pleased to see a picture of Dr. Orford and his family. We wish we could print the picture—it was such a splendid one—but since we are not able to do so, we shall tell you what was written under the picture.—

"Diphtheria quarantine Lifted In James Bay Area. An outbreak of diphtheria at Moose Factory, Ont., has resulted in quarantine, but did not stop the U.S. and Canadian hunters from arriving in droves for moose hunting. The quarantine has been lifted. Government physician for eight years at Moose Factory, Dr. T.J. Orford, shown above with his wife and children, Judy, nine and Elizabeth, six, left two days before quarantine, but offered to return, if needed, to help battle the dread outbreak which is abating."

Mrs. Orford Speaks For Her Husband.

When the first X-Ray survey was made in James Bay our Indians flocked to have their plates taken. They were not so enthusiastic, however, when it came to persuading those found suffering from Tuberculosis to take treatment in a Sanatorium. The idea of leaving familiar things and faces and going on a long journey amongst strange people was a frightening one. There was no Indian hospital for them, nor was it always possible to secure even two beds in the same Sanatorium so that they might have the companionship of their own people during the long months of treatment. Nevertheless, eventually some of them faced the necessity of this move and when, after a period, they returned well and cured, the more timid ones were encouraged to try it too.

So it is with absorbing interest, since our arrival here, that we watch the life at Cassell and the whole beautifully organized effort of the doctors and staff directed towards making a sick Indian well. When we look back and think of the long lonely stretches put in by our James Bay Indians amongst people who neither spoke their language nor understood their background, we wish and hope that the future may hold for them the good fortune of the patients here—a companionable place of rest and cure in their own Indian Hospital.

—Mena Orford.
NOVEMBER

November woods are bare and still;
November days are clear and bright;
Each noon burns up the morning's chill;
The fading's snow is gone by night;
Each day's steps grow slow, grow light,
As though the woo's I reverent creep,
Watching all things lie "down to sleep."

I never knew before what beds
Fragrant to smell, and soft to touch,
The forest sifts and shapes and spreads;
"I never knew before how much
Of human sound there is in such
Low tones as through the forest sweep
When all wild things lie "down to sleep."

Each day I find new coverlids
Tucked in, and more sweet eyes shut tight;
Sometimes the viewless mother bids
Her ferns kneel down, full in my sight;
I hear their chime of "good-night";
And half I smile and half I weep,
Listening while they lie "down to sleep."

November woods are bare and still;
November days are bright and good;
Life's noon burns up life's morning chill;
Life's night rests feet which long have stood;
Some warm soft bed in field or wood,
The mother will not fail to keep,
Where we can lay us "down to sleep."
— Helen Hunt Jackson.

THROUGH MY WINDOW PANE

All summer from the sun porch
I've gazed out through the pane.
I've loved the lovely sunsets,
The sunshine and the rain.

The garden full of beauty rare,
The asters and sweet peas
All looked so lovely as they waved
In the warm summer breeze.

And then one night the frost came,
And I could not be gay,
For all the pretty colors went,
And everything turned gray.

But soon my heart was light again,
As I sat up in bed
I saw the roofs of all the "huts"
Had turned bright green and red.

Composed by: Jean Coutureille,

Answer: One minds the train and the other trains the mind.

Ward II

Three of our little girls, Doreen Calihoo, Helen Lightning and Mary Deschamps have been moved to Ward VIII. We miss you, girls.

Hallowe'en plays pranks on us all. Lily Papin thought that the paper pumpkin in the window was real and did not discover her mistake until she was almost choked with a great big bite. Next time, Lily, take a smaller bite till you are sure.

Poor Agnes Augibelle spent all one evening getting ready for a show. But, alas, there was no show! Never mind, Agnes, we enjoyed seeing you all dolled up.

Delia Cardinal was taking the shopping list around one day. She came to Lily Papin's bed and asked her what she wanted. Without looking up, Lily said, "I want my sister to come and see me." Wouldn't it be grand if we could all order guests on the shopping list!

Ruth was writing a letter home for Lily. Lily wanted her to ask them to send her a hundred dollars and a hair net. When finished, (Cont'd)
it read, "one hundred dollars and a hair nest". I wonder what kind of a store keeps hair nests?

October was a fortunate month for us. We had three wonderful shows and the educational film.

They say Humpty Dumpty sat on a wall.
But 'twas Adeline Jackson who had the great fall.
She reached for her blanket, and oh, such a sprawl!
Head over heels she went. Blanket and all!

Delia Cardinal says she would like to broadcast in Cree and Eskimo. She cannot speak a word of Eskimo. Here is a good chance for Sarah, Ada or Doris to do some tutoring.

Doris Beaulieu has tried twenty times to make a paper guitar, but they always end in the waste-paper basket. Don't give up, Doris, "if at first you don't succeed, try, try again".

Agnes Augibelle had a visit from her parents and uncle recently, and Delia Cardinal was pleased to have her brother call on her the other day.

On November 4, the nurse found Alice Donald packing to go home. Sorry, but Alice was a little previous as the doctor has not yet given her permission to go.

If Claire Moses must talk in her sleep we wish that she would talk so that we could understand all she says. It is so aggravating to just hear part of such an interesting story.

Ward III C.

We were sorry to lose Nellie Little Light and Marie Blackrider. We shall miss them very much but are glad that they are able to go home.

Margaret Eaglechild had her operation in October and has since been in a private ward. Don't forget to come back, Margaret, for we miss you very much.

We hope the show on November 10 is as good as the one we had at the end of October. That one was well worth seeing and we wish to thank those who bring these entertainments to us.

Our chief story tellers are Mary Jane Boucher and Elise Laboucon. Recently they told us all about their life before coming to the hospital. Mary Jane loves her dogs. And as she told us about them we loved them, too. Meeksap is the favorite. Meeksap cannot eat anything but bannock and lard.

(Cont'd)
If there had been a prize for the best decorated ward for Hallowe'en we feel sure we would have won it. We had orange and black streamers, bats, owls, cats and witches. That night, when the lights went out, the witches began riding their broomsticks, the cats started meowing, the bats started flying and the owls started hooting.

What about the patients? Oh, well, we will leave that to your imagination!

Our next decorations will be for Christmas. How many more days?

Congratulations to Jean Coutoreille for her poem in the October issue of the Arrow. Do it again, Jean.

Ward IV E.

One day Miss Oakden was leaving the ward and suddenly missed her bag. Such a commotion! No one had her bag. She looked under the beds and under the sheets. Finally Miss Oakden had to give up and leave without her bag. A few days later we asked her if she had found her bag. She hung her head and said very humbly, "Yes, I found it. It was in the office."

Victoria Emile was advised by Victoria Sanscouteau to put her four one-cent stamps on each corner of the envelope. Victoria thought it looked very nice until a nurse came in and said, "Oh, so you are writing to the King!" This was too much for Victoria. She was not writing to the king. So she took all the stamps off but she learned that stamps go on easier than they come off.

Victoria Emile got quite sentimental as she watched the first fall of snow and the children playing ball outside. It almost caused the first fall of tears.

We all helped to get Ruth Wings ready for home on November 12. She had just half an hour and the whole ward was in a turmoil. Everybody was in a dither but we finally got her started for Cardston with her own pyjamas——— we hope!

Elise Grandjambe misses her sister Lillian who has been moved to Ward VII. She enjoys having Yvonne Tibbett opposite her, though. Yvonne has been moved from Ward III.

Ward IV C.

Leo Swan wants to tell the whole world that he is feeling fine and that he has been walking around for the past ten days.

Ernie Horseman and Jim Johnson have had rib operations. Ernie had his on October 27 and Jim on November 1. They are both fine.

The Third Floor patients are expecting some music now. They hear that Ernie Horseman has had his violin bow repaired.

Ward IV Sun Porch.

On Remembrance Day we three were awakened by the Ward III girls bursting into our room at eleven o'clock in the morning announcing that they were going down to church service. Kathleen Twiggs was out of bed in a minute and wanted the girls to wait for her. However, when she learned that only Routine 6 were allowed down she dived back into bed like a fish into water.

Ward X A.

Roy Hunter has been moved back to Ward IX A from the private. It will seem quite natural for Roy to be here. However, when Roy was in this ward before he was one of the oldest in the ward. Now he will be one of the youngest.

Edward Elanak has been moved to the private off IXA after his recent appendectomy—don't be alarmed—that is just a big word for an appendicitis operation. Edward is bright and happy again.

Ward IX B.

Maurice Buffalo is very proud of his new guitar, a gift brought to him recently, by his father. He is learning to play it.

Pat Mandville, a former Ward IX B patient, has been moved to Ward X A. Ward IX B say, "Good riddance!" (Just a joke, Pat.)

We welcome our new patient, Emile M. Traveller, who arrived late this week.

Such a time as we have been having during the house cleaning. We were moved to Ward IX A during the process. Roy Hunter was the only one there to welcome us. It is good to be home after the few nights' holiday.

Ben Adam is busy signing autographs, as usual.

Simon Jacko and Maurice Buffalo have been getting all the "Local" lately.

Lawrence Laroque and Harry Bull Lightning almost came to blows in an argument over the hockey match the other night.

Aloysius Good Rider went home to Cardston on November 12.

WHEN HOUSE CLEANING IS UNDER WAY?
WE'LL WRITE OUR PIT FOR THE ARROW,
WHEN WE GET BACK HOME TO STAY.

"Come on," said Harry Nedlin, as he saw the first snow of the winter, "We're going for our traps!" But Fred Laferty answered, "Can't go yet. My things are not ready." Speedy recovery, boys, and good trapping again, soon!

How about helping with the house cleaning down in this unit. Everybody welcome!

Ward X E.

We are sorry to hear that Mrs. Kerans will not be with us for some time and hope that it will not be too long till she is back.

November 11 was Remembrance Day. We were a little sad because we did not get any poppies. All the same we remembered the boys who had fought in both wars and especially those in the last war. We boys knew well, ten boys who had lost their lives. These were loud from home and we thought of them very reverently. Many were wounded and many came back safe. Veterans of the last War also served in the Veterans Guards at the German prison camps. We hope that War will never come again.

We are all in the throes of house cleaning. We were moved to IX A. We felt very much out of place, especially with all the orders from "Dr. H. Lightning." He was very strict with us boys from X B. We even had to phone back to Ward X for our meals. Our own Ward X doctor, "Dr. Gireux" was sick at the time and could not come to our aid.

Alex Little Wolfe
A Bunco Party

On Nov. 23rd we had a bunco party in honor of Saint Cecilia's day but it was nice! All the girls and boys were there for joy and happiness. The employees invited to come. Our dear Superior and all the Sisters enjoyed the party with us.

We played for over an hour, during this time, names were drawn by a girl, the first one was our teacher, Sister Rose-Holden, she sang a nice song then Irene Cardinal played the mouth organ and danced with Mary Anne Enow. Sister Laurette-de-Marie also played the piano. Piano duets were played by Madeleine Whitestone and Cecilia Jimmy. Mrs Lavigne was the last but not the least on the programme. She recited a beautiful poem.

This over, we had a delicious lunch served by Madeleine, Cecilia, Louisa, Irene and Melanie. The prizes were then given out. The highest score should have been 21, but nobody was lucky enough to have it. I had only three, but still I was satisfied with my prize.

We bid everyone goodnight and said a hearty thank you. Away we went to our dreams. I will never forget this wonderful party we had.

November 20th was a holiday, for everyone knows that it was the wedding of Princess Elizabeth, our future Queen.

Everyone was happy because we were going down to the lake to skate that afternoon. It was the girls' first skating, can you imagine the fun we had? Down we went, flat on the ice, over and over again. Each girl has two helpers, but sometimes we pulled them down with us, but no one was hurt. We were quite satisfied with our afternoon, we had so hard to skate. We are grateful for a hearty thanks to our Sister la-de-dos-inges who is doing such good work. We want her to stay with us a long time.

The other night we played games. That was on the sixth of last month. Mary Anne Enow and Irene Cardinal danced a jig.

Emma Jackknife and Cecilia Jimmy put a brown cow hide on their backs and wore men's socks. The most surprising is when they came dancing in. This was the funniest thing of all.

The medium sized girls played the musical chair. I was last with another girl. We both wanted to sit on a chair, but as it was too small we both sat on the floor. As a reward we each had an orange. There were quite a few other games but I can't mention them all, anyway we all had a wonderful time. We were tired and glad to jump into our beds.

LAUREN

THE MONTH OF THE HOLY ROSARY.

All the month of October, we had the great pleasure of reciting our rosary every night in our chapel. After every decade we sang a short hymn to the Blessed Virgin Mary. We have a great devotion to our Mother. We prayed her to intercede for us so that she may be with us at the hour of our death. We also had Benediction. We also remembered our family and our friends during these days. Our Blessed Mother will remember you all.

A CHANGE OF STAFF.

When we came back to school in September many changes had taken place. The Fathers, most of the Sisters and the employees are changed too.

Our Principal is Reverend Father St. Pierre and he is still working as missionary at Union Lake; Reverend Father Lucien who was at Cochin took Reverend Father Pascal's place. The latter had been our kind Principal for the past ten years.

Reverend Sister Lucie-des-Anges is the girls' new directoress. Reverend Sister Saint Theophila and Marie-Vital who were here several years ago are back. Sister Madeleine Sophie took the boys' sewing room. Sister Hélène-de-Rome is the boys' directoress now. Oh! I forgot to mention our new musician, Rev. Sister Laurette-de-Marie who was here about six years ago. We certainly miss our kind Principal and the Sisters who were with us for so many years. Rev. Sister Saint Honore is Superior at Walla Walla. Rev. Sisters St. Salomé and Sr. St. Paul-de-Dumas are in Delmas. Sister Saint Luc l'Evangéliste is in Biggar and Sr. Marie Noëlla is in Lacorner.

Our new employees are: Mr. Lord and his son from Bonnyville. Mr. & Mrs. Lavigne with their two children from Denholme. He came last spring to take Mr. Deveyrac's place. Mr. & Mrs. Fortier and their two children from Battleford.

We started our school year with happy smiling faces. We are ready to do everything with good will among our new friends.

Madeline Dubé

VISITORS FROM THE EAST.

It is the 30th day of September and it is the first day of our Reverend Mother Saint Cantaléon's visit, her assistant is Reverend Mother Marie-Ange. It is very pleasant to see them; it shows that they are glad to be in our midst. So are we, especially the Sisters, because it is one of the greatest visits they can have during the year.

Oct 3rd... The fourth day of Reverend Mother's visit, our teacher, Sister Rose-Hélène had to go to Lloydminster for some business with Mr. & Mrs. Lavigne. Now, as there is no Sister to take her place, we have the honor and luck to have Reverend Mother Marie-Ange for our teacher. The time went by very quickly.

Tonight we have our first house party in honor of Reverend Mothers; we all had a grand time. As usual a lunch was served and prizes given out.

Oct 6th... Now the week has passed and already our Visitors are leaving for Bonnyville; we are sorry to see them go so soon. We hope that they will come back before long.

Cecilia Young
Father Pascal, our kind principal, departed from us to work as a missionary at Cochin, on September 4th. In his face we could see that he was sad to leave us and so were we. We missed him very much and we do hope that he will come back with us someday.

We were glad to see him on Nov. 7th; of course he never forgets his children, so he brought us presents. What do you think it was? Balloons! With whistles at the end, he enjoyed them and had great fun.

Father said he liked it at Cochin though he misses our dear old school. We wish he will have all the happiness over there as he had here. We are anxious for his next visit.

ANOTHER FEAST

November 16th was Sister Superior's Feast. We had a concert, though not very long it was very nice. Everybody took part in it even the Sisters, they sang 'Ave Maria'. The address was read by Madeleine Whitstone.

Everybody was happy but I think our dear Sister Superior was the happiest of all. She is so kind and good to us, that we hope to have her among us many more years.

A KIND VISITOR

Mr. Bowers, the Superintendent of Schools, came for his annual visit here on the sixteenth and seventeenth of October. Of course he didn't tell us when he was coming. The first thing we knew he was at our door.

On the sixteenth he went to the primary classes. The next morning he went to the intermediates and senior classes. In the afternoon just before he left, we had a fire drill.

The boys then asked him if we could have the remaining time free. He gave his consent and told them to ask the Principal first. Of course Father St. Pierre couldn't refuse. We had a baseball game during that time.

We certainly are glad and grateful to have a good and kind Inspector like Mr. Bowers is. The children are never shy to speak him when he asks them a question. I hope that he was pleased with his visit here.

VISITS TO THE HOSPITAL.

It was Oct. 20th when Caroline Angus, Mary Elizabeth Patchegan and I went to the hospital to have our tonsils out. It was a nice long trip even though we had to go with the mail man in his truck. We had to cross the ferry at Frenchman's Butte because the river was too low at other places. We stayed there five days. We felt lonely, but after all time went by and how glad we were to see Reverend Father St. Pierre come to take us back to school.

We are not allowed to sing for some time until our throats are completely healed. That is my biggest tonsil trial.

Martha Fox's Death.

This little seven year old girl was at the hospital sometime in August, and she came back to school only in October. After a while her health failed again and she was put in the infirmary. Later on she was taken to the Paradise Hill Hospital. As she was getting worse she was taken by aeroplane to a Saskatoon Hospital. She died there after several days. She received the Last Sacraments.

Martha was buried at Saskatoon. She must be in heaven because she was a quiet little girl and a good little girl too.

OUR SCHOOL

What is a School? A school is a place where we learn to love one another sincerely, we learn how to work as Christians should do so and how to suffer generously.

It is the most important place where we can form ourselves to become worthwhile Canadian men and women.

The school is a place where we find the means to build our future life and to make the others progress.

For this we must live in unity while we are altogether in our school. We must not think of ourselves as individuals, by this I mean not to be alone by ourselves (in our own corner). That is, we must not be selfish; we must cooperate with each one and everyone of our schoolmates and teachers.

We must share our joys, and try to make a companion happy when we see that she or he feels sorry. Let us let others take part in our own happiness.

The happiest student is the one who shares with his fellow-students. This gives to the entire group a wonderful strength known only to a fraternal co-operation which is capable of overcoming all difficulties.

The Reverend Fathers and our Teachers have tried their utmost to teach us to become real men and women. It is up to us to behave if we want our school to have a good name and if we want happiness. If we wish we can make our school the finest by studying hard and as I said before by sharing our joys and works with each other.

St. Paul, speaking of the Mystical Body of Christ, explains the way we get together to be like one. "The eyes cannot say to the hand, 'I don't need you,' and not more the head say to the feet, 'I don't need your help'." On the contrary, the members which seem the most unnecessary are the most useful etc. Therefore a student cannot say to a fellow-student, "I don't need you" nor to his professor, "I don't need your help. I know how etc." The School must become a family where we enrich ones knowledge, share we profit of many talents belonging to others, where we direct our spirits towards a common ideal of life, a way of leading all the members towards the same good.

By staying in this school, it has made us love God. Let us thank Him for giving us this opportunity to learn many things and also the chance to get acquainted with other ideas. We shouldn't waste this important time of our life. If we spend it well, we shall live well with our fellow citizens and this will prepare us to live happily with God in heaven.

Cecilia Gouin

A REPORT OF THE MINISTER'S TRIP TO THE WEST

Ottawa, Ontario,
Nov. 17th, 1947.

The Honourable Paul Martin, Minister of National Health and Welfare, arrived in Ottawa today after a tour of inspection of Indian Hospitals and Family Allowances regional offices throughout the four western provinces. The purpose of Mr. Martin's visit was to see at first hand the work being done by the Indian Health Services division of the Department of National Health and Welfare and to confer with the officials of the Family Allowances offices in each province.

Mr. Martin's trip carried him as far north as Le Pas to the Clearwater Lake Indian Hospital and as far west as Nanaimo, B.C. In all the Minister of National Health and Welfare visited more than twenty Indian Hospitals, nursing stations, Indian reserves and residential schools in the four western provinces. Earlier in the year Mr. Martin made a trip to Moose Factory on James Bay, to Norway House and to the Indian agencies around Nipigon and Long Lac. Recently Mr. Martin also inspected Indian Health Services in the Maritimes. Since becoming Minister responsible for the administration of Indian Health Services less than a year ago, Mr. Martin has now visited the majority of the hospitals operated by his department.

During his visits to the various hospitals and reservations, Mr. Martin found much to impress him with the work being done to stamp out tuberculosis amongst the Indians. "Primarily our Indian hospitals are being used for the treatment of tuberculosis. This disease is by long odds the main cause of death among the Indian population. The rate per 100 thousand population is about 700 as against 40 per 100 thousand among the white population. At the present time about one per cent of Indians and Eskimos in our population contribute about 12 per cent of tuberculosis deaths in Canada."

Mr. Martin said that his Department is increasing its Indian Health Services staff along the lines set out in 1946 before the special joint committee of the Senate and the House of Commons appointed to examine the Indian Act. The total staff of the Indian
Health Services division including field workers and administrative personnel is between 800 and 900. About fifty of these are permanent civil servants, the remainder being temporary employees.

At the present time the Department of National Health and Welfare has some twenty hospitals across Canada for the treatment of Indians. In addition, the Department contributes to the support of twenty-one mission hospitals and uses the services of more than 400 conveniently located public hospitals.

Mr. Martin also said that the Department has an $300,000 construction program under way for building of new hospitals and nursing stations as well as extending existing installations to relieve overcrowded conditions. In the remote areas the Department is using two-way radio telephone to keep nurses and doctors in touch with treatment centres.

Mr. Martin paid a tribute to the work being done by the mission hospitals of all religious denominations. "From earliest times the churches have been active in this field and no praise is too much for the great work they have done."

At Edmonton, Mr. Martin visited the 350-bed Charles Camsell Indian Hospital, recently taken over from the American Army, and which is the largest single addition to the chain now being operated by the Department. Mr. Martin was also at Wetaskiwin to the Hobbema Reserve where he announced that the Department had under consideration a plan to construct a new hospital. The proposed addition would be used mainly for maternity cases with major surgical cases being transported to the Camsell hospital at Edmonton.

Also in Alberta, Mr. Martin visited the Saracee hospital at Morley and the Blackfoot hospital at Gleichen. Particularly Mr. Martin was impressed by the quality of work being done by officials in these places. This year to date more than 7,000 Indians in Alberta have been X-rayed for tuberculosis.

In British Columbia Mr. Martin visited the 185-bed Indian Hospital near Chilliwack and the 200-bed Nanaimo Hospital which was formerly a military hospital. At Miller Bay near Prince Rupert there are 150 tubercular Indians who are receiving treatment at the former RCAF hospital.
After leaving Regina Mr. Martin drove more than 400 miles to visit Indian Reserves, hospitals and residential schools in Saskatchewan. At Fort Qu'Appelle he inspected the modern 70-bed Indian Hospital there. Mr. Martin paid tribute to the assistance and cooperation given to the Department by the Saskatchewan Anti-Tuberculosis League which has played a major part in reducing the incidence of tuberculosis in Saskatchewan. A new powerhouse will be added to the Fort Qu'Appelle hospital as well as a 50-bed extension to the present accommodation.

On the Crooked Lakes Indian Agency near Broadview, Saskatchewan, Mr. Martin inspected the nursing station and visited patients in the general hospital at Broadview. Mr. Martin stopped over in Elkhorn, Manitoba and Griswold to visit the Indian agencies and confer with the medical staff.

At Brandon, Manitoba Mr. Martin visited the 200-bed former military hospital which has been taken over by the Department of National Health and Welfare and which is rapidly reaching capacity in the treatment of tuberculous Indians. From Brandon, Mr. Martin flew north to the Clearwater Lake Hospital above Le Pas. He was accompanied on the trip to Le Pas by Ralph Maybank, M.P. for Winnipeg South, newly appointed parliamentary assistant to Mr. Martin and the Honourable Ivan Schultz, Manitoba Minister of Health. Dr. F.E. Moore, Director of Indian Health Services, who has been with Mr. Martin throughout the whole tour of inspection was also a member of the party.

Mr. Martin was highly appreciative of the work being done by the Sanatorium Board of Manitoba which operates the Brandon and the Clearwater Lake hospital on behalf of the Department of Health and Welfare. He said that plans are being considered for a $40,000 addition to the Clearwater Hospital to increase the capacity to 185 beds and to supply a fireproof centre block for the institution.

Mr. Martin said that he had been greatly impressed by the beneficial effect of extending Family Allowances to the Indians. "In areas where hunting and trapping have been poor," Mr. Martin said, "Family Allowances have proved to be a lifesaver for many Indian families. The Indians realize that the allowances are for..."
their children and are using them for the purchase of better clothing and better foods."

Summing up the work of his Department amongst the Indians, Mr. Martin said, "We have a moral obligation to do everything possible to provide better health conditions among the Indians and to help them maintain themselves by improving their standard of living. Good health and better living conditions are the goals which the Indian Health Services division of the Department of National Health and Welfare keeps constantly in mind."

Executive Assistant to the Minister of National Health and Welfare.

A CHRISTMAS MESSAGE FROM DR. CHARLES CAMSELL

TO THE PATIENTS AND STAFF OF THE CHARLES CAMSELL INDIAN HOSPITAL.

Some time ago I was asked to contribute to the interesting new publication with which you are all familiar, "THE CAMSELL ARROW."

I have delayed my response to that invitation, but the approach of the Christmas Season affords me an opportunity to send my good wishes which I do not wish to forego.

First, I must congratulate those who planned for, and established, the "ARROW" for it is a most effective means of drawing together in common interest all those whose life centers in the hospital for such a great part of their time. I have read each issue published so far, and am convinced that "THE ARROW" is reaching its mark — and hitting the bullseye — to a gratifying degree.

All of the 43 years that I have spent in the Public Service of Canada have been devoted to the search for, and the development of, those material resources of our country which would open greater opportunities within the Dominion, strengthen its economic fabric, increase its prestige before the world and, most important, raise the standard of living of its citizens by making available for their benefit the products of this vast land. All of these things
are essential to our wellbeing, but they serve only our material interests.

The hospital of which you are a part has a much more personal and beneficent purpose. The building had already a long record of humanitarian service, both as a Church institution and as a medical centre for the men of the United States Army, before it was taken over by the Federal Government for its present uses. During my term of office as Deputy Minister of the Department of Mines and Resources and Commissioner of the Northwest Territories, I was charged with the welfare of the Indian and Esquimaux peoples of Canada. Later, that responsibility was assumed by the Department of National Health and Welfare.

When the then Minister of the Department of National Health and Welfare intimated that he would like to use my name for the newly acquired hospital, I felt deeply honoured. I was naturally very much gratified to have my name used in this connection. But my gratification was deeper than this small vanity. This is an institution devoted to a purpose more vital to Canada than the development of its material riches. It is working to restore and strengthen our human resources, potentially the most valuable asset a nation may possess. Especially is it vital work when it brings health and wellbeing to our citizens in the North Country, where exacting conditions demand unusual reserves of fitness and fortitude.

I know, from experience, how difficult that northern life can be, but as this Festive Season approaches, even in a year when much of the world is gravely troubled, I remember the cheery lines which Sir Walter Scott wrote in his poem "Marmion" -

Heap on more wood! The wind is chill,
But let it whistle as it will,
We'll keep our Christmas merry still."

I hope that all those within the walls of The Charles Gamsell Indian Hospital, upon the anniversary of the birth of The Prince of Peace, may find it possible to keep their Christmas merry - and to find before them a year of health and happiness.

Shall we join with Tiny Tim in
his little prayer for all who share the
Christmas Spirit "God Bless us every
one". Tiny Tim, of Dickens' Christmas
Carol, was a little cripple on crutches,
who, in spite of suffering and poverty,
brought sunshine and joy into his home
and into the somber life of his father,
Bob. At this time of the year it is not only our opportunity but our
duty to give joy and gladness to everyone within range of our influence.

In the Bible account of the birth of Jesus we read that the
Angel Choir sang, "Glory to God in the Highest and on Earth, Peace
to Men of Good Will". Without "good will" it is impossible to have
peace in our world, so this "good will" is needed in the hearts and
minds of all peoples, not merely those of one nation; and, also, in
the lives of boys and girls and men and women right in our Hospital.
As one of your Chaplains I have been much impressed by the cheerfulness
of the patients and I trust that this "good will" may be diffused
in spheres far beyond our Hospital walls.

It should also be remembered that the Christmas message
came not to the great and rich but to the humble shepherds
watching their flocks on the hill of Judaea. They were the first to
welcome the Christ Child, and to-day, the humble, the pure in heart,
and the peace makers are the most devout worshippers of the
"Prince of Peace".

I wish you all a very Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.

A MERRY CHRISTMAS TO ALL!

Every year we are so happy to recall the blessed event of the coming of the Saviour amongst us. The world, at the time, was in need of a Redeemer. The nations, the families and the individuals, nineteen hundred years ago, did not realize, as we do today, that the coming of the little babe at Bethlehem, would be the solution to all the problems of the human heart. "Glory be to God in the Highest! Peace be to all men of Good Will," the angels sang. And, true enough, the Infant Jesus brought to our earth the only peace and joy of any value.

This event is nineteen centuries away. But its effect is still with us. For Christ is still amongst us with His graces, His benedictions, and His peace. Every Christmas, and this December in particular, sees a renewal of all these benedictions in every man of Good Will. May you all enjoy a Merry Christmas with all possible consolations. This is my wish and my prayer for you all.

And may I take this opportunity to thank each and every one of the staff for the kindness, charity and devotion, which our dear patients have been so fortunate in receiving from you all. May the Saviour on this Christmas night enkindle in our hearts true love for humanity and the courage to imitate all his virtues.

God bless you all!

Merry Christmas!

"A Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year and God Bless every one of us."

Did you ever stop to think why everything is so different at Christmas? People are more generous to each other; not only is this shown by the exchange of gifts, but it is marked in the attitude of person to person. There are more smiles, more big and little deeds of kindness. The usually bad-tempered are better tempered; young and old, rich and poor. All are possessed of the desire to be happy.

Why is this? The fact is that on this day we think of God's gift to the world - the gift of His Son. We see in that Holy Family at Bethlehem something that inspires us. There we see Peace on Earth amongst men of Good Will, and catching the spirit of it, we exclaim, "This is what the world needs." If ever there were a time when the ancient prophecy were true that "A little child shall lead them", it is at this Christmas season.

May we all, like the shepherds of old, "Even now go on to Bethlehem and see what the Lord hath wrought for man." And, there, catching some of the spirit of God's love let us carry it through the year in our daily lives.

To the Medical Director, Staff and Patients, I wish the Blessings of Christmas and a Happy New Year.

THE NIGHT BEFORE CHRISTMAS

was the night before Christmas when all through the house,
Not a creature was stirring, not even a mouse.
The stockings were hung by the chimney with care,
In hopes that St. Nicholas soon would be there.

The children were nestled all snug in their beds,
While visions of sugar-plums danced in their heads,
And Mamma in her kerchief and I in my cap,
Had just settled down for a long winter's nap.

When out on the lawn there arose such a clatter,
I sprang from my bed to see what was the matter.
Away to the window I flew like a flash,
Tore open the shutters and threw up the sash.
The moon on the breast of the new-fallen snow,
Gave a luster of midday to objects below.

When what to my wondering eyes should appear,
But a miniature sleigh, and eight tiny reindeer;
With a little old driver, so lively and quick,
I knew in a moment it must be St. Nick.

More rapid than eagles his coursers they came,
And he whistled and shouted, and called them by name:
"Now, Dasher! Now, Dancer! Now, Prancer and Vixen!
On, Comet! On, Cupid! On, Donder and Blitzen!
To the top of the porch, to the top of the wall!
Now, dash away, dash away, dash away all!"

As dry leaves that before the wild hurricane fly,
When they meet with an obstacle, mount to the sky,
So up to the house-top the coursers they flew,
With a sleigh full of toys, and St. Nicholas, too.
And then in a twinkling, I heard on the roof
The prancing and pawing of each little hoof.
As I drew in my head, and was turning around,
Down the chimney St. Nicholas came with a bound.

He was dressed all in fur from his head to his foot,
And his clothes were all tarnished with ashes and soot;
Bundle of toys he had flung on his back,
And he looked like a peddler just opening his pack.

His eyes how they twinkled! His dimples how merry!
His cheeks were like roses! His nose like a cherry!
His droll little mouth was drawn up like a bow,
And the beard on his chin was as white as the snow.

The stump of a pipe he held tight in his teeth,
And the smoke it encircled his head like a wreath.
He had a broad face and a little round belly
That shook when he laughed, like a bowl full of jelly.

He was chubby and plump, a right jolly old elf,

A TALE OF CHRISTMAS EVE

(Told by a Christmas stocking)

It was long past midnight and the stocking was angry—very angry.

"To be taken out of a nice comfortable drawer on a winter's night," he grumbled, "and to be strung up here to a bed post like a common thing. For my word, it's too bad. I wonder what it is all about?"

A little girl lay fast asleep in bed. Her clothes were neatly folded on the chair, her stockings were hanging over the back and her two little red shoes were snoring together on the floor.

"I miss my mate," said the stocking, "It's downright monstrous to take one stocking from a drawer and leave its mate behind."

Just as it was finished speaking there was a noise in the chimney and the stocking was amazed to see a white-bearded gentleman in a red cloak descending to the hearth. It was none other than Santa Claus!

Old Santa let a big bag of toys slide to the floor.

"Ha," he said cheerfully, "How she has grown, to be sure! Last year I could have put her in my waistcoat pocket. What a tidy child she is! Clothes neatly folded, no broken toys about, last year's doll safely tucked into its cradle. The Teddy Bear hasn't lost an eye and the grey rabbit is still full of saw-dust. I shall give her lots of good things."

He put his hand on the stocking, "Well, my grumbling friend, what is the matter with you to-night?"

"Oh, I am lonely," answered the stocking, "They took me out of my nice warm drawer and hung me up here alone in the dark and away in the cold. I am lonesome for my stocking mate and I cannot understand it all."

"Oh, I'll warm you quick enough," laughed old Santa. Diving into his sack he began to cram the stocking right to the top with toys and goodies.

"Look out!" cried the stocking. "You'll split me if you are not careful. What do you think I am? I am a stocking—not a barrel! Hi, what are you up to now? I can't stand any more! You are stretching me out of shape. Just look at my toe! What a shape I am now! You'll burst me!"

In the morning bright and early the little girl awoke. She emptied the stocking of all the toys. The poor stocking fell forgotten to the floor. How forlorn it felt! It could have cried!

The little girl's mother put the stocking back in the drawer.

"Well," said its mate, "and where have you been all night? You ought to be ashamed of yourself, keeping me awake all night waiting for you."

"My dear," said the stocking, "I've never worked so hard before or had so much fun. Humans are queer folk! But permit me to wish you a merry Christmas and a happy New Year," and snuggling down in his drawer, he went to sleep.

"DREAD EPIDEMIC"

A strange disease, Castitis, has struck down eight known people here recently. Castitis is caused directly from Cantstayinbeditis—a fever which seems to develop in almost anybody who doesn't realize how serious a disease Tuberculosis is and how necessary bed rest is for cure.

Cantstayinbeditis usually comes on in one person at first but spreads fairly rapidly to others in the same ward and actually it should be listed as a communicable disease. Oddly enough, once it reaches the stage of Castitis in one case, the outbreak in any designated ward seems to rapidly subside. This quiescence is of varying length of time.

The onset of Castitis is usually insidious. As Cantstayinbeditis becomes more acute the case is reported to the Doctor. If symptoms continue despite friendly and then more severe administrations of the medical staff, the patient develops hard, white, stiff, thick casements with cross bars between, on both legs below the knees. As a rule this condition enforces full bed rest although cases have been known in which crusting breaks—by design or otherwise. When this occurs the only known treatment is removal, whereupon, a harder, stronger cast usually is seen to appear which sometimes spreads even to the chest. The disease is then, of course, in a very advanced and serious stage.

The usual treatment for a person with Castitis is rest and cooperation. The condition seems to improve those cases of tuberculosis which do not voluntarily accept recommended routine. After varying periods of time when the victim is convinced of the necessity for cooperation in the cure of his disease, tuberculosis, the cast suddenly and completely disappears and in the majority of cases does not recur.

The best way to avoid the disease is to keep clear of any symptoms of Cantstayinbeditis. Of course, it is to be hoped that the recent epidemic of Castitis is now completely under control.

Contributed - T.J.O.

Mrs. Grantham has asked me to write a story about our clinic's recent trip to the Indian Agencies in "The Land Beyond the Peace", as the country north of the Dawson Creek is so romantically called. I am writing from Toronto where I am enjoying a very pleasant holiday just now. We are having very mild weather with no snow and the north country seems very far away.

Dr. Smith and I left Edmonton on October 22 in the old laundry truck, to visit the Indians of the Fort St. John Agency. The Cree and Beaver bands of Moberley Lake had been suffering from an epidemic of whooping cough, and many of the children were very ill with it. We spent one night at Driftpile, enjoying the hospitality of Miss Jean Burgess, our Public Health Nurse there. The second day we arrived at Dawson Creek, where we stayed overnight at the Mile Zero Hotel. The next day we took the trail to Moberley Lake — and what a trail! For 23 miles we ploughed through mud, crawled up steep hills, and carefully wormed our way down mountainsides on a road never designed for motor transport. However, we eventually arrived at our destination, only having been stuck twice, which was something of an accomplishment. We lived in cabins at Moberley, I being the cook these days — and we both survived! We met Miss Margaret Lattimer, the British Columbia Public Health Nurse from Fort St. John, who had very kindly and most effectively gone to the aid of the Indians while we were not available. She had done a grand job of looking after all the sick people there and with her help, we were able to make sure that everyone was well on the road to recovery while we were there. Dr. Smyth held a dental clinic in the Post Office, very kindly opened to us by Mr. Harry Garbitt, and many people were relieved of their aching and decayed teeth. Mr. Galibois, the Indian Agent, joined us, and was most helpful in our work. We left Moberley in a convoy of four vehicles and were fortunate in reaching Fort St. John without incident.

We proceeded north with Mr. Galibois in his very comfortable and well-equipped truck and visited Indians at Doig River, Beaton River, Prophet River and Fort Nelson. We immunized all the children against whooping cough, diphtheria and small pox, examined all chests, and
extracted nearly all the bad teeth in this section of the Alaska Highway. We visited day schools at Prophet River and Fort Nelson, and did physical examinations of all children. The scenery along the highway is very beautiful, — snow-capped mountains and lakes all the way. North of Fort Nelson we visited the family of the famous Alaska Highway character, Charlie MacDonald,— we examined all ten children and gave them toxoid. At Muncho Lake we had a day's rest on Sunday. Dr. Smyth climbed a mountain and Mr. Galibois and I went to the hot springs. It was very cold, so we decided not to swim, but the water was as hot as a really hot bath and smelled very strongly of sulphur.

On Monday we proceeded north again seeing Indians at various places. We spent the night at Rancheria in the Yukon, and then on to Whitehorse. We saw Mr. Meek, the Indian Agent and Miss Hackett, Public Health Nurse, and with them visited the Indian schools in Whitehorse and Carcross and the hospital in Whitehorse. We also, saw the Indians at Champagne and Burwash. The Yukon is a very lovely country — mountainous and snow-covered at present, but still most fascinating. After an interesting and enjoyable visit Dr. Smyth and I set forth on the long journey home. At Fort Nelson his time was running short and he was obliged to take the plane back to Edmonton, so I completed the drive by truck alone. I had a very pleasant visit in Fort St. John and set out for Edmonton in the old Dodge, arriving Sunday, November 16, very much relieved to see the city lights again after nearly four weeks in the north.

I would like to take this opportunity to wish to all the readers of THE ARROW a very merry Christmas and all the best of good luck and good health in the new year.

Louise M. Parr,
(Louise M. Parr, Regn. N.)
(Northern Mobile Clinic.)

Dear Girls and Boys:

I cannot let this copy of "Island Breezes" go to press without expressing my sincere and heartfelt wishes for the New Year and without drawing your attention to the fact that you can easily find happiness in the everyday things of life. Happy New Year! Good Health to You All! You know how lonely you feel when you are sick in bed, so my first wish is that you be healthy. Happy also means cheerful. A kind child is what pleases me most. To be kind is to be polite. Jesus taught us true kindness and politeness. A truly Christian girl and boy is polite. St. Phillip of Neri, known as the lovable saint because of his politeness, never ordered anyone to do what he desired. He always said: "Please, or would you mind doing this?" It was a sort of prayer. It was a good life and a sad face do not go together. The better the children are, the happier they are because our Lord Jesus loves them and they love Him too, and they have every reason to be happy. Not long ago there lived a young lady who was so cheerful that when she was too busy to meet her friends they would say: "Where will be no laughing today." Sister Theresa is not with us. St. Theresa of the Child Jesus was so tenderly kind that everyone felt at ease with her.

Be polite, be cheerful and your days will be filled with happiness and it will go out to those around you. Make this little verse your very own for 1948:

"The kindest thing in the kindest way."

There are the wishes of your Father whose one great desire is that you be HAPPY. Father Remy, O.M.I.

FROM MOOSE TO MOCASSINS

Last summer while I was staying at Pachuanak with my father, I was interested in watching the women transform a moose's hide into beaded mocassins. This is how they did it.

The men had killed a moose—a rare event these past years—and brought the hide home to their women who immediately soaked it in a tub of water so that it would not harden before they worked on it. The men also made a frame with four poles—and their task was ended.

The women punched holes around the hide to tie it to the frame which they stood upright against 2 trees. With a sharp bone, they scraped off the fur on one side, the flesh from underneath and let it stand for a night.

The next day they removed the hide from the frame and rubbed it on both sides with the brains of the moose which the men had saved. This takes the place of oil, I was told. It was then left to dry in the sun for a few days.

When it was dry, they soaked it again in water to soften it. They took the hide to the bush, hung it over a strong branch, and wrung it with a stick, turning it over and over until not a drop of water could be squeezed out of it. While the skin was drying, the women scraped it and beat it with covers of pails to make it fuzzy and soft on both sides. It was now ready to be tanned.

They sewed the skin together lengthwise, leaving both ends open. With three sticks they built a tepee and made a fire with rotten wood directly beneath it. The smoke which curled in and out of the roll of skin, tanned it to a golden color.

Finally they cut out the mocassins according to a simple pattern of their own. Some sewed on the colored beads, scarce and expensive since the war, while others embroidered the floral designs which they had traced on the skin with a little stick dipped in a red solution made with a piece of crepe paper.

What patient labour it required—definitely a woman's work! Florence Ahenakew (IX)

REST.

Rest in bed is the only cure for Tuberculosis. If one breaks one's arm, the doctor puts it into a cast in order to put the arm at rest. In the same way pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum and Thoracoplasty, as well as bed rest, help to put the lung at rest.

Every patient in this hospital is placed on a routine that is best and safest for the amount of disease that he or she may have. So you can readily see how wise and important it is for everyone to stick to the routine ordered if they wish to get well as soon as possible. You must not think that it is enough to take just the regular rest periods. It is dangerous to take more exercise than is allowed by your routine. Do not forget that sitting or standing is work. So, also, is excitement or games.

The doctors and nurses are worried when they see the patients disregarding their advice and breaking routine. They know how much disease you have and what is best for you. That is why they are so anxious for you to stick to your routine. As you get better you will be allowed more and more exercise.

Don't forget the more rest you take the more healing occurs. The sooner you recover your health the sooner you will be able to go home to your loved ones and families.

M. Matas, M.D.

A book is like a magic box—
Brimful of lovely treasure;
One quaint, old-fashioned key unlocks
Good gifts in generous measure,
Gay songs, and words like jewels old,
Tales carved from ancient times,
And shining legends set in gold,
And chains of silver rhymes.
Patients in hospital suffering from Tuberculosis often feel as though their stay in bed is time wasted. This is definitely the wrong idea to have. Remember there are no insurmountable bars to at least some measure of success. Genius often comes from the most unexpected places.

One of the most beneficial effects on any person's life comes from the books they read. Whenever and wherever it is possible, each one of us should read good books and magazines and read them constantly.

Many of you are not on a high enough routine to do the things in which you are most interested. However, if you take the cure intelligently, that means keeping the rest periods faithfully each and every day, and if you maintain a happy outlook your recovery will be more rapid.

Robert Louis Stevenson (who suffered from Tuberculosis) once wrote, "To travel hopeful is a better thing than to arrive, and the true success is to labour."

L.A. Kautz,
Matron.

WARD I.

We are sorry that Ida Ward of Slave Lake has been moved to a private ward off Ward II as she has not been feeling well.

Mrs. Gardiner, who was our nurse for some time, has been moved to another ward. We miss her very much and hope she will be back some day.

The high routine patients in our ward enjoyed an excursion to the Edmonton City Bakery as part of our car ride on August 27. We saw the making of bread from the sponge to the wrapped loaf. When we had finished our tour, the man gave us each a gift of cookies.

Delphine and Louise Burnstick decided to spend the afternoon playing checkers. Louise defeated Delphine in the first game and suddenly the checkers ended on the floor. No further games were played that afternoon.

Margaret Ward has joined the Fashion Parade with a lovely new house coat.

WARD II.

On Thursday, September 4, five of us went for a car ride. We went through the grounds of the Parliament Buildings. The flowers were in full bloom and were beautiful. We had some snapshots taken. We had a lovely afternoon.

We miss Yvonne Tibbet and Glenna Mykoose who were moved to a private ward as they have been quite sick lately.

One night Lily Papin, already having two blankets, asked for a third. We went to the window thinking it must surely be winter, but found the grass was still green and it was only a chilly night.

One day during rest period, Eliza Whitehead was coloring and dropped her crayons. In trying to reach for them, she toppled out on the floor with a great thud. At first we were afraid it was thunder, but no, it was just Eliza! Moral: Don't color during the rest period.

On canteen order day, Doris bought 3 revels, 2 packages of life-savers, 2 chocolate bars and 2 bottles of pop. The order was delivered just before

(Cont'd)
rest period. Later we went to see her and all that was left were two empty bottles. What a rest Doris must have had!

Doris learned by bitter experience that a finger goes into a bottle more easily than it comes out.

Whenever Adeline hears music she starts to dance. Delia does her dancing in her dreams.

WARD III.

One evening we were talking about the contest that Bert Pearl and the Happy Gang were giving. Mary Jane Boucher and Margaret Eaglechild decided to enter the contest. We asked Maggie Royal if she were going to enter and she answered, "No, I am going to give the rest a chance to win first prize."

On Tuesday we were entertained by the show, "Roughly Speaking", starring Jack Carson and Rosalind Russell. We enjoyed it very much.

Little Marie Black Rider cannot speak nor understand English. But nevertheless when we tell funny stories she always joins our laughter. One day she was watching us play Bingo. After Marie had heard us call "Bingo" a few times, she called out "Finger".

In our ward Elise Laboucan is the entertainer. Whenever music comes on she is on her toes dancing.

Nellie Littlelight became tired of waiting for the ward aide to come for her after her X-Ray. She smelled something good and thinking it was chicken she hurried upstairs by herself. To her surprise it was only STEW for dinner.

The joke was on Angeline Willier. She hurriedly picked up the mail from the desk. Imagine her surprise when she started to sort it, to find that one was a letter she had put there to be mailed two hours ago.

WARD III D.

Jennie Cardinal is very cheerful lately as she gets visitors almost every visiting period. The other day her sister brought her a watermelon. We are all very fond of watermelon so we decided to be extra nice to Jennie that day. It worked for we all got a piece.

Leona Chalifoux gets rather upset when the nurse sends her back to bed after catching her taking exercise. So now she has decided that it is better to stick to routine and stay in bed and make puzzles. Not a bad idea, Leona!
WARD IV.

On Wednesday, August 27, we had a grand car ride. We visited the Edmonton City Bakery. A man showed us around and explained how bread was made, baked and wrapped. He showed us, also, the cake room where the cakes were made. We watched a decorator making fancy pink icing for a birthday cake. As we were leaving we were each given a box of cookies, and one for Ada whom we had to leave in the car.

A few days ago Ada and Doris received a letter from Aklavik in Eskimo. Apparently, the person who wrote it did not know much about the language, so they did not get much out of the letter. However, they had a good laugh and intend to answer it.

Can there be a ghost around? Sarah Koptana's things are always disappearing. She has lost practically everything but her locker, and is beginning to be a little irked about it.

On the night of August the ninth three patients from Cardston were admitted to our ward. Irene went into the washroom and, by mistake, went out the door leading into the hall. She tried door after door and finally found herself on the first floor. Here the night nurse rescued her and guided her back to her ward. She said, when she got into bed, "I have never seen a place with so many doors!"

Margaret Kendö is always laughing but no one seems to be able to find out what the joke is. If we ask her the only answer we get is, "That's what I would like to know!"

Arabella Fox and Irene have a ball game almost every day. It is a funny game for the ball is made of rags and the catcher never knows when the pitcher is going to throw the ball.

Although we had no news last month our ward is still very much alive. What with music by guitar, gramophone and radio there is never a dull moment!

Sister Laura Marie, of Fort Vermilion, visited Elise and Lillian Grandejambe a few days ago.

There is life alone in duty done,

THE LITTLE ELF.

I met a little Elf-man, once,
Down where the lilies blow,
I asked him why he was so small
And why he didn't grow.

He slightly frowned, and with his eye
He looked me through and through.
"I'm quite as big for me," said he,
"As you are big for you."

- John Kendrick Bangs.

We are pleased to see Roy Hunter feeling so much better.

Two little boys, who moved here from Ward VIII C, had been praised by the nurses for always eating everything on their trays. Imagine the surprise of the nurses when they found in the cupboard, one day, a box filled with meat, potatoes, bread and pudding.

WARD IX B.

Pat Mandeville bought himself a guitar recently and is really enjoying himself these days.

Fred Willier is learning to play the violin and is doing very well.

Francis Poitras must use a great deal of ink for his fountain pen is always on the go.

(Cont'd)
Billy Mosquito is a new patient in our ward. He says he doesn't mind being in the hospital for Tuberculosis keeps him company.

Simon, Louis and Ben spend most of their time reading.

John Pascal and Alphonse spend their evenings playing music.

Last Saturday we were pleased to see Dolphus Chibley who came to visit us.

We are all doing well and are happy. We hope the other patients are the same.

WARD IX C.

Greetings everyone! I appreciate and enjoy my treatment in this hospital. Time passes very quickly so I am never lonesome. I think of the future with pleasure and satisfaction. In July I had an operation on my toe. For a while I thought I had lost it but that afternoon when I counted I found I still had five toes.

- Sam Williams.

One day Jim Johnson surprised James Eagle in the wash-room. Suddenly James, with fire in his eye, wheeled about and started to remove his shirt. He grabbed Jim and pushed him against the wall. Jim, tremblingly, talked kindly to him and tried to bring about a reconciliation. Suddenly James' face broke into smiles and all was forgotten.

Harry Bull Lightning is still the cabbage champion. He skunks the rest of us most of the time.

Glad to report that Harry and James are getting over their colds and are able to sit up and take nourishment.

HOMEWORK!
A TALL TALE (WARD X A)

We, in this ward, are very interested in all wild animals. One day, in discussing them, we all agreed that the smartest animal was the beaver until we heard Harry Nedlin's story about the wolverine that stole the snowshoes and the pack sack.

The wolverine is a small animal something like a wolf or coyote. One day, a hunter left his snow shoes and pack sack to follow a moose across a lake. After killing the moose he returned for his gear only to find it had disappeared. He could see the snowshoe tracks in the snow, and wondered who could be the thief. He was hurriedly following the tracks when he heard, "Hello!" Looking up, there he saw an animal with the snowshoes on his feet and the pack sack on his back waving to him. It was a wolverine. Did you ever see a beaver do anything as smart as that?

We know the price of hair cuts has gone up, but Tommy Goose is the first person to take matters in his own hands and cut his own hair. Before you try it, you had better see Tom, for, confidentially he told us that it was not such a bright idea.

On August 20, John Martell was admitted to our ward, but soon after was moved into a private. Hope you come back soon, John.

On August 23, Fred Lafferty, from Yellowknife, joined us and shortly after Harry Nedlin was admitted. Welcome to you both.

Ward X B.

Ernest Horseman was moved to Ward IV to be prepared for his operation. We were pleased to hear that he had it on September 3, and that he is doing well. We miss Ernie very much for he is quite an entertainer with his violin.

A dance will be held in X B on Friday at 8:30 P.M. Since Professor Horseman is not with us, Mary Jane and her orchestra will provide the music. Lunch will be served. Everybody is welcome.

On August 19, Eddie Lafleur and John Giroux were admitted as patients. They are very nice boys and we welcome them.

John Lepine had a sick spell and was moved into the private ward formerly occupied by Dolphus Akinash, who has come back with us. We hope Lepine will feel better soon and be with us again.

(Cont'd)
Leo seems to be very lucky these days as far as visitors are concerned. His uncle, whom he had not seen for two years, surprised him the other day, also the district nurse from Canyon Creek.

When the Radar section is looking for new recruits we will have to recommend Leo and Robert. They have worked out a system of code of numbers by means of which they send secret messages to one another. It seems now that the code is not so secret for Jack Royal has been able to decipher it.

Two Years in the Hospital.

Saturday, September 6 is the second anniversary of my being hospitalized. I spent the first four and a half months in the General Hospital, after which time I was transferred here. I wish to thank the doctors in this hospital for their efforts on my behalf. I have tried my best to cooperate and keep to my routine. I feel much stronger, have gained weight and have a better complexion, but I hope that I will not have to stay another two years.

- Leo Sowan.

WARD X C.

Andy Shade went home on the first of September. Good luck, Andy! There are just four of us left in this ward. Aloysius was moved to a private ward. It pays to be good, Aloysius, for now Dan, being all alone, feels he is being punished too. The three boys in our ward, Louizon, Modeste and Danny Norris are in one end near the windows. They can see the highway and have fun watching the traffic. They also listen to their favorite programs on Danny's radio. Sometimes they play checkers.
