Our Mission School
A Special Holiday.

On November 20th we had a holiday in honor of the wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten. We had a special show in the afternoon and at 5 o'clock we listened to the rebroadcast of the wedding on the radio. Each province of Canada sent a gift to the Princess. Albert Twin, Gr. 5.

A Distinguished Visitor.

What a glad surprise for the children of the Yukon when His Excellency Bishop Couët came to visit us on November 23rd! We went to see him in his room. He gave us some candy and some beads. We were very happy to hear about our dear ones so far away. Bishop promised that when he went back to the Yukon he would see our parents and tell them all about us. Isaac Johnston, Gr. 4.

On December 8th eight sisters and some fathers from the various missions of the vicariate left in two trucks for the distant mission of Wabasca to help celebrate the Golden Jubilee of that mission. On their way back the truck broke down and the sisters had to come back by plane.

At Slave Lake they took the train to come back here. Mother Provincial came with them and spent three days with us. We were glad to see her. We were also glad to have the sisters back.

Louise Whitehead and Walter Twin, Gr. 5.

Feast of the Immaculate Conception.

On December 8th we celebrated the beautiful feast of the Immaculate Conception of the Blessed Virgin Mary. The church was decorated with vigil lights and flowers. We sang the high Mass in honor of the Blessed Virgin. It was a good time to ask for the favors we want. She will grant them if they are good for us, for she is the Mother of God and He cannot refuse her anything.

Frieda Shott, Grade 6.
A New Skating Rink for All.

On December 7th Father joyed it as we tried to do our best. I was Campagna came to replace in the star drill and rhythm band. We all Father Sauvé. On the 9th dressed nicely but had different costumes he had us help him make for the plays we had to do for the visitors. a skating rink. It took lots of time and hard work but we made it anyway. I think it is a good thing to have a skating rink. We have lots of fun. It is much better than going down to the lake to skate. We thank Father for his kindness in giving us this means of entertainment.

Francis Johnston. Gr.5.

Christmas Concert.

On December 19th we had the last day of school before Christmas. So our concert took place on that evening at 7:30. There were quite a few plays and songs. It opened with a welcome song. Then came the plays and other songs. Some of the plays were "The Three Kittens", "Sam's Toothache", "Old Mr. Particular", "The Truth Telling Machine"; other novelties were the Crouard Stampede, Santa Claus Is Coming To Town, some acrobatics and rhythm band selections. Last of all was the Tableau of the Christmas Story which was very nice.

Many people came for the concert. Some sisters came from High Prairie and Joussard. We all hope that everyone who came enjoyed it very much.

Bertha Twin. Gr.8.

We had our concert on Dec. 19th. Many people came. Even the Sisters of Joussard and High Prairie came. We hope they all enjoyed it as we tried to do our best. I was Campagna came to replace in the star drill and rhythm band. We all Father Sauvé. On the 9th dressed nicely but had different costumes he had us help him make for the plays we had to do for the visitors. a skating rink. It took lots of time and hard work but we made it anyway. I think it is a good thing to have a skating rink. We have lots of fun. It is much better than going down to the lake to skate. We thank Father for his kindness in giving us this means of entertainment.

Francis Johnston. Gr.5.

Christmas Holidays at Home.

Boy, the children were excited on the morning of the 20th., for some of them were able to go home for their holidays. The Whitefish Lake children were the first to go, by truck. Father Tessier, Brother Rossé and I met each other. Some of us slept on the way. Father Tessier told us two long stories to pass the time. We got there at four o'clock in the afternoon. We thank Father Tessier for letting us go home.

Russel Grey. Gr.5.

When we went for our holidays we saw our parents. They were glad to see us. On Christmas we went to Midnight Mass. We sang hymns to Baby Jesus.

Sylvia Grey. Gr.3

We were glad to go home for our holidays. Father Floch gave us our Christmas presents. This was a glad surprise that Sr. Superior thought of for us. Thank you, Sr. Superior. We were happy and so were our parents.

Alice Thunder. Gr.4.
Our Christmas Tree.

How happy we were on Christmas Day when the time came for our Christmas Tree. It was at 2 o'clock in the afternoon. How pleased we were to receive such lovely gifts! There were two nice accordions, two guitars, a banjo and a radio, wrist watches for boys and girls, pen and pencil sets, sleds and toboggans, and even a tricycle for the smaller girls. We were indeed all very pleased. All this came from the kindness of good Mr. Hill. We thank him ever so much for these lovely gifts which we all like and enjoy using. May God send his blessing upon him always and keep him in his care.

I was also pleased to receive lovely gifts from my father and thank him ever so much for them. We are all sure that everyone spent a merry, merry Christmas.

Mae Wong. Gr.7.

Midnight Mass.

Oh, how anxious everyone was for Midnight Mass! We went to bed earlier than usual that night so that we wouldn't be so sleepy. We were suddenly awakened by beautiful singing that sounded like angels. We dressed up in a hurry so as to be on time for Midnight Mass. The singing was very nice and many people came for Mass. As for me I think that Midnight Mass is the best part of Christmas. Don't you think so?

Lena Shott. Gr.8.

All the boys and girls went to Midnight Mass. I put some candy in the crib for Baby Jesus. My Mother came to Mass.

Freddy Stevenson. Gr.11.

On Christmas we went to Midnight Mass. We sang Silent Night, Glory to God, and some hymns in Cree. On Christmas Day we went to the boys' hall to get our presents.

Mary Eskagon. Gr.111.

I had lots of presents on Christmas Eve. After Midnight Mass I grabbed my presents. Jean and Mae Wong came for a visit. We had lots of fun.

Ruby Beauchamp. Gr.111.

Gift Exchange.

We had a Christmas tree in our classroom. Baby Jesus also had His place near the tree. All the children in our class wanted to have a gift exchange so it came off on the 19th of December. I had a nice barrett and some cookies. I was very glad because it was nearly dinner time, and so I had a lunch as well as a gift. We all enjoyed our gifts even though they were very small.

Christmas Mail in Grouard

How happy we were to see the mail coming in because we knew that our presents were here. We helped to unload the boxes. There were many bags on the sleigh. All over there were many boxes marked from the U.S.A. Thanks a million to all our generous friends over there who helped to make our Christmas such a pleasant one.

News Items.

We had Father Sauvé here to give us fun of all kinds, such as skating, bingo games, and socials; he even ate with us at our table for dinner and supper, several times. On other days we would all go down the hill to ski, or play hockey on the rink.

Leo Cardinal, Gr.7.

I think the Christmas holidays were enjoyed by the children of Grouard. Father Sauvé came to spend his holidays with us. He amused us with all kinds of games which the children enjoyed heartily. Those who didn't go outside played in the house with games they had received for their Christmas gifts.

Special thanks go to Father Sauvé who devotedly helped to make the Christmas holidays a happy time for all the children.

Lena Shott, Gr.8.

I liked my holidays very much. We played bingo in the boys' hall. We went down to slide on the big hill every day, and also skated. I had a sled for my Christmas present.

Donald George, Gr.2.

I had lots of fun with a tricycle inside of the house at home.

We had a joyful Christmas. A big thank you to all who made it such a happy time for us!

FIRE!! FIRE!!

Fire broke out on Wednesday morning, December 31st at 9:30. While we were cleaning the skating rink and some others were cleaning the church steps, George Grey and Peter Andrews spotted a fire in front of the power house. Fathers and Brothers ran to help while the boys ran for fire extinguishers. Girls and boys carried pails of water, and we all finally succeeded in getting the fire out. It was not an ordinary house that burnt; it was our electric plant.

For a week we had to use candles and lamps to light the mission. A big thank you goes to Sturgeon Lake Mission which so kindly sent us many gas and oil lamps to help brighten our homes. At present we have electricity for a few hours in the morning and a few hours at night. We surely appreciate it now.

Lawrence Layle, Edward Dion, and Cecil Grey.

New Year Party.

Due to the accident above mentioned, our New Year Party turned out to be quite a novelty. Candles proved both practical and decorative in their effect. Placed behind red paper in all the windows and on the pillars, they gave a very attractive and inviting appearance to the room as the children trooped in. Even all the games arranged for the evening were candle games, skill games in either lighting or extinguishing candles. As on other occasions, the group winning the highest number of points received prizes. I think that "Candle Night" will be remembered a long time in Grouard, and we might be tempted to call for another next year, even though we have no intention of tampering with the electric plant to fulfill our desire.

Return of Vacationists.

Before we went home we were told to come back on the 4th. We came by bus, and Brother was there to meet us. We enjoyed our holidays very much and hope that we will be able to go again next year.

Walter P. Twin, Gr.5.

Coming to The Training School.

On January 8th Albina Kidney and I came to Grouard for the Training School. From Fort Vermillion we came by plane to Peace River. Then we came up to Emilda by train where Brother Paquet met us with the car from Grouard. We surely enjoyed our trip, especially the plane ride, since it was our first.

We hope to do our best here at the Training School. We will be learning how to cook and sew, to do house work and many other things, which we didn't know before we came here. Grouard is a good place too. Sister Norbert and Sister Ann Theresa are keeping us. They are good to us. So we will do our very best in everything we do at the Home Centre.

Albina Adekat.

This is my first year at the Training School. I learned how to sew on the machine, and made a boy's coat and a girl's dress. This year my Christmas present was a nice big bicycle from Mr. Hill. I am so glad he sent it to me. He also sent a nice wrist watch to one of the girls. During the Christmas holidays we went skating and sliding.

Alice Bellerose.

I was glad to come to the Training School. I came with my little brother and sister on the 11th of January. Mr. Landry came to get us on Sunday afternoon at our place. I think I am going to enjoy myself here doing this work. We are ten girls here now. I like it here because the girls are good to me.

Another Change In Ground.

On January 17th the news came to us that Brother Paquet was leaving that night for Wabasso. We were all very sorry to see him go because he has always been so good to us. It was he who trained the altar boys so well; he gave the shows in the hall; he directed the singing; he was chauffeur; he did so much that it cannot be counted. Our heartiest thanks go to this good Brother for all his services and kindness to us. May God bless him and give him success in his new mission. —But please, Brother, don't forget your old friends in Ground who will not forget you ever!

Bertha Twin and Lawrence Loyie.

How pleased we were on Sunday night when Sister told us that we girls were going to have a bingo. Many of us won. There were paper dolls, candies and things that we all liked. We surely had a good time. Many thanks, Sister Clare Eva, for making us so happy!

It is a pleasure for me to welcome to our midst Father Serrand, who so generously spends a part of his time in teaching catechism in the first and second classes. We hope that you enjoy teaching us as we enjoy having you. Thank you, Father, and be assured of our deep appreciation.

Lena Shott.

A Special "Thank You!"

My grateful thanks go to Miss Lemieux who had the kindness and patience to teach me to print the journal. I hope that I make as good a pupil as she makes a teacher.

Lena Shott.

VISITORS

Once I played the organ for Sunday Mass at Driftpole. I was a little shy the first time and nervous. Next time I will try to play better because I like music so much. OFF TO WABASCA.

One morning very early before we were awake, two big trucks covered like a little house, and a car, started away up the Highway to go to Wabasca. The Bishops and Mr. Landry were there, many Oblate Fathers and Brothers. Mother Catherine of Bologne and seven Sisters. One Sister who stays here. This was Sister Michael of Jesus who is at the dairy went with them. It was the Golden Jubilee of St. Martin's Mission. 50 years since the Fathers opened the Mission. Our teacher was there once and told us about it. I would like to see it, but it is very hard to travel there.

NELLIE JANE COLLINS.

When Father Serrand was here, we asked him to come in our classroom and tell us all about his trip to Wabasca. He did come and we enjoyed his talk. It was so interesting. It made us wish to see Wabasca. So we hope Father Habay will send us in the big truck some day.

ELSIE CHALIFOUX.

VISITORS

Many Fathers and Sisters came here one night. They all slept here too. The next day when it was still dark they got in the trucks. They were going to Wabasca. Father Sauve went too. He was so glad, the girls made some drawings of the trucks it was good.

HENRY BADGER. Gr. II

GOOD NEWS

All the children were glad when Father told us the good news. "For the first time we can go home for our Christmas holidays." I sure was happy. I went home by bus to Kinuso. We had lots of fun.

BIG THANK YOU.

All thanks to good Fr. Giroux who is charge of the chickens. We often have eggs for our meals, and we want him to know how good they taste. Three cheers for Father Giroux, and we are ready to help you with the hens any time you need a boy.

RENE WILLIER.
TRAPPING

During the Christmas holidays I went trapping. I caught two weasels and five squirrels. I skinned them and sold the fur to trap. It is fun to shoot squirrels in the trees. My father taught me how to set the traps. I will draw a picture to show how it is done. Some day I hope to be a trapper.

FRANK CALLEO.

TRAINING.

This school year we have training several times in the week. Father Sauve takes the boys and Sister Guy the girls. This helps us to be strong and to stand straight too, but it is fun and we shall be able to make some fine drills.

DOROTHY BELLEROSE.

WORK SHOP

Very soon we boys will go to the work shop with Father Sauve. There we shall learn how to make tables, benches, and perhaps other things. We are to go on Mondays. I sure am glad I will feel like a real Carpenter like St. Joseph—What do you think of that.

A BIG SURPRISE.

It was a big surprise for me when I heard that Sister Paul-Bruno was in Grouard. All the people were so glad too. Sister Paul-Bruno is my cousin. I am so glad she came to stay close to us. We wish to see her soon.

DORIS BELLEROSE Gr.11

FUN CHANGED INTO SORROW.

I was having fun sliding down the hill, with boy friends, when Mrs. Callion from Canyon Creek gave me sad news. She said that my Grandfather had just died at the Hospital in High Prairie. He had been there three weeks. He was 72 years old. I have been staying with my Grandfather since I was 2 years old. He took good care of me and I loved him very much. I felt very sad.

On January 4th, they brought the body to the new Church in Kinuso. The next day was the funeral.

Father Sauve, Sister Superior Sr. Michael of Jesus and Sister Alicia came from Jousseard. There were many people in the church for the funeral service.

It was a very sad day for everybody. I shall never forget my dear Grandfather. I will pray for him.

BILL GIROUX.
On the last Sunday before Christmas we played games in the big hall like last month. I think we enjoyed it better than ever. All the girls and boys like this. It is kind of the Fathers to spend this evening with us, the Sisters too. Some of the games are clever, we have to be quick to learn to play them, but in time we shall do them even better. We won a prize. We thank good Father Sauve who does this for us, he takes much trouble to get it all ready. We thank the Sisters for coming and hope they enjoyed it as much as we girls and boys. So here is good success to all the games of 1945.

YVETTE BADGER.

CHRISTMAS

We had such a nice Christmas and this year we were allowed to go to our home. The Midnight Mass was splendid, we had practised the singing and the girls and boys sang ever so well. Father Sauve directs our choir and the singing was in parts. After the Midnight Mass we had nice hot cocoa and doughnuts. Some went home after that with their parents, but most of us waited till the High Mass next day. It was a grand vacation and we are grateful to those who let us go to be with our parents for the New Year too.

EDWARD WILLIER.

We all went home for Christmas. I rode on a sleigh. When we got home my little brothers were sleeping, we wake them and all hung our stockings. The next morning they were not filled. But when we came back to school we had many nice toys and candies.

ANGELINE OKIMAW.

A BIG THANK YOU TO ALL

Grateful thanks to those good Benefactors who sent us so many nice things at Christmas. We enjoyed them all, and we won't forget to pray for them. So Happy New Year kind friends who were so generous to St. Bruno.

ROBERT WARD.
HIP-hip HURRAH!

Everybody is here, not one missing. We were supposed to be back at the Mission for supper on Jan. 8th, and here we are every single one.

The Fathers said that we were very smart to be back on time. I suppose that we will have permission to go home again for the Christmas holidays next year.

BACK TO SCHOOL

I had very nice holidays at home but I was glad to go back to school. My brother and sister like to go to school too. I told my father that we wanted to be first ones to return to the Mission.

On Jan. 8th; after breakfast Dad hitched the horses to the sleigh and off we went. It's a long ride from Driftpile to Joussard.— When we arrived at the Mission, I jumped out of the sleigh and ran into the house to see if we were really the first ones here. Yes, no one else had yet returned. But it was not long before sleighs full of children began to arrive. By supper time everybody was back at the Mission.

The boys tell me that I will not be first next time. We'll wait and see.

CHARLIE NO HAT.

The evening we arrived at the Mission we had lovely Christmas gifts and plenty of fun.

Nice gifts had been prepared by our good friends at the school.

When we went into the hall, I was so glad and excited that I could hardly wait to find out what my gifts would be. We sang a Christmas song. Then Father Sauve gave us a short talk. He said that he was greatly pleased to see everyone present.

Father Sabay, assisted by other Fathers, then distributed the gifts. It was like a second Xmas. There were all kinds of toys, puzzles, for work, candies, nuts, oranges and apples.

We all want to say a big thank you to the good Fathers and Sisters for the joyous welcome they gave us on our return to school.

We had fun on the night of Nov. 1st. We could not have it on Hallowe'en night because it was like Saturday night. We played games, jokes and tricks. We had a peanut race, some little boys went first, then some little girls. We picked peanuts with one hand with spoons and put them in little bowls. When we were finished we ate the peanuts. A boy and girl played seeing the moon through a sleeve. The boy lay on the floor and the girl asked him if he saw the moon. The boy said "Yes". Then the girls threw some water in the sleeve. The boy yelled. We had a biscuit race too. Some biscuits were tied to strings, as we tried to bite them they would swing. After a while we caught them with our mouths. We had a very nice evening and I hope we will have some more games like that again.

I was in the Chinese prayer, and the dishpan race. There were lots of tricks. My sister was to make the ceiling bleed. She got up on a step-ladder. Then she dropped the knife on purpose and told a boy to pick it up. When he did, she poured some water on him. We had lots of fun!

Lloyd Cunningham - IV.

On the 20th of Nov., we had a holiday. It was a nice day to take it for it was Princess Elizabeth's wedding day. It was the feast of St. Elizabeth the day before. We went in the boys' hall for our dinner. The girls made some sandwiches and they put them in a bag. Each one had a bag and a bottle of soft drink.

There was a nice big piece of cake also. I was very glad on that day. After we had taken our dinner, we had a programme. We sang songs and recited some pieces. Some of the smaller boys and girls recited some very nice ones. I like "Many Lands are Fine". Some little boys said a very nice piece about what they would like to be a hundred years ago. Reno and Nora sang "When I was a Cowboy". Then at the end, one big girl came in with a long dress. She was taking the part of St. Elizabeth. She brought a box of apples, and gave us each one. All the boys and girls were very glad. We liked it all very much. After that we played outside until suppertime.

One day Father Roue came to the boys' hall and told us that some day he was going to make a slide for the boys. We were all excited when we heard that. And we asked him whom. Not long after, he came to take four boys to go to work with him. They bought many things. It took them two days, and at last it was finished. We put some snow and some water on it that evening. But when we came to play the next morning, the snow was not frozen. The weather was not cold enough. We waited another day and the snow was melting all over. But now there is lots of snow and we hope it will stay.

Marcel Kiyawasew - V.

Thank you, very much Father, for making such a nice slide for us.

All the Boys.

The new root cellar roof is made of dirt. It is right at the back of our yard. We have a nice yard now because the old chicken house and yard is gone. We use the roof for a slide and it makes a very good one. We are very glad to have it, and sometimes we go sliding on the boys' slide when they are not there. It is nice to play out in the snow.

SILENT NIGHT

After the 10:00 o'clock High Mass all the children went home except nine of us. O were we ever glad when the Christmas holidays came! As soon as the others went home, of course, we turned on the radio. In the afternoon, we went to the farm to play games and have a lunch. Every day we would race to dress ourselves. Then we would run down stairs to turn on the radio. We were laughing, shouting or having fun all the time. When it was dark, we would scare each other. I liked to make the others scream! There were big visitors who came too. They came from Jousard, Grouard and High Prairie; the Sisters enjoyed them very much. Mr. and Mrs. Landry, the Indian Agent, and their little baby came too. Victor Mitchell - I.

The day after we had gone, we went in a taxi to our home where they are cutting pulpwood. The next morning two trucks came to haul the pulpwood. Although only men went to cut down spruce trees, I went to help. Then I sawed wood with Gabriel. Early in the morning, I went to feed the horses. How I enjoyed going home for my Christmas holidays! But I am glad to be back again at school to go on with my schoolwork.

Howard Capot - VI.

Then we came back to the Mission we went to the Crib. Many of us put something by Baby Jesus. We had some candy, apples or some pennies. We will buy these things from Sister, and she will put the money together to buy a pagan baby.

Mary Jane Soos - IV.

On Jan. 6th, it was Kings' Day. We had lots of fun that day. At dinner, Lucy Martineau got the bean. She was Queen and Lloyd Cunningham was the King. We liked the cake very much because it was good. On top of the cake were some white things. After supper, Sister dressed Elizabeth Cunningham as the flower girl. Then we went to the boys' hall and played Bingo. We like to play that. We had a very good time and we went to bed happy.

Saverna Standing Ribbon - IV.

SAD NEWS

When we came back to school, Sister told us about the fire that burned down the electric plant at Grouard. We felt very sorry for all the people there.

Your friends of Sturgeon Lake.
BEAN PARTY.

On November 1st we had a bean party at Hutchison's Hall. All boys under school age were invited. We were 84 boys altogether. We were to bring a stick just as high as ourself for the bonfires, our own cup, plate and spoon. When we arrived at the meeting place there were men who acted as judges. They were to see that the stick was as high as the boy. Some of the boys had to take off their caps to make sure. After the judging was over we piled our sticks up together, and circled around the biggest bonfire. We had eight bonfires outside. But there was one big special one at which Mr. Foster, the policeman, told us what to do. We were to run a race and when we came back we were to run to one of the seven bonfires, and remain there until there was a group of twelve boys at each. Then the judges came to each of the groups. They gave us instructions how to play games. The winners received points for their patrol. We played until it was time for supper. The ladies served us as we passed by the counter with our plate. My, how delicious the beans were! We also had buns, doughnuts and cocoa. When supper was finished we played more games. At nine o'clock all was at an end. We then sang God Save The King. Before leaving we were treated with peanuts and apples. We thank Mr. Foster and all those who helped to make this evening an enjoyable one.

Jos. Courtoiselle, Grade 8.
VISITORS

On November 10th Mr. Gooderham, Inspector of all Indian Agencies in Alberta and N.W.T., and Mr. Patterson came to visit our Mission. They visited the mission buildings. They also came to our classrooms to see how well we worked. We sang a song for them and then Mr. Patterson gave the grade 3 pupils some Arithmetic and Spelling on the blackboard. I had a good laugh at them. Didn't know that Mr. Patterson would come on us next. He gave us a problem on selling furs. I got all my numbers mixed up. Next time I won't laugh at the others. It isn't so easy to work in front of visitors. Then Mr. Gooderham spoke to us. He told us that we did wonderful exhibition work and he encouraged us to keep on. Before leaving he said it was a holiday. He said we are not to take it until we have no more pop left in us. Sister said that if we wait for that day we will never see our holiday. Mr. Gooderham and Mr. Patterson left by plane on the 13th. Mr. Gooderham told us to watch for Mr. Patterson next spring. He will be coming in his 2½ ton car. We are sure going to watch for him. We still wonder if he will ever get here safely.

Helen Attillon, Grade 7

AN ANGEL

A baby girl was born to Mr. and Mrs. M. Fournier from Eleckie Reserve on November 15th in St-Therese Hospital. There was much rejoicing at home when the mother arrived home with the baby. A few days later God came to take this little angel to His Heavenly home. We offer our sympathy to the chief and his wife. God bless them and help them to bear their sorrow.

Albina Adekat, Grade 7

A SURPRISE

On October 1st there was much excitement around the house. I was downstairs and I wondered what was going on. As I was coming up the stairs the girls told me that there was a new Sister named Sister Olier. There was much talking and laughing. Everybody seemed glad to see her. It was surely a long time for Sister for the bakery. God answered our prayers. We are glad to have Sister here and we hope she will like it here.

Paul Tall Cree Grade 5

BAD LUCK

One evening the girls brought a weasel caught in one of their traps. The next day we decided to make some traps for ourselves. We wanted to catch a weasel too. That evening we went to the bush to set them. Everyday after school we went to see them. One day we noticed that there had been weasels in some of our traps. We thought that someone had taken them. So we set our traps across the river where they couldn't get away to say we didn't catch any weasels. Just a little mouse.

John Fournier, Grade 6
AN ACCIDENT

One evening while the girls were watering the slide Marina Flett wanted to have a slide. The girls told her not to slide until there they were finished. Marina did not listen. As she was going up the steps she tripped and rolled down the slide and broke her arm. Sister Celine took her to the hospital. The doctor put her arm in a cast.

Mary Ekle, Grade 6

Our SLIDE

What fun we have on our slide! The working men put big blocks of ice on it so that we can have better slides. Some of us slide all day and we never get tired. Brother Belcourt made us many sleighs this year. We sure make use of them.

George Alock, Grade 6

BIRTHDAY CAKE

December 10th was a happy day for little Emma Marcelet Flett. It was her birthday. Emma is now four years old. One of the kitchen girls made her a little cake and put four little candles on it. That morning while we were having breakfast Sister Bustacho brought the cake to Emma. Little Emma didn't know what to do. She had fun blowing out her four candles. When it was time to eat the cake Emma didn't forget to give some to her three sisters and her friends.

Evelyn Robert, Grade 6

ARRIVAL OF MISSIONARIES

The feast of the Immaculate Conception is a great feast for the Oblates Fathers and Brothers. On the 8th of December Father Jal and Brother Le Blanc came from Hay Lake to join in the feast. We were all glad to see them again. Brother Le Blanc did not stay with us very long. He went with Father Hommeur to Paddle Prairie for a week. Father Jal went back to Hay River for Christmas. Father Mariman went to help him. They are back now to stay for a short while.

Albina Kidney, Grade 5

A GIFT

One day Father Jal asked Sister Jean Leon to make him some flowers for his church at Hay Lake. That same day we also got busy to make him some. Some of us made two minute flowers and some others made roses. When we were finished we gave them to Father as a Christmas gift. He was very pleased. We were glad to work for his poor mission.

Grace Auger, Grade 5

HOME AGAIN

Everybody was glad to see Peter Courtoireille come back from the Camell hospital. Peter is lame. His father brought him to the doctors to see if they could do something for him. They kept him in the hospital for three years. Now he is back with us again. Peter is not much better. How glad his parents were to see him.

Walter Cassoncy, Grade 6
HAPPY NEW YEAR

Even though many children were in bed for Christmas we all enjoyed the day very much. We were not more than 20 children at midnight Mass. Everybody said we sang well. We sang the B.M.Mass. Father Jan taught some of the boys to sing the prayer of the mass. We were quite at first but two of the best singers got sick. I was one of them that sang; I was sure nervous. There were many people in church. Some of the children sang solos. The people said that they liked that the best.

We were very disappointed not to have our Christmas tree this year. Santa didn't forget us even though many were sick. Then we came to breakfast we had all our gifts at our places. How glad we were! Santa went to visit the sick upstairs. I don't think they enjoyed their toys very much, for they were too sick.

Paul Tall Cree, Grade 5

PICTURE SHOW

We had the best picture on the 4th of January. The name of it was "Jeep Hunters." There was much trouble at Mr. Martin's ranch so his son sent a telegram to his soldiers' friends for help. They came with their jeeps and in no time they captured the wicked men who were causing all the trouble. It was very funny at times. We sure had many laughs. It was all in technicolor. It was the first time we had one like that. We like it so much that Father let us see it again on Epiphany.

Evelyn Robert, Grade 6

"A VISIT"

Doctor Stone paid us a short visit on January 6th by plane. He came in the afternoon to see us. He examined our eyes and teeth. After he went through he said he had no complaints to make about us. Instead he gave us a good compliment. He said we were healthy and good looking. I hope he meant it. We all thanked him for the compliment and we hope we will always be healthy and good looking.

Doctor Stone left by plane on Thursday 2nd.

Rachel Cardinal

CHRISTMAS HOLIDAYS

I had a long Christmas holiday this year. My little sister had the measles on the 10th of December so my two brothers and I had to stay home. I got the measles too, but I was not very sick.

We started school on the 12th. I was glad to come back again. It seemed a long time I didn't come.

William Ourtereille
Grade 4
CHRISTMAS CRIB

When Sister Margaret Martha asked Fred and I to help her to make the crib in the church we were very glad. She said we were tall and strong enough to do the climbing and the running. Did we ever run! The crib looked very nice when it was finished. I like the scene at the back of the crib. We also helped Sister to make the decorations on the altar and around the church.

Louis Fournier, Grade 5

A JOLLY SLEIGH RIDE

On January 6th we went for a long sleigh ride. We went to the airport. We sang songs on the way and had lots of fun. Brother and Blankie sang songs for us. We surely enjoyed the ride.

When we came home Sister gave us a treat of peanuts and candies.

Ida Cassoney, Grade 4

RETURN OF FATHER ARBET

We were glad to welcome Father Arbet back from France. Father enjoyed dinner. He said he was glad his visit home but he said he was glad to come back to his home at Hay Lakes. He also said that times are hard in France, and that we should be grateful for what we get here in Canada.

Welcome Home Father! We hope you can stay with us for some time.

Fred Eklo, Grade 7

CHRISTMAS TREE

After dinner on Christmas day we had our gifts. They were placed around the tree. We were excited when Sister told us Father was coming to give us our gift. Everybody had nice gifts. I had a game of Freddy Frog. I enjoyed playing with it.

George Alock, Grade 6

A pretty little wedding took place in our chapel on January 7th. The couple were Florence Gayton from Peace River and Clifford Smith from Stoney Point.

The bride wore a floor length gown of blue nylon. She carried a bouquet of roses.

We sang hymns during the mass. When they were leaving the chapel, Sister played a march. They then went back to Stoney Point for the wedding dinner.

We wish the newly weds a long and happy life.

Grace Auger, Grade 5

DEPARTURE

On January 10th two of our school mates went to the Training School at Grouard. I was sorry to see them go for they were my best friends. They left by plane just before noon by plane just before noon. Some of the girls went to the airport to see them off. We hope they enjoy their trip. It was their first ride in the plane and also in the train. I always longed to ride in a plane and train. I hope that time will come someday.

I wish good luck to you girls and hope you will like it there. We know you will come back real smart. We miss you already.

Helen Attilon Grade 7
A NEW SISTER

Our Nurse, Sister Laura Marie is sick at Christmas Holidays, leaving us for Cranbrook, B.C. We are very sorry she is going. She was very nighty good to the sick.

Good Luck to you, Sister! Sister Alcide Marie came to take Sister's place. We hope she will like it here. Santa Claus did not forget me.

She arrived by plane on the 12th. He brought me a nice game.

Sister Gertrude Eugenia and Sister Eustache went to meet the plane in a caboose. They wanted to give Sister Our school was very nice for Christmas first ride, but they were too late.

When they got there Mr. Low from the Experimental Farm was seeing driving out the gate. He offered to take Sister to the mission. So the Sisters had to come home without her. I think they went just for the ride.

Norman Yotenawatam, Grade 6

GERMAIN COBERT, Grade 2

Rosalie Grandjambe, Grade 1

Therese Auger, Grade 2

Moise Makwayan, Grade 2

We heard during the holidays that our Inspector Mr. Wilson was changed. We didn't like the news. We are all very sorry. Mr. Wilson has always been very kind to us. I think they are very lucky to have him at?

George Alock, Grade 6

SAD NEWS

We are glad to see James Inlaye back with us. He came back by the plane. He was at the General Hospital. He sang a song for us.

Alma Manotch, Grade 2

We have four new pupils in our class. There are many children in our class.

Sarah Makwayan, Grade 2

I got a paint book and water colors from Santa Claus.

I like my paint book.

I let my sister paint in it sometime.

Louis Ekie, Grade 2

NEW COMERS

Five new children have come to stay with us since the holidays. Their Mother died about a month ago at Hay Lakes. The baby is only two years old. The oldest one is 12 years old. The two oldest ones have never been to school. They seem glad to start to school.

Helen Attion, Grade 7.

JUBILEE

On December 10th, 11th was the Jubilee of fifty years. There were many Fathers and Sisters. In the evening we had a Concert. The next day we had a Pontifical Mass. After Mass we had a big Banquet. Many people came. Some of the Fathers spoke. The next evening we had movies and it was the first time we heard talkies in Jabason. I liked them.

Lucy Auger Gr. IV

MIDNIGHT MASS

On Christmas Eve there were many people who came for Mass and received Holy Communion, for it was our dear Saviour's Birth. It was nice to see the chapel full. How Jesus must have been glad to see a great number of people. Some of them it was the first time they came for Mass for a long time. They wore in the bush trapping. There was a nice sermon by Father Guimont. During the Credo Bro. Gaucher passed around with a plate for those who would like to give some money to the Baby Jesus. We sang a nice Mass.

Hilda Bigstone Gr. VII

CHRISTMAS TREE

Dec. 23rd we had our Christmas gifts. We were very glad to have presents from Father Superior and Sister Superior. We each had an orange and a bag of peanuts and candy also.

Hilda Bigstone Gr. VII

Our Jubilee guests arrived by car, trucks, sleighs and plane. Bishop Routhier brought 11 Priests 5 Brothers and Mr. Landry with his secretary and interpreter.

Mother Catherine of Bologna, the New Mother Provincial came with 7 other Sisters. One was a Sister of St. Joseph from McLennan.

We looked for good Father Giroux but the Bishop said he was not able to come so we were sorry not to have him for the Jubilee.

It was wonderful to have so many visitors all at one time.

François Gladu

Bro. DUMAS'

DEPARTURE BY PLANE

On Dec. 2nd Bro. started from the barn with a horse and sleigh. The horse ran away and Brother got badly hurt when he jumped from the sleigh that they sent for him and he went to Edmonton. He is getting better but he is not back yet.

George Yellowknose
On Dec. 24th after Midnight Mass we all went home. Our parents came to get us. We were to have 14 days of holidays. We had lots of fun. We enjoyed them very much. We went to visit all our friends, and wish them a Merry Christmas and Happy New Year. We had a wonderful time.

Eliza Augor Gr.VI

THE FIRST LINN ARRIVES IN WABASCA

A large, large truck arrived here Jan. 1st, 1948. The man brought 7 tons of freight, some for the Mission and some for the H.B.C. The Linn weighs 11 tons and can carry much more freight. It is the first time that we see a truck made like that here. The Linn is about as large as a big truck but it is much more powerful. Half of it looks like a truck but instead of brick wheels it has a caterpillar under it. There was a two-wheeled cart behind it full of freight, also.

The Linn is owned by Mr. MacIntosh of Calling Lake, who is a Fish Contractor. He has two plans to carry fish also. The Linn has a diesel engine. I hope to have a ride in it some day.

Patrick Young Gr.VII
Gabriel Augor Gr.VII.

DEPARTURE FROM WABASCA
BY LINN TO SLAVE LAKE

When the Linn returned to Slave Lake Bro. Gaucher went to see his Father who is sick. Miss Hannas our District Nurse left at the same time for a few holidays. We wish them good luck and hope they will return soon.

Elsie Yellowknee Gr.VII

IMPROVEMENTS

Brother Laurin and Bro. Mathis arranged one of our furnaces which needed repairing very much. Since the Jubilee these two Brothers and Mr. George Gullion have been working hard putting in new and large heat pipes. Now we will be warm in our class and the girls' hall.

Thank you Brothers and Mr. Gullion for your quick work?

Louise Auger Gr.VI

THE CHRISTMAS CRIB

Each year we have a beautiful Crib in the Chapel. It is always fixed by our good Sister Superior and the Sister in charge of the Chapel. Before they fix the Crib they put colored cellophane paper, some green, red, orange and purple in the window beside the Crib. It is so nice when the sun is shining, we can see the beautiful colors on the Crib. Behind the Crib is a scene nicely painted. On it is the star, a little town and some sheep. It was painted by Bartholomew Gladu. We are always anxious to see the little Jesus at Midnight Mass. The statues are very nice for the Crib. We hope to have one every year.

Hilda Auger Gr.VII
(POINT ST. CHARLES)

THE FEAST OF SAINT CHARLES NOV. 4

On the day before the Feast of Saint Charles, our teacher told us that there would be no school the next day. We were very glad to have a holiday. On the feast of Saint Charles, the Fathers and the Sisters came to visit Saint Charles Mission. They went back to Saint Martin's in the evening.

Edward Cardinal, Grade II

GOLDEN JUBILEE AT SAINT MARTIN'S MISSION.

There was a GOLDEN JUBILEE at Saint Martin Mission. They celebrated this Feast for three days... It was very nice. We had no school on two of these days. We went to Saint Martin Mission too, to celebrate. It was nicely decorated in all the principal rooms. We went to the 10 o'clock Mass in the morning; there was a big banquet at 12.30. All the Indians ate in the Boy's hall which was decorated. There were nice flowers on all the tables... In the evening there was a moving picture show and talkies. It was very interesting. We enjoyed it all very much.

Mabel McLeod, Grade VI.

HIS EXCELLENCY BISHOP ROUTHIER VISITS ST. THERESE SCHOOL AT SAINT CHARLES MISSION.

The following Monday after the GOLDEN JUBILEE we had the pleasure of receiving His Excellency Bishop Routhier in our School. How glad we were to see His Excellency.... We were not so shy as we thought we would be... At first we made our pledge to the Cross and the flag and then sang "O Canada" in Cree. We also gave a short play called "OUR CREE". Little Mary Rose gave a hearty Welcome to His Excellency tho' it was very short. It was the first time that Mary Rose spoke a piece... His Excellency took the trouble to bless each and every one of all the 34 pupils present. He also gave us a Jubilee Souvenir card of Kateri Tekakwitha. Father Vandersteene then showed our Catechism Books with sketches and Cree Character. And we showed all our copy books of school work. His Excellency did not fail to question us in Religion. Before leaving us, we sang a song with our kazoos. His Excellency encouraged us to come to Mass and Communion often, then he bade us all good-bye.... We were sorry to see Him go.....

Mabel McLeod, Grade VI.

VISITORS.... BUT WE DID NOT SEE THEM???

We were very sorry to hear that Mother Provincial and her companion came to visit our school while we were at home. They visited our school on Sunday after High Mass.... They did not stay long, as Mother Provincial and all the Sisters were to leave that very day... for Slave Lake... They did not leave but they came back as the truck broke down. They then left by plane... We hope that we will not miss our visitors next time..... On another day all the Fathers
came to our school but we had just gone home... We were sorry to miss them also... especially those we had known at the Point. We wish to thank very heartily Father Tessier who was so kind as to give our teacher a large box of chocolate cookies for us..... Thank you Father, but please come again and stay a little longer.......

Fasceline McLeod, Grade IV

OUR DISTRICT NURSE PAYS US A VISIT

One day Nurse Hannas paid us a visit in our school... We were very glad to see her, and like to have her come to see us... Miss Hannas inoculated in the previous year... She brought us a treat of candy too... We dramatized and sang for Miss Hannas... Then she took a picture of the children in the school with the teacher. She also took a picture of us all on our school porch. We were eating our afternoon lunch and smiling...... We thanked Miss Hannas for her visit and we sincerely hope that she will come again...

Helen Gladu, Grade IV

OUR CHRISTMAS CONCERT

We had our Christmas Concert on the 19th for the Mission Children at Saint Martin's and we also had it on the 21st in the afternoon for all the Fathers and the Sisters at Saint Martin's and at our Mission. All our parents came too... We did our very best to speak loud and distinctly... All the people enjoyed our concert because they told us so... All the boys and girls had nice Christmas gifts... We were all very happy and glad to get our toys and gifts... I got a nice doll.

Marina Gladu, Grade III

CHRISTMAS VACATION

We had our Christmas Vacation right after our Christmas Concert. We came back on the 7th of January.....

Daniel Yellowknee, Grade III

BACK TO SCHOOL AGAIN.

I started to come back to school on the 7th of January and I was very glad to come to school. I was in Slave Lake. I am in Grade II but my teacher
said I would go in Grade III if I work very hard... I like school.

Georgina Cardinal, Grade II

BINGO... BINGO...

Our teacher promised us a BINGO if we would do our best at the Concert for the 19th and a party on Valentine Day if the concert on the 21st was good.... We tried hard and we won.... so now we are practising Bingo, for next week on Tuesday or Wednesday we will play for the prizes... We like to play Bingo...very much... We will invite Father Vandersteene and Sister Mary de Bethanis...

Mary Cardinal, Grade V.

A DOLL SHOW

One day little Eileen aged five brought her doll to school. We were all interested. All the girls wanted to bring their dolls to school... So our teacher told us that we could bring them. The next day there were thirteen or fourteen dolls.... All the dolls were wrapped up like real papooses... It was real nice to see them.

Marina Gladu, Grade III

TOYS IN SCHOOL

I brought my toy automobile to school... I wound it up and it went across the room. Everybody liked my little car...

Roy Belhomme, Grade III

TOOLS IN SCHOOL

I brought my tools to school. There are six tools.

Paul Gladu, Grade I

WINTER SPORTS

After dinner we go sliding every day. Nearly everybody has a sled. Brother Kerherve made our sliding place. Brother made all our swings and teeter boards too.

Roger Cardinal, Grade II

As we start a New Year, it is customary for us to try to live a better life than we did the year before. We usually call these efforts "New Year's Resolutions."

You have probably made several resolutions, but one I want to suggest to you is to "CHASE THE CURE" even better than you did in 1947.

Now you ask, "How can I chase the cure better?"

Firstly, observe your rest periods completely, using every moment of the specified period for complete physical and mental rest.

Secondly, apart from the official rest periods, spend as much time as you can in bed, and avoid using up extra energy.

Thirdly, closely adhere to the routine allotted to you by the medical staff.

Fourthly, co-operate fully with the nursing and other staff in their efforts to help you get well.

Fifthly, try to be cheerful at all times, and encourage your neighbors.

Let us all go forward — both patients and staff — to make this a year full of achievement and good cheer. Let us all hope and pray for peace in this troublous world of today.

(H. Meltzer, M.D.,
Medical Director.)

A NEWS CLIPPING FROM THE EDMONTON BULLETIN

Editor, Bulletin - We wish to take this opportunity of publicly thanking all those organizations and individuals who gave so generously of their time and energy to assist us in making Christmas more enjoyable for our Indian, Eskimo and D.V.A. patients.

It was most gratifying to see the spirit with which they entered into the various undertakings - decorating Christmas trees, entertaining the patients, wrapping gifts, and last but not least, giving presents and treats to all. Words cannot express the gratitude felt by both the patients and the staffs of this hospital.

We want to mention particularly the following organizations who gave gifts or cash donations: I.O.D.E., Elks, Red Cross, Kinettes, Gyrettes, Kinsman, Rotary, Kiwanis, Lions, Y's Men, Knights of Columbus, C.W.L., Legion, Veterans Hospital Recreation Council, and many others too numerous to mention.

H. Meltzer, M.D.,
Medical Director.
Charles Camsell Indian Hospital, Edmonton.

DID YOU HEAR MISS OATEN ON THE RADIO?

Canadian Broadcasting Corporation News Roundup Recorded 11-12-47

Service Message: Hospital convalescence is a trying period for almost anyone but Indian and Eskimo patients find it even more of an ordeal than others. In Edmonton, the Charles Camsell Indian hospital has inaugurated a handicraft program that serves two useful purposes. Miss D. Oakden, supervisor of the project, is interviewed by Enid Nemy of The Canadian Press.

(Continued)
Enid: Miss Oakden, just what is the program, does it take in a few specific crafts or a number of them?

D. Oakden: Well, actually the patients have their choice of all the usual handicrafts done in hospitals — but we try to get them interested in leather and bead work that will help preserve their ancient tribal crafts. The women do beautiful embroidery on mitts, mukluks and gloves. They work out their own designs and choose their own color schemes and, of course, they do their own cutting and shaping.

Enid: Do you find the designs and color schemes follow the usual pattern or are they generally original?

D. Oakden: They are quite original. Both Indian and Eskimo women have unusual taste in color and design. Often when they describe the colors they plan to use it sounds as if the finished article will be ruined but I'm always amazed— they can use almost unheard of color combinations and yet it seems just right when completed.

Enid: How about the men — do they take part in the program or are they content to leave the crafts to the women?

D. Oakden: No, they are just as enthusiastic as the women. They concentrate mainly on leather work which they can do well. They're exceptionally good on articles like belts and harnesses — they make some extremely smart ones and yet they are sturdy.

Enid: What happens to the work once it is completed — do they keep the articles they make?

D. Oakden: The work is sold to various people and business organizations and the money is divided among them in proportion to the amount of work done. Selling the completed articles makes the whole project self-supporting and also provides a great deal of incentive.

Enid: Other than keeping the patient interested, do you find there is any result from the program?

D. Oakden: Yes, most of them have done some sort of handicraft work before but working at it while they are ill and also allowing them full scope and giving them encouragement certainly helps to preserve their own crafts and native talent. Many patients ask to continue their work after

(Continued)
their discharge and once they find that only articles with good workmanship are saleable, they take pride in turning out the best work they can.

Enid: Thank you, Miss Oakden. This is Enid Nemy reporting from Edmonton.

WARD II (Private) (Continued)

Agnes—"One night just as I was dropping off to sleep I heard a tapping on the door. When I opened the door there stood a funny little brown man. At first I did not recognize him he looked so queer. A letter from Mrs. Mary Frances:

Hello friends,

Don't know what to write but I'll try. First I'll say thank you for the doctors and nurses and all the girls who work in the hospital. I sure thank God for them every day, because they try hard for the patients to better them. Ever since I got here I never do anything for myself. And another thing all the patients are good to me. I am very glad for all that. I have been in this Charles Camell Hospital for seventeen months. I am sure tired of it and lonesome for my children, because I have been away for a long, long time. My husband passed away before I came here, so I have no real home after I get better. Anyway, the people were good to me when my husband was sick and they will be good to me when I go back. And another thing I found to be thankful for in this hospital is that I have learned to write, although I can't write very well yet. Anyhow, I have learned lots of good things ever since I got here and I hope that I can remember them when I go back north and I will have lots of things to tell and show my friends.

Mary Frances.

"When I had my first operation I thought I was going to die any minute. But the nurse cheered me up and said that it would take more than that to make me die. GUIDES FOR MAKING INTRODUCTIONS CORRECTLY.

1. To introduce a boy to a girl, say the girl's name first; as,
   "Nancy, may I introduce John?"

2. To introduce a younger person to an older person, say the older person's name first; as," Mrs. Williams, may I present Bob?"

3. To introduce a man to a woman, say the woman's name first; as,
   "Miss Walter may I introduce Mr. Taylor?"

4. To introduce a very distinguished person either to a man or to a woman, say the name of the distinguished person first; as,
   "Mr. Justice Browne, may I present Mr. Robertson?"

5. To make conversation easy for people you have introduced, mention some common topic of interest; as,
   "Miss Brown, this is John Cain. John likes to make models of historic boats. Since you like ship pictures, I thought you would enjoy discussing his models."

GIRLS LEAVE FOR ANAHAM

It was indeed a memorable day, when we bade farewell to a group of girls, who were answering the call of a holy vocation. They were Irene Miller of St. Mary's School, Adeline Thomas of Kuper Island School, Dolly Thomas and Audrey Paul of North Vancouver. When they reached Nanaimo, they were greeted by Doris James of Kuper Island School, who has been with the Sisters at Anaham for two years and Teresa Edwards of St. Mary's School. Martha Smith of Christie School joined them several weeks later.

On the evening before Irene's departure, the girls of the Student Guidance Club gave a little party for her, which she enjoyed very much. Some weeks later our principal, Father Flory, went up to visit them. When Father finally returned he told us how well they were getting along and how happy they were. On December 8th, the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, the girls were made postulants under the title of Sisters of Mary Immaculate. This was a wonderful day for them. Sister Irene Miller wrote: "I was never so happy in all my life. At first when I put on my postulant's habit, I felt a little shy as I thought that everyone was staring at me on my way to the Church. We had a lovely Mass with a nice sermon by Father Sutherland. We had a turkey dinner, went for ride in the afternoon and put on a little concert in the evening. It was a most happy day for all of us." We wish these girls success in their vocation and trust that many more will follow in their footsteps.

June Silver.

GOLF CLUB

At the Mission Fair Sept. 3 and 4, our Golf Club won the first group of many prizes that fell to us this year. In the open class Jimmy Kolly's calf won a silver cup first place. For the most points in the ground, I got first place, also winning a silver cup. In showmanship, we each received cash prizes. On September 11, we went to Chilliwack Fair. We entered in the same classes again. In the open class Jimmy's calf came first again. In the showmanship all four of us came first; Jimmy Kolly, Kenneth Reid, Ray Frank, and Leslie Andrews.

On September 17, we went to Boundary Provincial Fair. This time it was for the final challenge. There were ten other clubs competing against us, but we beat them all, winning the Premier Farms Challenge Trophy for the best Holstein Calf Club in British Columbia. We previously won this Trophy in 1944. On Friday December 12, the shield and silver cups were presented to us by Mr. G. Hicks, president of the Canadian Holstein Association. We were guests at the annual banquet in the Russell Hotel, New Westminster.

Leslie Andrews, Gr. 9.

FATHER PROVINCIAL

On December 16, Father Birch, the new Father Provincial of the Oblates, came to visit us. He said mass in our chapel and gave us a nice sermon. We put on an entertainment for him, which he enjoyed very much. We were very happy when he promised us a special moving picture show.

On Wednesday morning, we visited the two rooms in the Father's building, which have been painted. One room is a nice light blue, and the other peach colour. The one I favoured most was the pink peach coloured room. Not only the colour of the room did I like, but there is a nice big comfortable bed in the room too.

Cortie James, Gr. 8

BROTHER ED.

SOCCER

The senior soccer league is great for the outside teams, because our team is not the team it was last year. We played eight games in the first half of the league. GIRLS LEAVE FOR ANAHAM

It was indeed a memorable day, when we bade farewell to a group of girls, who were answering the call of a holy vocation. They were Irene Miller of St. Mary's School, Adelina Thomas of Kuper Island School, Dolly Thomas and Audrey Paul of North Vancouver. When they reached Hanceville, they were greeted by Doris James of Kuper Island School, who has been with the Sisters at Anaham for two years and Teresa Edwards of St. Mary's School; Martha Smith of Christie School joined them several weeks later.

On the evening before Irene's departure, the girls of the Student Guidance Club gave a little party for her, which she enjoyed very much. Some weeks later our principal, Father Fleury, went up to visit them. When Father finally returned he told us how well they were getting along and how happy they were. On December 8th, the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, the girls were made postulants under the title of Sisters of Mary Immaculate. This was a wonderful day for them. Sister Irene Miller wrote: "I was never so happy in all my life. At first when I put on my postulant's habit, I felt a little shy as I thought that everyone was staring at me on my way to the Church. We had a lovely Mass with a nice sermon by Father Sutherland. We had a turkey dinner, went for ride in the afternoon and put on a little concert in the evening. It was a most happy day for all of us." We wish these girls success in their vocation and trust that many more will follow in their footsteps.

June Silver.

THE STORY OF JOHNNY T.B

One summer day I was strolling down the street of our Indian village. I was thinking how lucky I was to be strong and healthy, able to work and able to play on a day like that. I paused for a moment to enjoy the cool shade of one of the houses before continuing my walk when I thought I heard someone calling faintly. I looked around but saw no one near enough to know I was there. Again I heard a faint call, this time seeming to come from near my feet. I bent down and the sound was louder—loud enough for me to be sure it was actually someone who wanted to talk to me. Although I couldn't see anyone I said, "Who is it? Who called me? And where are you?"

The voice answered, "It's me, Johnny T.B., and I'm down here beside the stone. I was lonesome and I wanted to talk to someone." I thought it strange to hear a voice coming from a dirty spot on the ground by this stone, but I was interested. Looking around I found there were no villagers in sight just then who might think I was queer if I appeared to be talking to myself. Then I sat down on an old box which was handy and I said, "Well, it seems strange not to be able to see you Johnny, but I can stay here for a few minutes. If you want to talk, go ahead. What did you say your last name was?"

Johnny replied, "Really my last name is Tuberculosis, but everybody calls me 'T.B.' for short. Lots of people have nicknames,"
Johnny TB (Continued)

and that's mine. Boy, oh boy, I'm glad to see you. I was getting tired of being alone here, and someone nearly stepped on me, and I'm cold and I had a narrow escape yesterday and I wish I knew what was going to happen to me." I could see he was so anxious to talk his words were just tumbling out so I said, "I'll listen to your story Johnny T.B. and you can explain what happened."

Johnny said, "Thanks a lot. Some of the things I will tell you may be new to you so don't be surprised. You know, I'm a germ. I'm so very small it's no wonder you can't see me. There are lots of different germs in this world, but we Tuberculosis germs are among the toughest of the lot. We can live a long time unless we have some hard luck - and I guess my hard luck started yesterday. All of my brothers and sisters and a lot of my cousins and other relatives have been living in the lungs of your friend Peter. It was nice and warm there and we've been having a wonderful time. Of course, Peter didn't know we were there. And do you know why he felt too tired to go fishing this week? It wasn't just the 'cold' he thought he had. It was because some of my cousins became angry with him because he said he was going to get more rest. They started to work on him some time ago and have done a lot of damage to his lungs. That's what made him start coughing. That's what has made him tired and weak and get thinner and that's why he didn't go fishing.

"Peter was walking by this house yesterday and he was coughing and spitting. I was careless and got in the way and he coughed me out of his lungs. I landed here in the shade luckily - if I'd been around on the sunny side of the house I'd be dead by now. We T.B. germs can't stand sunlight at all.

"I had another close call yesterday. While I was resting after the bump I got when I splashed on the ground, your sister Mary came running along and nearly stepped on me. I don't mind being a bit dirty here on the ground (we germs seem healthier when we're dirty), but if Mary had stepped on me I might have been pushed deeper into the earth and perhaps I'd have had to stay there a long time. As it is now, once I get dried up a bit maybe the wind will blow me someplace where I can find a new home in some other..."
Johnny TB (Continued)

Indian's lung.

"If that happens I'll be safe again. Hope it's somebody who is healthy. It's more fun picking on someone who thinks he is as Samson."

Johnny paused for a moment, and I said - "What's going to happen to Peter if your cousins are still in his lungs?" Johnny replied, "Well, that's up to him I guess. If he's foolish, and keeps on working hard, and staying up late at night, he'll just get thinner and weaker, and die just like his father did three years ago. My father and mother and some of my uncles and aunts used to live in the old man's lungs, but they managed to get into Peter's lungs when he was caring for the old man after he got sick. That's the way my folks get around - on dishes used by some person we have made sick or when he kisses some else, or coughs near him. We really don't care whose lungs we get into as long as we get there - that's the best place for us. And we don't care much what happens to them as long as they don't look after themselves. We have our own lives to live.

"But if Peter should decide to go to the doctor one of these days and the doctor finds out what is wrong with him maybe I'll be the lucky one and my cousins will be unlucky. Why? Because the doctor might send Peter to the hospital and he'd get well again.

"I've heard they do strange things in those hospitals. They look at your lungs with a machine called the X-ray, they do different kinds of tests to see whether we germs are getting stronger or weaker, and they do little operations sometimes that help the patient but certainly don't help us. The commonest thing they do is to put a patient in bed even though he may not feel very sick. And mind you, maybe the doctors get him to stay in bed for a long time. We tuberculosis germs don't like that at all. We're the ones that get weak then - many of us die and the rest get all tangled up in what the doctors call 'scar tissue', a sort of living death I guess, as far as we are concerned. Whoops! there goes my hat. Looks as if the wind is getting stronger. Hope it does. Maybe I'll get a break and get blown someplace where..."
Johnny TB (Continued)

I can get a fresh start. Don't go yet, my friend. I've enjoyed telling you about — say, don't do that, it's not fair, you're hurting me, I can't breathe, you can't —".

But I could and did. I had listened to Johnny T.B. long enough. I was tired of his bragging. I knew he was dangerous even if I couldn't see him. I did know that he was somewhere in that dirty spot where Peter had spit so carelessly and I decided he should do no more harm. With a flat piece of iron I found nearby I had dug a hole and buried Johnny so the wind would never blow him into the lungs of any of my friends. As soon as I had finished I hurried off to find Peter. He was surprised when I told him I was sure he had T.B., but he was sensible about it and went to the doctor the very next day. And I'll know you'll be glad to hear that Peter did go to the hospital, that he stayed there till his lung trouble was better and that he's home again now, well and strong. After his next x-ray examination we believe the doctors will say he can go back to work again.

February 10 was Shrove Tuesday. It is sometimes called Pancake Tuesday in these days. In early times it was a day set aside for spiritual "cleansing" or preparation for the coming season of Lent.

Wednesday, February 11, was Ash Wednesday—the first day of Lent. The name was derived from an old-age custom of the Roman Catholic Church.

Lent is the 40-day period during which adherents of most Christian churches recall Christ's 40 days of fasting and temptation on the desert. The period ends Easter morning.

February 12 was Abraham Lincoln's birthday. He was one of the best-loved Presidents of the United States. He was a great story teller and most of them were spontaneous to bring out some point.

One day he was walking down the street in his own home town, with his two small sons, both of whom were crying loudly.

A neighbor stopped and inquired, "What is the matter with the boys?"

"Just what's the matter with the whole world," replied Lincoln. "I've got three walnuts and each of the boys wants two!"

He treated his ailments in a light vein. One day a visitor found him suffering from a severe cold. The visitor was very sorry. Lincoln looked down at his very, very large feet and said, "Well, I expect colds; there is so much of me on the ground, you know!"
THE BLIND

God pity those whose eyes can
never see the sun's good light -
Who dwell within the darkness of
an everlasting night - Who cannot
see the glories that surround us every-
where - The clouds, the stars, the trees, the
flowers - birds winging through the air...
And there are people in this world who
have the gift of sight - Yet never lift their
eyes to see the skies ablaze with light - Whose
eyes are blind to beauty, and the wonders
of the days - In mental darkness plodding
down their little humdrum ways ... They
only see the obvious - the solid
commonplace - and never pause to stare
into a flower's lovely face - or watch a
raindrop on a twig - a bead of shining glass -
and sparrows looking for the crumbs out on
the frosty grass - The world is full of beauty -
it's all here for us to find - But oh! we
do miss such a lot - We're all a little blind!
- Patience Strong

Indian O.T. or Handicraft Section

This is the last time that I, as your Handicraft Supervisor, shall have the opportunity of putting a message in the Camsell Arrow.

Most of the patients know, I think, that I shall be leaving this work at the end of February, to go to the United States. This section has grown so much, due to the splendid work of the patients and their co-operation. We have had our work on display at the Exhibitions in Montreal, Calgary and Edmonton. We have had orders from New York, Winnipeg, Oregon, Calgary, Banff and Vancouver. All our displays have been successful and our orders satisfactory.

The main object of this work at this hospital is to provide opportunity for our patients to have diversion so that they may be happier during their stay in the Hospital and during convalescence. "Busy fingers doing creative work" leave little room for those lonesome feelings, which come upon us when away from home. When we can be patient and help ourselves to recovery in this way, we are doing a great service to those in charge. This creative work has been greatly admired by all who have seen it. This had made possible our program of selling the articles we have made. This, too, had made it possible to give the patients some return for their work. We remember those sparkles in the eyes when the "Pay Envelopes came around" for work well done.

It should be possible to increase the scope of this work, keeping in mind the standard we have set, with the continued good work of those patients whose condition is such that they are allowed to be busy, together with all the support of the staff.

In conclusion I want to say "Thank You" sincerely to all the patients - men, women and children - for all that they have done. With all good wishes,

D.M. Oakden,
Handicraft Supervisor.

The Best Valentine of All

Betty was sitting at the little table in the living room making valentines. It was the Saturday before Valentine Day. Betty liked to make valentines. She was glad that Mother and Daddy liked the kind she made, better than the ones at the store. It was fun to cut out red hearts and paste them on white paper. It was fun to paste lace paper around the edges of valentines and trace the printed verses with gold paint.

She would finish the valentine with the two red hearts, for Daddy. The one for Mother was to be the loveliest of all, white and gold with a wreath of forget-me-nots and the words, "To One I Love."

Betty finished Daddy's valentine and read over a list of names, checking the valentines that were finished. Suddenly she sighed.

"What is it, Betty?" asked Mother, looking up from her work.

"Can I help you?"

"I was just wishing, Mother," said Betty, "that I had not spent all of my allowance. I would like to buy a pretty valentine for a little girl named Rosy. She has just come to our school. She is very shy. She does not have any money to spend, as her father is sick and her mother has to work. She said last night that she did not expect any valentines."

"Couldn't you make one for her?" asked Mother.

"I haven't much time left, and I want her to have a real nice one."

(Continued)
"I understand," said Mother, "wait a minute."

Mother went out and returned with a white box, which she handed to Betty.

"I meant it for a surprise for you, dear," she said. "I bought it when I was in the city last week, but you shall send it to Rosy if you like."

Betty looked at the dainty valentine, a small white satin fan, trimmed with gold lace. She hesitated, but only for a moment.

"Oh, Mother," she said, "It is beautiful. Rosy will be so glad."

It was a happy little Betty with shining eyes, who hurried home from school on Valentine Day, with her arms full of valentines from her little friends. "Oh, Mother," she said, "we had such a wonderful valentine box at school. Rosy was so happy and her valentine was the prettiest of all. Miss Alice had her come up and show it to the whole school and read the pretty verse. Rosy was so excited that she forgot to be shy and promised to go with me to the school picnic on Saturday. I know now what you mean when you say that it is more blessed to give than to receive."

"I am sure you do, Betty. It makes me very happy to know that my little girl thinks of others," said her mother. "Now open the valentine that came for you this afternoon."

"Oh, Mother," cried Betty, "a valentine just like the one I sent to Rosy, only blue - my favorite color," and Betty gave Mother a very special valentine hug.

Our best gift to Garnier will be to return the school promptly on the last day of January determined to profit one hundred percent by every means the school offers for our advancement. We believe that they can and will do still better than these must depend entirely on the work for us in other schools next year. We know they will return after the holiday and take the leadership of the school in good order, study, sport and above all in their very outstanding spirit of co-operation.

The juniors who delighted the school with their original Christmas Presentation, are very well settled now. HE'D BETTER STAY IN SCHOOL

By Basil Johnston, Grade X

Not so long ago it was quite common for a boy to leave school right after he had passed entrance examinations. After grammar school he would get apprenticed or learn a trade. There would be other boys in the same trade with not half the learning that he had and therefore he could get ahead faster than they.

In the old days, a boy with a very small amount of money and ambition could get a job as clerk in a store and handle it quite easily. He might rise to the job of manager. If it was a small store he might make it in a day but he had to lose a lot of money because he had no idea of bookkeeping and could not check his accounts or keep his things in order making a profit on. Try to get a job today in a store and unless you just want to work for nothing, the owner will ask you how far you went in school. If you take a commercial course you have a chance to finish your High School first because only once do you get the best jobs are those who have done both High School and commercial. They have a lot more training and a lot more training, and their spelling will not send their employer mad.

Farmers of not many years back used to laugh at "these young college fellers" but they send their sons right through school and off to Agricultural College too. The farmers get a lot more from his land if he knows all about the care of crops. If he hasn't got the right kind of corn, if he hasn't got the right kind of beans, if he hasn't got the right kind of cattle, if before he starts on his own farm, he knows what type of cattle suit his land and climate, he is going to stand fewer losses.

A mechanic apprentice who has already studied physics and chemistry in High School will certainly be far ahead of the boy who hasn't the vaguest notion of science.

THE PLAY'S THE THING

By Dominic McComber, Grade X

The time is coming when every one of us must leave school and take his place in the world of men. We will try to hold our position in whatever job we may choose. It is very difficult to hold your position if you are not sure of yourself. Some time you are sure of yourself but you do not make people think you are; you are lacking in manner, you are lacking shy and bashful. Suppose you join some club and are asked to make a little speech. You are finished High School and the crowd figures that you are the man who should be able to do it easily. You get stage fright and hang your head, feeling that you want to run away. Some of the bosses are present and this would show that you are lacking in certain qualities which they did not know of. You are in an awful state; you do not say anything clearly and you lose your audience. You forget what you were going to say; you try to get stopped and cannot find out to finish.

HOLIDAY SLEIGH-RIDE

Among the gay events of Christmas time was the sleigh-ride. It came off the second night after Christmas. On two team-drawn sleighs, the forty holiday boys climbed and squeezed. Winter clothes, blankets and straw helped the squatters keep feet and fingers warm. And so, with nothing but shining faces exposed to the full-faced moon, the holiday group went riding out on the country roads.

Christmas was already a thing of the past, but not so the spirit of Christmas. Marionos and McCombers, Buckshoe and Bonaparte, Whiskers and Ottawa were joined with the rear-singing and hoisting and howling, and keeping the townsfolk awake. Santa Claus sounded Christmas carols whose yells from wide-open throats rang out to the beat of the horses' hoofs. Silent wings of the snow gave way to Jingle Bells on the downhill. Peace, the heavely peace of Christmas, seemed to abound everywhere; all the world seemed rapt in praise. Even very trees and lifeless rocks seemed to be thanking heaven as fervently as the loudest voices for the bliss of so wonderful an evening.
