The Man With The Hoe

Bowed by the weight of centuries he leans
Upon his hoe and gleans on the ground,
The eminences of ages in his face,
And on his back the burden of the world.
Who made him deaf to rapture and despair,
A thing that grieves and finds no rest?
Stolid and stunned, a brother to the ox?
Who loosened and let down this brutal jaw?
Whose was the hand that slanted back this brow?
Whose breath blew out the light within this brain?

Is this the Thing the Lord God made and gave
To have dominion over sea and land;
To trace the stars and search the heavens
For power;
To feel the passion of Eternity?
Is this the dream He dreamed who shaped
The suns
And marked their ways upon the ancient deep?
Down all the caverns of Hell to their last gulf?

There is no shape more terrible than this--
More consumed with consume of the world's blind greed--
More filled with signs and portents for the soul--
More packed with danger to the universe.

What gulfs between him and the seraphim!
Slave of the wheel of labor, what to him
Are Plato and the swing of Pleiades?
What the long reaches of the peaks of song,
The rift of dawn, the reddening of the rose?
Through this dread shape the suffering ages look;
Time's tragedy is in that aching stock;
Through this dread shape humanity betrayed,
Plundered, profaned, and disinheritied,
Cries protest to the Judges of the World,
A protest that is also prophecy.

O master, lords and rulers in all lands,
Is this the handwork you give to God,
This monstrous thing distorted and soul-
quenched?
How will you ever straighten out this shape;
Touch it again with immortality;
Give back the upward looking and the light;
Rebuild in it the music and the dream;
Make right the immemorial infamies,
Perfidious wrongs, immeasurable woes?

O masters, lords and rulers in all lands,
How will the future reckon with this man?
How answer his brute question in that hour
When whirlwinds of rebellion shake all shores?
How will it be with kingdoms and with kings--
With those who shaped him to the thing
That shall be last?
When this dumb terror shall rise to judge the world,
After the silence of the centuries?

Gypsies

I am a gypsy, and you are too,
As we follow our dreams when the day is through;
At one with the fiddle-sorted clan,
We own the world and owe no man;
When twilight comes on silvery wings,
With shadowy forms and imaginings;
And when on tiptoe comes gradual night,
From out of the darkening infinite,
With bed of grass and pillow of clover,
We join the ranks of the "lonely rover."

Or -- gaily breathless, down wind-swept hill,
To the river's edge, we drink our fill;
Kneeling together in shady place,
Dripping and laughing face to face;
With the drift of the wind our cares unload,
As we heed the call of the open road.

There should be centuries to spare,
For this our world, that knows no care;
But only meagre hours have we,
To hold through all eternity.

London Snow

When men were all asleep the snow came flying,
In large white flake falling on the city brown
Stealthily and perpetually settling and loosely lying,
Hushing the latest traffic of the drowzy town;
Deadening, muffling, stifling its murmurs falling;
Lazily and incessantly floating down and down;
Silently sifting and veiling road, roof and railing;
Hiding difference, making unevenness even,
Into angles and crevices softly drifting and sailing,
All night it fell, and when full inches seven
It lay in the depth of its uncompacted lightness,
The clouds blew off from a high and frosty heaven;
And all woke earlier for the unaccustomed brightness
Of the winter dawning, the strange unheavenly glare;
The eye marveled--marveled at the dazzling whiteness;

The ear hearkened to the stillness of the solemn air;
No sound of wheel rumbling nor of foot falling,
Abd the busy morning cries came thin and spare.
Then boys I heard, as they went to school calling;
They gathered up the crystal manna to freeze
Their tongues with tasting, their hands with snow-ballimg;
Or roiled in a drift, plunging up to the knees;
Of peering up from under the white-mossed wonder,
"To look at the rees?" they cried, "To look at the trees!"
With lessened load, a few carts creak and blunder,
Full in the deserted way,
A country company long dispersed gathering;
Then now already the sun has ale diggly
Standing by Paul's high dome, spread forth below
His sparkling beams, and awoke the stirr of the day.
For now doors open, and war is waged with the snow;
And trains of somber men, past tale of number,
Tread long brown pathe, as toward their toil they go;
But even for them awhile no cares encumber
Their minds diverted; the daily word unspoken,
The daily thoughts of labor and sorrow slumber
At the sight of the beauty that greets them, for
the charm they have broken.

Romance

I will make you brooches and toys for your delight
Of bird-song at morning and star-shine at night.
I will make a palace fit for you and me,
Of green days in forests and blue days at sea.
I will make my kitchen, and you shall keep your room,
Where white flows the river and bright blows the broom,
And you shall wash your linen and keep your body white
In rainfall at morning and dewfall at night.
And this shall be for music when no one else is near,
The fine song for singing, the rare song to hear;
That only I remember, that only you admire,
Of the broad road that stretches and roadside fire.
Afterwards

Then the Present has latched its portern behind my tremulous stay,
And the May month flags its glad green leaves like wings,
Delicate-filmed as new-spun silk, will the neighbors say,
"He was a man who used to notice such things"?

If it be in the dusk when, like an eyelid's soundless blink,
The dewfall-hawk comes crossing the shades to alight
Upon the wind-warped upland thorn, a gazer might think,
"To him this must have been a familiar sight."

If I pass during some nocturnal blackness, mothy and warm,
When the hedgehog travels furtively over the lawn,
One may say, "He strove that such innocent creatures should come
to no harm,
But he could do little for them, and now he is gone."

If, when hearing that I have been stilled at last, they stand at
the door,
Watching the ful-starred heavens that winter sees,
Will this thought rise on those who will meet my face no more,
"He was one who had an eye for such mysteries"?

And will any say when my bell of quittance is heard in the gloom,
And a crossing breeze cuts a pause in its outrollings,
Till they rise again, as they were a new bell's boom,
"He hears it not now, but used to notice such things"?

This month I want to try to explain to you why some of you have to come so very far away from your home and your family to be treated in this hospital. Most of you have been very good and don't complain, but we all realize that you miss your own people and would rather be with them.

If any of you have been in the small hospitals which are on, or close to some of the reserves, you will realize that there is a great difference between these and the Charles Camsell Hospital. In the small local hospitals there is only one doctor and sometimes he can only spend some of his time there and part of his time in another place. Here we have six working full time, and you know that they very often work many hours overtime. In the same way a small hospital has one or two nurses, here we have over thirty-and so on with all the staff in the laboratory, dispensary and x-ray department.

Apart from the much larger staff, think of the equipment we have here. You know those x-ray machines are very expensive and they need highly skilled people to run them. It would be far too costly to have such machines in the many small hospitals and to employ an equal number of skilled men to operate them.

Many of you have been to the Operating Room. There, again, a great deal of very expensive equipment has had to be obtained—the tables, the lights and the many instruments. We certainly couldn't afford to have such costly things in each small hospital.

Many of you have had something wrong with your eyes, or perhaps a bone, a joint or some other particular part of your body.
"SPECIALIZED" TREATMENT
(Continued)

In such cases a "special" doctor has been called in and consulted. A "special" doctor is one who has studied very carefully one particular part of the body. He knows best how that particular part works, what might go wrong with it and how best to put it right.

Now, I think you can all see that in a small group of people, say 1,000 or even 1,500, there wouldn't be enough people who had something wrong with their bones to keep one man busy specializing in diseases of the bone. The same thing with eyes, ears, heart and all the other special parts. So these "specialists" as they are called, all live in the big cities where there are more people for them to look after.

The white people who live in the country and in small towns have to come into a big city, like Edmonton when they need to see a "specialist". They don't like to leave their home any more than you, but they know that it is the best way to get good treatment and that means the best way to get well as quickly as possible.

So next time you feel lonesome and wish you could be at home among your own family, try to remember that you have come here to get "specialized" treatment so that you can be cured as quickly as possible and then go home a happy, healthy, useful person. When you've remembered that, I think you'll also remember the other thing I've said so often. You can make your stay in the hospital so much shorter if you really help by doing everything the doctors and nurses tell you to do, and above all — REST!!

H. Meltzer, M.D.,
Medical Director.

TUBERCULOSIS AND PUBLIC HEALTH

Tuberculosis is a communicable disease spreading from person to person by contact. It is one of, if not the most important of all such types of disease, vitally important in any community because it is the greatest cause of death in the young vigorous section of the population between the ages of 15 to 50.

For certain communicable diseases we have very definite means of prevention. Smallpox and diphtheria can be and have been almost completely conquered in localities where a constant campaign of inoculation and isolation is carried out. Whooping cough, typhoid fever and certain other diseases are kept under control by similar preventive measures. It is now realized that Tuberculosis can also be greatly reduced where health authorities, working with the full co-operation of a community, are enabled to put into effect and to carry out those preventive and treatment measures which have been proven to stop the spread of the disease.

Tuberculosis is caused by a germ called the tubercle bacillus. This germ is one of the most difficult to kill. It can live for long periods of time in dust, cracks in the floor and unclean clothes and utensils. It can live without any food as long as it has oxygen. It is quickly killed by sunlight; hence, the need for clean bright airy rooms in every house.

These germs live best in the tissues of the human body where they can get all they need in order to survive and multiply. In taking their food from us they destroy our lungs or our bones or any part of our bodies and eventually cause us to die.

Any person with this disease is a great danger to everyone who is near him. Every bit of air he breathes out is loaded with tubercle germs and every breath of that air you breathe in is taking the germs into your lungs where they can live and thrive and eventually kill you if you are not treated. Every cough shoots a fine spray of moisture for 20 to 30 feet. This spray is deadly as any bullet. Every drop of sputum is a storehouse of vicious Tuberculosis. If left on the floor, on the ground, in a handkerchief and not safely destroyed, that sputum is as dangerous as any time bomb. Every drop of pus from a tuberculosis sore is loaded with germs almost as dangerous to handle as dynamite.
TUBERCULOSIS AND PUBLIC HEALTH

(Continued)

Because it is so easy for us to get Tuberculosis from one who has the disease; because Tuberculosis is such a serious crippling and killing disease, it is, therefore, absolutely essential to have these patients in a hospital, where they are not a danger to their community and where they have the best chance of recovery.

The number of deaths from Tuberculosis can eventually be enormously reduced by isolating the active cases. If the person with Tuberculosis disease is left at home he will infect others before he dies. If he is removed from his home to a hospital where treatment is carried out, he is first removed as a source of danger and, besides in many cases can be cured. If this program is not carried out we can never hope to stop the spread of Tuberculosis and reduce the number of deaths. None of us wants to see one of our children sick with Tuberculosis but a great many of them are unnecessarily suffering and dying from the disease. Whenever any member of a community is so selfish that he refuses to go to hospital for treatment he is to blame for the future deaths of those of his own or his neighbor's children who die from Tuberculosis. It is essential that the interest of the community as a whole must take precedence over any individual patient.

General examinations and x-ray repeated at least once a year and preferably every six months is the most important means at our disposal, of finding tuberculosis in a community. In the early stages of the disease there are no symptoms but tuberculosis at this time can be recognized from the x-ray film. Indian Health Services are attempting to have regular X-ray surveys of every Indian in Canada. You, in Alberta, are fortunate in having the Charles Camsell Hospital where you can be treated and where, I can assure you, every method of active effective treatment is carried out. For the most part the hospital has enjoyed co-operation from those Indians found, by X-ray or examination, to have tuberculosis. There are still, however, some who do not recognize their duty to their families and their community and who refuse to be admitted to hospital. Such an attitude by a person with tuberculosis is as criminal an act as starving some other member of the family. Just as surely as starvation will cause death, so surely will some member of that unreasonable person's family later develop and probably die from tuberculosis.
TUBERCULOSIS AND PUBLIC HEALTH
(Continued)

We at the Camsell Hospital, in fact all members of Indian Health Services, stand ready to co-operate with you and every Indian in Canada to treat every case of active tuberculosis. You must, however, realize that such treatment means removal of these cases to a hospital where they must remain until they are no longer dangerous to others. Such treatment does not mean that the sick Indian can enter a small hospital which has not the proper facilities for his care. Nor does it mean that he is free to return home when he feels well. He must abide by the decision of the doctors treating him—who understand his case and who know when he is safe to be discharged.

From you, we request an understanding of the dangers of the disease and the realization that your community, your band, your race as a whole is more important than any individual with tuberculosis. If you will believe in our aim to eradicate tuberculosis, in as far as it is possible to do so, each one of you will give full co-operation when we advise you that you have the disease and require treatment in Sanatorium. If that measure of understanding and trust does not develop between you and your health services then those of us who are devoting our abilities to your people's health can never hope to arrive at the satisfactory day where you and we can say that tuberculosis is no longer the dread scourge that it is now to you and your children.

Dr. T.J. Orford,
Staff,
Charles Camsell Indian Hospital.

A MESSAGE FROM FATHER MURPHY, ST. ANDREW'S

One day a little boy, Jackie, and his sister, Jean, were busy on a vacant lot building a little snow-house. When it was finished they began gathering sticks and placing them upright, one at a time, out from the snow-house at different points until they had a circle of sticks. Then they went to work in the little house with some little boxes and sticks tied up with thread. What were they doing? They had built a radio station and were going to broadcast to their friends who lived in the homes under the aerials they had set up.

Now, think how this is like the Camsell Hospital. From the hospital the doctors and nurses fly away hundreds and hundreds of miles to a place where boys and girls are very sick. They are growing weaker and no one can help them. The plane arrives. The children are given treatment. Supplies are left with them and the parents are told what to do. Some of them who are very sick will be sent down in planes to Camsell. The doctor and nurse will fly back with them. The little settlement will be happier and they will think about the good people in the hospital who saved their children. This will happen again to other places down north. The children who were taken to the hospital will get well and will return home. There will be many links between the settlements all over the big country and the hospital. It resembles Jackie's and Jean's radio network.

In the hospital, the Doctors and Nurses ask and beg the sick people to rest and be bright and be happy. To be happy when things are hard is difficult, but very important. For example: there was a soldier in Camsell who had had several major operations and the next day he was going up for another. When asked if it reminded him of going over the top, he said that when one went over the top he had a chance of coming out without a scratch; but, when one went up for an operation he was sure to get some kind of a wound. I won't tell you this man's name but it wasn't Mr. White. Now, he was laughing when he said this. That is what is meant by making the best of a bad case—a sense of humour. The Arrow shows, each month, that there is a sense of humour at work in the wards.

The Arrow is helping to knit together the people in the hospital with the many settlements and homes all over the big country, especially those in the great Northland. The Arrow is mighty important in the wonderful work the Camsell Hospital is doing.
THE WILD WILD NORTH

My "father" was a polar bear,
My "mother", an iceberg on the sea,
I do not know where I was born,
But I know the North is a part of me.

I hate the bustle of city life,
I feel the urge to roam,
If I could follow the bold North Star,
I know I'd find my home.

The frosty tang of the air,
A howl that's sent to the moon above,
And fades like a whispered pray'r.

Through the dark, deep and endless ocean,
God, look after His wandering child.

It's sweet and dark and cold down North,
That scene to leave I'd dread,
To return once more to an alien clime,

On March 17 we wear a shamrock for Ireland's patron saint. When St. Patrick preached Christianity to the pagan Irish he could not make them understand that God was Three Persons in One. So he picked up a three-leafed clover to teach them this fact—three parts but just one leaf.

There are many superstitions concerning the shamrock, such as:

Eaten like water cress, it is said to cure all fevers.
Worn next the heart, it will ward off evil spirits.
If placed in a baby's cradle, the baby will be free of childish ills that trouble children.

EASTER

Easter Sunday comes on March the twenty-eighth this year. Easter
is kept in honour of Christ's rising from the dead. It is a holiday
that appeals to everyone. Coming in the spring of the year, the whole
world seems to suddenly burst into new beauty.

We make the egg a part of our Easter festivities. The coloring
of eggs appears to be extremely ancient and was done in Persia, Italy
and Spain. The rabbit's part seemed to come from an early superstition
that rabbits laid eggs on Easter Eve. In early England the people used to
roll down Greenwich Hill. They gave this up and rolled the eggs down.

We "dress up" for Easter and wear our "best" just as the world
"dresses up" in its new clothes of green leaves and colored flowers.

In the spring, long before the last snow has disappeared, the "pussies" on the willow trees have burst from their purplish brown winter jackets and revealed their velvety grey buds. They are what is commonly known as pussy willows. Some of the grey pussies turn yellow, and bear the pollen. This pollen is carried by the wind and insects to the silvery green pussies, which remain after the leaves of the tree have unfolded. The seeds ripen with a cottony down and are carried away by the wind and planted in the soil. From these seeds willow trees will grow.

APRIL FOOLS' DAY

In nearly all parts of the world there is a day which corresponds to our April Fools' Day—April the First. It is a day set aside for the playing of practical jokes on friends and sending them on fools' errands and tricking them into doing foolish things.

It was not until the end of the seventeenth century that "April Fooling" became a common custom. There is no doubt whatever, that the English copied it from the French.
AN OLD ENGLISH LEGEND
of
THE TULIPS

A long time ago an old woman came to live by a fairy field, and she planted about her cottage a garden of tulips. The fairies became very fond of these gay flowers, and under their loving care the tulips became more fragrant than any rose or violet, and they blossomed all the year long.

The fairies used to carry their babies at night into the garden and put them in the tulips, and rock and sing them to sleep. They sang so sweetly that the old woman often sat up late to listen to their singing.

But, at last the old woman died. The new tenant was not fond of beauty. He did not love flowers. He uprooted all the lovely tulips and sowed cabbages in the garden. When the fairies saw the tulips dying, they were very sad. They cast a spell over the garden so that nothing would grow there again. Then they planted the tulips on the grave of the old woman who had loved them so, and there, it is said, the flowers still bloom.

The tulip belongs to the lily family. There are many varieties of tulips. Most of them have descended from three wild tulips found in South Europe, Siberia and Asia Minor. Holland is noted for the great variety of beautiful tulips grown there. The farmers grow acres and acres of them in the rich land back of the canals. Dutch bulbs are famous all over the world.

Mrs. Downie Duck's Easter Bonnet

Every year at Easter time, Mrs. Downie Duck declared she was going to get herself a new Easter bonnet. Something always came up to prevent it. Mrs. Duck always saw somebody who needed money. If it wasn't her own three ducklings - Fluff, Duff and Muff - it was some of her forty-seven-eleven other relatives who needed assistance.

As Easter approached this year, Fluff, Duff and Muff decided that their mother was going to have a new bonnet this time. Every bit of money they earned went into the yellow teapot which they called, "Mother's Easter Bonnet Fund."

On the Saturday before Easter Sunday, Fluff, Duff and Muff eagerly counted over the money. When they told Mother Duck about it, she thought of a hundred and one places for the money to go rather than to buy herself a new Easter bonnet.

"Fifty-six, fifty seven..." counted Fluff.

"I really should get my glasses changed," Mrs. Downie Duck began to murmur.

"Fifty-eight, fifty-nine, sixty!" chanted Fluff.

"And you children need new shoes," Mrs. Duck persisted.

"Sixty-one, sixty-two, sixty-three!" sang Fluff.

"And Grandma needs new curtains for her windows," continued Mrs. Downie Duck.
But Fluff, Duff and Muff paid no attention. "Goody, goody!" they cried, dancing about the room. "There's THREE dollars! That should buy you a nice bonnet with ribbons on it!" they boasted.

But Mrs. Duck said, "I can't bear the thought of spending so much money on myself."

The three ducklings were beginning to get worried. Then Fluff remarked slyly, "A new bonnet will make you look years younger, Mother."

That settled the question right then and there, Mrs. Duck threw on her shawl and put her market basket over her arm. She kissed the children and set out on her shopping trip.

"I won't speak to a soul," she said to herself. "If I do, I feel it in my bones that something will happen."

"Mrs. Downie Duck! Mrs. Downie Duck!" called Mrs. Nanny Goat from across the street. Mrs. Downie Duck pretended she did not hear and walked faster than ever. She knew she was always out of money and would want something for her children. Mrs. Downie Duck had not gone far when she began to wonder if some of Nannie Goat's children were sick. She was just about to turn back when she caught sight of herself in a shop window.

"Gracious! Can this be I? I look old enough to be my grandmother. I certainly do need a new bonnet to smarten me up a bit."

Mother Duck hurried on, never looking to right or left until she came to a shop with a sign that read - SMART EASTER BONNETS FOR SALE.

Mrs. Owl came forward with a big smile. "Something in a nice Easter hat? Yes, my dear. Take a seat and make yourself comfortable."

Mrs. Owl tried on quite a few hats, and then finally put a lovely pink one on Mother Duck's head. It was tied under the chin with a bow.

"It's beautiful on you, so stylish and has such YOUTHFUL lines!" said Mrs. Owl quite overcome with admiration.

"I'll take it," said Mrs. Duck, quick as a flash. "Never mind wrapping it up. I'll wear it. My, it does make me look young!

It certainly does do something for me!"
Then a strange change came over Mrs. Duck as soon as she put on the pretty bonnet. She tripped along the street almost as if she owned the whole town. She passed her friends with her head in the air. She walked haughtily into the grocery store and gave her order.

"Phew!" whistled Mr. Crow as she went out. "Somebody has gone HIGH-HAT and no mistake!"

"I notice she has on a new Easter bonnet," remarked Slippery Seal. "Like as not it's gone to her HEAD!"

Mrs. Downie Duck was slipping past Mrs. White Rabbit's house without even calling in to ask about her rheumatism, when Mrs. Rabbit spied her and called her in.

"Mrs. Brown Hen has four baby chicks. She fell and hurt herself. I'm taking care of the children. Come and see them."

There, on the bare floor, under the stove were the wee chicks.

"Poor wee things!" said Mrs. Duck. "No mother to cuddle them!"

"If I only had a basket to put them in, it would be a lot warmer." Suddenly her eyes lit on Mrs. Duck's bonnet. "Even a hat would be better than the floor!" she exclaimed.

Mrs. Duck hurried to the door. "I really must be going at once!"

She hurried along Sweet Clover Lane, clickety-clack, clickety-clack. She was so anxious to escape from Mrs. Rabbit and her queer ideas. All at once Mrs. Duck began to slow down. She thought of the baby chicks on the floor. She remembered how Mrs. Brown had come every day with broth and carrot juice when Fluff and Duff and Muff had been sick with colds. Finally, she could stand it no longer. Back she went to Mrs. Rabbit's house.

As she hurried up the steps, she snatched off her bonnet. She thrust it into Mrs. Rabbit's hands saying, cheerily, "Here, take this and make a nice cozy little nest for the wee baby chicks."

When she arrived home, Fluff, Duff and Muff ran to meet her. "Where is your nice new Easter bonnet?" they asked.

Mrs. Duck gathered them close and told them about the baby chicks. Soon, the three ducklings were crying as if their hearts would break.

"To think of the wee chicks on the cold, hard floor!" said Fluff.

"Such tiny helpless babies!" sobbed Duff.

"I'd give anything I had to keep them warm!" sniffed Muff.

"Would you have given your new Easter bonnet?" asked Mother.

"Indeed, we would!" the three shouted together.

"That's exactly what I did!" Mother Duck said. Then with a gay song she began to whisk up a carrot pudding for the family dinner.

- Helen Boyd

HIS EXCELLENCY LEAVES FOR ROME

We were all happy to see His Excellency, Bishop Routhier, leave for Eastern Canada on March 3rd. He was going to Rome! He was accompanied by Rev. Father Zinet of Jossard. They are going to Rome for the General Chapter of the Oblate Fathers. They are going to elect a new Superior General, for they haven't any just now. The Chapter will take place on May 1st.

We all hope that His Excellency will have a good trip and that no harm will come upon him during his journey—such will be our prayer every day.

We will pray too that the Holy Ghost will enlighten the minds of all those who are to choose the new Superior so that they may choose one according to the Will of God.

Such a nice treat of candy and oranges, from kind Sister Superior, we had on Easter Sunday. Father Serrand gave us permission to spend all afternoon with our parents. Some went home in the wagons, and some went to Jousard to have a treat with our father and mother.

BERTHA WILLIER GR. VI.

We have a picture show every week in our classroom. I like the picture show very much because we learn about Health and Nature Science. I like to see the film on Co-operative Living. We like the little stories at the end. Sometimes it is about Three little pigs, Little Red Riding Hood, Jack and the Beanstalk. The last one was The little Princess and the Frog. They were very nice. We thank Sister for the picture show. We write about the picture show. Fr. Serrand read the paper to us. After he was finished reading them he asked us which one was the nicest, and gave a reward to the best one.

YVETTE BADGER GR. IV.
SPRING IS HERE.

We went for a walk it was Sisters feast day. The snow is melting. Winter is sorry to leave us. Sometimes we play ball in the yard. We have lots of fun. Sometimes we dance, we play games in our yard, and we jig. Other times we help Father Serrand to carry the wood. Father gave us a treat of gum.

ELSIE GIROUX GR.111.

BINGO PARTY.

On Thursday evening of Easter week, we had a grand Bingo party in our classroom and just think who came to see us play and gave us lovely prizes of candy. Father Giroux and Sister Superior. We were sorry that Father Serrand was busy and could not come as he was suppose to preside. We had fun and fun. I hope we shall have some more Bingos.

DOROTHY BELLEROSE GR.VII.

We had a nice visit. It was good Father Giroux. He gave us lots of candy. We read for him.

GEOILE M. GIROUX PRIMARY.

We crowned the Virgin Mary. I had a crown. I went to put it on the Altar. Some boys payed vigil lights. We gave $1.40. Father came to see us. He said it was good.

GUY GIROUX GR. 11.

OUR FRIENDS AT EASTER.

Before Easter we all sent a card and letter to Father Lachance, and to the boys who are sick in Edmonton. We were glad to see our parents at Mass. I saw my grandmother but not my father because he was sick. We had lots of fun with our parents. We went to bed happy that night.

ANGELINE ISIDORE. Gr.111.

We have 14 Vigil Lights. There were 8 boys and there were 6 girls that bought them. We made a sacrifice.

ALICE OKIMAW GR.11.
PICTURE SHOW.

On the same day that Father Giroux came back, we had a Picture Show in the afternoon. It lasted till nearly five o'clock, but we thought it was a short time, because we were so interested. The last picture was about the soldier who learned to come down in a parachute; it was thrilling.

ALICE WILLIER GR.VI.

HOLY COMMUNION.

I made my first communion on Easter day. My mother brought me a dress for my Holy Communion.

ROSE CECILE CAMPION GR.I

I made my first communion on Easter day. Sister Superior gave me some beads.

LAWRENCE MATHEWS GR.II.

On the first of May, Victoria Willier put white roses on the Blessed Virgin's head. She put a crown on the Blessed Virgin's head.

ISABEL NO HAT GR.II.

Father Serrand gave us some chocolate bars. Four gave them to Sister Geraldine of Jesus to make a sacrifice. We all thank Father Serrand.

MARY JANE LABOUCAN GR.II.

We went for a walk. We saw some pussy willows and we saw some blue birds and a chipmunk. He went under the stone.

ROGER WILLIER GR.II.

THE MONTH OF MAY

We are getting ready for the month of May. We are putting up an altar in our classroom. We bought some vigil lights for our Mother in heaven. We gave each child a cent to sister. We are 30 children in our classroom. With the 30 cents we bought three vigil lights. We are decorating the altar and the classroom too. We took off the Easter decorations and put up the May decorations. May is her month. Sister will light the vigil lights when we will sing our hymn. She will give us some graces and help us always. I think the altar will be nice. The Blessed Virgin will be pleased to see the altar. The nicest month is May because it is the month of our Mother. We will have a nice class in May.

MARCEL WILLIER GR. IV.

Father bought us some hum a tinas. He bought 12 of them. We thank Father. We played a band for Father. He said it was good, and he gave us 30 packages of gum.

LEONARD PRINCE GR. II

BINGO and REWARDS.

We had a bingo one Friday afternoon. It was on Sisters feast. Before we play we sang some songs, then we started to play BINGO. When we were playing Father Giroux came in with a treat of candy. He put a gladd of candies when three of the boys had Bingo. Then Father Giroux had to give three glasses of candies instead of one. Father Serrand could not come because he was busy. Sister Superior came for a few minutes to see us. I had bingo only once but Father Serrand gave us Easter eggs because we had gold stars. Sister George Wilfred and two girls from our class made some pop-corn balls. It was so good. We thank Sister George.

CHARLES EDWARD GIROUX GR. IV.

I am glad to be the last one to wish all our friends a HAPPY VACATION. Yes, June will come soon. We will be going home. Hip hip Hurrah....Happy Vacation to all.

CECILE WILLIER GR. V.
VISITORS FROM H.Y. LAKES

Father Jal and Brother came to visit us from Hay Lakes. We were all very glad to see them. They came after our supper. The boys were all playing outside when they came. All at once the boys began to say, "Father Jal! Father Jal!" Then we ran to see them. Father Jal was glad to see us too. We talked to them and then ran to the attic's house to talk to them again. They stayed with us for two or three days then they made ready for the journey back to Hay Lakes. We were a bit sorry to see them go.

Norman Yotemawatam Gr.V

EASTER

On Easter morning we went to Church for Low Mass at 7 o'clock. Never before did we see so many people at church. It was really edifying and impressive. Large number, too, received Holy Communion. Our Risen Lord must have been very pleased to see so many people at Mass. All the boys and girls who were downstairs had to come up in the choir. It was quite packed. We sang beautiful Easter Hymns. The following day, Easter Monday we did not go to school.

Albina Adeckit Grade VI

VISITING ACROSS THE RIVER

On Easter Monday Father Jean went to visit a few families across the river. Sisters Emma Marguerite and Celina went too. Also two girls. They brought their dinner with them and had dinner at Saint Gabriel's mission. From there they went on to visit some of the families. They did not visit many as the population is far apart. I am sure that the sisters and the girls enjoyed the whole day as they looked very happy when they came back. The girls enjoyed the trip very much too.

Albina Kidney Grade V

PRIZE MONEY

When we made drawings for the HEALTH CONTEST I was the lucky third winner. So I got $2.00 for my drawing. After we had signed our checks we gave them to Father and he gave us our money. Then we made out an order for Eaton's. I bought a nice belt and a mouth organ. Peter had first prize and he sent for a baseball and a camera. Joche Fournier had second so he sent for lovely braces and a nice bit. We were very glad when our parcel came.

Fred Ekie Gr. VI
OUR NEW CUPBOARD

We have a new cupboard in the cellar. It very large. On one side we put all the costumes for the Entertainments. On the other side we put our tool chest and all our Woodwork. We think that it is very nice and handy too. We are very grateful to Father for all his kindness to us.

Frank Casson Grade VI

Sisters go to St. Louis

On the second Sunday after Easter Father Jean was at His post at St. Louis Mission. It was the Easter Mass for the people on the other side of the river. Sisters Edward of Jesus, Jean Leon and Henriette went early on Sunday morning. They sang the Mass and had dinner at St. Louis. They came back in the late afternoon.

George Alok Grade V

FATHER JEAN LEAVES FOR ST. LOUIS

Father Jean left our mission to go to St. Louis across the river. He will stay there until the ice is broken. He will help the people in their spiritual needs as no one can come across the river now as it is too dangerous. Here we are on the 26th of April and the ice has not bridged at all in front of the mission. The ice is still very solid for a number of miles from here. Though the ice is not broken yet the ice has risen and very high. Many people fear a flood like the year 1932. We hope that there will not be a flood as that means much damage for all the people in the district.

Mary Ekie Grade V

OUR CLASS

In our class, we have much more room now, as all our woodwork has been taken down with other things such as our Rhythm Band and tool box in a nice big cupboard that has been made for that purpose in the cellar. We have some new framed pictures too. Our certificate for the prize winners for the HEALTH CONTEST is also framed. We have some framed mottoes and two framed scenes with the names of the pupils who did them. We like our classroom.

EVELYN ROBERT GRADE V
OUR NEW PYROGRAPH

At last we received our long-desired pyrograph. We received it from a very generous benefactor. We are very grateful to have this electric pencil. Already we have made some very fine samples of this work. We mean to make special pieces for our Kind Principal and Superior, Rev. Father Rainville who was so kind as to get us such lovely wood to work with and work on. Sister said we would all have a try on the pyrograph.

Peter Martel Gr. VI

BLESSED OF THE STATUE

One day Sister Elaine received a beautiful statue of St. Theresa. It is a large statue and will be put in our hall. On April 23rd, Rev. Father Rainville, Superior was to bless the statue in the Girl's hall. The statue was a table nicely decorated with roses around the statue. Father blessed the statue. Then Father delivered a little talk about the LIFE OF ST. THERESE. It was very interesting. We listened very attentively. Then Father had finished speaking the same hymn to Saint Theresa. I think that Father loves the FLOWER OF JESUS very much too.

Helen Attion Gr. de Vl

OFF TO MONTREAL

In June we will be losing our dear Sisters Eustache of Rome and Joseph Napolcon. They will be going to visit their parents whom they have not seen for many years. It will be 19 years for Sister Joseph and 21 years for Sister Eustache of Rome. They really deserve a nice trip don't you after all these years of service in the Master's Vineyard. We wish them a real nice journey and hope that they will come back again to Fort Vermilion.

Celestine Siowepokaham Grade V

OUR LITTLE PUP

Once we had a little pup. My grandpa gave it to us when we were living up town. When we moved back to our summer home, the little pup could not come home. We took it home and tied it with a rope. But the puppy bit the rope and got away again. The little puppy went back to where we were living before.... When my Dad came home from the woods, my mother told him about the pup. So we went with my Dad in a dog sleigh to get the little dog. It was with Barbara Ann Love. We took it home in the Dog-Sled.

Ruth Courtereille GR V
MONTH OF OUR LADY

On April 30th we will begin the devotions of the Month of the blessed Mother. We will go to the church every evening for Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament. We will honor our Blessed Mother by our little sacrifices and prayers said more fervently.

In the month of May we celebrate Mother's Day. We honor our earthly mother on the second Sunday. We honor them because they have made so many sacrifices for our sakes. In class we will read stories and poems and sing songs to honor our MOTHER. We will not forget to offer our Mass and Communion on that day in gratitude for what they have done for us. God loves Mothers for HE took one HIMSELF. God bless our MOTHERS.

Albin Adekat Grade VI

S.E.M.
We were very glad to hear that Father Superior bought a new gramophone for the girls. We sure enjoy it because we had an old one which was bought two or three years ago. But only one girl is named to play it and her name is Miss Loonskin. We have some nice records to play, and some girls brought some from their homes. We gave the old one to the older girls who work at the Mission. We thank our kind Father for nice gramophone he bought for us.

Belle Nanotch

First Margaret Bevill died in March. She was 75 years old. It was a very sad day for the people in the Reserve because many were related to her. She had five sons living and two daughters.

We had a Requiem Mass for her and Mr. Joseph Bigstone. They were buried on the same day so we had a double funeral service. But they did not die on the same day. They died one day after the other. After the Mass we went in the graveyard where they were buried.

Before she died, old Margaret talked to her children. Some of her sons made promises to her. She was a very good woman. She used to come to Mass on Sunday when she was able to walk. She used to come to Holy Communion every First Friday. She was a very good woman here on earth. I am sure that she is well rewarded in Heaven, May she rest in peace and pray for us.

Elsie Yellowknife

On the 1st of March Rev. Father Superior, Sr. Superior, Sr. Helen and Sr. Leurent left by team with Geo. Gullion. We went to the Fathers' House to say good-bye to them. Before they went Father received a telegram that Sr. Helen's mother was very ill. We felt very sad for Sister. We hope they had a good trip, and that Sister got there in time to see her mother.

Sister superior goes to visit her relatives also but Sister Leurent stops at Athabasca.

Father Superior went to Athabasca business then by way of the bus to Athabasca and Calling Lake to visit his Mission.

Belle Nanotch

WINGS OF MERCY

Our Post Master, Mr. Geo. Arnold was very sick in the Hospital here so they asked for a plane to take him to Edmonton. Rose Gullion had been sick a long time too so the Nurse, Miss Hannah took them both out. We were sorry to see them go. But I hope they will come back well. We all wish them good luck.

Rita Beauregard.

More logs for our New Church and still 200 more to be hauled across the lake.
OLD AND NEW ARRIVALS IN NABASCA

On March 9th, we were happy to welcome back Sr. Luke back to Nabasca. She had been away to visit her mother who was very sick. She is very glad to be back again and to work among the Indians. She helps Sister Denis at the hospital.

It was on Sunday afternoon that Sister Luke arrived with Sr. Alfred-Leon. She said she is glad to be here. She will be with us on the girls' side. We hope you will like Nabasca, Sister and will stay a long time.

Eliza Jager

CHICKENS

On March 13th Miss Hannas R.N. returned by plane from Edmonton with 118 little chickens. We are very glad to have more chickens. They were only 1 day old. Sister Cassie, who is in charge of the chickens is working very hard every day in the chicken house. We eat more eggs every day. The next day we went to see the chickens. The door was locked so we looked through the window. They were running all over. Then we came back running too.

Miss Therese Gladu

NEW RADIO TRANSMITTER

After ten years of use the Radio Broadcasting Set here was not reliable even obsolete. So it was decided to ask for a new machine.

The Government Telegraph Service agreed to the demand and in February we heard that we were to receive a new set. It arrived with Miss Hannas on Mar. 15th in an Associated Airways plane piloted by Mr. Spencer Adamson. He was in the office when the machine was installed and tuned it expertly.

A call was made to Calling Lake where Father Guinmont, S.J., was on mission work and he had the pleasure to hear Father Sauvé speaking, as well as Bro. Gaucher and Miss Hannas who were in the office. As this radio is our only daily contact with civilization for the benefit of all Nabasca people we are deeply grateful for it.

Bertholomay Gladu

Since this article was written the pilot Mr. Adams and his plane and one passenger were reported lost in the North somewhere between Edmonton and Ft. McMurray. As he had made several trips to Nabasca, we deeply regret the untimely loss of this expert airman.

CALLING LAKE VISITED

For the first time since I have been in Nabasca I started on the road towards Slave Lake to go to Calling Lake Mission.

The deep snow and bad roads made this a necessity so I made a business trip to Edmonton first, then travelled from there by bus to Nabasca. This trip in a jeep was my first experience. I travelled with Mr. MacIntosh to his home where I said Mass twice.

We went on by team to Island Lake. Here I baptized five children, said Mass and performed a marriage ceremony. After visiting the 36 families there I returned to Calling Lake. About 40 persons came to Mass. There were five baptisms and one funeral service. It was a short visit but greatly appreciated by the people, as they see the missionary once a year only.

I returned by bus to Driftpile where I met the Indian Agent, Mr. Landry. He decided to return
with me to visit our school, we left by plane on Mar.14th in the afternoon and arrived at Athabasca 40 minutes later. The trip takes 4 days with horses.

B.Guimont, O.M.I.

YES? WE HAVE TONSILS TODAY???

On Mar.19th, good Dr.Riopel and Miss Parr R.N. arrived by plane to visit the children here. There were quite a lot of tonsils to be removed from the children of the Point and from here. There 14 cases in all. Miss Parr treated the eyes of 40 children. Four girls, Louise Auger, Mary O'Connell, Alice Rabbit and little Harry got nose bleeds; how to get glasses only one boy amongst us, P trick Young has to have them.

Dr.Riopel had a lot of work to do. He had 28 tonsils to take out, as there were 8 boys and six girls.

George Auger

"HAPPY FEAST FATHER SUPERIOR"

On Mar.21st, it was the Feast Day of our Principal, Father Guimont. On the eve we had a big Display in honor of St.Benedict, his holy Patron. There were four tableaux showing scenes from St.Benedict's life. The had a pretty Ribbon Drill. The P.T.Class did some of their Exercises. The band played and we sang some songs. It was a good Display, and Father Superior and Mr.Landry, were pleased with us.

In the morning at Mass the School sang. After breakfast we all played games in the yard.

After dinner good Brother Dumas came with the picture machine and we had the movies. We always enjoy his pictures. This time the pupils from Pt.St.Cherubs School came to the show.

After the movies a plane came to get Mr.Landry, when he told us good-bye he said he would return with the Toasty Party. He was very pleased with his visit here.

In the evening we had many games. We had a very nice day.

We thanked Father Superior, & good Father Sauvé for planning and helping the Feast to go well, also the Sisters who did their big share.

Bella Nanotch

MORE DEPARTURES

After a busy week Dr.Riopel and Miss Parr left by plane on Mar.26 taking some people from here. They were Mary Dina Auger, Paul Rabbit, Geo.Beaver and his sister Marie Jane. They had to go to be treated, and when the plane came they were ready. The plane that came in brought Samuel Auger and Rose Bigstone. Poor Rose her mother died while she was in Edmonton. We hope the others will be better soon.

Philomene Young

HOLY WEEK

The Holy Week ceremonies were carried out by Father Superior alone, as Father Sauvé was called to replace Father Campagna at the Point. He came to the hospital on Good Friday, very ill, with La Grippe.

We had a very nice Feast on Easter Sunday. There were two classes. Many people came to receive Holy Communion at the 6:30 Mass. The singing was very well. The Chapel was crowded for the High Mass at 10 o'clock. How it...
would please God to see as many each Sunday, especially as the nice weather is here again, and there is plenty of room in the chapel.

Easter Holidays

We were very glad when Father told us that we were going home on Easter Monday and Tuesday. We took the holiday Mr. Landry gave us when he was here on Tuesday. So we all enjoyed ourselves for two days with our parents. We came back Tuesday night, as next day was washing day. I hope Father will give us more holidays. Big Thank you, Father and Mr. Landry for our nice holidays.

Rita Beauregard

PRIZE MONEY

We made some posters of food to send to Ottawa. They sent money for those who had prizes. I had the First Prize of $5.00, John Auger had $3 and John Cat Third Prize $2.00. We were very surprised and pleased to receive the money, because we did not expect it. Now I will buy something useful. We thank our Ottawa friends.

Francis Auger

CATHECHISM LESSONS

We always have Catechism twice a week on Wednesday and Friday. Father Sauvé is teaching us. Now we are learning the Seven Sacraments. Father asks us questions one by one. I like Catechism time because Father explains so well.

One day Father said to a boy "How many Fathers are there here in the mission?"

"The Father, The Son and The Holy Ghost," said the boy.

Clara Gladu

On April 14th, we had a requiem high mass for the repose of the soul of Cardinal Villeneuve. We hope God heard our prayers for this venerable prelate who did so much for the Church here in Canada, and may he pray for us.

Hilda Auger

"ON YOUR FEET UP, AND BRING OUT THE MATS"

On April 17th at 4 o'clock we saw two boys carrying a big bundle with Fr. Sauvé from the warehouse. We thought right away it was the tumbling mat for training. The boys brought the mat in the Boys' Hall and they all came in to see it. It is heavy and hard. It is about 6 ft by 4 ft. Father sent to Mr. Hutton for it and he sent to Montreal for it. That is why it took so long to come.

Gabriel Auger

Last News Bits

April 25th. Mr. Adamson, Pilot and his companion found at Little Red River. How glad we are for that.

Sister Superior and Sister Helen are to leave Montreal May 4th. We are so anxious to see them again. That's ALL.
Even though the weather was not very bright yet Easter was a great feast as always. Many people came to church, it was Easter Day and many received Holy Communion. On Easter Sunday Father Sauve sang Mass because Father Broussard had flu. Father Sauve gave us a good Sermon about a little girl who used to kiss her father every night before she went to bed. One night she didn't kiss him because her father never went to church; so one evening her asked, "Why don't you come to kiss me any more, don't you like me anymore?" The girl said, "You never go to church," as the man told her, "I do not have to go to church to prove God that I love him." A little girl said, "I do not have to kiss you good night for you to know that I love you." Then the father understood and he used to go to church to show God he really loved Him. We enjoyed Father's short story. Father Compagnie is well and we hope that he will stay so.

Elsie Schroeder

First Holy Communion

This is good news. Jack and Lillian Anger made their first Holy Communion on Easter Sunday. They were baptized on Good Friday. We are happy for them. Lillian had a white dress and a veil. Jack had a white ribbon on his arm. I am glad they are just like us now. Many other people were there too because they came to make their Easter duties. Only a few little ones in our school did not make it yet. I made mine when I was ten years old now I am fourteen.

Mary Cardinal

Our New Phonograph

At last we have a new phonograph in our class room. We were wishing for one a long time. We have some new records too. We'll enjoy it because there are some nice songs. Sister wrote two songs that we learned. It will be nice when we cannot play outside on cold or rainy days. Many thanks to Sister Mary Bethanie and Sister Guy's mother. We are quite happy for this lovely gift.

Mable McLeod

Bingo

Last month we played Bingo. There were many nice prizes and lots of sweet stuff too. We liked it very much. I won two times only, but some won most all the time. Father Superior from Stony Point gave us some peanuts, that was a good treat. We liked them very much. Thank You Father Superior.

Helon Gladu
Sickness.

There are many that were sick here with the flu. But I have never been sick. One of my sisters have been sick too, one boy died. He used to go to school here. He was sick for quite a while and died today. We are sorry but we know he will go to heaven because he suffered much, and just made his First Holy Communion. So all will pray for him.

Pascaline No. Lood

Put her Up

I'm so glad to be able to play ball again. It is such a good sport. As soon as there was enough dry ground to stand on, we started playing. Every recess we have fun. Sometimes we have to play scrub when we are not enough. But we like to play ball anyway.

Jack Auger.

Eat Right, George! All the posters and more posters all around our class on the wall. They remind us to eat the right kind of food so we will be healthy. They are in nice bright colors. Everyone that looks at them has to read them. I try my best to eat right so I shall be strong.

Helen Claude.

A TRIP TO CROOKED CREEK

On Good Friday, Father took Sister and me to Crooked Creek. Three girls were supposed to go but the weather was too cold. There is a nice church there and now they have nice new pews too. Brother Mathis made them. He does very good work with wood. There is also a lovely liturgical altar too. The way of the Cross is up now; it is beautiful. Father heard Confessions and afterwards preached the sermon on the death of Jesus. We made the Stations of the Cross. Many people were in the church and again Father heard Confessions while Sister rehearsed the singing for Easter Sunday. Before we took supper, we decorated the altar for Easter. Hermine Manitos - Gr. IV.

OUR LENT

The night when the cords were given, we gave Father money for three handsome Sr. told the day-pupils to put money in the box. She said the one that put the most, she would give something. I put some in every week and I got the present. Then she told me to give the baby a name. I called him Eugene. The boys and girls in the halls each had enough to buy babies too. So we had money for three Japanese babies. We were glad to do something during Lent, to please Jesus.

Florestine Badger
Gr. IV.

DISTINCTIONS

Sister had taught us a little song about our cords, and Father took our prayers in the classrooms too. On the Friday before Good Friday we all went to the girls' hall after Benediction. Many of us who had our red cord got the white one. And some others got the red one. Now I am working hard to get the blue one. I would like to have it by June.

Dorothy Kiyawasew - IV.
EASTER MONDAY

Easter Monday was a holiday. In the morning we played after the work was finished. When we came down to the refectory at dinner-time we found little paper cups filled with nuts and candy. We thank the girls from Sacred Heart Academy in Missoula for sending us letters and things to make Easter happier.

After dinner we dressed up in our nice dresses that Sister and some of the big girls made. They made caps to match. Then Sister took our picture. She took the boys' picture too. After Benediction Father took our picture two times, and the boys too.

Florentine Tchowis-IV.

Then we came into the girls' hall and played Bingo. Everybody was there. The prizes were on the table but not wrapped. Father always calls the numbers our nice and loud. I did not get anything at the Bingo. We played until about half-past four. We had a nice time.

Genevieve Mitchell- IV.

After the Bingo, we girls prepared the table for supper. When the boys came they were surprised. The table looked very nice. It was nice around each plate. There was an Easter egg, in an egg cup, our dessert, a glass of soft drink and a little paper cup filled with nuts and candies. I was shy a little bit because the boys were there, and they put me next to Father Roue. I ate just the same.

Julie Tchowis- GR.V

EASTER FROLIC

On Easter Sunday morning, we went to Holy Communion. Quite a few people came. We sang hymns in both Cree and English. They were nice Easter Hymns. At the High Mass the little boys and girls were down stairs, but many people were coming into the church. So at last it got full and the small ones had to come upstairs. Fr. Roue preached in two languages Cree and English, but I understood the Cree better.

David Nabew - Gr. V.

EASTER WEATHER

This year Easter was two weeks earlier than last year. It was colder too than last year. It snowed during Holy Week and on Easter Sunday it snowed again. So we didn't have much time to play outside. But now we are having good weather. It was almost "Merry Christmas" again!

Max Papastisis-Gr.V
"What I thought about the supper"

We five officers had our supper with Father in the girls' hall, with the girls. They prepared the tables. We had cold meat and mashed potatoes with tomatoes, peas, buns, Easter eggs, jam, apples, biscuits and paper cups filled with peanuts and candy. For dessert there was real gelatin eggs in golden gelatine. I was shy, but I knew where to put all these things!!!

Gabriel Kiyawasew - GR. VII

I was the godfather for my little niece, my sister Mary's baby. They called her Eileen Dorothy. It was born on March 11th. That was the second time I was a godfather.

Virginia Sotseau will be married to Modeste L'Hirondelle soon. They have been called off twice already in the church.

Felix Harvey - VII.

My brother went home with Fr. Roue to have my little brother baptized. They called him Charles Edward. My mother was very sick. I prayed for her. My little brother died not long after he was baptized. I know he is in heaven. On April 8th, I went to the funeral and I am glad that my mother is getting better. I was so glad to see her when she came here.

Victoria Kiyawasew - IV.

My father died on 24th of March. He had been sick for a long time and he could not hear very well. Since he was sick, Denise and I went to see him quite often. He was getting worse. About two weeks before he died, we went to see him again. Father took us and some other girls went too. He was buried just before Holy Week. I was glad I was able to give Father a Mass stipend for my dear father. I pray for him that he will go to heaven.

Gertrude Sunshine - GR. V

I am a godmother too. About two weeks ago my little son was baptized. He was named Nelson Peter. I was glad that they let me be godmother.

Mary Moses - Gr. IV.

A WELCOME PLACE

Father Alice had been sick for a long time and after a while he said he would go to Edmonton to see a doctor. He was in the hospital for quite a long time. He is better now and is back here with us. We were glad when he came back. He is old but he does much work at the Mission. He knows lots about the engines. He always preaches to us in Cree, and we like that. I think he is glad to be back at Sturgeon Lake again and away from the hospital.

Mary Moses - Gr. IV.

LONG LIVE OUR GOOD MISSIONARIES

IN THE MINDS AND HEARTS OF ALL
IN HOLLAND

We were studying about Holland in class. Sister read the book called "The Silver Beatles" to us. We enjoyed it very much and we were anxious to know who would win the race. We were glad that Gretel did. I didn't know before that the Netherlands are below the sea and that they grow bulbs such as daffodils, narcissi, and tulips there. That they also hang pin-cushions on the door when a baby is born, a red one for the boys and a blue one for the girls.

We also learned some memory work about the storks. The Dutch choose must look very queer. We liked that very much.

Howard C. pot - V.

WORK ... WORK

We work on Exhibition things while the boys are doing woodwork on Wednesday afternoons. We finished some of them already. I embroidered a pair of pillow cases and I knitted some stockings. Many girls have their badges for knitting, sewing and housekeeping. Some of us have our first year badge for cooking. I have the first and second year badges for housekeeping and sewing and a first year badge for cooking and knitting. I like to do those things better than going to school.

Iva Tchowis - Gr. VII.

--- AND THE BOYS!

We do our woodwork in the class. I like to make something of wood. Five boys have finished their tables. My brother brought his table home. I am making a wash-stand for my home. Right now some of the boys are making small things because there is nearly no lumber left. Mr. Lindry said he was going to send some and now the ponds are dry, we hope it will come.

George Goodswimmer - VI.

When the time is almost up and we are getting tired, we make little toy guns and swords, or something else how we want cannons. We use spoons, little rubber inside with a little stick to wind it. On the other side we put a round piece of hide and a short stick to wind it. It will go, very much, with it in my hand.

Marcel Kiyawasew - IV.
ANOTHER ELEPHANT SURPRISE

At the end of April we were surprised to see four Fathers come here. One we were very glad to see was Fr. Bruckert from Grouard because he always runs the picture machine. So we had a show that night. I found one so funny. There was a man who had a fur skin from a real monkey and when he put it on he looked like a real one. After he got in the taxi he dressed up in this suit. He scared the man who was driving the car. He got so scared that he made a hole in the top of the car, and his head was sticking through! The car was going by itself in the street or on the sidewalk. I laughed very much. We were glad they came because it was a long time since we saw a show. Fr. got a big "Thank You" from us too.

Christine Tchowmis - VI

EXPECTING VISITORS

We are helping to wax and shine and now we know. They told us some Sisters are coming. They are Mother Provincial and Sr. Egbert and another Sister. I hope they will like it here.

Evelyn Capot - GR. III

In the show was a horse. It did some funny things, but the man who bought it was funny too. After a while the owner wanted it to run in a race. I liked this part of the show the best of all. I like horses very much and it is easy for me to draw horses. This is the picture that I drew because I liked the race, it was exciting.

Peter Tchowmis - VI

GARNIER WINS REGIONAL TITLE

Playing the final game of a best out of three series with C.Y.O. Blind River, in the Massey Arena, the boys from the Garnier Residential School emerged victorious in a hard fought game. This victory brought the Juvenile Championship of the North Shore and the right to advance into the District playoffs.

The ice on the Massey rink was fast and the large crowd in attendance saw a good game. Both teams were in fine form for the final meeting. Previously in league games Garnier had beaten Blind River but in the playoffs both teams were eager to win or catch up. The first period was not long under way when Maxie took a neat pass from Frankie to score for Garnier. Half time rounded off the same period. Maxie again assisted by Frankie beat the Blind River goalie for another goal ending the first half 3-0 for Garnier. The Black and White first line completely dominated the period and only stellar defense work kept down the score.

The second period was much more eventful than the C.Y.O. having moved around the goal. The Blind River boys are a scrappy, determined little team. They scored two goals in this period. Then came the rest. The period after the first line had rested. Adam scored with one of his long hard shots and the period ended with a 5-2 lead for Garnier. The defense on both teams played brilliantly and stopped many goals.

The third period opened up with a tremendous burst of speed on the part of both teams. Frankie broke away on a clean run to put Garnier in the lead 5-2. The C.Y.O. went out and at least tie the score and only fast back check-

ing and steady goal-tending kept them out. Near the end of the period Blind River rolled the puck out of a scramble in front of the goal and hit the net to make it 5-3.

SOCIAL HI-LIGHTS

Saturday, March 13, the 16teeners Club held its St. Patrick's dance and card party. The School Recreation Hall was tastefully decorated in green by veteran decorator Julius Neganigig, assisted by Cecil and Donald King. Twenty-five young ladies from St. Joseph's Residential School were the guests. One of the boys, John Buzzard, had said, "Where do the girls find the time to fix up their hair in all those fancy hair-dos?"

With a poise and a gracefulness that spoke of much practise some of the couples merrily tripped through the figures of the square dance. Others seemed slightly confused but followed the good rule of square dancing "when in doubt, swing your partner." Henry Pelletier at the piano was the one man orchestra for the fox trots. A few of the boys seemed to have a little trouble with the fox trots and kept looking constantly at the floor to see where their feet were going. However, none of the girls seemed to be limping after the dancing.

The Wall-flowers and the Wallflowerettes played cards and darts. The games varying with the skill and the inclinations of the players. One charming guest after a dance sat down at a card table occupied by three boys, and asked them, "What game are you playing?" The answer shocked her for a minute. "Spanish," she swallowed bravely and said, "How do you play it?" It was just another name for Crazy Eights. The rather offensive name of Studhro is an importation from Western Canada.

Lunch was served in the Boys' Refectory. Irishmen like O'Belleau, O'Connell, Mr. and Mrs. P. Peck and colleagues like Rita O'Chibbey and Violet Shannon O'Cooper agreed that it was one of the most enjoyable parties of the year. St. Patrick always seems to be ready to share the gaiety of the Irish on his feast day. Special guests were Miss M. S. Solomon, Mr. and Mrs. W. McGrath, Miss M. Whalen, Miss H. Lacey and Miss Dillon.

Unluckily the doors are locked or I would try some experiments myself. I know quite a lot about magnets because I was a Nosy-Nose when Gr. VIII booked its needlework morning. Porridge

Have you heard the fairy little pot story about the magic pot that the pot stopped boiling? If you haven't, here it is:

A little girl and her mother once lived in a small village and were very poor. One day while walking in the woods, they came across a kind old lady who gave them a magic pot which filled itself with sweet porridge. All that one had to do was to say "Wook little pot, cook." When the pot was filled, the words "Stop, little pot, stop," brought an end to the porridge making.

One day the little girl went to visit a friend in the village and her mother went with her. She said, "Cook, little pot, cook," and the pot filled with porridge. But alas she could not think of the right words to stop it so porridge and more porridge. Soon the little cottage was filled with porridge it ran out the door and into the village. It ran in streams down the streets and into the houses. Finally it reached the house where the little girl was visiting. She hurried home and cried, "Stop, stop, stop."

Gr. V.
Hundreds of years back when the earth was very young, "Wissakitchak" suddenly made up his mind to put into existence the first man of the earth. It was a serious decision. True, he had made the trees and the plants and the animals in the woods. However, this was different, a completely strange process. But Wissakitchak was wise and full of hope. Then again, he had been by himself so long. The earth seemed so sad. So Wissakitchak said, "I will make man."

He was slow at first in getting about it. And long after he had put together all the necessary materials,—an oven, fire and a great mass of sticky substance like powder. Still, he was at a loss as to what to do. It may be that at this point he was turning over in his mind the happy thought of making man seem physically like himself. Would it be for the good? Or would it be a foolish act for which he would have regrets in the future?

In the end, he made his decision. Man was going to be like him. He gave the substance, the form of his body, the same look on the face, the same eyes, and nose, and ears. Then he put the thing into the oven. And he said, "Now I will see what comes out of this."

Because he had no experience at all about such things, he did not get the thing out of the oven quick enough. When he did so, he saw much to his disgust that it was completely burned. It was black like coal. This was the first black man.

Was this his reward for all the trouble he had gone through? But Wissakitchak's purpose was strong; he was slow to give up.

So he made another attempt and he said, "I will not overdoo it this time."

He went through the same process again, taking care that the fire was low. This time, though, the waiting was too short. He did not give time enough before taking the substance from the oven. Missakitchak took one look at the thing before him, and he saw that it was again the sort of thing he did not have in mind. This was a poor picture of him, a form white as paste, altogether underdone. This was the first white man.

The second error seemed to give Wissakitchak more hope than doubt. Now he had the very thing he did not have before—experience. Knowledge had come to him the hard way. Now more than ever, he had a great desire to make another attempt.

"There will be no error this time," he said seriously.

He went about the process again with great care. He saw to it that the fire was not very high. He made certain that he took the form out of the oven at the right time. All these things he did.

He took one look at the completed form and a smile came on his face like sunlight. This was his idea of man, not very white, not so black, but with the color of a warm shade of brown. This was the first brown man. For him Wissakitchak had a smile and a feeling of love.

Passing on the Good Word

Whilst you have been in this hospital, you have learned many things—partly from these and other short letters that have been written for you, and partly from the Doctors and Nurses who look after you, and from just being here.

You have been told how Tuberculosis is spread from one person to another, and how if the person with the disease is careless about how he coughs and how he disposes of his sputum, the danger of giving his disease to someone else is great. You know that the Nurses and people who look after you wear masks and gowns to protect them when they are working near you. Even these precautions are not enough if you are careless.

You have learned, too, that the Tuberculosis germs do not like to live where it is clean and bright; they much prefer to get into some dark dirty corner where they won't be disturbed and can grow and multiply rapidly. Do you remember the story about "Johnny T.B." in the February "Arrow"? He said that he just couldn't stand sunlight—which is very true.

The most important thing that you have learned though, is that if you are given proper care, good food, lots of rest and good treatment, Tuberculosis can be stopped, and you can be made well to go home and live a normal, happy life.

Now I want you to do something—not for yourselves this time, but for those you love—your relatives and friends. They haven't had the chance to learn all the things you have learned about Tuberculosis. You can teach them. You can tell them how to protect themselves from getting the disease. You can tell them how they can find out whether they have any disease—by having X-rays taken even when they feel quite well. You can tell them how much easier it is to cure someone who has only a little disease than it is to help someone who has waited until he is really sick before he asks for help. You can tell them what can be done, and what is being done to stamp out this awful disease which kills about 2,000 Indians every year.

There is a very old saying that "An ounce of Prevention is worth a pound of Cure"... and in dealing with Tuberculosis it is certainly true! The fewer the people who get the disease the fewer there are to pass it on to others, and some day we shall beat "Johnny T.B."

Your catalogue arrived today,
Thanks for its cover bright and gay,
And all the lovely host it brought,
Delphiniums, forget-me-not,

THE COQUALEETZA INDIAN HOSPITAL

- by Dr. F.J. Porth

As most of you here know, I spent the month of February at the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital. It was a very interesting month to me, seeing new places and making new friends. Perhaps I can give you a few of my impressions gained during that month.

Coqualeetza is a beautiful name and from the time I first heard it several years ago I have always wanted to see this, as it were, "Garden of Eden". Although the time of the year was perhaps a little unfortunate, February can be cold even on the Pacific Coast, nevertheless all the beauty was there to be seen.

The Coqualeetza Indian Hospital is located at Sardis, B.C., a few miles from Chilliwack and only sixty miles from that great metropolis, Vancouver. It lies in the Fraser River Valley and a more beautiful spot would be hard to find. There are snow-capped mountains all around, not too close and not too far. There are evergreens everywhere and flowers, too, even in February. As Indian lore will have it, long before the white man stepped on this continent the inland Pacific Indians trekked yearly to the seas and one of their stopping places was Coqualeetza. It was their "place of cleansing" and resting place before the final lap to the seas.

There is a large park in front of the Hospital - grass, trees and flowers. The grass, too, at this time of year is green, which is unusual to prairie eyes. The building is of brick, three stories high with climbers all over the front. The driveway makes a long graceful arc through this sea of green.

Doctor W.S. Barclay, who met me at the station, is the Medical Superintendent of the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital. Perhaps you will remember him if I tell you he wrote the little story about Peter, a little Indian boy, and the germ that causes Tuberculosis. If you haven't read it I would strongly advise you to do so. It was published in the February issue of the Arrow. Doctor Barclay is a tall and kindly man but nevertheless strict when it comes to Tuberculosis.

As I should have perhaps mentioned sooner, the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital, like the Charles Camsell, is a treatment centre for Tuberculosis. Here, Indian boys and girls from the southern parts of British Columbia are brought to be treated for that dread disease.
THE COQUALEETZA INDIAN HOSPITAL
(Continued)

Like here, the mainstay of all treatment is rest, rest and more rest. It is surprising what a simple thing like rest can do to a tough customer like the Tubercle Bacillus. He just doesn't like it and pines away and gradually dies in spite of himself.

Besides bed rest, pneumothorax and pneumoperitoneum treatment is carried on at the Coqualeetza. Rest periods are insisted on and are much similar to the ones here at the Camsell. A great deal of Vocational Training is carried on and I was fortunate to bring away several small totem poles, made by the patients, as souvenirs of my stay at the Coqualeetza. These will always remind me of a very pleasant month spent at the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital and of the many friends I made and of many pleasant memories.
