IGLOO CHRISTMAS
-by Thomas Aneroluk
Ward X C

On Christmas Eve in the cold Northland
A crowded family in an igloo
Dared not stir nor go to sleep
But poured forth only prayers,
For a mighty blizzard on the creep
To-night their village and dogs and friends
Could cover over in a mountain of snow.
Then a little girl with a faintly smile
Cuddled close to her father's side;
"Daddy isn't God within our house,
As well as in the big blue sky?"
He kissed the angel face:
It was heaven's cheer for Christmas.
They woke in the moon at early dawn,
And found their world all safe and sound.
E. Pauline Johnson (Tekahionwake)

E. Pauline Johnson (Tekahionwake) was the youngest child born to G.H.M. Johnson, Head Chief of the Six Nations Indians, and his wife, Emily S. Howells, a lady of pure English parentage.

Chief Johnson was a descendant of one of the fifty noble families which composed the first historical Confederation. This was known at that time as the Brotherhood of the Five Nations. Since early times these Indians had been famed for their loyalty to the British Crown and for this fealty had been given the magnificent lands bordering on the Grand River in the County of Brant, Ontario, and on which the tribes still live. It was here, on her father's estate, "Chiefswood" that Pauline was born.

This little Indian girl had an intense love of poetry, and even before she could write composed many childish jingles about her pet dogs and cats. One time when she was just four a friend of her father's was going to the city. When he asked her what he could bring her for a present she said, "Verses, please." Her education was not extensive—a governess for two years at home, three years in an Indian school half a mile from home and two years in a school in Brantford.

In 1892 she became famous overnight after reciting "A Cry from an Indian Wife" at an evening of Canadian Authors in Toronto. Two weeks later Frank Yeigh arranged for her to give an evening of her poems. For this she composed the poem by which she is best known, "The Song My Paddle Sings". That evening, because she was nervous and because she had had scarcely time to memorize her new poem, she forgot her lines. But she did not lose her self-control and smilingly gave another poem.

Then a series of recitals were arranged for her across Canada in order that she might make enough money to go to England to have her poems published. This she was able to do just two years later. Here she made many good friends and was asked to give recitals in the drawing rooms of many diplomats, critics and nobility.

She had a very full and interesting life. She made other professional trips to England. She went to Newfoundland and the United States. She crossed the Rocky Mountains nineteen times and appeared as a public entertainer in every city and town between Halifax and Vancouver. Then she decided to settle down and devote her life to literature. However, shortly after she settled in Vancouver her health completely broke down.
Pauline Johnson, during her sixteen years of travelling, had many interesting experiences. She had driven up the old Battleford trail before the railroad went through, and across into British Columbia in the romantic days of the early pioneers, and once she took an 850-mile drive up the Cariboo trail to the gold-fields. She was an ardent canoeist and ran many strange rivers, crossed many a lonely lake, and camped in many an unfrequented place. These venturesome trips she took from her inherent love of nature and of adventure.

She died on March 7, 1913, and her ashes were scattered, as she had requested, from Siwash Rock in Stanley Park, the spot she loved so well. Canada will cherish her memory more and more as the years go by for of all Canadian poets she was the most distinctly a daughter of the soil.

"CANADIAN BORN"

We first saw light in Canada, the land beloved of God;
We are the pulse of Canada, its marrow and its blood:
And we, the men of Canada, can face the world and brag
That we were born in Canada beneath the British flag.

Few of us have the blood of kings, few are of courtly birth,
But few are vagabonds or rogues of doubtful name and worth;
And all have one credential that entitles us to brag -
That we were born in Canada beneath the British flag.

We've yet to make our money, we've yet to make our fame,
But we have gold and glory in our clean colonial name;
And every man's a millionaire if he can only brag
That he was born in Canada beneath the British flag.

No title and no coronet is half so proudly worn
As that which we inherited as men Canadian born.
We count no man so noble as the one who makes the brag
That he was born in Canada beneath the British flag.

The Dutch may have their Holland, the Spaniard have his Spain,
The Yankee to the south of us must south of us remain;
For not a man dare lift a hand against the men who brag
That they were born in Canada beneath the British flag.

- E. Pauline Johnson
THE SONG MY PADDLE SINGS

August is laughing across the sky,
Laughing while paddle, canoe and I,
Drift, drift,
Where the hills uplift
On either side of the current swift.

And oh, the river runs swifter now;
The eddies circle about my bow.
Swirl, swirl!
How the ripples curl
In many a dangerous pool awhirl!

And forward far the rapids roar,
Fretting their margin forever more.
Dash, dash,
With a mighty crash,
They seethe, and boil, and bound, and splash.

Be strong, O paddle! be brave, canoe!
The reckless waves you must plunge into.
Reel, reel.
On your trembling keel,
But never a fear my craft will feel.

We've raced the rapid, we're far ahead!
The river slips through its silent bed.
Sway, sway,
As the bubbles spray
And fall in tinkling tunes away.

And up on the hills against the sky,
A fir tree rocking its lullaby,
Swings, swings,
Its emerald wings,
Swelling the song that my paddle sings.

- E. Pauline Johnson
Dawn Marie Winslow and the Six Nations

- by Miss Minnie Hackett, P.H.N.,
White Horse, Yukon.

Dawn Marie Winslow - Bernice D.W. Loft before her marriage, was born near Ohsweken, the centre of the Six Nations Reserve, sixteen miles from Brantford, Ontario.

In 1939, she married Arthur Winslow, and later, went to Whitman, Massachusetts, U.S.A., where she has since resided, near the place his ancestors probably settled when they came in the "Mayflower".

Before her marriage she addressed groups of students at Queen's, McMaster, Toronto, and other Universities, interpreting the works of Pauline Johnson, the Indian poetess, and giving the history and the folk lore of the Six Nations.

The history of the Six Nations is colourful. Refusing to live under any other flag than the Union Jack or any other government than that of the British, when the rebels in America seceded the Six Nations forfeited their lands. They left the land where they had roamed as free men for many generations, and taking with them any possessions they could carry they trekked north after 1783. Among these possessions were their sacred Communion vessels given them by Queen Anne. These they buried under a large tree and did not remove until many years later, when they thought it safe to do so.

Landing on the north shore of Lake Ontario, near where Kingston now stands, they knelt and gave thanks to God for a safe journey. Here, the party divided. Col. Johnson, as leader of one group, remained to settle near where Toronto is today. The other group, under Joseph Brant, a Mohawk, continued to Lake Erie following the east side, and finally forded to the arable plains of the west bank. Brantford takes its name from that crossing. This land had been familiar to them and to their ancestors for hunting and as a resting place when they made raids on the white settlements to the south a century before.

Joseph Brant guided his people wisely. He was scholarly and cultured. Visiting England, he was received at Court by Queen Victoria, who was impressed by his grace and courteous manner.

The Six Nations claim the first Confederacy - the Confederacy of the Five Nations, Mohawks, Senecas, Oneidas, Cayugas and Onondagas - the sixth nation, the Tuscaroras, being taken in at a later date.

It is with this Mohawk background, that Dawn Marie Winslow writes of her ancestors, and tells spellbound audiences of their prowess.
To Oh-wen-Ji-yoh - "The Good Earth"

- by Dawn Marie Winslow
  (To her small daughter)

"Little Chief" your grandfather called you,
Your "Gampa", a chief of the Mohawks,
Called you that, as he watched your
Baby steps toddle and fall, and
Todle again. Straight as an arrow
Loosed to its mark you went.

"I loved, him, mother, why did he call
Me that, when he knew I was a girl?"

Little Earth Child, because he knew
The race of Chiefs was drawing to a close,
And his heart grieved for his people,
There would be none to follow him now,
And he wanted you to think as a Chief -
A woman Chief, with Nature's own
Nobility, and dignity, and beauty.
That is why he taught you to know
And feel the bark of Ga-lilt-donh,
The Red Oak, and to look up at its
Height and beauty, to know its
Heart was strong and tried and true.
He wanted you to learn
The beautiful stories trees tell,
And to heed their lessons well.
Trees are Earth world's true guides,
And they can be a guide to your
Mind and soul, too, if you will
Sit at their feet and listen.
Gampa Chief knew you would
Look up and beyond the trees
To the sky above. The blue
Of your baby eyes held this sky
Colour and the blue of your
Grandmother Winslow's eyes..."
Her gift to you at birth. She
Belonged to that great white race,
My little one, whose people braved
Unchartered seas to hold fast
Ideals of truth and justice and freedom.
The Indians welcomed them there
When they landed on the shores
Of New England's bays -
But the trees will tell you all this -
They hear and know much.
Your Grandma gave you courage,
And faith, hope, endurance, too.

"But the Indians and Gampa Chief
Gave me another name, Oh-wen-ji-yoh,
Mother, why did they name me so?"

Little Good Earth, because your Gampa
Knew the gold of your hair would
Turn to earth brown, and your
Eyes would hold the deep brown
Softness of our good Mother Earth,
The deep brown, too, of leaves
Enriching the land, when
They have left the Mother trees,
After the Moon of Falling Leaves.
One must live in tune with the Earth
To know the heights the trees would climb
And the depths, greater than the blue
Your grandmother's race crossed.
Think well, my little brown-eyed one,
For in you runs the blood of two
Great races, the red and the white,
Weigh well the good of both -
Of Gampa Chief and Grandmother Blue Eyes
And love will teach you the rest.

GREETINGS!

We regret very much that we have been so busy with many activities that we have been unable until now to compile a copy of our school magazine. We know that the parents and friends look forward to reading the Western Echo so we have made a special effort to get the magazine in the mails to you at last.

While the publication of the magazine has been delayed we have been busy with other work, and it all adds up to most successful year over a year to complete and which we are now occupying, have added much to the prestige of the school. The building comprises five classrooms, a manual training centre and a library. The primary room has been fitted with low tables and small chairs for the teacher and comfort of the children and we hope to institute a similar improvement in other classrooms for the better opportunity for study. Now that we are graduating pupils of this school who have the necessary qualifications and have the full support of their parents in the desire for higher education, from our grade nine to the public high schools, we have adopted the full public high school curriculum and more time must be spent by the pupil in studying. I am glad to say that our high school pupils in grades ten and eleven are doing well, and more than holding their own with other high school pupils.

During what has been a hot winter for health reasons, staff or the school has been excellent, and the health of the pupils has been maintained. We have excepted with only minor complaints, although we have shown a steady gain in weight and height. Our new boy, who came to school in September without uniforms, has actually gained 28 lbs in five months.

Promotions are already being made with the shipment. Complaints for the summer vacation, the parents will be advised in good time of the dates arranged.

I must congratulate the parents on the behaviour of their children in the school. We have not had one major breach of discipline during the past year; indeed kindness reigns supreme.

OUR ARTISTS
The weekly basket-ball practices in the Alberni Athletic Hall are looked forward to, both boys and girls taking part on alternate Mondays. Coached by Mr. Maize the pupils are showing keenness and great improvement. We have been promised a place in League competition in the coming season.

A girls Marching Team has been organized by Miss Bone, with the intent of putting on both marching and gymnastic displays when the weather permits. With uniform dress this team should be an attractive addition to the school activities on the Campus.

Athletics among both the girls and the boys should be furthered by the addition of two new staff members, Miss Prestley and Mr. Haddock, both of whom are taking gym classes. Wrestling has also been introduced. The game of Volley Ball has taken hold on the girl's side and on fine days many are using the high net.

It is through the whole-hearted co-operation and willingness-to-do spirit of the pupils that the best results can be obtained. It is the Team Spirit that the school wishes to foster, rather than individual performance. Everyone has a chance to share equally in school activities. A good school gathers a glorious and proud tradition through the years. Let us keep our school foremost in endeavours and above all—PLAY THE GAME!

Mr. Edward E. Peake—Many old Boys of Coqualeetza and Alberni schools will join with the present pupils in regretting the retirement of Mr. Peake from the school staff. Mr. Peake served these schools for many years, coming back to Alberni after four years overseas service with the Canadian Army. His health suffered as a result of his war services, but he carried on until he found it completely necessary to take a rest. He left for his home in England in February.

The Old Boys of Coqualeetza and Alberni are noted for their good sportsmanship and gentlemanly behaviour and it is to the instruction, and individual interest of Mr. Peake that they owe this enviable reputation.

The high regard in which Mr. Peake is held is evidenced by the many visits to the school of Old Boys, coming especially to see him. We all wish him God Speed, a Long Life and Prosperity, and hope to see him again.

Dear Camsellonians,

It is now just three weeks since the Dr. and I left Edmonton and although I am enjoying the trip tremendously I must admit that I am already beginning to feel that it will be grand to get back to see you all again.

We have travelled many miles since we last saw you; we have visited many interesting places and we have met many wonderful people. I wish I could describe everything to you but I'm afraid that would take too long.

Our first stop was in Ottawa. As you may imagine Dr. Meltzer was very busy there discussing all sorts of hospital matters with the heads of the Indian Health Services Department. He tells me it was a most successful visit and that he has been able to arrange many things which will improve our hospital. We saw many of our old friends in the Department and made many new ones, both in the Health Services and in the Department of Indian affairs. As many as possible were gathered together to discuss ways of making things better for all the Indians across Canada. The last three days we were there Dr. Meltzer attended the meetings of the Canadian Tuberculosis Association where all the people who are working to stamp out Tuberculosis in the whole of Canada, met to compare notes and discuss the ways in which this great effort could be carried on.

Ottawa is a beautiful city. There are many impressive buildings. Perhaps many of you have seen pictures of the Parliament Buildings, but I think I was more impressed by the lovely trees and gardens which abound in the city. It is, of course, a much older city than Edmonton and it has had time to become more settled. The streets are all paved and the houses themselves look settled down in their surroundings — they look as if they really belonged in their own particular spot and intended to stay there for a long time to come.

From Ottawa we travelled by car to Quebec City. It was a lovely drive and I think I enjoyed it so much more because the countryside reminded me of England. After the flatness of the
A Letter From Mrs. Meltzer
(Continued)

prairies it was lovely to see the countryside broken by little hills, and the small farms nestling in hollows sheltered by trees. I must tell you about the shutters on the houses. They are rather like our Venetian blinds but they are on the outside, and instead of being pulled up or down they open outwards like little doors. Most of the houses are built of stone and many are painted white and they really do look pretty. Most of them have a very high pointed roof—made of tin, which shines brilliantly in the sunshine.

Our stay in Quebec City was all too short. There is so much to see and learn about this old fortress. There are many monuments to honour great men in Canadian History. They have a beautiful park called, "The Plains of Abraham". It is the place where Wolfe defeated the French and first made Canada an English Colony. Our country has grown a great deal since that time to become one of the leading nations of the world but it is good to remember how we started and to be thankful that we have learned to live peaceably together.

We had to leave Quebec City and move on to Montreal, which is a large city compared to the other cities in Canada. Like all big cities it is very easy to feel alone there. There are so many people and they are all so very busy, and they all seem to be in such a hurry to get somewhere. The stores were full of lovely things and I certainly wished that I had lots of money to spend—but I just had to look. Montreal has some very beautiful buildings and churches. We took one tour of the city but the place is so big that to go and explore these places by yourself would not only take a very long time but I felt sure that I would get lost. Dr. Meltzer visited most of the hospitals there and saw what work they were doing.

We returned to Ottawa for two days and then went to London, Ontario. In this part of the world this city is referred to as "The Forest City" and they certainly have some beautiful trees. I certainly wish we had as many and such big ones in Edmonton. We spent a very happy week there, mainly, I think, because some of our relatives live there. There is a large Sanatorium there which the Dr. visited. He also visited the Westminster Hospital, which is a very big place. One place of special interest to some of you is the D.V.A. Lodge. I can't tell you much about it because
A Letter From Mrs. Meltzer
(Continued)

unfortunately I was unable to accompany Dr. Meltzer on his visit there. It is quite a large area of ground where all the D.V.A. Health Services for this district are being centralized. It is a short distance outside the city and from just driving past it seems an excellent arrangement.

One day we drove out to Springbank—which is quite a large park. Two things I saw I shall remember—one was a family of baby swans and the other was a peacock, which was very obliging and spread his tail for us to see. It was absolutely beautiful. Naturally that was one time I didn't have the camera with me.

Now we are in Toronto. Dr. Meltzer is visiting hospitals again this morning and I expect he'll be fairly busy all the time we are here, but it won't be very long now until we are on our way home.

Until we arrive, best wishes to you all and take good care of yourselves.

Yours sincerely,

D. Jean Meltzer.
(Mrs. H. Meltzer)

JAMES BAY INDIANS

Story II;
- By Dr. T.J. Orford

There are four thousand Indians living around James Bay today. These people are descendants of the original Cree tribe found there three hundred years ago by the first white traders. They are organized into ten main bands whose boundaries are defined by the limits of their trapping grounds. These people were never of a very warlike nature but occasionally, in days gone by, had inter-band raids and battles. Today, however, they live together as neighbors.

About forty years ago the Indian bands living in the Ontario section of James Bay began to sign Treaties with the Canadian and Ontario governments. Each member of every band receives five dollars a year paid in currency. Each band has a Reserve set aside upon which to reside and on which they have the timber and soil rights, but upon which they do not own mining rights. The trapping grounds are on Provincial Crown Lands and the Indians abide by the Ontario trapping and hunting regulations, subject to emergency needs, when they may
James Bay Indians
(Continued)

take animals for food. White trappers used to take out licenses to trap on some of the Indian trapping areas, but now each Indian trapper holds a license so that he and his family can keep the traditional hunting section as long as the license is renewed each year.

The first Indian Agent arrived in James Bay only in 1929. He was also the Doctor for this area. This arrangement continued until 1947 when both a Doctor and an Indian Agent were sent in by the Government. These men have to travel great distances to visit people. At first it was done by canoe, boat and dog team but now most trips are made by aeroplane. The Doctor now has fine nurses to help him. These women work amongst the Indian homes mainly but they also have two small hospitals. There are also five small hospitals operated by the Roman Catholic and the Anglican churches who staff these places with their own nurses. The government has this year started to build a large hospital for the treatment of Tuberculosis which will care for the Indians and Eskimos as far north as Hudson Strait—over one thousand miles distant.

Education is taken care of by a day school at each band centre and by four residential schools. All schools are run by the Roman Catholic and Anglican churches with government support. Because the Indians are trappers and must travel long distances with their families, many children do not receive much time at school but gradually they are all learning to speak English, and I am sure the day is not far off when some will continue on through high school and University for many are very clever boys and girls.

SLIPPERS and BOOTS and SHOES

You have slippers for a party, and sand-shoes for the sea,
Walking shoes with laces when you're going out to tea,
Rubber boots for splashing in the puddles down the street—
Just think of all the different things you wear upon your feet!

And Eskimos have knee-boots that are made from walrus hide—

I have just returned from a visit to Cold Lake, Keeheewin and Frog Lake Indian Reserves, having accompanied the Regional Supervisor of Indian Affairs, Mr. Cooderham, and the Saddle Lake Indian Agency party paying treaty annuities at those places.

The Cold Lake band numbers about 400, Keeheewin 200 and Frog Lake 200 — about 800 in all. They have recently come into the Saddle Lake Indian Agency and the Alberta jurisdiction, having formerly been a part of the Onion Lake Agency.

When these bands wish to see a doctor or go to a hospital they travel to Cold Lake, Bonnyville and Elk Point. The doctors here, as elsewhere, do not make house-to-house visits to the Indians. At Cold Lake is the John Neal Hospital. It is not very large and not very elaborate but it is well operated. At Bonnyville and at Elk Point are found the usual effective 40-50 bed hospitals, which are found all over Alberta. Dr. Ayotte, at Bonnyville, a French Canadian, is a competent physician and surgeon. The Elk Point Clinic, under Dr. Miller, Dr. Ross and Dr. Weigerinck, is rather renowned in and outside its locality.

Here we found the group of Indians rather more primitive than would be expected, considering the fact that they are living in a settled part of Alberta. Except for a few individuals they are doing little farming and stock raising. The Indians do a good deal of fishing and trapping. This is not a very good trapping country, and Cold Lake, the main fishing place of the district, is closed. One wonders just from where a source of income could be derived.

The children attend school at either St. Paul (Blue Quills), Onion Lake Residential or at the Day Schools at Keeheewin and Frog Lake.

I visited Mr. Dion (pronounced Deen) at Keeheewin. He has been teacher there for many years and has been a good friend and counsellor to the Indians. Many Indians can look back to having learned to read and write under Mr. Dion. Mr. Hunt, a successful teacher, has been at Frog Lake for eight years. It was a pleasure to visit Mr. and Mrs. Hunt.

Tuberculosis is not unusually prevalent but the eye disease, Trachoma, is very common above the age of childhood. However, I hope that soon I shall be able to do something towards laying out a detailed program to combat this disease.
Our recently completed X-Ray Survey was very interesting. It began with a 2½-hour train journey through regions of changing scenery from farm lands to muskeg, bush and lakes.

At Dawson Creek we were welcomed warmly by the B.C. provincial police and offered assistance in anyway. It proved later that Corporal Hall pinned our victim to the film holder while we took turns saying our famous pass-word: "Skwah-ta-moa, mcheetamo" (Take a deep breath and hold it).

The trip to Moberly Lake included interesting events. In some parts of the roads, the ditches were four feet higher than the road. Although there were no mountains yet nature provided hazards by piling small hills, one on top of the other.

We met relatives and friends of many patients in this hospital. At Wabasco we met Jean Beauregard whom all of us remember. We travelled over the Wabasco Trail for eight miles. This trail is noteworthy for its bumps. Where the Trail was smooth, pieces of wood were spaced about 3 feet apart. These, we were told, were for the horses to step on when the road was muddy.

Everywhere we went we were met with true northern hospitality. The trip by air was especially novel. Our clinic visited such places as Calling Lake, Long Lake, Trout Lake, Whitefish Lake and Rose Prairie.

Perhaps the most unforgettable aspect of the Journey was the mosquitoes. Folks tied the dogs and the children to keep the mosquitoes from carrying them away. Indeed we are sure that the mosquitoes or flies as they are known there, were so many that they worked in shifts and heaven help anyone caught in the rush when they changed—usually around 7 p.m. and 8 a.m. At these times they doubled in numbers and viciousness.

All things considered the trip was an interesting and enjoyable experience.
Dear Camsell Arrow,

Each month I look forward to that particular mail night when there will be a fat envelope for me with the Camsell Arrow inside. I wonder if other copies of the Arrow are as much read as my copy is. After the staff have finished looking over my shoulder to see the latest doings of any Saddle Lakers in Edmonton, the Arrow is pinned up on the bulletin board in the office. Here, it is perused at leisure, by all who come for medicines, etc. As each new copy is received, the old one is taken down and sent to Blue Quills School, where the staff and pupils may read about their friends. Now do not think that is the end of the trail, for when that paper reaches my hands again, I roll it up and mail it to my folks back East. Thus, your news is being spread far and wide. I do hope that you will all try to do your share in keeping your paper the lively and interesting one it is today, for it is only by working together and sharing the job that your paper can be a success.

H. M. Lillie.

(Public Health Nurse)

WARD FOUR A

Consternation reigned in Ward IV A recently. Suddenly there was a crash of thunder. We all thought the end of the world had come. Bang it went again—this time right on top of the hospital, it seemed. Annie Gotten jumped out of bed and ran out into the corridor with her rosary and her prayer-book in her hand. When the next crash came she ran back and tried to make a window blind out of her green housecoat. But at last the storm was over and we were settled down again. BUT next day we got the Venetian blind fixed and now all our worries are over—at the first sign of a storm we pull down the blind.

WARD FOUR C

Still He loves to save the sinful,
Heal the sick and lame,
Cheer the mourner, still the tempest,
Glory to His name.

Hello everybody. We five are fine and happy in our private ward to which we were moved recently. The weather sure is hot these days. We five Eskimos no like em hot weather—nearly get cooked. If this keeps on it will be:

Five little Eskimos
Sitting in the sun,
Melting, melting right away,
Melting one by one!

When you're feeling glum and blue,
Nothing here to anchor to—
Or to live for any more—
Till you reach the Heavenly shore—
There is God to glorify
And to live for till you die.

When life's storms beat on your head,
Till your hope is almost dead,
And you want to quit or die—
For no sunshine in your sky.
There is God to live for yet,
Do not murmur, do not fret.

He's not dead, nor doth He sleep,
But His purpose doth He keep—
That you glorify His name,
Daily guarding it from shame.
To His purpose then be true—
He has planned life's way for you—

and for me.

WARD IX C

Hello everyone! Nice weather we're having, sweet and pleasant! On June the first, I had my first car ride — that is hospital car ride. There have been fascinating stories told about the great North country. Well, here is one that should go in the news:

ADVENTURES IN THE GREAT YUKON RIVER

Mr. David Hammond was going down this great river which they call the Yukon. He was going to the famous Dawson City from Whitehorse. He was not in need of food—he had lots of it. One day while he was drifting down this mighty river, he saw a moose swimming across it. He rowed faster until he caught up to the moose. He did not want to kill it as he had no need of supplies, so he took the rope from the boat and tied it to the moose's horns. The moose kept on swimming down the river. David decided to let the moose do the work and he lay back and smoked and relaxed. Then a tragic thing happened. All he could remember was something hitting him in the back of the head. The moose had struck shallow water, and starting to run, had jerked the boat so hard that David had been knocked unconscious.

David finally arrived at Dawson City. He told the people about his adventure and only then did he realize that he had been unconscious FOR A WEEK!

Dear friends,

Time hurries on, doesn't it? Looking ahead two years seems a long time but looking back over it does not seem so long.

It has been quite a while since I left my pony, Sundown, waiting for me at the old home corral, lonely and weary, anxious to be on the trail again, rustling wild range horses and cattle. Many a lonely year Sundown has been a faithful pal to me. As you, my old friends, must know, an old saying is, "A cowboy's best friend is his pony." That is true—and I know you feel that way, if you are in the same boat as I am, man, and have left a faithful cowpony waiting for you at home. Don't make him wait too long, will you? When a cowpony gets used to his master it is mighty sad when they have to part.

We are missing all the shows, boys—the rodeos that are being held now all over the province. Our friends are having a "whale" of a time travelling from one show to another. Some have already sent in their entry fees to the Calgary Stampede office for the big Round-up being held July 5 to 10. They are entering the different events, such as: barsback bronc riding, both North American and Canadian saddle bronc riding, wild Brahma bull riding,
calf roping, steer decorating, wild horse racing, wild cow milking, etc.

Here we are, spending our time lying in bed, when we should be a contestant at the rodeo. Still, I feel, that soon we shall be better and able to do those things we enjoyed before we came to the hospital.

Think back! Remember the thrill it was - back in the saddle on your old cowboy - drawing by lot, the steer which you were to decorate, or the bronco which you were to take out of the chute. These memories do thrill one! So hurry, Jackie Labelle over in Ward 7 A and Louie and Joe in 9 A and Maurice and Danny in IX C. Let's waste no time in getting well, so that soon we may be catching that stage coach and heading for our own home town.

Adios,
Buddy Onespott.

This is the first time that I have written for the Arrow. I have not much to say, except that I have learned to play the guitar in twenty months - I think that is good news, don't you?

Hello friends, this time I am going to tell you about a dream I had a couple of years before I took sick. Two or three times I had the same old dream - always that I was going back to school again. It seemed so strange to me that I should be dreaming of school. The last time I had the dream I felt that it must be an omen that something was going to happen to me -- and it did! Sure enough my dream came true. I am doing school work again!

I am glad that I have had my leg repaired lately and am expecting my other leg to be repaired soon. I shall always be grateful to the doctors for trying to fix my legs so that I shall be able to walk again. Good luck and thank!

Robert Laboucon

"TOWARD THE SUN RISING"

We are fortunate that at St. George's we have a motto so easy to remember and yet so full of meaning. Far better its clear simple words than an obscure Latin quotation. For we know, each and every one of us, that although the sun may be hidden for a space by clouds, or the way be rough and difficult, that if we keep our thoughts turned upward, we shall go onward. "A MESSAGE FROM THE PRINCIPAL"

My dear Girls and Boys:

Thank you for inviting me to take part in your School Annual. I am quite sure I shall enjoy reading it. An important truth has forced itself on my mind more, perhaps, this year than ever before. It is this: Within each one of us there lies potentialities which, when discovered and brought into action, can give to us the maximum of happiness and fullness of living.

As I have told you many times in the past, and do so again now, true happiness and fullness of living is not plucked or derived from the lives of other people. Other people do contribute toward our happiness, but only in proportion to the measure that we give to them of the resources that are within us. The initial effort toward happiness and fullness of living must come from your own individual selves. You must, therefore, find out your own capacities and resources. Or, as one of the ancients, who lived many thousands of years ago said: "Know thyself." Find out what powers, what resources, what capacities for doing wonderful things, God has placed within each of you; even as He put them in the flowers and other things of His creation. We dare not and we must not be dependent on other people for our happiness and fullness of living. It will come to us as we seek to know ourselves, and as we draw from those resources divinely bestowed in each of us as the very crown and richness of our human heritage.

During the war years, many millions of young people were called upon to place themselves under orders. It was an enormous call, and a noble and splendid response was made by these millions of young people. They made a tremendous sacrifice; not the least of which was the sacrifice of their own initiative, which, in many instances was given little chance to mature. They depended on authority for all daily activity, and almost all their social and recreational life was ordered without any effort on their part.

You youngsters, and all other youngsters of this age and generation, must make it your most special and sacred duty to see that the forces within you, and which are the very vital part of your social structure; and from which true happiness and fullness of living is born, are not allowed to die or even remain dormant in you. Bring them into action; don't lean on other people, give of the best that you have within yourself to the welfare of others. In that way you will realize great happiness and fullness of living.

Love and best wishes from myself and Mrs. Hives,

Ever your friend,

[Signature]

Principal

To my Pupils:

Your cheerful cooperation has made teaching you a pleasant task. I hope that you will all be back at school next term. If we are to become useful citizens, the importance of education must be realized by each one of us.

For those of you who are graduates a very important part of life is beginning. Do not be content with a grade-eight standing. That is just the first milestone in your education. If you are ambitious, you will have the opportunity of attending high-school and some of you may go on to university. Without training you cannot become effective leaders of your people, and no matter what your career is to be, a good education is necessary to help you make a success of your life.

May you choose the right path and find the best way of fitting yourselves to follow it.

Best wishes to all,

Throughout the basketball season we had many good games. In October we chose four teams - the Black Hawks, the Rangers, the Hornets, and the Leafs. We played two games a week.

At the end of each month the two teams that had won the most games played for that month's Grand Championship. Near the end of the season we played two exhibition games, and the last game was for the school championship. The Black Hawks and the Rangers played for this and the former won by two points.

Although there were a few accidents, such as broken glasses and wrist-watches, the games were thoroughly enjoyed by both the players and the spectators. At the end of the season all the points were added up for each player with Roddy Tait coming first - 140 points; Albert Wells second - 120 points, and Eddie Boston third - 55 points.

Good sportsmanship was shown by all players and there were no fights throughout the season; the losers were just as happy as the winners.

=Albert Wells
"The Dragon"

The 24th of May

As it had been raining for three days we were a bit worried when we got up on the morning of the twenty-fourth of May and found that it was still cloudy, but soon the sun began to shine so everybody brightened up. After we had lunch packed, we started out for the field beside the swimming pool where we were to have our sports events.

Before we had our dinner we were divided into groups. The No. 2 and 3 girls and boys were together although the girls started to crowd away trying to get as far from the boys as possible until one of the staff said, "Now, don't they boys are not going to bite you." We soon mixed together playing British Bulldog. After a few games we sat in two circles for our lunch. We had run so much playing games that we were very hungry. Marjorie Alan broke the record by eating six winners smothered in mustard.

After we had finished our meal we marched around in a circle so the Hives could take our picture, then we started the various events.

Some of the highlights of the day were:

- The fish-pond where you could fish for necklaces, combs and other things with a magnet.
- No. One boys' cracker eating race which was won by Ranger Scymour, of course.
- No. 3 girls' standing broad jump won by Joan Thom, 7 ft. in, nearly breaking the boys' record of 7 ft. 7 in.
- The No. 3 boys' high jump was really a surprise won by Johnny Joe who cleared 4 ft. 7 in.
- The boys one mile race was a hot and long one won by Reddy Tait followed up by Wesley "Squash" Munroe.
- The last and most exciting event was the greasy pole climbed by the one and only Oliver "Blondie" Munroe.

—Phyllis Dunstan

KIWANIS HOBBY SHOW

On March 28th, news was passed around that three boys were going to Vancouver to see the Kiwanis Hobby Show. Who the boys were we did not know. That night Mr. Hives told us who was going to go and why he had chosen those three boys - Roddy Tait, Geoffrey San, and Albert Wells.

On April 1st we started for Vancouver at three o'clock in the morning. The ride lasted for about five and a half hours. We were teasing Jeff about the farmer going to the city for this was the first time he had been to Vancouver.

When we arrived in Vancouver we waited for Mr. Hives to come and pick us up at the station. He told Mr. Hill, our manual training instructor, to take us around to the big stores and then down to the Hobby Show.

After we had been through the stores and bought what we wanted, we walked over to the Show - about a three mile walk. We enjoyed the walk, however, for we saw many interesting things, such as the Burrard Bridge and Burrard Inlet. When we arrived at the exhibition building it was closed but after we explained where we came from they let us see all the other exhibits. We saw many interesting things there. There were locomotive engines that could pull five people around the room. The engine itself stood no higher than a foot off the floor and the engineer sat on top of the engine and fed it coal with a teaspoon. There was also woodwork, such as we sent in, and leather work from the Coquuletza Indian Hospital, totem poles, war equipment, plastic work, and many other displays. An odd hobby one boy had was collecting umbrella handles.

When the final results were known, we found that our school had taken third prize. In the individual work Donnie McIntyre took first, David Albert second, Norman Bustace third, and Roddy Tait third.

--Albert Wells

SOCIAL EVENTS

OUR HALLOWE'EN PARTY

Scenes around the school showed that Hallowe'en was only two weeks away. The whole school was humming with activity. Mr. Hives had bought some crepe paper so the girls started their costumes—cutting, fitting, and then sewing them. Everyone was busy and if you had walked around you would have heard someone say, "Where's my needle?" or another, "Who has the other sleeve of my blouse?" On the boys side you might have heard someone say, "Hey Jeff, where did you get the horse hair for your beard?" I swiped it from you last night," was the answer. Costumes were of all sorts—painted cannibals, blood-thirsty pirates, a wicked witch with his black cat, lovely Mistress Mary.

The Assembly Hall was eerily decorated with pumpkins at the windows, while black cats and witches roved the walls.

At last the longed-for night arrived and those that had costumes ready put them on. Everyone went into the hall and the parade of costumes began. The high school teacher from Lytton was the judge, and she had a difficult time choosing the winners. After the lucky ones were chosen and prizes given to the four smaller ones, the number ones played games before going downstairs for their refreshments. The older ones then had square dances and modern dancing. Prizes were awarded to the winners and refreshments were served. The party ended with the singing of "Now the Day is Over."

—Donna Bent

THE CHRISTMAS SEASON

The feeling we had that Christmas was near began about five weeks before the holidays when the children started practising for the Christmas Concert. It was well worth the time and effort for it was a great success. From the Kinder garden's Mother Goose to the Senior Class' Christmas Carol each item was thoroughly enjoyed. There were thrilling physical training displays, while the Boys' Shoe Shop play and song caused much laughter.

We were told by our principal that some of the children would be going home for a two-week holiday. This kept us all in suspense as to whether we were going or not. All was quiet while Mr. Hives read the list of the parents who wished to have their children home for Christmas but most of us were smiling when we came out of the hall.

(mont. next p.c.)
"The Christmas Season" cont.

The twentieth of December was the day the children were to leave. Everyone was rushing around getting their things ready and wondering if the afternoon would ever come. When they finally did leave, everything was quiet.

The children who didn't go home had treats. They saw a movie called "Tom Sawyer". On Christmas morning the girls woke up to find large panda bears at the foot of each bed. They went to the Assembly Hall where a lovely Christmas tree stood. Soon Santa Claus came and wished them a Merry Christmas and distributed the gifts. NEW LIFE

Now that we can see that Spring is really here and everything around is bursting into New Life, let us take a look at things which can be done to bring us back to health and give us New Life.

Let us suppose that you broke a leg bone. What would you do to make that leg strong and useful again? First of all, it would have to be "set"—that is, put in the right position. Secondly, it would have to be kept in that position either by splints or a cast until the bone had healed itself.

When your lung is diseased with Tuberculosis, a very similar thing is done. First of all, your lung is rested by resting your whole body. You know that if someone runs very fast, they have to breathe very quickly. Their lungs have to work extra hard to make up for the energy they used in running. So when you rest completely in bed, your lungs do not have to work hard and have a better chance to fight the disease. However, this takes a very long time and sometimes this is not enough. Then we have to do something else to rest your lung—just as a broken bone has to be put in a splint.

The first thing that we try is Pneumothorax. That is a long word but it simply means that we put air in between the chest wall and the lung, and that holds the lung in a collapsed position. It looks something like this:

```
CHEST WALL
AIR
LUNG
```

You can see how the lung takes up much less space after the air has been put in. It is held in that position until the lung has overcome all T.B. germs and so healed itself.

Another way to collapse the lung is to put air in the belly so that the lung is collapsed from below instead of from the side, like this:

```
LUNG
AIR
LUNG
AIR
```

This method is known as Pneumoperitoneum.

(Continued, next page)
NEW LIFE
(Continued)

These two ways are the simplest methods of "splinting" the lungs; but they are not always sufficient. If these methods fail, then some other way has to be tried. This method I will try to explain to you next month. The idea is always the same, however, - to find some way of keeping the lung at rest in one position - some way of "putting the lung in a splint" - so that it can rest completely and heal itself.

REMEMBER - a broken leg won't heal if you walk on it, and a diseased lung won't heal unless you REST it!

H. Meltzer,
Medical Director.

EMPIRE DAY

Once again Empire Day is here. Our country has now grown to the status of nationhood. By the statute of Westminster passed by the British Parliament in 1930, Canada became a completely self-governing country, bound to the Mother Country only by the silken thread of allegiance to a common Crown.

This does not mean, however, that Canada is any less a member of the British Empire - or the British Commonwealth of Nations - than she has ever been. Unity may be achieved by co-operation, just as well as by compulsion, and sometimes even better than by compulsion. The people of Canada and the Mother Country are one kindred. They inherit the same traditions, and they bear allegiance to the same throne.

Empire Day is a day when we should rejoice over the fact that we live in Canada, where we have peace and plenty, and should be thankful that we are a member of this great Commonwealth of Nations, which is such a force for world peace today.

James Bay is a long narrow, shallow sea extending south from Hudson Bay into the northern parts of Ontario and Quebec. Over a dozen mighty rivers, pouring fresh water constantly into it, make this sea less salty than most other oceans.

This section of Canada is rich in history. Nearly three hundred years ago two French trappers travelled about eight hundred miles from Montreal, by canoe and portage, and then in winter by overshoe, to be the first white men to see James Bay. They returned with stories of the vast wealth of beaver and tales about the friendly Indians found along the shores of this new ocean.

French traders of New France would not finance these two men as they wished; they therefore went to England and convinced the King to send a ship to this new land of wealth. This sailing vessel found its way through the Arctic waters of Hudson Strait and Hudson Bay. It wintered in James Bay and returned a year later laden with furs. The King of England then granted a charter to certain of his noblemen to form a trading company. To these men he gave possession of all the lands which we knew as Canada, excepting that part then under the rule of France. He did not, of course, realize the extent of his gift.
JAMES BAY INDIANS
(Continued)

The French, when they found out what they had missed, took warlike means to regain it. For many years battles were fought on the shores and waters of James Bay for the right to trade furs with the Indians who lived there. Sometimes the French and sometimes the English won the fights but finally the now historic Hudson's Bay Company emerged victorious. To-day they still carry on a thriving fur trading business in the same James Bay, which was the beginning of this trading empire. From points in James Bay these early traders travelled by foot and canoe to gradually discover the vast area of our present Canada.

For many years James Bay was reached only by the Arctic water route. Sailing vessels from England brought traders and their goods to isolated settlements and returned with a cargo of valuable furs. As the southern parts of Ontario and Quebec developed the river routes became well travelled by flotillas of large canoes carrying men and supplies. Slowly the railroad was built toward the north and about eighteen years ago finally reached James Bay where the new town of Moosonee was begun. The river and the Arctic water routes were then abandoned. Aeroplane service is now an almost daily occurrence to any point in the area so that the people who once were weeks and months of hard travelling away from civilization can now be reached in a matter of hours.

This is the FIRST of a SERIES of articles on the James Bay Indians, by Dr. T.J. Orford, which will appear each month in the Camsell Arrow.

Our flag, the Union Jack, has been formed from the three original flags of England, Scotland and Ireland - the Cross of St. George, the Cross of St. Andrew and the Cross of St. Patrick. In 1603, upon the death of his cousin, Elizabeth, Queen of England, James VI, King of Scotland, became also King James I, of England. He combined the Jacks of England and Scotland into one flag. Each country continued to fly its own flag on some occasions and the new flag at certain other times. This flag was known as the "additional" flag of James I. In the year, 1707, in the reign of Queen Anne, the Parliaments of England and Scotland were finally brought into Union in one Parliament. The flag of James I was accepted with a few small changes, and became the first fully authorized "Union Jack". During all these centuries the red cross of St. Patrick had continued alone. But the time came when another change was made in the Union Jack, and in 1801, under George III, the red cross of Ireland joined the sister crosses, resulting in the Union Jack as we know it today.

- History of the Union Jack

The staff held a very enjoyable party at the home of Mrs. Wood on Friday, May 7, in honour of Miss Zaremba and Miss Pomrenk, two members of the nursing staff, who are leaving soon to be married. Many lovely gifts were "showered" upon them. Attractive prizes for the most original costumes were given to Miss M. Cogill and Miss B. Aimer.

At the tea hour on Wednesday, May 19, the staff honoured Miss Bartman, Miss Pomrenk and Miss Kinderwater. Miss Taylor presented each guest with a farewell gift. Miss Bartman is leaving shortly for Wellington, New Zealand, to accept a position in the Wellington Hospital. Miss Kinderwater has accepted a position in St. Joseph's Hospital, Bellingham, Washington, U.S.A. Miss Marjorie Fazackerley, who has been with us for some months, will take charge of the dietetic department of the hospital. She has been assisting Miss Bartman in this department.

Our apologies to Roy Miner for calling him Jack in the last issue of the paper!

Mr. Johnnie Bridgen left this week to take over a store on the south side. Johnnie has bought the business and will handle groceries and meat.

We regret to learn that Mr. Ford will not be looking after the hospital grounds this summer. They were very beautiful last summer. Mr. and Mrs. Ford are leaving for California.
STAFF
(Continued)

Mr. Art Lyons, D.V.A., member of the Ad. office, left recently to go to the Coast. Mr. Watson, D.V.A., is paying a daily call.

Mr. M. Goodall has joined the staff and will be in charge of the X-Ray Department.

We are all glad to see Mr. Anderson back after his recent sick leave-of-absence.

Members of the staff surprised Miss Betty Bartman when they met in the kitchen staff dining room at the tea hour Friday. Mr. Latham, on behalf of those present, expressed their regret at her leaving and wished her good luck in her new position in New Zealand. A gift was presented to her by Mr. Latham.

Mrs. Kerans was recently discharged from the hospital. We shall be looking forward to seeing her back at work in the fall. At leaving she handed us this little poem, composed by her niece, Kathleen Moker, Age 11, St. Benedict, Sask.

The Bluebird

Please, dear Bluebird,
Sing us a song,
Sing it with words
That last the year long.

Please, dear Bluebird,
Make us a nest,
Make it so beautiful,
That words can't express!

And dear Bluebird,
With your song and nest,
We will love you
And slumber to rest.

THE ELF AND THE DORMOUSE

Under a toadstool
Crept a wee Elf
Out of the rain
To shelter himself.

Under the toadstool,
Sound asleep
Sat a big Dormouse
All in a heap.

Trembled the wee Elf
Frightened and yet
Fearing to fly away
Lest he get wet.

To the next shelter —
Maybe a mile!
Sudden the wee Elf
Smiled a wee smile.

Tugged till the toadstool
Toppled in two.
Holding it over him,
Gaily he flew.

Soon he was safe home
Dry as could be.
Soon woke the Dormouse —
"Good gracious me!"

"Where is my toadstool?"
Loud he lamented —
And that's how umbrellas
First were invented.

— Oliver Herford
WARD II

We are expecting Lillian to give a big party soon. She wrote to her brother for TWO pounds of sugar. It sounds like candy to us!

DRESSMAKING—done by the girls in II-1.

If you want your dolls to have the "new look" bring them to us!

Question: What did the mayonnaise say to the ice-box?
Answer: Shut the door, I'm dressing!

Ivy: Goodness, you use such hard words! So hard to form!
Margaret: What word did I use?
Ivy: You used HABIT.

Our buzzer is broken,
So what do we do?

The girls in II-D are happy to have Leona Chalifoux with them. She was recently moved from Ward III.

Adeline always has her nose stuck in a book. What kind? NOT mystery stories, NOT travel stories, NOT adventure stories, NOT ———— Oh well, maybe it is only spring fever!

We have enjoyed the shows that the Gyrettes have been showing twice a month since February. We shall be looking forward to the fall when they may start again.

WANTED—a clothes line—the radiators snag the stockings!

WARD III

Isabel Reid left us for home last Wednesday. She has been in the hospital for two years and we shall miss her very much. Her address is: Telegraph Creek, B.C.

I've tried out the Sunporch,
And also Four E,
Now I'm back once again
To my bed in Ward III.

Our little friend, Mary Not So Useful went home on the 28th of April. She was just as worried lest the train would go without her as she was excited over the prospects of getting home.

Some of the girls in our ward have been fortunate in having been granted the privilege of going out for a fresh-air walk each day.
WARD III (Continued)

Mary Jane Boucher and Frances Willier left for home about two weeks ago. The girls have been in the hospital for a long time. Mary Jane Boucher has been a patient for two and a half years. Good luck!

Ruth Lightning has been moved to a private. Hurry and get well, Ruth, we want you back in your accustomed place.

Maggie Royal is very happy these days since she has finished with her spinal operation. She had two surprises recently—her brother, Charlie, and her sister, Rosie, from Seattle, Washington, U.S.A. visited her.

Mary Jane was almost mistaken for Ruth Lightning recently. Mary Jane saw the "point" of this joke!

WARD IV SUNPORCH

Hello everyone, from Wards One to Ten,

We missed out last month, BUT we're back in again!

We are glad to have Agnes Augibelle with us now. She is good company and we all like her very much.

Kay wants to buy a whole gallon of milk and a whole loaf of bread and eat it ALL herself. After all I guess a "twig" does need a good deal of nourishment in the spring!

The girls have been having nightmares! After all Kay, you might have been sleeping on your arm instead of baking bread! And Margaret, your hot water bottle is a poor substitute for a milk bottle!

Adeline has a new name for the doughnuts—Bannock with a Hole in it!

WARD I V E

For four long years I have never been to church until I went on Sunday, May 9, when the Rt. Rev. W.F. Barfoot, the Bishop of Edmonton, presented Donald Ayalik with the Royal Humane medal. How nice it was to attend church again. I was pleased to see Tom Goose there, too.

— Sarah Kaptana

One night at bedtime Doris was reading her autographs and she dropped her little rabbit. "Where is my little rabbit?" she said. "Why, here I am!" said a voice from the other side of the partition. IT WAS ALICE BLACK RABBIT!

Sarah was making topless socks and putting the tops on afterwards. Sarah says it is easy to do this and she wishes it was as easy to get cured of the T.B. as it is to do this seemingly impossible thing!
W A R D VII

The children in Ward VII and VIII wish to thank the Rev. Miller of the Highlands United Church, and Mrs. Cobblewick, President of the Church Society, for the shows and icecream treats which they have been bringing to them during the winter months.

In the five months I have been in the hospital I have learned how fortunate we Indians, from all parts of the country, are to be able to come to such a hospital for the best treatment of tuberculosis and many other kinds of sicknesses. Most of all we are fortunate to be under the care of such experienced doctors who do such remarkable work. The nurses, too, do a wonderful work in comforting the patients when they are very sick, and I say the same for the Aids and Orderlies. I'm sure we have all learned to co-operate and to obey orders, even if they seem grim. We are doing it only for our own good and we should feel proud of ourselves if we co-operate with the staff.

We guys in Ward VII wish all the patients in the hospital a speedy recovery.

Kilroy.

W A R D IX A

We wish to send our best regards to Robert Onespott, who has been moved to Ward X A. Keep up the good practice at the Hawaiian music. It will take patience but the result will be well worth while!

Hello to Howard McMaster, who has had an operation recently! Hope you are getting along well. We are looking forward to the time when you will be back with us again!

We welcome John Tagmery back to our ward again after spending two months in Ward IX B.

W A R D IX B

Archie Half, who is an interesting story teller has been moved into our ward. Any one who can add to the entertainment of the ward is especially welcomed.

We are glad to have Jerry Chalifoux from Kinuso, Alta. with us. He has just been admitted to the hospital.

Ben Adams has been putting on a lot of weight. He is feeling fine and is looking forward to a higher routine.

We admire James Klalazee and Harry Nedlin. They are in the front when it comes to fun and singing but they also know when to be quiet, and co-operative at the right time.

(Continued)
WARD IX B (Continued)

John Tammery was back with us for a couple of days but has left us again for Ward IX A.

John Seseequon seems to miss Mr. Tammery. Why not return to us?

Bill M. and Simon J. and everyone else is doing fine.

WARD X A

Hello friends, What better can I wish you than that you will all be back with your parents and relatives soon! And once again we wish to thank all the doctors and the nurses for the splendid treatment we are getting. We miss Harry Martin from the ward. He has just had an operation. We are lucky to have Roy Hunter and Robert Onespott with us.

- Richard Dick

Well, I can understand Jimmie's incredible story about the big storm. They do happen sometimes. It's hard to believe, but one day I was working with a half-breed guy, Louzon Gladue, late in the autumn. The ducks had not gone to the far south to the warm country. Louzon was looking for his lost horses and came to a small lake. It was full of ducks! He came back hastily for his shot-gun. Taking a few shells he ran back to the lake. When he got close he could see the ducks were still sitting in the very same spot. So he took aim and shot. Bang! Bang! Bang! Finally after the third shot the ducks flew from the ice and to his surprise he saw that each duck was carrying off a big piece of ice stuck to each foot! After that the ice in the little lake was all opened up again.

I also agree with our friends, Jack Royal and Fred Lafferty, in their praise of the doctors and the staff. We thank them and wish them good luck. We also thank our nice kind teachers who help us and keep us supplied with reading material. We are very interested in our library reading. Thanks to all.

- Robert Laboucon

Hello to everyone! We are all fine, - good health and happiness to you all!

Glad to welcome back Richard Black, who is an old-timer, to our ward.

We are all looking forward to July. We hear we are to have a picnic that month.
Hunting season is on in our ward! The first big game was killed by G. Tecomba on May 3. It was a Moose—quito!

Modeste Piche has a habit of singing songs which he has learned from the radio programs. He enjoys the one called, "There's a Love Knot in my Lariat". Modeste sings it this way: "There's a Tough Knot in my Harriets".

Dear friends, it is indeed a pleasure to give you news of our ward. We are still the same jolly bunch taking the cure as best we can. We're lucky to have two fiddlers, Fred Lafferty and Eddie Lafleur and a couple of guitar players. "Keep it up, boys. Keep on the sunny side of life and chase the dark clouds away." Eddy Lafleur and Fred Lafferty are lucky boys, having visitors every once a week.

We have a concert every night with Eddy Lafleur, the North West Troubadour from Yellow Knife as chief performer. Hope all the rest of you are as well and happy and jolly as we are! You'll be hearing from us next month. Best regards to all and a fast recovery.

- The Boys of Ward X B.

FLAG USAGE

The nationality of a country is shown by its flag.

The nationality of a vessel is made known by the flag she flies at the stern.

To hoist the flag of one nation under that of another nation, on the same flag-staff, is to show it disrespect.

The lowering of a flag is a signal of surrender.

The raising of the victor's flag in its place is a signal of capture.

A flag at half-mast (halfway up its pole) is a sign of mourning.

A flag reversed is a signal of distress.

Miss Such, a former member of the nursing staff, surprised us at the tea hour on Thursday. She is at present taking a course in Davenport, Idaho. She had come on a visit to Edmonton to attend the wedding of her sister.
A.M.D.G.

On March 21, 1939, Rev. Father Rossignol gave his first blessing to the newborn "Island Breezes", the brainchild of Sr. A. Blanchette and Sr. A. Brady. A precocious child, to say the least, for in its very first infancy it achieved the distinction of being not only a chronicle of local events, but also a link between the school children and those who had formerly occupied the same well-worn desks and sweated over similar tasks. The following year, Sr. M.A. Bisson picked up the editorial pen and wielded it until 1946.

During these first years, guest articles in Cree, French and English were contributed by Rev. Guy Remy, Mr. H. Staines, Dr. P. Lavoie, Mr. E. Benoit, to name only a few. Re-reading the back copies in order, one can visualize the recent steady expansion of both mission and hamlet. One must stop to bow before a host of distinguished visitors from all walks of life whose short or long sojourn on the Island was faithfully recorded alongside the day-by-day activities ranging all the way from inoculations to the welcoming home of veterans of World War II.

In June 1942, "Island Breezes" gave a farewell kiss to the gelatin pad, and the following September warmly embraced the new Gestetner, the gift of His Exc. Bishop M. LaJeunesse. It was the beginning of an enduring friendship. Well and good to make a friend, but how to keep him is a more difficult proposition. Gestetner found a way in June 1946 by giving, for the first time, colour to the breezy little paper's Centennial Edition.

In September 1946, an attempt was made to classify the material printed in its pages—the same type as of old, but with a New Look. In this make-up did the first paper of the remote areas of Northern Saskatchewan take its first bow in the Saskatchewan Legislative Assembly in March 1948, on its ninth birthday—a novel way to celebrate one's anniversary.

-The Editor.

ABOUT RAT

On March 14, a first meeting was held in the parish hall to discuss the "rat" situation before the opening of the trapping season. 78 able-bodied men, sound of mind and firm of purpose, were there assembled to discuss the different aspects of this "bread-and-butter" question. They also wanted to prepare the all-important meeting with the Chief Overseer for fur conservation, Mr. W. Tunstead.

On March 21, Mr. Tunstead flew in from Portage La Loche, 3 hours behind schedule. The men, 120 strong this time, marched him to the parish hall where also present Mr. C.B. McNeil, Field Officer, Mr. J. Brocker, Game Warden and Rev. J. Kemy.

The men were satisfied with the assigned quota of rats, provided they can reach it. Married men can trap 165 muskrats, single men 100 and young people 60. Mr. Tunstead granted a larger quota and 5 days longer to the trappers going to the boundaries of Snake Lake and Pachuanak game blocks where beavers were stolen last season. They asked that the first payment be $2, but Mr. Tunstead answered that Regina had decreed that it would be $1... even though Sask. muskrats are second only to Labrador pelts (and are actually being auctioned off as high as $5 a skin). The second payment will be sent in June after auction is over. It is hoped that the Fur Marketing Service does not deal in recent cheques as the Fish Board.

The men of Ilc a la Crosse also requested that they be given rights to the Kazan Preserve, their former hunting ground. They also asked that greater authority be granted to the deputy game wardens to protect fur in their block against marauders. The deputies were told they were empowered to seize both traps and catch of any trespasser on a block.

On the whole, the meeting was a satisfactory one. But like the Pied Piper of Hamelin, the men may find it easier to trap the "rats" than to secure a fair price for their pelts.

Joe Landry, Leon Belanger, Charles Malboeuf, J.B. & J.M. & Auguste Darrocher, Jonas Pavel and many others helped to save the furniture.
