Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Welfare Teachers in Indian Schools.

As requested in your memorandum of 14 January, I present hereunder the reports on certain of our welfare teachers.

(a) In Hospital Schools.

Most of the teachers in these hospital schools are employed on a full twelve month year basis. In practically all instances they live in residence in the hospitals and are on call at all times.

They are engaged in two main types of teaching activity:

1. Bedside teaching; here a portable blackboard is used and two or three bed patients at a time are instructed. Much of this teaching is to adult Indians who have never been to school before and who learn to read and write for the first time when in hospital.

2. Classroom teaching; here up-patients are taught in a small room set aside for classroom purposes. In inspecting these schools our inspectors have been most satisfied with the results achieved in such classes.

In both the above instances, the teachers can carry on classes only at times prescribed by the medical superintendent.

This means that they carry on classes in the evening; on Saturdays and at any other time when they can be fitted in to
the hospital programme.

The medical superintendents of these hospitals have been most enthusiastic about these teachers and their work. Due to their teaching activities they are in close contact with the Indians and win their confidence. As a result they are able to carry out a worthwhile welfare programme in addition to their teaching duties. A few illustrations are:

1. The writing of letters to home reserves, Indian superintendents, residential schools, etc., on behalf of illiterate patients.

2. To advise these Indians concerning family allowances, school attendance of their children and many other matters arising out of such letters.

3. The conduct of adult education projects such as handicrafts, (I enclose samples from Coqualeetza Hospital School) educational films, hospital newspapers (I enclose the Charles Cassell paper), etc., have done a great deal to improve patient morale.

4. Assisting the hospital staff in a programme of health education by presenting in their health lessons the sanitary habits and procedures which the doctors wish the patients to follow when they return to their home reserves.

The most difficult part of this hospital education is the selection of a suitable type of teacher. Our success in this regard is best judged by the repeated requests from medical superintendents of these hospitals for "another teacher like Miss So-and-So".

The reports on the teachers marked are as follows:

Miss Alice Eaton, Grade 2 Welfare Teacher, Clearwater Lake Hospital; Second Class Teaching Certificate; 11 years Provincial Schools; 15 years Indian Day Schools.

Inspector of Schools H. P. Moffat, in his report of December 8, 1948, comments:

"Miss Eaton works for the most part with the bed..."
patients while Mrs. Smith has the classroom. The cheery optimism of Miss Eaton is quite marvellous to behold. She feels that she is doing a highly worthwhile work and forgets herself completely in the interest taken in the welfare of those in her charge.

"The amount of study which the bed patients are able to do is sharply limited by their physical condition, however, a good deal of work is being done. One young man of twenty-six is learning to read and write and enjoying it immensely. A good deal of beadwork and knitting is done by these patients. Miss Eaton appears to have the complete confidence and cooperation of those in her charge."

Mr. T.A.J. Cummings, the Secretary Treasurer of the Sanatorium Board of Manitoba, wrote on August 14, 1947:

"As you know, Miss Eaton has been doing excellent work at the hospital and is well recommended by the Medical Superintendent."

Mrs. A. L. Hughes, Grade 3 Welfare Teacher, Miller Bay Hospital, B.A.; B.C.L.; High School Teacher's Certificate; 10 years provincial schools; one year Indian hospital school; Specialist training at McGill in handicrafts and social welfare.

Mrs. Hughes opened this school just over a year ago and we have only received a preliminary report from Inspector Davey. In this report he recommended the employment of a second teacher as did the Medical Superintendent of the Hospital. As a result of these representations, we engaged the services of

Miss Mary L. Starratt, Grade 3 Welfare Teacher; Academic Teacher's Certificate; 15 years of provincial teaching experience, particularly with retarded children; also Social Service experience.

You will recall that this teacher was recommended to the Department by the Honourable Milton F. Gregg, V.C., C.B.E., Minister of Veterans Affairs.

We are anticipating the School Inspector's reports on both these teachers in the near future.
(b) In Day Schools.

Brother F. Leach, Grade 2 Welfare Teacher, Bloodvein School, Clandeboye Agency, Manitoba; two years of provincial school experience; twenty-eight years in Indian schools.

In recommending Brother Leach, Mr. Indian Superintendent Olson reported as follows on December 23, 1947:

"To us in this office the request merits every consideration. Brother Leach has 28 years' teaching experience in Indian schools and three years in Provincial Schools. His work as school teacher is of high standard and his handling of Indian children is outstandingly effective and desirable.

"Regarding welfare work, he has been our medical dispenser for years. He looks after all first aid and medical work. He visits the sick and has handled numerous maternity cases. He completely supervises our housing improvement program, bridge building, etc. In fact, Brother Leach is an excellent example of value of leadership and proper supervision given by one man. He is largely responsible for the welfare of the entire band.

"On the basis of sheer merit I have no hesitation in recommending your favorable consideration of this request."

A further report on February 11, 1948, stated:

"It is my desire to support this application for reclassification by saying that on no reserve in this agency is there being given such significant leadership to the Indian people as is the case with Brother Leach. His teaching work is very effective; his welfare activities among his people embrace all activities, such as health, dispensing drugs, supervising housing improvement, road and bridge building, gardening and canning fruits and vegetables. His cooperation with this office in our varied efforts leaves nothing to be desired.

"Your favorable consideration of this request is most sincerely recommended."
Mrs. L. E. Culton, Grade 2 Welfare Teacher, Homalco School, B.C.; Second Class Certificate; 15 years' experience in Provincial Schools; 7 years' experience in Indian Schools.

This is another isolated school and the teacher is the sole Departmental representative. Mr. Indian Superintendent Taylor has commented on the good work being done by her under isolated and difficult conditions. She was also recommended for this position by Inspector Davey and the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia. In his report of April 10, 1947, Mr. Davey stated:

"The register indicates that there has been a considerable improvement in this respect.

"Mrs. Culton has a very definite personality and is quite outspoken. This might not be accepted in some places but seems to be fairly effective here.

"This teacher is making an effort to develop a fluent use of English by her pupils and seems to be achieving good results in this respect. Reading and number work are fair. The exercise books of the class are neat and carefully supervised. The writing of the class is satisfactory."

Mr. William J. Brownlee, Grade One Welfare Teacher, Carmacks School, Yukon; Teaching Permit; two years' teaching experience in Yukon.

In recommending Mr. Brownlee for classification as a welfare teacher, Mr. Indian Superintendent Meek, on January 6, 1948, stated:

"Reasons for this recommendation are: Due to the isolated position of Carmacks, to the fact that Mr. Brownlee is the only Government employee there with the exception of the telegraph operator, and that by virtue of his position many requests from other Government agencies are made to him. Also due to the co-operation he has given this office to date, and his very conscientious manner in carrying out a specific request.

In commenting on the Indians at Carmacks, Mr. Meek said:
"There are more Indians on indigent relief at Carmacks than at any other point in the Yukon; the natives there have a notorious name for making home-brew with amazing regularity.

"From what I have seen of the Carmacks Indians, anyone living amongst them and endeavoring to raise their standard of living has a heart-breaking task and is entitled to the full consideration of the Branch."

Miss L. R. Nelson, Grade 2 Welfare Teacher, White Bear School, Saskatchewan; Second Class Certificate; 7 years' experience provincial schools; 20 years' experience in Indian schools (mostly in residential schools).

We have been very disappointed in the reports on Miss Nelson's work at this school. She had returned to our service in September, following a year spent in the United States, during which time she took a rural welfare course at the Scarrett College Rural Centre, Tennessee, and observed at some of the United States Indian Services large schools.

Her previous experience has been with smaller classes and with a male principal. It seems evident she cannot handle 33 children in a one-room school. Her discipline is poor and there is a strong antagonistic spirit in the school. When this was reported by the Provincial School Inspector we immediately wrote to Mr. Ostreander and he has recommended her replacement. He is to see the Superintendent of Education concerning this teacher tomorrow.

Miss M. E. O'Connor, Grade 3 Welfare Teacher, Sliammon School, British Columbia; First Class Certificate, 22 years' experience.

Miss O'Connor has just transferred to this school since the fire at Coqualeetza Hospital, where she taught formerly. In his last year's report on her work, Inspector Davey commented:

"Miss O'Connor has a very pleasant personality and secures a good response from her pupils. Her work is well prepared and carefully organized. Miss O'Connor is thorough in her instructions and in her supervision of the pupils' work."
Miss O'Connor is keenly interested in welfare work and is taking an extra-mural course in Sociology from the University of Washington in Seattle.

L. Allard, Grade One Welfare Teacher, Fort Rae School, N.W.T. Manitoba Permit teacher, two years' provincial experience.

He is really pioneering in this new school being operated in a fur trading post purchased by the Department. The school opened in April, 1943, and Inspector McKinnon was fortunately in the Territories and was able to help Mr. Allard to begin the classroom work.

Dr. Mulvihill reported on the Fort Rae Indians as follows:

"They are the most primitive in the Agency. They have absolutely no conception of the state of affairs except in their own small area. Very few have any education, very few speak English."

We hope to have Mr. Allard's sister, a teacher now at the University of Manitoba, join him next summer, when the pupilage at this school will rise to the 80's.

In general, we have tried to secure, for welfare work, the services of teachers who are either qualified for such work or who have had a great many years of Indian school experience and who know and have the confidence of the Indians. It has been very difficult to obtain fully qualified welfare workers, due to the great shortage of such trained personnel. This shortage is so great that welfare agencies are now adopting the services of untrained or partly trained workers and are arranging "in service" education for them.

We have consulted officials of the Canadian Welfare Council and hope to have some of our welfare teachers attend sociology courses next year. There are those who feel that some
of our older teachers with many years of Indian experience and given some professional social service training, could do more welfare work with the Indians than a young trained worker newly graduated from a University School of Social Science. This would be particularly true of isolated reserves where the day school teachers probably know and understand the local problems of the Indians better than any other Branch official.

However, we have required that both the local Indian Superintendent and the Regional Supervisor recommend a day school teacher for a welfare appointment on an isolated reserve. It is felt that personal suitability for such work can best be assessed by the field officials directly concerned with the progress of the particular reserve. We have appointed relatively few welfare teachers as we believe that proper supervision by adequately trained welfare officials is necessary in many cases. When such welfare officials are appointed it is felt that more rapid progress can be made, not only by providing guidance and professional aid to our present welfare teachers, but in conducting special courses for them and for future appointees.

I agree in general with your final comments. On the other hand, I think it should be anything possible to make sure the persons appointed to welfare positions are in fact capable of actually doing welfare work. I am still inclined to agree with your views on the question of the qualifications. From this course-section I am inclined to think that it would be desirable to have a list of the titles in each section to show exactly what duties incumbents in my opinion it would be wise to avoid from these classes, but more suitable. In the case of welfare teachers we must avoid the risk of assuming a competence that has not been demonstrated.

Thunderchild's Christmas

Dear Editor—I would like to tell your readers about our Christmas concert on the Thunderchild Reserve last week. Instead of accepting the charity of the white man and his old clothes, many people wanted their children to have something more—something of them themselves. It makes one feel one is inspiring them to help themselves. The good use they are making of the family allowance money is evident in the health and good clothes of the children.

Thirty-one, bright, smiling healthy Indians, the children all waiting for Santa to come and distribute gifts and treats, the funds for which had been raised by their parents and friends. That was the scene at the Thunderchild School, Turfird, Sask., on Wednesday afternoon, December 22.

First the children sang a program under the direction of the teacher. Then the school was gaily decorated and a pretty Christmas tree stood in one corner. Santa came and gave each child on the Reserve a toy and candy, and each family a bag of treats.

It was especially gratifying to those interested in the welfare of the Indians that this reserve had been able to raise funds for their Christmas dinner. This had been done by having three box socials during the year, all the efforts of W. Wapase. Assisting him were Albert Catagamis, assistant, Mr. and Mrs. Ross, and Mr. Chetagneur, and Mr. and Mrs. Ross.

Mrs. Ross is one of our best welfare teachers and has done a great deal to promote the formation of Homemakers' Clubs both on this reserve and in Saskatchewan.

A LEGEND ABOUT CHRISTMAS

In the little Austrian village of Hallein in 1818, what has come to be known as the universal Christmas carol was sung for the first time. The carol was suggested by the birth of a child in one of the poorest homes in this parish on Christmas Eve. As the pastor, Father Joseph Mohr, was returning from blessing the babe, the words, "Silent Night! Holy Night! All is calm, all is bright......" kept going through his head. Later that night the schoolmaster and organist, Franz Gruber, dropped in to tell the Father that the church organ had broken down; and that if there were to be any music at all at Christmas Mass it would have to be simple, very simple. He read the words which the priest had just written and decided to set them to music.

They were sung for the first time, on Christmas Day, by the school-children with only a guitar to guide them. Carols are now sung by choirs accompanied by orchestras and fine organs all over the world.
A CHRISTMAS MESSAGE

One of the most beautiful and famous Christmas stories is that written by Dr. Henry Van Dyke, entitled "The Other Wise Man". It is the story of a supposed fourth "Wise Man", who following a vision given by God, travelled far from the East to join his fellow pilgrims in their adoration of the Christ Child. However, his progress was constantly slowed down by demands on his sympathy, his nobility, and his sense of human needs; and by people in distress. Not only did he miss seeing the Divine Babe but his gifts and treasure had been given to those in need. He wandered for years in search of the King and finally found Jesus on the way to the Cross, but he also, found there the blessing that comes to those who give their all in service of their fellow-men.

We read, "Now are we the Sons of God"—those who take their places with the "Wise Men", with the "Shepherds", with the "Pure in Heart" and the "Peace Loving"; those who see the Star of Hope, and hear the Angelic Choir sing, "Peace on Earth to Men of Good Will". These are, indeed, "The Sons or Children of God." May we all be among that number at this Christmas season.

We were all thrilled a few weeks ago because of the birth of a Royal Prince. To-day we celebrate with joy the birthday of a greater Prince—the "Prince of Peace"—the "King of Heaven".

May I wish you all—the patients in the Charles Camsell Hospital, the Doctors and Nurses and all the Members of the Staff—a very Merry Christmas and Happy New Year. And again let us say with Tiny Tim, "God bless us every one."

JAMES BAY INDIANS

The Attawapiskat band numbers nearly 600 people who live and hunt in a large section of country reaching to the south shore of Hudson's Bay. These Indians have married to a certain extent with their neighbors to the west, the Ojibways; and have adopted two or three Ojibway families into their band but none of the Cree. Attawapiskat men have taken the status of a different tribe.

Many years ago these Indians had an abundance of food and fur animals in their large hunting grounds but by unwise trapping and hunting the country became almost depleted. The large herds of barren-land caribou used to end their summer immigration in Attawapiskat territory but for some unexplained reason they no longer roam so far south so that a source of meat supply has been lost to these people.

As a result of the loss of food and fur animals this large band has been greatly undernourished for years and they have had to depend to a large extent upon government relief. During the winter they can travel by foot and scatter in families so that it is easier to obtain what food there is. In the summer months travel over the muskeg country is very difficult so they gather at the mouth of the Attawapiskat River where the traders have stores and where the Roman Catholic Mission has a large church. It is during these summer months that living is so difficult. In the fall of the year they obtain large numbers of geese and ducks and by freezing and salting some of these birds, they have some food for part of the winter.

To overcome these difficulties the Hudson's Bay Company and the Indian Affairs Branch have created a beaver sanctuary out of the entire band trapping grounds. Each head of a family unit is paid a small yearly sum of money to count and record on a large map the number of beaver houses on his trapping ground. If his beaver houses are not increasing he is given a pair or more of beaver by the Indian Affairs Branch. These beaver do not cost him anything and he is supplied with food and equipment necessary to place them on his grounds. When the beaver house-count reaches such a number that some of the animals can be trapped and still leave enough to keep a constant level year after year, he is given a quota to kill depending upon the needs of his family.
JAMES BAY INDIANS
(Continued)

In this way the family not only has the meat of the beaver to eat but also the fur to sell, from which they receive money to buy clothing and other food.

This band has had very little schooling and few of them speak English. Some send their children to a residential school 150 miles away at Albany but the children are not left there long enough to receive a fair education. A day-school is being built at Attawapiskat where the children can go to school during the summer. In a few years, perhaps, with better food and better education these poor Indians will have better health.

At the present time their health is very bad. Seldom is it possible to see a fat Attawapiskat Indian, particularly amongst the children. A great many of the babies die during their first year of life. If they survive this first year many more of them die of tuberculosis before they become adults. Indian Health Services realize this bad condition and are trying to improve it. A nursing station is being built and a public health nurse will help the mothers to look after the babies and thus keep so many from dying. The large tuberculosis Sanatorium being built at Moose Factory will look after tuberculosis and the doctors from this hospital will treat the other medical and surgical illnesses of these people.

By the establishment of fur-hunting sanctuaries, schools and sufficient medical care it is hoped that in the next few years the Attawapiskat Indians will become a happy healthy group of people.

MAMA'S CHRISTMAS EVE VISIT TO THE HOSPITAL
(Arranged from MAMA'S BANK ACCOUNT by Kathryn Forbes)

It was Christmas Eve and sadness reigned in the home of our family - an immigrant family shortly over from Norway. Mama had tried everything she knew of to stop Dagmar's earache, but nothing had helped. When Dr. Johnson came he told Mama that Dagmar must be taken to the hospital.

"We must operate at once," said Dr. Johnson.

"Can wait?" Mama asked. "Until my husband comes home from work?"

"No time," the doctor said, "it must be done at once."

"We go!" said Mama.

Because Papa was at work Nels and I went to the hospital with Mama. When we got there two nurses put Dagmar on a high table and started to wheel her down the hall. Mama tried to go along, too.

"She is my little girl," Mama explained.

"Hospital rules," the nurse said firmly. "You must wait here."

Mama obediently let go of Dagmar's hand then, and walked with slow steps to the desk. They gave her papers to sign, but she didn't even try to read them. Her eyes kept looking down the hall.

We had never been in a hospital before. We watched the ladies in white uniforms, we watched the important looking men with little bags hurry in and out of doors; we watched the cleaning women as they took their mops and buckets out of the closet by the elevator.

When Dr. Johnson came hurrying down the hall Mama stood up.

"Dagmar came through it fine," he told us. "She is sleeping now."

Mama smiled and said happily, "I go to see her now."

Dr. Johnson coughed, "Sorry. Against the hospital rules. See her to-morrow night."

"But, she's so LITTLE," Mama said, "when she wakes she will be frightened."

"The nurses will take excellent care of her. Don't worry. You see for the first twenty-four hours patients are allowed no visitors."

Mama did not seem to understand. "I will not make a SOUND."

Dr. Johnson lifted his hat politely and hurried out.

Mama looked bewildered, "Come," she said to Nels and me.

"Come, we go find Dagmar!"

The nurse at the desk tried to explain the rules to Mama.
"Your child will get the best of care, madam," she repeated.

"In fine hospital, FINE," Mama agreed, "I go see Dagmar now?"

"NO visitors for the first twenty-four hours, madam."

"Am NOT visitor," Mama explained patiently, "I am her MAMA."

"AGAINST THE RULES!" The nurse spoke loudly and firmly.

We slowly left the hospital. Mama held my hand firmly as we walked to the street car and never said a word all the way home.

Christine had kept lunch hot for us, but Mama just drank two cups of coffee. She did not take off her hat.

"We must think of some way," she worried, "We must see Dagmar before Christmas Day." We children sat very still and watched Mama.

"They'll let you see Dagmar to-morrow. They said so," said Nels.

"But unless I see her to-day," Mama asked, "how will I know that all is well with her? What can I tell Papa when he comes home?"

She shook her head. "No," said Mama, "TO-DAY I see Dagmar!"

Suddenly she took paper and string out of the kitchen drawer. Carefully she wrapped up Dagmar's little doll in a neat package. We watched her uneasily. We wondered just what Mama was going to do next.

"It will be like this," Mama explained. "I will go past the hospital desk very quickly. If anyone asks where I go, I will just say, 'Delivering packages to Dagmar.'"

When Mama came back later — still carrying the package — we knew that she had been unsuccessful. We knew, too, that she was upset, because she answered us in Norwegian.

"Almost," she said wearily, "almost did I get down the hall!"

Then she tied her apron around her waist, filled the bucket with hot water, and started to scrub the kitchen floor.

"You scrubbed yesterday," Christine reminded her.

"And the floor isn't a speck dirty," I said.

"Comes a time," Mama answered, "when you must get down on knees!"

Mama had scrubbed all but the part near the back door when she stood up suddenly and handed the scrub brush to Christine.

"You finish the floor, Christine. Katrin, you come with me!"

"Come where, Mama?"

"To the hospital," said Mama — her face was serene. "I have thought of a way to see Dagmar sure."

We walked in so quietly that the nurse at the desk did not
even look up. Mama motioned me to sit still in the big chair by the door. While I watched - mouth open in surprise - Mama took off her hat and coat and gave them to me to hold. She tiptoed over to the big closet by the elevator and took out a damp mop. She pushed the mop past the desk and as the nurse looked up, Mama nodded brightly.

"Very dirty floors," Mama said.

"Yes. I'm glad they've finally decided to clean them," the nurse answered. She looked at Mama curiously, "Aren't you working late?"

Mama just pushed more vigorously, each swipe of the mop taking her farther and farther down the hall. I watched until she was out of sight and the nurse had turned back to the desk. Then I saw that I held Mama's hat so tightly that one side was all bent up.

After a long time Mama came back. Her eyes were shining.

Mama placed the mop neatly back in the clothes closet, put on her hat and coat and took my hand. As we left, Mama bowed politely to the nurse and said, "Thank you, thank you, much."

Outside Mama told me, "Dagmar is fine. No fever. I felt her forehead."

"You SAW her, Mama?" I asked in amazement.

"Of course. She wakened while I was with her. I told her about the hospital rules, she will not expect us till Christmas."

"You won't try to see her again," I asked, "before then?"

"Why," Mama said, "that would be against the rules. Besides, I have seen for myself that all goes well with her. Papa will not worry now. And we can all have a Merry Christmas to-morrow!"

I swallowed hard.

"It's a FINE hospital," said Mama, "a much FINE hospital."

Then she clicked her tongue disapprovingly. "But SUCH floors! SUCH floors I never did see! A mop is no good. Floors should always be scrubbed with a brush! Next time I use a BRUSH!"

ROB RABBIT'S CHRISTMAS PRESENT

"Wherever is that son of mine?" cried Mrs. Jack Rabbit, one late autumn morning. "Rob! Oh, Rob!"

No answer came.

"Father, have you seen Rob this morning?" she asked Mr. Rabbit, who was smoking his briar-pipe after a hearty breakfast.

"No, Molly, I haven't seen him, but I think I know where to find him." And taking up his cane, Mr. Rabbit set off at a hop across the fields.

He headed straight for Farmer Hill's garden, for he knew there were still some juicy, tender plants in one corner of it, and Rob was very fond of greens. Sure enough, Mr. Rabbit had no sooner stepped into the garden than he beheld Rob eating his fill of green leaves.

"Rob!"

Rob jumped fully three feet into the air, and came down facing Mr. Rabbit. His ears stood straight up in terror and his eyes seemed ready to pop out of his head, for when Mr. Rabbit used his gruffest tone, he sounded remarkably like Farmer Hill's hound—at least to guilty Rob. Then his ears drooped in shame on seeing his father. Mr. Rabbit caught him by one of those long ears.

"Your mother is looking for you, young man," said Mr. Rabbit sternly. "Never yet have I seen you around when there is work to be done."

Which was all very true, for Rob hated work as much as bears love honey, and he could smell it a mile off. When he scented an errand, he always got a few miles away from it as soon as he could!

But almost overnight, Rob changed! He became a different rabbit. No longer did he droop his ears and sulk when there was work to do. He simply waded into it, and when he had finished, asked for more! No longer did he waste time chasing his cottonball of a tail; he ran errands willingly; he gathered twigs and bark and young shoots for every meal, without reserving the tenderest and sweetest for himself as he had been wont to do. He obeyed his father and mother at once, and even minded Baby Bun and kept him from wandering off and losing himself. All in all, Rob underwent such a complete and sudden change that Mrs. Rabbit seriously considered taking him to Dr. Hare. Mr. Rabbit, however, merely twitched his whiskers and made the remark that Rob's nature would assert itself in a day or two.

But it didn't. Rob went right on being as good as gold, and as courteous and helpful as the Golden Rule advises us to be. Mr. Rabbit developed a great pride in his son and declared him to be a tuft off the old fur.

Then one day Mrs. Rabbit found Rob looking through the catalogue, and all at once a great light dawned on her. She looked at the calendar and then winked at the cuckoo clock. It was mid-December, and here was Rob with his nose in the catalogue. It took Mrs. Rabbit no time to multiply two by two and get the right answer, for, as you know, rabbits are good multipliers.

"Rob," she called, "run down to the meadow and bring me some bark for supper."

"Yes, Mom," said Rob, and hopped away, leaving the catalogue open on the table, just as Mrs. Rabbit had expected he would.

She went over and looked through the pages that Rob had been finding so interesting.

"So this is what he wants!" she exclaimed. "Well, he shall have it, for he certainly has been a good boy."
That night she told Mr. Rabbit what she had found out, and he agreed that Rob was a deserving little rabbit. They quite overlooked all his lazy naughty tricks. (Parents are like that, which is very lucky for children!)

And so it happened that on Christmas Eve, while Rob lay fast asleep, a shadowy figure crept in softly and filled his sock, which hung by the fireplace. Then it picked up the other sock, which lay on the floor, and crammed it full, too. (Santa attends to two socks only if children have been extra SPECIALLY good.)

Rob awoke early the next morning and looked at his sock. He rubbed his eyes with both paws and looked again. There were certainly TWO socks hanging up and both filled to bursting. Rob gave one happy squeak and jumped for them.

"Mom! Pop!" he cried. "Santa has filled BOTH my socks!"

And he at once began to empty them.

One was crammed full of peppermint sticks, chocolate cucumber bars and onion gumdrops. The other sock held a lovely white fur coat.

"Oh! Oh! Oh! Just what I wanted!" cried Rob. "My old brown coat is getting so patchy!"

"Indeed it is!" said Mrs. Rabbit, "and it's time you had a white coat, anyway, for there is a snowstorm coming up. As long as the ground was bare, your old brown coat was good enough, and much safer. But when snow covers the ground, you need a white one."

So Rob put on his fur coat, and he was the happiest bunny in Bunnydom!

— Myrtle Larsen

On Christmas Eve in the cold Northland
A crowded family in an igloo
Dared not stir or go to sleep
But poured forth only prayers,
For a mighty blizzard might sweep
To-night; their village and dogs and friends
Could hover over in a mountain of snow.
Then a little girl with a friendly smile
Cuddled close to her father's side;

As well as in the big, blue sky?"

THE SNOWMAN'S RESOLUTION

Oh, the snowman's hat was crooked — And his nose was out of place — And several of his whiskers — Had fallen from his face.

But the snowman didn't notice — For he was trying to think — Of a New Year's resolution — That wouldn't melt or shrink.

He thought and planned and pondered — With his little snow-ball head — Till his eyes began to glisten — And his toes began to spread.

And at last he said, "I've got it — I'll make a firm resolve — That no matter what the weather — My smile will not dissolve."

Now the snowman acted wisely — And his resolution won — For his splinter smile was wooden — And it didn't mind the sun!

— Aileen Fisher.

TRIP TO YELLOWKNIFE, FORT RAE AND FORT SMITH, N.W.T.

JULY 14TH. - 17TH., 1948.

For almost two years I had planned to fly North and see the "Territories" — and finally I realized this wish: At the request of Doctor Moore, Director of Indian Health Services, Ottawa, and Mr. Gibson, Deputy Commissioner for the Northwest Territories Administration, I flew to Yellowknife to arrange for an X-ray Survey of the entire community. I also had an opportunity at this time to visit the new hospital there.

While in the vicinity, I visited Fort Rae, and on my return stopped off for a day at Fort Smith.

My air trip via C.P.A. was uneventful as far as Fort McMurray. After leaving McMurray, we ran into disturbed atmospheric conditions and the plane did a good deal of bumping and side-slipping. At Fort Smith, fine sand and clay on the landing strip filled the air on the plane's arrival, and made it rather unpleasant, especially on a warm day, with hordes of bulldog flies and mosquitoes to add to the discomfort. From Smith to Resolution the trip was even rougher, but after leaving Resolution, on crossing Great Slave Lake, the flying became smoother.

Half the way to McMurray the view was the usual green patchwork quilt effect of farmland. After that, bodies of water, small and large, joined by winding rivers surrounded by forests, formed the scenery.

Fort McMurray is a small settlement on the Athabasca River, and Fort Smith is on the Slave River. We more or less followed these two rivers to Great Slave Lake and Fort Resolution.

The town of Yellowknife is on the North shore of Great Slave Lake, and is flanked on the West by Consolidated and Negus Mines, and on the East by the Giant Mine. The airfield at Yellowknife is a large one, used by the services as well as C.P.A. and privately-owned planes.

Doctor Bickford met me at the airport and drove me to the hotel, which is quite new and very modern. The day was really hot; it was quite a surprise to me to find Yellowknife much warmer.
TRIP TO YELLOWKNIFE

(Continued)

than Edmonton! But I no sooner got into my hotel room than a downpour of rain and hail, which lasted over an hour, replaced the heat.

The hospitality of the North was soon evidenced when I was invited to be a guest at their regular monthly Board of Trade dinner. I had the honour of being the guest speaker, my topic being the proposed X-ray Survey. I found the members of the Board of Trade and all the others to whom I spoke, most enthusiastic about the survey, and anxious to give their whole-hearted support toward making it a success.

The following morning I spent seeing the hospital and discussing various problems with Doctor Bickford, the Hospital Manager and the Matron. In the afternoon, I met Doctor Mulvihill of Fort Resolution, who reached Yellowknife by boat from Fort Rae, having gone there to pay Treaty. With Dr. Mulvihill were his charming wife and the Hudson's Bay Factor from Fort Rae.

Later in the afternoon, Dr. Mulvihill and I flew in a small plane to Fort Rae: This small isolated settlement is about 65 miles almost due north from Yellowknife, and a northern arm of Great Slave Lake. The settlement consists of many small huts and tents, placed on a small peninsula of rolling rock, with a Roman Catholic Mission Church and Hospital a few hundred feet inland; also in the same area are the Hudson's Bay Company store and the R.C.M. Police detachment.

We visited at the hospital, which I was amazed to find so clean, roomy and well-equipped for such an outlying area. Unfortunately only about 10 of the 30 available beds were being used. The Sisters and Father Laperriere were most friendly, and after our tour of the hospital served us a delightful cold drink and fruit. After this we visited the Mission, where Father Laperriere showed us some of the local Indian Handicraft Work. I admired some gloves and moccasins, and was presented with a pair of each to bring home.

I saw Michel Thom again, and found he had refractured his arm in a scuffle. When I suggested that he come back with me, he assented at once, and had his belongings ready in about ten minutes! I met the Chief of the Dogrib Band, who was very cordial
TRIP TO YELLOWKNIFE
(Continued)

in his welcome. I promised to take good care of Michel Thom who is his adopted son.

I also saw a woman with a Tuberculous knee whom I advised to come to the hospital, but she refused. She has since come in. (Mrs. Widzie - Ward 1).

Our air trip was most enjoyable as we had perfect weather. We flew directly over Yellowknife on our return, thus seeing the town layout beautifully.

I left Yellowknife for Fort Smith on Friday afternoon. Again it was a grand day. My main cause for wonderment on this visit was the complete daylight for almost 24 hours, with slight dusk for only about two hours — between 12:00 midnight and 2:00 A.M. As a result, it was hard to know just when to go to bed, and it seems that even the inhabitants have the same difficulty for they do keep late hours.

At Fort Smith I visited the hospital, which is very active and doing excellent work. I was more than welcome there, as there had been no doctor for almost three weeks, since Dr. Riddell had left, and no replacement had been made. Sister Chaloux, who incidentally is a most capable person, had carried the full medical responsibility in the absence of a doctor. I saw many of her problem cases, and felt that the visit was worthwhile as I eased her mind a good deal.

The following day, I was again at the hospital until plane time, seeing problem cases for the sister. I left Smith in the mid-afternoon and reached Edmonton about 7:00 P.M. after a reasonably smooth trip, although we skirted a rain storm near McMurray.

Thus ended my very interesting and instructive four-day visit to the Yellowknife area.

H. Meltzer, M.D.,
Medical Director.
The Moose band numbers approximately four hundred. These people have hunting grounds on the south shore of James Bay in country which is well watered by large and small rivers. Their grounds have been encroached upon in past years by some white trappers but since 1946 this is forbidden and the entire area is licensed by the band trappers from the province of Ontario.

Intensive trapping had up to 1942 greatly reduced the fur-bearing animals and consequently brought the band to a low income level. Formerly the area was teeming with beaver and muskrats and there was still an abundance of water and proper food for these animals. So in 1942 the trapping grounds were declared, by band consent and government arrangement, to be a fur sanctuary. Each year a certain number of beaver families were brought in from central Ontario game preserves at government expense, and released under the care of the trappers. By the winter of 1946-47 there were nearly 2000 beaver colonies by actual count and trapping was begun with each head of a family, man or woman, receiving a share proportionate to the family needs.

Trading is done with the Hudson's Bay Company independent local traders; and, as the railroad is available, many men take their furs to towns and cities, such as Cochrane and Timmins. The Indian Affairs Branch also maintains a fur buyer through whom most of the beaver are marketed.

In addition to a good income from fur many of the men are excellent labourers and make extra wages as sectionmen on the railroad and as lumbermen in the many nearby logging camps and lumber mills.

While some of the band gather at the railroad terminal of Moosonee most of them live on Moose Factory Island near the mouth of the Moose River. This settlement is the second oldest Hudson's Bay Company establishment in Canada. It was founded about 1672 and participated in the early wars between the English and the French trading companies. At one time it was a huge establishment and served as the main warehouse center for all of James Bay until the
JAMES BAY INDIANS
(Continued)

coming of the railroad made this unnecessary. Company "servants", as they were called, were brought from Scotland as carpenters, shipwrights, painters, blacksmiths and tradesmen of all kinds. These were necessary for a community to become self-supporting.

To-day some descendants of these Scotsmen still live at Moose Factory and retain their old customs and accents of speech. There has been a good deal of inter-marriage between these settlers and the Indians and they live side by side as friends, neighbors and relatives.

Nearly every one of the band speaks English as well as Cree due to many years of association with the white people. Residential and Day schools have been in operation for a long time. Many of the children stay at the Residential school during the winter but more of them attend Day school from May till October while the families live at Moose Factory. Some also attend the Public school at Moosonee and outnumber the white pupils there.

The Government Doctor and the James Bay Indian Superintendent live at Moose Factory. The Indian Health Services are now building a large modern Sanatorium on the Island which will serve not only the Moose band but all the James Bay area. It will cost over a million dollars and is expected to treat tuberculosis and all other sickness in the same way as the Charles Camsell Hospital is doing.

Tuberculosis at one time was a major problem in the Moose band but with constant X-ray surveys and treatment has been greatly reduced. In the year, 1947, only two active cases were discovered in the band. It is hoped that with the new hospital, more doctors and equipment, that in the years to come the whole Cree tribe living around James Bay can be similarly protected.

The band has a Chief and three Councillors. The Chief, John Fletcher, is a fine old gentleman who has guided his band wisely for over twenty years. He intends to retire this year due to his age. His stature of body is as great as his mind for he is six feet three inches tall. His son, Pat, is even taller. He is a very intelligent young man who may some day also be elected as Chief.
I am sure that the people of this Moose band would be interested in having a letter from some of the western Indians. Correspondence would serve to introduce you and help you to learn and understand the problems of each other. Should some of you here at Camsell or members of your band at home wish to write send your letters to Moosonee Post Office, Ontario. Here are some of the names of the Moose band men: John Fletcher, Pat Fletcher, John Jeffries, Abraham Cheechoo, John Carpenter, Angus Cheechoo, Angus Chum, William Hardisty, Gilbert Faries. Perhaps some of your younger brothers and sisters at school would like to begin a correspondence with Moose band children by writing to the Bishop Harden Memorial Residential School at Moose Factory, Ontario.

Fond du Lac, Saskatchewan,
August 17, 1948.

Dear Doctor Meltzer,

Just thought I would drop you a note before we pulled out of Fond du Lac.

So far the X-ray work is going very well; we have now done over a thousand X-rays. The Indians have been turning out very well. Yesterday we X-rayed 216 out of 245, which I would think is a good average.

The white people and Metis at Chipewyan were not co-operative at all; there were only 200 X-rayed out of a population of 500.

We have all been hit with an intestinal upset the last
READ WHAT OTHERS SAY
(Continued)

few days; although not severe, it was annoying while working.

Young Charles Stone was hit the worst.

Doctor Younger has been kept very busy, pulling teeth, &c.

He certainly is a very keen worker; he has been working day and night on this trip. He sets up his equipment in a corner somewhere and works from 9.00 A.M. to 6.00 P.M.; then after supper he makes calls to the various homes on the reserve.

We have collected a few items from the Indians -- shawls, moccasins and gloves.

I would imagine that we should hit the 1,500 mark in our X-raying, as we still have four more reserves to do. We are leaving for Stoney Rapids at noon and should arrive there to-night and finish our work sometime to-morrow night.

The greatest drawback on this trip is getting our equipment off the boat and up to the place of X-ray: At times we have to haul the things up a steep bank which would be some 200 feet, and then a good 400 feet to the building. By the time we get there we are all ready to lie down for an hour!

These people speak no English at all at this end of the lake, so it is quite difficult to get anything done; although Mr. Stewart, the Indian Agent, speaks Cree and could help us on our first lap of the trip, he is lost among the Chipewyan Indians.

You stated in your letter that it would be best to leave the X-raying of the Indians at Fort Smith and have the X-ray Clinic proceed direct to Yellowknife: I think I will have plenty of time to do them all before Mr. Berg comes up. If I don't, I am afraid they will not be there when he comes back from Yellowknife, because they will be heading back into the bush.

I only intended to write a note, but it looks as if I have written a book, so I will close for now. (Caught three fish last night.)

Best regards,

Don Harkness.
Dear friends at the Camsell Hospital,

Am sending greetings to my many friends at Camsell Hospital. To those of you who are still in bed— or are resting for "the cure" most of the time, I would like to tell you of some of my travels.

At present I am staying at Banning in Southern California, 89 miles east of Los Angeles where the movie stars work and live.

To the north and south rise high mountains, making a valley east and west. This valley is called the San Gorgonio Pass and looks out to the east and west — unlike the Whitehorse where its valley looks north and south.

Unlike the mountains in Canada — with grey rocks, green grasses and trees — these mountains are of red and yellow powdered lava or red slabs of soft rock easily crushed. No grasses grow — only cactus plants something like those in Alberta — only very tall— much taller than a man! There are many bushes but all are so unlike anything that grows in Canada. Here there are huge palm trees — like those you see in pictures of the land where Jesus was born. There are pepper trees with long green branches and shiny red berries in clusters. The eucalyptus tree gives shade to travellers — for the scorching sun brings the temperature up to 125 degrees F. and over.

Some of the flowers are very pretty — the oleander, hibiscus, bird of Paradise, yucca and many kinds of cactus flowers.

As we drive along the roads we can see, in the valleys, the water being sprayed all the time on the dark-leaved orange trees— the golden balls hanging like decorations on a Christmas tree, only the leaves are real leaves. Then we can see peaches, apricots, almonds, walnuts — each growing on its own kind of tree — and dates on the date palm, and olives on the grey green olive tree.

Just near the town of Banning, east toward the desert, about five miles is the Reservation owned by the Morongo Indians. Each family owns a farm on which they grow alfalfa, olives, oranges, nuts or whatever they wish. They sell their fruit to the town stores. They also have horses, cattle, trucks and cars.
Their houses are built of brick made from local mud—called adobe. The houses are quite open as there is little cold in Southern California. Thirteen above zero is very cold for this part of the country. The worst winter weather here is more like the summer weather in the Yukon.

Drinking water is a big problem—here are no rivers or lakes. Only a little rain falls between December and April. Sometimes a little snow falls in the valleys—but of course there will be snow on the mountain tops from December till April, though not as much as the Yukon.

The Morongo Indians look much the same as our western Canadian Indian people and dress much the same except for winter wear—which is never needed. The women tend the fields and house, shell almonds, pick oranges, peaches, etc., and in their spare time weave beautiful baskets and mats. The men tend their cattle and their farms, and hire themselves out to work for the local people in Banning and on near-by farms—which they call ranches. They are excellent workers and are held in high esteem by the local people. They do not travel around as do the people of the Yukon and the Mackenzie country.

Captain John Morongo gave his name to this group who once belonged to the ancient Cahuillas and Serranos. At one time there were many tribes, but being very war-like, they killed each other or were killed by the scorching heat in the desert, or by grizzly bears, wolves or lions. Lions may still be seen deep in the mountains.

Before these people settled on farms and before there were stores, food was very scarce and the Morongo people in the mountains ate acorns or roasted the stalks of the yucca plant and boiled its flowers. On the desert they ate fruit from the date palm, stalks and flowers of the cactus pine, juniper nuts, chia (a seed used for flour), wild plum, berries of the elder and sumac and flowers of the ocotilla (pronounced ok'-a-ti-ya).

There are many tribes scattered all through these valleys that I have not yet seen. Minnie Hackett, P.H.N.

Dear friends,

Here I am again writing for the Arrow news. I am sorry that I have no wonderful news for you - just the same old story of thanks to the doctors and nurses for the splendid work they are doing amongst us. We are receiving so many kindnesses. We enjoy the car rides. The picnic was a wonderful treat. It was so nice to see our friends from the other wards and have a visit - we have been lonesome for them since. It is nice to learn that some of our friends are returning home happy and well. I am getting better each day and hope to be going home some time myself, happy and well. I wish you all a speedy recovery and the best of luck!

WARD IV A

Hello, everybody! There are six of us in this private. We are glad to have Emily Wesley with us - also Bertha Quinn, who is quite a cheerer-upper with her funny sayings. The ward aids are getting tired of us bombarding them with questions about the T.B. cure. "Bad eggs" is what one calls us. WARD IV A (Continued)

"Goody, goody!" said Annie. "SPARE RIBS for supper! I haven't had SPARE RIBS since I came to this hospital many years ago!" (Annie has been in the hospital for five months only.)

WARD IV E

The girls in Ward IV were scattered here and there while their ward was being re-modelled. Victoria Sanscouteau was so disappointed that she was put in Ward I while most of her friends were put in Ward III right ABOVE her. One night we were all trying to get to sleep - but the whispering continued from the far side of the room. Finally Margie said, "Who's talking?". A mysterious voice, from out of the darkness answered, "My stocking!"

When evening lunch came around Marie Back took the BIGGEST apple on the plate, but sad to relate it was HALF bad. "You know," she said to Mildred, "I was a little too greedy. This apple is half bad - but I am so hungry that I will have to eat it!"

One night just after everyone had been moved from Ward IV Annie Cotton went a-visiting as usual. She stopped at the door and called out to Ward IV, "Hello, everybody!" "Hello, everybody," came the answer. Then she looked - the ward was empty! She went back to her bed and sat down in bewilderment. "That's strange," she said, "there isn't a person in that ward but I am sure somebody answered me and said 'Hello, everybody' so clearly!" (I guess the nurses must have forgotten to move Mary Echo.)

MY THOUGHTS TO THE GOOD LORD

Give me good understandings, Lord,
And also things to learn,
Give me a healthy mind, Lord,
With sense to keep it at its best.

Give me healthy deeds, good Lord,
To keep the good and pure in sight,
Which seeing sin, is not weak with fear
But finds a way to set it right.

Give me a mind that's not a bore,
That does not whine nor sigh.
Don't let me worry over much,
About the fussy things, called "I".

Give me a sense of humour, Lord,
The eyes to see a joke,
To get some happiness from life,
And pass it on to other folk.

K. Melinda Twigg.

Ottawa,
January 29, 1943.

To principals and teachers of Indian schools:

Re: Proficiency Badges

As illustrated by Mr. Doucet on various occasions, the proficiency badges will soon be ready and it is our intention to award badges for cooking, sewing, weaving, knitting, housekeeping, gardening, leather work, dairying and poultry raising.

Before making these badges available the Indian Affairs Branch desires the teachers of the various manual skills to make a list of the basic operations which, in their opinion, the pupil should cover for each year of a three-year course in order to entitle the pupil to receive a badge.

These basic operations should be progressive from the easiest to the more difficult. It must be kept in mind that the operations listed must be basic; namely, operations that are absolutely necessary in carrying out the simple duties of a housewife, of a cook etc. There should be about twenty basic operations for each year.

Principals should notify the teachers concerned and forward their lists as soon as possible to the Training Division, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
To principals and teachers of Indian schools:

Re: Chart for Proficiency Badges

You are being forwarded two charts illustrating the proficiency badges about which you were advised in circular letter of January 29, 1943. These charts should be framed and one posted in the boys' side of the building and the other in the girls'.

You will note that these charts indicate the basic operations which pupils must know in order to qualify for a badge.

When a pupil has efficiently covered the first group of basic units a green badge is awarded. When the second group is covered a red badge is awarded. Later you will be advised regarding the badge which will be awarded for covering the third group of basic units.

In the majority of cases it will require one year for a pupil to cover each of the groups of basic units. In some cases a pupil may cover this group in less time than a year, while other pupils will require a longer period than a year.

For reasons that will readily suggest themselves to you, it has been decided not to award any badge to a pupil under twelve years of age. It is true that some of the operations recognized for badges will have been learned before that age is reached, but these operations will not be recognized for badge purposes until the age mentioned.

When a pupil has qualified for a badge a special form is signed by the instructor and the principal and forwarded to this office. The badge will then be sent to the pupil. This badge should be awarded publicly as soon as possible after its reception, either by the Student Council or any similar school organization.

Teachers should keep in mind that the success of any enterprise depends on the enthusiasm shown by the teachers themselves. The Department, therefore, depends upon principals, teachers and instructors to use every possible effort to create interest and enthusiasm among the pupils in the badge system.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

You will note that these charts indicate the basic operations which pupils must know in order to qualify for a badge.

When a pupil has efficiently covered the first group of basic units a green badge is awarded. When the second group is covered a red badge is awarded. Later you will be advised regarding the badge which will be awarded for covering the third group of basic units.

In the majority of cases it will require one year for a pupil to cover each of the groups of basic units. In some cases a pupil may cover this group in less time than a year, while other pupils will require a longer period than a year.

For reasons that will readily suggest themselves to you, it has been decided not to award any badge to a pupil under twelve years of age. It is true that some of the operations recognized for badges will have been learned before that age is reached, but these operations will not be recognized for badge purposes until the age mentioned.

When a pupil has qualified for a badge a special form is signed by the instructor and the principal and forwarded to this office. The badge will then be sent to the pupil. This badge should be awarded publicly as soon as possible after its reception, either by the Student Council or any similar school organization.

Teachers should keep in mind that the success of any enterprise depends on the enthusiasm shown by the teachers themselves. The Department, therefore, depends upon principals, teachers and instructors to use every possible effort to create interest and enthusiasm among the pupils in the badge system.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

GENERAL DIRECTIONS TO USE PROFICIENCY BADGES.

1. These badges are awarded in two colours, Green for the first year and Red for the second. A special badge will be provided at the end of the third year.

2. Proficiency Badges, on the facsimile are numbered. These numbers correspond to the numbers on the "Basic Operations Required to Obtain Proficiency Badges" and the same number is inserted by the teacher on "Student Record of Mastered Basic Operations." These charts are of corresponding colours as follows.

| Badge | Subjects       | Basic Operation Chart | Student Record |
|-------|----------------|------------------------|----------------|
| #1    | Cooking        | Blue                   | Blue           |
| #2    | Woodwork       | White                  | White          |
| #3    | Housekeeping   | White                  | White          |
| #4    | Knitting       | Rose                   | Rose           |
| #5    | Gardening      | Green                  | Green          |
| #6    | Poultry        | Yellow                 | Yellow         |
| #7    | Sewing         | Rose                   | Rose           |
| #8    | Dairying       | Yellow                 | Yellow         |
| #9    | Metalwork      | Russet                 | Russet         |
| #10   | Weaving        | (Rosette follow)       | Rose           |
| #11   | Leatherwork    | Goldenrod              | Goldenrod      |

3. The Badges are awarded by the "Indian Affairs Branch." A special requisition must be made on a card form provided by the Department.

4. A pupil may be awarded any number of badges provided he has mastered the basic operations required for each badge and provided he has attained the age of 12 years.

YOU HAVE RECEIVED:

1. A facsimile of the eleven badges available.
2. "Basic Operations Required to obtain Proficiency Badges."
3. Student Record of Mastered Basic Operations.
4. Card# requisitions for Badges.
5. Instructions for the use of the Proficiency Badge System.

PROCEDURE:

1. Frame the facsimile of the badges and hang one in the boys' quarters and one in the girls' quarters.
2. Post the "Basic Operations Required to obtain Proficiency Badges" near the Facsimile.
3. Post the "Student Record of Mastered Basic Operations" in a place readily accessible to the students, preferably the class room. Each pupil should rule a sheet for his own record. (See student record for woodwork) At a definite period, once or twice a week, each pupil calls out his standing: Badge No., Basic Operation No., and standing A, B or C. The teacher posts these on the class Student record. The teacher should take advantage of this period for a general discussion.
5. Teachers should prepare a reading list and keep a record of each pupil's reading. This may advantageously be done by the pupils themselves. (See Reading Record Sheet for Woodwork). A definite discussion period on the reading should be provided.

The eleven badges so far provided do not comprise all the training that may be given to Indian children. Badges may be added from time to time. Commentaries and suggestions from the Principals and Teachers will be appreciated.

Reverend Father:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, I have carefully taken note of the contents.

I know that this system appears somewhat complicated but in reality, very simple. I am sorry that I have been unable to visit the B.C. schools as yet, but I hope in a future, not too remote, to be able to do so. My idea in this form of manual education is to motivate the child's endeavors so that he may earn a badge if he so desires. There are probably a number of pupils in your school that are deserving of a badge. The award of a badge I believe should greatly encourage them. Read the instructions sent with the coloured sheets (basic operations). You will notice what is required to qualify for these badges. I will be only too pleased to send badges to pupils who have qualified for them.

Education today needs a great deal of change. This goes for all types of schools. The whole child must be educated morally, physically, intellectually, and religiously. There must be more cooperation between the school and the home. If these principles are not carried out it is to be feared that more hardships must still fall upon society. These are a few principles that should
be studied by the teachers. I believe the activity program of study is the only program that will rectify some of the evils of society. In due course I will be sending books which the teachers should read, take notes and discuss among themselves. Let us work together in the adaptation of the activity mode of education.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Vincent:

The local Sister Superior has asked me to apply to you for badges #1 (Cooking) for Ann Mary White and Anastasia Francis. I told her that I believed these badges were awarded only at the end of the School year. She has asked me to write, nevertheless, and to ask for the badges as she believes these girls getting them will prove an incentive to others. The record shows that these girls have "a" for the various operations, while Ann Mary's last four superior to the others. This is Ann Mary's last year and ought to be possible (especially with her) to earn encouragement (suggested) for her to complete the five years' operations. This girl is the best of our plains organ players and accompanies at high Masses. She has made her future quite promising. Her parents at least, he has given up drinking and has paid up his debts. The granting of a badge to his eldest daughter may help him overcome a little his eldest daughter's vice (alcoholism). We need the new standard (for excellence).

I hope you will be doing fairly well. We hope...
had a case of chicken pox here for over 2 weeks, but, so far, we have managed to stop it from spreading. Quite a few Indians were already ill with the flu, so far, we have escaped it.

The sending of girls, as promised, to the Coqualeetza hospital has proved disastrous. Mr. Inspector Coleman, who is to meet the Indians here on Monday, will likely get an earful. I knew of three cases of very severe flu. I suggested what might occur & pointed out what might have prevented all this trouble.

Barre is leaving fairly close to his time you traced, but he is a little old to learn new tricks. Quite a few of the boys are rather good, in his opinion, and he isn't entirely mistaken.

I'm sorry that Mr. Campbell made it impossible for me to see you in Ottawa. However, he has likely saved me from mastoiditis. I'm still a bit deaf & therefore, am tempted to apply to the Indian Dept. for the position of "Hearer or Complaints."

With kind personal regards,

P.S. If you know where heat packs can be obtained, please let me know.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

It would almost seem as if we had done nothing about the very interesting looking Charts which arrived just before school closed in June, but such is not the case. I think the idea is a good one, but if I might make some comments I don't think the 'requirements' are very well graded, and some not very practical. There is much repetition and even the operations which are carried on in all schools have certain things listed which do not apply.

Most of our senior girls can do many things listed under all three jerseys, but they become discouraged when they see so many things which neither time nor place make possible.

For instance, who ever has heard of a cremaise? Bannock is foreign to our girls; we have no ice box, and don't need one, and few men wear home made suits and overcoats these days.

The most that any school has time to do in knitting, sewing, cooking or housekeeping is to learn the general mechanics of the project and hope the student will apply it in detail himself.

I would suggest that each school send to the Department for approval a 'Basic Operations' based on those you sent out but able to be applied to that particular school. Some of the requirements only come to perfection after years of experience.

I would very much like to know what has been the reaction from other schools regarding this project.

Please may I have a sample badge also a Reading Record Sheet for wood work? These were not included in my packet.

Many thanks, Yours truly,

Povesh Frenzel,
Povesh.

Your letter of the 13th ultimo has been referred to me for an answer. I have waited some time before making a reply to this letter because I wanted to see whether or not I could have these brooches special badges manufactured at this time. Having received a positive reply I wish to give you the following details:

In order to qualify for this silver brooch for knitting the pupil must have covered the basic operations for knitting and housekeeping and any two of the following: poultry, gardening, sewing and cooking. The pupil however, has excelled in knitting and knitting is the badge she wishes to obtain. If she has been unable to perform one or the other operations because of impossible conditions, this would not disqualify her. This we leave to the judgement of the instructor and Principal.

I wish to say for your information that the housekeeper's medal or special badge which would comprise housekeeping and cooking and any two of the following: knitting, poultry, gardening and sewing. The seamstress special badge which would comprise sewing, housekeeping and any two of the following: knitting, gardening, poultry, cooking. The cook's special badge which would comprise cooking, housekeeping, and any two of the following: poultry, gardening, dairying and sewing. There are also such badges for the boys.
in gardening, metalwork, poultry, carpentry and leatherwork.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Supt' of Welfare & Training,
Dept' of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

As the end of the scholar year draws near, I think it is great time,-if I am not already too late,-to ask for some Proficiency Badges for the children who deserve them.

Since it was my first year as Principal of a school, I confess that there was so much to do,-and to learn,-that I was unable to give all the attention required to take full advantage of the new Proficiency Badge System. Something has been achieved though and according to the Students Records there would be about 60 Badges to be distributed before the children go home for their holidays. Most of those badges are for the girls: knitting, sewing, cooking, housekeeping; a few for the boys in woodwork.

Among the papers supplied for the Instructor in woodwork a sheet entitled "Class Monthly Report" was recently brought to my attention. There is a note on the back of it that had completely escaped me; it says: "This Report is to be sent to the Department of Mines and Resources Training Division, at the end of each teaching month". If that is absolutely required, then I presume that we are out of luck to get any badges in woodwork this year; but if it is not mentioned on the "General Directions to use Proficiency Badges", I am wondering if they are, those monthly reports, strictly required. Please let me know, as well as if any similar reports should have been filled for the Department in the other branches of manual Training.

If the badges are to be awarded, shall I need in each case to send a badge requisition card, of which I have but one sample? In that case I would ask you to have sent to me about 60 of those cards. Or may be, since there are many at a time, a list of the children and the details of their proficiencies, would do? In either case, please let me know soon how to proceed, so that I may have the badges before the end of the year or before the middle of June at the latest,...and we have mail only once a week.

A few more questions I would like to ask you about those badges:
1/- Can a child be awarded in the same branch of training medals for two years of proficiency during the same scholar year?
2/-In the training for dairying, some boys would be qualified for badges except that since we have no goats here we have been unable to answer the first questions for the first year of training in dairying. Shall those badges never be awarded unless we have goats? And who should provide us with goats then?

3/-Are there any manuals made or being made for the better understanding and easier explication of all the operations for the various trainings, proceeding as per the basic operations charts provided?

Assuring you that I shall always try to the best of my ability to co-operate in your plans for the better education of our Indian children,

I am,

Very respectfully yours,

L. Poirier, O.M.I.
Principal.

Camperville, Man.

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I. Principal, Guy Indian Residential School, Sturgeon Landing, Sask.

Enclosed you will find sixty badge requisition cards which you requested in your letter of the 13th instant. I realize that the work that a new Principal encounters is very great indeed and that for some time many details may escape his observation. This however, should not disqualify the pupils from receiving Proficiency badges provided that they have mastered the Basic Operations required or would like to receive a Monthly Report of these Basic Operations which include Manual Training for girls as well as for boys because it creates more interest for the pupils as they know that there monthly record is sent to Ottawa. These reports are acknowledged by this office. It is impossible for me to send out these badges without knowing the names of the pupils, as they are addressed to each individual pupil, in care of the Principal. You will complete these cards and return them to this office at your earliest convenience and Proficiency Badges will be immediately issued to the pupils deserving them.

A child may be awarded as many badges as he deserves provided he masters the basic operations required for those badges. In other words the training that we have in mind is to induce each child to become as skillful as possible in the operations that are so necessary in later life. I believe that this answers your first question.

(Over)
In answer to the second question with reference to goats; goats or cows answer the purpose. If they can take care of a cow, this would fulfill the requirements. If you are interested in goats, get in touch with your Indian Agent, who will in turn notify our Welfare Branch who will give him directions on the best method of procuring goats.

In reply to your third question we are sending out reference books on the various subjects from year to year. You will receive some of these books in the near future.

I am gratified at the interest that you are taking in this work. If there is anything else I can do, do not fail to write.

A. J. Doucet,
Training Division.

To principals and teachers of Indian schools:

Re: Chart for Proficiency Badges

You are being forwarded two charts illustrating the proficiency badges about which you were advised in circular letter of January 29, 1943. These charts should be framed and one posted in the boys' side of the building and the other in the girls'.

You will note that these charts indicate the basic operations which pupils must know in order to qualify for a badge.

When a pupil has efficiently covered the first group of basic units a green badge is awarded. When the second group is covered a red badge is awarded. Later you will be advised regarding the badge which will be awarded for covering the third group of basic units.

In the majority of cases it will require one year for a pupil to cover each of the groups of basic units. In some cases a pupil may cover this group in less time than a year, while other pupils will require a longer period than a year.

For reasons that will readily suggest themselves to you, it has been decided not to award any badge to a pupil under twelve years of age. It is true that some of the operations recognized for badges will have been learned before that age is reached, but these operations will not be recognized for badge purposes until the age mentioned.

When a pupil has qualified for a badge a special form is signed by the instructor and the principal and forwarded to this office. The badge will then be sent to the pupil. This badge should be awarded publicly as soon as possible after its reception, either by the Student Council or any similar school organization.

Teachers should keep in mind that the success of any enterprise depends on the enthusiasm shown by the teachers themselves. The Department, therefore, depends upon principals, teachers and instructors to use every possible effort to create interest and enthusiasm among the pupils in the badge system.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
To principals and teachers of Indian schools:

Re: Proficiency Badges

As illustrated by Mr. Doucet on various occasions, the proficiency badges will soon be ready and it is our intention to award badges for cooking, sewing, weaving, knitting, housekeeping, gardening, leather work, dairying and poultry raising.

Before making these badges available the Indian Affairs Branch desires the teachers of the various manual skills to make a list of the basic operations which, in their opinion, the pupil should cover for each year of a three-year course in order to entitle the pupil to receive a badge.

These basic operations should be progressive from the easiest to the more difficult. It must be kept in mind that the operations listed must be basic; namely, operations that are absolutely necessary in carrying out the simple duties of a housewife, of a cook etc. There should be about twenty basic operations for each year.

Principals should notify the teachers concerned and forward their lists as soon as possible to the Training Division, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

R.A. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

PROCEDURE:

1. Frame the facsimile of the badges and hang one in the boys' quarters and one in the girls' quarters.
2. Post the "Basic Operations Required to Obtain Proficiency Badges" near the facsimile.
3. Post the "Student Record of Mastered Basic Operations" in a place readily accessible to the students, preferably the classroom. Each pupil should rule a sheet for his own record. (See "Student Record Sheet" for woodwork.) At a definite period, once or twice a week, each pupil calls out his standing: Badge No., Basic Operation No. and standing A, B or C. The teacher posts these on the class student record. The teacher should take advantage of this period for a general discussion.

The eleven badges so far provided do not comprise all the training that may be given to Indian children. Badges may be added from time to time. Commentaries and suggestions from the principals and teachers will be appreciated.

At the opening of the new academic year I wish to again direct your attention to circular letters of January 29, February 24 and May 8, 1943, with reference to the awarding of badges to deserving pupils. The Department would appreciate having a wider use made of these badges.

Since the badge system was instituted 1933 badges have been issued to students of Indian residential and day schools and a review of the names of those to whom badges have been awarded indicates that the greater number have been given to girls. This means that the Department's programme for vocational training for girls has received more attention than the courses suggested for boys.

It is realized that at the present time there is considerable difficulty in securing qualified teachers for vocational work, but at the same time the Department feels that a more definite interest should be taken in the development of our programme for boys.

I, therefore, suggest that at the opening of the coming academic year the principal should arrange a meeting of the teachers in his school and direct their attention to the circular letters mentioned above.

At this time I would like to refer to instructions previously given to the effect that badges should be awarded publicly as soon as possible after their receipt, either by the student council or any similar school organization.

If there is any further information that you require regarding either our vocational programme or the badge system, I would appreciate hearing from you.
