Dear Mr. James:

Thank you for your letter of Nov. 14th which has just come. As you are likely aware, the Indians generally take their father's Christian name as their family name & the pupils are generally known by that name in school & at home. On the Quarterly Returns, I generally give the real family name. That will partly explain my giving them the wrong names as I simply copied the lists given me by the Teachers.

Coy Nicholas is #265 Coy N. Eugene.
Mary Madeleine Johnson is #304 Mary M. Miller.
#345, Evelyn Alice is sometimes called Eva Alice.

As for those under age:
#282, Rudy Paul, was 11 in March (Report erroneous—by his own account)—He is now 12.
#0293, Susan Kroger, is still 11 but will be 12 in January.
#0310—Alice Jack was 12 in October.

Appears to have mentioned one ex-pupil.
Killed in Action (Sicily). Another has been killed recently, - one who was considered his best young man (20 yrs old) on the Reserve. As most local Indians get their mail here, I noticed that four overseas officers wrote to the boys' fathers. No mail has been good over there too. Another pupil, twice wounded, expected to be back for Christmas with a useless leg.

We have just had the visit of another former pupil who is in the U.S. Army and who was in Burma & India.

Our Doctor, who knows his business & therefore stays within his limits, reported that one girl required glasses and two others needed the attention of an optometrist. There is no oculist in Crookwood - the local optometrist found that his two had cataracts that she urgently needed an immediate operation. One all three to Lethbridge. There, a good oculist found no cataracts but T.B or Trachoma @ ears. He could do nothing for them two but give one glasses - as our M.D. has said, the 3rd girl needed glasses also.

With every best wish for the New Year.

Yours sincerely,

G. Farley Ouellet

Dear Sir,

Just a few days ago I sent you our first monthly report on manual training. It includes in fact four months; but from now on we shall try to be more punctual about those monthly reports.

I should have included with it the corrections we had begged to make to some items asked for the third year of knitting. In yours of November 13, you had approved of us submitting other questions or tests more practical here. So here are the first eight numbers for the third year training for knitting, as we would like to have them:

1. To choose rags for braided door mat.
2. To dye the rags.
3. To braid the rags.
4. To sew the braided rags.
5. To knit a toque.
6. To crochet a tan.
7. To knit a scarf.
8. To use a garter stitch.

So with your permission, if there is no objection found, our third year course of knitting will consist of the above items for the first eight numbers instead of the ones proposed in the official course as first published.

For all the branches of practical training we trust that whatever publications the Department may provide us with in order to facilitate our work, it will make available to us without our having to enquire often if anything new has been published on the matter. What you have sent already is so interesting, as regards woodwork and metalwork, that we look eagerly forward to something similar in all the other branches of manual training.

Yours very truly,

L. Foirier, O.M.I.,

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I. Principal, Guy Indian Residential School, Sturgeon Landing, Saskatchewan.

I have received your letter of the 13th instant, in which you suggest changes for the eight first numbers of the third year in knitting.

As mentioned before, this outline is meant to be very flexible so that it may be adapted in any locality. The changes which you suggest namely:

1. To choose rags for braided door mat.
2. To dye the rags
3. To braid the rags
4. To sew the braided rags
5. To knit a toque
6. To crochet a tam
7. To knit a scarf
8. To use a garter stitch.

are approved with the exception of number six. This number six reads "To keep cost accounts". This, I believe is very important as the correlative between arithmetic and manual training. I wish, therefore, that you would retain this number six possibly, in place of either number six, seven or eight which you suggest.

I have taken note of the contents of the last paragraph of your letter and will keep you on the mailing list for any new outlines which may be ready from time to time.

A.J. Doucet.

A couple of Indian parents, to whom I explained
after dinner the basis she learned about poultry,
seemed greatly to appreciate the fact that I was
teaching poultry raising. I showed our pictures of

heard that looked like the picture but that he
had heard that looked like "only lies." My poor pupils spotted
him with roses & killed & burned his affected
birds. In order to teach him better, I am taking

my papers have rated & my essay on poultry
diseases seems to have impressed the instructor.
One or two "White" visitors thought the idea of
teaching poultry raising good.

fore.

Dear Sir,

In reference to the third year proficiency badges, may I ask if they are all cancelled by the new graduation brooches?

On the "Circular re Special Badges" I read: "The Student must have satisfactorily completed the First, Second and Third year course in four subjects...." But as the pupil completes one or several of the third year courses, wouldn't it be possible to let him or her receive the third year badge, and then, when the pupil has perfected or is to perfect the fourth course required, be awarded the Special Badge coming with the graduation?

Especially in the case where a pupil has finished a few of the third year courses, or even four, but is not to be discharged yet, he would be encouraged in his work by those third year badges and would be eager to come back to receive the Silver Brooch at the time he is discharged. Having a few pupils in this case this year, I am confident that you may do something to keep their enthusiasm, as your proficiency system so well does in other cases. One girl here for instance has completed last year the first and second year course in four matters; this year she has completed the third year courses in the same matters, but I can not apply for the Silver Brooch for her since she has one more year to go to school: would it not be possible in such a case to award third year ordinary badges? and next year she would receive the Silver Brooch?

Ottawa, June 6th, 1945.

Rev. J. Angin, O.M.I., Principal, Thunderchild Indian Residential School, Delmas, Saskatchewan.

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo and I have taken careful notice of the remarks therein.

To obtain the housekeeper's brooch, the pupil is required to have covered the three years in housekeeping and the three years in cooking. You will notice, if you go over the basic operations in housekeeping for the three years that there are few operations that a girl from twelve to sixteen years of age does not actually have to do while working around the school. There should then be no difficulty in qualifying for this brooch, if the proper integration between the classroom subjects and the manual training subjects exists.

The seamstress's brooch requires housekeeping also. The knitter's brooch also requires housekeeping. I wish to summarize this for your information. We will take the seamstress's brooch:

A. Compulsory subjects:
   1. Sewing
   2. Housekeeping

B. Optional subjects:
   Any two of the following:
   1. Knitting
   2. Gardening
   3. Poultry
   4. Cooking
   5. Dairying
To qualify for this brooch the pupil will excel in sewing, that is, she will satisfactorily cover the first, second and the third year basic operations in sewing. Moreover, this pupil selects sewing because she prefers it and wishes special credit for it. As mentioned above she will, I may say unwittingly, qualify for housekeeping. Therefore, the difficulties which are met are more apparent than real.

I wish to draw to your attention, the fact that these brooches are not a diploma for one subject but as in the case of the seamstress's brooch, represents a course comprising four subjects. It may be described as an award for a special division of domestic science. In reality, it is a domestic science diploma representing extra skill in some special subject.

Should there be any other questions in regard to this work, I will be pleased to answer them.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

This is in answer to your letter of the
13th instant, re Manual Training Monthly Reports.
The numbers on the Student Record Sheet must correspond
with the number on the Basic Operation. In other words,
the Student Record Sheet is a record of the Basic Operations
covered by that student. Hence, a Monthly Report is a
copy of the Student Record Sheet. Consequently, these three
numbers must correspond. For example: if the Student has
learned the basic operation seven from the basic operations,
then, in the column seven of the Student Record Sheet is
inscribed the grade (A, B, or C). Let us suppose the
grade A in this case. In copying for the Monthly Report,
the figure on the column (which in this case is seven) will
be written and next to it the grade (7A).

The knitting machine was forwarded as soon as
received to the Company near Montreal, who have been
instructed to return it to you as soon as it is repaired.
If you should not receive it within a reasonable time,
please let me know and I will check this matter.

AJ. Doucet,

Dear Miss Whelan:

In answer to your letter of the 8th instant I would like to know what kind of books you refer? Are they library books or text books?

As regards text books it must be kept well in mind that they are but tools in the teacher's hands. I prefer direct, energetic teaching from the black boards. The text book is then used as reference under the guidance of the teacher.

If you refer to library books I might say that the Department is endeavouring to build a simple library for the pupils. In order to do this effectively send the inventory of the books which you have. Be sure to classify them according to grade.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

My report was sent in to the Local Indian Office Brantford, along with a list of the library books, about two months ago. However, these I am mailing direct to you.

Regarding library books, No. 10 SS is badly in need of same, and we shall be glad to receive any, particularly for junior grades. The children in this section are noticeably backward in English. Teachers should be made responsible in keeping the library books intact. The children have evidently been allowed to carry them home and have not returned them, and I have been unable to get trace of them.

This school has received books in the past along with the other schools, but they have disappeared.

Yours Truly,

Mrs. Wilma Jamieson

Mr. R.A. Hoy,

Dept. of Mines & Resources.

Dear Sir,

During the past six years which I have taught at Shawanaga Indian Day School, I have collected one hundred and fifty discarded library books from Barry Gold Library. Although these books are old, the children are enjoying reading them and we would appreciate receiving a few new ones.

A suggestion:

Chief Inspector Dr. V.K. Greer, in a recent circular recommended that "The Canadian Geographical Journal" should be in every school library. Address: Canadian Geographical Society, 49 Metcalfe St., Ottawa, Ont.

"Canadian Nature and The School" are also highly recommended by Inspector Scott.

We are already receiving "Canadian Nature and World Affairs" and wish to return thanks.

Yours truly,

Janet McCaig (teacher).

Scotch Settlement School
May 15th, 1915

To Mr. Story,
Dept. of Indian Affairs -

Dear Sir,

I am very glad to hear that you intend to add to our library.

I find that the children of this school read very little. They prefer fiction books, e.g., "Jack's Day" by Dorothy King. She exceptionally good! Large print simple stories. The children can read but the story has to be very simple for them to get any meaning from them. Personally I think no books greater than grade 7 should be sent to the schools in this agency. A few nursery rhyme books with pictures (and a number of National Geographics Second Hand) are very advisable.

My grades run from One to Grade 4. I had some girls in Grade 4 two years ago who read books of Grade 3 & 4 and liked that type; the age of these girls was approx.

I hope that you will not think me too forward in passing out this advice.

If we could make the adults speak English all the time we would show more advancement but try to do it.

Yours truly,

J.S. Wells.

Rev. Jos. Angin, O.M.I. Principal, Thunderchild Indian Residential School, Delmas, Sask.

Under separate cover you will receive a copy of "Teacher's Guide Book to the Activity Program". This book is at present out of print, but we have been able to procure a few, which we will keep in our library at Ottawa. These are sent out so that the teachers may read them and take notes, thereby becoming familiar with the activity program.

After the teacher has read this book please return it at your earliest convenience, so that other schools may have the opportunity of examining it.

Other books will be sent from time to time, for the same purpose. We feel sure that we have your co-operation in this matter.

Philip Phelan,

Re: Day School Libraries.

In reply to your letter of April 30th last, re Indian Day School Libraries.

The only Indian Day School in this Agency is situated on the Nicola-Mameet No.1 at Shulus Village. This school has not been in operation since June 1942. No available teacher.

On receipt of your letter I examined this School, but could not find any library books.

Presumably this school never has been supplied with Library books.

Re: Day School Libraries.

Dear Sir:

It is with pleasure that I noted the Department's desire regarding school libraries. I have found that illustrated books with written commentaries are very good. I have also used film slides with success.

While I have a number of supplementary readers and booklets, these are too well worn to be listed and should be destroyed.

My pupils have had access to such magazines as Hygeia, Geographic, Red Cross Junior, and Canadian Nature, which you send.

Sincerely yours,

J.M. Barre, Teacher.
